column2: A group of eight major oil companies is planning the construction of a pipeline to carry oil products from the Gulf the Washington, D.C., area as a means of avoiding manufacturing and transportation delays caused by maritime strikes.
The real estate concern of Geisinger Germain has resold the five-story apartment house at 2760 Grand Concourse, the Bronx, to a client of Irving J. Kulick, lawyer, after ownership of two months.
WARSAW, June 23 -- Edward Drozniak, Poland's new Ambassador to the United States, arrived in Washington this week with a primary mission of improving economic relations between the two countries.

Federal Judge Frederick van-Pelt Bryan yesterday ordered the release of the Swedish shipmaster and naval architect, John Paul Kracker von Schwarzenfeld, from the custody of the Immigration and Naturalization Service.

With traders "evening up" for the week-end, futures trading on the New York commodities exchanges was quiet yesterday. Uncertainties about the duration of the maritime strike helped to curtail market interest.

SARANAC INN, N.Y., June 23 -- The Chief Judge of the State Court of Appeals proposed today an amendment to the State Constitution that would compel the Legislature to create new Supreme Court judgeships on the basis of population.

GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., June 23 (AP) -- Don January nudged a No. 2 iron shot a mere 10 feet on the first hole today. However, he went on to shoot a 69 and tie Arnold Palmer at 135 for the lead at the midway point in the 72-hole Western open golf tournament.
WASHINGTON, June 23 -The United States Government is studying the possibility of offering Communist China equal representation in the United Nations General Assembly with Nationalist China.

WASHINGTON, June 23 (AP) -- Secretary of Defense Robert S. McNamara said today that he thought Vice Admiral H.G. Rickover was one of the outstanding authorities on atomic power but "I don't think I would put him in that category on education"
NEWBURGH, N.Y., June 23 -- Following is the text of the thirteen procedural changes in welfare administration that have been ordered in this city, effective July 15:
The Youth Counsel Bureau would become an official city agency under a proposed Charter amendment introduced yesterday into the City Council.
WASHINGTON, June 23 (AP) -- A spokesman for the Roman Catholic Church said today it was willing to accept non-Catholic volunteers from the Peace Corps on its welfare projects overseas.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 23 -- Sheriff Howard Fitzpatrick of Middlesex County and four of his jail guards were released today from indictments charging them with negligence.

WASHINGTON, June 23 -Adlai E. Stevenson told President Kennedy today that he had found discontent and a deteriorating economic situation throughout his tour of South America. Talking to newsmen after a call at the White House, Mr. Stevenson, who is the representative at the United Nations, said the situation in countries he visited on his eighteen-day tour seemed to have worsened since his last visit a year ago.
WASHINGTON, June 23 -The Religious Heritage of America presented awards to three persons today for their work in reporting religious activities.
NEWBURGH, N.Y., June 23 -- This city's new policy of getting tough with some kinds of relief claimants is finding widespread support in other parts of the country.

Springvale-on-the-Hudson, a privately built apartment project for elderly persons, has been sold to Springvale Associates, a limited partnership group, for a $750,000 syndication offering by Metropolitan Syndications, Inc.
GENEVA, June 23. -- The Right-Wing faction of Prince Boun Oum, Premier of the Royal Government of Laos, will take a seat at the fourteen-nation conference on Laos here.
WASHINGTON, June 23 (AP) -- The Government announced today an agreement under which the Publicker Chemical Corporation will stop importing molasses bought from Premier Fidel Castro's Cuba.
A Federal plan for a sixty-day cooling-off period in the seamen's strike collapsed yesterday when the major striking maritime unions rejected it. The employers accepted it.
ALBANY, June 23 -- The State Board of Regents refused today to license the original uncut version of the prize-winning Ingmar Bergman movie, "The Virgin Spring."
Ogden R. Reid, former United States Ambassador to Israel, was sworn in yesterday as a member of the State Commission Against Discrimination. He takes office July 1.
WASHINGTON, June 23 (AP) -- The Government today dropped a plan to close the border to Mexicans commuting daily to jobs wanted by unemployed Americans in Laredo and El Paso, Texas.
BERLIN, June 23 -- A relaxed and festive West Berlin tonight opened its eleventh International Film Festival with the announcement of a record participation by forty-seven countries.

A merger of the American-Marietta Company and The Martin Company was proposed yesterday by their directors. The consolidated company would have combined assets exceeding $600,000,000 and earnings of more than $41,000,000 a year.
WASHINGTON, June 23 (UPI) -- The Civil Aeronautics Board revealed today that it was investigating an airline practice of selling more tickets for flights than there are seats available.

BLOOMINGTON, Minn., June 23 -- Yankee fortunes seem to be following a peculiar pattern these days. The Bombers enter a town, see a manager discharged, then help the new skipper score a triumphant debut by losing the ball game.

WASHINGTON, June 23 -- President Kennedy summoned his leading policy advisers and legislative leaders to an unusual conference today on the problem of Berlin and other issues. The session lasted three hours.
The Curtiss-Wright Corporation, Wood-Ridge, N.J., has announced the signing of reciprocal trade agreements with Ardleigh Engineering, Ltd., and Hydro-Pneumatics, Ltd., both of England.

The Taylor Instrument Company reported yesterday that its net income for the nine months ended on April 30 was $1,362,556, equal to $1.67 a share. This compared with $1,499,006, or $1.83 a share, for the year-earlier period.

Alice Sachs, a Phi Beta Kappa from Wellesley who has used such esoteric tools as Chinese fortune cookies and crossword puzzles in campaigns for public office, went gathering signatures this week with nothing but a smile and a piece of paper.
WASHINGTON, June 23 -The index of primary market prices remained unchanged at 118.7 per cent of its 1947-49 base during the week last Tuesday, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today.
DETROIT, June 23 -- The five-week effort to arrange an exchange of 500 American-built tractors for 1,214 rebel prisoners in Cuba collapsed tonight.

HACKENSACK, N.J., June 23 -- Pony tails, earrings and lipstick are part of the baseball scene in Hackensack. They are in evidence at games of the Junior Miss Baseball program for girls from 9 to 13 years of age.
PARIS, June 23 -- Premier Michel Debre called on French farmers tonight to abandon agitation and work with the Government to accomplish necessary reforms of France's agricultural system.
CHICAGO, June 23 (AP) -Ernie Banks of the Cubs today sacrificed a possible National League record for consecutive games played rather than jeopardize his career by playing on an ailing knee.
The Bush Terminal Buildings Company has sold its five-story headquarters at 100 Broad Street, a downtown landmark since the turn of the century.
WHEN Joseph McDowell Mitchell accepted the post of City Manager of Newburgh, N.Y., last October he had little expectation that nine months later he would be catapulted into national prominence.

Activity in the market for new capital is scheduled to continue high next week, with major fixed-interest security issues aggregating $357,799,500 on the calendar. Those issues to be sold at competitive sealed bidding are expected to amount to $194,000,000.

AMES, Iowa, June 23 (AP) -- Bill Hoogs of the University of California ousted third-seeded Rafael Osuna of Southern California today to gain the singles semi-finals of the National Collegiate tennis championships.
AN arresting paragraph appeared in recent news story concerning food distribution in which a public official stated that "most families wouldn't know what to do with corn meal."
CHICAGO, June 23 (UPI) -- A Federal judge today ordered Ralph Capone to turn over all his ready cash to the Government as part payment on a $230,000 income tax bill.

Plans have been announced for a fifteen-story office building adjacent to the Connecticut Turnpike at the Connecticut Post Center in Milford. It will be built by Sol Atlas, developer of commercial real estate.

MILWAUKEE, June 23 (AP) -- The Chicago Cubs' rookie left-hander, Jack Curtis, tossed a five-hitter tonight with help in the ninth and beat Milwaukee, 5 -- 3. The Cubs snapped the Braves' four-game winning streak -- their longest of the season.

THE boxing term, uppercut, as applied to bridge, appeared in Philadelphia about thirty years ago and became a part of the world's bridge vernacular when Charles Goren used it in his best-selling bridge books.

On Tuesday, June 13, Algerian Affairs Minister Louis Joxe suspended the talks at Evianles-Bains between the French and the Algerian National Liberation Front (FLN) delegation for "a period of reflection" to last ten to fifteen days. The time is at hand for the discussions to be resumed to better purpose than the utter futility of the first round of talks.

WASHINGTON, June 23 (AP) -- Witnesses from the travel industry assailed today President Kennedy's bill to reduce from $500 to $100 the duty-free allowance for United States tourists who bring home goods from abroad.
The Japanese Premier has marked the New York phase of his visit to the United States with an outspoken defense of the Japanese position in regard to proposed new restrictions on Japanese imports.

Contemporary composers from this country and abroad are expected to contribute much to the vitality of the Berkshire Music Festival at Tanglewood, Lenox, Mass. As a result of the participation of the Fromm Music Foundation, a series of seminars, lectures and concerts devoted to new music will occur throughout the seven-week season, which begin Wednesday.
The State of Delaware borrowed $10,630,000 in the bond market yesterday to finance public improvements.

LAFAYETTE, Ind., June 23 (AP) -- Jack Nicklaus and Mike Podolski, both of Columbus, Ohio, set up the second allOhio State final in sixty-four years of the National Collegiate golf championship with comeback victories today.
Lawrence W. Pierce, an assistant district attorney in Brooklyn, was appointed deputy commissioner in charge of the Police Department's youth program yesterday.
Irene Mayer Selznick has signed contracts to open her production of "The Complaisant Lover," the Graham Greene comedy, at the Barrymore Theatre on Nov. 1.

AFTER a walk in the summer sunlight, stepping inside the house these days may be something of a let-down. The room that seemed so inviting on a gray wintry day may look drab in contrast to blossom-bright gardens and lush green foliage.
LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, June 23 -- Preparations for reopening the Congolese Parliament continued here today on the assumption that the first meeting would be held Sunday or soon thereafter.
ALBANY, June 23 (UPI) -State Welfare Commissioner Raymond W. Houston told the City of Newburgh today that it could solve its welfare crisis by unloading the problem on county taxpayers.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), June 23 -- Adolf Eichmann swore today that he once saved 20,000 German Jews and 5,000 gypsies from Nazi executioners.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, June 23 (AP) -- Dr. Sam Sheppard, convicted wife slayer, returned to the Ohio Penitentiary for medical tests today and told newsmen he did not think a lump on his chest was caused by cancer.
WASHINGTON, June 23 (UPI) -- The Senate Appropriations Committee approved today President Kennedy's salary for next year.

The Air Force sent up a Nike-Cajun research rocket yesterday in an attempt to obtain precise data on the density and altitude spread of a concentrated band of space dust discovered earlier this month.
TENAFLY, N.J., June 23 -Hitting her shots with near-perfect precision, Mrs. Philip Cudone of the Forest Hill Field Club retained the Women's New Jersey Golf Association's 54hole championship today.
THE president of Eagle Clothes is a men's ready-to-wear manufacturer who has a special feeling for clothes problems of the little man.
DEAUVILLE, France, June 23 (AP) -- Morton Olman of Cincinnati was the only American to survive the third and fourth rounds today in the French amateur golf championship.
CINCINNATI, June 23 -- In addition to its normal run of beasts, the Cincinnati Zoo had on view last night a trio of mermaids, a pair of Neolithic giants and a host of Niebelung dwarfs.
ALBANY, June 23 -- The Board of Regents today resolved its differences with Governor Rockefeller over the method of paying college students the state's new tuition-aid grants.

WASHINGTON, June 23 (AP) -- The Interstate Commerce Commission today generally upheld rate differentials on railroad freight passing through Middle-Atlantic ports and that passing through New York and other northern ports.

A recreation of the battle of San Juan Hill is given by Col. A.C.M. Azoy, retired, in a volume titled "Charge." The author analyzes the events leading to the Spanish-American War and gives sidelights on personalities vital in the victory, but who were overshadowed by the flamboyant Rough Riders.

CHICAGO, June 23 (AP) -Warren Hacker of the Chicago White Sox came in to retire Billy Klaus of the Washington Senators on a pop fly in the ninth inning tonight and protected a 4-3 victory for Ray Herbert.
LONDON, June 23 -- With buyers reluctant, most share prices continued to drift downward in the stock market today.

PHILADELPHIA, June 23 (AP) -- Philadelphia and Fort Pierce, Fla., filed civil antitrust suits for unspecified damages today against several electrical concerns, including the country's two largest. They charged that equipment they had purchased was artificially enhanced by a price- and bid-rigging conspiracy.
EDWARDS AIR FORCE BASE, Calif., June 23. -- The X-15 rocket plane roared to a mile-a-second speed record today, with its pilot virtually immobilized by malfunctions of equipment.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday moved 3 points lower to 16 points higher than on Thursday, (One point equals 5 cents a bale. )

CINCINNATI, June 23 (AP) -- The Cincinnati Reds, battling from behind all the way, defeated Los Angeles, 5 -- 4, tonight on Eddie Kasko's basesfilled single in the ninth and stretched their National League lead to three games over the Dodgers.
The Beverly Hotel at 125 East Fiftieth Street at Lexington Avenue has been leased by Henry Speter and Murray Knight, New York hotel operators, from Sidney Schwartz, real estate investor.

ORONO, Ont., June 23 (Canadian Press) -- Three European drivers posted the fastest times today -- unofficially breaking the track record -- in qualifying for Canada's first international sports-car race tomorrow.

JONES BEACH, L.I., June 23 -- Wisps of fog floated across Zachs Bay and the moon lay hidden behind thick clouds that threatened rain as Jinx Falkenburg strode center stage last night to manage the preliminaries to the main business at hand -the unveiling of "Paradise Island," the new summertime extravaganza.
The director of architecture of the Board of Education was accused yesterday of improper behavior by City Investigation Commissioner Louis I. Kaplan.
BLOOMINGTON, Minn., June 23 -- It seems that wherever the Yankees move, they bring bad news to some manager.
JACKSON, June 23 (UPI) -Four young Negroes were arrested in a Jackson bus terminal here today -- before starting a Freedom Ride.

KANSAS CITY, June 23 (AP) -- Lew Krausse, Kansas City's 18-year-old, $125,000 bonus pitcher, was on his way toward a second successive shut-out tonight when Gary Geiger hit a three-run homer in the seventh inning for a 5-4 Boston victory.

CHICAGO, June 23 (AP) -- Hedge selling appeared to be the controlling factor in wheat futures today, and prices lost a little ground on the Board of Trade. But other grains and most soybeans finished with moderate gains.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., June 23 (UPI) -- The Alabama State Supreme Court has set aside the divorce of Louis L. Lorillard and his wife Elaine on ground of insufficient evidence that Mr. Lorillard was an Alabama resident.
WASHINGTON, June 23 -- A device used by savings banks in New York to attract business soon may be a weapon in Congressional debate.

The recent power failure (the second one within two years) has again dramatically shown how dependent a large city is upon an uninterrupted electric power supply. The investigations started following such failures may at best lessen the chance of recurrence.
ALBANY, June 23 -- The New York City Advisory Commission on local school boards was chartered today by the Board of Regents.
Seatrain Lines, Inc., one of two remaining common-carrier coastal steamship companies, has elected Thomas F. Milbank chairman of the executive committee.
The Zionist Organization of America said yesterday it would fight efforts to oppose the growth of the movement in this country.
A former life-saving station that in 1879 became a church will open its doors tomorrow for summer worshipers.
DETROIT, June 23 (AP) -- A translation of Premier Castro's cable this morning to the Tractors for Freedom Committee follows:

WASHINGTON, June 23 (AP) -- A former United States Embassy aide pleaded not guilty today to having passed United States secrets to Poland. His attorney said that whatever he had done was to protect "the woman he loved," a Polish woman who is not his wife.
ST. LOUIS, June 23 (AP) -Stan Musial hit two home runs, one with the bases filled, to drive in seven runs and power the St. Louis Cardinals to a 10 -- 5 victory tonight over the San Francisco Giants.

The Lehigh Valley Railroad operated in the red again last month, as it has in every month since May, 1960. Last month's net loss was $661,774 and raised to $4,551,629 the line's net loss for the year to date.

The Times in its June 6th editorial titled "Mr. Lehman and Fusion" is somewhat critical of the Democratic reform movement and Governor Lehman for closing the door to any meaningful fusion movement outside the Democratic party.
WASHINGTON, June 22 -William J. Jorden, a reporter in the Washington Bureau of The New York Times, has been appointed a member of the State Department's Policy Planning Council.
PHILADELPHIA, June 23 -Arthur Judson, former manager of the New York Philharmonic Orchestra, was honored tonight by the American Symphony Orchestra League for distinguished service to music.
WASHINGTON, June 23 -The House Appropriations Committee voted a total of $42,711,105,000 in military appropriations today, nearly all that President Kennedy had requested.
CLEVELAND, June 23 (AP) -- Bill Bruton drove in four runs with two homers in leading the first-place Detroit Tigers to a 15-7 victory over the Cleveland Indians tonight in a battle of home runs.

Newspaper readers, especially those who think of Latin as a dead language, must have been astonished recently at the recurrence of Latin in the news. First there was a lively demonstration by Harvard students against the university's decision to break a custom of long standing and issue its diplomas phrased in English instead of Latin.

PURCHASE, N.Y., June 23 -- Mrs. Sophie Untermeyer of Century and Mrs. Charles F. Spalding of Round Hill finished in a tie today with Mrs. Sally Francis and Mrs. Bruce McGhie of Apawamis in the second annual Grace Herbert Memorial golf tournament.

The Supreme Court will have to supply road maps with its decisions if it continues to hand down rulings as tangled as those it rendered this week in two cases involving political spending and compulsory membership in labor and professional organizations. The justices needed ten separate opinions to give expression to their clashing views.
Leon Burley, managing agent of the Armstrong Hotel, which was recently termed a "rat ranch" by the city, was sentenced to thirty days in jail yesterday on 194 violations of the Administrative Code.

BUFFALO, June 23 (AP) -- The west struck for two touchdowns in the third period and added a touchdown and a safety in the final quarter to defeat the East, 30 -- 20, in a pass-filled All-America Graduation Bowl football game tonight.
Forty-six short subjects have been named by the Committee on International Non-Theatrical Events (C.I.N.E.) to represent the United States at film festivals.
Arthritis sufferers whose joints seemed, at home, to be harbingers of weather change have been unable to observe any such effect under laboratory conditions.

The nation's 515 mutual savings banks had deposit gains totaling $114,000,000 in May, raising total deposits in the thrift institutions to $37,100,000,000. The May increase was almost twice the size of the $58,000,000 gain recorded for May of 1960.

THE weather man having finally relented, matters got under way once again last night at Lewisohn Stadium. Youth was the order of the day, with the parennially young Pierre Monteux on the podium and the truly young John Browning at the piano.
The Worker, a weekly Communist newspaper, announced in its issue that came out yesterday that it planned to publish twice a week after Labor Day. It formerly was a daily tabloid.
WASHINGTON, June 23 -The inventor of the belt that enables a soldier to jump like a grasshopper has patented a "flying broomstick" for him to ride.

PITTSBURGH, June 23 (AP) -- Storming back with ten runs -- four of them unearned -- in the last two innings, the Philadelphia Phillies broke a sevengame losing streak tonight with a 12-11 victory over the Pittsburgh Pirates.

WASHINGTON, June 23 -A Senate Labor and Public Welfare subcommittee unexpectedly voted today to set up a twelve-year veterans education program. It would provide assistance as part of an expanded National Defense Education Act.
Premier Hayato Ikeda of Japan gave a polite but stern warning here yesterday that restrictions against Japanese products could threaten the economic and political stability of his country.

Having just returned from the Far East, where we spent several months, going from port to port in a freighter, the situation that has arisen there is no surprise. The only surprise is that it can have surprised anyone.

Mayor Wagner's discovery that Abe Stark would make a better Controller than President of the City Council was made after nearly eight years' study, so it can hardly be called a hasty decision. But if this "elevation" of Mr. Stark, as the Mayor puts it, is to be considered proof of Wagner's "independence" of bossism, the public can afford no more such successes.
DETROIT, June 23 -- The following statement was issued this evening by the officers of the Tractors for Freedom Committee:
WASHINGTON, June 23 -- The deadline for the Communist party to register with the Government was put off today from Aug. 9 to an indefinite time in the fall.
BONN, Germany, June 23 -A change seems to have taken place in Bonn's thinking on how to counter the Soviet Union's threats to sign a separate peace treaty with Communist East Germany.
THE standard picture of the hard-boiled, tension-ridden fashion buyer for a department store finds its exception in Carol Bjorkman.

A tall, frail-looking prelate chatted about baseball and volleyball, tennis and high-jumping with three children yesterday after they had made him an honorary member of the Catholic Youth Organization.
MINNEAPOLIS, June 23 -Senator Barry Goldwater of Arizona predicted tonight that his conservative brand of Republicanism would sweep the country by this time next year.

PARIS, June 23 -- Rudolf Noureev, the Russian dancer who claimed asylum last Friday, did not have to wait long for a job. He made his first appearance as soloist with a Western company tonight, dancing the role of Prince Florimond in "Sleeping Beauty" with the International Ballet of the Marquis de Cuevas.
HAGERSTOWN, Md., June 23 -- This little city did its best today to repair a breach in the delicate tapestry of international relations.
YONKERS, June 23 -- Three developments in the last few days have shaken the Yonkers Police Athletic League out of the placid course of its day-by-day efforts to reduce juvenile delinquency.

ELISABETHVILLE, The Congo, June 23 (Reuters) -- Army troops from the Communist-backed Stanleyville regime of Antoine Gizenga are moving from Kindu, in Kivu Province, toward Sentery, in north Katanga, a communique from the Katanga government said today.
WIMBLEDON, England, June 23 (UPI) -- Tradition will go by the board Monday when Neale Fraser opens defense of the Wimbledon title away from the center court.
Spokesmen for strikebound shipping companies said here yesterday that they were having little difficulty in rebooking travelers by sea and by air.
WASHINGTON, June 23 -President Kennedy has offered to share the burden of eliminating all causes of Israeli-Arab conflict if the parties wish the United States to do so.

WASHINGTON, June 23 (AP) -- The White House disclosed today that it was considering a plan to relieve the depressed mining industry by the Federal purchase of domestic lead and zinc, using dollars obtained from the foreign sale of United States farm surpluses.
A small ferryboat headed for Perth Amboy, N.J., with six passengers left its slip at Tottenville, S.I., at 6 A.M. yesterday and disappeared into the fog.
Demand for high-grade corporate bonds surged in the over-the counter market yesterday, registering for the bond market another unexpectedly active Friday trading session.

WASHINGTON, June 23 (AP) -- A Chesapeake Ohio Railway executive today outlined a $232,000,000 five-year program for improving the Baltimore Ohio Railroad system, which the C. O. seeks to control and eventually merge into its own line.

The opening Guggenheim Memorial concert by the Goldman Band on the Mall in Central Park, rained out on Wednesday night, took place last night. Richard Franko Goldman conducted, and the soloists were James Burke, cornetist, and Sarah Fleming, soprano.

The 3-year-old division is the attraction in half of the major stakes races today at the country's thoroughbred tracks, with the fillies battling it out in the $117,625 Coaching Club American Oaks at Belmont Park.

Aircrafts, electronics and other defense issues gave the stock market a healthy tone yesterday, helped by approval of the House Appropriations Committee of a defense appropriations bill $1,900,000,000 greater than that requested in January by President Eisenhower.

Back in 1917, when it was generally believed that the horse was here to stay for many years, Belmont Park instituted a race for 3-year-old fillies and named it for the Coaching Club. That organization was made up of sportsmen whose required ability to drive a coach and four was the envy of those less gifted.

LONDON, June 23 (AP) -Mead Johnson Co., United States pharmaceutical concern, is planning to acquire a large minority holding in British Drug Houses, Ltd., a 7,500,000 ($21,000,000) concern formed thirty-five years ago.

WASHINGTON, June 23 (AP) -- President Kennedy has announced that David M. Satz Jr. of South Orange will be appointed United States Attorney for New Jersey. He will succeed Chester A. Weidenbutner in the $18,000-a-year post.
The exporting subsidiary of the United States Steel Corporation has withdrawn its published price list on semi-finished steel products for export, it was disclosed yesterday.

GENEVA, June 23 -- The Soviet Union said today that any agreement to prohibit nuclear tests reached here in its negotiations with the United States and Britain would be only a "scrap of paper" because of France's position on disarmament.
Mayor Wagner said yesterday he would not shy away from a primary fight if one were forced upon him by Democratic organization leaders.

LONDON, June 23 -- In the second program of its season at the Royal Opera House, Covent Garden, tonight, the admirable young artists of the Leningrad State Kirov Ballet turned to the classic repertory and really came into their own.

WASHINGTON, June 23 (AP) -- Representative of five European textile-consuming countries, together with Britain, Canada and the United States, agreed today to recommend that their Governments significantly increase access to their markets by the low-wage textile producing nations of Asia.
In emotional outbursts yesterday Jack Soble repeatedly linked his brother, Dr. Robert Soblen, with a wartime Soviet spy ring here.

The unions on strike are the National Maritime Union, 37,000 members: the Seafarers International Union, Atlantic, Gulf and Lakes section, 22,000; the Marine Engineers Beneficial Association, 11,000; the Masters, Mates and Pilots, 11,000, and the American Radio Association.

TOKYO, June 23 -- Smack in the middle of central Tokyo and during the noon rush hour, the demonstrators got to work. The kit was quickly unwrapped -- red flags, slogan banners, leaflets denouncing the target (a Tokyo newspaper) and a small battery loudspeaker that made life hideous for a block around.
A ten-round middleweight bout between Jose Gonzalez and Yama Bahama heads tonight's boxing program at Madison Square Garden, the last here until July 15.
WASHINGTON, June 23 (AP) -- The American Association of University Women defeated today a proposal that it endorse medical care for the aged under the Social Security system.

DETROIT, June 23 (AP) -- Ward's Automotive reports said today that the General Motors Corporation, Chrysler Corporation and American Motors Corporation built more cars this week than in any other week this year although the industry total slipped slightly below last week's figure.

WASHINGTON, June 23 -Leaders of local Jewish community councils and Jewish religious and civic organizations today described baccalaureate graduation exercises in public schools as violations of the principle of separation of church and state.

HAVANA, June 23 (AP) -Premier Castro, in rejecting the United States committee's offer of 500 farm tractors today, was regarded here as having left open the possibility for continued negotiations that might free some of the prisoners.

WASHINGTON, June 23 (AP) -- Attorney General Robert F. Kennedy said today that he would like to see the Administration's proposal for a Youth Conservation Corps greatly enlarged, but questioned whether the money was to be had.

Plans for the merger of the Ingram Oil and Refining Company with the Murphy Corporation were announced yesterday by officers of the two oil companies. The transaction would involve an exchange of Murphy stock valued at about $16,770,000.
CUTLER, Me., June 23 (AP) -- The Navy dedicated the world's most powerful low-frequency radio station today, giving it the proud call letters, NAA.

The Transitron Electronic Corporation issued a statement yesterday at the request of the New York Stock Exchange concerning Wall Street rumors associated with the recent rise in price of its common stock.
WASHINGTON, June 23 -President Kennedy was pronounced "practically recovered" today from both his respiratory infection and his back injury.
HACKENSACK, June 24 -- Paul Cranis of New York scored two victories today at the opening of the Eastern clay courts tennis championships at the Oritani Field Club.

AN ever-popular theme -- how a small boy tames a supposedly untamable forest creature -- gets a skillful reworking in Hughie Call's new book, "Peter's Moose." Peter Lloyd finds a motherless moose calf in the Montana forest and nurses him to maturity, disbelieving his elders' warning that one day his pet will desert him and return to its wild ways.
Frank Budd of Villanova University covered 100 yards yesterday faster than it ever has been run under officially acceptable conditions.

Yachtsmen are smart enough, before, during and after National Safe Boating Week, to put first-aid equipment on board. It is one of the "musts", like an anchor and anchor line. Emergencies can happen without warning.

Retail volume fell a little below expectations in this area last week. Department store merchants estimated that sales were 2 to 4 per cent above those in 1960, and said that rainy weather during the middle of the week caused a slack in an expected brisk selling period.
LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, June 24 -- The leaders of three rival Congolese regimes promised the United Nations today to cooperate for an early opening of Parliament.
The State Investigation Commission was accused yesterday of "smear, hit-and-run tactics" in its hearings into irregularities in the city school building program.
THE present Laws of Contract Bridge were published in 1948 for rubber bridge, as played in homes and clubs, and in 1949 for duplicate bridge, as played in all tournaments.
CLEVELAND, June 24 -- Dick McAuliffe's 390-foot home run over the centerfield fence with two out in the ninth inning enabled the Detroit Tigers to beat the Indians today, 5 -- 4.
OCEANPORT, N.J., June 24 -- Steve Brooks rode the Calumet Farm's 3-year-old colt Beau Prince to a two-length victory today in Monmouth Park's sixteenth running of the $24,850 Lamplighter Handicap.
HACKENSACK, N.J., June 24 -- Steps are being taken here to bring industry and organized labor together in a campaign to improve their charity records.
A Bronx rabbi called yesterday for the establishment here of a liberal Reform Jewish day school to provide maximum religious education as well as training in secular subjects.

HUNTER COLLEGE of the City of New York will offer in its 1961 summer session a fifteen-session course, "Plants and Man." Color slides and microscopic preparations will be used in discussions of beverage and medicinal plants, insecticides and methods of improving garden plants. Students will meet for the first time at 11:30 A.M. on July 3 at the college, 695 Park Avenue at Sixty-ninth Street, New York City.

WASHINGTON -- The United States Government went into the travel business last week. Congress is venturing $3,000,000 this year in the hope of attracting thousands of foreigners to this country, thus cutting back the growing difference between what American tourists spend overseas and what foreign tourists spend here.

STAMFORD, Conn., June 24. -- Columbia again defeated Weatherly on Long Island Sound today, handing her 12-Meter rival a trouncing by the margin of five and a half minutes at the end of a twenty-two-mile course.

IT takes a certain temerity on the part of an ordinary mortal to "re-create" the mind of Michelangelo, for example, as Irving Stone has just done, or of Rembrandt as Gladys Schmitt does here. Yet there is a continuing popular demand for fictional biography, and sometimes this perilous literary approach can, quite for its own sake, yield rewarding results.
BOGOTA, Colombia, June 24 -- Adlai E. Stevenson stood beside a white-washed brick church in Lima, Peru, this week and saw Latin America's hardship in a mother's eyes.

The Navy's policy of allocating 80 per cent of ship repair and conversion work to its own yards "contradicts the very essence of free competitive enterprise," John T. Gilbride, president of the Todd Shipyards Corporation, declared last week.

LOS ANGELES, June 24 -Carrying such varied impedimenta as a golf trophy, a reducing book and a batch of unsigned state laws, Gov Edmund G. Brown traveled up and down the state this week opening a re-election campaign aimed at thwarting a political comeback by Richard M. Nixon.
With his announcement that he would run again for Mayor if he got running mates to his liking, Robert F. Wagner is attempting a new role in city and state politics.

The Gas Service Company of Kansas City, Mo., is planning the private placement of $15,000,000 of new securities, according to its president, R.M. Power.
JACKSON, Miss., June 25 (AP) -- Twenty Freedom Riders arrived today by train. Nine minutes later they were arrested.
Dr. Ray E. Trussell, Commissioner of Hospitals, has changed his mind about closing Fordham Hospital in the Bronx and Greenpoint Hospital in Brooklyn on Saturday.
SAN FRANCISCO, June 25 (AP) -- An inquest will be held in the death of George Vanderbilt, newly wed millionaire sportsman who plunged last night from a tenth-floor hotel suite here.

WIMBLEDON, England, June 25 -- Strictly on form, Neale Fraser of Australia and Sandra Reynolds of South Africa are top-seeded in the seventy-fifth All-England lawn tennis championships that open on the Wimbledon grass courts tomorrow.

SEOUL, Korea, June 25 -South Korea marked today the eleventh anniversary of the outbreak of the Korean war with a call to press "revolutionary tasks for better preparedness against any further Communist aggression."
A nation-wide campaign to raise $2,000,000 for a 300-foot "Statue of Liberty" in Israel as a goodwill gift from the American people was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 25 -- President Kennedy has ruled out any interference by his White House staff in the operations of departments and agencies. White House aides said this was not a new decision but was emphasized now because of newspaper reports that divided authority had hobbled operation of the State Department's Inter-American Division.
A Methodist minister urged all Christians yesterday to strengthen their churches -- not through large congregations, budgets and buildings, but through courage, conviction and commitment.
BRUSSELS, Belgium, June 25 -- The Lord Chamberlain of the court issued a statement tonight denying that Queen Fabiola of Belgium is expecting a child.

GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., June 25 (UPI) -- Arnold Palmer, golf's leading money-winner in 1960, staved off a bid by Sam Snead today and won the fifty-eighth Western Open golf tournament with a 72-hole score of 271. Snead had a 273.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 25 -- Following, as obtained in Amman, is the text of a letter President Kennedy sent May 11 to King Hussein of Jordan (the President sent similar letters to President Gamal Abdel Nasser of the United Arab Republic, President Fouad Chebab of Lebanon, Premier Abdul Karim Kassim of Iraq and King Saud of Saudi Arabia):
GENEVA, June 25 -- Many Swiss industrials continued their upward drive last Monday to push to historic highs, but they found the altitude too breath-taking and dropped back for the rest of the week.
An uncommonly colorful program of music from the West Indies was presented Saturday night at Town Hall.
PITTSBURGH, June 25 -Steel mills see their market curving off seasonally into the vacation period.

The O.W. Siebert Company, Inc., manufacturer of baby carriages and tricycles for more than sixty years, is diversifying its activities through the cash purchase of eight millwork jobbing houses. The acquisition was announced over the week-end by H.B. Pearl, president of Siebert and president and chairmand Ed of Herbert B. Pearl, Inc., parent of Siebert.

DETROIT, June 25 -- The United Automobile Workers and the three major auto companies, General Motors, Ford and Chrysler, will begin their 1961 labor negotiations this week holding unusually flexible positions.
BUFFALO, June 25 (AP) -The body of a 3-year-old boy, believed to have been kidnapped by a mentally deranged woman, was found today floating in a park lake.

Theatrical Protective Union, Local 1, representing the stagehands has rejected the appeal the League of New York Theatres, the organization of roducers and theatre owners, or a year's extension of the current contract, which expires May 31.

In a pairing as intriguing to many in the crowd of 12,244 as corned beef and cabbage with bagels, the Petah Tikva team of Israel played to a 2-2 soccer tie with the Shamrock Rovers of Dublin yesterday at the Polo Grounds.
MAMARONECK, N.Y., June 25 -- The Sheldrake Yacht Club, which has many active members but no clubhouse, staged a fine Yacht Racing Association regatta on Long Island Sound today.
BAGHDAD, Iraq, June 25 -Iraq laid claim today to the newly independent and oil-rich Persian Gulf sheikdom of Kuwait.
New York, which buys and eats more food than any other city in the country, is seriously short of skilled labor to prepare and serve it.
ZURICH, Switzerland, June 25 (AP) -- Hopelessly deadlocked in their angry dispute over South Tyrol, Austria and Italy decided today to abandon their talks here and seek outside mediation.

Because the availability of all qualifying athletes could not be established last night, the Amateur Athletic Union deferred until today naming the United States track and field squad for next month's dual meets with the Soviet Union, Poland, West Germany and Britain.
KINGS PARK, L.I., June 25 -- About 200 archers from the metropolitan area assembled today in the green forests of Long Island near here to match skills and have an open-air lunch.

A series of six concerts of jazz and chamber music will be presented this summer at the Wollman Rink in Central Park. The concerts will be under the auspices of the New York City Department of Parks, the New York Shakespeare Festival and Temple Rodeph Sholom.
SOME people cannot be satisfied with a ready-made fish tank.

Americans who like good wines may soon be making the pleasant discovery that there is a great deal more to Italian wine production than the familiar Chianti in its straw-basket bottle. Even those familiar with the fine Italian regional wines -- the Trentinos, Marinos, Piedmontes, Valpolicellas and many more -- will be learning that they do not have to go to Italy to enjoy them,
PETROS, Tenn., June 25 (AP) -- Rescue workers recovered today the body of Herley Carroll, 18 years old, from a collapsed mine shaft where he and two other men were trapped Friday afternoon.
CARACAS, June 25 -- A new tax program of the Venezuelan Government contains a provision that may result in additional taxes on oil companies here, it was learned today.

PARIS, June 25 -- Americans are accustomed to contradiction between the promises of Presidential nominees and their application of policy after they move into the White House. For stark reality and the burden of responsibility often brake intentions.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y. June 25 -- The United Nations reported today that the underdeveloped nations of the world still faced an "acute" shortage of money for sound development despite their efforts to eliminate mass poverty.
STAMFORD, Conn., June 25 -- Weatherly made it close today but lost to Columbia in the fourth race of the series for 12-Meter sloops on Long Island Sound.
Trading in the over-the-counter market last week was the quietest of the year to date. There was no presure or prices generally, although some issues stood out with sizable gains and losses.

BY universal consent Michelangelo and Rembrandt rank as two of the supreme artists of all time. Last March a gigantic historical novel about Michelangelo was published, Irving Stone's popular but undistinguished "The Agony and the Ecstasy." Today an even more gigantic novel about Rembrandt is published, Gladys Schmitt's brilliant, but lamentably long, "Rembrandt."*
MILWAUKEE, June 25 (AP) -- George Altman and Billy Williams tagged Warren Spahn for seven hits between them as the Chicago Cubs beat the Milwaukee Braves today, 5 -- 3.
Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz has asked the referee in a mortgage foreclosure to remove a racial restriction from the notice of a sale scheduled July 11 in Dutchess County.

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), June 25 -- Adolf Eichmann has done nothing on the witness stand to dispel the impression the defense is trying to convey that he was just a robot in the Nazi machine who under normal peacetime conditions might have become a model organization man.
WASHINGTON, June 25 -Administration civil rights experts are convinced that Negroes are on the verge of a political breakthrough in the South.
CHICAGO, June 25 (AP) -Dale Whisler of Dayton, Ohio, earned $28,850 for winning the Petersen Bowling Classic that ended tonight after a six-month run.
Jesus' command that men should love one another must be accepted positively, the Rev. Francis J. Ansbro said yesterday at solemn mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral.
City Council President Abe Stark indicated strongly last night that he would decline Mayor Wagner's bid for him to run for City Controller.
PITTSBURGH, June 25 (AP) -- Home runs spelled the difference today as the Pirates and Phillies split a doubleheader. Pittsburgh won the opener, 10 -- 5. The Phillies took the second game, 4 -- 3.
The most persistent argument advanced by advocates of Federal aid to parochial schools is that withholding such funds would be "discriminatory." It is a wholly misleading argument.

A new tiny amplifier -- one of the latest miracles of electronic microminiaturization -soon may enable listeners to catch satellite signals too weak to have been heard up to now. The amplifier was announced over the week-end by the Micro State Electronics Corporation, Murray Hill, N. J.

The unions on strike are the National Maritime Union, 37,000 members; the Seafarers International Union, Atlantic, Gulf and Lakes section, 22,000; the Marine Engineers Beneficial Association, 11,000; the Masters, Mates and Pilots, 11,000, and the American Radio Association.

The Communist countries, chiefly the Soviet Union, allocated roughly a billion dollars to foreign economic aid alone last year, the highest annual total so far and many times more than the few hundred millions appropriated in the initial period of Communist bloc aid seven years ago.

TOKYO, June 25 -- Japan's decidedly Marxist Socialist party has decided to go into business -- a decidedly bourgeois business.
ALBANY, June 25 (AP) -- The state has rejected identical low bids on contracts for laboratory supplies, sheet metal and crackers, the Office of General Services announced today.

Welch's grape juice, Land O'Lakes butter, Guild wines, Donald Duck citrus juices, Sun Maid raisins, Calavo avocados, Diamond walnuts, Sunsweet prunes, and Sunkist Oranges -- these are all cooperative brand names.
WASHINGTON, June 25 -The farm debate will reach a crisis in both houses of Congress this week. The result could be one of the worst legislative defeats yet suffered by the Kennedy Administration.

CLEVELAND, June 25 (UPI) -- The Cleveland Indians beat the Detroit Tigers, 4 -- 3, on Chuck Essegian's ninth-inning drive with the bases filled today. The Tigers won the first game, 6 -- 3, on Norm Cash's two home runs.

THE summer sends a throng of eager, cheery-faced young women to the beaches of Long Island and New Jersey, filled with anticipation of glorious week-ends with sun and surf. Yet, the reaction to this is mixed.

Clock-watchers in a banner crowd of 19,220 at Randalls Island were disappointed at the ordinary time of 4 minutes 4.9 seconds, but Dyrol Burleson accomplished his prime objective by soundly beating Jim Beatty in the mile yesterday.

Michael J. Quill, international president of the Transport Workers Union, has fired the opening publicity salvo of his negotiations for a new labor contract with public and private mass transit in New York City. A four-day, thirty-two-hour week is to be the main goal of bargaining with the Transit Authority and seven private bus lines.
The world of medicine moved into New York City in force yesterday for the 110th annual meeting of the American Medical Association.

KANSAS CITY, June 25 -- Gene Stephens' two-run home run and clutch relief pitching by Jerry Walker gave the Kansas City Athletics a 3-2 victory over the Boston Red Sox today in the second game of a double-header.

LEOPOLDVILLE, June 25 (AP) -- Security guards ringed the delegation from the Stanleyville regime when it arrived yesterday. A photographer, Horst Faas of The Associated Press, had his camera knocked from his hands when he tried to photograph the ministers.

BLOOMINGTON, Minn., June 25 -- The Yankees, adhering to a pattern, thrashed the Minnesota Twins in the series finale today, 8 to 4. In the process, they corrected any false notions the Twins' new manager, Sam Mele, may have entertained after his team had won the opener last Friday.
THE way American parents dress their children seems to be admired abroad and has caused the "American look" to come down in size while going up in prestige.
CHICAGO, June 25 -- Primitive artists, including American Indians, sometimes viewed their conquerors and colonizers with a droll and unterrified eye.
BUENOS AIRES, June 25. -- The Argentine Government was today standing by its program for a far reaching reorganization of the nationalized railway system despite a background of strike threats.
A picture of low wages for New York factory workers emerged yesterday from a new analysis of Federal labor statistics.

WASHINGTON, June 25 -- A Federal law requiring school districts to take by 1963 affirmative first steps toward compliance with the Supreme Court desegregation ruling was urged here today by Jewish leaders. The law would have its chief application in the South.
Prices of cotton futures gave ground last week and at the close of trading on Friday active contracts showed net losses ranging from 5 cents to $2.30 a bale.

DUBLIN, June 25 -- More than 90,000 persons crowded into Croke Park here today for the solemn religious high point of Dublin's Patrician Congress. A pontifical high mass was celebrated by the Papal Legate. Gregory Peter XV Cardinal Agagianian.

In the reorganization of Soviet science that began in April, the Academy of Sciences has been stripped of at least thirty of its research institutes. At the same time, however, it has been freed for more concentrated efforts in pure science.

CHICAGO, June 25 -- Nine Negro college students have received four-year medical scholarships with annual awards of from $400 to $1,250 under a program to help relieve the shortage of Negro physicians and surgeons.

It is important in these days for America to keep steadfast its image as the champion of individual rights. The Charter Revision Commission was urged yesterday to ignore Mayor Wagner's recent request that it consider creation of a city Department of Engineering and Construction to handle all city construction and maintenance work, including that done for the schools.

MIDDLEBURG, Va., June 25 -- President Kennedy went to mass today and said that he felt "fine -- very good" even though he remained seated when the Roman Catholic service called for kneeling. He and Mrs. Kennedy heard the Rev. Albert F. Pereira give a message that might have been addressed to the recuperating President.

Devaluation is often considered a bitter economic pill. Not so with the Canadians. For some time Government officials, economists and business men have been prescribing a cheaper Canadian dollar as a miracle drug to help solve a six-year-old chronic ailment -- more imports than exports. A cheaper Canadian dollar would give foreigners more for their money and hence stimulate tourism and exports, and, at the same time, discourage imports.

LOS ANGELES, June 25 (AP) -- Ron Hansen's homer in the fourteenth inning sent the Baltimore Orioles to a 9-8 victory over the Los Angeles Angels today. The Orioles had trailed by five runs in the early going.

" Sinclair Lewis: An American Life," Mark Schorer's new book which McGraw-Hill will publish, has been chosen the October selection of the Book-of-the-Month Club. The 850-page volume gives a portrait of the life and times of the "restless" author of "Main Street" and "Babbitt," who was born the son of a country doctor in Minnesota in 1885 and died rich and embittered in Italy in 1951.

In your editorial of June 8 concerning the desirability of reducing the amount of borrowing by New York City you state that "When you don't pay cash the cost of government is higher, no matter how you juggle the upside-down arguments."

VERSAILLES, France, June 25 -- The Tour de France bike race -- 132 gaunt young men in quest of a fortune -- pedaled south from Rouen this morning. Tonight it hovers here on the outskirts of Paris. Tomorrow morning it pedals on, and on and on and on.

The Chamber of Commerce of Greater Philadelphia has given provisional endorsement to a proposed interstate compact for the Delaware River Basin. The compact would make the Federal Government and the states of Pennsylvania, New Jersey, Delaware and New York partners in developing the basin's water resources.
ST. LOUIS, June 25 (UPI) -- Ray Sadecki's two-hitter in the second game of a double-header gave the Cardinals a 3-1 victory over San Francisco today after the Giants had won the first game, 6-4.
Speedy new methods of interior construction are making it easier for a company to move from one set of offices to another and avoid paying rent on both suites at the same time.
CHICAGO, June 25 (AP) -The Chicago White Sox extended their winning streak to ten straight today by whipping the Washington Senators, 7-3 and 6-3.

FOR Mrs. John Newton Pearce, a petite, brown-haired young mother who has her own spacious office at the White House, week days are filled with a rare kind of high adventure.

The super-sized, specialized ore carrier has eliminated small tramp ships and taken over the job of keeping the United States supplied with iron ore imports, according to an anlysis of the world's iron ore trade.

During the past week the weakness of the Canadian dollar was the principal feature of the foreign exchange market. The dollar fell to the lowest level since December, 1951, when it sold at a discount of 3 1/4 on Wednesday. The pronounced weakness was the result of the presentation of a deficit budget by the Finance Minister. It closed at 3 3/32 cents discount, a loss of 3.09 cents.

It may have come as amazing news to many readers that a man appointed as a notary could be refused a commission because he declined to declare his "belief in the existence of God." But, as a case just decided by the Supreme Court showed, this is what happened in Maryland, where a provision in the State Constitution authorized such a declaration as a prerequisite for holding office.

When President Kennedy's temperature went up to 101.6 last Thursday a London newspaper meditated gloomily that this "could not have occurred at a more unfortunate time." Others had been upset because the President lamed his back doing some spade work in Canada. But the crisis passed. Mr. Kennedy's temperature is now normal and he gets up and down stairs like the comparatively young man, athletic in body and mind, that he really is.
Nearly 93,000 persons overflowed Yankee Stadium yesterday at the final session of the six-day Jehovah's Witnesses convention.

Walter N. Thayer, president of the Whitney Communications Corporation, has been named president of the New York Herald Tribune, Inc., effective tomorrow. The announcement was made last night by John Hay Whitney, publisher and owner of The New York Herald Tribune.
Three of the nine occupants of a car were killed and the six others injured early yesterday when it collided with a bus on a curve in West Brighton, S.I.

THAT annual civic event known as Gershwin Night at Lewisohn Stadium was celebrated for the thirtieth time on Saturday night. The skies were clear, the music was serene and a good time was had by the crowd that filled about three quarters of the stadium's available space.

HONOLULU, June 25 -- Governor Rockefeller disclosed today that he expected some New York residents, as individuals, to challenge New Jersey's new commuter benefit tax law in the courts soon. As a state, New York is not planning any action now.

In an effort to block the proposed sale of 150,000 shares of Penn Fruit, Inc., stock to AFC-Wrigley Stores, Inc., for $20 a share, a group of Penn Fruit stockholders announced yesterday that it was offering $21 a share for such stock.

CHICAGO, Tuesday, June 27 -- Officials of the National League baseball clubs, after meeting for more than ten hours yesterday and early today, agreed on a plan for supplying players to the New York Mets and the Houston Colts.

The New York Times agreed yesterday to the reinstatement of Samuel Resnick, the former union chairman of The Times composing room. His dismissal last April 26 touched off a four-hour work stoppage by printers.
Prices of standard quality items in next fall's catalogue that was published yesterday by Spiegel, Inc., Chicago mail-order concern, average 1.5 per cent lower than a year ago.

WASHINGTON, June 26 -- Mrs. John F. Kennedy, who shares a sense of history with her husband, the President, has chosen Mount Vernon for a state dinner honoring Mohammed Ayub Khan, the President of Pakistan.

Four hundred fifty college and high school students and teachers will sail today for nine European and African countries to live with families there for eight weeks.

Contracts for future construction in the United States placed during May increased 5 per cent over those of the same period a year ago to $3,501,318,000, the F.W. Dodge Corporation reported yesterday. Gains in highways, commercial building, electric light and power systems and apartments were listed among the causes for the rise.

Representative John V. Lindsay was named yesterday to be Republican campaign chairman for the Mayoralty contest. He took the occasion to invite Liberal party members and all interested in good government to back the Lefkowitz-Fino-Gilhooley ticket.

KIAMESHA LAKE, N.Y., June 26 (AP) -- Negro golfers are often barred from professional tournaments, State Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz said today in disclosing that he was trying to break down the restriction.

Confusion likely to grow worse before it gets better struck the Democratic party in New York City yesterday, with Lawrence E. Gerosa's declaration of independent candidacy for Mayor and Abe Stark's final refusal to run for Controller on the Wagner or any other ticket. Thus the party is split wide open and the Republicans have cause to rejoice.
TOKYO, June 26 -- The hot, muggy days have arrived in Tokyo, bringing with them the special fruits of the Japanese summertime: extra cash and high-pitched advice on how to spend it.

United States amateur automobile-racing drivers licensed by the Sports Car Club of America were barred indefinitely yesterday from international events. The Federation Internationale de l'Automobile, the governing organization of world automotive affairs, levied the penalty.
