The Diana Stores Corporation, which operates about 300 women's apparel stores in twenty-nine states, is interested in expanding into the discount field, it was disclosed yesterday. Negotiations to acquire two discount chains have been under way for several weeks.

President Kennedy's recourse to the Taft-Hartley Law in the seamen's strike was almost inevitable once the unions had turned down Secretary of Labor Goldberg's proposal to establish an impartial panel to help settle the walkout. But Taft-Hartley will not necessarily open a clear way out of the dead-end waters in which the country's shipping industry is immobilized.
Following is the text of the statement issued yesterday by Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa:

WASHINGTON, June 26 (AP) -- The Veterans Administration asked today for restoration of $1,899,000 cut by the House from its request for operating and administrative funds for the year starting Saturday.

A CHILD is often the victim of a tragedy caused by his parents' unwitting negligences. One of the most common is the lack of advance parental planning to save chil dren from a burning apartment or house.
WASHINGTON, June 26 (AP) -- The White House is being asked to ratify a Treasury decision against printing paper money in a variety of colors.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 26 -- Ernest Lehman, one of Hollywood's ranking screen writers, stared at the sheet in his typewriter, put his feet on the typewriter table and posed what lawyers would call a hypothetical question.
YORK, England, June 26 (UPI) -- Dr. Donald Coggan was elected Archbishop of York today, succeeding Dr. Arthur Michael Ramsey, the new Archbishop of Canterbury.

OTTAWA, June 26 -- The Government staked its life today on Parliamentary approval of its demand for the dismissal of James E. Coyne, Governor of the Bank of Canada. His economic policies have clashed with the Government's.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 26 -- Arab diplomats found more psychological than military meaning in the "annexation" of Kuwait by Iraq that was announced by Premier Kassim yesterday.

DETROIT, June 26 -- The daily sales rate of domestically built passenger cars in mid-June was nearly 17 per cent higher than in the earlier part of the month. But it was almost 8 per cent below the sales rate for the 1960 period.
THE hat that is already being hailed as the "shape of the season" takes over Halston's fall collection for Bergdorf Goodman.

UNITY HOUSE, Pa., June 26 -- The merged labor federation's only Negro vice president called for the expulsion of the Virginia state affiliate if it went through with plans to hold its annual convention in segregated Norfolk.

A momentous change in Europe that is presumably one of the factors behind Premier Khrushchev's drive for a speedy settlement of the German and Berlin problems is now under way as the British consider joining the European Economic Community.

Johnston, Lemon Co. and Eastman Dillon, Union Securities Co. and associates offered yesterday to the public $25,000,000 of 5.40 per cent twenty-year sinking fund debentures of State Loan and Finance Corporation.

PARIS, June 26 -- Two trotting mares, a sheep-goat that thinks it is fighting bull, and a very nervous observer will board an Alitalia cargo plane here tomorrow night for the first leg of a journey to Roosevelt Raceway, the site of the International Trot on July 14.
A group of 160 young college graduates who had volunteered to teach school in East Africa enrolled yesterday for an intensive three-week orientation course at Teachers College, Columbia University.
WASHINGTON, June 26 (AP) -- Another bill offered by Attorney General Robert F. Kennedy to control crime was attacked today as the Senate Judiciary Committee ended hearings on the seven measures.
PARIS, June 26 -- In much of continental Western Europe today thoughtful men look across the English Channel and ask themselves: "What's going to happen to our club if those fellows join?"

LONDON, June 26 -- The United States opened here today the first of the Government-sponsored trade centers she is establishing in foreign countries as part of the Kennedy Administration's export expansion drive.

Output of steel eased again last week for the fourth consecutive time. But the decline was smaller than that of the preceding week. The nation's mills turned out 1,978,000 tons of raw steel, compared with 1,985,000 two weeks before and 2,042,000 three weeks earlier, according to statistics released yesterday by the American Iron and Steel Institute.
The State Lottery Control Commission announced new regulations yesterday aimed at curbing commercialism and financial looseness in the conduct of bingo games.

UNITY HOUSE, Pa., June 26 -- Labor's high command urged President Kennedy today to approve a plan put forward by three striking ship unions for moving emergency cargoes, without proceeding toward an injunction under the Taft-Hartley Act.

GROSSINGER, N.Y., June 26 -- The New York Public Welfare Association, representing all the public welfare departments in this state, took sharp issue today with the City of Newburgh, which has instituted a policy of getting tough with some relief recipients, beginning July 15.

WASHINGTON, June 26 (AP) -- The House voted today for a $5,000,000,000 temporary increase in the limit on the national debt. The legislation would set the ceiling at $298,000,000,000 and make sure that the Treasury can pay its bills next week.

WITH thirty-five years' experience, David L. Cole is recognized as one of the nation's leading arbitrators . . . Former director of the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service . . . A 1924 law graduate of Harvard, he became interested in conciliation when labor unrest rocked Paterson, N.J., silk industry, where his father was a mill owner . . .
WASHINGTON, June 26 (AP) -- More babies were born in the United States in the first four months of 1961 than ever before in a comparable period, the Public Health Service estimated today.

ONE of the favorite hide-aways for the active sports-woman has been the little department tucked behind the luggage department on the sixth floor at Saks Fifth Avenue. Well, hideaway it is no longer. Saks' Active Sportswear Department has expanded and moved to a recently acquired building at 16 East Fiftieth Street, adjacent to the big store.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), June 26 -- Adolf Eichmann told his Israeli judges today that he "felt like Pontius Pilate" when the Nazis met in 1942 to plot the annihilation of European Jews.
LOS ANGELES, June 26 -- The Yankees nudged their way to within a game of the league-leading Detroit Tigers tonight by downing Bill Rigney's Angels, 8 -- 6. But it took a tremendous effort.
Thirty-nine members of the track and field squad that will represent the United State next month in dual meet against the Soviet Union, West Germany, Great Britain and Poland were named yesterday.

KEY WEST, Fla., June 26 (AP) -- The ten anti-Castro prisoners who arrived here Saturday from Cuba said today that they had not come with the intention of making an appeal for funds for tractors to ransom about 1,200 of their companions.
Benton Bowles, Inc., whether by design or by chance, has struck the most telling blow so far in the advertising agencies' battle against increased station break time on television.
The second case of arson in a public school here in the last three days occurred last night on the lower East Side.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., June 26 -- One of the best saleswomen for President Kennedy's physical-fitness program will be honored by the Women's Westchester Bowling Association at a dinner here on Wednesday night.
SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., June 26 (AP) -- Death or nationalization faces the nation's railroads unless the Government alters its public transportation policies, railroad official said today.

The Massachusetts Investors Growth Stock Fund reported yesterday that net assets, share value, the number of shareholders and shares outstanding rose to record levels in its second fiscal quarter, ended on May 31.

Earnings of First National Stores, Inc., for its first fiscal quarter, ended on June 24, are expected to aggregate somewhat more than those of the period, a year earlier, Adrian O'Keeffe, president, told stockholders at the annual meeting yesterday in Somerville, Mass.
CHICAGO, June 26 (AP) -- Liquidation in soybean futures brought a sharp decline in that commodity today with prices off more than 6 cents a bushel on the July contract at the close.

LONDON, June 26 (Reuters) -- Australia survived a shock assault by England's pace attack to win the second test cricket match at Lord's today by five wickets. The scores: England 206 and 202 runs, Australia 340 and 71 runs for five wickets.
The Middle East has been described as "a desert floating on a sea of oil." Kuwait completely fulfills that description.

TOKYO, June 26 (AP) -- Mitsunori Seki, a 19-year-old who has had only twenty-four professional fights, meets Pone Kingpetch of Thailand tomorrow in an attempt to regain the world flyweight crown Japan surrendered six years ago.
The Virginia Electric and Power Company reported yesterday that operating revenues and net income for May and the five months and twelve months ended on May 31 exceeded year-earlier levels.
The post-war building revolution has caught up with a landmark of the financial district that is little known to the public but that is of key importance to the nation's banking system.
WASHINGTON, June 26 -- President Kennedy submitted to Congress today legislation seeking an expanded and accelerated Federal effort to convert saline water into fresh water.
A picture of two of the ages of man, blacker by far than any of Shakespeare's famous seven, was drawn here yesterday.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 26 -- Andrew W. Cordier, the official closest to the Secretary General, has resigned after sixteen years as executive assistant.
WASHINGTON, June 26 -- A Congressional committee was told today that proposed legislation to limit claims against shipowners would take away the rights of personal injury victims.
HONG KONG, June 26 -- Communist China has lifted restrictions on the amount of food that may be received as gifts from friends or relatives abroad, according to word received here.
Realty Equities Corporation has signed a contract to buy fifteen properties in New York, New Jersey and Massachusetts for more than $7,000,000.

American coal marketing agents in Western Europe, faced with a slow decline in sales, are concerned about the eventual results of United States aid to Poland and of the energy policy of the six-nation European Common Market.

PHILADELPIA, June 26 (UPI) -- Dallas Green's pitching in the last three innings saved a shutout for Jim Owens as the Philadelphia Phillies won, 1 -- 0, from the San Francisco Giants tonight. Green had to hurl his way out of a jam in each inning.
A PRESS-ON pattern that eliminates the need for tailor's tacking, tracing wheel and dressmaker's carbons was introduced today by McCall's Patterns.
THE following menu is suggested as a guide to the use of foods that are reasonable in cost. A recipe is given for an easy-to-prepare main dish.

George Alpert, president of the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad, and A. Gerdes Kuhbach, treasurer of the railroad, were in Washington all yesterday. Until late in the afternoon they still had received no word on the New Haven's request to the Federal Government of a new $5,500,000 loan.

Today's new film is "Rocco and His Brothers," an Italian-language drama with English subtitles, in a dual premiere at 8 P.M. at the Beekman Theatre, Second Avenue Sixty-fifth Street, and at the newly remodeled Pix Theatre, Forty-second Street east of Times Square.
HERE it is only the seventh day of summer and already fishermen have been snagged by strange and outrageous happenings and even an incomprehensible fact.
The use of enzyme "fingerprints" to diagnose ailments before they otherwise become evident was reported yesterday to have come a step closer with the development of a simple method of analysis.
SOME have spotted complexions; a few have a wooden look; the best effect is a coy blush.
Disappointing results in the treatment of lung cancer with high voltage X-rays were reported here yesterday.
A child's-size Noah's Ark, being about eighteen cubits in length, was launched in a sea of gravel yesterday at Central Park Zoo.

Representative John V. Lindsay told the graduating class at Junior High School 47 in Manhattan, the only public school for the deaf in the city, that the techniques that had helped them could also help "students with hearing, but who do not hear."
The State Board of Social Welfare, meeting here in special session yesterday, appointed a committee of five of its members to investigate the administration of public welfare in the city of Newburgh.

MME. GEORGES HEISBOURG, one of Embassy Row's liveliest residents, borrows her husband's thermal underwear, weeds her own garden, prefers Balenciaga clothes and does her best to keep up with life as it is lived in three different capitals -- Washington, Ottawa and Mexico City.
BAGHDAD, Iraq, June 26 (Reuters) -- The Baghdad radio broadcast today pledges of support by high-ranking Iraqi Army officers for Premier Kassim's claim of sovereignty over Kuwait.
Newburger, Loeb Co., security brokerage concern, has leased two and one-half floors in the new twenty-four-story building at 66 Beaver Street on Hanover Square.
CHICAGO, June 26 (UPI) -- A spokesman for a group of Protestant laymen said today that there had been "irregularities" in a recent vote to merge with two other Protestant denominations.
HONOLULU, June 26 -- Gov. David L. Lawrence of Pennsylvania asked the Conference of Governors today to pledge support to President Kennedy in his negotiations with Premier Khrushehev.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., June 26 -- A Wheatley Hills team of Alfred J. Schrafel St. and Jr. won the forty-second annual Father-Son Golf Association championship by a stroke at the Garden City Golf Club today. The Schrafels scored an 83 -- 13 -- 70 in the alternate-shot tournament that was decided on the basis of net scores.

JACKSON, June 26 (AP) -- City Judge James Spencer today convicted twenty-three more Freedom Riders on breach of the peace charges, raising to 163 the number found guilty since the rides, reached here a month ago.

In a drifting market strongly reminiscent of that in the early months of 1960, stocks slipped yesterday. There was no apparent pressure, except in a few issues affected by news developments or secondary distributions.
LONDON, June 26 -- Selwyn Lloyd, Britain's Chancellor of the Exchequer, said tonight that many problems had to be solved and decisions made before Western European unity could be achieved.
JERUSALEM, (Israeli Sector), June 26 -- Election lists were closed tonight with fifteen political parties Contending for 120 seats in Israel's next Knesset (Parliament).

WASHINGTON, June 26 (AP) -- A.C. Ingersoll Jr., President of Federal Barge Lines, Inc., of St. Louis, said today that the nation's railroads advocated a return to the law of the jungle in rate-making.

WASHINGTON, June 26 (UPI) -- The House Education and Labor Committee reversed itself today and decided against permitting teachers in parochial and other private schools to draw weekly stipends for attending summer school seminars.
DECLARER'S problem in this deal was not an unusual one, but it is doubtful if many players would have found the solution in the time one can politely take for thought in a bridge game.

The filth work by an American composer commissioned by the New York City Opera Company under a Ford Foundation grant will be "The Golem," by Abraham Ellstein of New York. The commission was announced yesterday by Julius Rudel, general director of the New York City Opera.
A woman was killed yesterday when an automobile mounted a curb in Jamaica, Queens, and knocked her into the path of a truck.

WASHINGTON, June 26 -- The Senate approved today amendments to the Social Security program that would give $780,000,000 in new or increased benefits during the next year to about 4,420,000 citizens who have reached retirement age. The vote was 90 to 0.

GENEVA, June 26 -- Marshal Chen Yi, Communist China's Foreign Minister, used about 5,000 words today to say "never" to the United States plan for international controls to guarantee the neutrality and independence of Laos.

LONDON, June 26 -- As the traditional protector of Kuwait, which supplies nearly 40 per cent of her petroleum, Britain initiated today a series of consultations on Premier Kassim's claim that the sheikdom was now an integral part of Iraq.
GARDEN CITY, L.I., June 26 -- A Federal Aviation Agency official said today that Mitchel Air Force Base could meet a need for a general airport in Nassau County.
Increased sales and earnings were reported by the Brown-Forman Distillers Corporation for the fiscal year ended on April 30.
Six members of New Rochelle's Board of Education were accused yesterday by Federal Judge Irving R. Kaufman of acting as a "super-Supreme Court."
WASHINGTON, June 26 (UPI) -- The Navy today ordered the end of an era that has spanned nearly half a century.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., June 26 -- Carole Wright of Brooklyn, the defender, and Carmen Lampe of Forest Hills, L.I, gained the final of the New York State women's tennis championship today at the Beach Point Club.

City Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa announced yesterday his intention to run for Mayor. He said he might enter the Democrat primary in September, but if he did not, he would definitely run as an independent in the election Nov. 7.
President Kennedy invoked the Taft-Hartley Act yesterday in an attempt to bring a quick end to the eleven-day-old strike of American seamen.
Trading was unusually light yesterday on the New York commodity exchanges. Prices moved in narrow ranges and future closed irregularly.

The unions on strike are the National Maritime Union, 37,000 members; the Seafarers International Union, Atlantic, Gulf and Lakes section, 22,000; the Marine Engineers Beneficial Association, 11,000; the Masters, Mates and Pilots, 11,000, and the American Radio Association.

Thousands of buyers viewed more than 500 lines of fall and winter home furnishings yesterday at the opening of the seventieth annual summer furniture market at the New York Furniture Exchange, 200 Lexington Avenue.
The only book pubilshed today is "Marriage in Philippsburg," a novel by Martin Walser. It is a story of life in a postwar West German city. Issued by New Directions, it sells for $4.50.
A stalled train disrupted Manhattan-bound local service for almost two hours yesterday at six stations between the Fifty-ninth and Pacific Street stations on the BMT Fourth Avenue Line in Brooklyn.
DUBLIN, June 26 -- Councilor Robert Briscoe, who was the first Jewish Lord Mayor of this predominantly Roman Catholic city, was elected again to the office tonight. He was elected previously in 1956.
WIMBLEDON, England, June 26 -- A sparkling performance by Ron Holmberg of Brooklyn today brightened the worst opening day in memory at the all-England tennis championships.

The New York State Theatre in Lincoln Center will be designed in a shallow horseshoe shape so that none of its 2,801 seats will be more than 140 feet away from the stage. This will create an intimate atmosphere in a theatre of rather large capacity.

GENEVA, June 26 -- Britain denounced the Soviet Union today for seeking to merge the nuclear test ban talks with disarmament negotiations after first having insisted that the two issues be kept separate.
ATLANTIC CITY, June 26 -- Members of the National Education Association received a resolution on school integration today that was described as "possibly the strongest we've ever had."
CAPE CANAVERAL, June 26 (UPI) -- The Navy fired its advanced model of the Polaris missile from a laboratory ship off the Florida coast today. Engine trouble dropped the rocket short of its target.

WASHINGTON, June 26 -- Congress sent to the White House today a new multi-billion-dollar highway bill carrying some tax rises for the trucking industry and a slight additional tax for every American motorist.

Sir Gaylord of the Meadow Stable, with more experience than any of his five rivals, won the colt division of the National Stallion Stakes at Belmont Park yesterday. The son of Turn-to scored by two and a quarter lengths over the Circle M Farm's I'm For More.
Dorothy Raedler, whose Gilbert and Sullivan verse singers, the American Savoyards, have become something of a New York institution, is planning to establish a full-time musical repertory next season.

WASHINGTON, June 26 -- Michel Sieplinski, a 54-year-old resident of Bronxville, N.Y., who fled his Polish homeland in 1941, has been named deputy administrator in the State Department's Bureau of Security and Consular Affairs.

WASHINGTON, June 26 -- President Kennedy announced today that he was recalling Gen. Maxwell D. Taylor, former Army Chief of Staff, to active military service with the title of Military Representative of the President. The assignment is effective July 1.
Construction has begun on two three-story dormitories and a two-story mess hall at the State University Maritime College at Fort Schuyler, the Bronx.
BERLIN, June 26 (UPI) -- Premier Khrushchev said tonight on the thirteenth anniversary of the Berlin airlift that a peace treaty with Germany this year was a "compulsive necessity."
DETROIT, June 26 (AP) -- The auto industry will wind up the first half of 1961 this week about 1,100,000 cars behind the production pace of a year ago.

LONDON, June 26 -- With buyers reluctant, small selling had a disproportionately depressing effect on prices in the stock market today.

In the aftermath of last year's one-day teachers' strike, the Board of Education appointed an impartial Commission of Inquiry to recommend a course of action in the controversial bargaining issue. The commission made its report in May. The board, after delaying publication of the report, finally rejected major portions of the recommendations.
PHILADELPHIA, June 26 -- The Department of Justice rested today in its suit to block the proposed merger of the Philadelphia National Bank with the Girard Trust Corn Exchange Bank.
WESTBURY, L.I., June 26 -- Harness racing fans no longer ask "Who's going to beat Adios Butler?" The question now is, "Who's going to be second to him?"

WASHINGTON, June 26 -- More than one quarter of the members of the House of Representatives and one-third of the Senate have filed a strong protest against the Administration's plans for handling textile imports.

COLORADO SPRINGS, Colo., June 26 (UPI) -- The Air Defense Command said today that four men were killed and twenty-nine others injured yesterday when a huge chunk of glacier crashed down on them at the edge of the Greenland ice cap near Sondrestrom Air Base.
The New York Central Railroad ended the first five months of this year $25,279,551 in the red, it was announces yesterday. It was the worst showing for any such period in the carrier's history.

NO Soviet athlete who had gained a place on his country's team for a dual meet with the United States would dare to beg off or even want to do so. With eager pride Ivan would accept his assignment. But the rugged individualists who exercise muscles and free will in America cannot be regimented.
President Kennedy's invoking of the Taft-Hartley Law yesterday marked the eighteenth time it has been used since Congress set up this emergency machinery in 1947 to deal with national labor disputes.
GENEVA, June 26 (UPI) -- President Kennedy pledged today the full support of the United States to the International Labor Organization, which is holding its annual conference here.
WILMINGTON, Del., June 26 (AP) -- The Federal District Court here upheld today the State Board of Education's "short range" plan for school desegregation this fall.
HERSHEY, Pa. June 26 -- Former President Dwight D. Eisenhower turned down tonight an invitation to be the Republican candidate for the Senate next year.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange advanced 8 to 20 points yesterday on commission house and trade support. A point equals 5 cents a bale.

Courtaulds, Ltd., the big British textile and chemical concern, has acquired 4 to 5 per cent of the outstanding common stock of Koppers Company, Inc., and the two companies are exploring "areas of mutual interest."
Police Commissioner Michael J. Murphy appealed yesterday to persons who expect to watch the fireworks display on the Hudson River tomorrow night to use subways and buses to get to the waterfront.

The nation's railroads have been besieging Congress to relax the Interstate Commerce Act to permit them to diversify into other forms of transport. So far the progress has been very slow. But, every once in a while, some roads make a bit of a breakthrough.

ELISABETHVILLE, the Congo, June 26 -- Moise Tshombe, President of Katanga Province, made a series of bitter charges tonight against the leaders of the Central Congolese Government he praised highly just two days ago.

A rare note of unity between maritime labor and management was sounded yesterday. Joseph Curran, president of the National Maritime Union, joined shipping operators in opposing President Kennedy's plan for reorganizing the Federal Maritime Board.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., June 26 -- The first two contingents of Peace Corps volunteers assigned to overseas projects began intensive two-month training courses today at Rutgers University here and at Texas Western College in El Paso.

ELIZABETH, N.J., June 26 -- A half-million gallons of fuel oil flowed into the Arthur Kill from a leaking storage tank at the Crown Central Oil Corporation's terminal at 450 South Front Street today and caused a fire hazard described as the worst in the history of the waterfront here.

Dr. John J. Theobald, the Superintendent of Schools, and his administration were accused yesterday by a member of the State Investigation Commission of having "callously" ignored known defects and needed repairs in the city schools.

If Secretary General Hammarskjold has his way, the United Nations Secretariat will change its nature somewhat during the next year or so, but it will not be directed by what the Russians call a "troika."

WASHINGTON, June 26 -- A House subcommittee has approved a bill to revamp the Federal Communications Commission. In some ways it is more sweeping than the President's reorganization plan, which the House recently killed.
ST. LOUIS, June 26 (UPI) -- Joe Adcock capped a six-run uprising in the third inning with his eleventh home run tonight as the Milwaukee Braves downed the Cardinals, 9 -- 6.
WASHINGTON, June 26 -- The Justice Department brought suit today to end racial segregation in the New Orleans airport terminal.
LONDON, June 26 -- The British Government proposed today new changes in the constitution of Northern Rhodesia that appeared to guarantee continued white control of the African protectorate.

Mayor Wagner reshuffled his Board of Ethics yesterday and took the occasion to declare that as Mayor he would continue to be "ruthless in attacking the bride, the pay-off, the gratuity and the conflict of interest."
CHICAGO, June 26 (AP) -- A suspended member of the Chicago Board of Trade sued for $1,544,537.75 in damages today and asked for a court order for reinstatement as a board member.
The Turner Construction Company has been awarded the contract to build an addition to the headquarters at 1 Wail Street of the Irving Trust Company.

THE middle initial "E" in Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa's name stands for "Ettore." But Walter J. Holmes, his assistant for public relations and perhaps his closest friend, says it should also stand for "Economy."

FARGO, N.D., June 26 (AP) -- William R. Burke of Los Angeles, national commander of the American Legion, predicted today this country would be at war with the Communists by the end of this year "unless Premier Khrushchev is bluffing on Berlin or we surrender."
GARDEN CITY, L.I., June 26 -- Plans for a $10,000,000 cultural center for Adelphi College were announced here today.

WISCONSIN-BORN, Prof. James J. Healy, 45, served on Presidential fact-finding boards in 1957 and 1958 . . . The first involved dispute between several railroads in New York and a maritime union; the second was a dispute between American Airlines and pilots' union . . . Active in arbitration proceedings in New York City and Boston . . . Impartial arbitrator on contracts covering several Boston concerns and unions . . .
PARIS, June 27 -- President de Gaulle announced tonight orders for the withdrawal of one French army division from Algeria. He said "more will follow."

LOS ANGELES, June 27 -- The Yankees became enchanted tonight by the dimly-lighted scoreboard that tops the right-field bleachers in Wrigley Field. They saw it show the Tigers blow the opener of their doubleheader with the Chicago White Sox at Detroit.
WASHINGTON, June 27 -- A House committee approved today a bill that would extend the National Defense Education Act and provide $375,000,000 in loans for parochial and other private schools.

In devising their strategy for coping with Premier Khrushchev's threats over Berlin the Western powers will have to take into account both the exact nature of his demands and the manner in which he proposes to enforce them.

CARACAS, Venezuela, June -- The casualty toll of the unsuccessful revolt in Barcelona yesterday was officially reported today at seventeen dead and thirteen wounded. Bombs and dynamite charges were land in two places in Caracas day.
WASHINGTON, June 27 -- President Kennedy is expected to make a nation-wide television appeal for support of his foreign aid program when it comes up for Congressional debate next month.
A delinquency prevention project that had been destined to end with the city's Juvenile Delinquency Evaluation Project will continue under the direction of the Community Service Society.
CHICAGO, June 27 (AP) -- Continued lack of moisture in parts of Canada raised prices of most grain futures on the Board of Trade today.

Morgan Stanley Co. and associates offered to the public yesterday $25,000,000 of twenty-year 5 1/2 per cent bonds of Australia priced at 97 to yield about 5.75 per cent to maturity. This was the third $25,000,000 bond issue of the commonwealth to be marketed in the United States in the last fourteen months.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., June 27 (UPI) -- The New York State Society of Newspaper Editors today ordered its Right to Know Committee to report next year on a recent Court of Appeals decision under which grand jury presentments are secret.

Both stockholders and bondholders of New York Central Railroad took the bad news announced on Monday pretty much in stride. Evidently the $25,279,000 deficit reported on Monday for the first five months of this year had been pretty much discounted.
PARIS, June 27 -- T.S. Eliot introduced the idea that "April is the creulest month," but it may be well in 1961 to reserve that dubious honor for October.

LONDON, June 27 (Reuters) -- The East African states of Kenya, Tanganyika and Uganda will set up a new organization to administer services now provided by the British East African High Commission when they are independent, it was announced here today.

Poor John Theobald -- one of our rare honest and experienced public servants, with a proved ability in public service -- who is now being made the fall guy. Any real mess in the Department of Education must have gotten its start before his appointment.
Manhattan is having tree trouble.

John Wiley Sons, Inc., a venerable publishing house that brought out "The Spy" by James Fenimore Cooper in 1821, as well as works by Herman Melville, Edgar Allan Poe and Nathaniel Hawthorne, yesterday announced the acquisition of Interscience Publishers, Inc.
TRENTON, June 27 -- Superior Court Judge J. Edward Knight ruled unconstitutional today preferential treatment extended to farmers in the state Property Assessment Reform Law of 1960.

HONOLULU June 27 -- Through some intricate political maneuvering, Democratic Governors appeared tonight to have blocked Governor Rockefeller's election as chairman of the National Conference of Governors for the next year.

CHICAGO, June 27 (UPI) -- The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People accused Chicago's school superintendent today of "increasing a strongly segregated school system" and opposed his reappointment.
A city magistrate explored the economics of the modern dance yesterday and found that a recent recital at Hunter College Playhouse had not been a public entertainment requiring a license.
Television sponsors have a right to control the content of their drama programs, a leading producer told Federal investigators here yesterday.
WASHINGTON, June 27 (AP) -- Former President Dwight D. Eisenhower says the method of electing a President is outdated.
WASHINGTON, June 27 -- President Kennedy named a Federal Reserve bank officer today to the Federal Reserve Board of Governors.

DETROIT, June 27 (AP) -- Juan Pizarro baffled the Detroit Tigers with five hits in the second game of a double bill tonight as the Chicago White Sox stretched their winning streak to twelve games with 6-5 and 11-1 victories.
WASHINGTON, June 27 (AP) -- Legislation to allow more service aviators to draw some flight pay without actually flying was approved today by the House Armed Services Committee.
MOSCOW, June 27 -- The Communist party instructed its members today to tighten their control over the economy in order to curb the falsifying of records by state managers in agriculture and industry.

WASHINGTON, June 27 (AP) -- Officers of two New York State banks that seek to consolidate appealed today to the Federal Reserve Board to reverse its March 27 rejection of their merger application.
MILWAUKEE, June 27 (AP) -- Six manufacturers of telegraph and telephone pole equipment have pleaded not guilty to Federal charges of price fixing.
BLOOMINGTON, Ind., June 27 (AP) -- The Minnesota Twins swept a twilight-night program from the Boston Red Sox tonight with 6 -- 5 and 6 -- 3 victories.
TEHERAN, Iran, June 27 (Reuters) -- Travelers from Kuwait reported today that violent demonstrations against Iraq had been going on in Kuwait since yesterday.

RIO DE JANEIRO, June 27 -- The United States was reported today to be giving active consideration to a long-range plan to stabilize world coffee prices. The Erie-Lackawanna Railroad operated at a deficit of $15,678,640 in the first five months of this year. The road's president, Milton G. McInnes, announced the loss following a board meeting here.

WARSAW, June 27 -- The moves of Pope John XXIII toward Christian unity have markedly improved the climate of relations among Christian churches, the Rev. Dr. Franklin Clark Fry, president of the Lutheran World Federation, said today.
CHICAGO, June 27 -- Secretary of State Dean Rusk said today that the United States "moratorium policy" on the question of admitting Communist China to the United Nations would "no longer suffice."
