" THE STRAUSSES IN VIENNA" was the title given to last night's Lewisohn Stadium concert. To be perfectly accurate, of course, it must be allowed that Richard Strauss spent most of his time somewhat to the north of that city.
An unusual compensation arrangement has been announced by O.S. Tyson Co., Inc.
BONN, Germany, June 27 -- Rear Admiral Karl Adolf Zenker has been picked by Franz Josef Strauss, Defense Minister, to become the new head of West Germany's naval forces, reliable sources said today.

Mayor Wagner, in inviting the State Commissioner of Education to intervene with a new investigation of charges of discrimination against Catholic teachers at Queens College, has repudiated his own Board of Higher Education, which long since found no pattern of bias in appointment or promotion of staff members at the college.
A moratorium on any increase in non-defense Government spending not directly affecting national security was called for yesterday by former Vice President Richard M. Nixon.
The Times' editorial of June 21, "New York's Low Wages," contains unfair criticism of the City Department of Labor.

A plot of land fronting 100 feet on Eastchester Road, seventy-five feet on Oakley Avenue, 166 feet on East 221st Street and fifty feet on East 222d Street, the Bronx, has been bought by Omega Homes, Inc., builders.

LONDON, June 27 -- Britain informed her partners in the European Free Trade Association, or Outer Seven, today that she had not reached any decision on whether to seek membership in the European Economic Community, or Common Market.

Otis Davis, Olympic 400-meter champion, and Bill Alley, javelin star from Short Hills, N.J., yesterday became the latest in a list of withdrawals from the United States track and field team scheduled to compete against a Soviet squad in Moscow, July 15 and 16.
San Diego, Calif., borrowed $42,500,000 in the bond market yesterday to finance expansion of its sewer system.

Operating profits of the Diamond National Corporation in the second quarter of 1961 were about the same as a year earlier despite a decline in sales, the company announced yesterday. It is a leading manufacturer of paper packaging and advertising materials.
Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 8 points off to 5 points up yesterday. (A point equals 5 cents a bale.) Only the far July rose.

CHICAGO, June 27 -- George Wilder Mitchell has combined a solid academic background with a talent for brisk administration. A tax and public finance expert, he is vice president in charge of research at the Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago.
JACKSON, Miss., June 27 (UPI) -- A Federal judge refused today to take cases against Freedom Riders out of the hands of the Mississippi courts.

A time-shortening, moneysaving process called Instant Sync for the post-synchronization and dubbing of films was demonstrated yesterday by Jean Lenauer and Myer P. Beck, president and vice president of Lenbeck, Inc., recently organized to market the invention, and Dennis Gunst, originator of the process.
" Have you 'just missed' being involved in an air collision?"
WASHINGTON, June 27 (AP) -- The Senate passed a bill today to establish a national seashore park area along the ocean side of Cape Cod, Mass.
TEHERAN, Iran, June 27 (AP) -- A military court sentenced Prof. Mozaffer Baghai to two years in prison today on charges of intimidating police officers.

PHILADELPHIA, June 27 -- Former President Herbert Hoover declared in Independence Square today that the "validity of our Beliefs in freedom is at stake on a global battle ground." He sounded the keynote of Freedom Week, this city's observance of the 185th anniversary of American independence.
CHICAGO, June 27 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

MONTAUK POINT, L.I., June 27 -- There apparently is no doubt that swordfishermen employing rubber-bait fish and lures made of corn husks have as good a chance as anyone to succeed here -- if they don't catch orange parachutes carrying secret space devices.
ST. LOUIS, June 27 (AP) -- Bob Buhl's six-hit pitching and Eddie Mathews' two-run home run gave the Milwaukee Braves a 3-0 victory over the Cardinals tonight.

RICHMOND, Va., June 27 (AP) -- The Virginia-Carolina Chemical Corporation is acquiring a 20 per cent interest in the Texas International Sulphur Company of Houston, Tex. The transaction is to become effective next Saturday.

CANTERBURY, England, June 27 -- In a ceremony drawing on nearly 800 years of Christian history in Britain, Dr. Arthur Michael Ramsey was enthroned today as the 100th Archbishop of Canterbury and Primate of All England.

Collins Properties, Inc., which built the six-story apartment house at 340 East Sixty-sixth Street in 1940, has sold the structure for cash over mortgages amounting to $530,000. The buyer was the Collins Property Company, an investment concern that is not associated with the seller. The William K. Langfan Company was the broker.
WERE the Nineteen Forties so different from the early Nineteen Sixties? Have we changed so much from the era of the New Deal to the age of the New Frontier?

BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 27 -- Kuwait alerted its British-supported army today against any incursion from Iraq and won another powerful ally in support of its independence. The United Arab Republic announced in Cairo its opposition to any Iraqi attempt to annex the oil-rich sheikdom at the head of the Persian Gulf.

MIAMI, June 27 -- A group of about fifty men are training in Miami for a possible invasion of Cuba, although their leader contends officially that they are taking a civil defense course, The Miami Herald said today in a copyrighted article.

BERLIN, June 27 (AP) -- Two thousand students from West Berlin's Free University staged a silent protest march today against the arrest and conviction by the Communists of a vice president of the International Liberal Student Federation.
A five-year agreement providing full hospital, home and office medical care to 9,000 hotel employes and dependents was signed yesterday at New York Medical College-Flower and Fifth Avenue Hospitals.

The Avco Corporation registered a 19 per cent increase in earnings for the six months ended on May 31, despite a 4 per cent decline in sales from the year-earlier level, the semi-annual report disclosed yesterday.
Encouraged by the success of the secondary distribution of Ford Motor Company stock, the market reversed its downward course yesterday and staged a brisk rally in the afternoon.

Another 5 per cent of the outstanding shares of the Ford Motor Company moved into public ownership yesterday when 2,750,000 shares were sold by investment bankers. The shares previously were held by the Ford Foundation.
WASHINGTON, June 27 -- Several married couples without children may be among the first volunteers going to teach school in West Africa, Peace Corps officials said today.
PARIS, June 27 -- Thousands of farmers blocked highways and isolated villages with their tractors and denounced the Government today for not having done more to improve farm conditions.

The unions on strike are the National Maritime Union, 37,000 members; the Seafarers International Union, Atlantic, Gulf and Lakes section, 22,000; the Marine Engineers Beneficial Association, 11,000; the Masters, Mates and Pilots, 11,000, and the American Radio Association.
LA PAZ, Bolivia, June 27 -- Fifteen thousand striking tin miners went back to work today, ending a twenty-day, walkout.

NOTHING is quite as quiet as an audience genuinely moved by respect. Monday night, in Norman Norell's showroom, which was filled with a highly critical professional audience, one mesmerized buyer said:

WASHINGTON, June 27 -- The Administration estimates that if its proposed international agreements on cotton textile trading should be adopted, cotton textile imports to the United States would be cut by 9 per cent next year.

CHICAGO, June 27 -- The broadcasting industry must strive to avoid mass conformity and remain independent of any governmental thought control, LeRoy Collins, president of the National Association of Broadcasters, said here tonight.
A FIREWORKS display over the Hudson River will be presented this evening by Macy's. It may be seen from the New York side of the Hudson from Seventy-second to 125th Street beginning at 9:30 P.M.
A major campaign to convince American motorists to buy and use safety seat belts began yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 27 (UPI) -- Acting quickly so that the Government can pay its bills after Friday night, the Senate Finance Committee voted today to increase the national debt ceiling temporarily by $5,000,000,000 to a peacetime record of $298,000,000,000.

WASHINGTON, June 27 (AP) -- Mrs. John F. Kennedy announced today that Mr. and Mrs. Jules Stein of New York and Beverly Hills, Calif., would refurnish and redecorate the long hallway on the second floor of the White House.

Westminster Fund announced yesterday that securities with a market value of $151,095,839 on June 12 had been accepted tentatively for exchange for its shares. June 12 was the cut-off date for the "tax-free exchange" type of fund.

Striking sea unions opened an all-out battle yesterday against President Kennedy's move to halt their twelve-day walkout with a Taft-Hartley Act injunction. As the impact of the strike deepened and a Presidential fact-finding board began holding hearings, the two officer unions in the dispute served notice that they did not believe the law applied to them.
E. Roland Harriman, national chairman of the American Red Cross, announced yesterday the appointment of William White as chairman of the executive board of the American Red Cross in Greater New York.
Gustave Ring's distance specialist, Don Poggio, is the top weight under 125 pounds and the probable 1-2 favorite in the Hempstead Handicap at Belmont today.

WASHINGTON, June 27 (UPI) -- Senator John L. McClellan told the United States Information Agency today either to cut its European budget or get ready to have the Senate Appropriations subcommittee cut it.
WASHINGTON, June 27 (AP) -- The House Rules Committee today cleared for floor action a bill that would approve an interstate compact to develop the water resources of the Delaware River Basin.

Short covering, new buying and light stop-loss purchasing raised hide futures prices yesterday on the Commodity Exchange of New York. The volume, ninety-two lots of 40,000 pounds each, was the second largest this year.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., June 27 -- A school of human biology and medicine, encompassing the first two years of a medical school curriculum, is being planned at Rutgers University.

A fine Italian film to stand alongside the American classic, "The Grapes of Wrath," opened last night at the Beekman and the Pix on Forty-second Street. It is Luchino Visconti's "Rocco and His Brothers" ("Rocco e i suoi fratelli"), and it comes here garlanded with laurels that are quite as appropriate in this context as they are richly deserved.

CHICAGO, June 27 (AP) -- The Cincinnati Reds sent four straight pinch-hitters to the plate in the seventh inning against the Chicago Cubs today. They produced two singles, a walk and a base-clearing triple in a five-run inning that gave the league-leading Reds a 10-8 triumph.
SPRING LAKE, N.J., June 27 -- Ned J. Parsekian, acting state director of motor vehicles, charged today that keeping political influence out of his administration was the "most salient task" he faced.
ELISABETHVILLE, the Congo, June 27 (Reuters) -- President Moise Tshombe and his Foreign Minister, Evariste Kimba, will take thirty days' leave from Government duties in Katanga Province.
A New York State Supreme Court order directing that a new election of directors for the Fifth Avenue Coach Company be held not later than July 28 was vacated yesterday by the Appellate Division.

State Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz, the Republican candidate for Mayor, appeared yesterday to have been put on a spot with the city's Puerto Rican voters as a result of opposing moves by Mayor Wagner and Governor Rockefeller.
The election of Edward F. Baumer as vice president of the Great Western Financial Corporation was announced yesterday by John F. Marten, president of the Los Angeles concern.

WIMBLEDON, England, June 27 -- Nancy Richey of San Angelo, Tex., was beaten by Margaret Smith of Australia in a tennis classic today. Miss Smith won, 3 -- 6, 6 -- 3, 6 -- 4, just as she was supposed to do, but America has a new star in the ascendancy.
CHICAGO, June 27 -- The major leagues took action today to curb spiraling spending for baseball "bonus babies."
TEEN-AGE anxiety over college admission is becoming a mental health problem in this country, a pediatric psychiatrist warned yesterday.

THE limp, tasteless green beans that too many restaurants serve are enough to discourage anyone from eating the vegetable. Yet, as home gardeners know, the beans, freshly picked from the vine, are full of flavor.
LONDON, June 27 -- Prices retreated all along the line in the stock market today.

Marion Aten of El Centro, Calif., who died four weeks ago, served with the Royal Air Force in the south Russian campaign during the civil war in Russia (1915-1920). His eyewitness account, written in collaboration with Arthur Orrmont, will be issued Sept. 19 by Messner under the title "Last Train Over Rostov Bridge."

After a year of strife that plunged the country into chaos and incipient civil war, the Congo now prepares to celebrate the first anniversary of its independence Friday in a spirit of reconciliation which, if put into practice, would open up new and bright prospects for central Africa.
A dog may be man's best friend but warm summer weather is no friend to the dog. It is during this season, when people are outdoors, that dog bites are a serious problem.
SUDBURY, Ont., June 27 (UPI) -- Branch Rickey, one of baseball's most imaginative pioneers, suffered a heart attack today at his fishing camp ninety-five miles southwest of here.

With a vigor befitting a younger man, Guy Bolton, who is 76 years old, is unremitting in his efforts as an author. Mr. Bolton, whose accomplishments cover more than two columns in Who's Who in the Theatre Since he became a playwright in 1911, is at work on two more entries.
LONDON, June 27 -- Eight Government appointments, moving up young ministers in the ten-year-old Conservative regime, were announced today, by Prime Minister Macmillan.
ALBANY, June 27 (AP) -- Work-relief projects for persons receiving welfare payments have been virtually halted in New York State for at least fourteen months.

WESTBURY, L.I., June 27 -- Ranking high on the Roosevelt Raceway calendar of important events is the $50,000 American Trotting Championship next Monday. At stake in the mile-and-a-quarter race, besides money and prestige, will be the lone spot reserved for an American horse against the best European trotters in the Roosevelt International Trot July 14.
An independent Norwegian line accused the Grace Line yesterday of using "fighting ships" in an attempt to drive it out of the United States-Venezuelan trade.

Thermo-electricity -- a three-headed genie -- has begun to develop into a force that may alter life for housewives, speed space achievements and make military and industrial operations more efficient. It promises a revolution in electric generation, heating and cooling.
KEY WEST, Fla., June 27 (AP) -- Premier Fidel Castro's prisoner-representatives conferred with an official of the Tractors for Freedom Committee for nearly four hours tonight.
PITTSBURGH, June 27 (AP) -- The Los Angeles Dodgers and the Pirates made thirty hits tonight, with the Dodgers winning the free-swinging contest, 9 -- 5.
HONG KONG, June 27 -- Communist China has instituted a new discussion group plan in an apparent attempt to bolster the regime.
WASHINGTON, June 27 -- The United States made new efforts today to break through the stalled Laos negotiations in Geneva.
VERSAILLES, France, June 27 -- More than 200 French and foreign debutantes were presented to society tonight at a glittering ball held in the Empire Salons of the Versailles Palace.

CLEVELAND, June 27 (AP) -- Gene Green drove in five runs with two homers and a single tonight and led Washington to an 8-5 triumph over the Cleveland Indians. The victory snapped a ten-game losing streak for the Senators.

LONDON, June 27 -- Britain has informed Premier Kassim of the British view that Kuwait is an independent state and that any threat to the sheikdom's sovereignty would be a matter of grave concern here.

The Metropolitan Opera Company has extended its deadline in its negotiations with major performers' unions concerning its forthcoming season. The company had announced previously that Friday was to be the date by which agreements were to be reached if the 1961-62 season was to take place.
How far may military officers legitimately go in publicly expounding a particular doctrine of "positive Americanism"?
Social Security, a controversial subject at most annual meetings of the American Medical Association since the Nineteen Thirties, appears this year to pose unusual difficulties.

WASHINGTON, June 27 (UPI) -- A coalition of Republicans and Southern Democrats in the Senate Agriculture Committee forced today committee rejection of the key production- control section of the Administration's omnibus farm bill.
WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., June 27 -- The intercity golf matches for the Mrs. Frank Enos Cup will be played tomorrow at the Ridgeway Country Club.
An experimental system of cancer therapy involving every weapon available to modern medicine was demonstrated at the American Medical Association meeting here yesterday.

SAN JUAN, P.R., June 27 -- A Dominican plea that exiles return home in exchange for steps leading to free elections has further split the already divided exile groups here and in New York, Mexico and Venezuela.
Two Long Island families complained yesterday that dive-bombing redwing blackbirds appeared to be trying to maroon them in their homes.

All licensed racing drivers of the Sports Car Club of America are facing indefinite suspension by the Federation Internationale de l'Automobile (F.I.A.). As of a week from today, unless the 12,000-member S.C.C.A. has found a method for working in harmony with other major organizations in United States auto competition, S.C.C.A. drivers will be denied entry in all F.I.A.-accredited international events.
MEMPHIS, Tenn., June 26 (AP) -- The Mississippi River's last Texas-deck sternwheeler will be offered for sale next month to the highest bidder.

UNITY HOUSE, Pa., June 27 -- The American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations decided today to urge its Virginia state affiliate to modify arrangements for racial segregation in some phases of its annual convention in Norfolk Aug. 28-30.

WASHINGTON, June 27 (AP) -- The Senate confirmed today President Kennedy's nominations for three judgeships, five United States Attorneys and three marshals. The action was taken shortly after the Judiciary Committee approved them.
In your editorial of June 12, "Better Job Training," you mention the plight of 5 million college and high school students seeking summer jobs.
WASHINGTON, June 27 (AP) -- A Federal grand jury indicted thirteen men today on charges of being involved in a nation-wide track betting system.

WARSAW, June 27 -- A program for Government expropriation of up to 850,000 acres of farm land was announced today. It was the first move toward forced collectivization in Poland since the end of the Stalinist era in 1956.

The fourteenth annual Blue Grass Ball will be held in the Grand Ballroom of the Plaza on Sept. 28 for the benefit of the New York Travelers Aid Society. Mrs. Elizabeth N. Graham is honorary chairman of the fete, which will again be slensored by Elizabeth Arden, Inc., of which she is president.
The board of Hiram Walker-Gooderham Worts, Ltd., Canada's second largest distiller, has elected a new president, it was announced yesterday.

GROSSINGER, N.Y., June 27 -- Joseph Carlino, Speaker of the State Assembly, declared tonight that the Newburgh City Council flouted the intent of the Legislature when it ordered a "get tough on relief clients" policy some parts of which be said were in violation of Federal and State social welfare regulations.
WASHINGTON, June 27 -- The Consumer Price Index declined by one-tenth of 1 per cent in May, putting it exactly where it was last November.

A suspended New York City patrolman pleaded guilty yesterday in General Sessions Court to a charge that he had taken part in a burglary last February in which ammunition was stolen by an African nationalistic group known as the First Africa Corps.

LONDON, June 27 -- Each program of the Leningrad State Kirov Ballet in its season at the Royal Opera House, Covent Garden, has been better than the last, and tonight's presentation of "Giselle" was certainly no exception.
Durward Kirby will succeed Arthur Godfrey as host of "Candid Camera" next season.
MELBOURNE, June 27 -- Australia's wool export income dropped 51,000,000 (Australian) ($114,240,000) for the first eleven months of this fiscal year, compared with the level in the 1960 period.

An action to estrain the Collector of Customs from interfering with the importation of a copy of Henry Miller's "Topic of Cancer" was dismissed yesterday. Federal Judge Thomas F. Murphy acted at the request the Government.

A $5,000,000 national campaign for a Civil War Hall of Fame was begun yesterday with the announcement that O. Roy Chalk, New York and Washington transportation executive, had accepted the post of campaign chairman.

If our credulity had not been strained so often and so heavily by American policy toward China in recent years, the report in The New York Times of June 24 about current plans to deal with Communist China and the United Nations would be tossed off as malicious satire.

TOKYO, June 27 (UPI) -- Pone Kingpetch of Thailand successfully defended the world flyweight title for the second time tonight, gaining a split decision over Mitsunori Seki of Japan in a fifteen-round bout.

Joseph T. Sharkey, Democratic leader of Brooklyn, ruled out yesterday any city slate headed by Mayor Wagner that did not have Abe Stark running for Council President and a candidate for Controller "acceptable to Charlie Buckley."

WASHINGTON, June 27 -- Gov. Luis Munoz Marin of Puerto Rico said today that the answer to the Cuban problem was to "put as much strength and speed as possible behind the Alliance for Progress in Latin America."

(UPI) -- Federal District Judge T. Whitfield Davidson today ordered Dallas schools to go ahead with a gradual plan of integration in September and warned all white citizens to accept the ruling peacefully.
WASINGTON, June 27 (AP) -- A Senate Labor subcommittee approved today President Kennedy's bill for the retraining of unemployed workers but struck out one key section.
WASHINGTON, June 27 (UPI) -- The Senate Antitrust subcommittee criticized the drug industry today as a near monopoly that it said extorted extraordinary profits from ailing Americans.

PHILADELPHIA, June 27 -- Quick run-scoring operations by the San Francisco Giants tonight saved Manager Alvin Dark's fingers from further do-it-yourself surgery. They wasted no time carving four tallies off John Buzhardt and kept hacking at his three successors for a 12-5 victory over the Phillies.
The first eight fellowships have been awarded for the 1961-62 academic year in Columbia University's new advanced international reporting program.

ONE of the more attractive innovations of summer television is the decision of the American Broadcasting Company and the Columbia Broadcasting System to give a showing of programs produced by stations in other cities.

The International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (World Bank) said yesterday that it had lent the equivalent of $15,000,000 to the Pakistan Industrial Credit and Investment Corporation, Ltd., to meet foreign exchange requirements of enterprises financed by the corporation.
BOSTON, June 27 (AP) -- The prospect of a heavyweight title defense by Floyd Patterson against Tom McNeeley in Boston appeared brighter today.
JACKSON, Miss., June 27 -- Freedom Ride leaders agreed today in a three-hour conference to continue tests of segregation in Southern transportation terminals.
No price trend was discernible in high-grade debt securities yesterday. Bond dealers continued to mark time in the same market space that was occupied on Monday.

MANHASSET, L.I., June 27 -- Carol Beinbrink of the Southward Ho Golf Club posted a 37, 40 -- 77 for low gross honors in the Women's Long Island Golf Association one-day tournament at the Deepdale G.C. today.
KANSAS CITY, June 27 (AP) -- Marv Throneberry, Jim Gentile and Ron Hansen hit home runs for Baltimore tonight as the Orioles twice downed the Kansas City Athletics, 5 -- 3 and 7 -- 2.
The liquor license of the Carlton House, prominent East Side hotel and gathering place, has been suspended for a week because the hotel served alcohol to a minor.
LONDON, June 27 -- Wildcat strikes are again plaguing Britain's hard-pressd automobile industry.

THE clothes that are worn by some of America's most elegant women at some of their most glittering events, and that cost from $250 to $5,000, are designed by a man who lunches at Schrafft's, dines at Hamburg Heaven and spends his spare time in an auction gallery.
Charley Coe of Oklahoma City, Deane R. Beman of Washington, Jack Nicklaus of Columbus, Ohio, and Robert W. Gardner of Spring Lake, N.J., head the United States Walker-Cup golf team named yesterday.

Mrs. Auguste Redman paid $200 in fines yesterday after changing her plea to guilty yesterday on charges of violating the Multiple Dwelling Law and the Administrative Code at a three-story tenement at 1986 Lexington Avenue.
MINEOLA, L.I., June 27 -- The Nassau County Planning Commission has recommended a 569-acre county airport at Mitchel Air Force Base.
A total of 1,182 persons were hurt in automobile accidents in the city last week, the Police Safety Bureau reported yesterday. This was 173 fewer, than in the comparable period in 1960.
If an Irishman emigrates to Boston, does he increase his chances of getting heart disease later?
WASHINGTON, June 27 (AP) -- A milkman from Syracuse, N.Y., today received a gold medal for heroism from Secretary of Commerce Luther H. Hodges.

The Certain-teed Products Corporation has filed a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission covering a proposed offering to stockholders of 127,632 additional common shares. The subscription basis would be one new share for every fifteen shares held.

WASHINGTON, June 27 (AP) -- The Navy explained today why its contractors made money buying parts and reselling them to the Government. It is "because we are buying more than hardware, we are buying service," a high official said.

WASHINGTON, June 27 -- The Senate Aeronautical and Space Sciences Committee unanimously approved today President Kennedy's proposal to speed the nation's space program in an attempt to beat the Soviet Union with a manned expedition to the moon.

CHICAGO, June 27 (UPI) -- The American Red Cross said today that a jeering crowd of white persons had forced the removal of eighty Negro fire refugees from a Chicago church that had offered them shelter.
Representative Samuel S. Stratton, Democrat of Schenectady, and Lieut. Gov. Malcolm Wilson have helped win a $200, 000 industrial contract for a depressed area upstate, Mr. Stratton said yesterday.

Stockpiling of worsted cloth by the armed services was proposed yesterday by Ely Callaway Jr., president of the Pacific Mills division, Burlington Industries, Inc., leading producer of the cloth. Worsted is used for combat and service uniforms.

NAIROBI, Kenya, June 27 -- An African elected member of the Legislative Council criticized today the Kenya Government's refusal to give passports to African students awarded scholarships to attend colleges behind the Iron Curtain.

A move by Dr. Robert Soblen to gain access to files of the Federal Bureau of Investigation and grand jury minutes is being fought by the Government as "extremely detrimental to the enforcement of espionage laws."
DETROIT, June 27 -- The United Automobile Workers has succeeded in establishing a precedent for investing pension funds in low-cost housing for members of the union.
BERLIN, June 27 -- Walter Ulbricht has served notice that East Germany wants to sit in on East-West talks about Berlin and future Allied rights in the city.
WASHINGTON, June 27 -- Mayor Wagner will have to fight his primary battle in New York without any help -- or at least any overt help -- from Democratic leaders in Washington.
SALISBURY, Southern Rhodesia, June 27 -- African political leaders angrily rejected today Britain's constitutional proposals for Northern Rhodesia.
The music of George Gershwin will figure heavily for a second time this season at Lewisohn Stadium, when an abridged version of his "Porgy and Bess" is presented on Saturday evening, July 15.

A white-haired patrolman watched a tugboat churn past, then pulled his foot from the sea-wall railing on Welfare Island. He turned toward the neglected clapboard house where the Blackwell family once lived.
GENEVA, June 27 -- David A. Morse, Director General of the International Labor Organization, said today that international civil servants should be objective rather than neutral.

ACCRA, Ghana, June 27 -- Fifty Ghanaian amateur actors will fly to the Soviet Union Saturday for an extensive tour of the Soviet Union with "Obadzeng," the first all-Ghanaian produced and acted musical. They are going in advance of President Kwame Nkrumah, who will pay a state visit to the Soviet.

The New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad may have piled up record losses in recent years, but in one endeavor it makes money where no other major railroad can. That is, in wining and dining its passengers.
WASHINGTON, June 27 -- The maritime industry today publicly criticized President Kennedy's plan for reorganizing the Federal Maritime Board.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), June 27 -- A new clue to a nineteen-year-old mystery -- the fate of the missing children of Lidice -- was offered today at the trial of Adolf Eichmann.
UNITY HOUSE, Pa., June 27 -- Labor's high command called on Congress today to give President Kennedy "full emergency power" to mobilize the nation's resources in any world crisis.
WASHINGTON, June 27 -- Senate and House conferees produced a $4,900,000,000 compromise housing bill today that gave President Kennedy almost all he had requested, plus some extras.
THE usual large New York delegation will go this week-end to the Sacandaga Championships, a tournament held over the Fourth of July each year at the Adirondack Inn at Sacandaga Park, N.Y.

UNITY HOUSE, Pa., June 27 -- Striking ship unions plan to rely heavily on the argument of two old enemies of the Taft-Hartley Act in a court fight to prevent the Kennedy Administration from utilizing the law's national emergency injunction provisions to halt the maritime tie-up.
ATLANTIC CITY, June 27 -- Ideological attacks on the nation's public schools have increased sharply this year, the National Education Association was told today.
LONDON, June 27 -- Prime Minister Macmillan raised today the possibility of negotiations with the Soviet Union on Berlin.

LAST summer when I was in Kenya and Tanganyika I was fortunate enough to meet several of the picturesque pioneers and rugged individualists who have long made their homes on the East African frontier.

TORONTO, June 27 (Canadian Press) -- There are encouraging signs that the pace of inflation in Brazil is slackening, Henry Borden, president of Brazilian Traction, Light and Power Company, Ltd., said today at the company's annual meeting.

HONOLULU, June 27 -- Vice President Johnson told the fifty-third annual conference of Governors tonight that the Soviet Union was engaged in a deliberate and powerful campaign to test the American strength of will.

John A. Kingston has been elected assistant vice president of James Talcott, Inc., industrial finance company, here. He had headed the commercial finance division of Commercial Factors Corporation, a subsidiary of CIT Financial Corporation.
The drug council of the American Medical Association endorsed yesterday the use of the Sabin oral vaccine against poliomyelitis.
WASHINGTON, June 27 -- The Russians, not for the first time, are forcing the allies to take decisions that should have been taken long ago without Soviet pressure.

WASHINGTON, June 27 -- William L. Cary, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, said today he was worried by an invasion of Wall Street by inexperienced, freewheeling brokers and salesmen.
GENEVA, June 27 -- Gen. Phoumi Nosavan will leave here tomorrow for talks in Washington.
Mayor Wagner indicated yesterday that the basis of the city's urban renewal program henceforth would be middle-income housing.

CHICAGO, June 27 (AP) -- The head of the National Waterways Conference declared today that the imposition of tolls on rivers and canals "would drive a lot of transportation" off the inland water lanes.

A bitter controversy between Lewis S. Rosenstiel, president and chairman of Schenley Industries, Inc., and his daughter, Mrs. Louise S. Frank, over the administration of a $15,000,000 foundation came to light yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 28 (AP) -- Over the objection of truckers, the Interstate Commerce Commission approved today two important forms of "piggyback" railroad freight service. The I.C.C. decision was greeted with enthusiastic approval by freight shippers.
PARIS, June 28 -- The European stock markets in general have sustained a decline even worse than that of Wall Street in the last three weeks.

IN the three-sided struggle for power in Laos, the "strong man" in the Western corner is Maj. Gen. Phoumi Nosavan, Deputy Premier and Minister of Defense in Premier Boun Oum's Cabinet. But Gen. Phoumi Nosavan will probably never be known as a hard-driving seeker of power.

The Allied Chemical Corporation and the Georgia-Pacific Corporation have announced that they are studying the possibility of developing commercial production of chemicals from wood. The studies involve processes, patented by Georgia-Pacific, for making chemicals from bark, sawdust and other waste materials of wood-processing operations.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 28 -A plan to build the largest atomic plant in the country was announced today by the Pacific Gas and Electric Company, one of the nation's biggest investor-owned gas and electric concerns.
PHILADELPHIA, June 28 (UPI) -- Perfect Photo, Inc., announced today it had bought five West Coast photo processing companies whose sales volume is $6,000,000 a year.
VERSAILLES, France, June 28 (AP) -- A French relay team reached its announced goal today and lowered the world record for 6,000 meters (about four miles) with a time of 15 minutes 4.2 seconds.
WASHINGTON, June 28 (UPI) -- A railroad economist today called for "resolute and timely action on a combination of fronts" to arrest the decline of the railroads.

HELSINKI, Finland, June 28 -- The Helsinki District Court ordered the dismissal today of all sixteen members of the board of directors of the National Pensions Institute, including Premier Vieno Sukselainen.
MOSCOW, June 28 -- The Soviet Union displayed today what appeared to be a new supersonic, delta-wing bomber, capable of undertaking intercontinental missions.
Mrs. William L. Hutton has accepted chairmanship of the annual Fan Ball, which will be held at the Plaza on Oct. 19 for the benefit of the Boys Club of New York.
WASHINGTON, June 28 -- President Kennedy brushed aside today former Vice President Richard M. Nixon's criticism of his Administration.
WASHINGTON, June 28 -One of President Kennedy's advisers on national strategy, Walt W. Rostow, said today that the nations of the world must resolve to cope with Communist guerrilla warfare.

Barring a negotiated settlement of the Algerian conflict, President de Gaulle intends to concentrate the European settlers and pro-French Moslems around the main coastal cities of Algiers, Constantine, Bone and Oran and cut that fertile agricultural strip off from the enormous but arid hinterland. No doubt the Saharan oil region would also be kept by France.
Allegheny Airlines, Inc., is planning to make a substantial investment in the National Car Rental Company, Inc., of St. Louis, with which it has been noegotiating for several weeks.

CHICAGO, June 28 (AP) -The Chicago Cubs swept a double-header from league-leading Cincinnati by scores of 16-5 and 7-2 today. The victors exploded for twelve extra-base hits -- five of them homers -- in collecting twenty-five hits during the two games at Wrigley Field.
SALISBURY, Southern Rhodesia, June 28 -- The two major African political parties in the Rhodesias have formed an alliance to oppose constitutional changes proposed by Britain for the two territories.

WASHINGTON, June 28 (UPI -- About 3,700,000 Social Security beneficiaries today were all but assured bigger checks in the first week of September when Senate-House negotiators agreed on a compromise bill.

The unions on strike are the National Maritime Union, 37,000 members; the Seafarers International Union, Atlantic, Gulf and Lakes section, 22,000; the Marine Engineers Beneficial Association, 11,000; the Masters, Mates and Pilots, 11,000, and the American Radio Association.

WHILE most of their neighbors barbecue on hibachis or conventional charcoal grills, Mr. and Mrs. William Frank more often than not use a smoke oven built into the wall of their guest house. Mr. Frank, who designed the stove, is a retired engineer; his wife is a producer for the Broadway stage.

The Tennessee Valley Authority borrowed $50,000,000 in the capital market yesterday at a net interest cost of 4.681 per cent. The money was raised through the sale at competitive sealed bidding of twenty-fiveyear bonds.

BOSTON, June 28 -- A proposal to merge Laboratory for Electronics, Inc., and Tracerlab, Inc., was authorized today by directors of the two companies. The stockholders will vote on the proposal at a date to be set later.

HONOLULU, June 28 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner of New Jersey indicated today that he favored a jet airport in the northern part of the state and said: "It's my understanding Morris County offers the best flight conditions."
LONDON, June 28 -- The Government confirmed today that a number of British missionaries had been ordered to leave northern Angola and that Portuguese authorities had declined to rescind the order.
LONDON, June 28 -- Prime Minister Macmillan will postpone a visit to the Far East this autumn because of the Berlin crisis and other major problems, qualified sources disclosed today.
TUNIS, June 28 -- The French-Algerian peace talks are expected to reopen early next month, following discreet contacts that have taken place in Geneva between representatives of both sides.

OFF Broadway proved again last night that Broadway does not have a monopoly on banality. It demonstrated this with two negligible, conversation pieces that were presented at the New Playwrights Theatre, located in the back room of a former saloon at West Third and Thompson Streets.

OCEANPORT, N.J., June 28 (AP) -- Wheatley Stable's Batter Up avenged the only defeat of her career by beating Meadow Stable's Cicada by a length today in the $24,350 Colleen Stakes for 2-year-old fillies at Monmouth Park.
WASHINGTON, June 28 (AP) -- A Chrysler Corporation spokesman told Congress today the General Motors Corporation financing subsidiary had a beneficial effect in the automobile credit field.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 28 -- George Seaton, the writer-director-producer, has returned from Europe to find that he has been selected to handle a job that can cause him more headaches than any of his many movies.
CHICAGO, June 28 (AP) -The grain futures market moved irregularly higher today on increased demand prompted mainly by unfavorable weather and crop news.

PHILADELPHIA, June 29 -Bona fide pennant contenders habitually stomp on lower forms of baseball life in their climb toward the top of the heap. By that criterion, the third-place San Francisco Giants deserved something less than a scintilla of respect off their fruitless performance at Connie Mack Stadium last night and early this morning.

A prominent French shipping official has been named chief executive of the French Line. Gustave Anduze-Faris is taking over the post of chairman of the board from Jean Marie the company announced yesterday.

Production of electric power declined in the week ended last Saturday to 14,870,000,000 kilowatt hours from 15, 345,000,000 the week before, the Edison Electric Institute reported yesterday. A year ago the figure was 14,604,000,000 kilowatt hours.
WASHINGTON, June 28 (AP) -- President Kennedy put it up to Premier Fidel Castro of Cuba today to rescue the tractors-for-prisioners exchange.
WASHINGTON, June 28 -President Kennedy challenged the Soviet Union today to accept the principle of "self-determination" in Berlin -- "and indeed in Europe."

WASHINGTON, June 28 -President Kennedy looked a little puffy today at his news conference -- his first in seven weeks after his recent illness -but he was elaborately calm about Berlin and even a little saucy.

Resting market orders, short covering and new commission house buying of copper futures touched off stop-loss purchasing yesterday on the Commodity Exchange of New York. Trading reflected news of continued unrest in the Congo.

There are some important points on the school-aid question that should be discussed. For example, the statement in your June 17 editorial that "aid to public schools for construction and teachers' salaries is a matter of first priority" is not backed by statistical proof that local and state aid is insufficient.

A school employe angrily accused the State Investigation Commission yesterday afternoon of "Gestapo tactics" a few hours after he had been suspended for allegedly shaking down contractors. In a fifteen-minute outburst Mario V. Ammirati called the commission's assistant counsel a "bum" and shouted obscenities at the chief investigator.
NEWARK, N.J., June 28 -The president of the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) called tonight for a "working partnership" between business, labor and government to meet the demands of the cold war.
PARIS, June 28 (Reuters) -Renewed peasant demonstrations flared today as French farmers blocked holiday routes to Spanish coastal resorts and barricaded the channel port of Calais.
DETROIT, June 28 (AP) -The first-place Detroit Tigers snapped the Chicago White Sox twelve-game winning streak today, pounding out sixteen hits in gaining a 12-5 victory.
WASHINGTON, June 28 -- Following are the highlights of President Kennedy's news conference today:

Members of the Merchants Ladies' Garment Association and the Industrial Council of Cloak, Suit and Skirt Manufacturers, Inc., have voted to merge. In announcing the action yesterday, Joseph L. Dubow, executive director of the Merchants, said that the resulting organization would have a combined membership of 400 manufacturers with a wholesale volume of more than $1,000,000,000 a year.
WASHINGTON, June 28 -Scientists have developed plans to place a fully equipped "camp" on the moon to greet the first man there, David Sarnoff said today.

FRANK SLOCUM, the trusty aide-de-camp of Commissioner Ford Frick, is on the prowl. He is flitting from clubhouse to clubhouse in both major leagues as a one-man Board of Elections, collecting ballots from the big leaguers as they vote on the starting line-ups for the All-Star game at San Francisco on July 11.
ATLANTA, June 28 (UPI) -The Georgia Attorney General today rejected a proposal for a law to help white students transfer away from integrated schools because it might lead to massive integration.
WASHINGTON, June 28 -Former President Dwight D. Eisenhower's strong opposition to the Kennedy Administration's public-education bill was made public today.
PITTSBURGH, June 28 (UPI) -- Joe Gibbon went the distance for the Pittsburgh Pirates tonight, scattering six hits for a 9-3 victory over the Los Angeles Dodgers.
"Continental Classroom" will teach American Government when it starts its fourth year on the National Broadcasting Company television network on Sept. 25.

THE greatest complaint of average bridge player is that he has trouble remembering what cards have been played. He would rather have a bridge teacher give him a rule for remembering than tell him how to bid.

ST. LOUIS, June 28 (UPI) -A rookie left-hander, Bobby Hendley, with eighth-inning relief help from Don McMahon, scored his first major league victory as the Milwaukee Braves defeated the St. Louis Cardinals, 8 -- 3, tonight.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), June 28 -- Adolf Eichmann explained today how he had introduced Nazi "know-how and efficiency" to the forced emigration of Jews.
MUSIC lost a loud battle to Fourth-of-July fireworks last night at Lewisohn Stadium.
METZ, France, June 28 (Reuters) -- Jacques Anquetil of France, who has been in front since the first day, retained the lead in the over-all classification of the Tour de France cycling classic today.

A MOTHER who recently took her 8-year-old daughter to the United Nations for the first time reports that although the child was duly fascinated by the earphones, conference rooms and other accoutrements of diplomacy, she was most impressed by the Meditation Room.

The question of what merchant ships would go into the North Atlantic Treaty Organization pool in case of war has been raised in an exchange between two shipping officials on "flag of convenience" fleets.
WESTBURY, L.I., June 28 -- Holding off Garnet Queen's stretch challenge, Demon Damsel won by a neck in the Miss Universe Handicap Trot before 20,339 fans at Roosevelt Raceway tonight.
Mayor Wagner ordered city agencies yesterday to mobilize their resources to prevent outbreaks of summer violence.
The Chase Manhattan Bank and the Hempstead Bank, Hempstead, L.I., announced yesterday that they planned to merge.
PARAMUS, N.J., June 28 -- Martin Issler of Essex County wont the metropolitan seniors' championship today with a 39, 36 -- 75 at the Arcola Country Club.

Senator Mansfield is magnificently right in asserting that mere firmness in defending the status quo in Berlin is not enough, even though his proposal to make all of Berlin into a free city brings up unhappy memories of Danzig and would not in any case solve the problem.
ATLANTIC CITY, June 28 -- Too much emphasis on the "right" way of getting the "right" answer can stifle a child's creative thinking about mathematics, a specialist in the subject declared here today.

The International Cooperation Administration last January asked Teachers College, Columbia University, to select a group of highly qualified Americans to be trained as teachers in East Africa. The stress was to be on careful screening and special training both here and at the center of East African teacher training, Makerere College in Uganda.
The Transit Authority estimated yesterday that it would lose $6,218,385 on its operations in the year beginning next Saturday.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved up 2 to down 10 points yesterday. (A point equals 5 cents a bale.) Only near December showed a gain.
An attempt to break the customary pattern of outdoor jazz concerts was made last night at Downing Stadium on Randalls Island.

LONDON, June 28 -- dispute over the rights to publish The New English Bible arose today when Eyre Spottiswoode, Ltd., the Queen's printers, announced they were issuing a paperback edition of The Gospel of St. John taken from the New Bible.
Dr. Jonas A. Salk disagreed sharply yesterday with an American Medical Association report that the Salk vaccine could not eradicate poliomyelitis in the United States.

A syndicate headed by Ehrlich-Corso, Inc., a New York investment concern, has taken title to the Sun Valley Motor Hotel in Harlingen, Tex. The property, which contains ten and one-half acres, is in the lower Rio Grande Valley about twenty-six miles from the Mexican border.
WASHINGTON, June 28 -The Republicans in Congress opened a battle today against any changes in United States policy toward Communist China.

AROUND town there are a number of small custom establishments that do an excellent job of turning out original designs that are seemingly well made and are reasonably priced for made-to-order fashion.

RIO DE JANERIO, June 28 -- President Janio Quadros signed today a decree empowering the official Government press agency to use privately owned radio and television stations for the transmission of Government programs whenever it would be "in the public interest."
WASHINGTON, June 28 (UPI) -- The Senate Government Operations Committee rejected today two more of President Kennedy's plans to reorganize Federal agencies.
SUDBURY, Ont., June 28 (UPI) -- Branch Rickey, in an oxygen tent after his second heart attack in three years, will be hospitalized for at least three weeks, it was said today.
The Tennessee Gas Transmission Company announced yesterday that two of its subsidiaries had bought a group of oil and gas leases off the coast of Louisiana for $97,000,000.
TWO well-known designers met this week, combined ideas and came out with a creation.

Why do not some of the distinguished independent Democrats of our city do what their predecessors certainly would have -- build a fusion movement around the Republican ticket? The only New York fusion movements of modern times have been based on Republicans -- Mitchel and LaGuardia.
The American Medical Association's House of Delegates approved yesterday an annual dues increase of $20 over the next two years.
The Liberal party convention endorsed Mayor Wagner for a third term last night by a vote of 378 to 28.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 28 (AP) -- Iraq hinted today that her claim to Kuwait was being extended to take in other oil-bearing regions on the Persian Gulf.
Summer living in the city may get a man heated on occasion, but a magistrate in Lower Manhattan Court issued a stern ruling yesterday: "Keep your shirts on."

WASHINGTON, June 28 -- President Kennedy expressed concern today for the problem of mounting textile imports, but he rejected the American textile industry's proposals for solving it. It is an "extremely complicated" matter, he said at his news conference, and must be approached with an eye to the country's general economic interests and foreign policy considerations.

Two of the major figures in modern jazz have joined forces at the Village Vanguard, where J.J. Johnson, a trombonist whose influence has pervaded jazz for the last fifteen years, is now playing with the Miles Davis Quintet.
ALL the world's a stage, and all the men and women, especially at a wedding, are merely players -- a state of affairs that has been adequately documented in the Bonwit Teller bridal salon.

Congress has wisely acted in great haste to raise the public-debt ceiling. Had the ceiling not been raised by tomorrow midnight the debt would have been higher than its legal limit and the whole world might come to know how meaningless the limit really is.

Harris County, Tex., raised $29,500,000 in the bond market yesterday to finance road and bridge construction, park development and flood control installations. The money was borrowed on four issues of serial bonds that were sold to investment banking syndicates at interest costs ranging from 3.3338 to 3.809 per cent.

WASHINGTON, June 28 (UPI) -- Congressional negotiators agreed today on a six-year, $570,000,000 program of grants to the states to clean up what President Kennedy has called the national disgrace of water pollution.

UNITY HOUSE, Pa., June 28 -- The Kennedy Administration, dissatisfied with the anti-strike remedies available to it under the Taft-Hartley Act, is drawing up a new legislative program for dealing with walkouts that cause national emergencies.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), June 28 -- Israeli officials saw the Jordanian Cabinet shuffle as a device to remove Foreign Minister Musa Nasir.

WASHINGTON, June 28 (AP) -- A Senate report today sternly criticized the Navy and the designers and builders of the radar Texas Tower that collapsed in a storm and carried all twenty-eight men on it to their deaths.

GROSSINGER, N.Y., June 28 -- Local public welfare commissioners from throughout the state decided today to seek new laws in Washington and Albany to permit communities to put able-bodied heads of relief families on public works projects.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., June 28 -- The State Supreme Court refused here today to give a Southampton woman access by land to her converted lighthouse home on Cedar Island. Neighbors have barred her from crossing their property to get to her summer home, as she has done in past years.
Some serious congenital defects defy detection in early infancy, according to a report to the American Medical Association made public here yesterday.

The spotlight today is on packaging. The Container Corporation of America, which has prospered in the lively art of walling in a multitude of products with a multitude of wrappings, has opened a museum in Chicago devoted to the subject.

WASHINGTON, June 28 -The Federal Reserve Board reported today that the condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended June 21, 1961.

THE American Stock Exchange announced yesterday that officers, directors and large stockholders of listed companies reported last month, pursuant to the Securities and Exchange Act, the following changes in stockholdings:

R.A. Appleman has been named manager of the new traffic department of Esso International Inc., an affiliate of Standard Oil Company (N.J.). He had been general traffic manager of the Esso Standard region of Humble Oil Refining Company, Jersey Standard's principal domestic affiliate.

A $102,165,000 development program to broaden and advance medical and social services throughout the metropolitan area will be started in September by the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies of New York.
BLOOMINGTON, Minn., June 28 (AP) -- The Boston Red Sox made the most of four hits tonight and defeated the Minnesota Twins, 6 -- 2.

WASHINGTON, June 28 (AP) -- Jerome K. Kuykendall has agreed to step down Sept. 1 from the chairmanship of the Federal Power Commission and allow Joseph P. Swidler, President Kennedy's choice for the post, to take over. Mr. Kuykendall will remain as a member of the five-man commission.
PURCHASE, N.Y., June 28 -Tommy Goodwin and Harold (Pete) Williams of the Westchester Country Club had a best-ball score of 69 to win the British Victory golf tournament today.
A dean's desire to return to teaching has led to two appointments, made public yesterday by Columbia University.
Secretary of Commerce Luther Hodges says (June 19) that the country's growth rate must rise or we will continue to have unemployment.

WASHINGTON, June 28 (AP) -- Representative John B. Bennett, Republican of Michigan, said today he would ask President Kennedy to stem a flow of iron ore imports, "which is having a ruinous effect" on the Northern Michigan iron mining industry.
The Metropolitan Museum of Art and the Brooklyn Museum will be open seven days a week again beginning Monday. The seven-day service was interrupted for two years because of a shortage of guards.
Record travel on highways in the metropolitan area is expected over the Fourth of July holiday week-end, which for many employes will be four days long.
WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., June 28 -- Mrs. Bernard Freeman of Inwood and Mrs. Murray Gordon of Harbor Hills won the John B. Mackie Memorial Scotch-foursome golf tournament today.
BOSTON, June 28 (AP) -- Eddie Arcaro rode Polylad to a photo-finish victory over Our Hope today in the twenty-seventh running of the $57,700 Massachusetts Handicap.
Highway bottlenecks caused by construction will be at a temporary low point for the Fourth of July holiday. Motorists can avoid most of these places without trouble.

In a television drama sponsored by the Chrysler Corporation, the name of President Lincoln was deleted because Lincoln is also the name of an automobile made by a competitor of the advertiser, a producer testified yesterday.

LOS ANGELES, June 28 -The Yankees' second transcontinental tour of the year ended in a 5-3 defeat tonight. Ryne Duren, their one-time fireballing relief ace, wreaked awesome vengeance on his former playmates.
WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., June 28 -- For the third year in a row, Boston won the intercity girls' junior golf matches at the Ridgeway Country Club today.
LONDON, June 28 -- Proposals to create a cooperative European space agency were criticized here today by a director of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration as insufficiently ambitious.
CHICAGO, June 28 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

YONKERS, June 28 -- The Metropolitan Regional Council decided at a fifth anniversary meeting here today that it had been crawling experimentally long enough without a budget, professional staff and official status.

WASHINGTON, June 28 (AP) A Senate subcommittee's report on drug prices was described by the president of the Pharmaceutical Manufacturers Association today as an "unjusitfied attack" on the drug industry.

LONDON, June 28 -- Industrial shares closed irregular on the stock market here today with the bulk of the blue chips improving a little. Most net changes, on balance, were less than 1 shilling (14 cents).

WASHINGTON, June 28 (UPI) -- The Senate today passed by voice vote and rushed to President Kennedy's desk a bill temporarily raising the national debt ceiling another $5,000,000,000 to a peacetime high of $298,000,000,000.

PARIS, June 28 -- President de Gaulle, speaking in Verdun, scene of one of the greatest battles of all time, told Frenchmen today their best chance for avoiding a new storm of war was to remain united among themselves and with their allies.
BERLIN, June 28 -- East Germany announced today it would impose restrictions on foreign air traffic across its territory, beginning Aug. 1.
WASHINGTON, June 28 -The House of Representatives approved today the President's $43,000,000,000 defense budget, but Republicans criticized him for having a general on his staff.
PARIS, June 28 -- The Government announced tonight that it world meet tomorrow with disgruntled farm leaders to seek solutions to the nation's agricultural problems.

WASHINGTON, June 28 (AP) -- The association that includes 4,600 of the nation's 5,400 brokerdealer concerns endorsed today a proposed Government inquiry into stock-market policing. It also suggested ways of expanding the study.

The Pennsylvania Railroad, the biggest in the nation, operated last month at a net loss of $2,324,400. This raised to $18,301,117 the carrier's deficit for the first five months this year. It was one of the worst showings for the period in the company's 114-year history.
KANSAS CITY, June 28 (UPI) -- Fine relief pitching by Wes Stock and a three-run home run by Earl Robinson gave the Baltimore Orioles a 5 -- 4 victory over the Kansas City Athletics tonight.

A Britisher's perspective on the American Civil War, told in 192 pages, will be published Doubleday on Aug. 4. The volume, called "The Civil War America," is by Alan Barker, headmaster of The Leys School, a school for boys in Cambridge, England.

LONDON, June 28 -- Members of the European Free Trade Association agreed today to "coordinate their actions and to remain united" throughout any negotiations they might have for membership in or close association with the Common Market.
Henry R. Luce, editor in chief of Life magazine, announced yesterday the appointment of Edward K. Thompson to the new post of editor.

TEHERAN, Iran, June 28 (Reuters) -- The security police arrested Ahmad Aramesh, former minister of state and head of Iran's Seven-Year Plan Organization, tonight for "acting against the security of the state." Mr. Aramesh also was accused of "creating confusion and unrest among the public by insidious propaganda."
WASHINGTON, June 28 -Congress approved the long-range compromise housing bill today and sent it to the White House.

If about one-third of a person's assets are in stocks, that is about average, it would seem. Americans owned $959,000,000,000 in financial assets at the start of 1961 some $200,000,000,000 more than in 1957, according to the National Industrial Conference Board.
HONOLULU, June 28 -- The Governors Conference approved today a resolution asking Federal aid for school construction and loans for the construction and improvement of higher education facilities.

The American Medical Association considered Las Vegas, Nev., yesterday as a site for a 1963 session, then quickly decided that the city of baccarat and blackjack was fine for carnival but not for clinical activities.

UNITY HOUSE, Pa., June 28 -- President Kennedy told labor's high command today that the country had "emerged" from the recession. His declaration drew an immediate denial from the people to whom it was addressed -- the Executive Council of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations.

The Broadway producing firm of Charles Bowden and Ridgely Bullock has been dissolved. They were to have put on Tennessee Williams' drama, "The Night of the Iguana," in which Bette Davis will have one of the starring roles.
LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, June 28 -- The opening of the Congolese Parliament is expected to be delayed a week or more.
WASHINGTON, June 28 -- President Kennedy defended his staffing of Latin-American affairs today with the observation that ferment and controversy were better than orderly stagnation.
TRENTON, June 28 -- New Jersey plans to subsidize and improve bus transportation as well as rail lines linking the state with New York, it was learned today.
The National Aeronautics and Space Administration announced yesterday an urgent need for scientists and engineers for Project Apollo and other space programs.

Wellington Fund reported yesterday that its $15.53-a-share net asset value on May 31, end of the fiscal half-year, was the highest month-end figure (adjusted for 100 per cent stock distribution in 1956) in the fund's history.
CONFUSION is mounting in culinary quarters over the merits of non-stick cookware.

Schenley Industries, Inc., reported yesterday a 63 per cent increase in income in the nine months ended on May 31. Lewis S. Rosensteil, chairman and president, also announced the election of Milo B. Hopkins as a director.
The Civil Aeronautics Board has denied Seaboard World Airlines the right to provide special low-fare seats in the rear of its cargo planes without a formal C.A.B. application proceeding.
Increases in sales and earnings were reported by the General Tire and Rubber Company in the semi-annual statement issued yesterday by Thomas F. O'Neil, chairman, and M.G. O'Neil, president.
The Board of Education approved $14,000,000 in salary increases yesterday for 47,022 teachers and supervisory employes.

LONDON, June 28 -- The British Labor party presented to the electorate today a program for the nation's internal progress that carried the moderate stamp of the leadership of Hugh Gaitskell, head of the party.

The Electric Bond and Share Company increased its net asset value by 11 per cent to $185,365,053, equal to $35.31 a share, in the year ended on June 16, George G. Walker, president, reported at the annual meeting yesterday.
LONDON, June 28 -- London's largest art sale of the season saw 169 impressionist and modern drawings, paintings and sculptures sold today at Sotheby's galleries for a total of 757,700 ($2,121,560).
Oil refining operations declined sharply last week as the shipping strike began to affect operations of coastal refineries.

The Kaman Aircraft Corporation announced yesterday that a letter of intent to acquire a fleet of five Westland Hotodynes for operation on Caribbean routes had been signed by a Puerto Rican-based company, Indies Air, Inc.

To millions of dog owners the American Kennel Club is an address -- 221 Park Avenue South, New York 3, N.Y. It is there one sends $2 to register a purebred pup just purchased. According to its recent annual report, the A.K.C. registered 442,852 dogs in 1960.

SPRINGFIELD, N.J., June 28 -- A field of eighty-six golfers faces a formidable test as the women's United States Open golf championship starts here tomorrow. The site is the lower course of the Baltusrol Golf Club.

WASHINGTON, June 28 (UPI) -- Maj. Gen. Phoumi Nosavan of Laos arrived in Washington tonight for talks with President Kennedy and other officials on a coalition government for the Communist-threatened Southeast Asian nation.

Visitors to the New York World's Fair in 1964 and 1965 will be transported around its 650 acres on electric motorized chairs twice the size of the familiar Atlantic City boardwalk variety and driven by chauffeur-guides.

KEY WEST, Fla., June 28 (AP) -- A delegation of ten anti-Castro prisoners awaited developments today on the fate of negotiations to free invasion prisoners in Cuba despite an announcement by President Kennedy that the next move was up to Premier Castro of Cuba.
The Presidential fact-finding board in the nation-wide maritime strike strove last night to find a settlement and avoid the Taft-Hartley injunction process.
WASHINGTON, June 28 -Premier Khrushchev's expectation of outproducing the United States by 1970 is a welcome challenge but is less than twothirds right, President Kennedy said today.
KIAMESHA LAKE, N.Y., June 28 (AP) -- Brith Abraham, Jewish fraternal order, re-elected Maurice Goldstein of Brooklyn today to a third term as grand master. Its leaders normally serve only two terms.

LONDON, June 28 -- Details of a proposed Constitution for the West Indies Federation designed to give the Caribbean territories "an effective and constructive role in international affairs" were made public today.
ST. PAUL, Minn., June 28 -- A Federal grand jury indicted four leading salt companies today on charges of fixing prices of rock salt.

A broad renewal of demand for high-grade corporate bonds in over-the-counter trading yesterday carried this important segment of the bond market out of the price impasse in which it had been stuck since Monday.
Frank Costello was released from the workhouse on Rikers Island yesterday morning, having completed a thirty-day sentence for contempt of court.
Two strains of infectious hepatitis virus were reported yesterday to have been isolated and photographed.
WASHINGTON, June 28 (AP) -- Congress received today a bill designed to test the rights of Congressional committees in investigations involving conflicts between Federal and state governments.
Former Vice President Richard M. Nixon will write a book about his experiences in public life.

NEW ORLEANS, June 28 (AP) -- A ship collision on the Mississippi River that resulted in the death of ten persons last October was caused by the failure of both vessels to navigate with caution, a Coast Guard official said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 28 -- President Kennedy and his Secretary of Agriculture expressed differing views today on whether the Food for Peace program is an instrument of the nation's over-all foreign policy.

CLEVELAND, June 28 (AP) -- Bennie Daniels held the Cleveland Indians to five hits in pitching the Washington Senators to a 5-2 victory in the second game of a twilight-night double header tonight. The Indians won the opener, 3-2, on the six-hit pitching of Jim Perry and Frank Funk.
The city hit back hard yesterday at state charges that it was lax in the supervision of its contracts with two electrical maintenance companies.
AMMAN, Jordan, June 28 (Reuters) -- Four ministers were dropped in a reshuffle of the Jordanian Cabinet tonight.
Federal Judge William B. Herlands yesterday granted most of the Government's requests to withhold parts of grand jury minutes on testimony by Jack Soble, confessed Communist spy.

WASHINGTON, June 28 (AP) -- Packages of Communist propaganda mailed to the United States in 1960 increased 137 per cent over the previous year to a total of 14,170,529, the Senate Internal Security subcommittee has been told.

WIMBLEDON, England, June 28 -- In a day of surprises, the two top-seeded players, Neale Fraser and Rod Laver of Australia, just staved off defeat in furious five-set matches at the all-England tennis championships today.

Cruelty anywhere is the concern of mankind everywhere. The city of Newburgh, N.Y., should not be surprised at finding itself famous overnight for writing its own rules for dispensation of welfare grants to the needy.

WASHINGTON, June 28 -Senator Maurine Neuberger joined two women today in accusing food producers of tricking consumers with packaging techniques.
DETROIT, June 28 -- Walter P. Reuther called on the General Motors Corporation today to lead the way in raising workers' wages and improving job security in the auto industry.

Electronics and many other "glamour" issues trudged steadily uphill in yesterday's lackadaisical session of the New York Stock Exchange. Despite a small sell-off near the close, the session ended with a slight gain.
WASHINGTON, June 28 -The nomination of the first Negro to the governing commission of the District of Columbia was withdrawn tonight by President Kennedy.

Max Hirsch, who has had many "firsts" in his comprehensive career in the thoroughbred world, enjoyed another at Belmont Park yesterday. The 80-year-old trainer sent the King Ranch's Disperse into the first running of the Hempstead Handicap over the distance of a mile and a half, and Disperse won the race.

CALLING your shots and making them is the greatest sport in the world," a character in one of Jerome Weidman's tales muses happily as she tramps her way to success through fields of glittering mendacity.

ELISABETHVILLE, the Congo, June 28 -- President Moise Tshombe of Katanga Province reversed today his decision to end Katanga's secession from the Central Government of the Congo. He said he would keep Katanga independent "at all cost."
LITTLE ROCK, Ark., June 28 (AP) -- Arkansas voters defeated the $60,000,000 state construction bond issue on which Gov. Orval E. Faubus had staked his political prestige.
A massive program of housing, urban renewal and neighborhood conservation was pushed forward yesterday when public hearings were scheduled for July 19 by the City Planning Commission.
WASHINGTON, June 28 -Mr. and Mrs. Richard J. Port of Stoneham, Mass., were selected today as trainees for Peace Corps teaching posts in Ghana. They are the first married couple chosen by the corps.
CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Thursday, June 29 -- A triple header rocket today hurled into orbit three satellites, including the first space package ever to carry an atomic battery.

The Friendly Frost chain of appliance stores has contracted to sell its property on Frost Street, near the Wantagh State Parkway, in Westbury, L.I., to the Wolf Corporation of New York, realty investors.

WASHINGTON, June 28 -- President Kennedy announced today that he had ordered a special committee of scientists to assess whether the Soviet Union could be con ducting secret atomic tests and thus making a significant advance in weapons technology.

In an atmosphere of mounting tension reminiscent of the hectic summers of 1914 and 1939 -yet radically altered by the atomic bomb -- President Kennedy and Premier Khrushchev have strongly reaffirmed their opposite positions on Germany and Berlin; but both have left the door open to further negotiations.
The city was embroiled in a pigeon-trapping war yesterday and friends and enemies of the pigeons were rapidly joining the issue.
WASHINGTON, June 28 (AP) -- The Kennedy Administration urged today retention of the present winner-take-all system of allotting a state's Presidential electoral votes.

Boudinot Atterbury has contracted to buy the five-story town house at 121 East Seventy-first Street from Fred H. Hill. The buyer plans to remodel the building into doctors' offices and two duplex apartments.

PARIS, June 28 -- Kracovie, the fastest trotting mare in France and the 1961 European circuit champion, took off early this morning for Roosevelt Raceway, Westbury, L.I., where she will race in the $50,000 International Trot on July 14.

TRENTON, June 28 -- Before Governor Meyner made his statement, a report was published in New Jersey that the Governor was supporting a jetport in Morris County. This report was denied by the Governor's office here.

HONOLULU, June 28 -- The Governors in the four states served by the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad appealed to President Kennedy today for an additional Federal loan to keep the line out of bankruptcy.
MOSCOW, June 28 -- Premier Khrushchev declared today the Soviet Union was ready to start negotiations looking "honestly and frankly" to an agreement and the signing of a peace treaty on Germany.
WINNIPEG, June 29 (Canadian Press) Canadian exports of wheat and wheat flour in May totaled 45,890,228 bushels, an increase of 20,839,324 over the same month last year.
WASHINGTON, June 29 -- Lawrence O'Connor, administrator of the Interior Department's oil import program, is expected to be the Kennedy Administration's third nominee to the Federal Power Commission.

Prime fixed-income investments of all classifications were in good demand yesterday, forcing prices up by small fractions. The major exceptions were long-term United States Government bonds of post-war issue, which sagged 2/32 to 6/32.
PARIS, June 29 -- The forty-fifth conference of the International Labor Organization called on South Africa today to withdraw from the United Nations agency because of its racial policy.

The Realty Equities Corporation, Morris Karp, president, has sold the five-story apartment house for fifty-eight families at 1183-87 Grand Concourse, corner of East 168th Street, the Bronx. The property, with a lot 128 by 129 feet, was purchased by investing clients of Louis Shron, lawyer, for cash over mortgages amounting to $300,000.
STAMFORD, Conn., June 29 -- The Board of Education, alarmed because high school students taking the General Course have had difficulty qualifying for jobs, has decided to re-evaluate the program.
Jack Soble, confessed Communist spy, caused such an uproar in Federal Court here yesterday that Judge William B. Herlands nearly took over his cross-examination.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., June 29 -- George Sanders, a 16-year-old junior from Chaminade High playing for International Business Machines, scored a one-over-par 38, 36 -- 74 today to lead the Long Island qualifiers for the Metropolitan Golf Association junior championship at the Cherry Valley Club.
The cotton futures market moved 7 points up to 4 points down on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday. A point equals 5 cents a bale.

WASHINGTON, June 29 -- Following are the texts of two letters on the proposed disarmament agency, one from President Kennedy to the Senate President and the House Speaker, and the other from John J. McCloy, disarmament adviser, to Mr. Kennedy:
Television station WNTA-TV is being sold for $6,200,000 to a group of citizens who plan to open it as New York City's first noncommercial educational station on Jan. 1.

THE deal shown was played by experts in a game earlier this week. At the time there seemed to be nothing outstanding about it, except for East's double of four hearts, which was ill-considered and costly.

LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, June 29 -- Flags flew along Leopoldville's streets today as the Congolese capital prepared for a celebration tomorrow on the first anniversary of the independence of the Congo.
Mayor Wagner announced yesterday that the city could not avoid renewing contracts with two maintenance companies that have come under fire from the State Investigation Commission.
WASHINGTON, June 29 -- A new avenue in the exploration of space and in peaceful applications of the atom on earth was was being pioneered today by the first satellite powered by nuclear energy.
CHICAGO, June 29 (AP) -- The lowly Chicago Cubs wrapped-up their series with first-place Cincinnati today, slamming four homers in a 15-8 rout of the Reds.

WASHINGTON, June 29 (AP) -- The normal tours of overseas duty for bachelor Army officers and enlisted men will be extended from two to three years in Hawaii and eleven European countries starting Aug. 1, the Army announced today.

The United States monetary gold stock rose $24,000,000 in the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. It was the fourth straight increase and compared with a $50,000,000 rise a week earlier.
WASHINGTON, June 29 -- The United States Travel Service, designed to persuade foreigners to spend their holidays and their dollars in this country, was established by law today.

Loans to businesses at the fifteen weekly reporting member banks in New York City rose $72,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, according to figures released yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

In a moribund market in which only the rubber issues showed signs of life, stocks jogged gently downward yesterday. Trading on the New York Stock Exchange fell away to the smallest total since Nov. 17.

GRAND BLANC, Mich., June 29 (AP) -- Joe Campbell, a cigar-smoking towhead, sank a 25-foot shot from a sand trap on the eighteenth hole today and took a one-stroke, first-round lead in the $53,000 Buick open golf tournament.
MOSCOW, June 29 -- The Soviet capital basked under the June sun, and in the summer lassitude there was a feeling of unreality about the talk of war over Berlin.
A tentative agreement was reached early today averting a strike scheduled for midnight on the Green Bus Lines, which carry up to 150,000 passengers a day in Brooklyn and Queens.

WASHINGTON, June 29 -- In commenting yesterday on criticism that the large and growing White House staff of Presidential advisers duplicate and overrule the formulations of policies within the provinces of the executive departments, Mr. Kennedy revealed his belief that "beautiful coordination" in government is desirable only in areas where "there is not much going on, * * * when things are non-controversial."

FOR outdoor cooking, which probably will be one of the most popular activities this Fourth of July week-end, many stores are featuring spareribs. That pork cut is always a great favorite for al fresco cooking despite certain drawbacks it presents.
HELSINKI, Finland, June 29 (Reuters) -- Premier Vieno J. Sukselainen resigned tonight following his conviction by a Helsinki court yesterday in connection with a housing scandal.
BERLIN, June 29 (AP) -- Ingmar Bergman, Swedish filmmaker, and the Japanese film "Ikuru" won the principal Selznick Golden Laurel Awards today.
Dr. J. George Horror was elected president of the Rockefeller Foundation yesterday, succeeding Dean Rusk, who resigned last January to become Secretary of State.
WASHINGTON, June 29 -- President Kennedy and his family looked forward today to a long Fourth of July week-end at their Hyannis Port home on Cape Cod, Mass.
WASHINGTON, June 29 (AP) -- The White House said tonight the Federal Bureau of Investigation was investigating the leaking of defense secrets at the Pentagon.
