WASHINGTON, June 29 -- The House of Representatives today approved a Federal-state compact governing the development of the water resources of the Delaware River Basin.
LONDON, June 29 -- Prices advanced modestly on a wide front in the stock market today.

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), June 29 -- Adolf Eichmann disclaimed responsibility today for one of the cruelest incidents of World War II, the shipping of 4,000 Jewish children from France to the gas chambers of Auschwitz.
WASHINGTON, June 29 -- Attorney General Robert F. Kennedy said today that from now on the public would have a chance to object to proposed antitrust consent decrees before they became final.

WASHINGTON, June 29 -- President Kennedy and the National Security Council discussed today diplomatic, military and civil-defense measures to cope with an expected period of dangerous relations with the Soviet Union over the next six to ten months.
KANSAS CITY, June 29 (AP) -- Baltimore routed Lew Krausse, Kansas City's bonus rookie, tonight and the Orioles went on to defeat the Athletics, 6 -- 2.

NEWBURGH, N.Y., June 29 (AP) -- City Manager Joseph McD. Mitchell of Newburgh said today he and the City Council had "no intention of defying any lawful subpoena" issued by the State Board of Social Welfare to attend a hearing on the Newburgh welfare situation.
Thousands of excited children played hooky from schools here yesterday with the approval of their parents.
WASHINGTON, June 29 -- The Bureau of Labor Statistics reported the following spot primary market prices for the dates shown:

The House Interstate and Foreign Commerce Committee has taken a reasonable approach to the problem of reorganizing and revitalizing the Federal Communications Commission. Although a bill it approved this week would not untie all the administrative knots in which the F.C.C. is entangled, it would make a good beginning.

WASHINGTON, June 29 (AP) -- The financing subsidiary of the General Motors Corporation gives G.M. life-or-death power over its dealers and an unjustified immunity from the antitrust laws, it was charged today by Truman Arnold, former assistant attorney general.

WASHINGTON, June 29 (UPI) -- The National Association of Manufacturers urged Congress today to overhaul the Electoral College system to "reduce the overwhelming concentration of political power" in the eleven most populous states.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 29 -- As a boy, Jack Warner Jr. used to spend his spare time at the Warner Brothers studio. During a high-school vacation in the early Nineteen Thirties, he worked as fourth or fifth assistant director on such films as "Public Enemy" and "I Was a Fugitive From a Chain Gang."

MONTAUK POINT, L.I., June 29 -- At 4:30 A.M., as one approaches the harbor through the awakening darkness, the lights splashing atop the signs on the Montauk Dock give the area the appearance of a miniature Las Vegas.
WASHINGTON, June 29 -- The Federal Government began efforts today to clean up the heavily polluted water of the Raritan Bay area in New York and New Jersey.
HAVANA, June 29 (AP) -- A Foreign Ministry source said today that President Kennedy's comments on the proposed tractors-for-prisoners exchange seemed to have closed the door to further negotiations.
Two modern apostles will board a forty-three-foot ketch at Glenwood Landing, L.I., on July 8 for the first leg of a 12,000-mile voyage that will end six months later in the Marshall Islands.

WASHINGTON, June 29 -- The pro-Western Royal Laotian delegation headed by Maj. Gen. Phoumi Nosavan conferred with high United States diplomatic and defense officials today. The day-long conferences discussed the neutralist future planned for the Southeast Asian kingdom.

CLEVELAND, June 29 (AP) -- Regal Discount Stores, Inc., Detroit, announced today it had purchased for $2,000,000 the forty-one-store Standard Drug Company. of Cleveland. Regal said it planned by Sept. 1 to convert the Standard stores into self-service discount units operating as Revco discount drug centers.

The sad and ugly transaction of trying to exchange a certain number of human beings for a certain number of tractors seems to have reached a futile end. The idea was, no doubt, originally put forward by Premier Castro "sarcastically," as The Times correspondent in Havana wrote at the time. When it was taken up seriously by Americans for humanitarian reasons, Castro was unabashed.
Your editorial of June 29, deploring the "dark age" welfare proposals of the City of Newburgh, cannot be commended highly enough.

Massey-Ferguson, Ltd., of Toronto, said to be the world's largest manufacturer of tractors and combines, and the Butler Manufacturing Company of Kansas City, producer of farmstead equipment and buildings, have jointly formed Massey-Ferguson-Butler, Ltd., in Conventry, England.

"The Case for Dr. Cook," by Andrew Freeman, originally scheduled for publication this month, will be issued by Coward-McCann on Aug. 28. It is an account of the contentions between Frederick A. Cook and Robert E. Peary in their explorations of the Arctic and the reaching of the North Pole.

The City of Newburgh deserves resounding support for its courageous position of standing up to the overpowering octopus of state-Federal welfare bureaucracy. It is a frightening thing that a community cannot run its own affairs and live within a reasonable budget in the best interests of its own citizens.
In what is probably television's, keenest spot marketing battle, Lestoil Products, Inc., have come up with an opponent they feel will be more than a match for the earringed Mr. Clean.
President Kennedy's fact-finding board indicated early today that it had worked out a settlement with a key striking maritime union and employers representing a major segment of the industry.
WASHINGTON, June 29 -- Employment in the nation's big industrial areas showed marked gains this month, the Labor Department reported today.

The unions on strike are the National Maritime Union, 37,000 "members; the Seafarers International Union, Atlantic, Gulf and Lakes section, 22,000; the Marine Engineers Beneficial Association, 11,000; the Masters, Mates and Pilots, 11,000, and the American Radio Association.
CHICAGO, June 29 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

WASHINGTON, June 29 (AP) -- The Chesapeake and Ohio Railway Company's top finance officer rejected today as impractical a New York Central Railroad proposal that the Central be drawn into a proposed merger of the C. and the Baltimore and Ohio.

In a world full of question marks there are not many abiding certainties, but Liberal party faithfulness to the Democratic party is one of these. It has remained true-blue in loyalty with its convention's overwhelming endorsement of "Fighting Bob" Wagner -- Vice Chairman Rose's perceptive characterization of the Mayor -- for a third term.

Two benefit theatre parties are being planned by the board of directors of Greer School, a privately supported institution at Hope Farm, Dutchess County, for 200 boys and girls who are homeless or whose parents cannot provide for their care.
Three new films will open in local theatres today.

ELISABETHVILLE, the Congo, June 29 (AP) -- President Moise Tshombe of Katanga Province declared today that he was unwilling to cooperate politically with the "corrupt and weak" Central Government of the Congo.
JOLIET, Ill., June 29 (AP) -- Basil (the Owl) Banghart, once called the "most crime-wise man in the nation," was freed on the parole today after twenty-seven years in prison.

HONOLULU, June 29 -- Political partisanship appeared to play a far larger role than usual at the fifty-third annual Conference of Governors, which ended here yesterday. Indications are that it will play an even bigger role in the future.
Puerto Rico's growing electronics industry marked a kind of graduation ceremony yesterday with announcement of it's first United States military contract.
ISTANBUL, Turkey, June 29 (Reuters) -- A plot against the regime has been uncovered in the wake of a raid on Communists, officials announced tonight.

LONDON, June 29 -- Britain diverted a commando carrier and other warships from the Far East toward Kuwait today and alerted other forces nearer to the threatened sheikdom on the Persian Gulf. Iraq has claimed it as part of her territory.
WASHINGTON, June 29 -- Senate Republicans started a drive today for "reasonable regulation" of foreign imports they contended were hurting domestic industry and employment.
PARIS, June 29 -- President de Gaulle, on a hand-shaking and speaking tour in eastern France, said today that the military operations in Algeria were "virtually finished."

Divine Comedy was the front-runner for the greater part of the mile-and-a-sixteenth feature purse at Belmont Park yesterday. More important, he was in front at the wire, by two and a half lengths over Arnold Hanger's Whitley.

I was most interested to see in the Drama Section of The New York Times of June 25 pictures from the plays to be sent on a goodwill tour of Latin America. I am curious to know why the selection was made.

The women's division of the United Hospital Fund's 1961 campaign will again be headed by Mrs. John Sheldon Tilney, 1120 Fifth Avenue. The appointment was announced yesterday by Howard W. McCall Jr., general chairman.
TRENTON, June 29 -- The controversy over whether a global jetport should be built in North Jersey was injected into the governorship race today as a major campaign issue.
WASHINGTON, June 29 (AP) -- The Administration won a second chance today to press for an increase in postal rates in the House of Representatives this session.
BLOOMINGTON, Minn., June 29 (AP) -- Frank Malzone slammed a three-run homer to pace Boston to six unearned runs in the fifth inning today as the Red Sox downed the Minnesota Twins, 9 -- 5.
Fair weather and temperatures near 90 from today through Sunday are expected to cause the Fourth of July holiday to open with a record number of private autos on the highways here.
State Rent Administrator Robert E. Herman yesterday ordered a substantial increase in the payments landlords must make to tenants who are evicted to make way for new private housing construction.
Mayor Wagner voiced the belief yesterday that a Democratic fight could be avoided if the party leaders "on reflection" would realize that the slate he has proposed is in the party's best interest.
WASHINGTON, June 29 -- Congress sent to the White House today President Kenny's program for increasing Social Security benefits for about 4,000,000 elderly persons.
Volatile Middle East politics has produced another critical clash of interests, this time in the little oil-rich sheikdom of Kuwait.
Increases in jet coach fares ranging from 10 cents to $2.25 on one-way tickets have been requested by four major domestic airlines in applications before the Civil Aeronautics Board.
The Long Island Railroad moved ahead into the black -- just barely -- in May after operating at a loss in the first four months of this year.

Francisco Molina, a supporter of Fidel Castro, was sentenced yesterday to a prison term of twenty years to life for the slaying of a 9-year-old girl during a brawl between pro and anti-Castro elements here last Sept. 21.

WIMBLEDON, England, June 29 -- The moment of glory came to Chris Crawford of California today. The towering blond from Piedmont took third-seeded Nick Pietrangeli of Italy, a darling of the Wimbledon galleries, wizard or racquet and the best tennis player in Europe, and crushed him in the third round of the all-England tournament.

GENEROSITY is a word that is not normally found in any baseball dictionary. In times of crisis or pressure the club owners react with a cynical selfishness. What's best for the sport has hitherto interested them not a whit. They have coldly asked: What's in it for me?

Dallas, Tex., sold $10,000,000 of school bonds due from 1962 to 1981 to the Chase Manhattan Bank and associates yesterday at an interest cost of 3.29238 per cent. The reoffering was at prices scaled to yield from 1.6 o 4.5 per cent.
WARSAW, June 29 -- Poland's managed economy has expanded rapidly this year, but personal income has risen faster than the production of consumer goods.

Blyth Co., Inc., and associates offered to the public yesterday $50,000,000 of twenty-five year 4 5/8 per cent sinking fund debentures of the Caterpillar Tractor Company. The debentures, priced at 99 1/2 to yield about 4.66 per cent to maturity, had a "fairly good reception," according to the underwriters.

WASHINGTON, June 29 (AP) -- The United States has decided to go ahead with talks with Communist Outer Mongolia, looking toward possible diplomatic recognition and a seat in the United Nations, despite the heated opposition of Nationalist China.

A study is being undertaken to search out inadequacies in treating problem drinkers in this city and to help develop programs for dealing with alcoholism. The National Council on Alcoholism and government and private agencies will conduct the study.

RYE, N.Y., June 29 -- Don Mazzilli, a 15-year-old sophomore from Lincoln High School of Yonkers, led the Westchester district qualifiers today for the Metropolitan Golf Association's junior championship. He posted a 74 at Apawamis.

The New York City Housing Authority yesterday took possession of the Armstrong Hotel, a seven-story rooming house on the upper West Side that has been charged with 523 violations for dirt, dilapidation and rat infestation.
Your recent series concerning the government and politics of Massachusetts presented a very broad overview of a problem that is presently harassing at least twenty other states.
An $18,000,000 stockholder's suit was filed in State Supreme Court yesterday against the Fifth Avenue Coach Company, charging twelve of its fifteen directors with mismanagement.
BOSTON, June 29 (UPI) -- Richard Cardinal Cushing told his flock today that he was guilty of "Words Without End, Amen." He promised to reform.
TOKYO, June 29 (AP) -- Japan s growing imports in recent months have surpassed cargo handling capacities of the nation's major ports, the Japan Shipowners Association said today.
In striking distance of first after a transcontinental road trip on which they won nine of sixteen games, the Yankees now set up camp at the Stadium for a home stand involving nine games in ten days.

A plan for paying off the long-defaulted dollar bonds of Saarbruecken, West Germany, and for settling twenty-six years of interest arrears was recommended to bondholders yesterday by the Foreign Bondholders Protective Council, Inc., which negotiated the settlement.

Calculations completed yesterday for the third annual Scotland Lightship predicted-log contest show the winner to be Elias A. Kalil in Irene K.V, last year's national champion. Second place was taken by Dr. Allen B. Dumont.

Daily average borrowings by member banks of the Federal Reserve System rose $39,000,000 to $81,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. Daily average reserves in excess of requirements rose $31,000,000 to $577,000,000 from a revised figure a week earlier.
WIMBLEDON, England, June 29 (AP) -- Gardnar Mulloy has been asked by Wimbledon authorities not to wear his modest tennis slogan here.
The Federal Communications Commission expressed confidence here yesterday that witnesses who had testified at its investigation of television would not be subjected to reprisals.

A Yonkers lawyer was arrested yesterday on charges of bribery and conspiracy as the college basketball scandal spread to two more universities and into last year's National Collegiate Athletic Association Tournament in Madison Square Garden.

The final gongs of the school season will clang at 860 public schools throughout New York today, liberating 967,000 pupils until Sept. 7. But at Brooklyn's P.S. 13, the city's oldest public school, the bell will never sound again.
JAMES GALANOS has reached the head of the American fashion parade by consistently marching to the sound of his own music.

Sidney Schwartz, New York realty investor and motel operator, has leased a motel and bowling center to be built in the proposed Lewis Empire Plaza, a shopping center in Schenectady, N.Y. The motel will contain 100 rooms.
GREAT NECK, L.I., June 29 -- In a reversal of the usual suburban pattern, a group of communities in this North Shore area of expensive homes is looking for Negro newcomers.
After a week's postponement because of rain, the summer concert series "Jazz in the Garden" got under way last night beneath a cloudless sky in the Sculpture Court of the Museum of Modern Art.
WASHINGTON, June 29 -- Department store sales in the week ended last Saturday were 2 per cent above sales in the corresponding week of last year.

Lumber production totaled 240,648,000 board feet in the week ended last Saturday, compared with 240,668,000 board feet the week before, according to reports from regional lumbr associations. A year ago the figure was 253,035,000 board feet.
WASHINGTON, June 29 -- The State Department, troubled by reported efforts to solicit students for trips to Cuba, issued a warning against such trips today.
The New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad disclosed yesterday that its directors had voted to defer the payment of interest on two bond issues that had been due today.
WASHINGTON, June 29 (AP) Construction activity made a better-than-usual showing in June with expenditures increasing by 9 per cent to about $5,100,000,000.
OPPOSITE the title page of his tumultuous novel, "Tropic of Cancer," Henry Miller quotes one of Emerson's placid reflections:
SPRINGFIELD, N.J., June 29 -- Mary Kathryn (better known as Mickey) Wright shared the lead today in the first round of the women's United States Open golf championship.
CARSON CITY, Nev., June 29 (AP) -- Two self-styled revolutionaries were indicted by a Federal grand jury today on charges of blowing up three telephone microwave relay stations in Utah and Nevada.
Robert Whitehead and Gilbert Miller will co-produce "The Diamond Orchid" on Broadway next season.
John W. Bindner, Arthur L. Kersey and Charles S. Cavanagh have been appointed assistant secretaries of the Manufacturers Trust Company.
A gleaming white ship equipped to find the tiniest mote in the vast expanses of the heavens will put to sea this morning from the Todd Shipyard in Brooklyn.
Marilyn Monroe had her gall bladder removed in a two-and-a-quarter-hour operation last night at Polyclinic Hospital.
The House of Delegates of the American Medical Association, at its final meeting here yesterday, voiced the expected opposition to medical care for the aged under the Social Security system.
CHICAGO, June 29 (UPI) -- Drought and the worst grasshopper infestation in nearly thirty years are threatening crop failures in the Northern Plains.

UNITY HOUSE, Pa., June 29 (AP) -- The American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations executive council today voted to terminate its two-year drive to organize agricultural workers on big farms in California.
WASHINGTON, June 29 (AP) -- The Civil Service Commission announced today new qualification standards for persons seeking Presidential appointment as postmasters.
The State Investigation Commission, ending six days of hearings on the city's school building program yesterday, charged there had been an "incalculable waste of taxpayers' funds."
WASHINGTON, June 29 -- The latest week's pattern of freight volume was mixed for the second successive week, the rail and truck industries reported today.
WASHINGTON, June 29 (UPI) -- Legislation increasing benefits for disabled veterans by $75,000,000 a year was approved today by the Senate Finance Committee. The measure has already passed the House.

TOKYO, June 29 -- For the last five days the affairs of the rest of the world have receded into the background in Japan. The only things that have really mattered have been the rains, the floods and the struggle against nature.
BERLIN, June 29 -- The Eastern bloc is taking "security precautions" in the event of a conflict with the West over the signing of a separate peace treaty with East Germany.

The nation's hundred largest corporations paid out last year more than $15,000,000,000, or some $5.29 a share on the average, in taxes. That whopping bill did not include excise and sales taxes, the First National City Bank of New York says in its latest monthly review.

WASHINGTON, June 29 -- House Republicans today elected Representative Bob Wilson of San Diego, Calif., a close friend of former Vice President Richard M. Nixon, as chairman of the Republican Congressional Campaign Committee.
The results of a mail referendum on whether public school teachers want collective bargaining will be announced here today.
LONDON, June 29 -- Britain's Foreign Secretary, the Earl of Home, warned his nation today of the "extremely dangerous" world situation developing out of the Berlin crisis.
THIS is the peak season for fashion shows, fresh strawberries and frightened runaways.
PARIS, June 29 -- French Government and farm officials indicated after a meeting tonight that new measures would be taken tomorrow to meet farmer demands for price supports.

WASHINGTON, June 29 (UPI) -- President Kennedy won the right today to streamline the Federal Trade Commission and Civil Aeronautics Board when the Senate approved his organization plans for the agencies. They had previously cleared the House.
NEW DELHI, India, June 29 -- The United States and India will mark tomorrow the tenth year of their economic cooperation.
PARIS, June 29 -- French official circles interpreted President Kennedy's news conference statements yesterday on the Berlin question as a lead from strength and gave quick endorsement to them today.
The formation of the Better Bellevue Association to focus public attention on improving the hospital was announced yesterday.

ATLANTIC CITY, June 29 -- America must share its wealth of teachers with the rest of the world in the same way that it has shared its mineral and industrial wealth, R. Sargent Shriver Jr., director of the Peace Corps, said tonight.
WASHINGTON, June 29 -- President Kennedy signed the multibillion-dollar highway financing bill today.

PHILADELPHIA, June 29 -- A semblance of order, propriety and proficiency returned to Connie Mack Stadium tonight as the Giants swept a twilight-night double-header from the cellar-lodged Philadelphia Phillies.

NEWARK, June 29 -- The ethnic composition of Protestant Episcopal congregations in the Newark Diocese has changed in the last thirty years from an Anglo-Saxon background to one of mixed nationalities.
Adlai E. Stevenson will start his own television show on the American Broadcasting Company network Oct. 1.

Because it takes place during the National Safe Boating Week which has been proclaimed by President Kennedy, the New York Athletic Club's traditional predicted-log contest to Block Island has a whole new string of additional safety precautions.
DETROIT, June 29 (AP) -- The league-leading Detroit Tigers extended their margin to two games in the American League today by downing the Chicago White Sox, 5 -2.

CHICAGO, June 29 (AP) -- Continued unfavorable crop weather in the Northwest and in Canada and a lack of hedge selling of any consequence brought price advances for practically all grain futures on the Board of Trade today.
The normal human liver produces a chemical factor that powerfully inhibits growth of experimental cancer in mice, a specialist reported here yesterday.

River Drive Apartments, Inc., representing a syndicate of investors, has taken title to the apartment development for 200 families at 380-400 River Drive, Passaic, N.J. The New Jersey Bureau of Housing was the seller of the project, which was built for war veterans.

THE performance of the New York press was examined by Charles Collingwood in a half-hour program over Channel 2 last night. The Columbia Broadcasting System's reviewer, usually seen on Sunday afternoons, appeared to have some difficulty in adjusting to the evening air; his critique for the most part was disappointingly bland and rather general.
Following is the text of a statement yesterday by Goodman A. Sarachan, chairman of the State Investigation Commission, at the conclusion of public hearings on the city's school-construction program:

Aggressive commission-house buying of potato futures and short covering by Midwest trade houses touched off light stop-loss purchasing yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange. The May option climbed to a new high for the life of the contract and the November position equaled its old high.
BERLIN, June 29 -- Western officials in Berlin today emphasized Soviet responsibility for Western rights of air access to isolated West Berlin.
United States owners of shipping registered under "flags of convenience" have taken issue with comments on the foreign-flag situation by a leading Norwegian shipowner.
WASHINGTON, June 29 -- Senator J.W. Fulbright made a plea today for restraint and calm in Washington's present fire-alarm atmosphere.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., June 29 -- Mayor Stanley W. Church appointed a Negro, a Jew and a man of Italian ancestry today as members of the local Board of Education and said he was "fed up" with erroneous portrayals of New Rochelle as a city of racial hatreds.

The appointment of the Rev. Francis J. Mugavero as diocesan director of Catholic Charities in the Diocese of Brooklyn, effective tomorrow, was announced yesterday by Bishop Bryan J. McEntegart of Brooklyn.
WASHINGTON, June 29 (UPI) -- Internal Revenue agents rounded up 123 persons and seized more than $110,000 today in their largest nationally coordinated raid against gambling.
DETROIT, June 29 -- The United Automobile Workers told the General Motors Corporation today that annual salaries for production workers would provide greater job security than hourly wages do.
WASHINGTON, June 29 -- The House Agriculture Committee completed today the dismantling of the Kennedy Administration's proposed new machinery for controlling farm production and prices.
WASHINGTON, June 29 -- Congress put aside today, for at least a week, the knotty problem of school legislation. Many members were wishing it could be shelved permanently.
The Beatrice Foods Company registered record sales and earnings in its first fiscal quarter, ended on May 31, William G. Karnes, president, reported today.

PATRIOTISM comes with a budget price tag this Fourth of July week-end. If the family's idea of a celebration is the traditional ham, it may be found for as little as 44 cents a pound for a whole or half at some stores.

CARACAS, Venezuela, June 29 -- The Latin-American Conference of State Oil Companies ended in Maracay, Venezuela, today. Eleven Latin-American nations that have state oil enterprises, including Mexico, Brazil and Venezuela, participated.
JACKSON, Miss., June 29 (AP) -- Brig. Gen. T.B. Birdsong, head of the Mississippi Highway Patrol, charged today that Freedom Rides were "directed, inspired and planned by known Communists."

WASHINGTON, June 29 -- President Kennedy propped today to establish an "agency of peace" to deal with disarmament problems. The agency, to be called the United States Disarmament Agency for World Peace and Security, would have primary responsibility within the Government for drafting disarmament proposals and conducting broad research on arms control.
WASHINGTON, June 29 -- The National Geographic Society has established a permanent space award in honor of the retiring Air Force Chief of Staff, Gen. Thomas D. White.
UNITY HOUSE, Pa., June 29 -- The merged labor federation today put off until October a showdown on the internal feuds that have imperiled its unity.

WASHINGTON, June 29 (AP) -- The Federal Trade Commission today ordered a hearing examiner to gather additional evidence on the acquisition of the Clorox Chemical Company, Oakland, Calif., by the Procter Gamble Company, Cincinnati.

Louis J. Lefkowitz hired the grand ballroom of the Astor Hotel yesterday and invited well-wishers to tell him how they would help elect his Mayor. Several hundred showed up, and the Attorney General seemed as pleased as any Republican candidate might be so early in the campaign.

WESTBURY, L.I., June 29 -- Hairos II, last year's winner of the $50,000 Roosevelt International Trot, will not defend in this year's race after all. The champion from the Netherlands suffered a bowed tendon, following a victory at The Hague last Sunday and was withdrawn today from the July 14 race.
Leaders of 700,000 union members here have decided to form their own political party to take part in this fall's citywide election.

WHILE a major portion of the garment industry has come out in favor of fit and flare, James Galanos, the California individualist who continues to be one of the potent voices of fashion, has cast his lot with a more fitted fit and practically ignored the flare.
ROME, June 29 -- Pope John XXIII announced today that his forthcoming encyclical on social and labor problems had been inspired the First Epistle of St. Peter.
The National Association of Investment Companies announced yesterday a reorganization plan designed to make the group an all-inclusive trade body of the mutual funds industry.
PITTSBURGH, June 29 (UPI) -- The Pittsburgh Pirates scored all their runs in an eighth-inning rally tonight to chase Sandy Koufax and defeat the Los Angeles Dodgers, 4 -- 2.
Webb Knapp, Inc., expects to break ground in August for the $40,000,000 office-and-apartment building it plans to erect just north of the United Nations headquarters on the East Side.

The Alleghany Corporation acquired yesterday the title to the Denver, Colo., Courthouse Square property from Webb Knapp, Inc., with payment by the real estate concern of a $2,000,000 remainder due on a $4,300,000 note.
WASHINGTON, June 29 (AP) -- A Federal judge today held that William G. (Big Bill) Lias was a natural-born citizen of the United States.

WASHINGTON, June 29 -- Had it not been for Col. Jack Lawrence Armstrong, there might never have been "Jack Armstrong, the All-American Boy," and the United States might not have had an atomic-powered satellite in orbit.

"BRIGANDS live by love and fear. When they inspire only love, it is a weakness. When they inspire only fear, they are hated and have no supporters." This concise summing up of the formula for successful brigandage may be found in "Memed My Hawk,"* by Yashar Kemal, a strange novel from Turkey about a young man who became a brigand of legendary fame and a folk hero worthy to rank with Robin Hood.
WASHINGTON, June 29 -- Keith Funston, president of the New York Stock Exchange, told Congress today that he did not believe a broad general review of stock market practices was necessary.
Oil and politics are usually a highly combustible mixture.

Ore-Ida Foods, Inc., Ontario, Ore., filed yesterday a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission covering a proposed offering of 220,000 common shares. Of the shares, 200,000 will be sold by the company and 20,000 by a stockholder.

CLEVELAND, June 29 (AP) -- Home runs by Billy Klaus and Marty Keough paced the Washington Senators to a 3-1 victory over the Cleveland Indians tonight in the finale of a fourgame series. Washington took the series, 3 games to 1.

The Celanese Corporation of America has announced plans to move its executive offices from 180 Madison Avenue at Thirty-fourth Street to the new Morgan Guaranty Trust Company building at 522 Fifth Avenue southwest corner of Forty-fourth Street.
WASHINGTON, June 29 -- The average American consumer was pictured today as one who reads closely the content labels on liquor bottles but relies primarily on his emotions in buying everything else.

DURING the intermission at Lewisohn Stadium last night, ballerina Maria Tallchief came out on the dimly lit stage in her kimono (and tiara) and walked about testing the condition of the floor. Not far behind her was a man with a mop who might have been polishing the floor had it not been far too slick already.

WASHINGTON, June 29 -- The world-wide debate on Berlin is at last beginning to move from the level of military threats to a more moderate discussion of rights and responsibilities, but there is still a great deal of dangerous imprecision about what is meant by the freedom of that city.

On my last visit to the Central Park Zoo, I was again shocked and horrified by the inadequacy of the cages, particularly those for the large animals. It is not humane to confine an animal in a space where it cannot exercise. It seems to me if we wish to maintain the zoo as it is now we should put over the entrance in large letters, "Abandon compassion all you who enter here."
PARIS, June 30 -- Once when discussing the intricate Algerian problem, General de Gaulle remarked: "Suppose you in the United States had a population of forty million Redskins.

"The World of John Lardner," a selection of the late writer's pieces, will be published Aug. 1 by Simon Schuster. It will include profiles, essays on a variety of sports, reports on World War II and a previously unpublished spoof, called "Drinking in America," which the author had brought up only to the Civil War.
WILLIAM PASSELL, one of this city's high-ranking tournament players, is a newlywed, married a month.

WASHINGTON, June 30 (AP) -- The United States Court of Appeals today upheld contempt of Congress convictions of Frank Grumman and Bernard Silber for refusal to answer some questions asked by a House subcommittee on Un-American Activities.
TRENTON, June 30 -- The State Supreme Court today voided the disbarment of Abraham J. Isserman and ordered his license to practice law in New Jersey restored.

NEW CITY, N.Y., June 30 -- The proposed purchase of three park sites by Rockland County for $2,000,000 was rejected in a referendum today. With all but three districts reporting, the vote was 8,842 to 3,793.
IF a Zulu tourist were to cross the threshold of Bloomingdale's tomorrow, he could count on being greeted in his native tongue. "Sacaborner," a bouncy, blue-eyed, blond woman would say to him.

STANTON, Del., June 30 (AP) -- Mrs. June H. McKnight's French-bred gelding Palladio, trained by Danny Smithwick and ridden by his brother Pat, easily defeated five rivals today in the $9,300 Spring Steeplechase Stakes at Delaware Park.

On June 21 The Times published an Associated Press dispatch from Washington which conveys the impression that the testimony I presented to the Senate Foreign Relations Committee on behalf of the United States Chamber of Commerce was an expression of opposition to the foreign aid legislation embodied in S1983.
DETROIT, June 30 -- The United Automobile Workers took issue today with the Ford Motor Company's stance on inflation.
What makes Frankie run?
WESTHAMPTON, L.I., June 30 -- The Off-Beach Theatre Club, an experimental project, will start a season of new plays and "extras" at this seaside resort next Thursday.

The United States infantry for the new guerrilla warfare is training at Fort Bragg, North Carolina, and elsewhere in highly unmilitary dress. These are the men of the Special Service who will parachute, or otherwise infiltrate behind enemy lines to form, or to cooperate with friendly partisan bands.
TRENTON, June 30 -- The State Supreme Court ruled today that the Princeton University Press and the Textile Research Institute of Princeton were not entitled to property tax exemption.

San Francisco's Candlestick Park and Clearwater's Jack Russell Stadium are far apart, but they have something in common. The first is the site of the major league All-Star baseball game on July 11. The second, in Florida, is where the Amateur Softball Association's four-game All-Star series culminates today.
WHITE PLAINS, June 30 -- Westchester County took the first step today toward giving railroads some of the public services at depots that airlines and bus companies receive.

FOR many families this weekend marks the official opening of the summer cottage. While the rest of the family looks forward to outdoor barbecues and long, cool drinks, the housewife knows there is no vacation from housekeeping chores.
The Indian Harbor Yacht Club's fourth annual sailing race around Long Island for the Greenwich Cup got under way off Rockaway Point at dusk last night.

In your June 23 editorial on the so-called "Alto Adige" The Times generously concedes the historical fact that the area had been under Austrian rule for centuries. Yet it finds nothing wrong with a hated alien government continuing to occupy it.
The Navy has been launching rocket-boosted telephone poles from the Pacific Ocean to test the feasibility of igniting large rockets when they are afloat.

BUENOS AIRES, June 30 (AP) -- An Argentine airliner with thirty-five persons aboard crashed short of an airport landing strip tonight and burst into flames. Authorities listed twenty-three persons as dead or missing.

Wool futures advanced yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange in very active trading. Prices for grease (uncleaned) wool were up 1.5 to 2.9 cents a pound, while tops (combed wool) advanced 0.7 to 0.8 cent.

WASHINGTON, June 30 -- The Government closes its books on a budget deficit of approximately $3,000,000,000 at midnight. It expects a larger deficit in the year ahead but a surplus in the following year.
TRENTON, June 30 -- New Jersey's commuter income tax takes effect tomorrow. The state will begin deducting it from the wages of about 45,000 New Yorkers who work in the state.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 30 -- The new state of Kuwait applied today for membership in the United Nations, thereby pressing for early commitment by the major powers against Iraq's claim to her territory.
HONOLULU, June 30 (AP) -- The Governor of American Samoa, in office only a month, charged yesterday that the United States had been neglecting the tiny South Pacific island territory.

Intent on filling a vacuum that doesn't exist, labor union leaders in New York City are going ahead with plans first broached in mid-April to form a new political party. The guiding spirit behind what might be called the Freedom party is Harry A. Van Arsdale Jr., president of the Central Labor Council, who along with several other of the union officials cooperating in the venture is a good friend of Mayor Wagner.
It was too warm for most New Yorkers yesterday but not for four newly arrived Congolese high school boys.

Declines in sales and earnings were reported yesterday by the Kroger Company for the first half of its fiscal year. Joseph B. Hall, president of the nation's third largest food chain, noted that earnings in the second quarter were better than in the first quarter, despite a 3 per cent drop in sales from the fiscal 1960 level.

With abetment from Roger Maris and Mickey Mantle, Whitey Ford made it a happy homecoming for the Yankees last night. Behind the five-hit pitching of their model south-paw, the Bombers downed the Senators, 5 -- 1.
LONDON, June 30 -- Selling of industrial shares in late dealings turned net price movements irregular in the stock market today.
BOSTON, June 30 (AP) -- Mike de la Hoz and Woodie Held batted in three runs each as the Cleveland Indians walloped the Boston Red Sox, 10 -- 2 tonight.

The United States early today was two-thirds protected by its radar warning system against intercontinental aerial attack. A large radar installation became operational at Clear, Alaska, about forty miles southwest of Fairbanks.
WASHINGTON, June 30 -- President Kennedy rebuked the Tariff Commission today for sloppy work and sent back its recommendations for three tariff increases. He asked for more information.
PARIS, June 30 -- Farm organization leaders called today for the maintenance of a truce on peasant agitation. Such a truce has yet to be observed by the farmers.
"REBELLION IN CUBA," A which opened yesterday at the Embassy, bears little resemblance to recent events on the Caribbean island.

HOT SPRINGS, Ark., June 30 (AP) -- Lon Stanton, a Lake Ozark, (Mo.) curio dealer, today regained the title in the instinctive-dintsion at the national field archery tournament with a total of 2,744 out of a possible 3,360 points.

NEW DELHI, India, June 30 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru suggested today that the United Nations could invoke economic sanctions against Portugal to force her to halt repressive measures in Angola.
The value of new securities offered here to the public in June was at highest level for any month this year and exceeded the totals for the month in the two preceding years.

The International Silver Company, Meriden, Conn., is offering its common stockholders the right to subscribe for $7,822,000 of 5 per cent convertible subordinated debentures due in 1981. The debentures are offered at $100 in the ratio of one $100 debenture for each fifteen common shares held of record of June 30.
WASHINGTON, June 30 (UPI) -- With President Kennedy looking on, Gen. Curtis E. Lemay was sworn in today as Air Force Chief of Staff, succeeding Gen. Thomas D. White.

The following table gives the amount of dealings in the stocks from which the averages are computed, the combined trading in both classes of issues, as well as the total daily transactions for week and month:

ATLANTIC CITY, June 30 (UPI) -- The National Boxing Association light-heavyweight champion, Harold Johnson, will make his bid for a shot at the heavyweight crown tomorrow night in a nontitle fight with Eddie Machen, a heavyweight contender.
Mrs. May Preston Davie retired yesterday as chairman of the Women's Auxiliary of the New York Republican County Committee.

The public's confidence in the administration of New York City's school system is badly shaken. Evidence of inefficiency, waste of resources, sloth, indifference, malfeasance, laxity in ethics and even corruption has been developed beyond plausible challenge by the State Commission of Investigation, and concurred in to some degree by findings of the city's Commissioner of Investigation.

ALBANY, June 30 -- The Public Service Commission refused today to let the New York Central Railroad abandon its Albany station and build new passenger and freight terminal facilities across the Hudson River in Rensselaer.
PITTSBURGH, June 30 (AP) -- Bill Virdon of Pittsburgh singled home two runs with two out in the ninth inning tonight as the Pirates beat the San Francisco Giants, 4 -- 3.

GENEVA, June 30 -- Britain and the Soviet Union, co-chairmen of the fourteen-nation conference on Laos, were reported today to have made progress on a message to be sent to the International Control Mission in Laos.

WASHINGTON, June 30 -- President Kennedy called on American business and the private foundations today to help him recruit a top-flight staff of executives to administer his proposed $26,000,000,000 five-year program of foreign aid.

Victory was claimed yesterday by the Diamond Alkali Company in its fight to gain control of and merge with the Chemical Process Company, a small West Coast chemical concern. The Commercial Solvents Corporation, another chemical manufacturer, had been seeking control of Chemical Process through a stock tender offer.
ALBANY, June 30 -- If the price of your favorite cigar doesn't go down 15 per cent tomorrow, don't blame Governor Rockefeller or the Legislature.
WASHINGTON, June 30 -- Four of the country's largest moving companies and five of their executives were indicted here today on criminal antitrust charges.
The espionage trial of Dr. Robert Soblen, 60-year-old psychiatrist, turned yesterday to consideration of data from the files of the Federal Bureau of Investigation.
WASHINGTON, June 30 (AP) -- The Navy said today that two of the three satellites fired aloft in a single rocket yesterday apparently had not separated and thus were working at reduced efficiency.
OCEANPOST, N.J., June 30 (AP) -- The Brae Burn Farm's Shirley Jones broke a fourteen-year-old track record at Monmouth Park today as she galloped to an easy victory in the Assembly Purse.

MIAMI, Fla., June 30 (AP) -- The National Brewing Company of Baltimore acquired today all the assets of the Miami plant of Anheuser-Busch, Inc., for a price reported to be slightly in excess of $3,000,000.

LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, June 30 -- Five thousand soldiers wearing brand-new uniforms and manning armored cars and mounted machine guns paraded past President Joseph Kasavubu here today in celebration of the first anniversary of the Congo's independence.

WASHINGTON, June 30 (UPI) -- The Bakery and Confectionery Workers Union and eight of its officers were found guilty of contempt of court today for their activities in an intra-union struggle growing out of corruption charges.

LOS ANGELES, June 30 (AP) -- Ken Hunt hit his fourteenth and fifteenth homers and drove in three runs tonight as the Los Angeles Angels scored their third straight victory, defeating the Chicago White Sox, 10 -- 3.
WASHINGTON, June 30 (AP) -- Henry Winston, who was convicted in the Communist conspiracy trial of 1949 and now is blind and in ill health, was ordered released from prison today.
WASHINGTON, June 30 (UPI) -- Representative Steven B. Derounian, Republican of Roslyn, L.I., said today that anyone could have a Cadillac. Just "own a farm," he said, "and don't farm."
WASHINGTON, June 30 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture reported today that farm product prices declined between mid-May and mid-June.

TUNIS, June 30 -- The Algerian nationalist Provisional Government called tonight on Algerians and on "brother and friendly nations" to demonstrate next Wednesday against a threatened partition of Algeria.
WASHINGTON, June 30 -- -- President Kennedy signed today an omnibus housing bill designed to help moderate-income families, the elderly and the poor obtain good housing in decent neighborhoods.

CHICAGO, June 30 -- The United States Circuit Court of Appeals upheld today a District Court verdict in which Parmlee Transportation Company lost a $19,200,000 antitrust suit against Railroad Transfer Company and other defendants.
Indications are strong that a safety system widely used by the military -- an arresting gear for planes running out of runway -- may be adapted for airline operations.

A YOUNG Frenchman may have started a male invasion of what has been known as a woman's occupation. According to Georgette Klinger, M. Jean Milhaut is one of the only men in New York who does facials for women.

WASHINGTON, June 30 -- President Kennedy signed with "great pleasure" today the legislation to increase Social Security benefits for more than 4,000,000 persons of retirement age. It becomes effective in September.

WIMBLEDON, England, June 30 -- Two 18-year-olds, Karen Hantze of Chula Vista, Calif., and Justina Bricka of St. Louis, and Mimi Arnold, an expatriate from California, swept into the fourth round of the women's singles before a parboiled crowd of 2,000 in the all-England tennis championships today.

LISBON, June 30 (UPI) -- Premier Salazar said today that the United Nations General Assembly operated by mob rule and that he had no intention of complying with a United Nations resolution calling on Portugal to stop fighting in Angola.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), June 30 -- Adolf Eichmann angrily denied today that he had recommended shooting 1,200 Serbian Jews in 1941.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., June 30 -- A Scotch Plains professional, Roy Faber, and Jules Gatesy finished in a tie with Ed Famula and Len York of Galloping Hill today in the annual pre-amateur tournament held in connection with the New Jersey Open.

WASHINGTON, June 29 (AP) -- The Federal Communications Commission today refused to reconsider an April 12 order limiting the form in which American Telephone Telegraph Co., could offer its "telpak" service at special low rates.
The city Board of Hospitals has agreed in principle on a plan under which some of the proprietary hospitals might lose their licenses.

EPINAL, France, June 30 (UPI) -- President de Gaulle said today that the world was on the eve of a serious crisis. He warned that lightning might strike out of the East unless the West remained firmly united.

WASHINGTON, June 30 -- Three New Jersey high school seniors, who are observing how Congress and Federal agencies operate, have decided they may seek a career in government or politics when they finish college.
Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer plans to distribute the Italian-made screen version of "The Leopard," the best-selling novel by Giuseppe de Lampedusa.
WASHINGTON, June 30 -- Treasury bill rates bounced upward again on today's sale of next week's regular issues. The sale was held today instead of next Monday to avoid the July 4 holiday.

A two-for-one split of the common stock of the Commonwealth Edison Company, Chicago, one of the nation's largest utilities, was proposed yesterday by directors. The move is subject to approval of stockholders at a special meeting on Sept. 6.
GENEVA, June 30 -- The conference on international trade in cotton textiles asked for by the United States will begin here on July 17, it was announced today.

LONDON, June 30 -- Britain has appealed to the United States and to the United Arab Republic and other countries in the Middle East to join her in restraining Iraq from attacking Kuwait, the Foreign Office announced today.
RIO de JANEIRO, June 30 (UPI) -- Dr. Albert Sabin said today the use of his live-virus polio vaccine could eventually eliminate the disease altogether.
HYANNIS PORT, Mass., June 30 -- President Kennedy and his family came home today for a long Independence Day holiday. The President's preoccupation for four days was officially announced as "rest."
MILWAUKEE, June 30 (AP) -- Joey Jay registered his tenth victory with the ninth-inning assistance of Bill Henry tonight as the first-place Cincinnati Reds blanked the Milwaukee Braves, 4 -- 0.

LEOPOLDVILLE, The Congo, June 30 -- Efforts to bring the leaders of the Congo's three rival regimes together around a conference table and to convene the country's Parliament have suffered a series of setbacks during the last few days.
The International Nickel Company of Canada, Ltd., increased yesterday the price of refined nickel by 7 1/4 cents a pound, to 81 1/4 cents.
NEWPORT, R.I., June 30 -- The Newport jazz festival opened tonight as sedately as a Tanglewood concert.

TEEN-AGERS usually have more sophisticated taste in cold summer drinks than their younger brothers and sisters. The smaller members of the family delight in "soda" and milk which they mix themselves with commercially prepared chocolate or fruit syrups.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed 2 points up to 11 points down yesterday. A point equals 5 cents a bale.
KUWAIT, June 30 -- Britain renewed assurances of support for Kuwait today.

LONDON, June 30 -- "We'll pay for this later," said a group of Londoners as they ambled through warm summer sun to tennis at Wimbledon, to cricket at Lord's, to family outings on the river or at pubs.

BONN, Germany, June 30 -- the Bundestag, West Germany's lower house of Parliament, appealed to the world powers today to work toward a German peace treaty based on "equal rights and self-determination" for all.

State welfare authorities were attempting yesterday to find a formula that would permit the employment of relief recipients on work projects, as planned by the city of Newburgh, without jeopardizing Federal grants.

IF WE cross all the bridges literature brings to us we'll have little time for anything else. What's more, the bridges are usually in peril. The London Bridge that is forever falling down in the nursery rhyme is joined, every publishing season, by several new ones that embattled factions want to preserve or destroy.
The National Labor Relations Board recommended yesterday that a union of staff members be certified as exclusive bargaining agent for employes of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union.

GRAND BLANC, Mich., June 30 (AP) -- Billy Casper, Dave Ragan and Johnny Pott -- three golfers who haven't won this year -- gained a tie for the lead at the halfway point of the Buick open today with fine second rounds.

LONDON, June 30 (Reuters) -- British Overseas Airways Corporation canceled sixteen scheduled flights in and out of London airport early today just before a strike of 290 maintenance electricians appeared to have been settled.
WASHINGTON, June 30 -- Gen. Phoumi Nosavan told President Kennedy today of efforts to set up a Laotian regime that would not fall under Communist control.
WASHINGTON, June 30 (AP) -- President Kennedy signed today an act extending the special children's milk program for another year. The act increases the authorization by $10,000,000 to $105,000,000.

LONDON, June 30 -- The 42-year old Earl of Cromer, who takes over tomorrow as Governor of the Bank of England, is believed to be the youngest governor in the long history of the Old Lady of Threadneedle Street.
CHICAGO, June 30 (AP) -- The Women's Western Golf Association junior title went today to Ann Baker of Maryville, Tenn., who scored a 5-and-3 victory over Mary Lou Daniel of Louisville.

Stockholders of National Phoenix Industries, Inc., at their annual meeting in Delaware yesterday, approved the merger of their company into Great American Industries, Inc., Great American would be the surviving corporation, if two-thirds of its outstanding stock votes in favor of the plan at a meeting later this month.
WALLOPS ISLAND, Va., June 30 (AP) -- A faulty rocket caused failure today in an effort to put up a new United States satellite to learn about space dust that may be a major hazard for astronauts.

LONDON, June 30 -- For the fourth ballet in its season at the Royal Opera House, Covent Garden, the Leningrad State Kirov Ballet tonight presented "Swan Lake," or as it is always known here, "Le Lac des Cygnes."
Television's organization men have postponed indefinitely an international TV assembly planned for next fall because unanticipated popularity has made it too disorganized.
William Zito, a 59-year-old groom at Belmont Park, will be arraigned in District Court, Mineola, L.I., this morning on a charge of attempted bribery.
For the fourteenth consecutive year New York City children will be given free transportation this summer in supervised groups to and from points of interest and recreational areas.

WASHINGTON, June 30 (AP) -- Secretary of Commerce Luther H. Hodges pushed a computer button today to inaugurate a new Federal service that will check on motorists convicted in drunken-driving or highway-death cases.
GREENWICH, Conn., June 30 -- Sweeping changes in the town government here were proposed today by a Charter revision commission.

A FEW oases beckon in the wide and lonely sands of art galleries closed for the summer. Greenest and most refreshing of these are two exhibitions of unusual interest, that of American drawings (Benjamin West to the present) from the Paul Magriel collection, at the Finch College Museum of Art, 62 East Seventy-eighth Street, and that of English drawings at the Drawing Shop, 45 Christopher Street.

HELSINKI, Finland, June 30 (AP) -- Two candidates emerged today as possible successors to Premier Vieno J. Sukselainen, who resigned last night after a civil court had convicted him in a pension fund scandal.

In his appearance before the Congressional subcommittee studying the need for a new investigation of the stock markets, Keith Funston, president of the New York Stock Exchange, indicated that the proposed inquiry had too narrow a target, a point with which we agree.

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), June 30 -- Israel charged the Soviet secret police today with "flagrant provocation" in bringing an accusation of espionage against Yaakov Sharett, first secretary of the Israeli Embassy in Moscow.

The Foxwood School in Flushing, Queens, a private institution established forty-eight years ago by Mrs. Elizabeth C. Dresser, has been sold by her and will be replaced by a six-story apartment building.
ALBUQUERQUE, N.M., June 30 (AP) -- Mike Herman of Yonkers won the 100-meter dash in 11 seconds tonight in the Amateur Athletic Union's national decathlon championships.
IT may take no more than a flower-filled garden behind Jill Lindberg's new salon to induce a sudden rash of newly blonded heads this summer.

The unions on strike are the National Maritime Union, 37,000 members; the Seafarers International Union, Atlantic, Gulf and Lakes section, 22,000; the Marine Engineers Beneficial Association, 11,000; the Masters, Mates and Pilots, 11,000, and the American Radio Association.
BERLIN, June 30 -- The Communist leaders of East Germany held out to their people today the prospect of "more toil, difficulties and sacrifices" before the year is out.
WASHINGTON, June 30 (AP) -- The Securities and Exchange Commission temporarily blocked today a proposed sale of 60,000 common shares by Broadcast International, Inc. of New York.

CHICAGO, June 30 (UPI) -- The St. Louis Cardinals, aided by Jim Schaffer's first major league home run, which came with the bases filled, scored all their runs in two innings today to rout the Chicago Cubs, 11 -- -4.
Hot and humid weather, punctuated by a few widely scattered thunder showers during the evening, marked the start of the Fourth of July week-end yesterday.
Thoroughbred horse racing in the metropolitan area will make a "big" switch today -- from Belmont Park to Aqueduct.
The early arrival in the United States of President Ayub Khan of Pakistan on a state visit should help ease some of the rough spots in relations between the two countries.

The old Collerd farm, a tract of five acres at Cedar Lane and River Road, Teaneck, N.J., has been sold by John R. Costanza. It was bought by the Countrywide Investment Company, which is headed by James D'Agostino and George Rothman.

WASHINGTON, June 30 -- President Kennedy sought today to break a procedural impasse in East-West dis armament discussions by conferring with the chief Soviet disarmament negotiator, Valerian A. Zorin.
Antimicrobial drugs may have reached the limit of their effectiveness against pneumonia, a Philadelphia physician declared here yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, June 30 -- Having escaped from the Pittsburgh Badlands -- where they had received one sobering shock after another -- the Los Angeles Dodgers got around to administering a few jolts themselves at Connie Mack Stadium tonight.
CIUDAD TRUJILLO, June 30 (UPI) -- The Trujillo family has asked the Government to de-emphasize the family name in the Dominican Republic.
TAUNTON, England, June 30 (Reuters) -- Bill Alley, a 43-year-old Australian left-hander, batted brilliantly for 95 runs in helping Somerset force draw against the Australia cricket team today.

TOKYO, June 30 -- Japanese officials and Western diplomats believe that Japan's leaders are moving slowly toward one of the most important psychological decisions since World War II -- the decision to enter the arena of international political responsibility.

WASHINGTON, June 30 -- A patent granted this week explains how a missile can be catapulted from a submarine. The Navy would say only that it was one of the designs taken into consideration in development of the Polaris launching system.

THE hands that wield the charge plates took a sharp slap at department stores this week. A random sampling of women shoppers in the New York area revealed that, despite the fact women flood into local stores like lemmings to the sea, things would indeed be different if they ran the railroad.
Pan American World Airways has asked the Civil Aeronautics Board either to give it an East Coast-Miami route or authorize a merger with Northeast Airlines.
WASHINGTON, June 30 (AP) -- A top executive of the Ford Motor Company said today that a bill to divorce auto manufacturers from their auto-financing subsidiaries was vicious.

LISBON, Portugal, June 30 -- Premier Antonio de Oliveira Salazar charged today that the United States had served Communist subversion in Africa by lining up with the Soviet Union on the issue of Angola.
WASHINGTON, June 30 (UPI) -- House members have quietly voted to give themselves a bargain basement in the guise of a stationery store.
State Senator Walter J. Mahoney said yesterday he would check on local officials to see that they act in good faith to enforce the state's new six-month welfare law, which goes into effect today.

NEW DELHI, June 30 (AP) -- Prime Minister Nehru announced today that a bill would be introduced in the session of Parliament beginning Aug. 7 to merge into India the former Portuguese enclaves of Dadra and Nagar Aveli.
SAN DIEGO, Calif., June 30 (UPI) -- A 14-year-old Boy Scout who had watched his grandfather and another man die during a three-day ordeal on a small liferaft in the Pacific was rescued today.
WASHINGTON, June 30 UPI) -- Senator Philip A. Hart adjourned the Senate's inquiry into deceptive grocery packaging today with the hope that the package could be made "a truthful salesman."

A WATER show by any other name would look as wet, a double somersault with a half twist by any professional aqua specialist would appear as expert and water ballets by other lithe aqua belles would be as eye-catching.
LONDON, June 30 -- "The Old Lady of Threadneedle Street" will have a new master tomorrow when the Earl of Cromer becomes governor of the Bank of England.
KANSAS CITY, June 30 (AP) -- Jack Kralick held the Kansas City Athletics to five hits tonight as the Minnesota Twins won, 8 -- 2.
HARTFORD, June 30 -- Most consumer and business tax rates in Connecticut will rise tomorrow as the state starts a new fiscal year.
WASHINGTON, June 30 -- The names of an additional eighteen men and ten women trainees for the tentative Peace Corps' project in Ghana were announced late today by the Peace Corps.

The pattern emerging from bargaining headquarters in the nationwide maritime strike is cause for grave concern, on the basis of the terms agreed to by representatives of two important management groups in this complex dispute: the subsidized fleet owners and a majority of the tanker operators.
Brooklyn College has named two students for the first time as winners of the annual Shakespeare Scholarship.
Democratic leaders are seriously considering state Controller Arthur Levitt as a candidate to oppose Mayor Wagner in the primary election Sept. 7.
BALTIMORE, June 30 (AP) -- Charlie Maxwell's twelfth-inning pinch single knocked in the winning run tonight as the first-place Detroit Tigers defeated the Baltimore Orioles, 6 -- 5.

Two thousand drivers of ready-mix concrete and other building material trucks went on strike last midnight against the multi-million-dollar construction industry here at the expiration of their contract.
WASHINGTON, June 30 -- The index of primary market prices rose 0.1 per cent during the week ended last Tuesday to 118.8 per cent of its 1947-49 base, the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today.
MELBOURNE, June 30 -- The Reserve Bank of Australia announced yesterday a major easing of the credit "squeeze" imposed by the Government last November as an anti-inflationary measure.
WASHINGTON, June 30 -- Representatives of the Western Allies met at the State Department today to work out the text of a reply to the Soviet Union on the German issue.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 30 -- Global consumption of natural rubber exceeded output for the third consecutive year, during 1960. As a recession began in the United States automobile industry, however, demand contracted and a sharp reversal occurred in both prices and trade in the commodity.
WARSAW, June 30 -- The theory that United States industry can sell goods as well as make friends at international trade fairs was tried out in Poland this year and appears to have passed the test.
WASHINGTON, June 30 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission was reported today to believe that the New Haven Railroad is headed for bankruptcy within a matter of days.
Salina, Kan., is planning the sale of $3,600,000 of water and sewage disposal system revenue bonds on July 11. The issue will come due from 1962 to 1986.
The Treasurers and Ticket Sellers Union has turned down the League of New York Theatre's request for a year's moratorium in a new contract.
WESTBURY, L.I., June 30 -- When 28,009 persons take the time and expend the effort to applaud a horse, it must be for something special.

Two-thirds of the country's merchant marine moved a little closer to a settlement in the nation-wide maritime strike last night. However, the other third said the settlement terms would ruin the industry.
TUNIS, June 30 -- The United States and Tunisia have signed aid agreements this week covering loans and grants of more than $25,000,000 outside the regular aid program.

The market for new capital offerings is scheduled to take a breather in the holiday week ahead. After several weeks of offering calendars in fixed-interest securities offerings in excess of $200,000,000, the week ahead promises only $63,300,000 of corporate bonds and debentures in issues larger than $5,000,000.

KEY WEST, Fla. June 30 -- The disbanded Tractors for Freedom Committee told Premier Fidel Castro today that it would not give him "$28,000,000 or $28" in exchange for prisoners from the April 17 attempt to invade Cuba.
WASHINGTON, June 30 -- A group of young Americans who will go to Africa next month have just gone through a refresher course in current race relations problems and progress in this country.
New York churchgoers will have an opportunity this month to hear a number of well-known preachers from other cities. Host churches and their guest ministers will include:

SPRINGFIELD, N.J., June 30 -- JoAnn Prentice of Birmingham, Ala., shared the lead in the United States Women's Open golf championship today. But instead of pacing the field with Mickey Wright, as she did yesterday, Miss Prentice found her 36-hole score of 148 equaled by Ruth Jessen of Seattle.
PARIS, June 30 -- There has been a minor "gold rush" in Europe this week, and the price of gold on the various free markets has risen a little.

DALLAS, Tex., June 30 (UPI) -- James J. Ling, 38, who was stringing power lines in subdivisions fourteen years ago with a company he organized on a $3,000 stake, became the master of a $195,000,000 aircraft, missile and electronics company today.
FAIRFAX, Va., June 30 (UPI) -- A plan to set up just south of the nation's capital a city having the second largest area of any in the United States met rejection today.
Bonds redeemed in June and the first half of 1961 before maturity reached the highest totals for the periods in several years.
Stock trading on the New York Stock Exchange in the first six months of this year was the heaviest in the market's history.

The State Investigation Commission will meet next Thursday to decide whether to refer to the District Attorney the "conflict of testimony" concerning Joseph R. Weiss, the Deputy Superintendent of Schools.
Aircrafts and chemicals were strong in yesterday's sleepy session of the New York Stock Exchange. The list as a whole showed a moderate gain.

CHICAGO, June 30 (AP) -- Buying of soybean and corn futures increased today on the Board of Trade, but some moisture in the drought-ridden North Central states and Western Canada brought selling of the bread grains and oats.
New Jersey will contest the sale of television station WNTA-TV to the citizens' group that plans to convert it to a noncommercial educational station on Jan. 1.
Casts for the Empire State Music Festival operas have been announced.
SEOUL, Korea, June 30 -- Lieut. Gen. Guy S. Meloy Jr. of the United States Army succeeded Gen. Carter B. Magruder today as head of the United Nations Command in Korea.
The high-grade bond market rode out the month of June on a strong note yesterday.

The state Banking Department has added the Washington Water Power Company, the Chesapeake and Potomac Telephone Company, the Lehigh and New England Railroad Company and the Tennessee Valley Authority to its "legal list."

ATLANTIC CITY, June 30 -- The National Education Association, representing more than 765,000 teachers, went on record for the first time today in support of the 1954 Supreme Court decision on public school desegregation.
KUWAIT, July 1 -- The Supreme Council of Sheiks, which governs this state under Sheik Abdullah al-Salim, issued today the following statement on the Iraqi-Kuwait conflict:

Interest-bearing certificates of deposit that banks made available to corporate customers earlier this year have been a major factor in rising time deposits in the New York City banks, according to M.A. Shapiro Co., Inc., bank stock specialists.
NEW DELHI, India, June 21 -- India has agreed to allow a bit more self-reliance to her Himalayan protectorate of Sikkim.

The business trend changed direction in the first half of 1961, bringing to an end a period of recession that had lasted about ten months. All signs point to a continuation of the upward trend for the rest of the year and well into 1962.
BOSTON, July 1. -- The Yankee voices that stopped bulldozers at Walden Pond are being raised against the specter of swinging steel balls in Scollay Square.

Faced by a continuing surplus of productive capacity and growling competition from other materials, manufacturers of pulp and paper are stepping up their research activities in an effort to develop new products and markets.

Drought and grasshoppers have combined in recent weeks to produce a calamitous effect on the farmers of the upper Midwest. Thirty-two counties in North Dakota and seventeen in Minnesota, and parts of two other counties, have been declared drought disaster areas.
Monaco, Rapid of Austria and Dukla of Czechoslovakia will play at the Polo Grounds for the first time today in an International Soccer League double-header.

ST. LOUIS, July 1 (AP) -- August A. Busch Jr., the Cardinal's owner, said today Solly Hemus would finish the season as the St. Louis manager, despite the club's sixth-place standing, but indicated next year may be another story.

When the marketing managers of the Ford Foundation's latest offering of 2,750,000 common shares of Ford Motor Company stock got together last Monday evening to enter a touchy market, Wall Street was by no means sure that the ending would be the happy one it turned out to be.

Despite the talk of war and crisis and preparations for another diplomatic showdown, both Premier Khrushchev and President Kennedy had the time and the inclination last week to discuss the fundamental and long-range contest between their nations -- the economic contest.

TO the French, Marcel Pagnol's Marseilles trilogy is a legend. If not a major classic, it is certainly a minor one. In the late Twenties it was two chronological plays, "Marius" and "Fanny," followed by the film, "Cesar."

ONE of the most famous locomotives in the history of American railroading, the General, will be restored to operating condition by the Louisville and Nashville Railroad, which now controls it, so that it can play an active part in the Civil War Centennial.
Police Commissioner Michael J. Murphy assigned forty-eight additional men to the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn yesterday in the aftermath of a youth gang slaying late Friday night.
Closed-circuit television will lend a special touch to the maiden arrival of the new P O Orient Lines passenger ship Canberra when the 45,000-ton vessel steams into San Francisco July 20.

The number of students in the summer session at City College has set a record, including one who registered from behind the locked doors of a near-by lunch-eonette. A total of 11,745 students registered for the eight-week semester, slightly more than the summertime bulge of veterans in 1947.
NEW DELHI, India, June 26 The main bazaar of Delhi is suffering from a rise of suburbia.
SOONER or later most empires break up. And recently there was a great rending sound when National Concert and Artists Corporation and Civic Concert Service came apart.

WIMBLEDON, England, July 1 -- Neale Fraser of Australia, the defender, American titleholder and best amateur in tennis a year ago, came to the end of the line today in the all-England championships. He was crushed in a furious two-hour struggle by little Bobby Wilson of Britain.
TO those who are young it may seem that contract bridge has been going on forever; to those who are older the game seems relatively new, for they can remember a time when it did not exist.
BERLIN, July 1 -- East Germany called on its police forces today to increase vigilance and "nip in the bud" any provocation staged by "West German militarists."
Israel this summer will attract a large number of American Jewish Orthodox spiritual and lay leaders as well as students and teachers.

MADRIGALS AND MOTETS; Budapest Madrigal Ensemble, Ferenc Szekeres, conductor. (Monitor MC 2054). A perfectly delightful record comes from an unexpected source. This ensemble of sixteen singers was formed in 1952, and one of the things they project best is the pure joy of singing together.
ALBUQUERQUE, N.M., July 1 (AP) -- Don Bragg and J.D. Martin tonight shattered the world record for the decathlon pole vault as they soared 15 feet 1 1/2 inches.

THEODORE ROOSEVELT would have considered this a bully good book. William H. Harbaugh's new biography is a big, lusty volume, vigorous in style, outspoken and combative in its judgments. It has a further quality that T.R. would hardly have disapproved: it portrays Theodore Roosevelt as a very great man indeed.

I ENTERED the literary world late in the immediate post-war years when changes of literary taste and loyalty were already in the air. The first broadcast I gave was, I remember, an attack upon Virginia Woolf. Her books had nurtured me as an adolescent, and I was in reaction against her influence.
LAWRENCE, L.I., July 1 -- The police arrested three men here this afternoon minutes after they had allegedly ransacked an expensive home for $5,000 worth of jewelry and furs.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 1 -- The United Nations Security Council will meet at 11:30 o'clock tomorrow morning to consider a complaint by Kuwait that Iraq is threatening its territorial integrity.
IT is perhaps untimely news to break to a confident public only two days before the Glorious Fourth, but there appears to be a serious missile gap in the nation's fireworks.

WHITE PLAINS, July 1 -- This suburban city of fine homes and big stores in newer neighborhoods turned the corner this week toward achieving a $50,000,000 urban renewal program for the old deteriorated downtown core.

ONE of the mysteries of Hollywood is now an independent producer, guaranteed a good share of the profits of his picture, will receive nothing, though the picture seems quite successful at the box office. As one of the leading independent producers put it: "The studios can give you 100 per cent of the profits and you still won't get anything."

The National Council of Churches acted yesterday to mobilize Protestants to press for Congressional approval of an aid-to-education program that would exclude any grants or loans to parochial schools.

Retailers in the Tenth Federal Reserve District reported sales in the final week of the first sixth months of 1961 above last year's and that the cumulative increase of 5 per cent for the year to date was well ahead of the national average of 1 per cent.
ALTHOUGH the outdoor symphonic drama trend has failed to gain a foothold in this section of the country, it continues to grow and flourish further south.

MONTAUK, L.I., July 1 -- Wyandanch, the chief of the Montauks, beat Frank Tuma here by about 300 years but if the place is ever given back to the Indians -- or even given to the Martians -- the chances are Tuma still will be hailed.
PITTSBURGH, July 1 (AP) -- Willie McCovey's run-scoring double in the eighth inning -- his second of the game earned San Francisco a 4-3 triumph today over the Pittsburgh Pirates.

ATLANTIC CITY -- With summer officially here and the Fourth of July at hand, New Jersey's seaside resorts are launching a packed program of hot-weather activities to augment the miles of ocean and beachfront that are the prime attractions along the shore.

A Paulist theologian with close Vatican ties said yesterday that all Christians -- Protestant, Roman Catholic and Eastern Orthodox -- must shoulder the blame for what he described as the "scandal" of a divided Christendom.

THIS first novel by Jesse Hill Ford is not only a work of considerable promise; it is a strong and satisfying performance in its own right. Mr. Ford deals with love and hate, with birth and death in his home state of Tennessee.

WHEN refinishing wooden lawn furniture with varnish or enamel, homeowners should remember to coat the bottom ends of the legs at the same time as they do the rest of the piece. If not protected with paint or varnish, these unpainted ends will tend to absorb moisture from the ground.
Warner M. Willcox's Stardust captured International Class honors yesterday at the Bayside Yacht Club's Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound regatta.

Brisk consumer buying lifted department store sales in this area last week above the 1960 level. Merchants put the gain at about 3 per cent. Favorable weather and special promotions helped the stores post the gain. Merchants said the good business carried into almost all departments.

The sheikdom of Kuwait (population 310,000) is a torrid desert land the size of Connecticut at the head of the Persian Gulf. It is bordered on the north by Iraq, on the south by Saudi Arabia. Kuwait's oil reserves, estimated at sixty-two billion barrels, are twice those of the United States and one-third the reserves in the entire Middle East.

FIVE small herb gardens at Plimoth Plantation, Plymouth, Mass., are so exquisite in design and planting that modern gardeners might use them as models. The plantation, a recreation of the original Pilgrim colony, as it looked in 1627, is well worth a visit.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 1 -- Qualified estimates here indicate that the United States will not again be able to prevent the discussion of the admission of Communist China to the United Nations.
Herman Christian Nolen was a professor of marketing waiting to give a speech at a sales convention in the spring of 1947 when a fellow speaker fell dead.

Opening of a new film on the "Atlantis" theme reminds us how eternally fascinated we are with the idea of a lost continent. A huge number of books have been written on the existence -- or nonexistence -- of Atlantis, supposed by tradition to have have swallowed by the Atlantic Ocean thousands of years ago.

The New York Giants of the National Football League engineered one of their biggest trades in many a year yesterday when they sent three seasoned men to the new Minnesota Vikings in exchange for two players and two draft selections.

The state's prosecutors called upon Governor Rockefeller yesterday to join them in seeking a reversal of a United States Supreme Court decision forbidding the use of illegally seized evidence in state criminial trials.
