DURING World War II, Irwin Shaw wrote a short story which described a man walking away from a railroad station where he had bade good-by to his soldier sore As he wandered off in the gloom, he wondered whether he would ever see the boy again, and he bitterly reproached himself for his restraint and conservatism.
KUWAIT, July 1 -- British forces moved into Kuwait in a howling sandstorm today. They came in response to a call by Sheik Abdullah al-Salim al-Sabah for help against an Iraqi threat.
Reversing an earlier hands-off policy, the New York Civil Liberties Union is now supporting a Puerto Rican's court plea to be permitted to vote here if he proves his literacy in Spanish.

MIAMI, Fla., July 1 (AP) -- The ten Cuban prisoners who came here as a team for the tractors-for-prisoners deal said tonight they would attempt to negotiate with a new United States committee to free the 1,197 men being held in Havana.

THIRTY-ONE years ago Clarence Streit went to Geneva as a correspondent for this newspaper. He was a good and objective reporter. After ten years in Geneva he considered it his duty to stop being objective and to write a book advocating an international association that would succeed where the League of Nations was failing. He published "Union Now," first as a private edition in 1938, then through regular book channels in 1939.

I have read with interest your excellent June 19 editorial "To Test or Not to Test," in which you give reasons why it may be more dangerous to resume testing of atomic weapons than to continue the moratorium for a while.

I notice that the questions asked by reporters on news conference television programs are often more elaborate and longwinded than the answers by the persons interviewed. On one program recently, a noted columnist gave three or four minutes of rather familiar and laborious background information before coming to his question, which turned out to be obvious and dull.

Prices of most commodities, the raw materials for industry and the food we eat, are around the same levels today as at the beginning of the year, or slightly higher. However, there have been some wide price fluctuations during the first half of the year. The quotations for most of the items traded on the New York commodity futures exchanges moved independent of each other.

Dave Rosen is an amateur golfer who runs a pro shop without a course. But there are some who insist that he helps more players with their games than any other person in the metropolitan area.
CHILOQUIN, Ore., June 7 -- The red man has astonished his defenders and detractors as well as many neutral onlookers in southern Oregon.
MILWAUKEE, July 1 -- The Port of Milwaukee is running far ahead of the overseas commerce it had expected, Port Director Harry C. Brockel said today.

CENTRAL CITY, Colo., which was founded in 1859, quickly became a boom town as miners dug quantities of gold, silver and other minerals from the surrounding hills. With prosperity came one of Central City's most substantial buildings, its Opera House, which was completed in 1878.

Millions of Americans were enjoying a long week-end of rest and recreation yesterday at beaches, the mountains and in the comfort of their homes, but there were grim overtones as early traffic fatalities rose at a record pace.

The present beautifully printed volume contains his two early books of essays, "Ideas of Good and Evil" and "The Cutting of an Agate," with some later pieces and three of the introductions he wrote for that ill-fated edition.
The sight of homeless children huddled in a street doorway in Bogota so moved Joshua B. Powers that he started a campaign here to win support for an orphan asylum in the Colombian capital.
CHICAGO, June 27 (AP) -- An expert figured today that the adoption of tolls on inland waterways could result in a $281,000,000 annual increase in the nation's food costs.

Spotlighted before the remorseless cameras on the set of "Gigot," Jackie Gleason was trying to be funny. As everyone in the entertainment business knows, no undertaking could be more serious than that.

MORAN, Wyo. -- A tent village just completed in the heart of the vast wilderness of Grand Teton National Park here has met with such resounding success that officials of the National Park Service are hopeful it will set the pattern for similar developments in national parks throughout the West.

A court test of last week's Interstate Commerce Commission approval of Plan III and Plan IV piggyback rates was considered virtually certain as trucking industry leaders recovered from "shock" at the unexpected decision.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., July 1 -- Harold Dobson's Cibou II of the Manhasset Bay Thistle fleet won opening honors in the three-day interfleet series with City Island today.
MILWAUKEE, July 1 (AP) -- Lew Burdette scored his first victory of the season over Cincinnati today, 5 -- 1, but needed help from Don McMahon in the ninth.

BOSTON, July 1 (AP) -- Unbeaten Barry Latman, making his first pitching start for the Cleveland Indians, defeated the Boston Red Sox, 7 -- 3, today. The right-hander posted his seventh triumph as he scattered eleven hits.
ATLANTIC CITY, July 1 -- Harold Johnson of Philadelphia, the National Boxing Association's light-heavyweight champion, fought his way into the ranks of heavyweight contenders tonight.

STANTON, Del., July 1 (AP) -- Clipping one second off the grass-course record, Mrs. Stephen C. Clark Jr.'s Shield Bearer blazed to an easy front-running triumph today in the $31,300 Sussex Turf Handicap before 22,114 fans at Delaware Park.

JUDGING from the spring publishers' lists and those for the fall which I have so far seen, the production of books in 1961 promises at least to match the record set in 1960. District Attorney Frank D. O'Connor of Queens has broadened his inquiry into the school building program to include the selection of school sites and other matters.

BOSTON -- After years of brooding in granite majesty -- possibly over a fate that denied it the chance to fire a gun in anger -- Fort Warren on George's Island in Boston Harbor will be opened later this summer to begin a whole new career as a recreational establishment.

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- The Presidential intelligence board headed by Dr. James R. Killian Jr. is holding a series of secret meetings here this holiday week-end to develop proposals on reorganizing the Central Intelligence Agency.

OCEANPORT, N.J., July 1 -- Unraced since his victory in the Carter Handicap at Aqueduct on May 6, Mrs. Ada L. Rice's 4-year-old gelding, Chief of Chiefs, won the $28,050 Rumson Handicap at Monmouth Park today. Louis Lee Haggin 2d's Careless John, the 13-10 favorite, was a neck behind.
The stock market reflected indecision and caution last week on the part of traders and business men. There were reasons.
A big question facing Wall Street at midyear is, "The bond market: where is it going?"

BOGOTA, Colombia, July 1 -- Powerful leaders of Colombia's major political parties have begun formal negotiations to elect a Conservative President next year with coalition support.

When a worker -- top executive, editor, young man on the way up, secretary or stock room boy -- can see what he is doing and see it well, production goes up, spoilage and breakage are cut, labor turnover is reduced and absenteeism declines.

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- A step to provide United States ground forces in West Germany with vastly increased fire power through the new Davy Crockett rocket weapon was indicated today among possible military moves in the Berlin crisis.
"Change at the Broadway Bridge" will become as familiar over the next six months to bus riders in upper Manhattan as "Change at Jamaica" has been for Long Island Rail Road riders.

The smoldering medical controversy over the relative merits of the dead-virus polio vaccine, developed by Dr. Jonas E. Salk of the University of Pittsburgh, which is given by injection, and the attenuated live-virus polio vaccine, developed by Dr. Albert B. Sabin of the University of Cincinnati, which is given by mouth, flared up in the open last week at the annual meeting of the American Medical Association in New York City.
WARSAW, July 1 -- The Polish Communist party decreed an administrative reform this week that might eventually make life more agreeable for 30,000,000 Poles.

Carloadings increased substantially to 7,774 in the week ended on June 17. It weas the !highest weekly total since October, 1960 reflecting both seasonal factors and the upturn in steel production. Inbound traffic declined slightly to 4,533.
CALNE, England, July 1 -- Prime Minister Macmillan warned the Soviet Union today that there would be trouble if the Russians used force in Berlin.

WE took a long-awaited opportunity last week to interview an artist who has been making a quiet sensation in art circles lately -- Miss Amy Crush, whose paintings executed entirely in raspberry jam have contributed significantly to contemporary explorations of new methods and materials.

PANAMA, July 1 -- Exports of shrimp from Panama reached a new high of 10,598,653 pounds in 1960, the fisheries division of the Panama Government has reported. The export value of the record shipment was set at $6,000,000.

MILFORD HAVEN, Wales, June 26 (Reuters) -- The charred and badly damaged 1,845-ton Israeli cargo ship Etrog was refloated here today after firemen had put out a thirty-hour blaze that threatened to capsize the vessel. She had been beached to fight the fire.

GREENWICH, Conn., July 1 -- Mills H. Husted's Rumour II led the Indian Harbor Luders-16 Class sloops in today's regatta conducted by the Riverside Yacht Club. Andrew Kostanecki's Climax took the 110 Class race, and Walt Pierson, accompanied by Debbie Ashley, sailed the winning Blue Jay ahead of eleven rivals.
SPRINGFIELD, N.J., July 1 -- Mary Kathryn (Mickey) Wright, a slim, blonde player from San Diego, Calif., became the Women's United States Open golf champion today.
GREENWICH, Conn., July 1 -- Light air apparently has slowed the progress of yachts competing in the fourth annual Greenwich Cup race around Long Island.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 1 (AP) -- Richard Gump, a third-generation capitalist, says he doesn't think business should be taken seriously.
State Controller Arthur Levitt was reported yesterday to be stiffening his resistance to a possible offer to run in the Democratic primary against Mayor Wagner.

ALGIERS, July 1 -- A Moslem strike call in support of the rebel National Liberation Front turned into a riot here and in Blida today. Ten persons were killed and seventy-one wounded, most of them demonstrators.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 1 -- The first expansive survey of the Indian Ocean will start next year in an effort to provide new sources of food for a quarter of the world's population.

KUWAIT, July 1 -- When Britain on June 19 exchanged an anachronistic treaty of protection with Kuwait for a more modern treaty of friendship, consultation and assistance, few Kuwaitis took much notice. Nothing changed in Kuwait except a few papers.

TO the audiences of Moscow, Leningrad, Minsk, Rostov, Baku and Tiflis, my recent concert tour of the Soviet Union may have meant merely the importation of another American violinist. TUNIS, July 1 -- Reports circulated here tonight in usually well-informed circles that ministers of the Tunisian and the Algerian nationalist Provisional Governments had reached agreement on the difficult Saharan question during a meeting that lasted from 10 A.M. to 5 P.M.

BELFAST, Northern Ireland, June 29 -- A multimillion-dollar plant for the manufacture of isocyanates, a basic raw material used in the production of urethane foams, will be built by E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co. at its Londonderry site, it was announced today.

WESTBURY, L.I., July 1 -- Del Miller, the harness racing driver who has made a habit of winning the big ones, settled for a little one tonight at Roosevelt Raceway. Raubinger, New Jersey State Commissioner of Education, warned that teaching machines, along with television and other "technological devices" threaten to "destroy diversity and place pupils in molds."

The usual slackening of late June in big store sales was a bit accentuated here as volume last week in the St. Louis area slipped 24 per cent below that of the preceding week and 6 per cent below a year ago. One of the chief factors was the continued cool weather.

NEW ORLEANS -- The New Orleans Tourist Bureau reports that much of the mail it receives from prospective visitors asks, "Where can I stay in the French Quarter?" For many years, this was a difficult question for the bureau because the Quarter provided limited very accommodations.
CAMBRIDGE, England -- Oxonians are inclined to refer disparagingly to Cambridge University as "the other place," thus inferring that in their opinion Cambridge is somewhat inferior.
General of the Army Douglas MacArthur left New York International Airport shortly before noon yesterday to begin what he called a "sentimental journey" to the Philippines.

LOS ANGELES, July 1 (AP) -- Bill Nieder, the world shot-put record-holder, today urged a campaign to "clean up the ranks of officials and policies of the national A.A.U. and give the athletes a break."

POMPANO BEACH, Fla. -- After one failure, harness racing with pari-mutuel betting is slated to make a comeback in Florida. In a somewhat surprising vote, the State Legislature overrode Gov. Farris Bryant's veto of bills to permit the establishment of sulky tracks here at Pompano Beach and near Sanford.

PARIS, July 1 -- President de Gaulle made two speeches today voicing hopes for international and domestic peace against a background of bloody rioting by Moslems in Algeria and demonstrations by angry farmers in central and southern France.

THOSE who read and think can only be grateful to Claude Levi-Strauss that he at last overcame his loathings "of writings of travels and travelers" to write on his own anthropological explorations into Brazil. It is at times a bitter book -- "What travel has now to show us is the filthy, our filth that we have thrown into the face of humanity" -- but is, more often that not, ironical.
Prof. Julius Goebel Jr., legal historian, left Columbia University last week after forty years of teaching there, to give full time to reading and writing in his field.

THE recent International Rhododendron Conference, the first ever to be staged in this country, was a horticultural highlight of the 1961 spring season. Sponsored by the American Rhododendron Society, the three-day conference attracted 250 registrants to the meetings in Portland, Ore.

GUATEMALA CITY -- Many commercial launches ply both coasts of Central America, often to coastal points that can be reached in no other way. Almost any sizable port has at least one such company, and in every port one hears talk of islands worth a visit.

WHY would a European tourist want to visit America? What an extraordinary question! Yet it was posed, in haft-seriousness at least, by Mr. Holden. My reply would be: Because it's there, because it's America, because it's the most fascinating, variegated, vulgar, sophisticated, ugly, beautiful, exciting country in the world. Not to mention important.

A fearful new nuclear weapon called the neutron bomb, until recently a top secret, is now being openly discussed. Unlike the present atomic weapons, it would not destroy and kill by the heat and blast effects of the explosion. It would, rather, by its action as a "death ray," kill all personnel within a limited area by a burst of lethal neutrons.

THE Fourth of July week-end marks the full arrival of summer. To make this relaxed season of outdoor living easier than ever to enjoy, manufacturers of leisure-time equipment have been busy this year refining old ideas and producing good-looking new ones.

Long Island Sound ports are full of yachtsmen who wear grooves in the water between City Island, Manhasset Bay and Lloyd Harbor. Back and forth they go, Execution Light to Lloyd's, month after month, season after season.

"HE is little more than a 'deformation professionelle,'" said Jean Cocteau of the dancer, Vaslav Nijinsky. He meant that Nijinsky's personality and physique mysteriously blended to incandescence upon the stage, while offstage he was a cipher.

A variety of a Rumanian winter sports series, released this spring, has been turned up by Martin Sellinger and M. Bernstein of White Plains. The variety might be considered something of a freak, inasmuch as it appears on a canceled-to-order block of four of the perforated issue of this set, the 55 bani, blue and gray, depicting a skier in air.

A report issued by the United States Office of Education in May has unexpectedly become a rallying point for fears of Federally controlled education. Last week, Homer D. Babbidge Jr., Assistant United States Commissioner of Education, considered the controversy over the report serious enough to warrant refutation.

Travel by Americans to Western Europe last spring and so far this summer has fallen off, after a decade of uninterrupted rise that culminated in the record year of 1960. However, there are signs that the trend already has been reversed.

CHICAGO, July 1 (AP) -- Will Ye, owned by George H. Willis of Chicago, scored a one-and-a-quarter-length victory in the $21,600 Arch Ward Memorail Handicap at Arlington Park today. Winonly, the 7-5 favorite of the crowd of 23,665, finished second.

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- Not a horn blew. Not one Government official walked around with a funny hat. Not a note of "Auld Lang Syne" was heard anywhere around here. The new fiscal year of 1962 began quietly today.

Commuters and Connecticut residents protested yesterday against any cut in passenger service on the New Haven Railroad and called for the Government to run it if it goes into bankruptcy this week, as predicted in Washington.
Globemaster adhered to his pattern of running in front and won the Saranac Handicap at Aqueduct yesterday.

Call the customer engineer! This is the command sounded when trouble develops with a computer. And this technician is usually the one who gets the machine -- and the data processing system of which it is a part -- started again.
The country's subsidized steamship industry last week chose Vice Admiral John M. Will, retired, as its chief spokesman.
WASHINGTON, July 1 (UPI) -- The nation's bachelors outnumber single women by more than three million.

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector). RECENTLY a delegation of court attorneys visited Ratisbonne Hall, the old French monastery in Jerusalem, where the Eichmann trial is being shown on closed-circuit television each weekday to the 570 persons who get there first.

One of Mr. Goldman's examples, used to exemplify agitation, was the U.A.W.'s sit-down strike. While Mr. Goldman aptly points out that this eventually won U.A.W. recognition, I object to that union's and other unions', "unabashed violence."

THE average young homemaker of colonial times had a garden suited to her needs. Even with household help she was a real do-it-yourself worker. There were no machines to help her with spinning, candle making and the countless other chores that filled her day, so the colonial garden had to be easy to maintain.

Reference was once made in this column to a form of advertising that was unusually effective. It was a word-of-mouth kind that might be labeled the Chicago school of marketing of the Nineteen Twenties. It consisted of an insistent tap on the shoulder and the rather ominous advice: "You buy your beer from the boss, or else."

BALTIMORE, July I -- The league-leading Detroit Tigers continued their domination of the Baltimore Orioles today, scoring four runs in the eleventh inning for an 11-8 victory. It was the second successive extra-inning triumph here for the Tigers, who have won five straight games in Baltimore and have a 6-1 edge over the Orioles this season.

Historian Eric F. Goldman's article on the integration problem ("Progress -- By Moderation and Agitation," July 18) was illuminating, but, I would suggest, a bit too tolerant and optimistic. Seven years after the Supreme Court's first ruling, we find integration of Southern schools nonexistent in several states, and only on a token basis in others.
Efforts to settle the sixteen-day-old maritime strike took a sudden turn for the better early today.

With ominous thunderclouds gathering again over Europe, the Western powers have to realize that a united Western front is the best and possibly only chance to avert a conflict that could turn into an even greater holocaust than in 1914 and 1939. The new unity, which in the face of a common peril must and does rise above any secondary differences, manifests itself in common military precautions.

Here -- a bright quartet of beach fashions calculated to add relish to week-end wardrobes through the summer. Rare finds this late in the season, they are available in stores now. All are in gleaming white -- smartest color near the water. Three are spiked with sharp blue trim.

BABYLON, L.I., July 1 -- A fleet of more than 170 craft had ideal sailing conditions today as the Babylon Yacht Club's weekend regatta got underway. A so'wester, somewhat unstable at the start, freshened for the afternoon.
In an effort to avoid unnecessary costs in the expensive jet age, American Airlines has called-for industry cooperation in common purchasing and use of ground servicing equipment.
MIAMI BEACH, July 1 -- James R. Hoffa is slated to become the country's highest-paid union president at the convention of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters here next week.

SEATTLE -- The municipal hydroelectric project deep in the Cascade Mountains wilderness that furnishes this metropolis of the Northwest with its electric power is a matter of much civic pride. And with its spectacular setting, it holds such fascination for sightseers that conducted tours of it have been organized for the summer months.

TALLAHASSEE, Fla. -- A wide-scale promotional campaign aimed at attracting more tourists to the Sunshine State on a year-around basis is under way here, and a highlight of the program will be a contest with cash awards for the best letters written on "Why I Enjoyed My Florida Vacation This Summer."
WARSAW, July 1 -- The Executive Committee of the Lutheran World Federation issued an appeal to all peoples today to foster peace and better relations among nations.

Steamship operators and the stevedore contractors who handle their cargoes testified last week in support of a bill that would bar longshoremen from filing liability claims based on the seaworthiness of vessels.
AN injustice was done on Sunday, June 18, television page to a large number of American, European and Canadian filmmakers, including the undersigned.

THE nation's book dealers -- members of the American Booksellers Association -- met in Washington the other day. A scout whose ears were so close to the ground they constantly were being trampled, has turned in his report. Mood down there was of cautious optimism.

CHICAGO, July 1 (AP) -- The Chicago Cubs put together a sixteen-hit attack, a seven-run fifth inning and three home runs to jolt the St. Louis Cardinals, 13 -- 1, today. It was only Chicago's third victory in eleven games against the Cards.

RHEIMS, France, July 1 -- The Grand Prix De France, counting for the race-car drivers' world championship, will be staged tomorrow at nearly 130 miles an hour, in bright sunlight probably, before 50,000 or more champagne-swilling customers.

MOSCOW, July 1 -- Jay Silvester of the United States Army, the American champion in the discus throw, did well below his best performance today. He took only third place in a track and field meet staged in honor of the "Brothers Znamensky, War Heroes."

UNITED NATIONS N.Y., July 1 -- After a hiatus during the two preceding years, expansion of world beef production resumed in 1960 so markedly that a new record was established, as indicated by statistics of the Food and Agriculture Organization.
Political confusion runs high this year in New York City and there is widespread speculation about the possibility of electing a Republican as mayor in a town that is overwhelmingly Democratic.
SPRINGFIELD, Ill., July 1 -- Illinois worked its way out of a fiscal corner today when the state began collecting an extra half-cent sales tax.

Employment in Pennsylvania advanced 93,000 to 4,229,000 between the recession's February low point and mid-May. During the four weeks ended in mid-May employment rose 33,800, a gain that exceeded the normal seasonal increase by nearly 33 per cent, according to the Pennsylvania Department of Labor and Industry.
Business continued to show improvement during June, the National Association of Purchasing Agents reported last week, following a survey of members.
MOSCOW, June 24 -- Dr. Claude S. Beck, a noted United States heart surgeon, has found support among Soviet scientists for his thesis that the "dead" too often are neglected.
BUENOS AIRES, June 30 -- President Arturo Frondizi's attempts this week to gain the support of the restive General Labor Federation for his latest economic plans have been brusquely rebuffed.

HYANNIS PORT, Mass., July 1 -- President Kennedy celebrated his first fiscal new year's day in office today by indulging in a favorite outdoor recreation -- boating. A breezy day lured Mr. and Mrs. Kennedy to a two-and-a-half-hour afternoon cruise on Nantucket Sound aboard the Kennedy family's cabin cruiser, the Marlin.

IN the past sixty years the world has been turned upside down and inside out. New ways of making things, of doing things, of transporting our thoughts and ourselves have dislocated all the old familiar arrangements.

President Kennedy will be getting as much rest as possible during the long holiday week-end at his summer home at Hyannis Port, Cape Cod. But Mr. Kennedy had to take his briefcase to the shore, along with his bathing suit and golf clubs. The telephone will ring more often and more insistently than for other men.

A FEW weeks ago, 300 Viet Cong (Vietnamese Communist) guerrillas raided the village of Bentranh in the rich Mekong delta of South Vietnam. Nguyen Thanh, a rice-grower whose family has lived in Bentranh for countless generations, did not care to talk about the incident.

WASHINGTON, July 1 -- When they tidied up the Declaration of Independence 185 year's ago this weekend, the Founding Fathers made a couple of observations about human nature that are highly relevant to the West's political crisis today.

ALBANY, July 1 -- New York State said today it could not agree at this time to grant New Jersey residents employed in this state the liberalized personal income tax deductions approved earlier this year for nonresidents working in New York.

The Board of Education announced yesterday it would decide as soon as possible on plans for a vote on how collective bargaining for public school teachers is to be put into effect. It said Friday's election clearly showed they want it.
THERE is a prevalence of Shakespeare in the pleasant town of Stratford, which sits comfortably on the plain of Western Ontario.

THE British Isles are the habitat of the zoophilist. There are probably more animal lovers per square inch than in any other part of the world. As well as the normal run of enthusiasts who found homes for ancient horses or beauty parlors for poodles, there are the earnest budgerigar and canary breeders, people who keep alligators in their baths, pythons in their pockets or jars of stick insects on the dining room table.

David Sarnoff, board chairman of the Radio Corporation of America, told the National Press Club in Washington last week that R.C.A. has developed plans for establishing -- through remotely controlled electronic equipment -- a well stocked camp on the moon complete with food, water and power before the first man arrives there.

YONKERS, July 1 -- John Botts 3d of the Bronxville Field Club upset the defender, top-seeded William Tully of the Racquet Club of Yonkers, 1 -- 6, 6 -- 3, 6 -- 4, in the first round of the Paul Martin Memorial tennis tournament today.

GORE VIDAL, a playwright-scenarist-writer, who is more successful than most of his compatriots, is working, very quietly, on another screen project. This, Mr. Vidal revealed, "is the story of a contemporary demagogue, who happens to be a Senator."

SUMMER can be a difficult time for lawns, especially where spring rains have spurred grass into lush, tender growth that can fall prey to burning sun and hot breezes. Lawn success in the trying weeks ahead demands proper mowing, correct watering, timely weed and crabgrass control and a watchful eye for insect and disease damage.

All independent food store merchants are not being squeezed out by the chains. On the contrary, many are prospering.
MEXICO CITY, July 1 -- Mexicans will go to the polls tomorrow to elect a new House of Representatives in possibly the greatest number ever.
ROME, July 1 -- The Vatican newspaper L'Osservatore Romano observed its 100th birthday today.
BRITAIN'S carefully supervised commercial television, now in its fifth year, is earning impressive profits and has grown as much as it can under existing conditions.

Roger Maris and Mickey Mantle, the Yankees' one-two punch; Willie Mays of San Francisco and Eddie Mathews of Milwaukee were the only repeaters from 1960 named yesterday to the starting line-ups for the All-Star baseball games on July 11 at San Francisco and on July 31 at Boston.
GOLDENS BRIDGE, N.Y., July 1 -- Cutty Sark, a black mare owned by Margaret Spencer of Bedford Hills, N.Y., captured the green working hunter championship of the Goldens Bridge Horse Show today.
WOLFSBURG Germany, July 1 -- More than 7,000 West Germans converged on this city today to exercise their rights as new owners in Europe's biggest car manufacturer.
JERSEY CITY, July 1 -- This city today switched its form of government from the five-man City Commission to a Mayor and nine-member City Council.

By 9 A.M. tomorrow a Taft-Hartley board of inquiry into the maritime strike is required to make a report to President Kennedy on whether the walkout has caused a national emergency warranting further Presidential action. Yesterday the prospect of a settlement that would forestall resort to the law's full emergency procedures appeared dim.
THE hearings of the Federal Communications Commission, which have just ended a two-week run in New York, contain nothing new or surprising for either the industry or the viewer.

FIVE country homes in New Milford, Conn. will be open to the public on Saturday when the New Milford Garden Club stages a house tour and flower show. Visitors will be welcome from 1 to 5:30 o'clock in the afternoon.

MANILA, June 27 -- The Philippines is girding herself for four months of rough-and-tumble politics as the island republic moves into what is expected to be the hardest-fought campaign in years.

The opinion is commonly expressed by bankers, industrial executives and business analysts that the trend toward recovery was not quite as vigorous in June as had been the case in April and May. All of these people report continued improvement but at a decelerated rate.
Retailers were buying confidently for fall, resident buying offices reported last week. Better coats along with dress and sportswear lines were active, the buying offices said.

MADRID, June 25 -- The Spanish monarchist movement is in the phase marked by growing public indifference on the one land and active repressions by regime of Generalissimo Francisco Franco on the other. Lor for many years have top Spanish monarchists appeared pessimistic.
WASHINGTON, July 1 -- The appointment this week of General Maxwell D. Taylor as military representative of the President caused mixed emotions in Washington, particularly in the Pentagon.
LOS ANGELES, July 1 (AP) -- Mickey Cohen was sentenced today to fifteen years in prison and was fined $30,000 for Federal income tax evasion.

WASHINGTON, July 1 (AP) -- The tracking and communications network that will link America's first orbited spaceman with earth will be tested late this summer with a 100-pound satellite, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration said today.

LIME ROCK, Conn., July 1 -- Roger Penske of Villanova, Pa., beat Palmer Ryan of Montreal by eight-tenths-of a second today in the feature national sports car race at Line Rock Park. Penske averaged 81.91 miles an hour for thirty laps over the mile-and-a-half course.

WASHINGTON, July 1. -- Labor Department attorneys are looking for a way to eliminate segregation in one of the most sensitive areas touching on job employment in the South -- the state employment offices.

The beebalms are now in bloom, and bumblebees and hummingbirds are celebrating. The raggedy, untidy heads of bloom are their particular delight, the nectar stores reserved to the long tongue and the long, slim beak. He who would know hummingbirds seeks out the beebalm in the meadow; and he who would have hummingbirds in his yard sees to it that beebalm, especially the crimson-flowered variety, has a corner of his garden.

LIKE the Army mule and musket, the fife and drum corps, with its measured cadence of 110 beats a minute, its airs rooted in folk ballads and its richly colorful uniforms, has for the most part slipped away into oblivion.
WASHINGTON, July 1 -- The United States endorsed today Britain's action in sending troops to Kuwait as a measure of protection against claims on the sheikdom by neighboring Iraq.

WITH the publication of these two volumes the monumental "Collected Writings of Walt Whitman" makes its debut. Twelve more volumes -- like these two under the general editorship of Gay Wilson Allen and Sculley Bradley -- are promised.

WORK will start on New York's newest television station, an ultrahigh-frequency affair to be called, appropriately, WUHF, in two weeks. If everything goes according to plan New York City, working through its broadcasting unit, WNYC, will find itself a major programer, filling perhaps as much as fifty-six hours of time a week.

Commercial construction in the Chicago area in the first five months of this year was valued at $126,721,000, the Chicago Association of Commerce and Industry reported. In April sixty-four projects had a value of $36,516,000.

AUCKLAND, N.Z. -- This little island nation is less than 1,000 miles long, covering an area equal to New York, New Jersey and Pennsylvania. Yet, New Zealand packs in as much scenic beauty and natural wonders as a continent.
KANSAS CITY, July 1 (AP) -- The Minnesota Twins defeated Kansas City, 9 -- 3, today. Harmon Killebrew hit a grand-slam homer in the ninth inning.

TUSTIN, Calif., July 1 (AP) -- A blonde with the vigor of the California forty-niners and about as much gold is helping change a historic 93,000-acre ranch into a sprawling suburbia, just at freeway hop from Los Angeles.
TRENTON, July 1 (AP) -- Jimmy Davies of Gardena, Calif., the national midget car champion, set two world records for one-mile paved speedways today.

RALPH HOUK, the new manager of the New York Yankees, is in the exquisitely uncomfortable position of having for a predecessor the most successful master-mind in major-league history, to say nothing of one who, in an era in which baseball became an integral part of show business, was also an accomplished pantomimist and double-talker, combining the talents of both the late Willie Howard (visually) and his vis-a-vis, Al Kelly (verbally).

BANGOR, Me. -- An ambitious program of the State of Maine to restore and care for its ten remaining covered bridges in their old age is rapidly nearing completion. Here in Bangor, within the city limits on Valley Avenue, the largest project of the entire rehabilitation program is well under way.

Although yearly percentage increases in the purchasing power of a teacher's pay check are beginning to keep pace with percentage increases for industrial workers, the gap between the two groups is still enormous. Only since 1953 have educators' and workers' salaries increased at the same percentage rate.
LONDON, July 1 -- The Foreign Office announced today that the military forces landed in Kuwait were in response to an "urgent and formal request" by the ruler of the sheikdom.

NEW DELHI, India, June 29 -- A thirteen-page statement and a three-hour speech reminded Indians today of a one-time national hero many of them would prefer to forget -- Shiek Mohammed Abdullah of the State of Jammu and Kashmir.
ATLANTA, July 1 -- This city expects to demonstrate on Aug. 30 that careful preparation can prevent the violence that has accompanied public school desegregation in some Southern areas.

GENEVA, July 1 -- Britain and the Soviet Union agreed today on instructions to the International Control Commission in Laos to enable it to procure equipment to police the ceasefire in that country.

Once outside of New York City and beyond the dreary miles of second-hand-car-dealer lots, one encounters men and women of such friendly feelings, and manifestations of such understanding as you rarely meet in Europe.
GREENWICH, Conn., July 1 -- Henry Mercer's Weatherly, four times a loser in the Long Island Sound phase of the season's competition for 12-meter yachts, made up for past disappointments today.

THE most dramatic development in radio broadcasting since the introduction of frequency modulation (FM) is now a practical reality. THE largest assemblage of musical scholars ever to gather in the United States will meet in the New York area from Sept. 5 to 11. This will be the Eighth Congress of the International Society for Musicology, an organization formed in 1927, with headquarters in Basle, Switzerland, and this will be its first meeting in this country.

IN little more than a week, Paul Pender will defend his fractional share of the world middleweight championship against Terry Domes in London. Within a month of that epic clash between ring titans, Gene Fullmer will defend his fractional share of the same crown against Florentino Fernandez in Fullmer's Utah backyard on an equally historic occasion.

WIMBLEDON, England, July 2 -- There never seems time during this hectic fortnight to watch the girls who play at tennis in the latest frills and fashions. Or to see Jean Borotra, the old Bounding Basque, who won here twice in the Nineten Twenties cavorting in the mixed doubles with his pigtailed French partner.

ALBANY, July 2 -- Democratic legislative leaders renewed their plea today to consider separately the proposal authorizing the Port of New York Authority to acquire the Hudson and Manhattan Railroad and to build a World Trade Center in Manhattan.

BABYLON, L.I., July 3 -- An informal regatta was held at the Babylon Yacht Club today, with most of the skippers taking the day off in preparation for tomorrow's finale of the annual Fourth of July weekend regatta.

TORONTO, July 3 (Canadian Press) -- Clairtone Sound Corporation Ltd. announced today that it had acquired merchandising rights in Canada and the United States for all radio-stereo record-player and sound-reproducing products manufactured by Max Braun Company of Frankfurt, Germany.

WASHINGTON, July 3 (UPI) -- Imports of new automobiles in the first half of 1961 were at a low level, largely because of the successful competition of the new United States compact models with the European and Japanese low-price small cars.

TRENTON, July 3 -- The problem whether New Jersey residents are to receive the benefits if liberalized deductions now provided in the New York State income tax law remains solely with Albany, officials here indict.

SOUNDING a long blast on the whistle, Captain Charles M. Hyde backed her out of Pier 43 into the river. "She has twin rudders," he said approvingly. "She backs as easy as she goes forward. I could back her to Albany."
WASHINGTON, July 3 -- The United States and Japan have failed to agree on Japan Air Lines' proposal for a route to New York City and beyond.

Wall Street was in pretty much of a holiday mood yesterday. Trading on the New York Stock Exchange dried up to the smallest amount in more than eight months, while prices showed a moderate gain on average.
There apparently is no doubt now that Ralph Houk and Bob Scheffing are beginning to wilt in the heat of the American League pennant race.

FURNISHING a home need not be a ponderous process in which each piece takes months to find. It took Martin Henry Miller only two hours and seven minutes to select most of the furnishings for an apartment (which he didn't have at the time) while on a business trip abroad.
HELSINKI, Finland, July 3 -- Vieno J. Sukselainen's resignation as Premier of Finland has been accepted by President Urho Kekkonen and the whole Government has resigned with him.
HYANNIS PORT, Mass., July 3 -- Mrs. John F. Kennedy's fine-arts hunt has already yielded a rich harvest of history-laden furniture, furnishings, paintings and other decorative creations.

GRAND BLANC, Mich., July 3 (UPI) -- Jack Burke Jr. of Kiamesha Lake, N.Y., shot a one-under-par 71 today to win the $52,000 Buick open golf tournament. His rivals in an 18-hole play-off, Bill Casper Jr. and Johnny Pott, carded 74's.

The Marine Midland Trust Company had net operating earnings of $3,259,779 for the six months ended last Friday, compared with $3,140,369 for the 1960 period. The profit equaled $2.61 a share, against $2.51 for the 1960 period.

KUWAIT, July 3 -- Brigadier Derek Gordon Horsford, commander of the British troops in Kuwait, announced today that his men now numbered more than 3,000 and had penetrated to within five miles of the Iraq border.

The Shamrock Oil and Gas Corporation and its subsidiaries reported yesterday that net income for the six months ended on May 31 was $4,810,651, equal to 98 cents a share, on gross revenues of $30,443,022.

A court order temporarily halting the maritime strike was issued last night at the request of President Kennedy. Federal Judge Sylvester J. Ryan issued the order under the provisions of the Taft-Hartley Act.
PARIS, July 3 -- Western Europe moved another smart step toward free trade today.

St. Lawrence Seaway cargo tonnage in April and May was up 20.7 per cent on the Montreal-Lake Ontario section and 1.1 per cent on the Welland Canal over the same period last year, authorities have announced.

HONG KONG, July 3 -- George W. Ball, Under Secretary of State for Economic Affairs, asked Hong Kong's cooperation today in Washington's effort to bring this British colony's high level of textile exports to the United States under control.

CHICAGO, July 3 -- The Midwest Stock Exchange today announced a series of amendments to its rules, including some of those under which the exchange checks on the operations of specialists on its floor.

When a building becomes a trade center, as several major showroom structures in the city have, its owners are challenged to provide unusual services from which the tenants can benefit as occupants of an industry hub.

WICHITA, Kan., July 3 (AP) -- Robert Martin, trustee in bankruptcy, today reported court and creditor approval of sale of the E.C. Wedell Properties to a syndicate headed by Edwin James, Kansas City certified public accountant and investor.
WASHINGTON, July 3 (UPI) -- Secretary of Labor Arthur J. Goldberg announced today the establishment of twenty labor relations committees to head off strikes at government missile sites.

What a sad letter for a distinguished man of science to write! I am referring to Harold C. Urey' letter published June 25. It indicates a distorted sense of values and a limited comprehension of human problems.
MIAMI, July 3 -- A Cuban plane was hijacked and flown to Miami today after a pro-Castro militiaman was shot during a flight from Havana to Varadero Cuba.

Institutional Growth Fund and Institutional Foundation Fund reported yesterday combined net assets of $190,190,719 on May 31, reflecting a gain of 26 per cent from the $150,032, 293 reported on Nov. 30, 1960, end of the fiscal year.

Middle South Utilities, Inc., and subsidiaries reported yesterday a gain of 7.1 per cent in electric operating revenues for the first five months of 1961. However, operating revenues fell one-half of per cent below the 1960 level.

WASHINGTON, July 3 (AP) -- Secretary of Agriculture Orville L. Freeman imposed today limitations on sales of Government stocks of oats, barley and corn. The aim is to conserve supplies to meet possible needs of drought-plagued livestock farmers in the northern Great Plains.
PEARL necklaces are getting longer, platinum is being mated with gold, and carats have no place at breakfast.

Used to be, when kids were kids and fun had fairly well defined borders, that a policeman had only to scowl or maybe tap his nightstick on the curb to send the youngsters fleeing from gushing fire hydrants.
BERLIN, July 3 -- Gen. Bruce C. Clarke, commander of the United States Army in Europe, warned here today that American troops "cannot be too well prepared for the missions that may lie ahead."
Hundreds of millions of dollars worth of construction in this city and on Long Island was slowed and in some cases halted yesterday as a strike of 2,000 truck drivers took hold.
KETCHUM, Idaho, July 3 -- There will be no inquest in the shotgun death of Ernest Hemingway, Blaine County authorities decided today.

The public emergence of Maj. Gen. Pak Chung Hi as the strong man of anti-Communist South Korea comes as no surprise. It was a move in the making ever since the early morning hours of May 16, when the military coup d'etat suddenly struck in that half of "The Land of the Morning Calm."

MEXICO CITY, July 3 -- The Administration's Revolutionary Institutional party appeared today to be headed for a clean sweep of the 178 seats in the House of Deputies as a result of yesterday's election.
Three of the clubs that saw action in Sunday's International Soccer League double-header at the Polo Grounds will return today.

WIMBLEDON, England, July -- Chuck McKinley of St. Louis reached the semi-finals of men's singles today in the all-England tennis championship. By sheer weight of stroke, he smashed the delicate control of Bobby Wilson of Britain and triumphed, 6 -- 4, 6 -- 4, 4 -- 6, 6 -- 4.

The Westinghouse Electric Corporation plans to enter the transport cooling equipment business. The giant electrical manufacturing company announced yesterday an agree ment to purchase the assets of the Thermo-King Corporation in return for common stock.

IF booming noises are heard in the vicinity of the Yankee Stadium on this glorious Fourth of July, they will not necessarily be fireworks. They may be made by the Yankees on a Tiger hunt, letting blast with their favorite instrument of destruction, the elephant gun. Purists frown on the use of such a high-powered weapon for anything less than elephants.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector) July 3 -- The counsel for Adolf Eichmann said today that the Nazi Foreign Ministry took the initiative for the deportation and slaughter of 500,000 Hungarian Jews.
BALTIMORE, July 3 (UPI) -- Milt Pappas held Cleveland to four hits and Gus Triandos drove in three runs with a single and a homer tonight as the Baltimore Orioles defeated the Indians, 5 -- 0.
Operating costs of Manhattan buildings, reckoned on a square-foot basis, are lower for large buildings than for small ones, according to a recent study.

Columbia University has purchased six contiguous parcels, totaling about 45,000 square feet, on Broadway, between Sixty-third and Sixty-fourth Streets, from Chapel Hill, Inc., an affiliate of Riverside Memorial Chapel, Inc.

John Somerville in his letter published June 23 says, with respect to both the Declaration of Independence and Communist doctrine, that "forcible revolution is justified only when the government in question is a tyranny which is unwilling to carry out peacefully the will of the majority, and the masses (majority) support revolutionary measures."

Federal intervention in the maritime strike, now moving into the next stages of the Taft-Hartley process, has not been successful; but it has pointed up certain facts and it has raised some compelling questions.

ALBUQUERQUE, N.M., July 3 (UPI) -- Twenty-year-old Paul Herman of Westmont (Calif.) College received his certification today from the Amateur Athletic Union as the national decathlon champion. But it wasn't cut and dried.

VALHALLA, N.Y., July 3 -- Residents of a big school district in the commuter belt of central Westchester County were embroiled today in a controversy over a school budget they have twice rejected. It will come up for a third vote on Wednesday.

LUANDA, Angola, July 3 -- Rebels in northern Angola, mostly Bakongo, are killing Africans of other tribes that maintain loyalty to Portuguese authorities and cooperate in agricultural work and other activities.
FARMVILLE, Va., July 3 -- More than 200 Negro children in Prince Edward County started today their first formal schooling in two years.
Last week's upturn in bond prices carried over into the eve of the Fourth of July holiday yesterday.

MANILA, July 3 -- General of the Army Douglas MacArthur returned today to the Philippines, to a land he has long known and to a people he has loved. Nearly 2,000,000 Filipinos turned out to greet their World War II liberator, who is on a ten-day sentimental journey to the scenes of some of his famous battles.

DAMASCUS, Syria, July 2 (AP) -- The American-owned Trans Arabian Pipeline Company has agreed in principle to double the annual payment for the passage of its pipeline across Syrian territory, the semiofficial Middle East News Agency said today.

ELIZABETH, N.J., July 3 -- State Senator Robert C. Crane, a Union County Republican leader, said today he would ask the Federal Government to appoint a commission to find a suitable New Jersey site for an "international jetport."
The transport of grain, the world's principal cargo for tramp ships and dry-bulk carriers, may be the exclusive domain of these two types of vessels by 1965.

LARGE shrimp of the size that come twenty to twenty-five to the pound are the most convenient to use. There is less cleaning to do than with smaller specimens that number thirty-five or more to the pound.
The initial stages of a $150,000,000 food and grain storage program of wide significance to this country and India has been approved for immediate implementation, it has been learned here.
WASHINGTON, July 3 (AP) -- A Senate subcommittee is gathering material for public hearings on the constitutional rights of American Indians.

LOS ANGELES, July 3 -- A swarm of California Republican leaders will converge on West Los Angeles next week for a conference with Richard M. Nixon. They will meet at the temporary home the former Vice President has rented among those of movie executives.
A special exhibit honoring the 100th anniversary of a distinguished alumnus' joining the Union Army was set up this week at Columbia University.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 3 -- Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold rejected today Soviet demands that United Nations jobs be distributed on a political basis.

Premier Khrushchev and Leonid I. Brezhnev, Soviet chief of state, sent Fourth of July, greetings to President Kennedy yesterday in which they urged joint efforts to seek a "speedy solution of the pressing problems" left in the wake of World War II.
The storied sugar maple tree may be going into oblivion like the famed American chestnut.
The Cunard Steam-Ship Company, Ltd., will mark its 121st anniversary today.

PHILADELPHIA, July 3 -- A new Protestant denomination with an estimated membership of 2,000,000 will be formally constituted here tomorrow. It is being formed as the United Church of Christ by a merger of the Congregational Christian Churches and the Evangelical and Reformed Church.
DETROIT, July 3 (AP) -- The auto industry moved into the second half of 1961 today with most of its assembly plants closed at least part of this week because of the Fourth of July holiday.

WASHINGTON, July 3 -- The orators and historians of the Fourth July have no need to exaggerate. as some of them annually do, event at Philadelphia in 1776 or its moral and political implications. The Declaration of Independence was an extraordinarily courageous venture of a highly civilized people, a unique in that no other up to that time had formally revolted against a motherland and established an independent government.

BOGOTA, Colombia, July 3 -- The leader of Colombia's Conservative Opposition, Dr. Laureano Gomez, attacked today the Government's hopes of electing a Conservative President next year with Liberal support.
WASHINGTON, July 3 -- Representative John R. Pillion has begun a one-man campaign for a world declaration of political and psychological war against international communism.

LONDON, July 3 -- Light but persistent selling of industrial shares cast dullness over the main sections of the stock market here today. Net losses, however, were generally no more than a shilling (14 cents).
MIAMI BEACH, July 3 -- James R. Hoffa asserted today that the American people were on the "threshold of an uprising" over the problems created by automation and large-scale unemployment.
OCEANPORT, N.J., July 3 -- John W. Galbreath's 3-year-old filly Primoneta easily scored her eighth consecutive victory at Monmouth Park today.

Kelso will be back in action today. The star of the Bohemia Stable will run as the strong favorite against nine rivals in the $100,000 added Suburban Handicap at Aqueduct. He will be ridden by Eddie Arcaro, who has been on seven winners of the stakes.

A man in a gray business suit robbed the Manufactures Trust Company Bank at Eighth Avenue and Forty-third Street of about $10,000 yesterday and calmly walked out with the bills in a paper bag. He disappeared in the late noontime crowd on Eighth Avenue.

GARY, Ind., July 3 (UPI) -- The Amateur Athletic Union picked seventeen women today to represent the United States in dual track and field meets against four European nations this month. The first meet is in Moscow July 15-16.

In the latest of a series of legal actions against the Fifth Avenue Bus Lines, Inc., a stockholder filed a suit yesterday in Supreme Court accusing the directors of misuse of funds, waste and failing to provide a fair rate of return on investment.
A device to increase the visibility of automobile turn signal lights in daytime without making them too bright at night is being developed.
ROME, July 3 -- The Italian Communist party is seizing on the dispute over Alto Adige (South Tyrol) in an effort to disrupt the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.
ATHENS, July 3 (AP) -- United States diplomats in this ancient city have a new embassy building that hangs from modernistic pillars and beams.
JEREZ DE LA FRONTERA, Spain, July 4 (UPI) -- Antonio Ordonez killed two bulls here today in memory of Ernest Hemingway.

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), July 3 -- The Knesset, Israel's Parliament, was convened for a special one-day session today. Called to debate an election booklet that had been distributed to members of Israel's armed forces, the session was dominated by attacks on David Ben-Gurion, acting Premier and head of the majority Mapai party.

WASHINGTON, July 3 (AP) -- The Atomic Energy Commission today ordered a review of a preliminary decision by one of its examiners that would have revoked the industrial radiography license of the New York Shipbuilding Corporation of Camden, N. J.
BLOOMINGTON, Minn., July 3 (AP) -- Bob Allison hit his third bases-filled home run of the season tonight in leading the Minnesota Twins to a 7-6 victory over the Chicago White Sox.

Dale T. O'Donnell and Leon Schop have been named partners in Lubetkin, Regan Kennedy, members of the New York Stock Exchange. Mr. O'Donnell had been with Carlisle Jacquelin. Mr. Schop was senior cashier at the New York office of Walston Co.
MIAMI BEACH, July 3 -- The much-investigated Teamsters Union cautioned its convention delegates today to beware of "Mata Haris" allegedly sent here by the Federal Bureau of Investigation.
MOSCOW, July 3 (UPI) -- Eight American gas company executives began today a thirty-day inspection tour of Soviet gas facilities.

PARIS, July 3 -- While a small group of men in the world's main capitals is deciding, almost literally, the fate of the world in the matter of Berlin, another small group in mostly the same capitals is wrestling with a question that might be nearly as momentous.
CHICAGO, July 3 (AP) -- Grain futures were in good demand today in active dealings on the Board of Trade and prices generally were firm to strong after overcoming a slight early weakness.

HYANNIS PORT, Mass., July 3 -- Urgent foreign and domestic matters broke into President Kennedy's holiday today. These and overcast, breezy weather apparently caused him to cut his boating to two and one-half hours.
More than 2,000 Boys Scouts and 200 adult leaders left the city yesterday for two-week stays at Ten Mile River Boy Scout Camps, Narrowsburg, N.Y.
LONDON, July 3 -- Prime Minister Macmillan told the House of Commons today that the danger of an Iraqi attack on Kuwait was continuing despite British military intervention.
Signs of new strains in the Soviet-Chinese Communist alliance have increased recently.
LONDON, July 3 (Reuters) -- Colonial Secretary Iain Macleod presented today the proposed framework for a new Constitution for Mauritius, a British colony in the Indian Ocean.
WASHINGTON, July 3 -- Forty-three sites linked with the country's development in the nineteenth century have been added to the Registry of National Historic Landmarks.

Sixty-four local government housing authorities subsidized by the Public Housing Administration will receive bids on July 11 on issues of temporary loan notes totaling $58,193,000 to finance construction of low-rent projects.
ALBANY, July 3 -- The state acted today to make it less expensive for its employes to move when their duty stations are changed.
JERSEY CITY, July 3. -- The new City Council started reorganizing the government today by providing for the regular appearance at City Hall of some familiar faces, as well as some new ones.
THE president of the Unity-Metropolitan Club, Herman Goldberg, offers this deal to illustrate one of the basic principles of expert play: Never give your opponents any information you don't have to.
KUWAIT, July 3 -- The Kuwait Oil Company said today it had closed outlying drilling and pumping operations to keep out of the way of the British armed force now building up in Kuwait.

BOSTON, July 3 (AP) -- Whitey Ford heads the pitchers on the 1961 American League all-star team. Ford, the New York Yankee southpaw, and Frank Lary and Jim Bunning of Detroit were the dominant mound figures selected today by Manager Paul Richards for the first game, July 11 at San Francisco.

NORWALK, Conn., July 3 -- A report on flood-control activities in Norwalk indicated today that projects of more than $800,000 had been approved and that additional work on control and erosion here was under consideration.

Fleming of England, which brought into being the Electronic Age with all its marvels.

ALBANY, July 3 -- The state acted today to make it less expensive for its employes to move when their duty stations are changed.
JERSEY CITY, July 3. -- The new City Council started reorganizing the government today by providing for the regular appearance at City Hall of some familiar faces, as well as some new ones.
Councilman Earl Brown appeared yesterday to be the leading contender for a six-month-old vacancy on the three-man Housing and Redevelopment Board.
Significant changes in the operations of the city schools appeared likely yesterday in the wake of recent disclosures of inefficiency and irregularities in the school building program.
