Robert K. Sharpe, a 30-year-old Chicagoan whose television documentaries and short subjects have earned him a solid reputation in those fields, plans to enter feature film production this fall with an independently financed melodrama to be shot in Harlem.
A Government tax levied by a South American country to recover from the damage of an earthquake has revised the New York Repertory Theatre's itinerary and cancelled one of its bookings.

ALBANY, July 3 (AP) -- Mayor Erastus Corning 2d announced tonight that he had selected two men and a woman to represent this city on the eighteen-member Temporary State Commission on the Capital City.
JACKSON, Miss., July 3 (UPI) -- A Federal judge said today that racial violence could have resulted if Mississippi authorities had failed to arrest Freedom Riders.

ORLEANS, Mass., July 3 -- When the summer vacation season here on Cape Cod gets under way "officially" tomorrow, there will be many bowlers among the bathers. Most of them could have saved valuable automobile trunk space by leaving their bowling balls at home because this is candlepin coun try.
Americans pursued happiness in generally good weather across the nation yesterday but at such a pace that a record for highway fatalities for the four-day Independence holiday appeared likely.
GENEVA, July 3 -- Communist China tried today to have the conference on Laos turn to the proposed guarantee of the Southeast Asian Kingdom's neutrality.
FOR every woman who fibs about her age and dress size, there is a man who cannot accept the truth about his neck measurement.
CINCINNATI, July 3 (AP) -- Jim Maloney held the Pittsburgh Pirates to five hits tonight but needed help from two relief pitchers on the last two outs as the Reds won, 4 -- 3.
PARIS, July 3 -- The French nation received the news of Ernest Hemingway's death with shock today.
NEW DELHI, India, July 3 -- Indian officials are disturbed about the possibility that Britain may join the European Common Market.

The polio season is just getting under way. The only effective polio vaccine now available for general use is the killed-virus vaccine developed by Dr. Jonas E. Salk, which has been in effective use for the past five years. These being the facts, the action of the House of Delegates of the American Medical Association in unanimously recommending the use of the oral, attenuated live-virus vaccine as "offering longer protection" is highly regrettable.
The New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad's $5 preferred stock broke a point yesterday and closed at $4.62 1/2, a new low.
The first space voyagers to find their way to earth will look more like Man O' War than Superman, a prominent anthropologist has predicted.

NEW LONDON, Conn., July 3 -- Petrel, a seventy-foot yawl owned by the United States Coast Guard Academy, finished just before midnight last night and won the intermediate off-shore race held by the Corinthians, an amateur sailing group.

LOS ANGELES, July 2 -- The Administration's promise to give the Western states additional power has stirred hopes but also rekindled the controversy of public-private control of utilities. Most Westeners acclaim the vast water and power developments under way or projected for the next decade. But to many, the big question is:
GENEVA, July 3 -- The Soviet Union said today that more than two years of negotiation here had made it "crystal clear" that the United States did not want a treaty to ban nuclear tests.

PHILADELPHIA, July 3 -- A study at Temple University shows small businesses are more likely to prepare their financial statements to satisfy the Government and creditors rather than as a management tool.
A charge that "activity is again in process in our country in preparation for another invasion of Cuba" was made yesterday at a conference of the Fair Play for Cuba Committee.
WESTBURY, L.I., July 3 -- Merrie Duke, a 31-to-1 betting chance in the field of seven, rallied from next to last place tonight and won the $50,000 American Trotting Championship at Roosevelt Raceway.

BAGHDAD, Iraq, July 3 -- Iraq termed the landing of British troops in Kuwait a direct threat to Iraqi security today and called on all Arabs to unite against "this tyrannical imperialistic aggression."

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 3 -- The jubilation that greeted the announcement of an oil strike in the Republic of the Philippines in recent months may have appeared dis proportionate to the outside world, in view of the minor volume of crude petroleum produced to date. To Filipinos, however, the event had a double symbolism that more than justified the rejoicing.
Four men were arrested yesterday -- two in Brooklyn and two in Manhattan -- as dealers in fireworks.

ACCRA, Ghana, July 4 -- Ghana's foreign assets are to be consolidated in the state-owned Bank of Ghana and the Ghana Central Government under sweeping financial reforms, President Kwame Nkrumah announced in Parliament today.

DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., July 4 (AP) -- David Pearson that a world stock car record today, winning the Firecracker 250-mile race at Daytona International Speedway in an average speed of 154.294 miles an hour.
WASHINGTON, July 4 (AP) -- Deputy Attorney General Byron R. White has reaffirmed the Justice Department's stand in favor of letting states authorize wiretapping in whatever criminal cases they wish.
WASHINGTON, July 4 (AP) -- The Savannah, the world first nuclear-powered merchant-ship, may be given her first tests later this month or in August and make trial runs a sea soon thereafter.
WESTPORT, Conn., July 4 -- A 26-year-old gunman was wounded in a running pistol battle at police headquarters here early today after he had slain his father and wounded two policemen.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., July 4 -- A fellow doesn't have to be a fisherman long to know you can't believe everything you hear. Some anglers, when offering advice, never stray from the truth. But the number that do is said to be frightening.

The seventh volume in Will Durant's series "The Story of Civilization" will be published by Simon Schuster on Sept. 6 under the title "The Age of Reason Begins." Dr. Durant is joined by his wife, Ariel, as coauthor -- thereby making "official'' a collaboration that began with the research work on the first volume of the series, "Our Oriental Heritage," which was published in 1935.
PARIS, July 4 -- The annual Fourth of July party at the United States Embassy here did not take place today and only a few regrets were expressed at its passing.

WASHINGTON, July 4 -- In the first six months of the Kennedy Administration, the most successful legislative tactic of the President's supporters has been to make calculated concessions to the entrenched minority of Southern Democrats.
GENEVA, July 4 -- The United States accused the Communist countries today of making every effort to prevent the restoration of peace in Laos.
KEY WEST, Fla., July 4 (AP) -- Cubans flew three airplanes to the Florida Keys today and authorities immediately seized the planes on behalf of an American business man.
LISBON, Portugal, July 4 (AP) -- Portugal denied today charges that she has carried out "barbarous repression" and "deliberate extermination" in her strife-torn West African territory of Angola.

TURIN, Italy, July 4 -- What is left of the Tour de France bike race struggled wearily, slowly over the Alps today. For more than seven and a half hours -- 156 miles -- the men pedaled uninterruptedly, mostly in the same direction -- up.

Operating in a manner that left little doubt it would collar the second-section title in the International Soccer League, Dukla of Czechoslovakia tightened its hold on first place by whipping Rapid of Austria, 6 -- 0, in the feature game of a twin bill at the Polo Grounds yesterday.
SALEM, N.H., July 4 (AP) -- George Proulx' Gold Sky won the $5,000 feature before a crowd of 19,108 at Rockingham Park today.

RALEIGH, N.C., July 4 (UPI) -- Gov. Terry Sanford granted executive clemency today to seven textile union members imprisoned for a dynamite conspiracy at Henderson in 1959. The action made the men eligible for parole.

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), July 4 -- The defense picture of Adolf Eichmann as a small cog in the Nazi apparatus for killing Jews was shaken today by the submission of testimony from wartime associates.
KEY WEST, Fla., July 4 (AP) -- Premier Fidel Castro announced tonight the rationing of animal and vegetable fats in Cuba until the current acute shortage is solved -- perhaps in a year and a half.
Agreement between the Western and Communist powers at the Geneva Conference on Laos continues to be blocked by the basic differences apparent when the conference began nearly two months ago.
LONDON, July 4 -- A Kennedy Administration limitation sharply reduced Fourth of July celebrations at the United States Embassy in London and other capitals today.
Shipping operations revived slowly yesterday despite a Federal Court order that the maritime strike be halted immediately under provisions of the Taft-Hartley Act.
The Board of Education's emergency summer repair program will get under way today when 600 school maintenance men -- twice the normal staff -- start work on priority projects.
WIMBLEDON, England, July 4 -- Christine Truman of Britain and Renee Schuurman of South Africa are in the all-England tennis semi-finals tonight by the skin of their teeth.

BONN, Germany, July 4 -- President Kennedy's answer to the Soviet memorandum on Berlin, presented by Premier Khrushchev in Vienna June 4, will be preceded by a West German note rejecting Moscow's suggestion of Feb. 17 for bilateral talks on Germany, informed sources said here today.

WASHINGTON, July 4 -- The greatest danger of war over Berlin today lies in the Soviet Union's profound misunderstanding of the American spirit. Being chess players themselves, they think we are a logical people and this is obviously a preposterous idea, disproved by our whole history.
LONDON, July 4 -- Britain is reinforcing her naval flotilla off Kuwait with a task force from the Mediterranean fleet, the Foreign Office disclosed tonight.

ST. LOUIS, July 4 (AP) -- Charlie Smith and Jim Coker drove in seven runs and powered the Philadelphia Phillies to a 10-6 victory over the St. Louis Cardinals and a split in their double-header today. The Cards won the first game, 10 -- 7.

Whatever the merits of the State Investigation Commission's inquiry into the New York City school system, it is as unfair as it is cruel for the commission to suggest, only by inference, that architects who designed some of the school buildings were endangering the lives of school children.

STANTON, Del., July 4 (AP) -- I'm For More, owned and bred by the Circle M. Farm of Mrs. Edward S. Moore, outran fourteen other 2-year-olds today in the twenty-third and richest running of the Dover Stakes at Delaware Park.
A new air traffic control system is to be tested soon at the Federal Aviation Agency's experimental center in Atlantic City.
TOKYO, July 4 -- This was a disappointing Independence Day for the American civilian community in Tokyo.
LONDON, July 4 -- The depression in the stock market deepened and widened today and there were very few plus signs to be seen in the principal lists.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., July 4 -- Norman Elliott of the Sheldrake Yacht Club cut Ed Cerny's winning streak in the Rhodes-19 Class today and while about it dispatched some class skyrockets, as befitted the day.

While thousands of youths flapped in the sea and basked in the sun yesterday, thirty cerebral teen-agers matched minds within the quiet, brooding walls of the Manhattan Chess Club, 35 West Sixty-fourth Street.
RIO DE JANEIRO, July 4 -- Brazil and Chile declared today that President Kennedy's Alliance for Progress plan opened new prospects for inter-American cooperation.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., July 4 (AP) -- The College of Agriculture at Rutgers University announced today that the "Kilmer Oak" would soon undergo surgery and other treatment in an effort to lengthen its life.

WASHINGTON, July 4 (UPI) -- The American Jewish Conference urged the Senate Foreign Relations Committee today to retain an anti-discrimination clause in President Kennedy's $4,800,000,000 foreign aid bill.
BINGHAMTON, June 23 -- A foundation composed of twenty-eight Binghamton industries has virtually superseded City Hall in planning the rebuilding of this city's decaying downtown core.
WASHINGTON, July 4 (AP) -- Representative Don Magnuson, said today a bill before the House Rules Committee threatened the existence of the West Coast shipbuilding industry.

DON MOSSI sat in the clubhouse at the Yankee Stadium yesterday, untroubled by the fact that he was about to take part in the most important double-header of the season to date. The powerful left-hander has lived with crises for his entire baseball career, first as a relief pitcher and now as a starter whose proficiency is reflected in the glittering 9-and-1 record he brought to town.
PHILADELPHIA, July 4 -- A new denomination in American Protestantism was born today when the constitution of the United Church of Christ was declared "to be in force."

PARIS, July 4 -- The Kuwait crisis reminds us that this century's most profound revolution is not that promoted by Lenin but that which sprang from Wilson's vague ideas on self-determination. In fact, there is a striking contrast between the results of these two revolutions.

BERLIN, July 4 -- The international jury at Berlin's eleventh film festival tonight honored an Italian film with its top prize. The Golden Bear went to "La Notte" (The Night), a feature directed and written by Michelangelo Antonioni.

LONDON, July 4 (AP) -- Mikhail A. Suslov, a secretary of the Central Committee of the Soviet Communist party, said today that the Soviet Union was striving to strengthen the "unity and solidarity" of world communism.
School is out and the voice of the junior marketing man is heard in the land.
In Governor Rockefeller's office it is a breach of etiquette these days to talk about 1964. Nevertheless he maintains a team capable of waging a Presidential campaign on short notice.
Senator Jacob K. Javits defended President Kennedy yesterday for his Berlin stand and pleaded for stronger support from the United States' allies in the world situation.
MISCHA ELMAN shared last night's Lewisohn Stadium concert with three American composers.
The City Housing Authority yesterday announced an increase in income limits for families in Federally aided housing developments.

Giacomo Puccini's "Il Trittico," a triple bill of one-act operas, will open the New York City Center Opera season on Oct. 5. The three operas, "Il Tabarro," "Suor Angelica" and "Gianni Schicchi," received their world premiere at the Metropolitan Opera House in 1918.
MOSCOW, July 4 -- Approximately 1,000 persons attended the Independence Day reception given today by Llewelyn E. Thompson Jr., the United States Ambassador, at his residence, Spasso House.
There doesn't seem to be anything that can stop Kelso, the 4-year-old gelding owned by the Bohemia Stable.
Patrolman Richard Montana warily watched a roof for rocks or bottles yesterday as his partner, Patrolman William Doheny, shut off a fire hydrant.

The Coudert Brothers law firm has leased 16,000 square feet of office space in the Pan Am Building, which is under construction just behind Grand Central Terminal. It will occupy half of the twentieth floor in the fifty-nine-story skyscraper.
BALTIMORE, July 4 (AP) -- The Baltimore Orioles, again paced by the home run hitting of Gus Triandos, whipped the Cleveland Indians, 5 -- 1, today in a single twilight game.

WASHINGTON, July 4 (UPI) Steel production has jumped sharply since the first of the year but only a few thousand idle workers have been recalled to their Jobs In the mills, according to a Government report.

FLEMINGTON, N.J. -- Buddy Dodd of Quincy, Mass., a 28-year-old designer, captured the 100-kilometer (62 1/2-mile) bicycle road-racing event here, one of a season-long series to determine the United States all-around championship, today.

CHICAGO, July 4 -- The rolling stock of American railroads is in the poorest condition since the depression of the Nineteen Thirties and is incapable of meeting the needs of a resurgent economy, Walter Renz, executive vice president of the American Railway Car Institute, said today.

A YEAR ago today, when the Democrats were fretting and frolicking in Los Angeles and John F. Kennedy was still only an able and ambitious Senator who yearned for the power and responsibility of the Presidency, Theodore H. White had already compiled masses of notes about the Presidential campaign of 1960.
GOSHEN, N.Y., July 4 (AP) -- Gallant Hanover won the $19,950 E.H. Harriman Challenge Trophy for trotters at Historic Track today.
A water-pollution control program for the New York metropolitan area will be undertaken soon by the Federal Government.

THE bridge laws implicitly give each player the right to "condone" an illegal bid or play made by an opponent. By bidding or playing over the irregularity, as the case may be, a player accepts it and waives the right to penalize it.
STRATFORD-ON-AVON, England, July 4 -- The Royal Shakespeare Theatre presented "As You Like It" tonight to a warmly appreciative audience of tourists, first-nighters, and fans of the Bard.
Several hundred Puerto Rican farm workers were stranded over the week-end at New York International Airport even though they had bought plane tickets to San Juan.

WASHINGTON, July 4 (AP) -- A proposed reduction in the State Department's overseas personnel threatens the development of foreign markets for American products, Senator Clair Engle, Democrat of California, said today.

The fabled exploits of Izzy and Moe, the team of prohibition agents who provided, comedy relief during the turbulent Nineteen Twenties with their infinite variety of disguises and antics, will serve as the mainspring of a new Broadway musical.
WARSAW, July 4 -- Ambassador Jacob D. Beam gave his fifth and biggest Fourth of July reception in Poland today with a guest list limited strictly to Poles and diplomats.

ELISABETHVILLE, the Congo, July 4 (AP) -- Katanga's Parliament today dealt a new blow to hopes of a unified Congo by rejecting President Moise Tshombe's agreements to cooperate with the Central Government.
WASHINGTON, July 4 (AP) -- An industrial personnel director said today that the public schools were training students to "go into jobs that are non-existent."

In your July 3 news story on Ernest Hemingway's career, reference is made to The New Yorker's "multipart profile of Mr. Hemingway" by me as a "brilliant but savage series." You continue: "It stirred much controversy and appears to have made more friends for Mr. Hemingway than for Miss Ross.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 4 (AP) -- Lauren Bacall and Jason Robards Jr. were married this afternoon in Ensenada, Mexico.
John Chancellor will become host of the National Broadcasting Company's "Today" show starting July I7.
A day such as inspires poets to write odes covered most of the United States yesterday to provide a perfect setting for the 185th observance of the signing of the Declaration of Independence.
Harold Lloyd's long-planned compilation of cliff-hanging sequences from his most famous silent comedies will be ready for release in art theatres this fall.
MILWAUKEE, July 4 (AP) -- The Milwaukee Braves bought a southpaw pitcher, Johnny Antonelli, from the Cleveland Indians tonight for an undisclosed amount of cash.

Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold has clearly and firmly restated his basic opposition to the efforts of the Russians to turn the United Nations into an at least partly controlled Communist satellite. This is the gist of the Secretary General's comment on the recent report of a U.N. committee on reorganization and on the Russian proposals which went far beyond the committee's comparatively moderate recommendations.
BLOOMINGTON, Minn., July 4 (AP) -- Jack Kralick pitched and batted Minnesota to a 4-2 victory over the Chicago White Sox today as the Twins completed a sweep of a doubleheader.
EUGENE, Ore., July 4 (UPI) -- Ron Morris and Dyrol Burleson set meet records today in the Oregon Amateur Athletic Union's track and field championships.
BERLIN, July 4 -- Mayor Willy Brandt of West Berlin called on the Western powers today not to neglect political preparedness in their military plans to counter the Kremlin's offensive.
KETCHUM, Idaho, July 4 (UPI) -- Ernest Hemingway will be buried under a blanket of red roses; beside one of his closest friends.

District Attorney Frank O'Connor of Queens County returned to New York last night after an unpublicized trip to London, reportedly in search of a key witness connected with last year's tow-car scandals.
NEW BRITAIN, Conn., July 4 (UPI) -- The American Hardware Corporation said today it had completed a deal with Netherlands hardware interests to supply the European Common Market.

New York State discriminated for many years against commuters resident in New Jersey and Connecticut in refusing to allow them tax deductions equal to those of New Yorkers on income earned in New York. Finally justice was achieved through legislation passed at Albany. It was going into effect this year when New Jersey upset the apple-cart with a strange device that would apply an income tax to commuters only, whether to or from New York.
A majority of United States business men oppose protective tariffs, but many also are deeply concerned about mounting competition.
The suspension of Sports Car Club of America race drivers from all international events licensed by the Federation Internationale de I'Automobile goes into effect today.

MIAMI BEACH, July 4 -- James R. Hoffa's only announced rival for the presidency of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters asked today that the choice of the union's new officers be put up to a secret vote of its 1,700,000 members.

CIUDAD TRUJILLO, Dominican Republic, July 4 (UPI) -- The Government announced yesterday that twenty-five persons charged with conspiracy had been released from prison in accordance with a new amnesty law.
Manhattan Borough President Edward R. Dudley has taken steps to find out in what sections of the borough the widening of crosstown streets is desired, and in what sections people want it deferred.
LOS ANGELES, July 3 -- Growth is synonymous with water, especially in the Western half of the United States.
Work is about to begin on a new shopping center in north-east Paterson, N.J.

HYANNIS PORT, Mass., July 4 -- President Kennedy replied to Premier Khrushchev today that the United States was still committed to the "revolutionary principles of individual liberty and national freedom."
MOSCOW, July 4 -- Premier Khrushchev paid his first visit in three years to the United States Embassy in Moscow today to salute the American Independence Day.
ROOSEVELT, N.J., July 4 -- Ground was broken here this afternoon for a monument to Franklin D. Roosevelt.
A Jamaica social club's moonlight cruise on the Hudson River erupted in a series brawls early yesterday morning. Two of the fourteen per cent injured were hospitalized.
Capt. Ferruccio Soranzo, who joined the Italian Line as a third officer in 1933, has been appointed master of the passenger liner Vulvania.

In what is regarded as an honest election, the Mexican people have cast a record vote for the ruling Revolutionary Institutional party of President Lopez Mateos. This party has held a monopoly of political power for the last three decades. It is stronger than ever and appears to have made a clean sweep of the 178 seats in the House of Deputies.

CHICAGO, July 4 (AP) -- The San Francisco Giants reached their season peak in hits and runs today in routing the Chicago Cubs, 19 -- 3, then tapered off and lost the second game of the double-header, 3 -- 2.

WESTBURY, L.I., July 4 -- If there is, as the horseplayer phrases it, a "knock" against the great Adios Butler, it is that the world's fastest standardbred either can't or doesn't care to pace beyond a mile.
BUFFALO, July 4 (UPI) -- A 15-year-old girl described as a "prime suspect" in the kidnap-murder of 3-year-old Andrew Ashley was admitted to a hospital today for psychiatric examination and treatment.
LONDON, July 4 -- The British Government rejected today any proposals for the future of Germany and Berlin that did not include a provision for German reunification.
OCEANPORT, N.J., July 4 -- Closing with a powerful rush in the stretch, Marion R. Frankel's Call the Witness won the $29,800 Longfellow Handicap on turf at Monmouth Park today.
LONDON, July 4 -- Chancellor of the Exchequer Selwyn Lloyd told the House of Commons today that Britain was passing through "very anxious days" ecomonically.
The Soviet Ministry of Foreign trade has revealed that Communist China owes the Soviet Union more than $300,000,000 as a result of a failure by Peiping to meet export commitments to Moscow last year.

A proposed merger of the Davega Stores Corporation and Wilcox-Gay Corporation on a share-for-share exchange basis, was announced over the holiday by Joseph Axler, president of Davega and Leonard Ashbach, president of Wilcox-Gay.
MANILA, July 4 (AP) -- The Philippines staged her biggest, most glorious Fourth of July independence parade today in honor of General of the Army Douglas MacArthur.

ROME, July 4 -- Ambassador G. Frederick Reinhardt, a career diplomat, led an "America Day" ceremony at Italy's 1961 International Fair in Turin today. But in Rome there was no official celebration of the Fourth of July.

Responding to the roars of the season's largest baseball gathering, a crowd of 74,246, the Yankees stormed into the American League lead at the Stadium yesterday. But they remained there only a few hours.

LAST week, while Congressmen brought their sightseeing constituents into her Capitol Hill office and reporters hounded her for news, Mrs. Elizabeth S. Carpenter was further refining the practice of frontiersmanship.
TITOVO UZICE, Yugoslavia, July 4 (UPI) -- President Tito said today that the world's unaligned nations were meeting in September in Belgrade in a bid to avert the 'biggest catastrophe of all."

ST. ANDREWS, Scotland, July 4 (AP) -- Arnold Palmer unleashed a streak of birdies on the final three holes and whipped Gary Player of South Africa by five strokes today in their duel for $10,000 over the St. Andrews course.
MANILA, July 4 (UPI) -- Following is the text of an Independence Day speech today by General of the Army Douglas MacArthur:

NEW YORK'S Ninth Avenue has been called the culinary melting pot of America. Walking north from Thirtieth Street, a visitor is faced with a fascinating hodgepodge of fabulous foods from around the world.
MEXICO CITY, July 4 -- Authorities here were watching carefully today the developing political situation in the city of San Luis Potosi, where a riot was narrowly averted last night.
LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, July 4 -- Maj. Gen. Joseph D. Mobutu, army commander, pledged today that the Congolese Army would not get involved in politics.

MILWAUKEE, July 4 (AP) -- The Los Angeles Dodgers pounded two rookies, Bob Hendley and Don Nottebart, for six runs in the first inning today and made them stand up for a 6-5 victory over the Milwaukee Braves.

Robert Barker of Manhasset, L.I., and Dr. Richard Raskind of New York won two matches apiece yesterday and gained the third round of the New York State men's tennis tournament. The event is being conducted at the North Shore Tennis and Racquet Club in Bayside, Queens.
SEOUL, Korea, July 4 -- The revamped military Government intensified its anti-Communist campaign today, accusing former Premier John M. Chang of having collaborated with Left-Wingers.
AMAGANSETT, L.I. July 4 -- A former Navy barge, carefully made un-shipshape and beached in a hardly navigable harbor, has taken on its first crew members here.
Several hundred persons who work in Manhattan below Sixtieth Street soon will be approached on the question of staggering their working hours.

It was recently my obligation to be present in the New York City Traffic Court. Before and since our recent move to the state, we have read many disparaging and critical articles aimed both at the police force and the associated courts.
ANTIQUES row in Brooklyn is doomed to demolition. Sometime next year wrecking gangs are due to chew up the Fulton Street emporiums, paving the way for a housing development.

PHILADELPHIA, July 4 (AP) -- Seymour Cromwell of the Riverside Boat Club in Cambridge, Mass., won the 2,000-meter singles rowing race and the quarter-mile dash in the regatta on the Schuylkill River today.
CINCINNATI, July 4 (AP) -- Joey Jay yielded only three hits today as he pitched the league-leading Cincinnati Reds to a 2-0 victory over the Pittsburgh Pirates.
Your editorial on "Premier Ikeda in New York" (June 24) correctly states the interest of the United States in maintaining the economy of "a major force friendly to us in Asia."
WINNIPEG, Man., July 4 (UPI) -- Aided by the general drought, grasshoppers pose a critical problem across the Prairies.
OTTAWA, July 4 -- The Government prevented today a new attempt by the Liberal Opposition to obtain a hearing in Parliament for James E. Coyne, Governor of the Bank of Canada who is facing dismissal.
Plans are progressing for the annual opera benefit of the Bagby Music Lovers Foundation, Inc., to be held at the Metropolitan Opera House Nov. 9.
BABYLON, L.I., July 4 -- Two skippers completed sweeps today as the three-day invitation regatta of the Babylon Yacht Club ended.
CHICAGO, July 4 (UPI) -- "Color streets" will be tested on Chicago Avenue soon and if the scheme is successful, there may be "color highways" all over Illinois.
PURCHASE, N.Y., July 4 -- Stirling bagpipes and bright spartans were the order of the many at the Blind Brook Polo Club today.
LONDON, July 4 (UPI) -- The American Wind Symphony Orchestra gave its first British concert tonight, playing to an open air audience from a barge anchored in the Thames River.
ALGIERS, July 4 -- Algeria braced today for a strike by Moslems called for tomorrow by the Algerian nationalists.
THE tenth annual Junior Angler Fishing Contest opens tomorrow at Prospect Park Lake. The contest is for children 6 to 15 years old and will run daily from 8 A.M. to 8 P.M. through July 30.
An expert in the care and handling of testy and troubled children considers "punishment" a dirty word and "reward" a poor incentive.
President Kennedy has been considering an appeal by the New Haven Railroad for an immediate $5,500,000 Federal loan, which the line's officials say is needed to stave off bankruptcy.

CARACAS, Venezuela, July 4 -- The Supreme Court has asked Congress to deprive two !extremist Congressmen of their parliamentary immunity, it was announced today. The Congressmen are Dr. Domingo Alberto Rangel, head of the Movement of the Revolutionary Left, and Teodoro Petkoff, a Communist. [ Both have been.accused by[ the Government of having in-[ cited anti-Government riots[ last November. However, be-[ cause they enjoy immunity,[ they have not been prosecuted.[

Leaders of the New York bar and bench are increasingly determined to curb partisan political pressures in the selection of judges, and to insure the high quality of those who are chosen. An interesting example is the proposal of Presiding Justice Botein of the Appellate Division, First Department, that bar associations run their own candidates for election to the New York bench when unqualified candidates have been nominated, especially as the result of political deals.

RIO DE JANEIRO, July 4 -- About 4,500 United States citizens residing here and their Brazilian relatives and friends celebrated the Fourth of July on their own today without reliance on the United States Embassy.
The Chemical Bank New York Trust Company had net operating earnings of $21,534,317 for the six months ended last Friday.

CHAPEL HILL, N.C., July 4 (AP) -- The Chapel Hill School Board laid down a broad policy of pupil assignment last night that would racially integrate all elementary schools here. The policy applies only to pupils in the first grade.

RIVERSIDE, Conn., July 4 -- The latest in the series of races for 12-meter yachts on Long Island Sound became "no contest" today. The three sloops failed to finish the course within the four-hour time limit.

HACKENSACK, N.J., July 4 -- Fourteen new internes and fifteen resident physicians have entered Hackensack Hospital's medical teaching program, which has helped to keep the hospital fully staffed despite shortages elsewhere.
REGINA, Sask., July 4 -- Widespread soaking rains in the next few days could put $100,000,000 to $200,000,000 into the pockets of Western Canada's farmers.

LONDON, July 4 -- For its final change of bill in its London season, the Leningrad State Kirov Ballet chose tonight to give one of those choreographic miscellanies known as a "gala program" at the Royal Opera House, Covent Garden.
The first leg of a 345,000-volt transmission line that ultimately will triple peak power available to New York City has been put in operation, the State Power Authority announced yesterday.

KUWAIT, July 4 -- As British, Kuwaiti and Saudi Arabian forces passed the 10,000 mark here today, the Secretary General of the Arab League arrived in search of a nonmilitary solution to the Iraqi-Kuwaiti crisis.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 4 -- An over-all expansion in the export trade of primary-producing countries in 1960, compared with 1959, was widely distributed.

Some dead ships began to come back to life yesterday. Within hours after a Federal Court ordered a halt to the eighteen-day maritime strike, mates, radio operators and seamen were at work on cargo ships, tankers and passenger liners on the Atlantic, Gulf and Pacific Coasts.

COLORADO SPRINGS, Col., July 4 (UPI) -- Bobby Unser of Albuquerque, N.M., won the Pikes Peak hill climb for the fourth consecutive year today. And for the fourth straight time his auto set a record over the twisting, 12.5-mile course.

LOS ANGELES, July 4 (AP) -- The Los Angeles Angels hit five home runs -- including Rocky Bridges' first in two seasons -- and escaped from the American League cellar today by beating Kansas City twice, 12 -- 5 and 7 -- 5. The Athletics dropped to last place.
PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., July 4 -- The Manhasset Bay One-Design Class skippers defeated the Resolute Class sailors, 30 to 24 1/2, in a team race interclub sailing today.
NEW DELHI, India, July 4 -- The United States Embassy here celebrated Independence Day in its customary manner of the last few years -- with a "Dutch-treat" party for Americans.
WASHINGTON, July 4 (AP) -- Tom Cheney made his first start for Washington today and pitched the Senators to a 7-3 victory over the Boston Red Sox.
WASHINGTON, July 4 -- The chance that President Kennedy will see your letter to him is small, but there is a chance.
OTTAWA, July 4 -- James Elliott Coyne, Governor of the Bank of Canada and the most controversial public servant in Canada's recent history, is a man who practices what he preaches.
The long-range $5,600,000,000 catch-all housing bill signed by President Kennedy last week represents one of the new Administration's brighter legislative victories.
INGLEWOOD, Calif., July 4 (UPI) -- Johnny Longden used all his racing skill today to win with Prince Blessed by a neck over Dress Up in the $55,850 American Handicap at Hollywood Park.

LONDON, July 4 -- The Most Rev. Arthur M. Ramsey, who was enthroned last week as Archbishop of Canterbury and Primate of All England, proposed today a re-examination of the present methods of appointing Bishops and deans.

The eight major department stores in the New York metropolitan area recorded an average gain of 6 per cent in sales last month over those of June, 1960, according to a survey made yesterday by The New York Times.

KANSAS CITY, July 5 (UPI) The Kansas City Athletics battered Juan Pizarro and Frank Baumann for eight runs in the first two innings tonight and went on to defeat the Chicago White Sox, 8 -- 3, in a game halted after six innings because of rain.
LOS ANGELES, July 5 (UPI) -- The original will of Lif Chandler, actor, was filed today in Superior Court. It vested his two daughters, Jamie, and Dana, 11, as sole heirs to the $631,000 estate.

WASHINGTON, July 5 -- Information on the transformation of Albania from a Soviet to a Chinese Communist satellite is regarded here as the most convincing evidence to date of acute strains between Moscow and Peiping.
HENLEY-ON-THAMES, England, July 5 (AP) -- Four American crews swept to opening-heat victories on the Thames today in the Royal Henley Regatta.

The New York and American Stock exchanges announced yesterday that officers, directors and large stockholders of listed companies reported last month, pursuant to the Securities Exchange Act, the following changes in stockholdings:
WESTBURY, L.I., July 5 -- Sunrise was at 5:31 this morning. Thirty-one minutes earlier, racovie of France was out on the main track at Roosevelt raceway.
BJORN WIINBLAD, the internationally famous Danish artist-designer, has created two wallpaper panels named for characters in Oscar Wilde's play, "The Importance of Being Earnest."
Coffee futures climbed to new highs for the life of the contracts yesterday in heavy trading on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange.
Sales and earnings of Corning Glass Works and its subsidiaries declined in the first half of this year, according to the semi-annual report issued for publication today.
SUMMER puts a new emphasis on a woman's beauty habits.

The Estate Securities Company, realty operator, has bought the six-story apartment building at 625 Ocean Avenue, Brooklyn, from the Cherose Realty Corporation and has resold it to a group headed by Harry Silverstein.

Since Gen. Pak Chung Hi became its chairman a few days ago, the ruling military junta in South Korea has made startling charges of pro-Communist activities against former Premier John Chang and many of his associates. These accusations have been announced simultaneously with the promulgation of drastic new security measures, including up to seven years in prison for persons who "praise, encourage or sympathize" with pro-Communists.
Street fighting involving 400 Puerto Ricans and Negroes broke out in a West Side "trouble" block yesterday afternoon. Nine police cars were sent to stop the brawling.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., July 5 -- The Board of Education tonight re-elected as president Merryle Stanley Rukeyser, the economist and writer, who is a leading figure in the fight over segregation at the Lincoln school.

Raymond C. Moley, business columnist for Newsweek Magazine, advised The New York Times yesterday, that he did not regard himself as an "adviser" to Senator Barry Goldwater, Republican of Arizona, as reported in this newspaper on Monday.

TOKYO, July 5 -- A cartoon in a Tokyo newspaper today showed the Premier of Japan peering intently down a rifle barrel. The rifle was marked "Korea" and the caption read: "Don't touch! It may explode any minute."
MIAMI BEACH, July 5 -- A querulous delegate to the Teamsters Union convention was laughed off the floor today after he had inadvertently trampled on a hallowed labor tradition.
WASHINGTON, July 5 -- President Kennedy exhorted leaders of the Americas today to stand together against alien forces that would block the path of freedom and progress.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector) July 5 -- Israel fired a rocket fifty miles into the atmosphere this morning from an undisclosed launching site on the Mediterranean coast, the Defense Ministry announced.

BOSTON, July 5 (AP) -- The Boston Red Sox shaved the Detroit Tigers' American League lead to a half-game over New York tonight, with a homer and a single by the catcher, Jim Pagliaroni, providing the difference in an 8-3 victory.
White House-Pentagon relations reached a new low last week as agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation "invaded" the Pentagon.
NEWBURGH, N.Y., July 5 (UPI) -- City officials served notice today that they would broaden a thirteen-point code aimed at cracking down on welfare frauds.
Mrs. Alice Snow Barbee Lurcy has apparently moved out of a five-story town house at 813 Fifth Avenue in compliance with a court order.
WASHINGTON, July 5 -- Both employment and unemployment showed increases in June, the Labor Department reported today.
CHICAGO, July 5 (AP) -- The grain futures market moved both ways today from the preceding session's closes on the Board of Trade and finished in a mostly mixed range after fairly active dealings.
ALBANY, July 5 -- New York tax officials supported Governor Rockefeller against Governor Meyner tonight in the complex dispute over New York-New Jersey income taxes.

Arthur Kavanagh of County Carlow, Ireland (1831-89), although born without legs or arms, became a skilled artist, an expert horseman and angler, a devotee of sailing and a "lively" writer. He married, reared a sizable family, managed his estates in Ireland and served in the British Parliament eleven years.
PARIS, July 5 -- The way has been cleared for Western Europe to join the United States and the Soviet Union in the exploration of space.

WASHINGTON, July 5 -- The International Monetary Fund announced today that it had "entered into a stand-by arrangement" by which the Government of South Africa may draw up to $75,000,000 during the next twelve months in currencies held by the fund.

PHILADELPHIA, July 5 -- The first president of the new 2,000,000-member United Church of Christ, the Rev. Dr. Ben Mohr Herbster, is a 5-foot-7 churchman who is regarded by many of his colleagues as an authority on theology.
TAIPEI, Taiwan, July 5 (AP) -- Foreign Minister Shen Changhuan conceded today the existence of new and serious issues between the United States and Nationalist China.
PHILADELPHIA, July 5 -- Despite two big bank mergers in Philadelphia within a decade, the smaller banks have had a rapid rate of growth.
KETCHUM, Idaho, July 5 (UPI) -- The family of Ernest Hemingway was reunited tonight for the author's funeral tomorrow.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 5 -- In a year of decreased yields for its major commodity, high-quality, long-staple cotton, the Sudan completed 1960 with a relatively insignificant deficit of only $1,000,000 in its balance of trade -the difference between exports and imports.
DETROIT, July 5 -- A Federal judge ruled today that a Detroit company planning to move to Tennessee must offer jobs to its present employes at the new location.

THERE are astonishing differences in regional preferences for food. Take cottage cheese, for example. Californians dote on it, New Yorkers enjoy it, while Southerners by and large can take it or leave it alone. The preference is at least party a matter of climate, an industry spokesman noted this week.
The Supreme Patriarch of Thailand, dressed in saffron robes and toe-thong sandals, rode silently to the top of the Empire State Building yesterday.

How is the public going to know whether Mayor Wagner, the Board of Education and the Superintendent of Schools have made good on their promises to clean up the disgraceful conditions in the city's school plant revealed by the State Commission of Investigation? This is a question that should have a satisfactory answer now, before time's passing dims the public memory and indignation, and before official zeal for reform cools off.
WASHINGTON, July 5 (AP) -- A Senate Commerce subcommittee announced today it would public hearings on July 25 and 27 on a "fair trade bill."

One of the most ambitious French film ventures in years, a romantic "pageant" entitled "Les Amours Celebres," has entered production at the Boulogne Studios in Paris, with a cast that includes many of the major screen talents of the contemporary Gallic screen.

BLOOMINGTON, Minn., July 5 (UPI) -- Steve Bilko and Ken Hunt drove in three runs apiece tonight as the Los Angeles Angels downed the Minnesota Twins, 6 -- 2.
Rear Admiral David Lamar McDonald has been appointed commander of the United States Sixth Fleet in the Mediterranean. He has been commander of Carrier Division Six based in the Atlantic.
PARIS, July 5 -- French Government spokesmen sought today to discount the prospect of partition of Algeria, which, has unleashed violence in Algeria and strong political opposition in France.

CIUDAD TRUJILLO, Dominican Republic, July 5 (AP) -- Three Dominican exiles arrived today from Puerto Rico and said they had returned to "contribute to the birth and consolidation of democracy in the Dominican Republic."
WELLINGTON, New Zealand, Thursday, July 6 (Reuters) -- Britain promised today to seek special arrangements to protect the trade of Commonwealth countries before entering the European Common Market.

The Treasurer of the United States, Mrs. Elizabeth Rudel Smith, wants to print paper currency in a different color for each denomination. To do so would help those who have to put on their glasses to tell a "1" from a "5" or a "10" from a "20." It would also be of immeasurable aid to those who have to handle large sums of currency.
The Montecatini Company, the largest chemical and mining concern in Italy and one of the largest in Europe, is further expanding its interests here.

Alex Brown Sons and associates are offering to the public today $20,000,000 of 5 7/8 per cent first subordinated debentures due in 1981 of Jim Walter Corporation, with common stock purchase warrants attached. The offering price for each $1,000 debenture with warrant attached is $1,002.50.
COLUMBIA, S.C., July 5 (UPI) -- A Negro minister who fought extradition from New York for two years returned to South Carolina yesterday and surrendered to authorities.

BETHESDA, Md., July 5 (UPI) -- Bryan M. (Bitsy) Grant today reached back twenty-five years for the shots that once beat the world tennis leaders to pull out a tight match in the national senior clay-court championship.
WASHINGTON, July 5 (AP) -- The Treasury announced today it will borrow $500,000,000 in new cash next week through an issue of one-year securities.
WASHINGTON, July 5 -- President Kennedy stepped out of a helicopter and strode briskly to his White House desk today, sun-tanned and looking rested after his Cape Cod holiday.

When the Congress killed a section of the omnibus farm bill that would have increased the powers of the Secretary of Agriculture, the lawmakers appeared to be rebuking the Kennedy Administration. But when it included programs for wheat and feed grains in the same measure, Congress tacitly conceded the Administration's point that strict control of agricultural production is sensible and necessary.

TWO of baseball's more colorful and talkative operatives were encountered in succession yesterday, the James Boys of Cleveland, both fast on the draw with a quip or pungent comment. The first was James Joseph Dykes, the Indian chief, and the second was James Anthony Piersall, his most bellicose brave.
It seems to me that a very important and widespread instance of corruption in our city administration is demonstrated daily for all to see.

TRENTON, July 5 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner said tonight he planned a personal tour of the area and the gathering of further data before deciding whether to permit the erection of a $44,600,000 high-speed rapid transit line for commuters in the Camden-Philadelphia region.

I agree with Walter Binger's statement in his letter published in your columns on June 29, under the heading "Urges City Fusion Movement," that municipal government should be as free as possible from the influence of state and Federal politics. The political issues that divide our national parties have little to do with the problems of running a city.

LONDON, July 5 (Reuters) -- The London premiere of "Oh Dad, Poor Dad, Mamma's Hung You in the Closet and I'm Feelin' so Sad" by Arthur Kopit, a 24-year-old New Yorker, proved tonight to be as baffling as its title.
Joseph P. Kelly, former New York State Commissioner of Motor Vehicles, became the port's forty-first Collector of Customs yesterday.
BERLIN, July 5 -- East Germany announced today plans for a major Government shake-up designed to bring an "urgent solution" for the country's new economic problems.

HELSINKI, Finland, July 5 (UPI) -- Jay Silvester of the United States Army, a shot-putter, and Bob Avant of the Southern California Striders, a high jumper, scored victories in the track and field "world games" at the Olympic Stadium tonight before a crowd of 15,000, but United States runners did not fare so well.
WASHINGTON, July 5 -- President Kennedy has invited several members of the Business Advisory Council to the White House tomorrow to tell about their grievances.

CHICAGO, July 5 (AP) -- The United States district court today gave E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co. sixty days to submit its proposed plan for disposing of its 63,000,000 General Motors Corporation shares.
Dark horses continued leading the major league packs after the Fourth of July -- a prophetic pole in baseball races, according to one of the game's respected legends.
The Cuban invasion captives in Miami announced last night the forming of their own committee to try to carry through a prisoners-for-tractors deal with Premier Fidel Castro.
A voice (and an important one) that has so far remained silent amid the furore touched, off by the increase in television station break time, is now being raised.

An 11-year-old schoolboy, Thomas Midgley of Paterson, N.J., is participating in a program that until recently was open only to farm youngsters. As a foster owner, he is helping to raise Seeing Eye dogs. The Seeing Eye, Inc., is a nonprofit organization in Morristown, N.J., that trains dogs to guide the blind.
PITTSBURGH, July 5 (AP) -- Vernon Law, his ailing pitching arm no better, returned from Chicago today for further treatment. The Pittsburgh Pirates' ace right-hander may go on the disabled list.
ALGIERS, July 5 -- Eighty Moslems were killed today in clashes during Algerian nationalist demonstrations and a general strike.
TUNIS, July 5 (AP) -- President Habib Bourguiba accused France today of sowing doubts about her real intentions concerning the evacuation of Bizerte, the French naval base in Tunisia.

Mayor Wagner proposed a broad program yesterday to keep the New Haven Railroad going. It included an immediate $5,500,000 Federal loan and repeal of the Federal transportation tax, at least for travel within a 250-mile radius of a central city.
The State of Maryland announced plans yesterday for borrowing $16,943,000 in the public market to finance public improvements. The bonds will be put up for sale on Aug. 2.

WASHINGTON, July 5 (AP) -- President Kennedy formally nominated deLesseps S. Morrison, Mayor of New Orleans, today to be United States representative on the Council of the Organization of American States.
GENEVA, July 5 -- Communist North Vietnam denied today a United States charge that it was intervening militarily in Laos.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector) July 5 -- Adolf Eichmann said today that his wartime offer to trade 1,000,000 Jews for 10,000 army trucks had been inspired not by pity but by bureaucratic pique.
Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange were unchanged to 5 points up yesterday.

The New York City League of Women Voters charged yesterday that voters might be disfranchised and nominating petitions invalidated because of the Board of Elections "failure to complete an annual mail check" on voting lists.

ACCRA, Ghana, July 5 -- The United Nations Commission on South-West Africa has warned Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold that South Africa's administration of the territory has caused a "grave situation."
OCEANPORT, N.J., July (AP) -- William G. Helis Jr Vox Pop, an 18-1 shot, scor an upset in the Sation Pur today at Monmouth Park as t favored Im Willing finish fifth.
VIENNA, July 5 -- Deputies in Parliament today urged the Government to go directly to the United Nations General Assembly with the dispute between Austria and Italy on Alto Adige.
The Broadway Bridge over the Harlem River at 225th Street was closed to traffic yesterday for the six-month job of installing lift machinery and reconstructing approach roadways.
WASHINGTON, July 5 -- The Embassy of Ghana confirmed today that President Kennedy had offered assurance of United States support in financing that country's Volta River hydroelectric dam.
GREENWICH, Conn., July 5 -- The Town of Greenwich met resistance today on plans to condemn a sizable portion of the Greenway homestead for park purposes.
LONDON, July 5 -- Queen Elizabeth II conferred an earldom on Sir Anthony Eden today.

MILWAUKEE, July 5 (AP) -- The Milwaukee Braves snapped a four-game losing streak by sweeping a double-header from the Philadelphia Phillies. The Braves won the opener, 5 -- 4, in twelve innings and took the second, 4 -- 0, behind Lew Burdette.
LOS ANGELES, July 6 (AP) -- Bill White hit three homers and Bob Gibson another to power the St. Louis Cardinals to a 9-1 victory over the Los Angeles Dodgers tonight.
LONDON, July 5 -- Lord Carrington, First Lord of the Admiralty, announced today that he intended to establish a new security department in his Ministry.
BLANTYRE, Nyasaland, July 5 -- Colin Cameron is a young lawyer who came to Nyasaland from Scotland four years ago determined to make the idea of racial partnership work.
BUFFALO, July 5 (AP) -- A warrant charging 15-year-old Chyrel Lee Jolls of Buffalo with the kidnapping of a 5-year-old boy on June 22 will be issued tomorrow, the police said tonight.
Contracts totaling $375,792 for widening twelve crosstown blocks to speed the flow of traffic were announced yesterday by Manhattan Borough President Edward R. Dudley.

MIAMI BEACH, July 5 -- The convention of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters gave blanket "approbation" today to every action taken in the last four years by James R. Hoffa and all other officers and employes of the much investigated union.

In the editorial "Flare-Up Venezuela" in your June 27 issue year make the statement: "The Americans petroleum industry, which is so vital to Venezuela's economy, is not helping the Betancourt regime."
The Cleveland Indians, who have fallen on evil days in recent weeks, proved to be just what the Yankees needed to get going yesterday after their holiday stand-off against the Tigers.

MANILA, July 5 -- General of the Army Douglas MacArthur told the Philippine Congress today that the United States' failure to see the Korean war through to victory was "a major disaster for the free world."

For a lad who was advised in high school to stop writing because he had no talent, the late Ernest Hemingway managed to get forward pretty well with prose. He wrote limpid English, but this did not prevent him from having the warmest admiration for Pound and Joyce and certain other writers of the nonlimpid school.

Aggregate market values on the New York Stock Exchange climbed about two-thirds of 1 per cent yesterday. Almost every group participated in the advance, which came on increased volume, but oils were weak and steels were mixed.
LONDON, July 5 -- The Labor party leveled a strong attack in the House of Commons today against British policy toward Portugal.
DETROIT, July 5 -- Distribution of Federal food stamps to welfare recipients and others of low income began in Detroit today.

SEOUL, Korea, July 5 (AP) -- South Korea's military rulers pressed their anti- Communist campaign with new vigor today. They charged a former law school dean, his wife and three others with being Communist spies.
CHARLOTTE, N.C., July 5 (AP) -- The police said a millionaire realty man admitted today that he had slapped a woman who later was found dead in her bed.

A former Navy shipbuilding expert has joined Grace Line in the newly created post of technical director. He is Rear Admiral Philip W. Snyder, whose appointment was announced here yesterday by Wilfred J. McNeil, president of the steamship line.
The twentieth consecutive season of weekly noonday band concerts in downtown Manhattan will begin today.
MANILA, July 5 (AP) -- General Douglas MacArthur told the Philippine Congress today that "global war has become a Frankenstein to destroy both sides."
LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, July 5 -- President Joseph Kasavubu signed a decree today declaring the opening of the Congolese Parliament as of July 15.

WASHINGTON, July 5 (AP) -- The Baltimore Orioles defeated the Washington Senators, 2 -- 0, tonight behind the four-hit pitching of Dick Hall. It was the Orioles' twelfth victory in their last fifteen starts.
Two former officials of a building maintenance company were arraigned in General Sessions Court yesterday on charges of having embezzled $184,626 by adding fictitious names to a payroll.

The first four plays in the Five Enchanted Evenings series for the benefit of the Hospitalized Veterans Service of the Musicians Emergency Fund have been announced by Mrs. Alfred N. Steele (Joan Crawford), honorary chairman of the events, and Mrs. Joseph A. Neff, chairman.
The city's billion-dollar-a-year construction industry began to feel the effect yesterday of two strikes that had been called at midnight Friday.
The Brooklyn Democratic organization formally endorsed State Controller Arthur Levitt yesterday as an opponent of Mayor Wagner for the Sept. 7 primary.
WASHINGTON, July 5 -- A Federal advance of $146,500 has been approved for New York City to begin a general plan for the so-called Museum of Natural History urban renewal area.
A touch of color and comfort was added to the subways yesterday when the Transit. Authority installed turquoise plastic benches on the platforms of several stations.
Following is the text of a statement issued yesterday afternoon by Mayor Wagner on the New Haven Railroad situation:
WIMBLEDON, England, July 5 -- America has a native son in Wimbledon final for the first time in six years.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 5 (AP) -- Vada Pinson and Gordy Coleman blasted homers for the Cincinnati Reds tonight as the former San Francisco relief pitcher, Sherman Jones, turned starter and beat the Giants, 3 -- 2. It was the first time Jones ever had started a major league game.

Leonard K. Guiler and Charles F. Donnelly have been elected vice presidents of S.H. Kress Co. Mr. Guiler, now chief financial officer, will continue as treasurer. Mr. Donnelly will continue as secretary and general counsel.

The New Haven Railroad, as it is known today, seems to be in its death throes. The eighty-nine-year-old carrier appears to have gone as far as it can as an independent entity operating in the general framework of private enterprise.
ROME, July 5 -- Pope John XXIII denounced today an "evil design" in Communist-dominated countries of Eastern Europe to eradicate the Christian faith.
The Federal Maritime Board announced yesterday the adoption of three general orders tightening its regulatory procedures over shipping companies engaged in foreign trade.
Fellowships have been awarded to eight journalists for the fourth year of Columbia University's advanced science writing program, the university announced yesterday.

Ships freed by a court order halting the maritime strike started moving out of coastal ports yesterday. But they left behind a deepening tangle as the rank and file of a major local rebelled, rejecting one contract won in the last days of mediation.

WASHINGTON, July 5 -- The American Medical Association opposed today major provisions of a bill aimed at reducing prices of ethical, or prescription, drugs and imposing new controls on drug manufacturer and distribution.
A $5000,000 emergency repair program to remove fire and health violations in the city schools was mapped yesterday by school officials.
Building permit values in 200 cities throughout the country set a new record in May, according to Dun Bradstreet, Inc.
None of the 338,000 persons receiving public welfare assistance here is likely to be dropped from the relief rolls because of the new state law that became effective last Saturday.
WASHINGTON, July 5 -- Senator Hubert H. Humphrey proposed today that the United States seek United Nations supervision over a program of underground nuclear test explosions.

THE day of the 10 per cent tip has vanished, according to Don A. Reed, a Chicago advertising executive who spends at least two days of every week away from home. The going rate in the East is 20 per cent, and in other parts of the country 15 per cert is acceptable.
John M. Bailey, the Democratic national chairman, said yesterday he was taking a "hands-off" position on the make-up of the party's city ticket.
Hugh O'Brian, better known to American Broadcasting Company viewers as Wyatt Earp, will co-star with Jane Powell in a special musical show on the network next season.
WASHINGTON, July 5 -- The United States was reported today to favor continued surveillance of the situation in the Dominican Republic by the Organization of American States.

Bill Tym of Montville, N.J., Karl Hedrick of Freeport, L.I., and Don Thompson of Forest Hills, Queens, scored upset victories in the third round of the New York State men's tennis championships yesterday. They reached the quarter-finals at the North Shore Tennis and Racquets Club in Bayside, Queens.

LONDON, July 5 -- The Monopolies Commission recommended today that the Imperial Tobacco Company, Britain's largest manufacturer of cigarettes and pipe tobacco, divest itself of its substantial holding in Gallaher, Ltd., its closest competitor.

Net operating earnings of the First National City Bank of New York for the six months ended June 30 were $35,448,000, or $2.84 a share, the bank reported yesterday. This compared with combined net operating earnings of the bank and its trust affiliate of $37,929,000 and $3.04 in the like period of 1960.

Employes of Bethlehem Steel Company have just learned through the company's Bethlehem Review, issued periodically, that, with the start of June, orders, production and employment showed a slight drop. In the first five months of this year all three were on the rise.
LONDON. July 5 -- The slide in stock market prices continued today.
MOAB, Utah, July 5 (AP) -- A bandit flagged down a car of tourists from Rockville, Conn., on a desert road last night, shot and robbed two persons and fled with a teen-age girl.
Hopes for a reunification of the Congo have been dimmed again by new feuds among the Congolese leaders.
The massive job of transferring driver license data on 7,000,000 New York motor vehicle operators to magnetic tape for electronic processing has begun in Albany.

The more-than-month-long battle as to whether Philadelphia's Playhouse in the Park to the right to stage next week Broadway's Pulitzer Prize-winning drama, "All the Way Home," is expected to be reviewed tomorrow.
WASHINGTON, July 5 (AP) -- A Nigerian economic delegation arrived today to promote trade between Nigeria and the United States.
PHILADELPHIA, July 5 -- The Rev. Dr. Ben M. Herbster of Norwood, Ohio, was elected first president of the new United Church of Christ today.
DETROIT, July 5 (AP) -- The five domestic auto manufacturers built 1,100,000 fewer passenger cars in the first half of 1961 than in the first half of last year, official company figures showed today.

MILWAUKEE, July 5 (AP) -- Twelve of the nation's leading ski jumpers were named today by the National Ski Association for the training squad for the 1962 international jumping championships in Zakopane, Poland.

Dr. Carl E. Barnes, vice president for research of the Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company (3-M) has resigned because of a difference of opinion over the company's research policy, it was learned yesterday.
" MARRIAGE IN PHILIPPSBURG,"* by Martin Walser, is a sort of "Babbitt" about the rising materialists of contemporary West Germany.
JACKSON, Miss., July 5 (AP) -- Seven Negroes sought to break the color line in Jackson today. All were arrested on charges of breach of the peace.
WASHINGTON, July 5 -- The Federal Trade Commission announced today far-reaching rule changes designed to speed the disposition of its case load.

The National Concert and Artists Corporation, the second largest concert management organization, has been sold to a music publisher, the Summy-Birchard Publishing Company of Evanston, Ill. The company recently bought the Civic Concert Service, Inc., a subsidiary of National.

TRENTON, July 5 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner took sharp issue with Governor Rockefeller of New York today for not signing a bi-state agreement designed to end inequities under the New York State income tax law.

TRENTON, July 5 -- The Appellate Division of State Superior Court ordered the State Board of Medical Examiners today to restore immediately to Dr. Albert L. Weiner his license to practice medicine, which was suspended eight months ago.

Second-quarter earnings of the Bristol-Myers Company increased about 15 per cent over the level of a year earlier, Frederic N. Schwartz, president, reported at the annual meeting yesterday in Wilmington, Del.

BAHREIN, July 5 -- Britain's chief political representative in the Persian Gulf area declared today that British troops would remain in Kuwait "as long as Kuwait's independence is threatened or as long as the ruler of Kuwait wants us."

Fifteen Iranian students staged a sit-in demonstration yesterday in the thirtieth-floor suite of Iran's Consulate General at 30 Rockefeller Plaza in an attempt to obtain passport extensions for two officers of the Iranian Students Association here.

When a hold-up man comes into Charles DiMaggio's grocery on Lexington Avenue and points a gun in his face he almost yawns. It has happened twenty times in the last fourteen years. Bandit No. 20, in fact, visited him last night.

SAN SALVADOR, July 3 -- The Salvadoran Coffee Company, S.A., is seeking a writ of relief from the Supreme Court to nullify a new decree-law that would give the El Salvador Government controlling powers.

RICHMOND, Va., July 5 (AP) -- A series of explosions hurled giant fireballs through a gasoline storage area on the city's waterfront early today. Homes across the street blazed from the intense heat and the James River was turned into an oily inferno.
Vito P. Battista, 50-year-old Brooklyn architect who will seek the Republican nomination for Mayor in the September primary, began his campaign yesterday.

The election of A.S.C. Hulton as president and a director of the Asiatic Petroleum Corporation, a member of the Royal Dutch-Shell Group, was announced yesterday. He succeeds David H. Barran, who has been appointed a managing director of the Royal Dutch-Shell Group in London.

Henry Winston, organizational secretary of the Communist party of the United States, said yesterday that President Kennedy's decision last week to commute his prison sentence had been "an act of courage."
WASHINGTON, July 6 (AP) -- Gen. Lyman L. Lemnitzer has declared that the United States cannot afford to give up one more yard to communism, for "we have been on the losing end for too long a time."
CERTAIN nice points in defense came up in today's deal. But the key defensive play was not made and so the defense failed. South made his contract and North-South went on to win the rubber.

ANTIBES, France, July 5 -- The Tour de France bike race is both outright violence and cunning subterfuge. It is men assaulting mountains like today's, legs pumping until the veins appear and hard knots of muscle move rhythmically under the skin.

Some of the town's nightclub impresarios will, as usual, shut their doors for from two weeks to two months and will breathe mountain air, enjoy ocean breezes or search for talent overseas. But many of their colleagues will be catering all summer long to some of their regular customers and, hopefully, a good percentage of the 4,000,000 to 5,000,000 persons who, from now until Labor Day, regard New York as a nice place to visit.
Floyd Cleveland Miller, a writer who served as a Communist agent here twenty years ago, identified Dr. Robert Soblen in Federal court yesterday as his contact with Moscow in 1945.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 5 -- The United Arab Republic and the Soviet Union demanded in the Security Council today that British military forces be withdrawn from Kuwait. The U.A.R. stated its position after Dr. Adnan M. Pachachi of Iraq had accused Britain of "gunboat diplomacy" in sending troops and naval units to the Persian Gulf sheikdom last Saturday.

Two hundred and forty-two fewer persons were injured in automobile accidents here last week than in the like period a year ago, the Police Safety Bureau reported yesterday. The total of injured last week was 974.

The Beatrice Foods Company has acquired the assets and business of Westerville Creamery Company of Westerville, Ohio, for 72,000 of its common shares, it was announced yesterday.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 5 -- Coroner Henry W. Turkel said today that an inquest into the death of George Vanderbilt would be held here tomorrow as originally scheduled. The widow of the sportsman will not be present. She is hospitalized because of an infection.
WESTPORT, Conn., July 5 -- Charges of murder and attempt to kill were lodged today against Brendan McLaughlin, 26 years old, who killed his father and wounded two policemen yesterday.

Injun of the Red Oak Stable ran as if a posse was out to get him in the feature race at Aqueduct yesterday. Taking the lead at the start of the mile-and-an-eighth Lawrence Purse, Injun remained there all the way to score by half a length over the Greentree Stable's Tutankhamen.

The widows of eight of the twenty-eight men who perished in the collapse of a radar tower off the New Jersey Coast last January filed suit in Federal Court yesterday for $2,800,000 in damages. The suit named the Federal Government and three private contractors as defendants.
The city's oldest fruit dealer, the Brown Seccomb Fruit Auction Company, Inc., filed a voluntary petition In Federal Court here yesterday for an arrangement of its debts.
A broad and active demand for high-grade corporate debt securities carried the bond market forward again yesterday with the resumption of trading after the Independence Day holiday.
ST. PAUL, Minn., July 5 -- The Minnesota Disaster Committee asked Secretary of Agriculture Orville L. Freeman today to declare seven more of the state's eighty-seven counties drought disaster areas.
GOSHEN, N.Y., July 5 (AP) -- Duke Rodney, driven by Eddie Wheeler, won the $7,050 Dickerson Cup at Historic Track today, scoring easily over Mata-star.

WASHINGTON, July 6 (AP) -- The Association of American Railroads today estimated the net income on the nation's Class I lines at $17,000,000 in the first five months of 1961. This compared with a net of $195,000,000 in the like period of last year and $234,000,000 in the 1959 period.

The wholesale commodity price index inched ahead to 84.5 on Wednesday from 84.4 on Monday. There was no index for Tuesday, Independence Day. The index, compiled by the Bureau of Labor Statistics, stood at 85.3 on June 28, 1960.
WASHINGTON, July 6 (AP) -- The Federal Bureau of Investigation appeared today to have ended its inquiry in the Pentagon for the sources of alleged leaks of military information.
Fidelity Capital Fund reported yesterday new highs in net assets, share value and number of shareholders as of May 31, the end of its fiscal quarter.

ACCRA, Ghana, July 6 -- Dealings in gold and external currency in Ghana are to be restricted to banks, corporate bodies and persons authorized by the Government, according to provisions of a bill introduced in Parliament today under a certificate of urgency.

Whatever the mountainous labors of the Democratic leaders produce today in the way of agreement on a New York City election ticket, a memorable string of conversational pearls has been left behind to adorn the political record. Dropped at various stages of the accommodation process, mostly in reply to reporters' questions, these include the following:
WASHINGTON, July 6 (UPI) -- The Washington Senators snapped the Orioles' four-game victory streak, 1 -- 0, tonight, as Dick Donovan pitched a four-hitter.
LONDON, July 6 -- A more cheerful tone dominated the stock market here today with buyers drawn in at the lower levels.
Another influential member of Congress has expressed concern to the Secretary of Defense about reports that the Joint Chiefs of Staff are being bypassed or ignored.
The Urban Renewal Administration granted $752,280 yesterday for the survey and planning of three urban renewal projects in New York City and two in suburban communities.
Broadway producers are pessimistic about reaching an agreement with the stagehands' union in time to avert a shutdown of legitimate theatres this summer.
AN hour of "Gunslinger" was eliminated last night on Channel 2 so that viewers could see and hear the late Sir Thomas Beecham as he conducted a program of light classical music.

Trans World Airlines, Inc., which last year had so much difficulty arranging new financing for purchases of equipment, is expected within the next two weeks to complete arrangements for borrowing some $140,000,000 from a banking insurance company group headed by the Irving Trust Company and the Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States.
A cramped, seventh-floor room overlooking Morningside Drive has become an informal, intellectual annex of Columbia University.

WASHINGTON, July 6 -- Atomic Energy Commission officials said today they had no information confirming a report of an explosion in the Soviet Union that was said to have demolished a mountain in the northern Caucasus region.

PARIS, July 6 -- Jacques Chaban-Delmas, Speaker of the National Assembly, warned President de Gaulle and Premier Michel Debre today that Parliament would not be content with being a "simple rubber-stamp" body.
BOSTON, July 6 (AP) -- Phil Regan, Detroit right-hander, beat the Boston Red Sox, 3 -- 0, today with the assistance of Terry Fox and Rocky Colavito.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 6 -- The Mark Hopkins Hotel, a nineteen-story Nob Hill landmark since 1926, was sold today. The purchase price was given as "between $10,000,000 and $15,000,000."

MUCH of the interior of Australia is an arid waste and a good deal of it is genuine desert. In the middle of the Northern Territory there is an area called the Sturt Plain, the size of England and Wales together, where there are only three small towns and two roads. The rest is nearly uninhabited desert, a desolate region of sand, scrub, barren ridges, salt pans and patches of timber.

HENLEY-ON-THAMES, England, July 6 (AP) -- The rowing eights of Kent School of Connecticut and Eliot House of Harvard University emerged today as America's hopes in the Thames Challenge Cup event of Royal Henley Regatta.
I submit that your June 29 editorial "The Dark Ages in Newburgh?" could be in error. I willingly join those you defame as "know-nothings."
The nine City Councilmen from Brooklyn unanimously elected John F. Hayes yesterday as Borough President for an interim term expiring at midnight on Dec. 31.

The Appellate Division yesterday vacated the conviction of Martin Schulman, an operator in Greenwich Village tenement houses, who had been sentenced to fifteen days in jail for building code violations.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 7 points up to 2 points off yesterday. The far October contract showed the only decline. A point equals 5 cents a bale.
DETROIT, July 6 (AP) --The Fourth of July holiday observance is expected to cut United States car production 30.9 per cent from last week's level, Automotive News said today.

Archaeologists looking for treasure to dig probably couldn't do better than a group of university students in Japan. A large chunk of Japanese pre-history going back to Paleolithic times is conveniently situated on the campus of Japan International Christian University, near Tokyo.
WASHINGTON, July 6 -- President Kennedy discussed Civil Defense reorganization and fund requests today with top aides, but no firm decisions were made, according to White House spokesmen.
LONG BEACH, L.I., July 6 -- Irwin Steuer, New York restaurant owner and a Long Beach City Councilman, was found dead this morning in his car in the garage of his home. He was 42 years old.
Operations of the National Tea Company in the first half of this year resulted in higher sales and earnings than those of the 1960 period, the semi-annual report disclosed yesterday.

OTTAWA, July 6 -- James E. Coyne, Governor of the Bank of Canada, denounced Prime Minister John Diefenbaker today as the "evil genius" behind the effort to remove him from his post as the nation's monetary chief.
An important personnel change will be announced at the beginning of next week and it may have rather significant overtones.
Three unions will argue in Federal Court today against a permanent injunction sought by the Government in the nationwide maritime strike.

BINGHAMTON, N.Y., July 6 -- Mayor John J. Burns denied yesterday that a group of Binghamton industries called the Valley Development Foundation had "virtually superseded" City Hall in the planning of Binghamton's $80,000,000 renewal program.

The Carpenter Steel Company announced yesterday the acquisition of Nth Products, Inc., El Cajon, Calif., makers of thin wall tubing, for 15,000 of its common shares. Carpenter closed on the New York Stock Exchange at 44. Nth Products shareholders would receive one share of Carpenter stock for each ten shares of their shares.
KETCHUM, Idaho, July 6 (UPI)--Ernest Hemingway was buried today in the soil of the Western mountains he loved near the home where he wrote much of his prize-winning literature.

INSULATED picnic bags and metal coolers now make it possible to take almost any dish on an outing that involves eating al fresco. This includes vegetable salads of the type that are best served chilled.
PARCHMAN, Miss., July 6 (UPI) -- Two Minnesota officials on a mission ordered by their Governor paid a visit today to five Freedom Riders from Minneapolis held at the State Penitentiary here.

THE biggest drop in prices shoppers are likely to notice today is on blueberries, which are down a dime to 39 cents a pint. That sum may seem a bit extravagant, especially to anyone who has ever gone out and picked several quarts of wild blueberries in a short time.
A well-known British passenger liner will soon exchange the Red Duster for the tricolor of Italy.
KANSAS CITY, July 6 (UPI) -- Early Wynn posted his seventh victory of the season and 291st of his major league career today as the Chicago White Sox won, 4 -- 3, from the Kansas City Athletics.
Check transactions in the twenty-six leading cities of the nation totaled $25,888,525,000 in the holiday week ended Wednesday, Dun Bradstreet, Inc., reported yesterday.
PHILADELPHIA, July 6 -- Mayor Richardson Dilworth said today that his address at Independence Hall on July 4 had been borrowed from an article in last Sunday's New York Times Magazine.

SEOUL, Korea, July 6 -- Authoritative sources said today that the removal of Lieut. Gen. Chang Do Young from the military Government had become necessary because he had led a plot to "eliminate" his rivals in the ruling junta.

It is a problem to keep newborn infants and babies comfortable and cool when the temperature spirals up to the 90's. Inexperienced mothers are offered the following method, suggested by Miss Barbara MacCready, Public Health Coordinator for Obstetrics at Mount Sinai Hospital:
CINCINNATI, 6 (UPI) -- Manager Danny Murtaugh abided by the players' votes today in naming National League pitchers and reserves for the all-star game at San Francisco next Tuesday.
