ALBANY, July 6 (AP) -- A 13 per cent increase in the rates for insurance covering volunteer firemen injured on duty was announced today by the point Legislative Committee on Fire Laws.
WASHINGTON, July 6 -- Poland is seeking a loan of $180,000,000 worth of United States surplus commodities. mostly wheat. Negotiations have been proceeding here quietly but slowly since last month.

WASHINGTON, July 6 -- Inter-city truck tonnage in the week ended July 1, was 1.7 per cent above the 1960 level and 2.9 per cent above the preceding week of this year, the American Trucking Associations reported today.
SHAKESPEARE had a word for everything, even for the rain that disrupted Wednesday night's "Much Ado About Nothing" opening the season of free theatre in Central Park.

LOS ANGELES, July 6 (AP) -- The St. Louis Cardinals, mired in sixth place in the National League, today discharged Solly Hemus as manager and installed Johnny Keane as his successor. A manager of Cardinal farm teams for twenty years, Keane had been Hemus No. 1 coach.

TRENTON, July 6 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner said today that Governor Rockefeller and other New York officials "earnestly hope" New Jersey would be "foolish enough" to reject a new jet airport in North Jersey.

The Chase Manhattan Bank reported yesterday net operating earnings after taxes of $34,549,179, or $2.47 a share, for the first six months of 1961. This compared with $36,699,253, or $2.63 a share, in the 1960 period.
I say, "Well done, Newburgh!" for one, trust that the Newburg movement will spread and gather strength.
The Appellate Division of the State Supreme Court unanimously reversed a lower court decision yesterday that had supported the city's former ban on folk singing in Washington Square.

The Sun Oil Company and seven other petroleum concerns denied yesterday charges by independent tanker companies that they were using their vessels to carry competitors' oil at artificially depressed prices.
MANILA, July 6 -- General of the Army Douglas MacArthur returned to an old battlefield today as he visited the town of Lingayen, 100 miles north of Manila.
TRENTON, July 6 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner, in a protest to the Federal Communications Commission, moved today to block the sale of WNTA-TV to a New York educational group.
The band played, notables spoke and a crowd gathered for a close look yesterday at the ceremonial opening--again--of the city's oldest park, Bowling Green.
In spite of the nation-wide recession last year, the city's income from sales and business taxes rose to record levels. The taxes are generally regarded as business barometers.

The chairman of President Kennedy's fact-finding board in the maritime strike last night described some of the labor and management leadership in the negotiations as "the most callous people," who were less concerned with the national health and safety than with their own rivalries and jealousies.
TRENTON, N.J. July 6 (AP) -- All insurance companies with home offices in New Jersey will be required to block "conflicts-of-interest" by their officials under a new state directive.
Stocks rose yesterday for the fourth successive market day, although the rate of gain was considerably reduced.

BAHREIN, July 6 -- "Sir Charles is like a sheet of glass," said an awed subordinate of Air Marshal Sir Charles Elworthy, Commander in Chief of Britain's Middle East Command, the other day. "He is always exactly the same whether he is under pressure or not.
WASHINGTON, July 6 -- The State Department characterized the Soviet-North Korean treaty today as another "military link in the Communist colonial empire."
LOS ANGELES, July 6 (AP) -- Johnny Keane got a rude welcome as the new St. Louis manager tonight when Don Drysdale of Los Angeles held the Cardinals to five hits and the Dodgers won, 10 -- 1.
A 30-year-old housewife from Palisades, N.Y., was announced last night as the grand prize winner of radio station WQXR's twenty-fifth anniversary contest.

The flurry caused by Iraq's threat against the Sheikdom of Kuwait appeared yesterday to be dying down. The U.A.R. argued at the United Nations that the British ought not to have landed troops in Kuwait; but President Nasser did not interrupt the movement of British ships of war through what he considers his private waterway, the Suez Canal. The Russians objected, too, but only in words. They moved no troops.

The Anglo-Catholic faction of the Protestant Episcopal Church and Episcopalians yesterday met merging with other Protestant denominations would jeopardize the church's chances of reuniting with the Roman Catholic or Eastern Orthodox communions.

LONDON, July 6 -- The Royal College of Surgeons has awarded the Walker Prize to two Americans. Dr. Ludwig Gross of the cancer research unit of the Veterans Administration Hospital, the Bronx, N.Y., and Dr. Charles Brenton Huggins, director of the Ben May Laboratories at the University of Chicago.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 6 -- A coroner's jury of eight men decided today that George Vanderbilt had committed suicide. The jury attributed the act to despondency over ill health.
The State Investigation Commission, which last week completed its public hearings on the city's school building program, may inquire into other aspects of the schools here.

CLEVELAND, July 6 (AP) -- David Ott, president of the National Boxing Association, today warned the heavyweight champion, Floyd Patterson, that he must defend his title against a qualified challenger by Sept. 13 or the N.B.A. no longer would recognize him as champion.

The United Arab Republic was reported yesterday to have negotiated for the purchase of research rockets from private manufacturers in the United States. Washington is not expected to block the purchases.
An "Uncle Sam" daily double of $788.80 held the spotlight at Aqueduct yesterday.

THE glory day for the modern big leaguers will come in San Francisco on Tuesday when the all-star game is played. A week ago in Houston, however, baseball paid tribute to a remarkable little guy whose skill and integrity demonstrated the inherent honesty of the sport when such a demonstration was most needed.

CINCINNATI, July 6 (AP) -- The United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit, affirmed today the conviction of William Presser of Cleveland, president of the Ohio Conference of Teamsters, on a charge of obstructing the work of the United States Senate rackets committee.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 6 -- Britain pledged today that her military forces "will vanish from Kuwait as swiftly and as effectively as they arrived" if Iraq dropped her annexation policy toward the tiny sheikdom.

Alden Properties, Inc., has sold the six-story apartment house for sixty-five families at 3155 Grand Concourse, corner of East 205 Street, the Bronx. The building, which was erected by the seller in 1938, was sold for cash over mortgages amounting to $610,000. Anne Inselstein was the broker.
A Police Department traffic survey of the first six months of this year shows that 72 per cent of the victims of fatal and critical-injury accidents in the city were men.
MILWAUKEE, July 6 (UPI) -- Frank Thomas came through with a bunt in the seventh inning to squeeze home Lew Burdette and give the Milwaukee Braves a 7-6 victory over the Philadelphia Phillies today.
HAVING completed the enormous manuscript of "The Life and Times of Eugene O'Neill" Arthur and Barbara Gelb wonder what their life will be like in the future.

Price trends in the high-grade bond market parted company yesterday. Prime-risk corporate obligations continued in broad demand at prices 1/8 of a point higher than Wednesday's. But United States Government obligations eased in price by 2/32 to 6/32 in a dull trading session.

Hanover Properties, Inc., which built the six-story apartment house at 325 East Seventy-seventh Street in 1940, has sold it to an investing client of L. Fribourg, lawyer. The William K. Langfan Company was the broker in the sale for cash over mortgages amounting to $542,000.
The New York City Chapter of the National Association of Social Workers applauds your thoughtful and timely editorial.
Joseph Curtis White, a tax lawyer here, died Wednesday night after falling on a gangplank at West Fifty-second Street and the Hudson River and striking his head. He was 72 years old.
Strong White House pressure on city Democratic leaders to drop their plans for a primary fight against Mayor Wagner was reported yesterday.

WESTBURY, L.I., July 6 -- Because of a dearth of physically-sound, top-flight trotters in Europe, the third annual $50,000 Roosevelt International will be staged with a six-horse field the night of July 15 at Roosevelt Raceway.

WASHINGTON, July 6 -- Senator Estes Kefauver suggested today that the American Medical Association had relaxed its standards on drug advertisements in its publications to get more advertising revenue from drug makers.

Arthur Beeby-Thompson, a British oil engineer, has pioneered the exploration for petroleum from the African coast to the Baku oil fields of Imperial Russia to the booming wells of Texas. In "Black Gold," his autobiography, he relates the "incredible" adventures involved in a career that began in 1898.
The City Art Commission grudgingly approved yesterday the request of Robert Moses for removal of the "ornamental masonry" from the Brooklyn and Manhattan plazas of the Manhattan Bridge.
WASHINGTON, July 6 -- It is part of the mythology of official Washington that the American people have a tendency during international crises either to go crazy or go fishing.

TRENTON, July 6 -- In opposing the proposed establishment of an educational television station on Channel 13, Gov. Robert B. Meyner has some arguments in his favor. Economically and culturally, they may not be especially desirable or particularly practical.
CHICAGO, July 6 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), July 6 -- "I have never killed anyone, never mishandled anyone, never beaten up anyone."

WASHINGTON, July 6 -- The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People asked the Administration today to investigate alleged discrimination against Negroes by Westinghouse Electric Corporation and seven leading textile concerns.
" GREAT GHOST TALES," a dash of live television at a time when the medium is more moribund than usual, demonstrated last night that quality need not be confined to ninety-minute network splurges.

WASHINGTON, July 6 -- An unusual oceanographic research vessel -- a 355-foot-long tube that will float like a buoy and carry a four-man crew -- will be built this year under the sponsorship of the Office of Naval Research.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 6 (AP) -- Cincinnati's league-leading Reds scored their sixth straight victory today, beating the San Francisco Giants, 3-2, behind Jim O'Toole, a left-hander.
CHICAGO, July 6 -- Chao-ling Wang, A Nationalist Chinese Navy officer who lost a six-year fight against deportation last month, is living in Sao Paulo, Brazil, his lawyer said yesterday.

Quentin Gardens, Inc., of Brooklyn, has taken title to Quentin Gardens, an apartment development for sixty families at Quentin Avenue and Somerset Street in New Brunswick, N.J. The property consists of almost five acres of land and ten two-story buildings, each of which has six five-room duplex apartments.

PHILADELPHIA, July 6 -- Delegates to the General Synod of the new 2,000,000-member United Church of Christ indicated here today that they favored Communist China's admission into the United Nations and her recognition by the United States.
WASHINGTON, July 6 -- The Federal Government refused today to lend $5,500,000 to the New Haven Railroad. An announcement from the White House said there was no legal justification for the loan.

SALLY VICTOR fitted an outsized black velvet breton over her wispy gray-blond hair, pronounce it lovely but definitely not her type and, glancing into a mirror, discovered she was without both earrings and lipstick.

The Eighty-seventh Congress would be acting within its powers if it chose to ignore a promise written into the Colorado River Storage Project Act, a promise that Rainbow Bridge National Monument in the State of Utah would be protected from the waters impounded by Glen Canyon Dam. But whether ignoring this promise would be the course of honor and in the national interest is quite another matter.
MIAMI BEACH, July 6 -- James R. Hoffa predicted today that the merged labor federation would readmit the exiled International Brotherhood of Teamsters within eighteen months or break up.
THE Moiseyev Dance Company dropped in at Madison Square Garden last night for the first of four farewell performances before it brings its long American tour to a close.
The John Birch Society is asking its members to help it build up "the most complete and most accurate files in America on the leading Comsymps, Socialists and liberals."
Four of the proudest peacocks in town have special reason to be pleased. They decorate the north garden of the United Nations where their spectators include Dag Hammarskjold, the Secretary General.

In one of the most surprising moves in recent motion-picture affairs, Darryl F. Zanuck shifted one of his major films from Twentieth Century-Fox, the company he helped to organize and in which he is one the largest stockholders, to Warner Brothers, where he previously had been a top producer.
Rate reductions of 25 per cent on combined surface-air shipments between Alaska and the forty-eight states south of it will be available next month Alaska Airlines and REA E. press said yesterday.

Bellevue Hospital announced yesterday that a major operation scheduled for today would have to be canceled because of a shortage of blood. The hospital appealed for fifty pints of a common type, O-positive.
Commodities on New York exchanges showed a somewhat stronger tone yesterday in dull and featureless trading.

The mutual defense pact Russia has signed with North Korea has a significance that goes beyond the announced Moscow justification for the new treaty -- the need to counter "a growing threat" of aggression by the new military junta in Seoul.

DETROIT, July 6 -- Walter P. Reuther suggested today that the improved financial position of the American Motors Corporation would permit it to take the lead in setting a pattern in 1961 labor contract negotiations in the auto industry.
The new president of K.L.M. Royal Dutch Airlines said yesterday that this year would be unsatisfactory for most of the international air carriers even if there were a late summer upturn in business.
The Yankees, it seems, can just about do everything these days except elbow their way into first place.
BLOOMINGTON, July 6 (AP) -- Albie Pearson singled home the winning run in the ninth inning today as the Los Angeles Angels defeated the Minnesota Twnis, 12 -- 11.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), July 6 -- Shimon Peres, Deputy Minister of Defense, said today that Israel had given priority to her rocket program because of "grave defense problems."
MOUNT TABOR, Vt., July 6 -- Game wardens in many states have shortwave radios to cheek the license plates of cars parked near fishing waters. In Vermont, however, they still go by the book.

UNIVERSITY PARK, Pa., July 6 (UPI) -- Former President Dwight D. Eisenhower, citing a radical transition in world thinking, advised a group of 1,000 Explorer Scouts today to prepare for future leadership through education.
WASHINGTON, July 6 -- A Senator's daughter-in-law rescued President Kennedy's 3-year-old daughter Caroline from water over her head in a swimming pool last Thursday.

NEWARK, July 6 -- The New York Central Railroad stood fast today in its position that it wanted no part in restoring communter service on its River (West Shore) Division, which was stopped on Dec. 10, 1959 with permission of the Interstate Commerce Commission.

GREAT NECK, L.I., July 6 -- Mrs. David Johnstone shot a 41, 39 -- 80 for a 36-hole total of 159 and a two-stroke lead in the Women's Cross County Golf Association 54-hole medal play championship at the Wheatley Hills Club today.

Singly and in small groups, the athletes who compose the track and field squad that will represent the United States in dual meets against the Soviet Union, West Germany, Great Britain and Poland, began arriving in New York yesterday.
CHICAGO, July 6 (AP) -- Roberto Clemente, climbing to within 5 percentage points of the National League batting lead, today led a twenty-hit Pittsburgh assault that routed the Chicago Cubs, 15 -- 3.

Daily average borrowings by member banks of the Federal Reserve System declined $33,000,000 to $43,000,000 in the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. Daily average reserves in excess of requirements declined $82,000,000 to $530,000,000.

WASHINGTON, July 6 -- Nearly a dozen of the capital's leading real estate men promised the Government today that apartments they own would be immediately available for rent to African diplomats and their families.

The League of Women Voters yesterday stuck to its charge of faulty administration of the Permanent Registration Law by the Board of Elections despite denials by the board, and added details to support the charge.

Loans to business by the fifteen weekly reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve System in New York City declined $56,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.

Production of electric power totaled 15,183,000,000 kilowatt hours, compared with 14,870,000,000 the week before and 14,646,000,000 kilowatt hours a year ago, the Edison Electric Institute reported yesterday.
WASHINGTON, July 6 -- Department store sales in the nation in the week ended July 1, were 1 per cent below the level of the year-ago period.
ALGIERS. July 6 -- Seven plastic bombs exploded in Algiers tonight, wounding three persons. For the most part, the bombs had been placed before Moslem businesses.

WASHINGTON, July 6 -- Following is the text of the letter from Frank B. Ellis, Director of the Office of Civil and Defense Mobilization, to Secretary of the Treasury Douglas Dillon on the New Haven Railroad's loan request:
CHICAGO, July 6 (AP) -- A variety of influences contributed to an active grain futures trade today in which prices ranged from weak to strong.

PHILADELPHIA, July 6 (AP) -- Hearings on a Government petition to halt the merger of two large Philadelphia banks were postponed today until July 17 because of the death of United States District Judge Thomas C. Egan.

Drunkenness. Unemployment. Gambling. Overcrowding. Prostitution. Homosexuality. Narcotics addiction. Despair. These are things that went into the making of a brawl on West Eighty-fourth Street, in which 400 Negroes and Puerto Ricans battled Wednesday afternoon, fighting for they knew not what.
A charwoman asked the Government to cash two income tax bills yesterday and in the resulting confusion it was found she had $48,020.54 in her purse.

LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, July 6 (AP) -- Antoine Gizenga's leftist Stanleyville Government is quietly deploying troops around the home towns of Parliament members from the northeast Congo, United Nations military intelligence officers reported today.
PARIS, July 6 -- A rapid series of events in far-flung places has suddenly complicated, and probably lessened, the prospects of British entry into the European Common Market.

Detroit's ambitious boat-racing family, Joseph L. Schoenith and his son, Lee, has entered two speed boats of unlimited power for the summer's big event at Seattle on Aug. 6. This will be the $40,000 Seafair Trophy race which Seattle sportsmen organized when this years's Gold Cup was assigned to Reno on Aug. 26-27.
Plans are being completed for Joan Crawford to appear as narrator of "The Ziegfeld Touch" on National Broadcasting Company television next fall.
WASHINGTON, July 6 -- The Justice Department filed two suits in Mississippi today charging that Negroes had been denied voting rights in two counties.

WHEN Evelyn Lohoefer was 7 years old, she was called upon to perform in a joint piano recital with a number of other tyros. She dreaded the day. But her parents and piano teacher were insistent. When she finally faced the keyboard before an audience of other children and their parents, her stage fright deepened into such paralyzing fear that she fled the room after playing the first few bars.

WASHINGTON, July 6 -- The chairman of the House Committee on Un-American Activities set out today to abolish a State Department bureau largely because of the two men chosen by President Kennedy to run it.

BERLIN, July 6 -- Walter Ulbricht, East German Communist leader and chief of state, said today that his Government would not use force to attain its aims in Berlin. He declared: "There will be no shooting."
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 6 -- Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold was asked today to consider convening the Security Council because of "an explosive situation" in South-West Africa.
ST. PAUL, July 6 (UPI) -- Six golfers, including a club professional and a salesman, fired 6-under-par 66's today and tied for the first-round lead in the $30,000 St. Paul open tournament.
MIAMI BEACH, July 6 -- John Roosevelt told the Teamsters union today that if he were a member he would vote for a new five-year term for James R. Hoffa.
The Export-Import Bank has completed arrangements to lend to the Brazilian railroads $4,000,000 for new equipment purchases.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 6 -- If striking improvements are to be made in the quality of television series, they are more likely to be effected by Roy Huggins than by any of the writers or producers who complained at the recent Federal Communications Commission hearings that Hollywood has become video's "sausage factory."

Local premieres have been announced for two new features. Twentieth Century-Fox' "Francis of Assisi," a biographical drama in color with Bradford Dillman, Dolores Hart and Stuart Whitman, will open on July 27 at the Rivoli. The charity opening will benefit the Third Order of Saint Francis.

WASHINGTON, July 6 -- The Business Advisory Council, a semi-official adjunct of the Commerce Department for twenty-eight years, declared its independence today in a disagreement with Secretary of Commerce Luther H. Hodges.

The New York Giants acquired Jim Podoley and Joe Walton yesterday and sent their stock for the 1961 season soaring. The club thus filled a void that had been hampering its recent National Football League operations -- the lack of fast-moving ends who can catch the ball.

Hunt Foods and Industries, Inc., and Harbor Plywood Company are considering a plan whereby Harbor would be merged into Hunt through an exchange offer by Hunt for outstanding Harbor stock, it was made known yesterday by Martin Deggeller, president of Harbor Plywood.
KARACHI, Pakistan, July 6 (AP) -- President Mohammad Ayub Khan said today that Pakistan was concerned, upset and disappointed about "United States policy in these regions."

The Times fails to comment on an aspect of the organization of welfare in New York State which establishes a circumstance in which such developments are almost bound to occur, by placing on small county and city governments responsibilities which are beyond their ability either to finance or to administer.

WASHINGTON, July 6 (AP) -- The Federal Communications Commission announced today a proposal to order both upward and downward adjustments in the rates charged by the American Telephone and Telegraph Company and the Western Union Telegraph Company for private-line service.

NOSTALGIA WEEK at Lewisohn Stadium, which had begun with the appearance of the 70-year-old Mischa Elman on Tuesday night, continued last night as Lily Pons led the list of celebrities in an evening of French operatic excerpts.

The strike of 2,000 truck drivers who haul building materials continued yesterday. As its effect on the city's billion-dollar-a-year construction industry widened, management sought the intervention of Mayor Wagner and Governor Rockefeller.

THE summer bachelor is a man who has come face to face with a fantasy. It is the fantasy of freedom, and the confrontation can be perplexing. These men, whose wives and children have departed the city for bungalow colonies and resort hotels, journey to their loved ones on Friday evenings and return to their offices Monday morning.
Twenty local housing authorities subsidized by the Public Housing Administration will offer issues of serial bonds totaling $60,315,000 Aug. 2 to finance low-rent projects.
A German who worked with the Office of Strategic Services here in 1943 and at the same time served a Soviet spy ring was identified in court yesterday as Dr. Hans Hirschfeld.
SYRACUSE, N.Y., July 6 (AP) -- It would be "far better" to drop President Kennedy's education proposals altogether than give support to parochial schools, a Methodist Bishop commented today.
GENEVA, July 6 -Communist China refused today to consider controls to guarantee the observance of a projected international pledge to respect the independence and neutrality of Laos.
The First Boston Corporation and Dean Witter Co. and associates are offering to the public today 375,000 common shares of Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation at $40 a share.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., July 6 -- A record entry of 179 began the forty-first New Jersey open golf championship today. Play started at 8 A.M. at the Plainfield Country Club and the last of the contestants teed off at 3 P.M., when tourney officials refused to allow any more to participate.
The city's first pre-paid prescription drug plan, covering 7,000 members of seven Bricklayer local unions and their families, went into operation yesterday.

MIAMI, Fla., July 6 (UPI) -- Federal agents seized alleged Communist-made linens in ten Miami-area shops yesterday and charged the "Crying Adjmis" with conspiracy to smuggle Chinese Communist goods into the United States.

WASHINGTON, July 6 -- Secretary of State Dean Rusk warned today that any serious cuts or changes in the Administration's foreign aid program would be "a great mistake" in view of "our present relations with the Communist world."

The Soviet Union was said yesterday to be making strenuous and apparently successful efforts to prevent the principal Asian Communist regimes from slipping into the Peiping orbit. This was the interpretation placed by specialists in Soviet affairs on Premier Khrushchev's announcement of a new SovietNorth Korean mutual defense pact.

MOSCOW, July 6--The Soviet Union signed a ten-year military aid treaty with North Korea today. Moscow pledged to support the Korean Communist regime against possible attack "with all forces and by every means."

WIMBLEDON, England, July 6 -- It will be an all-British women's final in the All-England tennis championships for the first time since 1913. Angela Mortimer, a 29-year-old Devonian who took up for physical therapy, meet the top-seeded player, Sandra Reynolds of South Africa, 11 -- 9, 6 -- 3, in an interactive baseline duel today.
THE annual bi-state tournament conducted jointly by the Westchester and North Jersey Bridge Associations, will begin today at the Town House in Yonkers.

Tel-A-Sign, Inc., achieved record sales and operated in the black in the fiscal year ended last Feb. 29, A.A. Steiger, president, told the annual meeting of shareholders in Chicago yesterday. The company had had two straight unprofitable years.
WASHINGTON, July 6 (UPI) -- The Veterans Administration today opposed legislation that would permit 16,000,000 service veterans to reinstate their wartime life insurance policies.
WASHINGTON, July 6 (UPI) -- The Senate Agriculture Committee tentatively approved today two Administration measures aimed at cutting farm surpluses as part of a farm bill.

WASHINGTON, July 6 -- The United States Government has apparently discarded as unfeasible a tentative plan to offer Communist China equal representation with Nationalist China in the United Nations General Assembly.
WASHINGTON, July 6 (AP) -- It took two White House ceremonies today for Prosident Kennedy to present prizes to the two winners of the Elks' national youth-leadership contest.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I. July 6 -- The Thomas Halsey house on South Main Street here, whose main section was built more than 300 years ago by one of the founders of the town, soon will be open to the public.
I write to register my disapproval of your June 21 editorial re "The Birth Control Decision."
New Haven commuters at Grand Central Terminal showed little surprise yesterday at the news that time railroad had decided to seek bankruptcy.
LONDON, July 7 -- British officials are increasingly concerned about the lack of a clear-cut Western approach on how to deal with Soviet pressure on Berlin that is expected next autumn.
KUWAIT, July 7 -- Now that the British are here, Kuwaitis fee safe again. As a matter of fact, they feel safe enough to worry out loud about how to get the British out again.

HONG KONG, July 7 (AP) -- The Chinese Textile Manufacturers' Association reaffirmed yesterday its opposition to any form of restrictions on Hong Kong textile exports to the Kingdom and the United States.
SCHENECTADY, N.Y., July 7 (AP) -- A device so sensitive it can find a single speck lost among one trillion others has been developed for use against air pollution, it was announced today.
What a yachtsman might call flukey winds kept the stock market slatting its sails yesterday. After changing direction four times, the leading market indicators showed a small loss on the day.
Three film premieres have been announced for midtown theatres.

State Controller Arthur Levitt's candidacy for Mayor on the Democratic ticket completes the biggest political confusion in the biggest city within the memory of man. Although he quickly declared that "I am not obligated, nor will I be committed, to any person, group or organization," he is first and foremost the candidate of the Buckley-De Sapio-Sharkey triumvirate of party bosses, without whose support he would not now be in the race.
A supper dance has been arranged for Aug. 2 in the Embassy Ballroom at the new Summit Hotel. Proceeds will go to the Birth-of-a-Baby Foundation to encourage research in pre-natal problems.
The Federal Communications Commission has moved closer to hearings on problems affecting two New York radio stations.

The New Haven Railroad's petition for bankruptcy raises the question what will happen in its long-standing dispute with the New York Central Railroad over the Central's rich real estate in the Grand Central Terminal area.

SAN DIEGO, Calif., July 7 (AP) -- Lieut. Charlene Suneson, 27 years old, was getting ready today to say good-by to shore duty and become the Navy's first female line officer assigned to duty at sea. Her ship will be the U.S.S. Mann.

LONDON, July 7 (Reuters) -- A plan for a two-stage advance toward internal self-government for the Indian Ocean island of Mauritius was announced today by Colonial Secretary Iain Macleod at the end of talks here on a Constitution.
The New Haven Railroad filed for reorganization under the Federal Bankruptcy Act yesterday.

TACLOBAN, the Philippines, Saturday, July 8 (AP) -- General of the Army Douglas MacArthur arrived today in triumph on Leyte Island where sixteen years ago he waded ashore to fulfill his historic World War II pledge, "I shall return."
ROME, July 7 -- The "sweet life" of Rome seems even sweeter this summer.
A chronic traffic congestion problem at a midtown exit from the West Side Highway has worsened recently.

IN many respects, Riverhead, L.I., is a typical American small town. Main Street is the shopping center and is lined with the usual specialized shops. However, Riverhead is probably the only town in America where women buy their hats in a hardware store.
Rumor has it that Councilman Earl Brown is slated for the post in the Housing and Redevelopment Board recently vacated by Dr. Robert Weaver.

CIUDAD TRUJILLO, Dominican Republic, July 7 -- Dominican policemen opened fire tonight on a surging anti-Government mob. The demonstrators marched through the streets with torches and burned the studio of Radio Caribe.
WASHINGTON, July 7 -- President Kennedy will officiate at a White House ceremony Monday opening a national campaign to win support for his hard-pressed foreign aid program.
The Rev. Henry Ward Beecher, a man who auctioned slaves into freedom and campaigned for Abraham Lincoln, has been honored indirectly by the Federal Government.
VANDENBERG AIR FORCE BASE, Calif., July 7 (AP) -- The twenty-sixth Discoverer satellite-rocket was fired into orbit today with a 300-pound capsule destined for Hawaii.
WASHINGTON, July 7 -- William T. Smith was feted by twenty Republican Senators today for the ingenuity of his one-man campaign to get the Government out of agriculture.

The directors of the City Investing Company will vote on a proposed 5 per cent stock dividend at their meeting on July 19, it was announced yesterday. The company, which paid no stock dividend last year, previously declared the usual quarterly dividend of 12 1/2 cents a share payable on Aug. 11.
AN entry is a card that will win a trick, giving the lead to the hand that wins it. A winning card is not called an entry unless the player who holds it can make good use of his right to lead.
WASHINGTON, July 7 -- President Kennedy will meet with three of his principal advisers at Hyannis Port, Mass., tomorrow to discuss the problems of Berlin and Germany.

The special Presidential commission appointed to solve the airline industry's controversy over flight crews will open three days of meetings today in Washington with airline and union representatives.

A rat that assertedly was chased from under a radiator in a Harlem school during an inspection visit by Mayor Wagner was probably imaginary and was part of a "cleverly handled public relations stunt." Superintendent of Schools John J. Theobald said last night.
The restraining order that halted the nation-wide maritime strike last Monday was extended in Federal Court here yesterday until 4 P.M. next Wednesday.

The International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (World Bank) has approved a loan equivalent to $21,000,000 to the Commissioners of the Port of Calcutta, India. The loan will help to finance dredges and other floating craft to maintain navigation on the Hooghly River approach to Calcutta and equipment and works to improve the port.
From now on, anybody who steps into the Washington Square Park fountain will be all wet.

The market for new capital will be occupied with a number of smaller issues next week. In all, fixed-interest securities aggregating $90,663,000 are to be offered at competitive sealed, bidding. Most of the offerings will be municipal debt issues.

BALTIMORE, July 7 (AP)-A record-tying grand-slam homer by Jim Gentile and complete-game pitching by Chuck Estrada and Hal Brown sparked the Baltimore Orioles to a double-header victory over the Kansas City Athletics tonight.
PARIS, July 7 -- John Osborne's new play "Luther" opened here last night at the Sarah Bernhardt Theatre to mixed notices.
ALBANY, July 7 -- A special state investigating committee decided today that the proposed program to tighten welfare regulations in Newburgh violated both state and Federal laws.

WASHINGTON, July 7 (AP) -- Senator Jacob K. Javits, declaring that Soviet production could outstrip that of the United States by 1970, proposed today creation of a United States peace production board.

MORRISTOWN, N.J., July 7 -- Hickory Tree, Green Village, New Vernon, Chatham and surrounding hamlets, villages and towns in Morris and Union Counties made final plans tonight for an invasion of Trenton on Wednesday to oppose any jetport near here.
LONDON, July 7 (Reuters) -- A strike of 150 maintenance men over working conditions affected British Overseas Airway Corporation services at London Airport today for the second time in two weeks.
WASHINGTON, July 7 -- Representative Samuel S. Stratton accused Governor Rockefeller today of planning to "lay low" on reapportionment decisions for New York until after the fall Mayoralty election.
STAMFORD, Conn., July 7 -A twelve-acre tract has been given to this city for use as a park and a center for the performing arts.
JACKSON, Miss., July 7 (UPI) -- Eight more Freedom Riders were quietly arrested here today after refusing orders to leave the white waiting room of the Trailways bus station.
FORT BENNING, Ga., July 7 (UPI) -- Lightning from a summer thunderstorm hit an Army rifle range today, killing four soldiers and injuring at least sixteen.

THOSE who cook only on occasion, and then more for the pleasure they derive from it than from necessity, are likely to look down their noses at prepared mixes. But a busy mother with three meals a day to prepare finds such short cuts a great help.

Life in Alaska is described by two women in books to be published soon. One volume is Sara Machetanz's "The Howl of the Malemute," which William Sloane Associates will issue Aug. 9. Mrs. Machetanz has spent the last fourteen years traveling to and through Alaska with her artist husband, Fred.

WASHINGTON, July 7 -- Bell Telephone Laboratories, Inc., received a patent this week for a passive communication satellite. The parent concern, the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, has proposed a series of satellites to supplement existing cables and radio and to relay television across the ocean.
BATON ROUGE, La., July 7 (AP) -- The Southwide Conference of Municipal Officials was formed here today. It is designed to push the region's political and economic objectives.

ST. PAUL, Minn., July 7 (AP) -- Minnesota officials who interviewed five Freedom Riders imprisoned at Parchman, Miss., reported late today that they had found the young Minnesotans had not been mistreated.
The Democratic party here split wide open yesterday when State Controller Arthur Levitt accepted an invitation from organization leaders to challenge Mayor Wagner in the Sept. 7 primary.
WARSAW, July 7 -- Poland's senior Communist leaders left today for Outer Mongolia on a trip that may produce a new ideological attack on Communist China in its rift with the Soviet Union.

Hula Lou picked her way deftly through the pack and won the feature race by a half-length at Aqueduct yesterday. The 4-year-old filly, owned by the Rokeby Stables, was the favorite with the crowd of 27,128, and her victory was worth $6.60 for $2.

Gross operating income of the Superior Oil Company increased substantially in the quarter and nine months ended on May 31 from the levels of the year-earlier periods. Net income, however, was down, according to a report issued by the concern yesterday.
DETROIT, July 7 -- A surge of passenger car purchases in the final ten days of June kept retail sales of new cars for the month close to the strong May pace.

Late last summer the Murchison brothers of Texas -- Clint W. Jr. and John D. -- were ousted from the board of directors of Investors Diversified Services, Inc. The Murchisons announced soon thereafter they would wage a proxy fight to gain control of the Alleghany Corporation, the holding company which, in turn, controls Investors Diversified.
LONDON, July 7 -- Pakistan will not stand in Britain's way if she wishes to join the European Common Market, President Mohammad Ayub Khan said on his arrival here today.
UNTIL yesterday, Arthur Levitt was known as a man who took care to avoid making political enemies. There were far more friends than fights along his path to the office of State Controller.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 7 (AP) -- The St. Louis Cardinals presented their new manager, Johnny Keane, with his first victory tonight on a two-run rally in the ninth that beat the San Francisco Giants, 3 -- 2.

BURGENSTOCK, Switzerland, July 7 (Reuters) -- Jules Moch, former French Premier, warned the United States today that "ballistic isolationism," whereby it would not use nuclear weapons unless directly attacked, might compel its European allies to seek independent atomic weapons.
Rollins Broadcasting, Inc., is going into the outdoor advertising business.
WHEN the Prom Queen meets the big man on campus they get married, so the story goes. "And P.S. we did," the former Doris Krehmbrink said.
ALBANY, July 7 -- The Court of Appeals ruled today that it was legal for public schools to open each day with the non-sectarian prayer recommended by the Board of Regents.

GENEVA, July 7 -- W. Averell Harriman, United States delegate to the fourteen-nation conference on Laos, returned here today from a flying visit to Rome to see Prince Norodom Sihanouk, head of state of Cambodia.

The effective conduct of American diplomacy will be helped by the agreement of some leading real estate men in Washington, D.C., at last to make it easier for dark-skinned African Ambassadors and their families to find comfortable housing. It is strange that this should have been a problem, but it was. The State Department has also done something in a quiet way to make it pleasanter for diplomats from Africa to travel in the South.
The defense of Dr. Robert Soblen, on trial in Federal Court on charges of wartime espionage, sought to show yesterday that he dealt only in information of no military value.
A group of dissident shareholders of the Valley National Bank of Long Island, Valley Stream, have given up their attempt to upset the election of directors at last January's annual meeting.

WASHINGTON, July 7 (UPI) -- Republicans charged today that the bill carrying aid for parochial schools had been "loaded" by Democrats with political amendments to woo votes for President Kennedy's bill to help the public schools.
WASHINGTON, July 7 (AP) -- President Kennedy signed today a billion-dollar veterans' housing loan bill.
MOSCOW, July 7 -- A United States corporation signed contracts here tonight to act as agent for the sale of Soviet technological processes.

WIMBLEDON, England, July 7 -- Rod (The Rocket) Laver of Australia is the new champion at Wimbledon. And high time. The lithe, 22-year-old redhead, the runner-up the past two years, demolished Chuck McKinley of St. Louis, 6 -- 3, 6 -- 1, 6 -- 4, on the center court in fifty-five minutes today.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 7 -- The Soviet Union vetoed today a British resolution aimed at winning United Nations recognition of Kuwait's new independence and deterring Iraq from claiming the neighboring state.

ROME, July 7 - Efforts by national and international Roman Catholic offices for moral and cultural improvement of movies in the last twenty-five years have not "achieved durable results," Pope John XXIII said today in a letter to Archbishop Martin John O'Connor, American chairman of the Pontifical Commission for Cinema, Radio and Television.

DIOGENES' search for an honest man could be rivaled by a search for a man who feels that he earns as much money as he really needs and removes himself from the workaday world three months a year to soothe his nervous system and spend more time with his family.

The nation's crude oil output dropped 208,700 barrels to an average of 6,888,060 a day in the week ended Friday, June 30, the American Petroleum Institute reported yesterday. The decline was attributed partly to the maritime strike which resulted in supplies piling up at deep water terminals.

In the crusade for freedom he has proclaimed, President Kennedy faces one particularly difficult and delicate problem. This is how to deal with dictatorial regimes. Dictatorship is, of course, the very basis of Communist rule and no Communist regime could survive without it. But there are also dictatorial military regimes in countries outside the Communist bloc, including countries that are our allies or friends.

Jackson, Mich., Union High School District sold yesterday $4,300,000 of bonds due from 1964 to 1987 to Lehman Brothers and associates. The borrowing cost the government body 3.5398 per cent interest. The bonds were reoffered at prices to yield from 2.2 to 3.65 per cent.

The M.W. Kellogg Company has sold its property consisting of several industrial buildings and thirty-three acres of land at Route 440 and Droyers Street in Jersey City. The company is centralizing its production of piping systems for electric utilities in Williamsport, Pa.

LOS ANGELES, July 7 (AP) -- The Cincinnati Reds, capitalizing on a dropped fly ball, scored four unearned runs in the fourth inning and defeated the Los Angeles Dodgers, 11 -- 7, before 65,000 tonight.
The John A. Hartford Foundation, Inc., has awarded $101,459 to the Hospital for Joint Diseases to be used for establishing a biochemical laboratory.
BOSTON, July 7 (UPI) -- The Soviet Union is mapping the New England coastal waters in detail through its trawler fleet and a submarine, according to a top Navy officer.
BUFFALO, July 7 (UPI) -- The confession of a 15-year-old girl prompted officials today to prepare the kidnap-drowning of 3-year-old Andrew Ashley for grand jury action.

The East Ninety-first Street Realty Corporation has purchased the three five-story apartment houses at 306-08-10 East Ninety-first Street. The property, with a plot 75 by 100 feet, was sold for cash over mortgages amounting to $75,000.
JYVAESKYLAE, Finland, July 7 (AP) -- Murray Halberg of New Zealand cracked the world record for the two-mile run by 2 seconds today with a time of 8 minutes 30 seconds.

While State Department representatives were briefing members of the United States track and field squad here yesterday on how to conduct themselves behind the Iron Curtain, the conditions of selecting the squad fell under Congressional fire in Washington.

WASHINGTON, July 7 -- The use or surplus United States food to help finance the migration of more than 100,000 persons from the blighted drought area of Brazil's northeast to adjacent humid regions will be discussed here next week by Administration officials and a special Brazilian envoy.
PEARL RIVER, N.Y., July 7 -- A survey here shows that good students watch television with half an eye, but poor students tend to concentrate on the screen to the exclusion of other activities.
The $100,000-added Hollywood Derby and the $75,000-added Arlington Classic, both for 3-year-olds, are the top attractions of the thoroughbred racing program today.

Baseball's ultimate weapon -- the home-run bat -- was employed once by both sides at Yankee Stadium last night. Its benefits to the Boston Red Sox were negligible, however, and its contribution to the Yankees' 14-3 triumph was only a belated cruel redundancy.

LONDON, July 7 -- The stock market here finished the week on a slightly better note. The ending of the account coupled, with bargain hunting following Wednesday's heavy losses brought in buyers who had been deferring their purchasing until they considered the reaction had spent itself.

WASHINGTON, July 7 (AP) -- The Chesapeake and Ohio Railway closed its main case for its proposal to acquire control of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad by offering testimony today that the move "promises the salvation of the B. O."
WESTBURY, L.I., July 7 -- Adios Butler missed the world pacing record for a mile and a sixteenth by a second tonight in winning the $25,000 Little Pat Pace in 2:07 2/5 at Roosevelt Raceway.

WASHINGTON, July 7 (UPI) -- An Agriculture Department official said today that the Government would ignore local authorities in distributing surplus foods to needy persons in Tennessee's Fayette and Haywood counties.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., July 7 -- Senator Thomas J. Dodd, Democrat of Connecticut, declared tonight that most Americans were ready to champion freedom, but that political extremists threatened to "pull us off the track."
WASHINGTON, July 7 -- The United States and the Soviet Union will begin talks here July 18 on direct New York-Moscow air service, the State Department announced today.
MOSCOW, July 7 -- The Soviet Union asserted today that the United States was preparing to resume nuclear testing.
WASHINGTON, July 7 (UPI) -- The Department of Agriculture reported today that United States farm exports set records in both value and volume in the fiscal year ended on June 30.

A short while ago this newspaper recorded the exodus of "more than 5,000 happy youngsters" from the Grand Central Station to camps in the country and pictured excited parents saying good-byes to them near location signs bearing Indian names.

OTTAWA, July 7 -- The House of Commons voted today by 129 to 37 to dismiss James E. Coyne, Governor of the Bank of Canada. The Liberals opposed the Government bill to declare vacant his $50,000 job, because, they said, the Government had refused to let him state his case as is the right of any Canadian citizen under the Bill of Rights.
WASHINGTON, July 7 (UPI) -- The Air Force was taken to task today for paying $41,000 for a new screw-making machine even though the Navy had two of them in storage.

GOOD news for those families that move out-of-doors these hot sunny days is the Spanish Bazaar, which has recently opened on Altman's eighth floor. Lighting fixtures and decorative accessories for the patio and garden are high lights of the shop's collection.
WASHINGTON, July 7 -- The names of two prominent trans portation officials were mentioned in Washington today as possible trustees of the New Haven Railroad.
LONDON, July 7 -- The World Union for Progressive Judaism was informed today that Jewish religious activities in Cuba had been virtually eliminated.
WASHINGTON, July 7 (AP) -- The Federal Communications Commission elaborated today on what it wants to know about programming in reviewing radio and television licenses.

After long delays, a bill to create a Cape Cod national seashore already has passed the Senate and a similar measure is scheduled to come up in the House on Monday. We urge the House to pass it, thus assuring for the present public and for future generations a chance to see and enjoy unspoiled the sweeping beaches and wild dunelands of the Cape's "mightie headland."
MIAMI BEACH, July 7 -- James R. Hoffa was re-elected by acclamation today to a new five-year term as president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters.
WASHINGTON, July 7 (AP) -- Federal Judge Edward A. Tamm ordered the Bakery and Confectionery Workers Union today to hold a special convention here on Sept. 25 to elect officers.

BAYONNE, N.J., July 7 -- The appointment of Rear Admiral William Knickerbocker as commander of the Navy's Supply Center here was announced today by the Office of Chief of Naval Information in Washington.

LONDON, July 7 (UPI) -- The International Tin Council announced today that it had informed the United States that the council wanted to enter into consultations regarding the disposal of America's strategic stockpile of tin.
QUANTICO, Va., July 7 (AP) -- Capt. Ernest C. Brace, convicted of desertion by a Marine Corps court-martial, was sentenced today to "punitive dismissal from the Marine Corps."
MILWAUKEE, July 7 (AP) -- Pittsburgh rallied for two runs in the ninth inning off Warren Spahn to beat the Milwaukee Braves, 6 -- 5, tonight.

Scanners of the high-speed ticker tape -- especially those investors and observers with an interest in the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad Company -- will have to watch their V's and Q's in the future.
LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., July 7 -- Mrs. Allan A. Ryan of the home club captured the Women's Cross County Golf Association's 54-hole medal-play championship with a 75 for 236 at The Creek today.
Following is the text of the statement issued yesterday by George Alpert, president of the New Haven Railroad, after the filing of a petition in bankruptcy:
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 1 point off to 4 points up yesterday. Near October showed the only dip. A point equals 5 cents a bale.
A Protestant minister is off on a 35,000-mile circuit ride of the country's national parks.
Commodity futures moved in narrow price ranges yesterday in quiet trading on New York exchanges. More commodities showed declines than advances.

HENLEY-ON-THAMES, England, July 7 (UPI) -- Eliot House of Harvard and South Kent School of Connecticut maintained a powerful American challenge for Royal Henley Regatta honors today by qualifying for semi-final races tomorrow, the last day of the carnival.

The city's fifteen public welfare centers will begin on Monday to send to the State Employment Service applicants for aid who are suspected of having come here for the purpose of getting on the relief rolls.
ISTANBUL, Turkey, July 6 -- Preparations have been going on throughout Turkey for a popular referendum Sunday on a new Constitution.

WASHINGTON, July 7 -Planning for one of the stateliest of state dinners ever held in metropolitan Washington has raised some challenging problems in social logistics, insect control and weather hazards.
DETROIT, July 7 (UPI) -- Home runs by Steve Bilko and Earl Averill enabled the Los Angeles Angels to beat the Tigers, 4 -- 2, tonight for their seventh straight victory.
WASHINGTON July 7 (AP) -- Salaries of national leaders of American unions cover a wide range, with James R. Hoffa's $75,000 heading the list.
PHILADELPHIA, July 7 - "All the Way Home," the Pulitzer prize-winning play, will be performed by a stock company next week, as scheduled, at the John P. Kelly Playhouse in Fairmount Park.

WASHINGTON, July 7 -- Adolf A. Berle Jr. retired today as chairman of President Kennedy's task force on Latin America. In that post he helped to recast United States policies toward the hemisphere while becoming the center of a major controversy within the Administration.

CLEVELAND, July 7 (AP) -- Barry Latman pitched shutout ball and Willie Kirkland hit a two-run homer as the Cleveland Indians snapped a four-game losing streak with a 9-0 victory over the Chicago White Sox tonight.

Net operating earnings of the Meadow Brook National Bank Jamaica, Queens, for the first six months of 1961 were $3,223,747 or $1.13 each on the 2,840,935 shares outstanding. These were after certain nonrecurring expenses resulting from the acquisition of the Colonial Trust Company and the Queens National Bank.
DETROIT, July 7 -- The United Automobile Workers presented a series of proposals to the General Motors Corporation today aimed at creating additional job opportunities by reducing work time.

ROME, July 7 -- A spokesman for the Italian state fuel concern confirmed today a report that the Iraqi Government had asked if it could supply enough Italian technicians to replace all non-Iraqi personnel now employed by the Iraq Petroleum Company.

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), July 7 -- Adolf Eichmann, wilting under the first blast of cross-examination, admitted moral guilt today as an accomplice in the wartime annihilation of millions of Jews by the Nazis.

The State Supreme Court has dismissed a $1,075,000 damage suit brought by Local 824 of the International Longshoremen's Association against the Waterfront Commission. Justice Morris E. Spector found the commission "immune from liability" as a public agency.

The Western Union Telegraph Company reported yesterday gains in gross revenues for the first five months and for May of this year. Net income from operations for both periods, however, fell below the year-ago levels.
The man who guided the New Haven Railroad through its last period in bankruptcy -- from 1935 to 1947 -- said yesterday that he had no easy solution to the line's present problems.

It is far from generally recognized that the underlying cause of the economic, social and political difficulties which confront the under-developed parts of the world is the explosive rate of increase in their populations. Although this is really not a new set of forces, its impact upon the rapidly changing world of the twentieth century has emerged as of almost controlling importance.

WASHINGTON, July 7 (AP) -- Two members who praised in the Senate today J. Edgar Hoover, Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, and deplored any attempt to remove him stirred a burst of applause from spectators in the gallery, a breach of Senate rules.

OCEANSIDE, L.I., July 7 -This school district's summer recreation program, canceled because the State Education Commissioner had invalidated the school budget, will be able to continue if recreation employes are willing to work without pay for awhile.

The Realty Equities Corporation, Morris Karp, president, has sold the six-story apartment building at 3908 Bronx Boulevard, corner of East 222d Street, the Bronx. The buyer was an investing client of Arthur Friedland, lawyer.

The coronation of James R. Hoffa as sovereign of the giant Teamsters Union was duly solemnized yesterday by the same docile convention that had already rendered unto him the highest salary, the biggest war chest and the most centralized authority possessed by any union leader.
NEWARK, July 7 -- Indictments that resulted from a grand jury investigation of kickbacks in union welfare fund insurance were dismissed yesterday by Superior Court Judge Alexander P. Waugh.

The New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad was created as an auxiliary to the lively shipping trade and the thriving factories of nineteenth century New England. Its current ills are traceable largely to the sharp technological changes of the twentieth century.
Every weekday morning at 11:30 about two dozen men assemble around a large semicircular table in a modern office building at 113 Allen by Road, Tel Aviv, Israel.
MOSCOW, July 7 (UPI) -- Isaac Berger of York, Pa., was the only American to win tonight in a weight-lifting meet between the United States and the Soviet Union.

" THE GOLD-HATTED LOVER,"* by Edmund Keeley, is a summer novel about Americans on a Grecian holiday. It has the picturesque brightness of a postcard, and some lines that are as funny as those you get from your wandering friends in the morning mail at this season.
CHICAGO, July 7 (AP) -- Heavy late selling cut deeply into the prices of some wheat and soybean futures today, but other grains were mostly steady to firm in brisk dealings on the Board of Trade.
GOSHEN, N.Y., July 7 (UPI) -- Elaine Rodney set a world record at Historic Track today in winning the $14,500 Titan free-for-all trot.
LONDON, July 7 -- The pound sterling, under pressure for the last four months, had an erratic time on the foreign exchange markets today.
Following are the texts of the statements issued yesterday by State Controller Arthur Levitt and Mayor Wagner on the Democratic mayoralty race:
CARACAS, July 7 -- The Venezuelan Government's oil company has begun to drill a second well in Lake Maracaibo, it was announced today.

Running downhill for a long time, the New Haven Railroad has finally had to file for reorganization as a bankrupt. The petition has been accepted by the court and approved, as made "in good faith." All avenues of help had been explored and found closed.
WASHINGTON, July 7 -- The Association of American Railroads reported today that freight carloadings last week were 11.1 per cent below the level of the preceding week.

ST. PAUL, July 7 (UPI) -- Buster Cupit, a 34-year-old golf-club professional from Fort Smith, Ark., took the 36-hole lead in the $30,000 St. Paul open today with a five-under-par 67 for 133. He was a stroke ahead.
CHICAGO, July 7 (AP) -- Don Cardwell struck out eleven batters in a five-hit performance today as the Chicago Cubs defeated the Philadelphia Phillies, 9 -- 3.
A summer slump in donors has resulted in a dwindling but not critical supply of blood in the city's blood banks.

PHILADELPHIA, July 7 -- The General Synod of the United Church of Christ approved today the admission of Communist China into the United Nations. The action came at the end of the denomination's five-day meeting here in the Bellevue-Stratford Hotel.

Production of lumber in the week ended last Saturday totaled 209,740,000 board feet, compared with 240,648,000 the week before and 237,909,000 a year ago, according to reports from regional associations.
WASHINGTON, July 7 (AP) -- Joe McClain, Washington's rookie right-hander, shut out the Minnesota Twins on three hits tonight, 3 -- 0.

Prices of high-grade corporate bonds and of long-term United States Government securities moved in opposite directions again yesterday. For the corporate obligations, the trading session was strong and active.
A whodunit show for would-be connoisseurs of primitive art will open Monday at the I.B.M. Gallery of Arts and Sciences, 16 East Fifty-seventh Street.
KETCHUM, Idaho, July 7 (UPI) -- Mrs. Ernest Hemingway will meet four newsmen tomorrow morning to "clear up historical inaccuracies" about her late husband.

CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., July 7 (AP) -- An Atlas missile hurtled out of the Western sky and crashed into the Indian Ocean early today at the end of the longest military rocket flight on record -- a 9,050-mile journey from Cape Canaveral.

ABOARD THE UNITED STATES COAST GUARD CUTTER DEXTER EN ROUTE TO HONOLULU, July 7 (AP) -- Sirius II, the scratch boat in the twenty-second biennial yacht race from Los Angeles to Honolulu, held her front-running position today.
LONDON, July 7 -- The Soviet Union opened an impressive trade fair here today, said by Soviet representatives to be the largest it has ever held abroad.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., July 7 -- Stan Mosel of Essex Fells shared the lead in the New Jersey open golf championship at the Plainfield Country Club today, following a four-under-par 58. The 29-year-old professional, a native of San Antonio, Tex., posted a 36-hole aggregate of 144.

Westinghouse Electric Corporation's ordnance department received a $6,500,000 contract to produce a Navy torpedo, John H. Clotworthy, department manager, said yesterday. The torpedo can be carried by both conventional and nuclear-powered submarines, he added.

ALBANY, July 7 -- The Court of Appeals today ordered a new trial for a youth convicted of a double teen-age slaying on the West Side of Manhattan in 1959. The death sentence for a second youth was upheld.

I would like to submit a proposal for a practical compromise on nuclear tests. My suggestion is that the United States and Britain should agree to admit the "troika" method, not in general principle, but for a limited period of experiment.

WASHINGTON, July 7 (AP) -- The State Department said today that export licenses had been issued to permit the sale of weather rockets to the United Arab Republic by private United States manufacturers.

WASHINGTON, July 7 -- The United States and the Soviet Union have exchanged new accusations over the stalemated negotiations to achieve a prohibition on tests of nuclear weapons. Moscow, in a note it delivered Wednesday and made public today, charged that the United States was seeking to justify its intention to resume tests.

PARIS, July 7 -- in a sense the most important development uncovered by the Kuwait crisis is the decline of Soviet prestige among the Arabs. In 1955, with the decision to send arms to Egypt, Russia dramatically leapfrogged over the Baghdad [now CENTO] Pact and established a massive Middle East presence.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 7 -- Premier Abdul Karim Kassim of Iraq has stated categorically that he never said he intended to attack Kuwait. The Premier declared that he meant to bring about a union between Iraq and Kuwait by peaceful means. He added a threat of "major" consequences to those who opposed him.
HYANNIS PORT, Mass., July 7 -- President Kennedy arrived here shortly after 6 P.M. today for his second straight week-end in the sun.
In a test of occupational stresses, air traffic controllers will soon be wearing small radio transmitters strapped to their bodies during working hours.

SAN JUAN, P.R., July 7 -- More than thirty newsmen from the Western Hemisphere have concluded a series of seminars organized by the Inter-American Federation of Working Newspapermen's Organizations. The main purpose was to "warn against Communist penetration of the Latin-American press."

WASHINGTON, July 8 -- Outdoor Shakespeare has come here, thanks to a New Yorker who served her apprenticeship in Central Park. The impresario is Miss Ellie Chamberlain, who got her enthusiasm for outdoor Shakespeare from Joseph Papp and turned that enthusiasm into a successful production of "Twelfth Night."

I AM astonished at Mr. Greenberg's sudden modesty. I seem to recall, when I first met him in 1948, that he spoke loudly and clearly on all occasions about vanguard American art and artists. Also I seem to remember attacks under his byline on Arshile Gorky's paintings and that Mr. Greenberg later publicly apologized for them at a symposium where I happened to be the moderator.

A 37-year-old Brooklyn man fell thirty feet to his death yesterday from the backyard of one upper Manhattan building into the rear court of another. He was helping a friend move a refrigerator into an apartment house at the time.
A kind of domestic Peace Corps has settled on West 122d Street east of Morningside Park, spreading goodwill and paint in about equal amounts.

The B.F. Goodrich Company has consolidated sales activities of its various divisions with the Federal Government into one division. The new unit is called B.F. Goodrich Aerospace and Defense Products, it was announced last week. It supersedes B.F. Goodrich Aviation Products.

WASHINGTON, July 8 -- Those responsible for initiating and shepherding foreign aid legislation through Congress have long known and privately acknowledged that its most effective boosters are the men who direct the twists and turns of international communism.

The drought in the spring wheat belt of the United States and in the prairie provinces of Canada, the granary of that nation, may cut the yield of this year's wheat crop to the point where the North American output may be no greater than the demand.

MODERN musicologists in search of our musical past are a bit like archaeologists on the trail of a lost civilization. A few memorials and records survive and, somewhere, buried cities await the spade. But they don't even know where to start digging.

WICCOPEE, N.Y. -- Within two hours' driving time of New York, or about seventy miles, the lovely Wiccopee area east of Beacon on the Hudson River is a pastoral district with an unbelievable feeling of remoteness.

WESTBURY, L.I., July 8 -- There are many harness racing stakes that are older and quite a few that are richer, but there is none, that for glamour, pageantry, excitement and wild wagering matches the Roosevelt International Trot.

HOLLYWOOD THERE is no subtly plotted scheme in Hollywood to transform the image of the Hollywood producer. But without any assistance from Madison Avenue, the producer-stereotype is changing and has been changing for at least a decade.

MONTREAL, July 8 (Canadian Press) -- Marine engineers, worried by a steady fall in the level of the St. Lawrence River, are preparing a detailed study of a fifty-four-mile stretch of the river's channel east of Montreal.

During the recent debate over continuing the Federal "bonus" to states controlling outdoor advertising along the new interstate highways, all the old arguments were dusted off by Senator Kerr and the billboard lobby -- and were effectively demolished by Senators Neuberger and Cooper and their colleagues who led the fight for clear roadsides.

THE thirty-fifth annual festival of the International Society for Contemporary Music was held this year in Vienna. The event that attracted visitors from all parts of Europe and made this festival memorable was the world premiere of Arnold Schoenberg's oratorio "Jacob's Ladder."

THE conclusions that Harry Schwartz, Soviet affairs specialist for The New York Times, reaches in this review of developments in Russia are hardly optimistic: "Much of the growth in relative Soviet power and prestige as against the United States since 1945 has basically been the product of superior Soviet leadership.

CLEVELAND, July 8 -- A group of educators, religious leaders and business men have formed here an organization to alert the public of the area to the methods, history and perils of communism. It was incorporated this week as the Cleveland Council for Information on Communism.

THERE came to this desk the other day an item billed as "the hard to find edition of "The Whirligig Id and Other Regressions,' by Frank Irwin." The book is published by the Hillside Press of Franklin, N.H., and in truth it is hard to find. Measures 2 1/8 inches by 1 3/4 inches.

I was impressed by Tad Szulc's "The Two Cubas of Fidel Castro" (June 25). It points up democracy's problem with clarity. Can a free society provide for the workers the Soviet-style state's "not inconsiderable social and economic achievements" Mr. Szulc writes about?

AMERICAN photographers contribute about one-half of the ninety-four pictures in the recently published "Photo Maxima IV" (New York: Photo Maxima, $5.95). Italian photographers, who have been steady contributors to this annual publication from its inception, have about twenty pictures and Frenchmen have ten.

THOSE who have seen the film, "Tunes of Glory," for which James Kennaway provided the richly muted screenplay based on his own first novel, know that he is a writer strong on character and atmosphere. In his second novel, the 33-year-old author shows a taste and a gift for unconventional literary form, so superbly controlled that the word "experimental" seems a crude description.
This year's Gotham Ball will be held, as is customary, on Thanksgiving Night, Nov. 23. Mrs. William J. O'Shea is chairman of the twelfth annual event, which will take place at the Plaza.
The New York County Lawyers' Association made public yesterday its list of the standing and special committees for the year 1961-62.

MANY gardeners do not realize that not all cone-bearing trees (conifers) are evergreen; a few are deciduous (leafless during the winter). Two highly ornamental deciduous conifers, members of the pine family, are larch (larix) and bald cypress (taxodium).
Evidence sugesting a sharp rise in tension between the Soviet Union and Communist China provided a leading topic for world diplomatic speculation last week.

WASHINGTON, July 8 -- United States officials are convinced that the Soviet Union would be rebuffed by an overwhelming vote if it attempted to carry its case on the test ban issue to the United Nations General Assembly.

EDMUND KEELEY'S novel is adroitly written, comic in tone but edged with sadness. Its title, "The Gold-hatted Lover," is from F. Scott Fitzgerald; and his spirit, elegiac yet ebullient, informs its slight but shrewdly observed portrait of young Americans abroad.

MILWAUKEE, July 8 (AP) -- Two Pittsburgh left-handers, Joe Gibbon and Bobby Shantz, held the Braves to five hits today as the Pittsburgh Pirates scored a 4-3 victory and made it two in a row over Milwaukee.

College professors complain that the need to "publish -- or perish" hangs as an academic sword of Damocles over their chances for promotion. College presidents, especially in public speeches, agree with the professors' point that teaching is the first criterion by which faculties should be judged.
WASHINGTON, July 8 (AP) -- Nine Senators plan a "last-ditch effort" to revive the Alien Orphan Adoption Act, which expired June 30.
WINNIPEG, Canada, July 7 -- The Canadian prairie provinces are in the grip of the worst drought since the "dirty Thirties."
WARSAW, July 3 -- Jacek Holowka, a crew-cut, 18-year-old high school graduate, walked out of a Warsaw University classroom at 11:25 A.M. today with a nervous smile on his face.

The International Ladies Garment Workers Union has given raises to 245 staff employes on its international payroll. The raises bring total increases for its 800 staff members this year to $1,000,000 annually. Earlier raises were effective in May.

IN his engaging autobiography, "Stride Toward Freedom" (Jawaharlal Nehru called his just "Toward Freedom"), Martin Luther King Jr. rescounts how listening to a sermon by the president of Howard University, he stumbled upon "the little brown saint," Mohandas Gandhi, and his philosophy or nonviolence.

MODERN art, which already has found acceptance in the American home, is now moving out-of-doors. Increasingly, architects and designers are treating gardens, terraces and balconies as open-air rooms. Now artists are creating sculptures that decorate and enhance alfresco living.

WASHINGTON, July 8 (AP) -- The United States Tax Court mundanely defined today such things as cost-basis and capital gains in relation to some of the Dead Sea scrolls -- regarded by many as priceless.

WELLESLEY HILLS, Mass., July 8 -- Betty Tobin, a 16-year-old golfer with a picture-book swing, returned to her home at 52 Standish Circle in this Boston suburb last week after a trip to "dreamland."

SAN FRANCISCO, July 8 (UPI) -- President Warren Giles of the National League and President Joe Cronin of the American League, early arrivals for the all-Star game on Tuesday, both predicted today their clubs would make good showings.
Mayor Wagner scored a strategic victory in his fight with Democratic organization leaders yesterday when he won the consent of Abraham D. Beame to join his ticket as candidate for city Controller.
The Espanol soccer eleven of Barcelona takes on the Shamrock Rovers of Dublin in the second game of today's International Soccer League doubleheader at the Polo Grounds.
The Union Castle Line's $30,000,000 passenger-cargo ship Transvaal Castle is being fitted out for her maiden voyage from Southampton to South Africa next Jan. 18.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 8 -- The latest effort to unionize California farm workers is about to become history.

TO attend the Royal Danish Ballet and Music Festival in Copenhagen this year after an absence of five years was to be both impressed and depressed, and to come away ultimately with a sense of the logic of the situation, which lies somewhere between these two extremes.

MARTINSBURG, W. Va., July 8 -- Fresh apples from the 1961 crop were moving from this belt today, and at the market one could still find some fresh apples from the 1960 crop, out of storage.

WASHINGTON, July 8 (AP) -- Representative John H. Dent, Democrat of Pennsylvania, said today he had asked and received the resignation of Stanley Metzger as chief of a House subcommittee studying the effect of imports, but Mr. Metzger said he had quit on his own initiative.
CHICAGO, July 8 -- Leonard P. Sasso's Globemaster passed Editorialist, a 70-1 shot, in the closing strides today and won the $108,900 Arlington Park Classic by a neck.

The California, first of four cargo vessels being built for the States Steamship Company, will be launched July 28 at the yards of the Newport News Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company, Newport News, Va., the shipbuilder announced yesterday.

OCEANSIDE, L.I., July 8 -- The majority of the staff working on this school district's summer recreation program agreed this morning to stay on the job voluntarily despite the voiding of the budget under which they were to have been paid.

WASHINGTON, July 8 -- The United States and the Latin American Governments are preparing to launch next month a ten-year cooperative program of economic and social development for the American republics.
BUENOS AIRES, July 8 -- Argentine officials in a flurry of diplomatic activity are seeking to work out with their neighbors a common line of action at next month's Alliance for Progress conference.

The piloted bomber, often characterized as "obsolete" in the age of the missile, appears to be extending its useful life in both the United States and the Soviet Union. Congress recently insisted, despite Administration opposition, on adding $525,000,000 to a military procurement authorization bill to obtain additional piloted bombers.

RED BANK, N.J., July 8 (AP) -- Bob Perri of Oceanport, N.J., and Victor Bupp of York, Pa., won Eastern Division championships today in the twenty-second annual National Sweepstakes Regatta on the Navesink River.

This summer, the islanders are up in arms against the devil, planning mass meetings on the beach and threatening to try to unseat elected officials who even think about a road down their precious sandspit.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., July 8 -- Another Farrell became an open golf champion today. This one was Billy, 25 years old, who became the New Jersey open titleholder with a seventy-two-hole score of 288.

This is one conclusion almost reached by the Columbia Broadcasting System, which has been trying to scare up some authors for six dramas to be seen next season.

MIAMI BEACH, July 8 -- One of the few things James R. Hoffa has never been accused of is excessive modesty. The chesty president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters has carved out for himself the most ambitious organizing assignment undertaken by anyone since John L. Lewis founded the old Committee for Industrial Organization in 1935.
BUERGENSTOCk, Switzerland, July 8 (AP) -- Senator Hubert H Humphrey of Minnesota proposed today that space be kept demilitarized permanently under United Nations control.

THE "Visit the U.S.A." program took a giant step forward when Congress approved and President Kennedy signed into law, less than a fortnight ago, the International Travel Act of 1961. The new bill established the first United States Travel Service, an agency dedicated to the pursuit of more foreign tourist business for the United States.

ARRIVING in the blackened ruins of Chicago from England just after the great fire, the Rowlands and their seven children set up housekeeping in three rooms. Though full of hardships and difficulties, the first year in the ruined city proved to be a happy one.

The Children's Health Service, now in its eighty-ninth year, will be the beneficiary of an Anniversary Dinner Dance in the Embassy Ballroom of the new Summit Hotel on Nov. 9.

LONDON. BETWEEN leaving his London office one recent Friday and returning to it on Monday, M.J. Frankovich attended meetings in Copenhagen, Munich and Paris. This drastic departure from the traditional English week-end would not strike Mr. Frankovich as worth remarking on.

WIMBLEDON, England, July 8 -- After twelve years of trying, Angela Mortimer is the women's champion at Wimbledon. She won today from Christine Truman, beset by cramp, bedeviled by nerves and dogged by bad luck, in the first all-British final here since 1914. The scores were 4 -- 6, 6 -- 4, 7 -- 5.
HONG KONG, July 7 -- To a newcomer, this tiny British Crown Colony on the brow of Communist China is a place of extraordinary contrasts and contradictions.

The National Aeronautics and Space Administration announced yesterday that it will soon launch a third Tiros meteorological satellite from Cape Canaveral, Fla. If successful, the 285-pound satellite will circle the earth every 98 minutes in a 400-mile-high orbit and, like Tiros I and II, will transmit thousands of television pictures of the earth's cloud cover for weather analysis.

NAPLES, Fla. -- Marco Island lies at the northern end of Florida's still wild and watery Ten Thousand Islands, in the Gulf just north and west of the Everglades National Park. GREENWICH, Conn, July 8 -- The thirtieth Stratford Shoal race of the Riverside Yacht Club had seventy-two entries, the most the fixture ever drew, today. MONTPELLIER, France, July 7 -- Mr. Average European Bike Racer spent today pedaling across Provence in a pack of his fellows. He pedaled easily this thirteenth day of the Tour de France because the country was flat.

For thirty-one years there had been no casual outdoor violence in Trujillo City, capital of the Dominican Republic.
