With its matinee on Wednesday, "My Fair Lady" plays its 2,213th performance and dethrones "Oklahoma!" as long-run musical champion. "Oklahoma!" achieved its 2,212 showings in 270 playing weeks, while "My Fair Lady" took 278 to bag 2,213 performances. The reason for the discrepancy is that the "Lady" adhered to an eight-performance-week schedule, while "Oklahoma!" had fifty-three nine-performance weeks.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., July 8 -- Commodore James B. Moore's Lure finished twenty-six seconds in front of Howard Seymour's Mutiny to capture Resolute Class honors in interclub sailing on Manhasset Bay today.

LEOPOLDVTLLE, the Congo, July 8 (AP) -- President Joseph Kasavubu today invited Gen. Victor Lundula to give up his rebel army command in Stanleyville and return to the Central Government with full military honors.

WASHINGTON, July 8 (UPI) -- The Federal Communications Commission announced the appointment yesterday of Roscoe L. Barrow, dean of the University of Cincinnati Law School, as a consultant on broadcast network practices.

The imagination of a school principal and the unwitting generosity of twenty alumni classes have made it possible for eleven juniors at Prospect Heights High School in Brooklyn to get a taste of college this summer. The girls enrolled last week in a six-week college-credit program for talented high school students at the New York State University College of Education in Potsdam.

Business statistics for Chicago and the State of Illinois displayed a mixed trend during April, according to the June Bulletin of the University of Illinois' Bureau of Economic and Business Research. Building permits for the city totaled $32,479,000 during the month for a gain of 17.5 per cent from the same 1960 period.
THE job of building a concrete terrace or patio can be speeded up considerably if the home owner orders his concrete delivered to the site already mixed and ready for pouring.
WASHINGTON, July 8 -- An African diplomat's chances of finding a place to live in Washington without meeting discrimination are better than ever, but his housing problem is still far from solved.
Anthony F. Arpala, vice president of R.E.A. Express, Inc. (formerly the Railway Express Agency), said yesterday he might accept a post as trustee of the New Haven Railroad if it were offered.

ALGIERS, July 8 -- Algeria's Moslem nationalists -- who by French estimate represent at least 85 per cent of 9,000,000 Moslems of this land -- showed this week that they can cripple the economic functioning of Algeria by stopping work.

LITCHFIELD, Conn., July 8 -- The annual Litchfield Horse Show Ball has been arranged for Aug. 12 at Kilravock Inn. The horse show will take place earlier that day, when it will mark its 122d anniversary.

ASHEVILLE, N.C. -- Summertime visitors to the colorful vacationland surrounding this resort city in western North Carolina will find a new attraction here this year, the restored log-cabin birthplace of one of the South's most picturesque political figures, Zebulon Baird Vance.

For the eighteenth time since the Taft-Hartley Act was passed in 1947, the law's emergency procedures were in operation last week -- this time in the dispute of maritime workers with the merchant marine. On Monday the Attorney General obtained a temporary injunction as the first step toward an eighty-day "cooling off" period in the strike.
LONDON, July 8 -- British diplomacy will seek an international arrangement to guarantee the integrity of Kuwait, qualified sources said today.

LEEDS, England, July 8 (Reuters) -- Fast bowling by Fred Trueman, who took five wickets without cost in twenty-four balls, played the major part as England beat Australia by eight wickets today and evened their test cricket series in the third match.

RIVERHEAD, L.I. -- The perennial proposal to construct a $300,000,000 vehicular bridge across Long Island Sound from the northeastern tip of Long Island to the Rhode Island-Connecticut shore has become of current interest again after a lapse of several years.

WHITE PLAINS, July 8 -- The creation of a fifty-member Board of Supervisors, providing for representation based upon population distribution, was proposed for Westchester today.

CHICAGO -- The changing skyline of this, the second largest city in the United States, is being seen by an ever-increasing number of visitors. Many are coming directly from European countries since, with the opening of the St. Lawrence Seaway, passenger liners to and from foreign ports now dock here.

HENLEY-ON-THAMES, England, July 8 -- South Kent School of Connecticut and Eliot House of Harvard were defeated today as Britain, Australia and the Soviet Union shared the major honors in the Royal Henley Regatta on the Thames today.

Only 10 per cent of oil terminals in the United States are deep enough for berthing supertankers, according to a comprehensive study of facilities completed recently by marine officials of the Humble Oil and Refining Company.

LONDON, July 8 -- Dr. Albert Schweitzer, philosopher and missionary surgeon, has agreed to serve as honorary head of a "spiritual summit" of world religious leaders proposed by Rabbi Maurice N. Eisendrath, president of the Union of American Hebrew Congregations.

AMITYVILLE, L.I., July 8 -- Assemblyman James Grover, a sailing enthusiast, took first place today in the Blue Jay Class open division as the invitation regatta of the Narrasketuck Yacht Club got under way in Great South Bay.

MR. Longstreth, a veteran writer of novels for boys, has cooked up a real clam chowder this time. It is a modern fairy tale with a Maine setting -- mystery, romance, danger and suspense, to the boom-boom of the surf. The hero, Howard "Howdy" Williams, is a "prince in peasant raiment" -- sensitive, bright, witty and brave.

FARMINGTON, Conn., July 8 -- Ch. Evening Star de Luchawon her fifteenth best in show -- all under different judges -- in the all-breed event of the Farmington Valley Kennel Club on the Polo Grounds today.

OCEAN CITY, Md. -- Tucked away on the extreme eastern terminus of the Old Line State on a sandy strip off the mainland, this bustling community is known affectionately to Marylanders as the "sun porch" of the state.

ANTHONY NEIL WEDGWOOD BENN, a fresh-faced, blond, 36-year-old Socialist, is the Prince Charming of a constitutional pantomime now being played out in Britain. Benn's title for the show is "The Persistent Commoner." Others call it "The Reluctant Peer" -- but that, Benn says, sounds like a bored nobleman refusing to do the household chores.
WASHINGTON, July 8 -- Psychiatric examinations of applicants for posts in the United States Information Agency have been suspended. There appear to be little prospect that the tests will be resumed.

SEVERAL years ago a young music instructor decided she should learn to play some of the music of Bach on the organ. She was already an accomplished pianist, but she thought -- quite rightly -- that she might gain increased understanding of some contrapuntal techniques she would have to teach in the future.

BUFFALO, July 8 (AP) -- The Justice Department has charged that Greater Buffalo Press, Inc., would hold a virtual Eastern monopoly in the printing of newspaper color comic supplements if allowed to shift printing operations south.

GREENWICH, Conn., July 8 -- Bob O'Connor of the New London fleet sailed Rambler to a 1-point lead as the District championship series of the International 110 Class began with two races off Indian Harbor Yacht Club today.

THE supreme tragedy of the twentieth century is ably detailed in this book by a young man who was 5 years old when the Spanish Civil War began. That war, originally a conspiracy by four generals against the legally elected government of the Republic of Spain, turned into a struggle between the right and left ventricles of the heart of Western man.

WITH new books in the summer doldrums, it is a pleasure to point out the admirable old ones in the current crop of paperback reprints (35 cents each unless otherwise noted), and in particular to remark that the serious, substantial detective story is much more in evidence on the newsstands than it used to be.

LOS ANGELES, July 8 -- Rather mixed prospects for recapturing the nation's second largest state in 1962 will confront California Republican leaders coming here Tuesday for a strategy meeting with Richard Nixon, titular leader of the party nationally.

JOHN KENNEDY'S political science teacher at Harvard, Arthur Holcombe, used to say that the heart of American politics lies in the national campaign. Not for a century, I think, has a campaign bared that heart so nakedly as last year's contest. And no book that I know of has caught the heartbeat of a campaign as strikingly as Theodore White has done in "The Making of the President, 1960."

LONDON -- A good case could be made that a grown-up can have more fun entertaining a child tourist in London than in any other place on earth. THE architect's completed plans for the New York State Theatre at the Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts were made public less than a fortnight ago. Six men were seized by a swift-moving team of detectives, patrolmen and policewomen early yesterday morning on charges of operating a gambling ring that had mulcted at least $100,000 from business men, a top-ranking diplomat and society personalities.
MEXICO CITY, July 3 -- There are increasing signs that the flow of Cuban and Communist propaganda is being slowed in Mexico.

The Federal Government will make a survey of consumer buying plans the week of July 17 in New York and 332 other sample areas of the country. The data will provide a clue to the extent to which recovery from the recession may go.

LEMOORE, Calif., July 8 (AP) -- The Navy commissioned its biggest air complex today. Under Secretary Paul B. Fay Jr. declared it was fitting that the jet and atomic age installation be located in the state where carrier-based flight was born.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., July 8 -- When Harvard was looking around recently for a new assistant director of athletics, officials decided that the ideal choice was occupying the desk of director of intramural athletics.

SMALLEST Brownie wishes three times for a toadstool house on Midsummer's Eve, but almost as soon as his wish is granted a boy toadstool collector threatens its destruction. DRIGGS, Idaho -- Many travelers, in their haste to reach the celebrated Yellowstone and Grand Teton National Parks near here, hurry past the Teton Basin without giving it a second thought, and this is a great pity.

BUENOS AIRES, July 4 -- A drastic decline in wheat exports this year and sharply expanded purchases of machinery and industrial parts abroad are continuing Argentina's unfavorable trade balance.

BOSTON, July 8 -- A proposal by the National Park Service for a national recreation area along the Allagash River in northwestern Maine is stirring discussion in New England.

RICHMOND Va., July 8 -- The ability of Senator Harry F. Byrd's political organization to re-establish its dominance over Virginia in Tuesday's Democratic primary appeared in doubt today.
JERUSALEM, July 8 -- The question "Who is a Jew?" is still a major topic of discussion in Israel.

IN the chronic self-examinations which have come to be our national sport, one area of comfort, one beachhead of satisfaction seems to hold against the tide of doubt. We are getting more and more cultured all the time: the figures say so. More people go to symphony concerts than to baseball games.

THE fall schedule of cruises sailing out of Port Everglades in Florida is expected to be the heaviest in that port's history. From September through December, there will be a total of fifty-one departures by cruise liners. That is eight more sailings than there were in the same period last year.
CLEVELAND, July 8 (AP) -- Cleveland beat the Chicago White Sox, 3 -- 2, today although Jim Grant's shutout bid was spoiled by Al Smith's two-run homer in the ninth inning.

THE current trend to the extremely fast lenses of "approximately f/1" aperture is premature, a German authority indicates in a recent article. There were corpses again in the streets of Algeria last week. The new outbreak of violence raised questions, first, as to the prospects for a settlement of the long and bitter conflict over Algeria; and second, as to the status of President de Gaulle, who has a heavy stake in an Algerian solution.

THIRTY-ONE years ago this summer one of the strangest legal battles in the annals of music was fought to its conclusion in the New York City courts. Retail sales in this area last week went above the 1960 level. Estimates of business by leading department store executives put the gain in volume at 6 to 8 per cent. BUFFALO, July 8 (UPI) -- Jackie Donnelly of Buffalo used in-and-out tactics tonight to win an upset split decision from Paolo Rosi of New York and take the vacant state lightweight championship.

Riley, director of the Cleveland office of the Ohio State Employment Service.

PAWTUCKET, R.I. -- The tourist with an hour to spare, whether he be following the new Heritage Trail through New England or simply heading for the Boston area by way of Providence, can spend it pleasantly and profitably inspecting America's first cotton mill and the first successful manufacturing plant in the Western hemisphere.

MOSCOW, July 9 (AP) -- Gina Lollobrigida walked out on Premier Khrushchev and other dignitaries at the opening of the Moscow Film Festival tonight. She had not been able to wait any longer for a bath and a change of clothes.

STAMFORD, Conn., July 9 -In the wake of yesterday's surprise defeat of Paul Shields' Columbia by Easterner and Weatherly, one of the largest spectator fleets of the series turned up at mid-Sound today for the informal 12-meter competition.
BOULDER, Colo., July 9 (AP) -- Bill Toomey, who was graduated from the University of Colorado this year, retained the Amateur Athletic Union pentathlon championship yesterday.
MILWAUKEE, July 9 (AP) -- Bill Virdon's two-run single in the seventh inning led the Pittsburgh Pirates to a 5-4 victory over the Milwaukee Braves today and a sweep of the three-game series.
Slightly firmer prices, which reflected steadier dry-cargo freight rates, characterized the ship sales market during the second quarter of this year.

Columbia College has "suspended" its compulsory sophomore course in Contemporary Civilization. The action came as a regretful admission that contemporary civilization had become too complicated and specialized to be taught by the ordinary contemporary teacher.
Herbert H. Lehman charged yesterday that the election of state Controller Arthur Levitt as Mayor would make Carmine G. De Sapio the undisputed political boss of the city and state.
BERLIN, July 9 (UPI) -- The Helmstedt access route to Berlin sprang to life yesterday with Soviet military activity and troop movements.
IDAHO FALLS, Idaho, July 9 (AP) -- Senator Frank E. Moss, Democrat of Utah, and six other persons were shaken up but uninjured when an airplane made a crash landing at Idaho Falls early today.

Lewis Littlepage, born into the Virginia aristocracy in 1762, sailed to Europe when 18 to join John Jay in Spain. There he began a career that brought him into close contact with most of the great figures of Europe and America.
Reports that George Alpert, president of the New Haven Railroad, might be named a trustee of the line when it is reorganized next month were circulated in Washington and New Haven over the week-end.
PARIS, July 9 -- The best time to halt trouble is before it starts, but nobody yet involved in the gathering Berlin crisis seems ready to accept this evident logic.

The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People reported yesterday that Negro political action last year increased in 95 per cent of the areas touched by the association's voter registration program.
The Association of National Advertisers has entered a vigorous protest against a part of the Defense Appropriation Act of 1962, already passed by the House and now before the Senate.

WASHINGTON, July 9 -- The United States was advised today that it must treble investment in scientific education and research in the universities if it is to meet its scientific needs over the next ten years. It was told that it must insure an opportunity for every interested student to become a scientist or engineer.

The State of New York has made a handsome purchase of 3,500 acres in the southwestern Adirondacks, including Nick's Lake, for a new public camp site. This is the first large Forest Preserve acquisition from the $75-million park bond issue -- and very valuable, because the state up to now has done little for that section in the park.
The notion that parents should not teach pre-school-age children to read may soon be overriden.

NEWBURGH, N.Y., July 9 -Ed Winrow of the New York Athletic Club finished first in the twenty-kilometer (12.42 miles) senior metropolitan Amateur Athletic Union championship and open road run today. The New York Pioneer Club gained the team title.
A team of experts of the Atomic Energy Commission will meet in San Francisco July 25 for a two-day discussion of problems in ocean transportation of radioactive material.

It is generally conceded that the architecture, the furniture and the dress of a people are determined to a large extent by the attitude and spirit of the age in which they live. The stresses of the fourteenth century, for example, are held to be responsible for the distortions and eccentricities that are evident in the architecture of the time.

DAR ES SALAAM, Tanganyika, July 9 -- Tanganyika is approaching independence in December with a minimum of fuss. But several subjects related to the new status, including problems of diplomatic relations and the maintenance of an expatriate civil service here, are widely discussed.
HONG KONG, July 9 -- Communist China reported tonight new food crises arising from drought in Anhwei Province of eastern China.

CIUDAD TRUJILLO, Dominican Republic, July 9 (AP) -University of Santo Domingo students today held their first unauthorized public rally in thirty-one years. It was promptly broken up by heavily armed national policemen.

Sulray, Inc., New York drug and cosmetics manufacturer, has entered the electronics field through the purchase, for cash, of Coast Coil Company, Los Angeles, Calif., it was announced over the week-end by Hal A. Salzman, president of Sulray.

GENEVA, July 9 -- The Swiss stock markets sagged heavily in the final two days of trading last week. Net losses, some of them sharp, prevailed in all Swiss sectors by the time trading closed on Friday.
Espanol of Barcelona, one of the Big Four of the game in Spain, may prove the main threat to Dukla of Czechoslovakia in the second section of play in the International Soccer League.
BRIDGEHAMPTON, N.Y., July 9 -- Vic Meinhardt of Merrick, L.I.; Frank Dominianni of Valley Stream, L.I., and Bob Grossman of Nyack, N.Y., provided the thrills for the sports-car racing crowd today.

LOS ANGELES, July 9 (AP) -- Frank Robinson drove in seven runs with two homers and a bases-filled double today as the league-leading Cincinnati Reds defeated Los Angeles for the third time in their four-game series, 14 -- 3.

Backing up his move with stepped-up military preparations and a spectacular air-power display in Moscow, Premier Khrushchev again calls for a "peace conference" to "liquidate the vestiges of World War II." By self-assumed "right" he summons to it President Kennedy, Prime Minister Macmillan and President de Gaulle, but not the country with which peace is to be made -Germany.

PARIS, July 9 -- The "word" is out in Western Europe: Germany will come around. What it means is that West Germany, after her September elections, will make the necessary concessions to permit a start on a common agricultural program for the six-nation Common Market.

TUCKAHOE, N.Y., July 9 -A throng estimated by Michael Finnerty at "no less than 6,000" watched performers estimated by Mr. Finnerty at "no less than 1,450 in number" compete in 110 events this afternoon at the fifth annual feis of the Erin Minstrel Society of America.
JACKSON, Miss., July 9 (AP) -- The number of Freedom Riders arrested in Jackson soared over the 200 mark today as seventeen travelers tried unsuccessfully to integrate terminal waiting rooms.
With one dramatic pronouncement following another, the nature of the Sept. 7 primary battle within Democratic ranks is taking on substance for the average voter.

FORT MADISON, Iowa, July 9 (AP) -- Craig R. Shaeffer, an Assistant Secretary of Commerce in the Eisenhower Administration, died today of a self-inflicted gunshot wound. He was a son of the founder of the W.A. Shaeffer Pen Company.
WASHINGTON, July 9 (AP) -- Bryan M. (Bitsy) Grant Jr. of Atlanta rallied today to win his third straight national senior clay courts tennis championship.

TENRI, Japan, June 9 (AP) -- Donna de Varona of Berkeley, Calif., bettered her unofficial world record in the women's 300-meter individual medley swim today. She covered the distance in 2 minutes 37.2 seconds, swimming against a four-member Japanese relay team.

WARSAW, July 9 -- An incident affecting the fate of one man has infused some optimism in the liberal branch of the legal profession, which holds that Western traditions of justice still flourish in Poland.

Seasonal slackening of steel output is likely to continue and similar easing of activity is likely in other major industries, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York says in its Monthly Review out today. Output in the automobile industry, in particular, will be affected by an early model changeover.
RIVERSIDE, Conn., July 9 -Robert Miller's Souffle, a thirty-two-foot ketch from the City Island Yacht Club, won the Riverside Yacht Club's thirtieth annual Stratford Shoal race today.

WASHINGTON, July 9 -- The United States plans to pledge to Latin America at next month's ministerial conference in Uruguay far-ranging financial assistance within the framework of the Alliance for Progress program.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., July 9 -- Herman (Swede) Whiton sailed the International Class sloop Alfa to victory over Warner M. Willcox's Stardust by half a length in the eighteenth Yacht Racing Association regatta of the season today.
Butterfingered safecrackers came away empty-handed yesterday from a burglary in Brooklyn.

ITALIAN night at Lewisohn Stadium Saturday evening was not the operatic free-for-all fun that it has sometimes been, but any loss of entertainment value was more than made up for by the gain in musical worth.

The Negro leader of a movement to prevent the integrated community of Lakeview, L.I., from becoming all-Negro said yesterday that the home mortgage policy of some Long Island banks was militating against integration.
ANKARA, Turkey, July 9 -Indications late tonight were that the voters of Turkey had approved the new democratic Constitution presented to them by Gen. Cemal Gursel's regime in the day's referendum.
For the fourth successive year, WPIX (Channel 11) will offer a season of educational programs, beginning on Monday, Oct. 2.
Mr. Wagner strengthened his ticket for the 1961 city campaign when he picked Abraham D. Beame as his running mate for Controller.
THE mention of an Emme hat brings two people to mind: the amiable little woman who is known in the hat trade as Miss Emme and the friendly, soft-spoken man who is Adolfo, her designer.

WASHINGTON, July 9 (UPI) -- Marie C. McGuire, Public Housing Commissioner, said today construction was started on more public housing units in the twelve months that ended July 1 than in any year since 1953.

HONG KONG, July 9 -- Growing uncertainty over Washington's policies in Asia has seriously shaken the confidence of its Eastern allies in its determination to defend the area against communism, according to reports reaching here from several key capitals.
DETROIT, July 9 (AP) -- The Tigers beat the Los Angeles Angels twice today, 1 -- 0 and 6 -- 3, behind the pitching of Frank Lary and Jim Bunning.
LAUREL HOLLOW, L.I., July 9 -- -Neal Shapiro scored 36 points and won the grand championship today at the North Shore Club of Equitation horse show.

The Music Grove in Prospect Park usually reverberates to the Sousa sounds of the Goldman band, bus yesterday it echoed to Shakespeare and competed with picnickers who preferred to sleep, perchance to dream.

ALBANY, July 9 (AP) -The state today limited to four ounces the quantity of medicines containing narcotics -- such as cough syrups -- that may be sold to an individual during a twenty-four-hour period.

The eleven-member Development Assistance Group, created to promote world trade and the development of under-developed countries, meets in Tokyo tomorrow to discuss, among other things, American protests against rising cotton textile imports into the United States.
MOSCOW, July 9 -- The Soviet Union exhibited new supersonic jet fighters and bombers today in an impressive show of air power.
THERE is an Arabic saying to the effect that the quantity of food that a guest consumes is a measure of his esteem for the host.

Empire Fund, the latest of the so-called "tax-free exchange type" of funds to receive an advance approval on tax-free status from the Internal Reve nues Service, has filed a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

GREENWICH, Conn., July 9 -- The largest entry of the season, thirty-five boats, competed today in the fifth of a series of regattas staged by the Greenwich Cove Racing Association. The skippers were favored by a five-to-seven-knot southeasterly wind.
Suicides fail to realize that tension and obstacles make life challenging, not futile, the Rev. George N. Marshall of Boston declared here yesterday.

MERCURY, Nev., July 7 -The heat of an atomic bomb detonated nearly four years ago is still oppressively perceptible in a deep mountain cavern here. But the heat, and concomitant radiation, have diminished to a point permitting, in the last few weeks, investigations that scientists originally suggested might not be possible for a hundred years.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 9 (AP) -- Jack Sanford and Sam Jones of San Francisco combined for a four-hitter in the second game of a double-header today, beating St. Louis, 6 -- 1, and ending a Giant losing streak at six games.

The American Civil Liberties Union will support a petition for a rehearing of the decision of the United States Supreme Court that upheld the constitutionality of the registration section of the Internal Security Act of 1950.
The Real Properties Corporation of America, Theodore R. Sayers, president, has contracted to buy the fifteen-story office building at 72 Wall Street, corner of Pearl Street.

WASHINGTON, July 9 -- Seventy-two Republicans and eleven Democrats in the House of Representatives protested today against the Administration's proposal for "back-door borrowing" to finance long-term foreign aid.
MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., July 9 -- Firemen kept two downtown streets closed today while they pulled down tottering walls, damaged by the "toughest" fire in Mount Vernon's history.

Harry Horwitz, realty investor, has taken title to the property at the northwest corner of Third Avenue and Thirty-seventh Street, which he bought recently from Anthony L. Adrian. The property, which consists of two store and apartment buildings on a plot 52 by 80 feet, is known as 560-62 Third Avenue and 167 East Thirty-seventh Street.
ST. PAUL, Minn., July 9 (UPI) -- Don January made up a four-stroke deficit with a 64 today and won the St. Paul golf open with a 72-hole total of 269, nineteen under par.

THE program called "Accent" illustrated anew yesterday afternoon the pleasures of modest television. The half hour on Channel 2 consisted of a leisurely and relaxed visit to Stratford-on-Avon in England and an informal conversation with Christopher Plummer, Vanessa Redgrave and Peter Hall, director of the Royal Shakespeare Theatre.
Justice and love are synonymous so long as justice is practiced according to Christ's teachings in the Sermon on the Mount, the Rev. John G. Donohue said yesterday in St. Patrick's Cathedral.

MARBLEHEAD, Mass., July 9 -- A close-winded pair of yachts, Wells Morss' yawl Legend and James L. Madden's sloop Gesture, today led a record fifty-one boat fleet in the Boston Yacht Club's Marblehead-to-Halifax race.
HYANNIS PORT, Mass., July 9 -- Chilly, gloomy weather made it easy for President Kennedy to devote himself today to his homework on Berlin.

Manhattan Borough President Dudley, discussing the city's continuing program for widening crosstown streets in his borough, says that only parts of some streets can be widened because of high vocal community opposition to some of the contemplated improvements. In general, he points out, business areas want the widenings; residential areas do not.
New York has the highest rate of traffic deaths in proportion to registered vehicles of any of the nation's nine largest cities, the Greater New York Safety Council said yesterday.

The new style mutual fund salesman hasn't got horns. He doesn't go around kicking dogs and cats and pushing old ladies into gutters. He isn't even that free-wheeling and inexperienced man described several weeks ago in Washington by William L. Cary, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, and by Representative Peter F. Mack, Jr., Democrat of Illinois, chairman of the House Commerce subcommittee that has threatened the complete investigation of the securities business.
LONDON, July 9 -- Opponents of unilateral nuclear disarmament by Britain carried their fight into the camp of the enemy tonight.
CEBU, the Philippines, July 9 -- General of the Army Douglas MacArthur left for Iloilo today on his last stop of his tour of the Philippines before his return to Manila.
TEL AVIV, Israel, July 9 -- Israel's announcement last week of the launching of her first metrorological rocket was designed to raze the wind out of the sails of the United Arab Republic.
The Ruppert Brewery will show a profit in the first half of this year -- the first initial haft-year gain since 1957, it was learned over the week end.
Five new films are scheduled to arrive in local theatres this week. The programs follow:
Except to a silk expert, efforts to make silk silkier might seem like trying to make water wetter.
The head of the State Investigation Commission said yesterday that the commission had found a "wide variety of pay-offs and bribery" in every New York City department it had investigated.
The fall opening of the Embassy Club of the Sheraton-East on Sept. 11 will be a benefit for Jobs for Youth. It will mark the first event in the 1961-62 series of the Friday Evenings.
The chaplain of Columbia University said yesterday that Episcopalians should not demand in merger discussions that other Protestant denominations accept the system of bishops as dogma.

CLEVELAND, July 9 (AP) -- The Chicago White Sox swept a double-header from the Cleveland Indians today. They took the opener, 7 -- 5, on Sherm Lollar's ninth-inning pinch grand-slam home run and the second one, 9 -- 8, despite Willie Kirkland's three home runs.
SEOUL, Korea, July 9 -- South Korea's military ruler is fighting desperately and so far successfully to wipe out opposition within the army junta that now controls the country.

The Rev. Dr. Paul Scherer, a guest preacher yesterday at St. Thomas Protestant Episcopal Church, Fifth Avenue and Fifty-third Street, said that generation after generation sought not only bread from God, but also plucked at God's sleeve demanding a miracle as proof of His existence.
LONDON, July 9 -- The British Government has withdrawn the permission given to the United Nations committee on South-West Africa to visit Bechuanaland.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 9 -- Major changes in the executive echelon at Twentieth Century-Fox were made known today by Spyros P. Skouras, president of the company.

The Stanley Warner Corporation in the quarter ended on May 27 more than doubled its profit for the preceding year's period. Profits in the nine months ended on the same date rose 30 per cent above the year-earlier level, according to the report of S.H. Fabian, president, released for publication today.
WASHINGTON, July 9 (AP) -- Camilo Pascual set down the Washington Senators on five hits today as the Minnesota Twins finally broke the jinx of their former home park with a 7-1 victory.

Prices of cotton in the domestic market closed the past week on mostly firmer ground despite a narrow trading range. At the close of trading on Friday, active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange were up 21 to down 6 points for the week.
KUWAIT, July 9 (AP) -Sheik Abdullah al-Salim al-Sabah, ruler of Kuwait, mounted a diplomatic campaign today to bolster his support among other Arab states.

How do the butcher and the baker view taxation? The National Federation of Independent Business, Inc., has just completed a nation-wide survey of small business regarding President Kennedy's tax revision program.

Dr. Mina S. Rees, Dean of Faculty at Hunter College, has been named Dean of Graduate Studies of the newly established City University of New York. Her appointment was announced last night by Dr. John Everett, chancellor of the university.

MANY people believe that the popularity of the oversized bed today is a new trend. However, the giant-size sleeper has its roots in the Elizabethan Age when community-style sleeping accommodations were common at wayside inns.
VANDENBERG AIR FORCE BASE, Calif., July 9 -- An Air Force C-119 Flying Boxcar recovered the capsule from the Discoverer XXVI satellite in the air near Hawaii today.

The committee on Federal legislation of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York endorsed yesterday a bill amending the immigration laws to ease quota restrictions and eliminate discrimination against Negroes and Orientals.
The summer exodus from the heat of the city is under way for a great many eager boys and girls, eager for camp, travel or perhaps just the green and shade of the woods.
MARCH AIR FORCE BASE, Calif., July 9 (UPI) -- Mickey Thompson, a 32-year-old driver from El Monte, Calif., set fourteen national and international auto speed records today.

LONDON, July 9 (AP) -- Jumbo Jim Elliott, the head coach of the United States track team that is heading to Moscow for a meet against the Soviet Union next week-end, threatened to pack his bags and go home today.

SIGHT-SEEING of an uncommon kind has resulted in two uncommon new books by British writers, Sybille Bedford and Robin Maugham. They set out to gaze if they could upon the countenance of justice in the countries they visited. For getting to know a place this appears to be as good a way as any and better than some ways.

TOKYO, July 9 (AP) -- Foreign Minister Chen Yi declared today that communist China would "abide by the 1957 Moscow declaration and the 1960 Moscow statement," Hsinhua, the official Chinese communist press agency reported.

The Chock full o'Nuts Corporation proposes to offer stockholder rights through the issuance of subscription warrants for the sale of $7,500,000 convertible subordinate debentures, it was announced over the week-end.
Rocks thought to be the first specimens ever obtained from the deepest layer of earth's crust have been dredged up from ocean depths north of Puerto Rico.

THE season in the sun, with its accent on outdoor living, triggers a new set of safety hazards that should make parents more careful about where they allow their children to play, the Greater New York Safety Council warned recently.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 9 -- A fleet of tankers belonging to the Navy's Military Sea Transportation Service is being transferred from a West Coast operator to three East Coast companies. It means the loss of about 350 jobs to members of the Sailors Union of the Pacific.

ABOARD THE COAST GUARD CUTTER DEXTER, July 9 (AP) -- The seventy-two-foot ketch Ticonderoga retained the lead today in the 2,225-mile trans-Pacific yacht race but was challenged for handicap laurels by the untried fifty-foot sloop Ichiban.

The Yanks polished off the Red Sox yesterday for the third time in a row, 3 -- 0, as Roland Sheldon scored his second consecutive shutout with a five-hitter and Roger Maris crashed his thirty-third homer. This made a gaudy show for a festive crowd of 47,875 at the Stadium.
CHICAGO, July 9 (AP) -Weather was the major consideration in the grain trade this week, although some other factors exerted influences as the market went into occasional broad swings.

An investment group headed by Edward Isaacs has acquired Hattie Carnegie, Inc., and its affiliated companies, according to an announcement made over the week-end. Mr. Isaacs said an immediate plan of aggressive expansion and diversification into fashion and allied areas would be undertaken.

John M. Bailey, the Democratic national chairman, and Representative William E. Miller, the Republican national chairman, were named yesterday to the board of trustees of the Citizenship Clearing House.

LOURENCO MARQUES, Mozambique, July 9 -- A Portuguese ship ran aground off this Portuguese East African colony last night and then was rocked by an explosion. Reports reaching here tonight said at least twenty-five of the 550 persons aboard had been killed.
FARMVILLE, Va., July 7 -Thirty-three teachers have given up vacation time to relight the lamp of knowledge for victims of Prince Edward County's school desegregation dispute.

WASHINGTON, July 9 -- The commander of the Allied forces in Europe believes that now is the time for a quiet building of strength "that would go a long way toward passing the Berlin ball back to Mr. Khrushchev."
The work of the special Housing Court, which was established in 1959, was praised yesterday by Chief Magistrate Abraham M. Bloch for its "importance in our continuing battle against the slumlord."

ADJECTIVES that professional wine tasters use to describe the qualities of various wines often confound the amateur. Some of the experts' terms, like "modest" or "pretentious" also have come in for ridicule, as Frank Schoonmaker, an American wine authority, recently admitted.

Your June 26 editorial "Religious Beliefs and Jobs" states that the Supreme Court held that the provision of the Maryland law requiring a test oath of public officials violated Article VI of the United States Constitution.
Three Brooklyn teen-agers in a stolen car just couldn't get away from the police yesterday.

SALISBURY, Southern Rhodesia, July 9 -- The eight-man United Nations committee on South-West Africa held a series of closed meetings in a Salisbury hotel today after learning that the British Government had suspended permission for the group to go to Bechuanaland.

The New Haven Railroad's bankruptcy presents the region it serves, the state governments concerned and the Federal Government with hard decisions. The railroad's essential commuter services cannot be discontinued and someone must pay for them.

The provisional closing notice has been posted backstage at the Forty-sixth Street Theatre, where "Donnybrook!" is playing. If business does not improve by Thursday, the musical will close Saturday night.
An Indonesian said here yesterday that the spirit of Christianity was "more alive in the younger countries of Asia where Christianity is a minority religion" than it was in Europe.
WASHINGTON, July 9 -- A massive jam is developing in Federal judicial appointments, and it is unlikely to be broken before Congress adjourns.
WASHINGTON, July 9 -- The earthy pork-barrel, in which politicians love to dip for projects for their home districts, has acquired proportions stretching into space.
PASSAIC, N.J., July 9 (UPI) -- A drunken gunman kidnaped a 31-year-old Clifton woman early today, but she disarmed him and leaped from her car before he could carry out his threat to kill her.

WALDEN, N.Y., July 9 (AP) -- The Ring's Banshee, a bassethound owned by Chris G. Teeter of Birmingham, Mich., and handled by W. Frank Hardy, today took best-in-show honors at the Wallkill Kennel Club's fourth all-breed dog show and obedience trial.
Greenwich Village burghers stared suspiciously yesterday as Henry Hope Reed Jr., the architectural historian, led another of his tours of places in the city.

An ever-growing army of part-time securities salesmen, whose 30,000 members include real estate men, insurance agents, housewives, taxicab drivers and policemen, was worrying Wall Street leaders last week.

Two weeks ago yesterday Premier Abdul Karim Kassim laid claim to the oil-rich sheikdom of Kuwait, which Britain had just released from the obligations of a sixty-two-year-old protectorate. Britain's answer was 5,000 troops and other defensive facilities, sent at the request of the Sheik of Kuwait, Abdullah al-Salim al-Sabah, in order to encourage Abdul Karim Kassim to adhere to what he called his peaceful intentions.

NEW DELHI, India, July 9 -The Indians are awaiting with keen interest, some uneasiness and a tinge of disdain the visit of President Mohammad Ayub Khan of Pakistan to the United States starting Tuesday.
A patrolman shot and killed a teen-ager who tried to run him down in a stolen car yesterday and who then fled a mile through the Bronx.
BONN, Germany, July 9 -Chancellor Adenauer asserted today that "controlled disarmament is the most important thing in the world -- nothing else."

BUFFALO, July 9 -- The Kennel Club of Buffalo presented its thirty-sixth annual best-in-show award today to a wire foxterrier, Ch. Cairncorm Rambler. The dog is owned by Barbara Worcester of Little Falls, N.Y., and handled by Ted Ward.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 9 (UPI) -- Six western states have united in an attempt to block efforts by both the Sante Fe and the Southern Pacific Railroad to acquire Western Pacific.
A revolution in low-cost housing projects to humanize them by providing concierges, English-style pubs and teen-age candy stores has been proposed by a housing specialist.
Weakness in the British pound sterling and Canadian dollar continued in foreign exchange dealings during the past week.

LONDON, July 9 -- Uneasiness over the state of Britain's economy and the expectation that the Government soon would invoke anti-inflationary measures had a depressing effect on the stock market last week.

WESTPORT, Conn., July 9 -- Who shall represent the United States abroad in the arts? Since ours is an open, democratic society, we generally do not order actors, musicians or dancers to travel or to stay home any more than we issue passports only to those who will be the most tactful overseas.
There have been changes in the night life of suburbia and near-by resorts during the winter.
BALTIMORE, July 9 (AP) -Steve Barber yielded only four singles today as the Baltimore Orioles blanked the Kansas City Athletics, 8 -- 0.
The election of Nicholas D. Biddle as chairman of the executive committee of the Puerto Rican Board of Guardians, Inc., 570 Fifth Avenue at Forty-fifth Street, was announced yesterday.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 9 -- In the Chinatown section of this exquisite city this is the Year of the Buffalo. In big league baseball circles, however, it is known as the Year of the Home Run. The blasters have been booming at a record rate this season and therefore the most awesome collection of power hitters in the annals of the all-star game is assembling here for Tuesday's mid-summer festival in Candlestick Park.
LEVITTOWN, L.I., July 9 -Residents of this community welcomed a delegation from Levittown, N.J., today to compare notes on the similarities and disparities of the sister communities.
ATHENS, July 9 (Reuters) -- An agreement was signed here today making Greece an associate member of the six-nation European Economic Communtiy.

CHICAGO, July 9 (AP) -- The Chicago Cubs' batting power offset seven errors today for a double-header sweep of the last-place Philadelphia Phils, 9 -- 8 and 8 -- 5. The second game was called after eight innings because of darkness.

Herb Fitz Gibbon 2d of Garden City, L.I., upset Dr. Richard Raskind of New York, 8 -- 6, 6 -- 4, 6 -- 2, in the New York State men's tennis final yesterday at the North Shore Tennis and Racquets Club, Bayside, Queens.

New York City banks charged an average of 4.65 per cent interest on short-term loans to business in the first half of June, according to the regular quarterly survey of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York of eight banks and twenty-three of their larger branches.

JACKSON, Miss., July 10 (AP) -- In Federal District Court today Judge Mize set Aug. 10 for a hearing on a 28-year-old Negro's suit for admission to the all-white University of Mississippi. The hearing was to have come up today, but it was postponed because of Judge Mize's participation in the three-judge panel acting in the Freedom Riders case.
WASHINGTON, July 10 -- The Government's borrowing costs rose slightly on two short-term bill issues in the latest auction, it was announced by the Treasury today.

Eighty-seven French architectural students arrived by air from Paris yesterday. Within a few hours, they were dispersed on foot throughout the midtown area, agreeing to begin with that New York's numbered streets were sensible -- in fact, "plus pratiques" than those at home.
After showing small gains during most of yesterday's session, stocks wilted just before the close of trading of the New York Stock Exchange and ended the day with trifling losses.
UTICA, N.Y., July 10 (AP) -- Fire officials sifted for evidence of arson today in the rubble of a new, $700,000 insurance building that was shattered by a pre-dawn explosion and fire.

A New York group has set up the first Negro-owned small business investment company to be licensed under the Federal law of 1958 creating this source of venture capital for small enterprises. The new company is known as Hudgins Associates Small Business Investment Corporation with offices at 501 West 145th Street.

DROP an orange and the result is generally a bruise. However, when an employe of the Air Reduction Company dropped one, the result was a potential new flavoring agent. The orange was frozen at the time of its fall and it shattered into thousands of tiny juice cells. The cell walls remained unbroken, retaining full flavor and making the crystals ideal as flavoring agents.

EASTCHESTER, N.Y., July 10 -- The Harrison Country Club team of George Duffy, assistant pro, and Mike Tartaglia took best-ball honors with a score of 32, 31 -- 63 at the Vernon Hills Country Club today in the one-day pro-amateur tournament of the Westchester Professional Golfers' Association.
Juvenile delinquency among Puerto Ricans in New York may be twenty times as high as in Puerto Rico -- and the cause appears to be tied to living in slum neighborhoods, not any ethnic trait.
Eight hundred of 2,000 striking construction drivers voted yesterday to accept a new contract, partly ending a nine-day-old tie-up here.
