A report just released by West Germany's Central Association of the Advertising Industry notes that advertising expenditures in the six Common Market countries aggregated some $1,500,000,000 last year.

TRENTON, July 10 -- The Erie-Lackawanna Railroad is planning to rehabilitate and improve substantially its passenger equipment and service throughout North Jersey, including possibly a rapid transit system.
Twenty-five kindergarten pupils are learning about birds -- and the birds and bees -- these days from three chickens that have been enrolled in Public School 125 at 425 West 123d Street.

Stephen J. Leslie, president and business manager of the Marine Division Local 25, International Union of Operating Engineers, reported yesterday his group had achieved two major bargaining successes in Southern areas.
A television series of four programs filmed in England will be presented on the "Catholic Hour" at 1:30 P.M. on successive Sundays, beginning Aug. 6, over the National Broadcasting Company network.
I was pained to discover that what I mistook for the sketch of a late eighteenth-century theatre -- Page 35 of your June 27 issue -- is, in fact, to be the theatre of the Lincoln Center, anno 1964.

AMAGANSETT, L.I., July 10 -- The Amagansett Village Improvement Society, which underwrites the cost of the upkeep of greens and trees here, will benefit at a fashion show-luncheon it is sponsoring at Gurney's Inn on the Montauk Hills on July 18.

Patrons of the Homemaker Service of the Children's Aid Society have arranged a theatre party at the Oct. 26 performance of "Sail Away." The new musical comedy by Noel Coward will open at the Broadhurst Theatre Oct. 3.
ON Saturday the Thoreau Society will hold its twentieth annual meeting in the First Parish Church in Concord, Mass.
The Quaker Oats Company would add cookies and crackers to its wide line of cereal products, feeds, flour and ready mixes, through the proposed acquisition of Burry Biscuit Corporation.

WASHINGTON, July 10 (AP) -- A Presidential emergency board recommended today that railroad yardmasters accept a wage increase identical with the settlement pattern adopted by virtually all other rail employes in 1960.

WARSAW, July 10 -- Wladyslaw Gomulka, Communist chief of Poland, said today that the "enemies" of communism had been disappointed in their hopes for an ideological dispute that would lead to the disintegration of the Communist bloc.
NEW DELHI, India, July 10 -- The Government made known today plans for the rapid spread of a system of grass-roots democracy throughout rural India.

Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz predicted yesterday that the "mess" in Mayor Wagner's administration would create enough revulsion against the Democrats to result in the election of several local Republican candidates as well as himself and his city-wide running mates.
A block of 727,200 shares of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation was sold yesterday by a group or underwriters headed by Kidder, Peabody Co.
WASHINGTON, July 10 -- President Kennedy has ordered an urgent review to determine whether the United States should increase its military strength to meet Soviet threats on Berlin.
TRENTON, July 10 -- Representatives Peter Frelinghuysen Jr. and William B. Widnall said today they planned to oppose at a public hearing here on Wednesday the building of a jetport in North Jersey.

A 4-year-old girl was killed and her 3-year-old sister was critically injured last night when the two fell from the roof of a four-story building while playing near their home in the Bushwick section of Brooklyn.

SEOUL, Korea, July 9 -- The Soviet Union's formal warning that it would commit its strength against any attack on Communist North Korea is regarded here and in Japan as a propaganda move that may have an adverse effect for Moscow.
WASHINGTON, July 10 (AP) -- The White House announced today the forthcoming retirement of two admirals and a series of command changes that would result.

WASHINGTON, July 10 (AP) -- The house today passed by a roll-call vote of 278 to 82 a bill sponsored by Representative Hastings Keith, Republican of Massachusetts, to create a 25,700 acre national seashore area along the outer coast of Massachusetts' Cape Cod.

WASHINGTON, July 10 (UPI) -- The Air Force confirmed today a Congressman's complaint that missile experts and other airmen had been assigned to swimming pool and golf course duty at a Kansas air base. It said this was wrong and that orders had been issued to stop it.

HAMILTON, N.Y., July 10 (AP) -- Delegates to Colgate University's twelfth annual Foreign Policy Conference responded to an appeal from President Kennedy today. They petitioned Congress to support the Administration's foreign-aid economic program.
ALBANY, July 10 -- State motor vehicle officials discovered to their consternation today that thousands of speeding convictions on their records had been invalidated over the week-end.
ALBANY, July 10 -- The state said today that it planned to resume its investigation of Nicolas Darvas and his book, "How I Made $2,000,000 in the Stock Market."

WASHINGTON, July 10 -- The Defense Department gave general endorsement today to a controversial provision that would prevent defense contractors from collecting Government funds to pay for advertising.
PHILADELPHIA, July 10 -- The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People opened its fifty-second annual convention here today in a mood of quiet purposefulness.

Service to and from Coney Island on two city transit lines was disrupted for three quarters of an hour yesterday by a stubborn fire in a three-story frame building. Two firemen were hospitalized by smoke poisoning.

OTTAWA, July 10 -- James E. Coyne, Governor of the Bank of Canada, whose dismissal has been ordered by the House of Commons after his refusal to resign, presented his case today before a Senate committee.
A new scapegoat has been found for the deplorable conditions in the city school system: the principals.
WASHINGTON, July 10 -- Abraham A. Ribicoff suggested today that child-labor laws be eased to allow children a "valuable" taste of "useful, gainful employment."

A new concern has been formed by Lear, Inc., to sell and construct American prefabricated homes in Europe, It was announced yesterday. The concern, called Methodes et Materiaux de Construction, will be a subsidiary of the Lear International division.
LOS ANGELES, July 10 -- James R. Hoffa's convention threat to "move in" on American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations jurisdictions was carried out on the West Coast today.

WESTBURY, L.I., July 10 -- There is one horse at Roosevelt Raceway that will never be a dog. If anyone doubts his permanent identity the horse has three heads to make the point insistently. He is the raceway's International Trophy and stands unequivocally for success.
The last of six modern banana carriers being built for the United Fruit Company will slide down the ways of a West German shipyard tomorrow.

Setting an example for all countries under military rule, Turkey, the biggest nation in the Middle East, has taken the first step toward a return to democracy by approving a new Constitution in a national referendum.
ALDERSON, W. Va., July 10 (AP) -- Mildred Gillars was released from the Federal Reformatory for Women here today.

CARACAS, Venezuela, July 10 -- Maj. Gen. Arturo Espaillat, former aide of the late Generalissimo Rafael Leonidas Trujillo Molina, was reported today to be under arrest in Ciudad Trujillo, capital of the Dominican Republic.
To determine good workmanship when buying clothes, the American Institute of Laundering offers the following advice:

BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 10 -- Experts on the Middle East and its oil industry expect Premier Abdul Karim Kassim to use Iraq's July 14 Independence Day celebrations for an anti-British campaign. They expect that the predominantly British Iraq Petroleum Company will be his immediate target.

BIRKDALE, England, July 10 (UPI) -- Left-handed Bob Charles of New Zealand and a young Scottish pro, John More, matched surprising six-under-par 66's today to break the Birkdale course record and lead the first-round qualifying play in the 1961 British Open golf championship.

WASHINGTON, July 10 (AP) -- New York State officials were told today that the new Federal program of aid to dependent children should cause little, if any, financial interference with relief recipient's working on public projects.
Household Finance Corporation, Chicago, the nation's largest personal loan company, hopes soon to begin financing durable goods purchases, H.E. MacDonald, president, said yesterday.,

WASHINGTON, July 10 (UPI) -- A member of the House Armed Services Committee asserted today that American taxpayers were being asked to bear $7,500,000 of the cost of a strike against the United Aircraft Corporation last year.

WASHINGTON, July 10 -- President Mohammad Ayub Khan of Pakistan arrives here tomorrow for talks with President Kennedy and will be the guest of honor at one of the capital's most talked-about social events of the year.
TOLEDO, Ohio, July 10 (AP) -- The Port of Toledo started operating the first foreign trade zone on the Great Lakes today.

WASHINGTON, July 10 (UPI) -- Speaker Sam Rayburn made it official today that there would be no House action this year on President Kennedy's proposal to include hospitalization for elderly persons under Social Security.

Since the emergence of the human species only one large land area of the world has been free from war. That is the ice-locked continent of Antarctica. Man is a newcomer there and he has been too busy combating the elements to fight his neighbors. In that vast region not a single human life has been lost at the hands of another.
LONDON, July 10 -- Stock market prices moved aimlessly here today with most of the net changes in pennies.
WASHINGTON, July 10 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture estimated today that this year's cotton acreage amounted to 16,561,000 acres or 3 per cent more than the 16,080,000 acres of 1960.

PARAMUS, N.J., July 10 -- Three Girl Scout troops for mentally retarded girls have been organized by the Girl Scout Council of Bergen County. The Bergen-Passaic unit of the New Jersey Association for Retarded Children is cooperating.
CHICAGO, July 10 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

The owner of a "sordid and shocking" rooming house at 307 West Twentieth Street paid $520 in fines and received a sixty-day suspended sentence to the workhouse in Housing Court yesterday. The defendent, Benedetto Tamburello of 309 West Twentieth Street, had pleaded guilty to a long list of housing violations when arraigned on May 9.

THERE is no way of telling how many people showed up at the Wollman Memorial Rink in Central Park last night expecting to see "Much Ado About Nothing." Instead of Shakespeare, they got Pergolesi, Rossini, Debussy, Britten and Colgrass.
CHICAGO, July 10 -- The leaders of the American Osteopathic Association attacked the American Medical Association today as a politically motivated group out to destroy osteopathy.
The military significance of alleged espionage here by Dr. Robert Soblen during wartime was stressed by the Government yesterday in Federal Court.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 10 -- Indications that American movie production is on the upgrade have been supplied by the Association of Motion Picture Producers, which represents most major studios in Hollywood.

The extension to Chile of a road-improvement credit equivalent to $25,000,000 was announced yesterday by the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (World Bank). The bank's affiliate, the International Development Association, joined with it in providing the major part of the credit, $19,000,000, which is to be used for secondary road improvement in southern Chile, the country's main agricultural region.
Mayor Wagner declared yesterday an "all-out war on the forces of crime, slum blight and poverty that have infected Manhattan's West Side."
LONDON, July 10 (AP) -- Joan Littlewood, the producer who discovered Brendan Behan and Shelagh Delaney, said today she had resigned from her much-praised Theatre Royal in London's East End.

MOSCOW, July 10 (AP) -- The United States track and field team arrived in Moscow tonight, more than two hours overdue because of a mix-up by the Soviet navigator assigned to guide the plane into Moscow Airport.
The American Telephone and Telegraph Company and its telephone subsidiaries consolidated -- the Bell System -- reported yesterday that it cleared $1,279,172,000 in the twelve months ended on May 31.
Coronet magazine will be discontinued with its twenty-fifth anniversary issue in October.

The opposition of Gov. Robert B. Meyner of New Jersey to the establishment of an educational television station on Channel 13 should not deter the Federal Communications Commission from the earliest possible approval of the metropolitan area's newest cultural outlet.
DUBLIN, July 10 (AP) -- Top-seeded Whitney Reed of Alameda, Calif., defeated Joe Hacket of Ireland in the first round of the Irish open lawn tennis championship today, 6 -- 4, 2 -- 6, 6 -- 4.

The First National City Bank of New York, second largest bank in the city, is reducing its service charges to regular checking account customers on Aug. 1. In contrast to special checking accounts for which a customer may pay 10 cents a check plus a monthly maintenance fee service charges on regular checking accounts are based upon the expenses incurred in handling the account, less a credit for the average balance kept on deposit.
LAS VEGAS, Nev., July 10 (AP) -- The United States project to put a nuclear-powered rocket on the moon is being delayed by a plumbers' strike, a spokesman for the Atomic Energy Commission said today.
DETROIT, July 10 -- The United Automobile Workers expressed opposition today to overtime for some workers while others were laid off.

WASHINGTON, July 10 (AP) -- The Atomic Energy Commission announced today it would make available about $80,000 worth of equipment to help develop peaceful uses of atomic energy in Argentina, Brazil and Israel.

Surely there must be a considerable reaction of protest to the news published June 18 regarding the partisan political activities of certain middle and high ranking officers in our armed services. I was pleased to see your editorial of June 28 protesting these activities.

LOURENCO MARQUES, Mozambique, July 10 (AP) -- The storm, explosions and fire that destroyed the Portuguese ship Save left 227 persons dead or missing and presumed dead, maritime authorities said today.
For a weapon which has been so long described as obsolescent, the bomber has shown a remarkable longevity and viability.
Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange rose 6 to 14 points yesterday. A point is 5 cents a bale.
A total of 196 selected high school students -- thirty-six of them girls -- started a four-week course in astronomy and space science yesterday at the American Museum-Hayden Planetarium.

CANBERRA, Australia, July 10 (AP) -- The United States called today on the Soviet Union and other signers of the twelve-nation Antarctic Treaty to honor its provision for unlimited inspection of the continent to make sure that the pact is being observed.

TELEVISION never has found a way to make very engaging use of the band show and last night's venture, "Glenn Miller Time," does not seem likely to break the jinx. The program over Channel 2 was a notably pallid affair; musically, it seemed little more than a passing suggestion of the late orchestra leader's handiwork and the incidental chitchat was terribly cloying.
TO Mohammad Ayub Khan, the intellectual is a "dangerous chap who may be good at debating but cannot make up his mind."

HARTSDALE, N.Y., July 10 -- Top-seeded Barbara Menoff of Lynbrook, L.I., won her opening match in the 15-year-old division as the New York State girls tennis championships got under way at the County Tennis Club today.

WASHINGTON, July 10 -- Top officials of the American Stock Exchange urged Congress today "by all means" to provide funds for the Securities and Exchange Commission to conduct a broad investigation of the nation's securities markets.
ATLANTA, July 10 (AP) -- Four railroads withdrew today their opposition to the proposed purchase of stock control of the Central of Georgia Railway by the Southern Railway.
LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, July 10 (AP) -- Secessionist Katanga Province seemed today to have veered again to an endorsement of the idea of Congolese national unity.

GENEVA, July 10 -- Adlai E. Stevenson, chief United States representative at the United Nations, said here today that Washington would regard a disarmament agreement as an "economic opportunity" rather than a "threat to our economic prosperity."

WASHINGTON, July 10 -- The index of average wholesale primary market prices rose 0.1 per cent during the week ended Tuesday, July 4 to 118.9 per cent of its 1947-49 base, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today.
Retail sales volume is continuing to gain but the total is still below the year-ago level.

The Midland Capital Corporation, a New York investment concern, and a Philadelphia investor have bought two shopping centers in Pennsylvania and one in New Jersey for a total of $4,100,000, subject to mortgages and blanket leases held by the J.A.R. Leasing Company.
Bank clearings in the twenty-six leading cities of the nation last month totaled $131,265,043,000, the highest for any June on record, it was reported yesterday by Dun Bradstreet, Inc.
A man, his wife and a former employer were arrested in Brooklyn yesterday and charged with conspiracy and grand larceny involving fraudulent claims for unemployment benefits.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), July 10 -- Adolf Eichmann foiled prosecution attempts today to force an admission that he hated Jews.

Earnings of the Great Atlantic Pacific Tea Company, Inc., in the thirteen weeks ended on May 27, were below the level of the first quarter of the preceding fiscal year, according to the report of Ralph W. Burger, president, issued yesterday.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., July 10 -- The Suffolk County Board of Supervisors today turned down a proposal by the Long Island Rail Road that its fifty-five passenger stations in the country be maintained by the local municipalities.
Departments of the city government will offer part-time jobs for the first time to qualified high school students who might otherwise drop out of school, Mayor Wagner announced yesterday.
Production of steel in the nation last week showed the sharpest week-to-week drop in 1961. The industry's usually slack summer period was deepened by the Fourth of July holiday.
WEST ORANGE, N.J., July 10 -- Mrs. William Tracy of Essex Fells led the qualifiers in the Garden State Women's Association championship today.

The Business Advisory Council completed its break with the Department of Commerce yesterday by changing its name, dropping its quasi-official status and offering its consultative services directly to any Government agency that asks for them.
ALBANY, July 10 -- The State Civil War Centennial Commission said today that a small parcel of New York State land in Virginia would be transferred to the Federal Government July 21.
WASHINGTON, July 10 -- President Kennedy said today he would appoint John B. Duncan, a career Government employe, to be one of the three members of the District of Columbia Board of Commissioners.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 10 -- The luggage of the St. Louis Cardinals was stacked neatly in the hotel lobby last night, ready to be whisked to the airport for the return trip to St. Loo. There was a gleam of satisfaction in Stan Musial's eyes as he walked buoyantly past the stacked valises. His was not among them. He was remaining.
The markets for fixed-interest securities drifted downward slightly in inactive trading yesterday.

Little Dick Weber explained his recent success on the Professional Bowlers Association tournament circuit yesterday by saying, "My carry was phenomenal." It certainly was. The 125-pound bowler carried home $17,030, including five first-prize checks, when the ten-tourney circuit was completed last June 23.

All the states, North and South, were full of excitement one hundred years ago as the Civil War engulfed the land. In Washington thousands of "three-month volunteers" were spoiling for a fight while a special session of Congress was passing taxes and loans and authorizing Lincoln to seek half a million recruits "for the duration."

Mayor Wagner promised yesterday to fight block by block, borough by borough, in the primary, in the general election "and for all of the full four years ahead" to smash the influence of Tammany Hall in the city.
DETROIT, July 10 (AP) -- The automobile industry is shifting its attention from the production lines to the labor conference rooms this month as the 1961 model run draws to a close.

RICHMOND, Va., July 10 -- Between 350,000 and 400,000 Virginians are expected to turn out tomorrow for the Democratic primary in what is regarded as a test for the dominant organization, headed by Senator Harry F. Byrd.
The temporary restraining order in the maritime strike was extended yesterday into an eighty-day injunction, staving off any renewal of the walkout until late September.

Joseph R. Weiss, the deputy superintendent of schools in charge of buildings, has been subpoenaed to appear today before a Queens grand jury investigating irregularities in the city's school building program.

Portland, Ore., sold $2,500,000 of harbor installation bonds at competitive bidding yesterday. A $1,500,000 issue of general obligation bonds of the Port of Portland, due from 1962 to 1981, was sold to an investment banking group headed by Chemical Bank New York Trust Company.
Nine carefully selected college graduates embarked yesterday on a year-long training program that the city hopes will begin to fill the desperate need for experts in urban renewal and housing.

ROME, July 10 -- The Foreign Ministers of the European Economic Community reached basic agreement today on political cooperation within the six-nation group. It is composed of France, Italy, West Germany, Belgium, the Netherlands and Luxembourg.

PURCHASE, N.Y., July 10 -- Five seeded players, led by Carmen Lampe of Forest Hills, Queens, the defender, won in straight sets today as the women's Eastern clay courts tennis tournament opened at the Century Country Club.
PARIS, July 10 -- France was said today to be dragging her feet in Euratom, the six-nation European Atomic Energy Community.
WASHINGTON, July 10 -- Following is the transcript, as released by the White House, of President Kennedy's remarks to the Citizens Committee for International Development today:

SAN FRANCISCO, July 10 (AP) -- Don Drysdale, a pitcher for the Los Angeles Dodgers, was fined $100 today and suspended for five days by the National League's president, Warren C. Giles, for throwing at a hitter.
Wool prices were sharply higher yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange. Tops (combed wool) climbed 1.6 to 2.3 cents a pound and grease wool rose 1 to 1.7 cents. Volume was heavy.

Elisabeth Bergner will return to the Broadway stage this season, after an absence of thirteen years. She has agreed to star in Samuel Taylor's new comedy, "First Love," which is being produced by Roger L. Stevens and Frederick Brisson.
BUFFALO, N.Y., July 10 (UPI) -- A fleet of big ships moved into this Great Lakes port today to signal the official opening of the new $6,500,000 north entrance to Buffalo harbor.

Mrs. John W. Galbreath's Clover Leaf ran away before the $37,675 Tremont at Aqueduct yesterday. Then, when the contest was on and running really meant something, Clover Leaf, under the strict control of Bob Ussery, won the stakes by three-quarters of a length. The riding success was Ussery's third of the afternoon.

LONDON, July 10 (Reuters) -- Viscount Simon, chairman of the Port of London Authority, suggested tonight that the United States and Britain should jointly run a "prestige" trans-Atlantic passenger liner service.

DON'T look now, but the animals are getting ready to take over. High time, too, perhaps. Anyway, accounts of their prowess, charm and intelligence crowd all kinds of publications. Someone has translated "Winnie the Pooh" into Latin, and first thing you know there will be a demand that it be translated back into less sticky English.

WHILE most of the bridge elite from New York City were striving in the tournament played at Yonkers last week-end, Harry Fishbein of the Mayfair Bridge Club went to Philadelphia to play in a similar sectional tournament there.

A new book by Ivan T. Sanderson, zoologist and explorer, will be issued Sept. 20 by Chilton and will be called "Abominable Snowmen: Legend Come to Life." It is an account of the search for the mysterious creatures from earliest time to the present.

WASHINGTON, July 10 -- "There is no new thing under the sun" remains as tenable a commentary on the troubles raised for mankind by human nature and the elements as it was when set forth in Ecclesiastes, I, 9. And an immediate example is the current series of proposals for dealing with the critical problem created by the disintegrating state of American railroads.

Office building construction in Manhattan has maintained its record pace in the first six months of 1961 and remains at its highest rate since 1945, according to a new study. Nearly all of the construction activity is centered in the midtown business district.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 10 -- Whitey Ford, the bellwether of the Yankee mound staff who last spring set two goals for himself, will have his chance to attain one of them tomorrow.
BERLIN, July 10 -- East Germany served notice today it would assume full control over Allied land and air access to Berlin after it had signed a peace treaty with the Soviet Union.

WASHINGTON, July 10 -- The New York Central Railroad called for a "cooling-off" period today in its battle with the Chesapeake and Ohio Railway for control of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad. As the public airing of a year-old duel continued at an Interstate Commerce Commission hearing, Alfred E. Perlman, president of the Central, tasked the I.C.C. to call a halt to what has turned out to be the biggest railroad struggle in modern times.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., July 10 -- The business of determining the women's sailing champion of Long Island Sound started today. Twelve crews from Connecticut, Westchester and Long Island turned out for the annual Syce Cup races at the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club.
The Better Business Bureau here has published a pamphlet designed to alert the public to abuses in sales of new or used cars.
A Chinese Communist statement purporting to deny that there was a Soviet-Chinese ideological rift was sharply revised before being published in Moscow, it was revealed yesterday.

The article entitled "Right-Wing Officers Worrying Pentagon," written by Cabell Phillips and published in the June 18 issue of The New York Times, was inaccurate in so far as it concerned activities at the Naval Air Station, Seattle, under my command.

Two statements filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday disclosed that Dal-Tran Service Company had bought an additional 1,900 common shares of Fifth Avenue Coach Company, raising its holdings to 54,100 shares.
A court test of the legality of New York State's legislative apportionment statute was ordered yesterday by Federal Judge Richard H. Levet.
WASHINGTON, July 10 (AP) -- President Kennedy's Labor-Management Advisory Committee set up five subcommittees today to seek answers to five of the nation's most difficult economic questions.

THOSE who would descend into the sea in order to impale a fish on a spear should learn to take it easy, says Jim Christiansen, a strapping 35-year-old crew-cut blond from Long Beach, Calif. Christiansen is the coach of a team of young men who will compete at Alamirs, Spain, on Aug. 17 and 18 for the world spearfishing championship.

A five-member special committee of New York's Board of Social Welfare has declared, after a public hearing in Albany, that the City of Newburgh will be violating both state and Federal law if it proceeds with its thirteen-point program for a tightening of regulations for dispensation of welfare to the needy.

" Secrets of Women" will arrive at the Fifth Avenue Cinema today. The Swedish-made comedy-drama, directed by Ingmar Bergman, has English subtitles and features Eva Dahlbeck, Gunnar Bjornstrand, Maj-Britt Nilsson, Anita Bjork and Jarl Kulle.

QUELIMANE, Mozambique, July 10 (UPI) -- Forty survivors of the Portuguese ship disaster waited for rescue amid wreckage and bodies on a narrow beach, menaced by marauding lions in a near-by mangrove swamp.
PARIS, July 10 -- West Germany today became the second member of the Common Market to be charged with an alleged violation of the Common Market treaty.
LONDON, July 10 -- Paul Pender and Terry Downes relaxed today after strenuous training that left both fit and confident for their world middleweight championship fight at Wembley Pool tomorrow night.
THE following dinner menu is given as a guide to the use of foods that are reasonable in cost. A recipe is offered for an easy-to-prepare main dish.
The owner of an East Side apartment house has lodged a formal protest against the lifting of rent controls from his building.

A major part of the fortieth floor of the new Chase Manhattan Bank Building at 1 Chase Manhattan Plaza has been leased by the Panhandle Eastern Pipe Line Company, a gas transmission concern, for its headquarters.
MORE grandmothers -- or women in that age group -- are going to work than ever before. Many of them turn to careers for the first time only after their children are grown.

WASHINGTON, July 10 (AP) -- Twelve Iranian students were released from jail today with a friendly lecture when the Iranian Embassy did not press charges against them in a dispute over passport renewals.

JACKSON, Miss., July 10 (UPI) -- The Federal Government entered today a suit to strike down Mississippi's travel segregation laws. It charged that local authorities had gone "beyond the scope of their lawful power" in the arrests of Freedom Riders.

WASHINGTON, July 10 -- Secretary of State Dean Rusk set forth today a new basic aim of United States foreign policy: to establish a common denominator of self-interest among all nations that do not want communism forced upon them.
WHITE PLAINS, July 10 -- The Westchester County Board of Supervisors voted today to acquire the 250-acre Boyce Thompson tract in Yonkers and Greenburgh.
LONDON, July 10 -- Sir Anthony Eden has chosen the title of Earl of Avon, it was announced here today. The Earldom was conferred on him last Wednesday by Queen Elizabeth.
WASHINGTON, July 10 -- The State Department is satisfied that the problem of housing African diplomats in Washington is largely solved.

POINT ARGUELLO, Calif., July 10 (AP) -- The United States' first attempt to launch a Midas missile-alarm satellite into an orbit that would have taken it over the Soviet Union failed today when the ninety-eight-foot projectile failed to lift from its launching pad.

CHICAGO, July 10 (AP) -- Hedge selling, probably the heaviest of the year, hic the wheat futures pit today and prices weakened on the Board of Trade, while other grains worked well ahead in active dealings. Soybeans lost ground on liquidation.

Your excellent editorials on the issue of aid to nonpublic schools have not seemed to influence the political maneuverings going on in Washington. May I add a point of view which I have not yet seen expressed.

WASHINGTON, July 10 (UPI) -- The State Department today postponed for a week the swearing-in of Salvatore A. Bontempo to its top security post. Mr. Bontempo's appointment is under attack from Representative Francis E. Walter, Democrat of Pennsylvania.

While security trading in this country-notably on the New York and American Stock Exchanges -- has attracted enormous public attention because of a spectacular first half-year, Canada has been experiencing a somewhat similar, though less publicized, trading enthusiasm.

NEWBURGH, N.Y., July 10 -- The Welfare Commissioner of Newburgh resigned today in protest against a new code of welfare regulations adopted by the City Council on June 19. The code is scheduled to take effect Saturday.

BROWNSVILLE, Tenn., July 10 (AP) -- The Federal government began distributing surplus food today in racially troubled Haywood County, where many Negroes say that they have lost their jobs since they registered to vote.

WEST TISBURY, MARTHA'S VINEYARD, Mass., July 10 -- John W. Garrett 2d, 66-year-old retired New York City investment banker, shot himself yesterday with a rifle. The State Police at Oak Bluffs, Martha's Vineyard, called his death a suicide.

ABOARD THE COAST GUARD CUTTER DEXTER EN ROUTE TO HONOLULU, July 10 (UPI) -- A see-saw duel between the scratch boat, Sirius II, and Ticonderoga today saw Sirius II regain the lead in the twenty-second biennial trans-Pacific yacht race.
GENEVA, July 10 -- The Soviet and British co-chairmen of the fourteen-nation conference on Laos reported today that they were deadlocked on how the talks should proceed.
SAN ANTONIO, July 10 (AP) -- A New York schoolboy, Jon Weber, bettered the national record for swimming in the modern pentathlon today during competition for the United States pentathlon title.
LONDON, July 10 -- The World Union for Progressive Judaism criticized the Chief Rabbinate of Israel today for its "exclusionary attitude'" toward B'nei Israel Jews.

MARBLEHEAD, Mass, July 10 -- With the pace-setting schooner Nina covering barely sixty miles in the first twenty-four hours the slowest of all Marblehead-to-Halifax yacht races appeared in the making today.

WESTHAMPTON BEACH, L.I., July 10 -- Pat Stanley and Sigmund Goldner of the Island Hills Club shot a 32, 31 -- 63, five strokes under par to take first prize in the Long Island Professional Golfers Association pro-amateur tournament today at the Westhampton Country Club.
A bill to exempt railroads in reorganization from the 10 per cent Federal tax on passenger fares was proposed yesterday by Senator Prescott Bush as a means to aid the bankrupt New Haven Railroad.
" DICKIE" DICKERTS started out wanting to save mankind via social welfare work. Instead, she rescues women from banality, boredom, plainness or ridicule, by selling them becoming hats.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 11 (AP) -- Mickey Mantle, the New York Yankee outfielder, was knocked down and stunned by a golf ball yesterday.
There were mob scenes yesterday at Polyclinic Hospital and at New York International Airport for two movie stars.

Blood will be donated to the Red Cross today at The New York Times, 229 West Forty-third Street. Donations also will be made at Fort Hamilton, Brooklyn, and in the armory at 321 Manor Road, West New Brighton, S.I.

A FEW years ago, cooking turkey during the summer was unheard of. Now one of the best suggestions for the outdoor barbecue -- or for cooking indoors -- are the small turkeys weighing four or five pounds.
GREENWICH, Conn., July 11 -- A record fleet for a New York Yacht Club junior regatta sailed today. There were 183 sloops of five classes racing in nine divisions.

WASHINGTON, July 11 (AP) -- The Justice Department today accused Suburban Gas of Pomona, Calif., a large seller of liquefied petroleum gas, of violating anti-merger provisions of the Clayton Antitrust Act.
WASHINGTON, July 11 -- Following are the texts of the greeting extended by President Kennedy to President Mohammad Ayub Khan at Andrews Air Force Base today and of President Ayub's reply:
WASHINGTON, July 11 -- The Treasury announced today the raising of $500,000,000 in new money as it marketed $2,000,000,000 in one-year Treasury bills.

COLORADO SPRINGS, Colo., July 11 (UPI) -- The National Collegiate basketball tournament committee recommended today that all N.C.A.A. tournaments be played on college campuses to help eliminate bribery of players.

THE sleepy-eyed, rotund North Korean who signed a new military assistance pact with Communist China yesterday took the name of a Korean anti-Japanese guerrilla leader at a propitious moment in history.

The Port of New York Authority has joined the select group of billion-dollar enterprises, with its investments at $1,012,540,000. On that basis it could be ranked eighteenth among the 500 largest industrial concerns in the country.

The special welcome given in Washington yesterday to President Ayub Khan of Pakistan set the stage for discussions that will be of exceptional importance for the future of our alliance with mainland Asia's biggest Moslem state.
Five-cent transfers for Fifth Avenue Coach Lines passengers changing at Fifth Avenue and Fourteenth, Twenty-third or Thirty-fourth Street will be available beginning Aug. 1.

SEEK a more satisfying concert than last night's at Lewisohn Stadium and you're a greedy man indeed. Mark it down as one of those rare evenings when divers elements were neatly in tune, and when a good time seemed to be had by all.

WASHINGTON, July 11 -- The Defense Department is studying plans to mobilize certain National Guard and Army Reserve units. This would be a speedy build-up of military manpower to deal with the Berlin crisis.
INWOOD, L.I., July 11 -- Several sons of district professionals contributed to the interest as the Forty-fourth Metropolitan Golf Association's junior championship started today.

WASHINGTON, July 11 (UPI) -- A showdown vote on the Administration's compromise $592,000,000 increase in postal rates was postponed for two days today by the House Post Office Committee. President Kennedy was indirectly responsible.
MANILA, July 11 -- General of the Army Douglas MacArthur subdued and pensive, returned today to "the Rock," which he had left in the shadow of defeat on March 12, 1942.

PHILADELPHIA, July 11 -- A massive registration of Negro children in Southern schools next fall will be proposed at the fifty-second annual convention of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People.
LONDON, July 11 -- Industrial shares responded to selective demand on the stock market here today although many of the important sections closed no better than steady.

WASHINGTON, July 11 (UPI) -- A sharply modified version of President Kennedy's request for new curbs on tax deductions for entertainment, gifts and other business expenses was tentatively approved today by the House Ways and Means Committee.

ULAN BATOR, Outer Mongolia, July 11 (Reuters) -- A colorful crowd of 50,000 paraded in the main square here today to celebrate the fortieth anniversary of Outer Mongolia's declaration of independence.

The Board of Standards and Appeals overruled the protests of a group of Greenwich Villagers yesterday and decided that a private builder could build an eighteen-story apartment building overlooking McCarthy Square.
DETROIT, July 11 (UPI) -- The United Auto Workers proposed today a pension program featuring a cost-of-living clause, survivors' benefits and optional retirement at age 60.

Paperboard production fell last week to 202,725 tons, the lowest point since the first week of the year, from 335,511 tons the week before, the National Paperboard Association reported yesterday. In the same holiday period last year the output was 174,810 tons.
WASHINGTON, July 11 -- Gov. J. Millard Tawes of Marylands today apologized publicly to four African Ambassadors who had met with discrimination in restaurants along Route 40 in Maryland.

PARIS, July 11 -- Any Latvian, Estonian or Lithuanian born in July, 1940, would come of age this week having lived his entire life as a Soviet citizen. For it is precisely twenty-one years since Russia absorbed the Baltic states as one consequence of the Hitler-Stalin pact.
CHICAGO, July 11 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
A report that a top school official had appropriated school-building supplies for his personal use is being investigated by District Attorney Frank D. O'Connor of Queens.
SOUTH was criticized for his three-heart rebid in this deal, which was played at rubber bridge in New York. Most experts will agree that South should simply have raised to three no-trump.
WASHINGTON, July 11 -- A White Citizens Council and a county registrar in Louisiana were charged today with illegally purging 4,800 Negroes from voting rolls over the last five years.
NEW ORLEANS, July 11 (UPI) -- Carlos Marcello, New Orleans underworld figure, was ruled an undesirable alien today. He was ordered deported.
ALBANY, July 11 -- A nine-member state commission that will attempt to preserve the scenic beauty of the Lake George area was appointed today by Governor Rockefeller.
Israel's Dead Sea will be developed more quickly as the result of a $25,000,000 loan announced yesterday by the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (World Bank).
The Bronx residents who recently hanged Parks Commissioner Newbold Morris in effigy had reason to be glad yesterday that it had been a mock ceremony.

The first clue to the reaction of rank-and-file unionists to the plan of their leaders for a labor political party in this city will be given in a referendum today among 35,000 unionized hotel and-club employes.
The Play Schools Association will benefit from theatre parties at the Nov. 1 and 6 evening performances of "When No One Is Looking," which is scheduled to open Oct. 26 at the Belasco Theatre.

CARACAS, Venezuela, July 11 -- The Creole Petroleum Corporation announced today that it would form a $10,000,000 investment company here to stimulate the Venezuelan economy. The announcement was made by Harry Jarvis, president of the company.

LISTED among the good buys now is Kohlrabi, a light green turnip-like bulb that can serve as two vegetables. The leaves are excellent when cooked like other greens and the bulb may be served raw or cooked.
WESTMINSTER, Md., July 11 -- Whittaker Chambers is dead.
If you want to get a real feeling for New York in the summertime, pick a Tuesday evening and walk through the lower East Side to an Evenings-by-the-River concert.
The Board of Estimate yesterday paved the way for city television to get under way by Oct. 15.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 11 -- Prime Minister Julius K. Nyerere of Tanganyika said today that a federation of East African countries was practicable and desirable.

The Bank of America, National Trust and Savings Association and associates yesterday won the award of $18,800,000 of general obligation bonds of Los Angeles, with a bid of 100.79 for 3 1/4 and 3 1/2 per cent coupons.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., July 11 (AP) -- The Illinois Parole and Pardon Board was urged today to recommend a full pardon for Nathan Leopold, thrill killer of the Nineteen-Twenties, so that he can be free to engage in social work and teach in Puerto Rico.
A transportation adviser to the Polish Trade Mission here has gone into hiding and asked for political asylum, the Polish American Immigation and Relief Committee said yesterday.

The over-the-counter market for corporate debt obligations reported substantial volume at generally steady prices yesterday after price restrictions were removed from the offering of $50,000,000 of consolidated Edison 4 3/4s of 1991.

WASHINGTON, July 11 (UPI) -- A House Education subcommittee approved today President Kennedy's three-year, $275,000,000 "youth opportunities program," including a revival of the Civilian Conservation Corps of the Nineteen Thirties.
WASHINGTON, July 11 -- The Senate was urged today to strike a blow at communism by declaring that Uncle Sam was a real-life resident of New York State.

Five members of the New York Repertory Company, which begins a theatrical tour of Latin-American cities tomorrow, will devote the next three weeks of their off-stage hours to an American-Argentine film adaptation of Jean-Paul Sartre's "No Exit."
WASHINGTON, July 11 -- A House subcommittee recommended today that the Securities and Exchange Commission conduct a full-scale investigation into the nation's securities markets.

WASHINGTON, July 11 (AP) -- The president of a New York Central Railroad subsidiary said today that the Central would face eventual bankruptcy if excluded from pending merger plans among Eastern railroads.
The American merchant marine has acquired from Israel its first large new foreign-built, dry-cargo bulk carrier -- a rare vessel under the United States flag.

SEASIDE, Ore., July 11 (AP) -- Twelve-year-old Becky Roever was rescued last night after a three-day ordeal without food an with only a trickle of water from a spring. A helicopter flew through heavy fog to lift her off a rock beach on the Oregon coast.
An epidemic of Dutch elm disease is alarming suburban and city officials.

WE have to depend on our enemies, said Plutarch, to hear the truth. That was what Senator William E. Borah of Idaho heard when one of his enemies called him "the spearless leader." The remark at least was a half truth. It took its cutting edge from the fact that Borah didn't have a consistent political program and often failed to rally and lead others on charges toward an objective.
HONG KONG, July 11 -- Communist China and North Korea signed a military assistance treaty today. It is similar to the one signed last week by North Korea and the Soviet Union.
HILO, Hawaii, July 11 (AP) -- Kilauea crater on Mauna Loa erupted suddenly last night, with three fountains shooting bright orange molten lava as high as 700 feet.
LONDON, July 11 -- Maj. Yuri A. Gagarin, the Soviet Union's space pioneer, received a tumultuous welcome here today and an invitation to luncheon Friday with Queen Elizabeth II.

WESTBURY, L.I., July 11 -- Everyone agreed it would be a good idea if Roger Vercruysse and Jean Morvillers, the two Frenchmen who will drive in the Roosevelt Raceway International Trot Saturday night, would compete in a race before the $50,000 event.

YOUNG adults would welcome a chance to "grapple with life" but they lack encouragement from the passive pattern set by their elders, according to Michael Whyte, Harvard '63. As editor of a student magazine that recently received newspaper notice for a special edition devoted exclusively to Africa, Mr. Whyte and his undergraduate staff express editorially some viewpoints of today's youth.
MOSCOW, July 11 (AP) -- The controversy between the United States and the Soviet Union on the procedure for scoring their track meet this weekend apparently was resolved today.
Queens Democrats handed Mayor Wagner a stinging rebuff last night. They overwhelmingly endorsed State Controller Arthur Levitt to oppose the Mayor for re-election.

The widow of a research physicist whose death in February, 1958, was attributed to exposure to radioactive materials has been awarded a lump sum of $5,430 and $30 a week by a referee for the Workmen's Compensation Board.
WASHINGTON, July 11 -- The Tennessee Valley Authority announced today a reduction in electric rates to a new national low.
Cotton futures moved 25 cents a bale off to 75 cents up yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange. Only the distant December showed a gain, on a bid, with no trades in that delivery during the day.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), July 11 -- Services of a Christian fundamentalist missionary group in Jerusalem have been called off following stone-throwing attacks by Jewish religious fanatics.
One of the great Fifth Avenue mansions associated with the Vanderbilt family will be torn down to make way for a twenty-story cooperative apartment house.

WINNIPEG, Man., July 11 (Canadian Press) -- The Canadian Wheat Board jumped its price on durum wheat by more than 72 cents a bushel today after a day in which it canceled all quotations on the grain, used in the manufacture of macaroni products.
Mrs. Hortense W. Gabel started work yesterday on her assignment from Mayor Wagner to wage "all-out war" against crime, slum blight and poverty on the West Side.
The Federal Aviation Agency has resumed monitoring jet aircraft approaches at New York International Airport to determine the extent of low-flying violations.
The American Jewish Committee announced yesterday that Louis Caplan, a Pittsburgh lawyer, had assumed the presidency of the fifty-five-year-old civil rights agency.

Staff members of Coronet Magazine began the grim ritual of emptying their desks yesterday following the announcement that the magazine would suspend operations with the October issue. Lewis W. Gillenson, editor, said: "We're heartbroken, that's all there is to say."

TRENTON, July 11 -- On the eve of what is expected to be a belligerent public hearing on a bill to ban the construction of a jetport in Morris County, two major groups came out in favor of the project today.
PARIS, July 11 -- The remarkable growth in scale and complexity of the industry of Western Europe found both a symbolic and practical expression here today.
The Transit Authority submitted to the city yesterday a record capital budget of $283,144,800 for 1962.

Several brokerage and investment houses have been "discovering" growth aspects of the insurance companies recently, with the result that a spate of market letters has mentioned selected insurance stocks.

WASHINGTON, July 11 -- A nine-man panel of President Kennedy's Labor-Management Council has been assigned to submit recommendations for new Federal approaches to major labor disputes, Labor Department officials said today.
WASHINGTON, July 11 -- The average factory worker's weekly earnings rose to a record of $94.24 in June, the Labor Department reported today.
Two well-known business service organizations -- Dun Bradstreet, Inc., and The Reuben H. Donnelley Corporation -- are planning to merge.

The Patrolmen's Benevolent Association is polling its 20,000 members to see if they want to continue working forty-two hours a week with $325 a year more or forty hours and no extra pay. If the majority wants forty and no extra pay, the association said, it will seek to get the forty-hour week and the extra $325.
CARSON CITY, Nev., July 11 (AP) -- Two men pleaded not guilty today to charges of sabotage in the destruction of telephone relay stations.

The circumstances surrounding the North Korean-Chinese Communist defense pact suggested to specialists on Soviet affairs yesterday that it might have been a sop designed to soothe ruffled Chinese feelings.

LOURENCO MARQUES, Mozambique, July 11 (AP) -- The Mozambique naval command increased to 259 tonight the number of persons killed or missing and presumed dead from the explosions and fire that destroyed the Portuguese ship Save.
PARIS, July 11 -- Three former generals and five former colonels, fugitives since the collapse of the attempted military coup in Algeria in April, were sentenced to death today.
There is a curious air of unreality about the President's order to the Defense Department for another major review of our military strength and readiness.

The city's Fair Housing Practices Law was criticized yesterday by a committee of the New York County Lawyers Association as "bold in concept" but "cautious and conservative" in its operating provisions.

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), July 11 -- Attorney General Gideon Hausner shouted "liar" at Adolf Eichmann today in a number of sharp exchanges over Eichmann's role in the Nazi plan for annihilating Jews.
The National Labor Relations Board has reaffirmed its contention that certain foreign-flag vessels under United States control are subject to United States labor relations laws.
DUBLIN, Ireland, July 11 (AP) -- Whitney Reed of Alameda, Calif., the favorite in the Irish tennis championships, gamed the quarter-finals today by beating Mark Cox of Britain, 6 -- 0, 6 -- 4.

T.H. Tetens, author of several books on Germany, will have a new one published Oct. 2 by Random House entitled "The New Germany and the Old Nazis." It describes the "resurgence'' of nazism and anti-Semitism in West Germany and tells of measures by which Nazis continue in high places, such as the courts, the police and the Foreign Office.

ALBANY, July 11 -- State tax officials reported today that the discussion of income tax liability with jockeys at the Aqueduct race track was "a routine matter" but had been prearranged with representatives of the riders.
PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., July 11 -- The competition was close today as two races were completed in the five-race series for the women's sailing championship of Long Island Sound.

The Durst Organization, which has constructed several office buildings on the East Side, has purchased property forming an "L" around the northeast corner of Third Avenue and Forty-ninth Street. The seller was Harry Horwitz, realty investor. Durst made no announcement about plans for the site.
Mayor Wagner called yesterday for a program for the preservation of structures of historic and esthetic importance to the city.
GETTYSBURG, Pa., July 11 (AP) -- The United States must stand firmly in Berlin and "not let anybody scare us out," former President Dwight D. Eisenhower said today.
WASHINGTON, July 11 -- The United States plans to take the offensive in Latin America in propaganda, information and education to counter growing Communist activities.

NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y., July 11 (UPI) -- An eighteen-foot putt in a play-off made Mrs. I. Wayne Rutter the medalist in the qualifying round today of the New York State women's amateur golf championship at the Niagara Falls Country Club.

It is increasingly clear that James R. Hoffa will use the unlimited power granted to him by the Teamsters Union convention to blackmail the A.F.L.-C.I.O. into taking him back or to build a rival federation under his own unsavory auspices.
DENVER, July 11 -- At least eighteen persons were killed here today when a jetliner, landing with 120 persons aboard, careened off the runway into a truck and burst into flame.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 11 -- In as loosely played a game as baseball's midsummer classic ever has known, the National League today defeated the American League in the first of 1961's two all-star games before a roaring crowd of 44,115 fans.

ALBANY, July 11 (AP) -- Raymond W. Houston, State Welfare Commissioner, predicted today that his recent order to local districts to halt work-relief programs would be rescinded because Federal rules had been relaxed.

ABOARD COAST GUARD CUTTER DEXTER, en route to Honolulu, July 11 (AP) -- The eighty-one-foot sloop Sirius II, the scratch boat among forty-one yachts in the trans-Pacific race, edged further into the lead today.

In unexcited trading, prices on the New York Stock Exchange held virtually even yesterday. The New York Times and Standard Poor's indicators were down slightly at the close. The Dow, Jones Co. industrial average was higher.

OTTAWA, July 11 -- The Governor of the Bank of Canada accused the Government today of violating its international obligations by acting to reduce the external value of the Canadian dollar without having consulted the International Monetary Fund.

A public offering of 1,000,000 Class A common shares of Harvey Aluminum, Inc, Torrance, Calif., is being made to the public today at $29.25 a share. The underwriting group is headed by Kuhn, Loeb Co., Inc., and Tucker, Anthony R.L. Day.
WASHINGTON, July 11 -- President Mohammad Ayub Khan of Pakistan was welcomed by President Kennedy as "a friend of immediacy and constancy" on his arrival today.
CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., July 11 (AP) -- The astronaut selected to make America's second manned space flight began his final week of preparation today.

Although earnings of the Lukens Steel Company in the second quarter this year rose from those of the first quarter and from those of the second quarter a year ago, the net for the first half of 1961 was 41.4 per cent below last year's level.

GENEVA, July 11 -- The United States said today that the "immediate and most pressing task" of the conference on Laos was to enable the International Control Commission to carry out its mission in the Southeast Asian kingdom.
CLIFFSIDE PARK, N.J., July 11 -- A professional debt collector was named today to accomplish what the library here has tried and failed to do -- retrieve between 600 and 700 overdue books.
American investment interest in Western Nigeria has recently begun to take concrete form in terms of new enterprises, according to Adebiyi O. Adeyi, Minister of Trade and Industry of the region.
BERLIN, July 11 -- The flight of East Germans to West Berlin has increased substantially in the last few days, refugee officials said here today.
CAMBRIDGE, N.Y., July 11 -- A good way to back out of an early-morning fishing trip is to open an old trunk and discover with feigned dismay that the waders that are stored there leak.

HONG KONG, July 9 -- Numerous local complexities, some perhaps inadequately understood in the United States, are said here to be involved in the bitter opposition of Hong Kong textile producers to the voluntary export quotas proposed by Washington on behalf of the American industry.
LONDON, July 11 (UPI) -- Although the worst phase of the depression in the Western shipping industry may be ending, brokers are taking a gloomy view of the outlook for British yards.
WASHINGTON, July 11 -- President Kennedy's long-range foreign aid program went aground today in well charted legislative waters.

LOS ANGELES, July 11 (AP) -- Former Vice President Richard M. Nixon, despite obvious pressure from some party leaders, reiterated tonight that he did not intend to run for Governor of California. But he added:
Mayor Wagner's Committee on Exploitation has established a full-time investigating staff to war on employers and unions who collaborate to victimize Negro and Puerto Rican workers.

Thirty-one motorboats of various designs and sizes are scheduled to take part in the third annual marathon race around Long Island today. Starting at 8 A.M., the drivers will attempt to break the race record of six hours set last year by Chuck Mercerean.

Dukla of Czechoslovakia and Espanol of Barcelona, Spain, regarded as the top teams in the second section of International Soccer League competition, will face strong opposition in a double-header at the Polo Grounds tonight.
WASHINGTON, July 11 (UPI) -- Gov. David L. Lawrence of Pennsylvania said today that the hostile youngster was "society's time bomb" and had been dangerously neglected in the past.

Your June 30 editorial "The Liberals Tag Along" was excellent. As a Liberal who has often disagreed with your editorials on the subject in the past, I now find myself in hearty agreement. Also your attack on the balanced ticket as an appeal to prejudice is to be commended.

PARIS, July 11 -- Jean Monnet's Action Committee for a United States of Europe proposed today that the six members of the European Economic Community pool part of their gold and foreign exchange reserves into a single "European reserve union."
ZANZIBAR, July 11 -- One of Africa's thorniest political problems has developed on this East African island.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., July 11 (AP) -- The Tennessee Valley Electric Corporation today for $20,000,000, charging that Westinghouse had supplied defective, low-efficiency steam generators for three power plants.

LONDON, July 11 -- Terry Downes won the world middleweight title from Paul Pender by a technical knockout at Wembley Pool tonight when a bad cut over the left eye forced the defender to retire at the end of the ninth round.
Sidney Cole, a 31-year-old jockey, was killed yesterday at Aqueduct. He died after being thrown by a 2-year-old filly in a workout between the first and second races.

Other New York City banks said yesterday that they were studying their charges to regular checking account customers in the wake of the decision of the First National City Bank of New York to reduce such charges on Aug. 1.
WEST ORANGE, N.J., July 11 -- Mrs. Marge Mason of Ridgewood started defense of the Garden State Women's Golf Association championship with a victory today.
CANBERRA, Australia, July 11 (Reuters) -- Australia lodged a stiff objection today to Britain's entry into the European Economic Community.
The Government and the defense completed their cases yesterday in the espionage trial of Dr. Robert Soblen in Federal Court.

ALBANY, July 11 -- State Motor Vehicle officials spent the day today trying to get speed limits back into effect in 2,500 zones in the state. They made some progress in the paper work, but at the day's end there were still no legal speed limits in the zones.
TRENTON, July 11 -- New Jersey is ready to apply for a Federal grant to finance a study of the feasibility of linking major commuter rail lines in North Jersey with the Hudson Tubes system.
THOMASTON, L.I., July 11 -- An 18-year-old boy was accidentally shot and killed by a companion in the companion's home here today.
Governor Rockefeller announced yesterday that he had named Harold Russell Tyler Jr. to complete the un-expired term of New York's member of the bi-state Waterfront Commission.
DETROIT, July 11 -- A survey of consumer attitudes made public today indicates encouraging prospects for sales of new cars this fall.
WASHINGTON, July 11 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture's first comprehensive crop report of the season indicated today a sharp drop in the acreage of crops being grown this year.

Accustomed for nearly eight years to a Mayor slow to anger and sluggish in pace, New York must evidently adjust itself now in the pre-election season to a "Fighting Bob" Wagner -- to quote Alex Rose's unforgettable phrase. "Fighting Bob" will now apparently declare war daily against somebody or something.

WASHINGTON, July 11 -- When Mikhail Alekseyevich Menshikov arrived in Washington as Soviet Ambassador in February of 1958, he was immediately nicknamed "Smiling Mike," the most agreeable Ambassador from Moscow since Maxim Litvinov.

MARBLEHEAD, Mass., July 11 -- The Halifax race leaders were located today just before the first boats in the 360-mile contest from Marblehead entered the ninety-mile stretch from Brazil Rock to Sambro Lightship.
Charles Collingwood will view the press at a new, later time of day temporarily, starting July 29.
LONDON, July 11 -- The London newspaper reviewers were full of praise for Jean Anouilh's "Becket," which opened tonight at the Aldwych Theatre.

Representatives of Mayor Wagner have asked Governor Rockefeller's office to convene both the state committee on the Long Island Rail Road and the interstate staff committee on the New Haven Railroad in view of the two commuter lines' financial problems.

COOPERSTOWN, N.Y., July 11 -- The Lake and Valley Garden Club is sponsoring a tour of five homes and gardens here on Thursday and Friday afternoons. Mrs. Damon L. Getman and Mrs. James M. Symington are co-chairmen of the event, proceeds of which will help to finance projects in which the club has a continuing interest.
VIENNA, July 11 -- The Italian Government took action against Austria today as Italian railroad lines were bombed in the dispute over Alto Adige, Italy's northern province.

Leading sales finance companies reduced by one-eighth and one-quarter percentage point yesterday the rates on two maturities of their short-term unsecured obligations sold directly to investors. The new rates are: five to twenty-nine days, 2 per cent, down one-quarter point; and thirty to fifty-nine days, 2 1/4 per cent, down one-eighth point.

TUNIS, July 11 -- President Habib Bourguiba was reported today to have decided to put the full weight of his Government, his political party and his people into a campaign for evacuation by the French of Bizerte on the Mediterranean coast and the Saharan regions south of the Tunisian border.
ROME, July 11 -- Four railroad lines linking Italy with Western and Northern Europe were dynamited by terrorists last night and this morning. The lines were out of operation for several hours.
BIRKDALE, England, July 11 (UPI) -- Bob Charles, a former bank clerk from New Zealand, shot a two-under-par 70 today and took the medal with a 136 in qualifying for the British Open golf tournament.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 11 (UPI) -- Roberto Clemente beamed in the dressing room today.
NEW DELHI, India, July 11 -- Indians were searching with-in themselves today for an answer to a problem regarded by some leaders as alarming -- a growing national disunity.

OF what is the fashion-consious Polish woman made? Very possibly of hair subtly tinted with a German-made shampoo; of a fresh complexion enhanced by English cosmetics; of a silhouette defined by French undergarments; of a smart knit suit styled in Italy; of novelty jewelry made in Czechoslovakia; of slim-heeled shoes designed in Hungary, and of sleek nylons imported from America.

CHICAGO, July 11 (AP) -- The grain futures market was about equally divided into strength and weakness today as dealers evened up commitments in advance of the Government's July crop report, which was issued after the close.
The performance of "When No One Is Looking" on Nov. 16 will benefit the Kips Bay Boys Club. The new psychological thriller by Frederick Knott is scheduled to open at the Belasco Theatre Oct. 26.
RICHMOND, Va., July 11 -- A Byrd organization ticket headed by Albertis S. Harrison, former State Attorney General, won a one-sided victory today in Virginia's Democratic Gubernatorial primary.
LOS ANGELES, July 11 (UPI) -- Former Vice President Richard -. Nixon praised Whittaker Chambers today as a man who had the courage to break with the Communists and atone for his mistake.

' TWAS the night before Christmas, which is the night "Susan Slept Here" begins, and through parts of the 41st Street Theatre last night, playgoers were stirring. The script was hung with care, but the comedy was thin, like a nylon stocking, and St. Nicholas would not have been too jolly if he had been there.

The Magnavox Company had good news for its stockholders yesterday. The producer of radio land television sets and components achieved record sales and earnings in the first six months this year. Its directors yesterday also authorized a 50 per cent increase in the dividend rate on the newly split stock.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 11 -- The winds were peculiarly quiescent for most of the game. So were the American Leaguers. Then the gales came swirling across Candlestick Park and everything became disorderly, including the thirtieth all-star festival. Flags fluttered stiffly. Papers, dust and anything not fastened down took flight, fleeing before the sirocco.

Chemical Bank New York Trust Company said yesterday that it was purchasing a substantial minority interest in the Bank of Liberia, Monrovia, through a new, wholly owned subsidiary, Chemical International Banking Corporation.

RIO DE JANEIRO, July 11 -- A statement by Ambassador John Moors Cabot of the United States that Brazil could not be considered an "uncommitted nation" has been followed by an admonition by President Janio Quadros against "meddling."
The largest sports car racing program of the year has been scheduled for Aug. 5 and 6 at Bridgehampton, L.I.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 11 (UPI) -- The thirtieth all-star game made a colorful debut in San Francisco's Candlestick Park today -- marked by a record turnout of 44,115 and a near-record number of heat prostration cases.
SAN LUIS POTOSI, Mexico, July 11 -- Tension pervades this graceful old city, the capital of the state of San Luis Potosi.

The Glickman Corporation, Louis J. Glickman, president, announced yesterday it had contracted to buy the thirty- five-story office building at 63 Wall Street, corner of Beaver Street. The contract involves cash over two mortgages amounting to $9,000,000.

Liquidation and hedge selling of potato contracts touched off stop-loss selling early yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange. Short covering and trade buying rallied futures from the lows of the day.
NEWBURGH, N.Y., July 11 -- How Newburgh's new welfare code will be put into operation Saturday was decided today by the City Manager and legal advisers.

PITTSBURGH, July 11 (AP) -- Robert Baker, a Teamster organizer, was fined $400 in Federal Court today for contempt of court. He was found guilty of leaving the court's jurisdiction while free on bond pending his appeal on an extortion conviction.
Richard Davis, who has been termed "the most important" witness in the Queens tow-car racket investigation, flew here last night from London.

The Civil Aeronautics Board has granted blanket permission to two freight-carrying airlines -- Flying Tiger and Seaboard World -- to offer trans-Atlantic passenger charter flights for the rest of the summer without special board permission.
Twelve hundred house wreckers ended a ten-week strike last night when they ratified an agreement to return to work tomorrow.

In the face of Premier Khrushchev's war threats over Berlin, Secretary Rusk has called on the whole free world, both Allied and uncommitted, to rally around the United Nations in defense of peace and freedom. He has indicated that the Berlin problem may be put before the United Nations "at some stage," as it was during the Berlin blockade.
LITTLE ROCK, Ark., July 11 -- Four jailed Freedom Riders, the first to test transportation segregation in Little Rock, refused to post bond today.
MOSCOW, July 11 (UPI) -- Isaac Berger of York, Pa., scored the only victory for the touring United States weight-lifting team today in a dual meet with a Soviet Union squad.

WASHINGTON, July 11 (AP) -- A Civil Aeronautics Board examiner today tentatively set in mid-December the hearing on an application of Northeast Airlines for renewal of authority to operate its New York- Florida route.
MOSCOW, July 11 -- Premier Khrushchev declared today that the Soviet Union would rely on force to resist any United Nations decision that threatened its security.

Convinced that most out-of-towners still imagine Third Avenue to be a dim thoroughfare of drunks, derelicts and pawnshops, a group of business men on the avenue urged yesterday that the city rename it the Avenue of the Promenades.
Directors of Texaco, Inc., at a meeting yesterday declared a dividend of 40 cents a share on the new shares following approval by stockholders of a previously proposed two-for-one stock split.
A total of 966 persons were hurt in car accidents here last week, the police reported yesterday. This was a decrease of forty-five from the like 1960 week.
WASHINGTON, July 12 (AP) -- The Defense Department announced today an 8,000-man Army draft call for August.
LOS ANGELES, July 12 -- Borax, the stuff which dots the desert, may help man reach the deserts of the moon.
James J. Lyons rang down the curtain on twenty-eight years as Borough President of the Bronx with the announcement yesterday that he would not be a candidate for reelection.
LITTLE ROCK, Ark., July 12 -- Four Freedom Riders changed their minds today and decided to go to jail.

WESTBURY, L.I., July 12 -- At 8 o'clock this morning Kracovie of France worked a quarter-mile in 0:29 and forthwith Roger Vercruysse, the 27-year-old driver of the 7-year-old trotting mare, became the unhappiest man in the vicinity of Roosevelt Raceway. He had aimed for a quarter in 0:28.
GUATEMALA, July 12 -The Government of President Miguel Ydigoras Fuentes imposed a state of siege -- modified martial law -- in Guatemala tonight.
The Department of the Interior will sacrifice principle to expediency in the National Park System if it yields to local pressures by surrendering Yellowstone Lake almost entirely to the motorboats.

WASHINGTON, July 12 -- The House of Representatives approved by voice vote today legislation designed to correct so-called "inequities" resulting from the enforcement of a law aimed primarily at denying Government annuities and retirement pay for Alger Hiss.
CHICAGO, July 12 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation reported yesterday that its service organization, Federal Electric Corporation, had received an extension of its contract to operate, maintain and support a land-based segment of the distant early warning line (DEW Line).
ALBANY, July 12 -- The State Social Welfare Commissioner ordered Newburgh city officials today not to carry out their stringent new welfare rules.
SEOUL, Korea, Thursday, July 13 -- Former Premier John M. Chang was accused today by South Korea's Military Government of having accepted bribes while in office.

NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y., July 12 (AP) -- Mrs. Harry Nevil of Cooperstown, seeking her fourth straight New York State women's golf championship, was forced to go twenty holes today before turning back Sylvia Maurycy of Schenectady, 1 up.

MONTAUK, L.I., July 12 -- Pete Mazur of Montauk scored a 34, 37 -- 71 and tied Joe Maresco of Woodmere, who posted a 36, 35 for the first-round lead in the Long Island Professional Golfers Association championship at Montauk Downs today.
WASHINGTON, July 19 -- Members of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People called on President Kennedy today to praise and criticize his actions on civil rights.

One sure conclusion arising from the otherwise thoroughly confused maritime dispute is the need for a review of the nation's ship subsidy policy. Unofficial estimates of what is entailed in the projected 21 per cent increase in crew costs, for the subsidized segment of the merchant marine alone, range from $75,000,000 to $100,000,000 over a four-year period.

DETROIT, July 12 (UPI) -- The United Auto Workers Union said today it wanted General Motors Corporation to pay the full cost of hospital-medical insurance for its 335,000 active and retired workers. The company said this demand would cost $86,000,000 a year.
WASHINGTON, July 12 (AP) -- The Food and Drug Administration warned today that Hayden's hollandaise sauce could cause food poisoning.
Mayor Wagner got an assurance of election support yesterday from Michael J. Quill, president of the Transport Workers Union.
ALBANY, July 12 -- Republican state officials laid plans today to seek out 3,500,000 New York residents who are eligible to vote but don't, and line them up behind party candidates.
WASHINGTON, July 12 (AP) -- The Securities and Exchange Commission said today it was temporarily blocking a proposed $2,000,000 debentures offering by Faradyne Electronics, Inc. Belleville, N.J.
WASHINGTON, July 12 -President and Mrs. Kennedy were in some hot water today over a question that has plagued other White House residents:
A color film of the first American astronaut's flight into space will be presented by the National Broadcasting Company on Sunday.

Premier Khrushchev has now served notice on both the United Nations and all the world that Soviet Russia is a law unto itself and that, relying on its armed might, it will flout any United Nations decision it does not like.
A demand for a 10 per cent wage increase for 9,000 embroidery workers was submitted to seven employer associations yesterday.

NEW HAVEN, July 12 (AP) -- A ruling by the State Civil Rights Commission that a developer could not refuse to sell a site for a house to a Negro couple was overturned yesterday by Superior Court Judge Alva P. Loiselle.
WASHINGTON, July 12 -- Preliminary estimates by the Commerce Department show that the gross national product in the second quarter may reach a record annual rate above $512,000,000,000.
WASHINGTON, July 12 (UPI) -- Government auditors accused the Radio Corporation of American today of deliberately misleading the Air Force to increase the price of 442 long-range radio sets.

The return of Sylvester L. (Pat) Weaver Jr to the field of television was announced yesterday. Mr. Weaver, the former president and chairman of the National Broadcasting Company, was named president of M-E Productions, the radio and television division of Interpublic, Inc.
A cloudless sky, benign temperature and a pleasantly varied and well-conducted program would seem to be the right formula for attracting a large crowd to Lewisohn Stadium.
ALBANY, July 12 (AP) -- The Court of Appeals has set the week of Aug. 7 for the execution of Salvatore (Capeman) Agron for a double slaying during a New York City playground fight.
The defense and prosecution delivered their final summations yesterday in the espionage trial of Dr. Robert Soblen, but the center of interest was the gaunt and pallid 60-year-old psychiatrist.

Only two books are published today. One is "A Reporter Here and There," by E.J. Kahn Jr. (Random House), which is reviewed by Charles Poore in the Books of The Times column. The other is "101 Camping-Out Ideas and Activities," by Bruno Knobel, illustrated by Georges Mousson.
A QUEENS COLLEGE psychologist reports that older children who are chronic bed-wetters are often helped by being encouraged to splash about in the bathtub before bedtime.
Tenants of Hillman Houses yesterday won the right -- for the fifth time -- to park their automobiles on property owned by the East Side cooperative.

WASHINGTON, July 12 -- Thomas E. Stakem, chairman of the Federal Maritime Board and head of the Maritime Administration, today urged a Congressional committee to permit President Kennedy's reorganization plan for the two maritime agencies to become effective.

Losses of 3 to 6 points were more common than usual in yesterday's session of the New York Stock Exchange, but the bulk of stocks held fairly well and the aggregate market value declined only about one-half of 1 per cent.

Oren Root, State Superintendent of Banks, approved yesterday one merger application by the State Bank of Albany but disapproved another. The decisions were his first on merger applications since his appointment as superintendent last month.

WASHINGTON, July 12 -- The Administration was reported tonight to be confident that its plans to establish diplomatic relations with Outer Mongolia would not complicate the progress of the foreign aid bill in Congress.
WASHINGTON, July 12 -- Following are excerpts from an address before a joint session of Congress by Mohammad Ayub Khan, President of Pakistan.
SAN ANTONIO, July 12 (AP) -- Lieut. L. Jackson of the United States Army won the national modern pentathlon championship today, though he did not capture any of the five events.
CASABLANCA, Morocco, July 12 -- A Czechoslovak airliner hit a power line in an attempted landing in fog near here today and carried seventy-two persons to death.
CLINTON, N.C., July 12 (AP) -- Eight persons were killed and one was injured today when a bolt of lightning ripped into a tobacco barn where they had taken refuge during a rainstorm.
CHICAGO, July 12 (AP) -- The Government's July crop report exerted some influence in the grain futures market today but the bullish ones were of short duration.

Electric power production slipped to 14,133,000,000 kilowatt-hours last week from 15,183,000,000 the week before, the Edison Electric Institute reported yesterday. A year ago the figure was 13,408,000,000 kilowatt-hours.

The Realship Company has sold the nine-story apartment building with self-service elevator at 108 East Sixty-sixth Street to an investing client of Murray Steyer, lawyer. The building, which occupies a lot 25 by 100 feet between Park and Lexington Avenues, contains nineteen apartments.

The New York State Employment Service said yesterday that it was not its function to determine whether applicants for public welfare aid had had "reasonable assurance of gainful employment" before coming here from another state.
