SAN FRANCISCO, July 12 -- When Candlestick Park was under construction, frequent inspections were made by Chubby Feeney, the vice president of the Giants. The architect brought him out morning after morning to see for himself how beautifully everything was progressing. It was a reassuring sight.

NOWA HUTA, Poland, July 12 -- In one of the sunnier moments in recent Polish-United States relations, Ambassador Jacob D. Beam ceremonially opened today a new production line at the big Lenin Steel Works here.
LONDON, July 12 -- Dr. Solomon B. Freehof of Pittsburgh, Pa., was re-elected today president of the World Union for Progressive Judaism.

SPOLETO, Italy, Thursday, July 13 -- Jerome Robbins' new ballet, "Events," had its premiere last night at the Festival of Two Worlds. The work, set to the modern music of Robert Prince, was on the choreographer's "Ballets U.S.A." program, which opened at the Teatro Nuovo.
DENVER, July 12 (AP) -- A dispute arose today over the amount and the availability of fire-fighting equipment at Denver's airport, where a jet airliner crashed yesterday, killing seventeen persons.

PURCHASE, N.Y., July 12 -Carmen Lampe of Forest Hills, Queens, the defending champion who heads the draw, and Nadine Netter, 16, of Scarsdale, seeded fourth although still a junior, reached the semi-final rounds in the women's eastern clay courts championship today.

A public offering of $17,250,000 of special revenue bonds of the Dade County, Fla., Port Authority is being made today through a negotiated agreement with Smith, Barney Co., and associates, the marketing group.
A Polish seaman rescued from the waters of the Upper Bay Tuesday told the police yesterday that he was seeking political asylum in this country.

HARTSDALE, N.Y., July 12 -- Nadine Netter of Scarsdale, who heads the draw, and Joanne Swanson of Pawtucket, R.I., seeded second, led the way into the semi-final round of the New York State girls' tennis championship today.

CHICAGO, July 12 -- Muntz, TV, Inc., today asked holders of its promissory notes, most of whom are suppliers to the company, to accept Muntz common stock in exchange for their claims against the television and radio set manufacturer.

LAKEHURST, N.J., July 12 -- Crews of civilian and service personnel at the Naval Air Station here have begun deflating, dismantling and mothballing the last fifteen blimps in the nation's lighter-than-air fleet.
LONDON, July 12 -- In a quiet session, stock market prices drifted downward in the principal equity trading here today.

Although your editorial of Tuesday, July 4, "Polio Vaccines and the A.M.A." was undoubtedly written in the best of faith, I fear that you are misinformed regarding some of the facts on which you base your conclusions.
Federated labor in Virginia has made a breakthrough on the elimination of segregated hotel facilities for its annual convention in Norfolk Aug. 28-30.
MOSCOW, July 12 (AP) -John Thomas would high jump at least four inches over his listed world record if he were under the tutelage of Russian coaches, the coach of the Soviet track team said today.
It will cost slightly more to sail to Europe next year.

Only 20 per cent of English households have dogs, compared to more than 40 per cent in this country, according to Harry Miller, the director of the Gaines Dog Research Center, who recently returned from a trip to a dozen countries. However, in England 60 per cent of the dogs are purebreds, a figure that is about twice as high as any projected for our own country.

BIRKDALE, England, July 12 (AP) -- Kel Nagle of Australia, the defending champion, shot a 68 today and shared the first-round lead in the British Open golf tournament with Dai Rees of Wales and Harold Henning of South Africa.
TRENTON, July 12 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner was repeatedly booed and hissed today at a public hearing on a bill to ban a jetport in North Jersey. But the Governor stood fast for the airport proposal.
Charles H. Silver, the president of the city's Board of Education, visited four more schools yesterday to check on repairs that were under way, and he gave three projects passing marks.

WHITE PLAINS, July 12 -- A family in Rye that says it has had to stay besieged indoors or risk forays through falling golf balls to get out of the house won its battle today. The Ryewood Country Club agreed to put up a protective fence, plant eight large poplars and supply special window screens.

AS a master of the small, wildly audacious public relations coup -- he once carried a flag to the highest point of Manhattan's Marble Hill and "claimed" it for the Bronx -- James Joseph Lyons had no trouble in becoming the best known of the city's five Borough Presidents after taking office in 1934.

The Puritan Fashions Corporation, a large manufacturer of women's apparel, announced yesterday the election of its first board of directors. Puritan was formed recently as the parent of six former women's divisions of Reliance Manufacturing Company.

WASHINGTON, July 12 (UPI) -- A small squadron of United States warships will circumnavigate South America and conduct anti-submarine maneuvers in conjunction with South American countries during a four-month period beginning Aug. 7.
PANAMA, July 12 -- About 100 members of a pro-Castro group were arrested at their headquarters early today after a well-known revolutionary blew himself up, apparently while making a bomb.
A contract to buy a large number of Manhattan properties owned by the Rhinelander Real Estate Company has been signed by a group of investors, it was learned yesterday.
WASHINGTON, July 12 -- Representative James J. Delaney raised a new threat today to House action on the Administration's $2,484,000,000 school-aid bill.

WASHINGTON, July 12 -- President Kennedy's chances of getting his foreign aid program through a reluctant Congress improved noticeably today after a bluntly eloquent address to a joint session by Pakistan's President Mohammed Ayub Kahn.
Diahann Carroll will have the lead role in the new musical play by Richard Rodgers and Samuel Taylor.
A former deputy police commissioner, Vincent L. Broderick, has been appointed chief assistant United States attorney for the Southern District.

The International Business Machines Corporation has added a new milestone to its sales and earnings record. The results for the latest three and six-month periods were the highest in the history of the big business machines maker.

OPERATING out of various New York bivouacs, E.J. Kahn Jr. has for years almost ceaselessly explored the world. He is, like the late John Charles Fremont, a pathmarker rather than a pathfinder. But he has seen many odd places and he writes about them in a cheerfully readable way.

ELMONT, L.I., Juy 12 -- Residents of communities affected by the noise of jet planes using New York International Airport were asked today to use their cameras to help establish whether the planes were observing minimum altitude regulations.
DETRIOT, July 12 (AP) -Dick Sikes, the medal winner, beat two opponents today in the thirty-sixth national amateur public links golf championship.
The $10,950,000 sale of radio station WMGM by the Loew's Theatres Broadcasting Corporation to the Crowell-Collier Broadcasting Corporation has been called off.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., July 12 -- Timothea Schneider, a 21-year-old University of Michigan naval architecture student, today skippered the Seawan-haka-Corinthian Yacht Club's entry to victory in the annual Syce Cup competition for the women's sailing championship of Long Island Sound.
Judson Hall -- New York University's dormitory for co-eds at Washington Square -- is getting its first bath in seventy-one years.

The New York and American Stock Exchanges announced yesterday that officers, directors and large stockholders in listed companies reported last month, pursuant to the Securities Exchange Act, the following changes in stockholdings:
LONDON, July 12 -- The establishment of a National Theatre, long sought by theatrical and other cultural groups here, is now a definite possibility.

FREEPORT, L.I., July 12--A thirty-one-foot Bertram in-board piloted by Sam Griffith, with Dick Bertram as mechanic and Robert Bavier as navigator, won the third annual Around Long Island Marathon today.
BIZERTE, Tunisia, July 12 -- Tunisians are preparing openly for a test of strength and nerves with the French command at the naval-air base here.

The International Transport Workers Federation, comprising 6,500,000 seamen and other transport workers in seventy-one countries, threatened yesterday a boycott of the Suez Canal or of Arab ships throughout the world.

ATLANTIC CITY, July 12 -Bad weather in the South forced a twenty-four-hour extension of the fifteenth annual Powder Puff Derby today -- the first such action in the history of the all-woman trans-continental air race.

Sales and earnings of the Scott Paper Company for the second quarter and first half of this year surpassed previous records in all corresponding periods of the company's history. Second-quarter sales were higher than in any other three-month period, the company reported yesterday.

Dr. Frederick A. Whitehouse's July 4 letter attacking Dr. Harold Urey's letter of June 25 and the Administration's space program is a variation on a theme that scientists have been listening to for years. Dr. Whitehouse writes: "Ask * * * afflicted people whether they would have preferred the eradication or amelioration of their impairment or a space exploration program."
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 12 -- Portugal has invited the chairman of the United Nations' inquiry committee on Angola to go to Lisbon for talks.
The Holland-America liner Nieuw Amsterdam will steam out of port Sept. 21 with 500 socially prominent passengers aboard just for the evening.
WASHINGTON, July 12 -- The United States placed two experimental satellites in orbit today. One is designed to detect missile firings and the other to spot hurricanes.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., July 12 -- The gallant Empire State Music Festival opened its seventh season tonight. Despite the fact that as recently as seven weeks ago the fate of the festival was in doubt, it began with its most adventurous offering.
ST. LOUIS, July 12 (AP) -- Stockholders of the Pet Milk Company approved today its merger with the C.H. Musselman Company, which will become one of Pet's four major operating divisions.

WASHINGTON, July 12 (UPI) -- A House Armed Services subcommittee voted today to require enlisted men to swear before God allegiance to the Constitution. They would be barred from the service if they refused.
WASHINGTON, July 12 (AP) -- The United States now has twenty-eight man-made satellites orbitting the earth. That total was reached today with the launching of Tiros III and Midas III.
The market for fixed-interest securities was mixed yesterday.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 12 Tony Curtis, one of the most recent major stars to become a producer-actor, has he fervor of a horse player who thinks he has the formula for beating the horses. He believes he has a system for beating two of the toughest problems of independent production.

OTTAWA, July 12 -- The Senate voted today, 38 to 17, against restoring to a Government bill arbitrary powers for the Minister of Revenue to fix tariffs on "goods of the same class or kind" as those produced in Canada.
WASHINGTON, July 12 -- Attorney General Robert F. Kennedy urged today greater Federal activity to prevent development of an "unbeatable" wave of juvenile delinquency in the next decade.
Six hundred advocates of natural diet sprang to the defense of their spokesman last night when a patrolman and state and Federal inspectors raided a meeting at 1685 Broadway, at Fifty-third Street.

WINNIPEG, July 12 (Canadian Press) -- Tony Lema of San Leandro, Calif., fought his way out of some rough spots today on the rain-soaked Niakwa Country Club course for a five-under-par 65 and the first-round lead in the Canadian Open golf championship.
RENO, Nev., July 12 (UPI) -- The American Telephone and Telegraph Company filed suit today for $2,750,000 over the destination of three communication stations in Utah and Nevada on May 28.
The appointment of Dr. George Cline Smith as a director and a senior partner in MacKay-Shields Associates, Inc., economic consulting organization, was announced yesterday.
Following is the text of the preliminary report made by the New York City Charter Commission yesterday:

The California Electric Power Company sold yesterday $8,000,000 of 5 p6er cent first mortgage bonds, due 1991, to Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., and associates on a bid for 100.15. The group is reoffering the bonds at 101.09 to yield about 4.93 per cent.
HONG KONG, July 12 -- Official comment in Peiping on the Chinese and Soviet military assistance treaties with North Korea was that they reflected the unity and solidarity of the Communist bloc.
WASHINGTON, July 12 -- The Senate Foreign Relations Committee recommended today the confirmation of the Administration's two top spokesmen on Latin-American policy.

Directors of Yonkers Raceway, Inc., voted yesterday to split the stock four-to-one, subject to approval of shareholders at the deferred meeting to be held on Sept. 8, it was announced by Alfred Tananbaum, chairman.
BERLIN, July 12 -- Chancellor Adenauer reaffirmed today the basic principles of Western rights in Berlin after meeting here with the city government.
A fight for the Democratic nomination for Manhattan Borough President was assured yesterday.

The Eastman Kodak Company has leased part of the twenty-ninth floor in the Pan Am building, which is being constructed at 200 Park Avenue adjoining Grand Central Terminal. Eastman will use the space for the East Coast division of its motion picture film department.
It became more evident last night that Dukla of Czechoslovakia will be the team to beat for the second-section title in the International Soccer League.
The New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad's bankruptcy petition of last Friday already has cost the Federal Treasury $11,781,000.
Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange were unchanged to 5 points (25 cnts a bale) up yesterday.

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), July 12 -- Adolf Eichmann agreed at his trial today that it was right for the Allies to have hanged top Nazis at Nuremberg fifteen years ago. But he asked his Israeli judges to remember that he was never "first violin" in the Nazi orchestra.

WASHINGTON, July 12 -- The General Electric Company, the Radio Corporation of America and six other leading defense contractors signed White House agreements today aimed at improving Negroes' access to jobs and promotion.
ALBANY, July 12 -- Speed limits in 2,500 zones in the state were legalized at 1:50 P.M. today.
William Ewing's Four Lane, the horse that won the first race ever run at the new Aqueduct track, came back to the familiar surroundings of the winner's circle at the Big A yesterday.

The politician who is a good prose writer is often to be found far ahead of his less lyrical colleagues. He travels fast while they stumble along behind under their burden of wooden phrases. Prose used skillfully persuades with both logic and emotion; unskillful prose often makes the reader resist persuasion even when he was originally inclined to agree.
HE admits he is a genius and the greatest couturier-milliner in the world, and he has tried to forget that he once was a boy from New Rochelle named Hans Harburger.

SAYVILLE, L.I., July 12 -- Mrs. T.H. Bradley of Piping Rock and Mrs. Joseph Dempsey Jr. of Southward Ho scored a seven-under-par 33, 36 -- 69 and won the Women's Long Island Golf Association handicap best-ball tournament today at the Island Hills Golf Club.
AMRITSAR, India, July 12 -Another fast appeared certain today in a long campaign of the bearded Sikhs for estab-I lishment of a state that they' could dominate.
Mayor Wagner's Charter Revision Commission made public a proposal yesterday that would increase the Mayor's executive powers and add ten boroughwide members to a stronger City Council.

New and higher Federal excise taxes to pay for the expaning interstate highway system on schedule -- 1972 is the target date for completion of the project -- went into effect on July 1. Not surprisingly, the consumer already is beginning to pick up a good part of the tab.

WATERTOWN, N.Y., July 12 (AP) -- All but one of ten Army Reservists injured when a twenty-five-ton armored personnel carrier slid into a swamp at near-by Camp Drum have been discharged from the base hospital, the Army said today.
ALBANY, July 12 -- Governor Rockefeller announced today that the state's second Youth Rehabilitation Center would open in October at Auburn.
A graduate student in Teachers College of Columbia University was mugged and robbed at 1 A.M. yesterday near the entrance to her Barnard College dormitory at Broadway north of West 116th Street.

Prices for oil-country goods -- steel casings and tubings used by the oil industry -- were reduced with an accompanying change in distribution methods by the National Tube division of the United States Steel Corporation yesterday.
WASHINGTON, July 12 (AP) -- The Public Health Service reported today "a remarkably low level" of poliomyelitis cases in the United States this year.

The Jones Laughlin Steel Corporation, the nation's fourth largest producer of the metal and the first major company in the industry to report half-year results, lifted second-quarter earnings by 10.8 per cent but had a 54.7 per cent drop in the first six months from the figure of a year ago.
WASHINGTON, July 12 (UPI) -- President Kennedy sent Congress work plans today for nineteen watershed-protection and flood-prevention projects in sixteen states and Puerto Rico.
A man described as "the most important" witness in the Queens tow-truck racket investigation and twenty-six police sergeants and former sergeants appeared yesterday before the Queens grand jury.
Federal Judge Sylvester J. Ryan yesterday denied a motion of one of the unions in the nation-wide maritime strike to modify the terms of an injunction suspending the walkout for eighty days.
RENO, Nev., July 12 (AP) -- Three teen-age boys admitted last night having committed a hold-up slaying for which the victim's wife was held in jail for five months, the police reported.

WHEN bridge was first played in the Eighteen Nineties, and for thirty years thereafter, it was the rule always to lead one's highest card in a suit bid by partner. If the opening leader's partner had bid hearts, the opening lead from K-8-7-2 would be the king.

HALIFAX, N.S., July 12 (UPI) -- Robin Too II, a thirty-six-foot yawl owned and designed by a Marblehead (Mass.) sailmaker, Ted Hood, tonight was declared the over-all winner of the Marblehead-to-Halifax yacht race.

INWOOD, L.I., July 12 -- Claude (Butch) Harmon Jr. gained the semi-final round of the Metropolitan junior golf championship today. By rolling in a 25-foot putt for a birdie at the nineteenth hole of the Inwood Country Club, the 17-year-old player beat Stan Stamile of Island Hills.

A fully automatic flame-cutting machine has just been demonstrated by Air Reduction Company at its equipment manufacturing plant at Union, N.J. The device, said to be the first of its kind, was developed by Air Reduction in cooperation with General Electric Company.
WASHINGTON, July 12 -- The Administration endorsed today a proposal to go slower in turning the Indian out on his own.

WEST ORANGE, N.J., July 12 -- Mrs. Marge Mason of Ridgewood, the defending champion, and Mrs. William Tracy of Essex Fells led the way into the semi-final round of the eighth annual Garden State Women's Golf Association championship today.

THERE is a saying on the continent of Europe that veal is best when milk is cheapest. It is a maxim that does not apply on the local scene. Because veal in this country comes from many sources, it is available twelve months a year and the quality can vary about equally in May or December.

ROME, July 12 -- The most Rev. Lawrence Joseph Shehan, Bishop of Bridgeport, Conn., was named today titular archbishop and coadjutor with the right of succession to Archbishop Francis P. Keough of Baltimore.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 12 (AP) -- Candlestick Park's howling winds are causing growls by the all-star baseball players which may speed corrective attempts.

EIGHT years ago, a young matron escaped from the boredom of her household routines by executing a scarf trick. Today, the concern that bears an abbreviation of her name, Dore, is one of the leading high-fashion accessory manufacturers in the United States.
LONDON, July 12 -- Maj. Yuri A. Gagarin, the personable Soviet cosmonaut, said in Manchester today that his flight into space would "soon be followed by a second, a third and many, many more."

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), July 12 -- Two ministers of the Church of Christ here have begun appealing to congregations of their church in the United States for the widest possible support for their missionary activities in Israel.

Kimberly-Clark Canada, Ltd. is entering the field of industrial sanitary and specialty paper products in Canada through its acquisition of the Interlake Tissue Mills Company, Ltd. While no terms were revealed, it was learned yesterday that the trans action would involve more than $2,000,000.
In the midst of a heated Tammany Hall executive committee meeting yesterday a woman leader rose to make "a nonpolitical motion," which was carried unanimously.
Trade and speculator buying sent wool prices sharply higher yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange. Profit-taking and hedge selling lowered quotations from the highs of the day.

LOS ANGELES, July 12 (UPI) -- A $2,000,000 libel suit against United Industrial Corporation was filed in Superior Court of California today by the former president and former executive vice president of the electronics concern.
RICHMOND, Va., July 12 -- Virginia was virtually assured today of four more years of conservative rule under the political organization of United States Senator Harrison F. Byrd.
The commission appointed by Mayor Wagner to write a new City Charter yesterday made public its outline of recommendations that could vastly improve local government.
ROME, July 12 -- A bill empowering the Government to deprive "unworthy" German-speaking persons in Alto Adige of Italian citizenship and to expel them is expected to become law soon.

ABOARD COAST GUARD CUTTER DEXTER, EN ROUTE TO HONOLULU, July 12 (UPI) -- The seventy-two-foot ketch Ticonderoga and the eighty-one-foot sloop Sirius II were staging a two-boat battle today in the twenty-second biennial Trans-Pacific yacht race to Honolulu.
LONDON, July 12 -- The Western Big Three will accuse the Soviet Union of using East Germany to change the map of Central Europe, Allied sources disclosed tonight.
WASHINGTON, July 12 -- Hundreds of applicants for Peace Corps duty will take general entrance examinations at centers across the country at 8:30 A.M. tomorrow.

The nation's inventories of gasoline declined only 618,000 barrels in the holiday week ended last Friday, according to the American Petroleum Institute. At the week-end, total supplies were 199,557,000 barrels, compared with 200,175,000 a week earlier and 201,302,000 a year ago.

At a quick, half-hour meeting late yesterday afternoon stockholders of the Chemical Bank New York Trust Company voted overwhelmingly in favor of acquiring the Long Island Trust Company. The count showed that 6,368,480 shares, or well above the necessary two-thirds of the 8,476,590 shares outstanding, favored the merger, with only 39,320 shares opposed.
WASHINGTON, July 12 -President Mohammad Ayub Khan of Pakistan cautioned the United States Congress today not to end or curtail the foreign-aid program.

The Lehman Corporation reported yesterday it had net assets of $343,995,485, equal to $30.72 a share, on June 30. This was the highest net asset value for any quarter in the closed-end investment company's thirty-two year history.
GIVE a British cast an aviation drama to enact, with characters displaying calm fortitude when faced by mechanical disaster, and it is only logical to expect an admirably underplayed performance.
LOS ANGELES, July 12 -Richard M. Nixon has just about decided to "gamble" on maintaining his titular leadership of the Republican party without running for Governor in his home state in 1962.
CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., July 12 (UPI) -- Two candidates for the second manned United States space flight tested their reflexes today.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, July 12 (Reuters) -- The International Lawn Tennis Federation agreed today to the experimental introduction of a limited number of open tournaments, but deferred details until next year's meeting.
The Times' recent series of editorials culminating in the July 7 "The Crux of the Algerian Issue" calls for a full and complete reappraisal of The Times' Algerian policy.
PARIS, July 12 -- President de Gaulle said tonight there was "no chance" that the West would yield to Soviet pressures for a change of status in Berlin.

EDDIE CONDON, the garrulous guitarist whose duties as host at his club, Condon's, 330 East Fifty-sixth Street, have often kept him so busy conversing with the customers that his guitar has remained untouched for nights on end, has put himself back on full time duty as a musician.

The first tax-exempt bonds of the New York State Housing Finance Agency, intended to aid financing of middle-income housing, were placed yesterday at a net inte rest cost to the agency of 3.97 per cent.

BONN, Germany, July 12 -The West German Government implicitly turned down today a bid by the Soviet Union for bilateral peace talks and said that only a freely elected government representing all of Germany could sign a peace treaty.

WHITE PLAINS, July 12 -- The head of a driving school and three former clerks of the Westchester County Automobile Bureau were indicted today for providing shortcuts for immigrants to get drivers' licenses.

WASHINGTON, July 12 -- The Federal Reserve Board reported today that the condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended July 5:
LONDON, July 12 -- The British Government intends to make further reductions in its forces in Kuwait, the Ministry of Defense announced today.
Following are the statements made yesterday by Mayor Wagner and Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa commenting on the report by the New York City Charter Commission:

There is strong opposition in Congress -- and, of course, from the Chinese Nationalists -- to United States recognition and United Nations membership for Outer Mongolia; but we see no compelling reason why the State Department should retreat from its intention to normalize relations with the Mongolian republic. The United States has proposed recognition of the Ulan Bator regime, and the Mongols have announced their readiness to discuss the establishment of relations.
WASHINGTON, July 12 -The Air Force is preparing a vigorous appeal to Congress to invest more heavily in bombers and other manned aircraft in view of the impressive Soviet air show last Sunday.

The Western Union Telegraph Company, Kimberly-Clark Corporation, Republic Aviation Corporation and King's Department Stores, Inc., all filed registration statements with the Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday.

Kidder, Peabody Co. and White, Weld Co. and associates are offering to the public today 40,000 shares of 5.48 per cent preferred stock of Brockton Edison Company at $102.4299 a share, plus accrued dividends from June 1, 1961.

WASHINGTON, July 13 (UPI) -- The Senate Interior Committee approved a bill today to create a system of wilderness areas that would guarantee vast tracts of public lands against commercial exploitation.

BIRKDALE, England, July 13 (UPI) -- Arnold Palmer battled gale winds as he shot a one-over-par 73 in the second round of the British Open golf championship today. He missed a chance to tie for the 36-hole lead when he incurred a freakish one-stroke penalty.
WASHINGTON, July 13 (AP) -- The Treasury will conduct next week a $16,000,000,000 borrowing operation, it announced today.
PARIS, July 13 (AP) -- After years of unsuccessful combat against the pigeons of Paris, the city has decided to try a form of birth control to cut its winged population.

POINT ARGUELLO, Calif., July 13 (AP) -- A Midas satellite equipped to detect missile firings was circling the earth every two hours and forty minutes today in a record-breaking orbit that takes it over the Soviet Union.
MONTAUK, L.I., July 13 -- Joe Maresco of the Woodmere Country Club won the Long Island Professional Golf Association championship today with a 54-hole score of 213 at the Montauk Downs Club.
BOSTON, July 13 (UPI) -- Doll Schwall gained his eighth victory as he pitched the Red Sox to a 3-2 triumph over Baltimore tonight at Fenway Park.

IT seems to be fruit week at local stands, where the jewel-colors of all sorts of berries and cherries attract the eye. Also attractive, in the main, are the price tags they wear -- about 45 cents a pound for excellent Bing cherries and about 35 cents a pint for blueberries.
The Flight Engineers International Association pledged yesterday to maintain Pan American World Airways' service into West Berlin in the event of an engineers strike against that line next week.
Kermit Bloomgarden said yesterday that he would produce "King Kong," the South African musical with a native cast of sixty, on Broadway next February.
ROME, July 13 (UPI) -- Pope John XXIII will announce tomorrow the Roman Catholic doctrine on labor relations for this age of automation, state planning and awakening underdeveloped nations.
CHICAGO, July 13 (UPI) -- An executive of the A.M.A. said today that Dr. Salk had "misinterpreted" the organization's stand on his vaccine.
WASHINGTON, July 13 -- In the last few weeks the Kennedy Administration has been showing great sensitivity and even irritation about public criticism of its acts.
WASHINGTON, July 13 -- The House rejected today the Kennedy Administration's proposal to convert a new plutonium-producing reactor at Hanford, Wash., into the world's largest atomic power plant.
PARIS, July 13 -- Frenchmen will celebrate tomorrow the 172d anniversary of the fall of the Bastille -- on July 14, 1789 -- and of the 1,000-year-old monarchy that went down with it.
ORLANDO, Fla., July 13 -- James R. Hoffa won another round in his legal battle with the Government today. A Federal judge dismissed mail-fraud charges against him and two of his associates.

Steel-making furnaces in this country poured 44,857,804 net tons of ingots and steel for castings during the first half of the year, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday. This was a rise of 16.4 per cent from the output for the second half of 1960 but a drop of 26.2 per cent from that in the first half.

The American Stock Exchange made public yesterday the vote taken by its governors on Dec. 16, 1959, in connection with their "trial" of Gerard A. Re and his son, Gerard F. Re, on charges of "willfully" violating various of the exchange's trading regulations.

The rapid-fire editorial pronouncements of The Times on the maritime dispute certainly did not help to clarify either the issues in the dispute or the problems of the merchant marine (editorials of June 15, 24, 27; July 1 and 4).

Coincident with the issuance of its earnings report for the forty weeks ended on June 8, Loew's Theatres, Inc., announced today the signing of a five-year contract with the American News Company to service and operate concession stands and vending machines in its chain of movie houses.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 2 points up to 2 points off yesterday. Six of the eight contracts on the board were unchanged.

SPOLETO, Italy, July 13 -- The world premiere of Jerome Robbins' abstract sociological ballet "Events" was received with wild enthusiasm by a Festival of Two Worlds' audience here last night. Rome critics termed it a "truly great masterpiece of twentieth century ballet."
WHAT doth the Green Crow say? He says that young people should take pagan delight in the pleasures of love.

The thirteen-story building containing thirty-seven apartments at 300 West End Avenue, northeast corner of Seventy-fourth Street, has been purchased by its occupants, who plan to operate it as a cooperative.
A man who needed $285 to pay his son's overdue college tuition bill held up a savings-and-loan office yesterday and fled with $1,015, but was captured moments later.

WASHINGTON, July 13 (AP) -- President Kennedy gave final instructions to his principal disarmament adviser today for a new round of negotiations with the Soviet Union on setting up an international disarmament conference this summer.
BINGHAMTON, N.Y., July 13 -- Governor Rockefeller said today that he favored a plan to convert the forty-nine institutions of the State University to year-round use.
The establishment of a nationwide program to develop natural-science centers for youth was announced yesterday.
The Port of New York Authority has retained former Gov. Thomas E. Dewey to help handle the appeal of the criminal contempt conviction of Austin J. Tobin, executive director of the bi-state agency.

The Avco Corporation announced yesterday it had received $29,627,500 in Air Force contracts for continued missile work at two of its divisions. One contract for $14,980,000 has been assigned to the research and advanced development division, Wilmington, Mass., and the other, for $14,647,000, is for the continued production of re-entry vehicles and support equipment at the Lycoming division, Stratford, Conn.
The market for United States Government securities marked time yesterday awaiting the Treasury's announcement of its financing plans.
TRENTON, July 13 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner said today he was "still convinced" that the bulk of North Jersey's residents wanted a global jetport in the Great Swamp of Morris County.

VIENNA, July 13 -- Informed sources said today that the Italian Government might take more' punitive steps against Austria unless something was done to curb the dynamiters active in Alto Adige (South Tyrol) and other provinces in the north of Italy.
LITTLE ROCK, Ark., July 13 (AP) -- Four Freedom Riders were freed today on their promise to get out of Arkansas without making further bus station segregation tests.
LONDON, July 13 -- Prime Minister Macmillan described to Conservative Members of Parliament tonight the dimensions of the economic crisis facing Britain.

Sharp criticism of briefing officers of the International Cooperation Administration and the State Department was expressed yesterday by a group of young college graduates a few hours before they left to teach in British East Africa under I.C.A. auspices.

Foreign governments and cen- {tral banks sold $1,000,000 in} Lgold to the United States in the! week ended on Wednesday, the' {Federal Reserve Bank of New iYork reported yesterday. This' lincreased the nation's stock of' gold to $17,551,000,000, up $148,-! 000,000 in the last six weeks., [but left the total $216,000,000i below that on Jan. 1, 1961.

The John Birch Society -- headquarters, Belmont, Mass. -- is now endeavoring to build up "the most complete and most accurate files in America on the leading Comsymps, Socialists and liberals." According to its latest bulletin, the society wants from its estimated 60,000 members scattered throughout the country "the background, connections and activities of all the leading liberals * * *."
WASHINGTON, July 13 -- The Federal Communications Commission warned broadcasters today that if they want their Federal licenses renewed they must live up to public commitments on programming.
GUATEMALA, July 12 -- The Defense Minister, Col. Enrique Peralta Azurdia, reported the country quiet today following the failure of a Rightist plot to overthrow the Government.

LONDON, July 13 -- Frank Cousins, general secretary of the Transport and General Workers Union, triumphed today when delegates to his union's biennial conference at Brighton reaffirmed its support for unilateral nuclear disarmament by Britain.
Premier Khrushchev heaped honors on Yugoslavia's visiting Foreign Minister, Kova Popovic, despite Communist China's hostility to the Belgrade regime.
WASHINGTON, July 13 -- President Kennedy rejected today a Republican compromise intended to win greater bipartisan support for his long-range foreign aid program.

Dr. Robert Soblen was found guilty here yesterday of wartime espionage for the Soviet Union. The Federal District Court jury of ten men and two women reached the decision in one hour and nineteen minutes of deliberation.
WASHINGTON, July 13 -- A delegation from Mali has warned the Administration that if United States funds are not pledged soon to build a hydroelectric project Soviet aid will be sought.
WASHINGTON, July 13 -- Following is the text of a joint communique issued today by President Kennedy and President Mohammad Ayub Khan of Pakistan:

PHILADELPHIA, July 13 -- Dissatisfaction with what they consider lack of help from their parent organization is being expressed here by some members of the youth and college section of the National Association for the advancement of Colored People.

ONE of New York's most creditable Chinese restaurants is a score or more subway stops from Chinatown. It is a restaurant with a loyal clientele and, as a quidnunc might put it, a place whose fame has been hushed about for seven years.

NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y., July 13 (AP) -- Gail Purdy, a 19-year-old college sophomore better known as a speed skater, gained the semi-finals today in the thirty-second annual New York State women's golf championship.
BAGHDAD, Iraq, July 13 (Reuters) -- Premier Abdul Karim Kassim ordered today the release of four former Premiers tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, July 13 (AP) -- The Department of Justice today entered the bitter struggle between the New York Central Railroad and the Chesapeake Ohio Railway for control of the Baltimore Ohio Railroad with a proposal that both bids be rejected.
Herman Levin, producer of "My Fair Lady," won the right yesterday to have the motion picture, television and other subsidiary rights to the production be put up for open bidding.

TREVISO, Italy, July 13 (AP) -- Priceless art masterpieces were destroyed or damaged when a United States jet fighter plane dropped its fuel tanks over an ancient church at near-by Preganziola yesterday. United States officials promised to repair the church and pay damages.

WASHINGTON, July 13 -- About 1,800 enthusiastic foreign-exchange students turned a White House visit into a virtual stampede this morning. The only damage was to the shrubbery and to the dignity of several of the visitors.

The Board of Elections has decided to use paper ballots in the Sept. 7 primary. With city-wide contests in prospect in all three parties, the decision promises to introduce a new element of confusion into a primary already certain to be the biggest and most turbulent in city history.

WEST ORANGE, N.J., July 13 -- Charlotte DeCozen of Montclair and Mrs. William Tracy of Essex Fells will meet tomorrow in the 36-hole final of the Garden State Women's Golf Association's eighth annual championship.
WASHINGTON, July 13-- Rail and truck freight loadings took a sharp drop last week, both from the preceding week's volumes and those of the corresponding period of 1960.
HARTFORD, Conn., July 13 (AP) -- A railroad crossing attendant told the police today that someone had stolen his artificial legs containing his life savings of $17,800.

HARTSDALE, N.Y., July 13 -- Nadine Netter of Scarsdale, N.Y., seeded No. 1, and Joanne Swanson of Pawtucket, R.I., No. 2, gained the final today of the New York State girls' tennis championship at The County Tennis Club of Westchester.

Production of lumber dropped to a low for the year of 129,809,000 board feet in the week ended last Saturday, according to reports from regional associations. The holiday week total compares with 209,740,000 board feet the week before and 141,469,000 board feet a year ago.
CLEVELAND, July 13 (AP) -- Ted Lepcio's grand-slam home run paced the Minnesota Twins to a 9-6 victory over the Cleveland Indians tonight.

IT was bound to happen. "The Student Prince" finally has made it to Off Broadway. Not that there ever was any doubt that it would not make it. Since 1924, the tuneful tale of Old Heidelberg has wandered the land from East to West and back, showing itself on the silo circuit, in auditoriums and at summer operetta festivals.
IN the person of Thomas James Mackell the Democratic organization ticket has gained some conviviality to balance the solemnity of State Controller Arthur Levitt, the Mayoralty designee.
WASHINGTON, July 13 (UPI) -- Several air safety and fire officials complained today that many of the nation's largest airports needed more men and equipment to fight fires in airliner crashes.

PURCHASE, N.Y., July 13 -- Mimi Kanarek of Brooklyn eliminated Sheila Maroshick of Brooklyn, seeded third, 6 -- 4, 6 -- 2, today and reached the semi-finals of the women's Eastern clay court championship.

The Bankers Trust Company has started a series of advertisements in several European publications describing the virtues of Yellowstone National Park, hemlock trees and student poetry at Yale University.

WASHINGTON, July 13 -- Under the laws and policies now existing in the United States the Government, which has just rejected a $5 million loan application to keep the New Haven Railroad out of bankruptcy proceedings, has dispense nearly $1.4 billion since 1946 for railroad projects ha other countries.
Dr. John J. Theobald, the Superintendent of Schools, acknowledged yesterday that students at a vocational high school had built a boat for him last year in his brother-in-law's name.
WASHINGTON, July 13 -- The State Department announced today that it had failed to reach agreement with Dutch aviation officials seeking a route to the West Coast.
With an abundance of numbers and of mediocrity, New York City's election year cast of characters is nearing completion.
CHICAGO, July 13 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

Up Scope of the Darby Dan Farm enjoyed the fast track at Aqueduct yesterday. So much so that this 3-year-old son of Helioscope turned in the fastest six furlongs of the meeting in capturing the feature, the Clearview Purse.

NEW HAVEN, July 13 (UPI) -- The Federal court in New Haven refused today to grant a temporary injunction against the enforcement of a 300-year-old Connecticut law permitting deportation of newcomers who receive welfare payments.

Tri-Continental Corporation reported yesterday new highs in investment assets, share value and investment income for the first half of the year. The mid-year report of the closed-end investment company ascribed the gain of $51,476,082 in investment assets mainly to "appreciation in the market value of investment holdings."
WASHINGTON, July 13 (AP) -- A Senate inquiry into the relative missile and bomber strength of the Soviet Union and the United States will open Tuesday.

MARBLEHEAD, Mass., July 13 -- Massachusetts ports of call are having their biggest pleasure-boating summer in history. Yachtsmen are going farther from home than ever before for their summer vacations.
WASHINGTON, July 13 (UPI) -- The armed services have ordered more than 600 copies of a new Defense Department film, "The Challenge of Ideas," dramatizing the struggle against communism.

THAT low rumble over Lewisohn Stadium last night was more than the usual aviation maneuvers reserved for the evening hours. It was the weatherman, tinkering with potions and muttering imprecations against music makers and the handful of the faithful who would turn out to hear them on a night obviously designed for meteorological disasters.
WASHINGTON, July 13 -- Department stores sales in the United States in the week ended Saturday, July 8, were 6 per cent above the level of a year earlier.

SEOUL, July 13 -- South Korea's Supreme Court upheld today the conviction of six officials of the former Government of Dr. Syngrnan Rhee for the attempted assassination of Dr. John M. Chang five years ago.
WASHINGTON, July 10 -- Baird-Atomic, Inc., of Cambridge, Mass., built the infrared sensors riding in the nose of Midas III, the Air Force satellite designed to detect missile firings.
TRENTON, July 13 -- The New Jersey Turnpike Authority has begun a study to determine the desirability of linking the toll highway with the New York State Thruway.

Anyone who knows Elliott Shapiro, principal of P.S. 119, will reject with indignation the incredible charge that he produced a rat as a "publicity stunt." This is another example of the frantic efforts of Superintendent John Theobald as well as Board President Charles Silver to make the school principals scapegoats for the sorry state of neglect in our school buildings, uncovered in recent investigations.

WINNEPEG, Ont., July 13 (AP) -- Jacky Cupit of Longview, Tex., tied Tony Lema of San Leandro, Calif., for the lead at 135 in the Canadian open golf championship today. Cupit shot a one-under-par 69 in the second round.
BERLIN, July 13 -- Chancellor Adenauer said today that "panic" was apparently gripping Communist East Germany as refugees continued to flood into West Berlin.
WESTPORT, Conn., July 13 -- The First Selectman here is withholding the salaries of the Board of Tax Review in a controversy over an assessment reduction.

Daily average borrowings by member banks of the Federal Reserve System declined $1,000,000 to $47,000,000 in the week ended Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. Daily average reserves in excess of requirements rose $90,000,000 to $637,000.000.

Loans to business by the fifteen weekly reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve System in New York City fell by $47,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday. Repayments by tobacco manufacturers were the major cause of the decline.

Max and Erwin P. Staller, builders, have announced the start of construction on the second section of the Jefferson Shopping Plaza on Main Street (Route 112), half mile north of Nesconset Highway at Port Jefferson Station, L.I.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 13 -- Prime Minister Julius K. Nyerere of Tanganyika reminded the big powers today that in concentrating on the world's trouble spots they tended to forget peaceful but impoverished friends.

The R.J. Reynolds Tobacco Company, makers of Camel cigarettes and one of the nation's two largest tobacco concerns, has proposed splitting its common stock for the fourth time in forty years. Directors yesterday also increased the quarterly dividend on the pesent common with the declaration of 75 cents a share, payable on Sept. 5 to holders of record of Aug. 15.
LONDON, July 13 -- Premier Khrushchev has been told bluntly that the British Government regards his political offensive on Berlin as artificial and illegal.
At a luncheon here yesterday, rolls floated in mid-air, salt shakers disappeared and bottles of soda were converted into fifths of whisky.
Dr. Jonas E. Salk accused the American Medical Association yesterday of "tampering with science."

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), July 13 -- An Israeli official assured the United States today that two American missionaires of the Church of Christ would be given whatever police protection they needed to permit them to continue their religious activities here.
One of the major steamship lines involved in the nation-wide maritime strike has filed actions against the National Maritime Union in Federal Courts in New York and San Francisco.
CHICAGO, July 13 -- Thanks largely to soaring home runs by Roger Maris and Mickey Mantle, the Yankees regained the top of the American League standing tonight.

WASHINGTON, July 13 -- Senator Hubert H. Humphrey reported today that the Communist bloc was grappling with staggering food shortages and that this might be behind the Soviet Union's pressure on West Berlin.

AS a student of man's evolution I view him as the most extraordinary of all nature's performances: a most improbable creature, brash and bright, a spoiled brat, in fact -- full of promise, only a small part of which has been realized."

The advent of a revolutionary world-wide communication system, using satellites orbiting thousands of miles in upper space as microwave radio-relay stations, has opened up many complicated policy problems, now being considered at Congressional hearings that opened yesterday.
WASHINGTON, July 13 -- Legislation to create a Federal advisory council on the arts, long sought by cultural organizations of the country, moved toward the House floor today.
INWOOD, L.I., July 13 -- With a brand of golf worthy of an experienced campaigner, 17-year-old Claude (Butch) Harmon Jr. won the metropolitan junior championship today.

General Electric Company reported a gradual improvement in its over-all business during the second quarter of 1961. This was stressed yesterday by Ralph J. Cordiner, chairman, in issuing the results for the period.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., July 13 -- The John G. Anderson Memorial golf tournament, an amateur best-ball fixture at the Winged Foot Golf Club since the early nineteen thirties, began today with ninety-two pairs going after thirty-one berths in the match-play draw.

The September and November domestic sugar contracts fell to new lows for the move yesterday on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange. Trading was influenced by a lack of interest in actuals. The trade was on both sides of the board.
BINGHAMTON, N.Y., July 13 -- Governor Rockefeller said today that he disapproved of the stringent new welfare code that Newburgh plans to put into effect on Saturday.
With an initiative that is becoming rare among the Eastern railroads, the Erie-Lackawanna is talking about enlarging and improving its passenger service.

The General Development Corporation has acquired the Hooper Construction Company, one of the South's leading earth-moving and heavy construction contractors. The transaction involves more than $4,000,000, according to F.E. Mackle Jr., chairman of General Development.
COLUMBIA, S.C., July 13 (AP) -- Records of an insurance concern headed by A.D. Cudd, Spartanburg's Mayor, have been impounded, and a state investigation has been ordered into its operations.
WHITE PLAINS, July 13 -- The distribution of many large estates may be controlled by a ruling awaited in State Supreme Court here on whether a husband or wife died first.
The hospital patient wears safety like a nightcap with a new monitoring system displayed here yesterday by Minneapolis-Honeywell Regulator Company.
Mrs. John F. Kennedy had a fine idea in using George Washington's home at Mount Vernon as the setting for a state dinner in honor of the President of Pakistan.

Armino A. Campagna, realty investor, has sold a vacant plot of about 100 by 100 feet on the west side of Riverdale Avenue between West 235th and 236th Streets in the Riverdale area of the Bronx. The land was bought by Tummolo Brothers, builders, for improvement with an apartment house.
Plans to convert a vacant factory at 102-106 Park Row into an apartment house were filed with the Buildings Department yesterday.

SEOUL, Korea, July 13 -- Twenty-seven men in olive drab now rule South Korea from a dingy office building patrolled by sentries and ringed with black jeeps. They are, for the United States and South Korea, a new breed of men.
DETROIT, July 13 (AP) -- The United Automobile Workers asked General Motors today for an increase of at least twenty-six cents an hour in the basic wages of the company's 310,000 production workers.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), July 13 -- The trial of Adolf Eichmann reached a dramatic climax at noon today when the former Gestapo officer finally spoke the words Israelis wanted to hear from him.

AKRON, Ohio, July 13 (UPI) -- The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company has been granted authorization by the Government of Turkey to form a $13,000,000 company in association with local interests to build a tire factory, it was announced today.
WASHINGTON, July 13 -- President Mohammad Ayub Khan of Pakistan spoke out strongly today against any United States military assistance to India.

HALIFAX, N.S., July 13 -- Proving that fat "little keel" boats can win ocean races as impressively as beamy center-boarders, Ted Hood, the Marblehead sailmaker turned yacht designer, won the 360-mile Marblehead-to-Halifax ocean race by 2 hours 38 minutes 59 seconds with his thirty-six-foot yawl Robin Too II.

BY American custom in tournament play, a victory counts the same whether the margin is large or small. The winning of the Vanderbilt Cup has been decided by 10 points -- less than the value of one overtrick at a part-score contract in clubs.
Yonkers Raceway is seeking to acquire a majority interest in Roosevelt Raceway, its rival for the claim of being the premier harness-racing track.

Stocks declined yesterday for the fifth successive day, losing a little more than two-thirds of 1 per cent of aggregate market value on the New York Stock Exchange. At the close the gains of early July had been all but extinguished.
LA PLATA, Md., July 13 (AP) -- Two passenger cars and a tractor-trailer collided yesterday, killing a retired chief engineer of the United States Lines and two other persons.
CHICAGO, July 13 (AP) -- Setbacks in grain futures prices were general and broad today, with numerous contracts down more than 2 cents a bushel and the near-by rye deliveries off more than 3 cents.
General of the Army Douglas MacArthur, arriving here last night after a triumphant ten-day visit to the Philippines, urged that this country give more aid to the Philippines to repair war damages.
WASHINGTON, July 13 (AP) -- The House Ways and Means Committee killed for this year today President Kennedy's requested repeal of two tax provisions favoring stockholders.

A study of the rise to power of a military elite in Egypt and Syria has been made by P.J. Vatikiotis, Associate Professor of Government at Indiana University. In "The Egyptian Army in Politics" he presents information largely from Arabic sources on the social background and personal motivation of Nasser and his chief lieutenants.
OTTAWA, July 13 -- James E. Coyne resigned as Governor of the Bank of Canada today after winning vindication for his conduct in office from the Canadian Senate.
The wholesale commodity price index inched ahead to 84.6 on Wednesday from 84.5 on Tuesday. The index, compiled by the Bureau of Labor Statistics, stood at 85.2 on July 6, 1960.
THE sight of a frizzed head and the sound of a plaintive, "But you must do something about it -- I can't go around looking like this," has caused many a hairdresser to hold up his hands in despair.
WASHINGTON, July 13 -- A self-styled "slave laborer for the Federal Government" unraveled today the tale of a futile maneuver in the Electoral College to block President Kennedy's election.

PARIS, July 13 -- The Greenwich, Conn., High School senior chorus ended a three-week European tour here today with a warmly received concert at the headquarters of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization.
LONDON, July 13 -- The stock market closed with widespread falls here today. Selling, although described as not heavy, was persistent.
Milwaukee County, Wis., sold $11,429,000 of sewer and expressway bonds at competitive bidding yesterday.

Defective fire escapes and a long list of other violations at 229 West 101st Street led to fines of $500 in Housing Court yesterday for each of two women who had bought the apartment house in partnership about a year ago.

NAIROBI, Kenya, July 13 -- A.J.F. Simmance, Crown Counsel, contended in a Nairobi court today that documents found in possession of Muturi Kariuki, a Kikuyu, indicated that there were preparations for "a militant and aggressive action."

MOSCOW, July 13 (AP) -- Jim Beatty of San Jose, Calif., insisted today he would run the 1,500 meters in the United States-Soviet Union track meet Saturday and Sunday despite pressure to make him run the 5,000 meters.
GENEVA, July 13 -- V.K. Krishna Menon of India made the opening move today in his effort to end the deadlock at the fourteen-nation conference here on Laos.

ELIZABETH, N.J., July 13 (AP) -- Assemblyman Nelson F. Stamler today accused Gov. Robert B. Meyner of taking a "dog in the manger attitude" and an "incomprehensible position" in seeking to block the sale of station WNTA-TV to a New York educational television group.

CAMBRIDGE, N.Y., July 13 -- The box containing the new plug bore the claim that "noisy action kills bass." There was the additional information that the jitterbug was a "noisy, rollicking, wiggling surface dancer."
A community of Hassidic Jews in the Rockland County Town of Ramapo has won State Supreme Court endorsement in a long battle to incorporate as a separate village. Its name will be New Square.

WASHINGTON, July 13 (UPI) -- The House approved today legislation giving the Federal Government power to discipline industries or cities polluting any one of the nation's lakes and streams. Passage was on a voice vote.
Both Arthur Levitt, the Democratic organization designee for Mayor, and Louis J. Lefkowitz, the Republican candidate, said yesterday they favored Charter reform for the city.

In "The Plight of the Railroads" (July 6) you call for a Federal subsidy for the New Haven. I have a better plan. Let the New Haven charge "what the traffic will bear" on its commuter runs. Then if it still cannot stay in business, close it up.
LONDON, July 13 -- Maj. Yuri A. Gagarin, the Soviet Union's hero of space and now the darling of Londoners, was "imprisoned" in the Tower of London today by an enthusiastic crowd.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 13 -- Buzzie Bavasi bristled at the news. The general manager of the Los Angeles Dodgers had just learned that the new Washington Senators had swung a deal with the Pittsburgh Pirates almost before they had had time to appraise the players gained in the expansion draft last December.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 13 -- The Alcazar Theatre was marked today for probable demolition early next year to provide a parking area behind the Stewart Hotel.

LOS ANGELES, July 13 (AP) -- The pitcher, Stan Williams drove in three runs with a bases-filled double as the Los Angeles Dodgers scored six times in the fourth inning tonight and dealt the futile Philadelphia Phils their eighth straight loss, 7 -- 2.

The last gap in the Brooklyn-Queens Expressway will not be closed until late in 1963, almost a quarter-century after the construction of the eleven-mile road began, Queens Borough President John T. Clancy said yesterday.
A strike of clerical workers against Hellenic Lines, Ltd., yesterday halted cargo handling operations of three freighters berthed at the line's pier at Fifty-seventh Street, Brooklyn.
MOSCOW, July 13 -- The Soviet Union and Yugoslavia appeared bent today on improving their state relations despite the existence of ideological differences between their Communist parties.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 13 -- A Broadway producer may receive strange answers these days when he comes here in search of an actor to play the lead in a drama.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 13 -- It seems to be one of the ironies of baseball that the playing schedule invariably brings together two clubs at the moment both are striving to improve their none-too-robust pennant prospects.
CHICAGO, July 13 -- Directors of Victor Adding Machine Company and of Comptometer Corporation, two manufacturers of office machines, have unanimously approved a merger, it was announced today.
State Controller Arthur Levitt yesterday selected State Senator Thomas J. Mackell of Queens as his running mate for President of the City council.

Auto executives are known for their persistent optimism. At the moment, however, they are not talking quite so optimistically -- or as readily -- as they did early this year, according to the Associated Press.
Richard D. Heffner has been named acting general manager of Educational Television for the Metropolitan Area, Inc.

ATLANTIC CITY, July 13 -- The finish of the fifteenth annual Powder Puff Derby was postponed for twenty-four hours more today. But there were indications that improving weather might bring an end to the woman's transcontinental air race by the new deadline of 1 P.M. tomorrow.
Rainbow Shops, Inc., of Brooklyn, a chain of women's apparel stores, has leased three new locations in the New York metropolitan area.

Lewis Gruber, chairman of P. Lorillard Company, tobacco products manufacturer, yesterday resumed leadership of the concern following the death on Sunday of Harold F. Temple. Mr. Temple had been chief executive officer since last Dec. 1 and president since Jan. 1, 1959.
ROME, July 13 -- Premier Amintore Fanfani told the Chamber of Deputies today that his Government was determined to "defend the tranquillity" of Alto Adige (South Tyrol).
DETROIT, July 13 (AP) -- Dick Sikes of the University of Arkansas, the medalist, gained the semi-finals today in the national public links golf championship.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 13 -- On the eve of the third anniversary of Iraq's revolution, developments in the Arab community of nations are increasingly unfavorable to Premier Abdul Karim Kassim.
Executives of private electric utilities said yesterday that the Tennessee Valley Authority's rate reduction of 8 per cent was merely "a cheap publicity stunt."

CINCINNATI, July 13 (AP) -- Frank Robinson hit his twenty-fourth home run in the seventh inning tonight and drove in the winning run in the ninth as the Cincinnati Reds beat the Chicago Cubs, 4 -- 3. It was only the fifth victory for the National League leaders in thirteen games with the seventh-place Cubs.
WASHINGTON, July 13 -- Rules were issued today to guide Federal contractors in complying with the Administration's ban on discrimination against Negroes in hiring and promotion.

How unfair and misleading of Richard Brenneis to write (Times, July 1) about an "Italian yoke" in Alto Adige and "foreign oppressors" still attempting to "italianize this completely un-Italian section of old Austria"!

WASHINGTON, July 13 -- Legislation providing stiffer penalties for antitrust law violations and making top management officials responsible for illegal activities of subordinates was introduced in Congress today.
ST. LOUIS, July 13 (AP) -- Carleton Willey pitched brilliantly in relief and Joe Adcock hit a two-run home run tonight as the Milwaukee Braves scored a 6-3 victory over the St. Louis Cardinals.

OCEANPORT, N.J., July 13 (AP) -- Tom Kelly, his trainer, said today that Leonard P. Sasso's Globemaster, who won the Saranac Handicap at Aqueduct and the Arlington Classic in Chicago on successive Saturdays, would pass up the $100,000 added Monmouth Handicap this Saturday.
Twenty active and retired police sergeants were reported to have been identified yesterday as having received payoffs in the tow-truck racket in Queens.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 13 -- Plans for the annual Shaggy Dog Ball for the benefit of the Hampton Animal Shelter were announced this week by Mrs. Sidney R. Warren, permanent chairman, and Mrs. Clyde Newhouse, executive chairman.
Your recent editorial "School Aid: Discrimination" opposing Federal aid to private and parochial schools argues irrelevancies as if they were the essential questions.
The polio rate across the nation, including New York City, is very low this year, the city's Health Department and the United States Public Health Service announced yesterday.
PHILADELPHIA, July 14 (UPI) -- Six electrical equipment companies denied liability today in six damage suits brought by the Government in behalf of the Tennessee Valley Authority.
In Alvin Shuster's brilliant story from Washington (The Times, July 9) the Central Intelligence Agency informs us (at our expense) that it will never inform us on how they spend our funds.
"To our venerable brethren -- the Patriarchs, Primates, Archbishops, Bishops and other ordinaries in peace and communion with the Apostolic See."

ROME, July 14 (AP) -- When Pope John XXIII issued his encyclical today, he was expressing the mind of the Church on modern world problems -- not defining a doctrine of faith or morals that binds Roman Catholics under pain of sin.
WASHINGTON, July 14 (AP) -- The Air Transport Association reported today that domestic trunk airlines had a net loss of $4,361,000 in May.
One achievement of President Ayub Khan of Pakistan in Washington was to convey to American officials the seriousness with which he views the dispute over Kashmir between India and Pakistan.
TO see professionals return to the classroom is always a treat for the layman, and this is no less the case with hairdressers.

WASHINGTON, July 4 (AP) -- A hospital spokesman urged the Food and Drug Administration today to stand firm against industry protests over proposed regulations for labeling hazardous substances used around the house.
One man was killed and eight trains delayed last night when a speeding automobile went out of control, plunged through a steel fence and hurtled down thirty-five feet into a Bronx railroad cut.
The Rev. James A. Gusweller, the leader of a fight for better housing on the West Side, said yesterday that his church planned a concurrent effort against juvenile delinquency.
PHILADELPHIA, July 14 -- Charles (Sonny) Liston, the top-ranking contender for the heavyweight boxing crown, was suspended indefinitely today by the Pennsylvania Athletic Commission.

QUITO, Ecuador, July 14 -- School is out here on the Equator this week. The students are joyous and their feelings are matched only by the bliss of their parents, who have undergone a peculiarly strenuous examination week with their children.
Mayor Wagner directed the City Commissioner of Investigation yesterday to make an immediate and intensive inquiry into certain activities of Dr. John J. Theobald, the Superintendent of Schools.
Conflicting reports circulated yesterday on the progress of Yonkers Raceway's efforts to acquire a 25 per cent stock interest in Roosevelt Raceway's $21,000,000 plant at Westbury, L.I.

CLEVELAND, July 14 (AP) -- Eighth-inning singles by Don Dillard and a pinch-hitter, Bob Nieman, drove in the two runs that enabled the Cleveland Indians to gain a 7-5 victory over the Los Angeles Angels tonight.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 14 -- Warren S. Titus, North American president of P. O.-Orient Lines, reported today that his division's sales for the first six months of 1961 doubled those for the first half of 1959. He did not disclose the figures.
The Great Northern Railway's earnings plummeted in the first half this year to $1,751,343 from $8,061,241 in the 1960 period.

WASHINGTON, July 14 (AP) Chairman Frank W. McCulloch said today that President Kennedy's plan to revise procedures of the National Labor Relations Board would cut four or five months from the time required to dispose of a charge of unfair labor practice.

WASHINGTON, July 14 -- The United States threatened today to use its veto if necessary to prevent the adoption of Premier Khrushchev's proposal to replace the Secretary General of the United Nations with a three-member directorate.

BERLIN, July 14 -- The Communists disclosed today that restive East German farmers had threatened to break up collective farms in protest over the critical situation in the regime's agricultural system.
WASHINGTON, July 14 (AP) Stiffer taxes on mutual savings banks and savings and loan associations were proposed today by the Treasury.
HAWORTH, N.J., July 14 -- Mrs. Thomas Hory and Bernard Curry of Winged Foot won the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association's twenty-seventh annual sister-brother golf championship today.

The calendar of new issues tentatively set for sale next week in the new capital market is dominated by issues managed by financing agents chosen by the companies. Major competitive issues are lacking with a $9,600,000 bond issue of Maine and an $8,000,000 bond issue of Newark, N.J., accounting for most of the volume.

WESTBURY, L.I., July 14 -- Music, floodlights, six horses, one goat, $50,000 and upward of 50,000 persons -- these are the component parts of the Roosevelt International Trot tomorrow night at Roosevelt Raceway.
The acquisition of movie, television and other subsidiary rights to "My Fair Lady" by the Columbia Broadcasting System was upheld as valid by an arbitration panel.

The Morgan Guaranty Trust Company of New York and six upstate banks filed formal applications yesterday to form a new state-wide bank holding company, the Morgan New York State Corporation. The proposal was disclosed originally last January.

BIRKDALE, England, July 14 (UPI) -- A torrential rain forced postponement today of the final two rounds of the British Open golf championship. Officials said if the last thirty-six holes could not be played tomorrow the tournament would be declared void.

LONDON, July 14 -- The widespread gloom over Britain's economic situation eased a bit today with a Government announcement of an improvement in trade. However, the improvement was not sufficient to stimulate the stock market, which is awaiting with some trepidation the series of anti-inflationary measures the Government is expected to invoke in a week or ten days.

TAILORED WOMAN unveiled yesterday its first precious jewel collection from France and Italy. The collection, valued at slightly less than a million dollars, included a variety of precious stones, yellow and white gold and platinum.
LONDON, July 14 (Reuters) -- A strike of 650 maintenance workers at London Airport tonight cause cancellation of all British Overseas Airways Corporation flights across the Atlantic.
DETROIT, July 14 -- Retail automobile sales dipped sharply during the first ten days of July.

NEW DELHI, India, July 14 -- Considerable differences in outlook were evident today at the conclusion of three days of talks between Indian officials and Peter Thorneycroft, British Minister of Aviation, on the possibility of Britain's joining the European Common Market.
WASHINGTON, July 14 (AP) -- The United States satellite communication system should be open to all nations, Edward R. Murrow said today.

THE Greeks were probably the first to savor the tart taste of fresh currants. Even today the Corinthian peninsula produces more currants than any other area in the world. But Greek currants come here only in dried form.

TRENTON, July 14 (AP) -- The New Jersey Supreme Court ruled today that a municipality cannot change its street construction standards on a housing developer after it has given final approval to a development.
ATLANTA, July 14 -- Southern Governors are scheduled to meet on Wednesday in Jackson, Miss., to discuss Federal-state relations. They may also air grievances against the Kennedy Administration.
BAGHDAD, Iraq, July 14 -- "You British, get out of our land!" Premier Abdul Karim Kassim shouted tonight.
Rocky Fumerelle of Buffalo and Don Fullmer of West Jordan, Utah, are rated even for their ten-round middleweight fight at Madison Square Garden tonight.
SPRING LAKE, N.J., July 14 -- Both the Democratic and Republican candidates for Governor took sharp issue with Gov. Robert B. Meyner today over the plan for a jetport in North Jersey.

MOSCOW, July 14 (UPI) -- The United States' chances of a third straight track and field victory over the Soviet Union were jeopardized today. The American mile champion, Dyrol Burleson, and the high-jump star, John Thomas, became doubtful starters in the two-day meet opening tomorrow.

ROYAL OAK, Mich., July 14 (UPI) -- Dick Sikes, the medalist, and John Molenda, both college students, won 36-hole matches today at Rackham to advance into tomorrow's final of the United States public links championship.
HYANNIS PORT, Mass., July 14 (UPI) -- President Kennedy issued a "captive nations week" proclamation tonight similar to one that irked Soviet Premier Khrushchev in 1959.
WASHINGTON, July 14 -- Work stoppages on the nation's missile bases have all but ended during the last two months as a result of recent Government, union, and management efforts.

WASHINGTON, July 13 -- Destroyers tying up at a new Navy pier at Galveston, Tex., will have to generate their own electricity unless a local utility agrees to sign a Federal supply contract containing an anti-discrimination clause.

Dr. John J. Theobald had a boat built for himself (in his brother-in-law's name) by a Brooklyn vocational high school class. Apparently, Mayor Wagner smells another rat, even if he doesn't see one, since he has ordered his Commissioner of Investigation to look into this matter affecting his seagoing Superintendent of Schools.
MONTGOMERY, Ala., July 14 (UPI) -- The Alabama House of Representatives approved today a bill establishing a state Un-American Activities Committee.
MENDHAM, N.J. July 14 -- The hunt is on for a black bear that has been reported roaming near this little Morris County community for a week.

LONDON, July 14 (UPI) -- John Lawlor of Ireland, a student at Boston University, won the hammer throw in the British Amateur Athletic Association track and field championships today with a heave of 201 feet 4 1/2 inches.

This has been a good week for that dedicated "New Breed" -- America's missile men. United States earth satellites Nos. 44 and 45, both of them of enormous potential significance to the future of life on earth, were catapulted into orbit from opposite sides of the continent. This was the first time a successful double launching has occurred on the same day.
The State Supreme Court has issued a broad injunction against the James Scott Hosiery Company, Inc., and others, forbidding their use of the James Scott name in business.
WASHINGTON, July 14 -- The United States has proposed in a confidential document to eighteen Latin-American Governments that they sign an "accord for the establishment of the Alliance for Progress."

ROMAN patricians were not satisfied with the election of a peasant's son as Pope in 1958. Shortly after Angelo Giuseppe Cardinal Roncalli became Pope John XXIII, as the story is told in the Vatican, the new Pontiff passed some stern-set women in black mantillas as he was walking on the grounds.

HELSINKI, Finland, July 14 -- The Governor of Lapland, Martti J. Miettunen, was nominated tonight as Premier of a new Agrarian minority Government. It will replace Vieno J. Sukselainen's Agrarian Government that resigned July 3.
Twenty-six men and seven brokerage corporations were indicted here yesterday on charges of conspiring to defraud the public in the sale of 575,000 shares of United Dye Chemical Corporation stock.
CHICAGO, July 14 -- Juan Pizarro of the White Sox stopped the Yankees, 6 -- 1, on seven hits tonight before a raucous crowd of 43,450 at Comisky Park.

OTTAWA, July 14 (Reuters) -- a British-Canadian communique said tonight that Canadian officials had expressed "grave concern" over the implications of possible negotiations for Britain's entry into the European Common Market.
WASHINGTON, July 14 -- Recovery from the recession is continuing, fresh Federal Reserve System data showed today.
CINCINNATI, July 14 (AP) -- The seventh-place Chicago Cubs regained their mastery over the league-leading Cincinnati Reds tonight, winning, 8 -- 7, with a run in the tenth inning.

DETROIT, July 14 (AP) -- A petition asking that a temporary injunction be issued to bar Vickers, Inc., from moving its operations to plants in other states was denied today by United States District Judge Fred W. Kaess.
Chas. Pfizer Co., Inc., has signed a contract to acquire the New England Lime Company in exchange for about 300,000 shares of Pfizer common stock.
LONDON, July 14 -- United States shipping practices were denounced last night in the House of Commons.

General Douglas MacArthur is home again after a twelve-day trip to the Philippines. This journey, in his eighty-first year, must have warmed his heart. When after nearly two decades 2,000,000 persons turn out to greet a man, their enthusiasm bespeaks sincerity -- and means more than any decoration.
WASHINGTON, July 14 -- President Kennedy dismayed some protectionist interests today by appointing Ben David Dorfman of Washington as a member of the United States Tariff Commission.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 14 (AP) -- Roberto Clemente hit Pittsburgh's first grand-slam homer of the year tonight in the eighth inning and gave the Pirates a 6-4 victory over the Giants.

An unidentified bail bondsman was one of many persons who went to the aid yesterday of a man who tried to hold up a savings and loan association Thursday to get money to pay his son's overdue college tuition.

DETROIT, July 14 -- A vice president of the General Motors Corporation said today that the 1961 contract demands of the United Automobile Workers represented "the most expensive economic package" submitted to the corporation in twenty-five years of bargaining with the union.

Shipments of domestic refined copper to industrial users in this country in June aggregated 139,700 tons. This was 7,853 tons more than in May, the top volume for any month since June, 1959, when 150,117 tons were shipped.
ATLANTIC CITY, July 14 -- Fifty-six planes in the Powder Puff Derby crossed the finish line here by the 1 P.M. deadline today in the weather-plagued transcontinental air race for women.

The State Supreme Court yesterday ordered the withdrawal of a show-cause order sought by the Wilson Lines to restrain permanently Local 333 of the National Maritime Union from picketing the company's two excursion boats. They run to Atlantic Highlands, N.J., and Rye, N.Y.
Blood will be given Monday to the Red Cross at the House of Detention for Men, 125 White Street.

WEST ORANGE, N.J., July 14 -- Mrs. William Tracy of Essex Falls, a housewife who playedas if anxious to return home to her two young daughters as quickly possible, captured the Garden State Women's Golf Association title today.
NEWTON, Iowa, July 14 (UPI) -- A survivor of the United Air Lines jet airliner crash that killed seventeen persons at Denver Tuesday attacked today the conduct of the plane's crew.

TORONTO, July 14 (Canadian Press) -- Earnings of the Mexican Light and Power Company, Ltd., down considerably this year because of low rainfall and other factors, are expected to improve in the third quarter, it was stated today at the concern's annual meeting.

WASHINGTON, July 14 (AP) -- The Department of Justice said today it had not decided what position it would take on proposals for legislation to ease the tax liabilities growing out of forced stock sales under antitrust decrees.

In all the years of American political history there has hardly been a more exciting one than that of 1924. That was the year in which it took the convening Demcrats 103 ballots to select a candidate for the Presidency of the United States.
WASHINGTON, July 14 (AP) -- Bernard Goldfine asked the Government today for an immediate hearing on his income tax case.

CHICAGO, July 14 (UPI) -- A study of ninety-four cases of nonfatal aspirin poisoning among juveniles indicated that all but one of the children had been told the medication was candy, a Boston physician reported today.
ROME, July 14 -- Pope John XXIII appealed in an encyclical today for aid to under-developed areas without the creation of a "new form of colonialism" or the spread of the materialistic "poison."
PARIS, July 14 -- Allied military planners are considering proposing an East-West agreement to avoid nuclear attacks on cities and population centers in another war.
