New Yorkers can get bargains in merchandise and services at most of the city's vocational high schools if they are willing to take a few risks.
ROME, July 14 -- Today's social encyclical by Pope John XXIII will be known as "Mater et Magistra" after the opening words of the Latin text.
A key witness in the Queens tow-truck racket inquiry charged yesterday that "the police are paid off every time an accident requiring a tow-truck occurs in this city."
ALBANY, July 14 -- A 27-year-old Albany clergyman who is an enrolled Democrat will run on a Republican ticket against Democratic Mayor Erastus Corning 2d next fall.
ROME, July 21 -- Following, as made public today, is the text of the unofficial English translation from the Latin of Pope John XXIII's encyclical:
The Ideal Cement Company had slight gains in sales and earnings in the quarter and six months ended on June 30 over the similar periods last year, the semi-annual report disclosed yesterday.
The Freedom party announced yesterday that it "definitely" would be on the citywide ballot this fall as an independent labor political organization.
WASHINGTON, July 14 (AP) -- Senators and spokesmen for private agencies appealed to Congress "in the name of decency" today to open the country to more refugess from despotism.
CAPE CANAVERAL, FLA., July 14 (AP) -- Two finely tuned astronauts intensified preparation today for a rocket flight that will send one of them briefly into space next week.

Conservationists, bird lovers and sportsmen the length of the Atlantic Coast should be alerted to the grave danger threatening the magnificent flights of migratory waterfowl using the Atlantic flyway. This flyway is like a funnel with its mouth spreading across the Canadian provinces.

WASHINGTON, July 14 -- Scientists at the Rutgers University Institute of Microbiology have patented a new antibiotic called candicidin, which is effective against fungus diseases of plants and humans. A spokesman termed it of "substantial significance."
The investment community looked over yesterday the wares shown by the Treasury in its $16,000,000,000 financing and decided it liked what was being offered.
WASHINGTON, July 14 -- The Senate Foreign Relations Committee decided today to go into day and night sessions next to speed consideration of President Kennedy's long-range foreign aid program.

CIUDAD TRUJILLO, Dominican Republic, July 14 (AP) -- Former Defense Minister Jose Rene Roman Fernandez has been sentenced to thirty years in prison for complicity in the assassination of Generalissimo Rafael Leonidas Trujillo Molina.
NEWBURGH, July 14 -- Five investigators from the State Department of Social Welfare moved in on the Newburgh Welfare Office today and began checking relief records.

Dr. Robert Soblen, convicted on Thursday as a spy for the Soviet Union, was warned yesterday that he would be punished severely unless he cooperated in tracking down other agents of Moscow in this country.

WASHINGTON, July 14 -- The Government of South Africa has told the United States that a proposed visit by G. Mennen Williams, Assistant Secretary of State for African Affairs, would not be "convenient'' at this time.
After five days of successive declines, the stock market staged a rally yesterday, moving briskly upward from a somewhat lower opening.

DETROIT, July 14 (AP) -- United States auto makers, in a final surge of 1961 model production, turned out 127,005 units this week, an increase of 47.9 per cent from the preceding holiday week's level, Ward's Automotive Reports said today.
BOSTON, July 14 (UPI) -- Dick Williams hit a three-run ninth-inning homer tonight to give the Baltimore Orioles a 7-6 victory over the Boston Red Sox.

WASHINGTON, July 14 -- Tax withholding on dividends and interest was approved by the House Ways and Means Committee today in a move to stop leakage of about $500,000,000 a year in income tax revenues.
PHILADELPHIA, July 14 -- Representative Adam Clayton Powell Jr. served notice tonight that he would block any legislation aiding craft unions that practiced discrimination against Negroes.

CHICAGO, July 14 (UPI) -- The Chicago, Milwaukee, St. Paul and Pacific Railroad will oppose the Atchison, Topeka and Santa Fe Railway Company in its plan to acquire control of the Western Pacific Railroad, it was announced yesterday.

It may be injudicious of me to exclaim "O tempora, O mores" after that laudable reference in the Topics column of June 24 to the Latin Festival June 9 at Hicksville, L.I., of which I was director, and after its sequitur commending the study of Latin and Greek, with which I concur in toto.

LOS ANGELES, July 14 (AP) -- Don Demeter, a former Dodger, singled home the winning run tonight as the Philadelphia Phillies ended an eight-game losing streak by defeating Los Angeles, 7 -- 5, in ten innings.

ROME, July 13 -- As the important Italian designers prepare to show their fall collections in Florence, the biggest news of the Alta Moda is that Capucci is deserting Italy after showing his current collection in Florence, beginning Tuesday.

WASHINGTON, July 14 -- The Senate approved and sent to the White House today a $570,000,000 Federal program to expand and strengthen the control of water pollution throughout the country. A voice vote completed the Congressional action. The House acted yesterday.

ONE of the biggest aids to easy living this season of the year is a wardrobe of bags and carry-alls for a variety of occasions -- week-ends in the country, overnight jaunts into the suburbs or picnics at the beach.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., July 14. -- Sam Nield, a former Rhode Island amateur champion, and Bob Wilke of Winged Foot eliminated Deane Beman, the United States Amateur titleholder, and Bill Buppert of Bethesda, Md., today in the Anderson Memorial golf tournament.
MASSENA, N.Y., July 14 -- The State Council of Parks moved today to acquire the old Schoellkopf hydroelectric power plant in Niagara Falls, N.Y.

Commodity futures, except those in wool, closed irregularly yesterday in generally dull trading on the New York exchanges. Most of the volume involved evening of holdings prior to the week-end. Potatoes and sugar rose; wool and cottonseed oil declined, and price improvements for coffee, cocoa, copper, lead, hides and rubber were mixed.

Globemaster, whom Leonard P. Sasso bought as a yearling for $80,000 at the Saratoga Sales, will be the favorite in today's Dwyer Handicap for 3-year-olds at Aqueduct. The son of Heliopolis has won $309,731 in his twenty-one starts.

Headed by two $100,000 added handicaps and the $85,850 Dwyer, thoroughbred racing will have one of the summer's richest programs today. The top-money events are the $162,100 Hollywood Gold Cup at Inglewood, Calif., and the $112,300 Monmouth Park Handicap at Oceanport, N.J. The Dwyer Handicap will be run at Aqueduct.

WASHINGTON, July 14 -- West Germany's Defense Minister, Franz Josef Strauss, and Secretary of Defense Robert S. McNamara affirmed in a brief statement today their support of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization and "the need for Western solidarity in the face of the growing Soviet threat to Berlin."

A structural steel worker was killed yesterday morning when he was struck by a 500-pound iron weight ball while working on the steel skeleton for the fifty-nine story Pan Am Building adjoining Grand Central Terminal.
The demolition of sheds on three East River piers and one Hudson River pier will start Monday, the Department of Marine and Aviation announced yesterday.
SAN DIEGO, Calif., July 14 (AP) -- "In the whole city of San Diego, only five flags were flying on the Fourth of July," Arthur Godfrey said on his morning radio show today.

One man and a computer regularly keep tabs on the ups and downs of 1,108 common stocks on the New York Stock Exchange -- practically the entire list. The man is Harold Clayton of Hemphill, Noyes Co., a large brokerage concern.
THE South player in this deal was criticized for a play that cost his contract.

ROME, July 14 -- Roman Catholic sociologists here said that the encyclical issued today was a recodification of church teachings on social and economic questions rather than an enunciation of new concepts.
WASHINGTON, July 14 (AP) -- Following is the text of a statement by Secretary of State Dean Rusk on the United Nations:
An official of Hellenic Lines, Ltd., which has three ships immobilized here in a strike of the company's office workers, said yesterday that figures released by the union on its demands were too low.
GREENWICH, Conn., July 14 -- The Indian Harbor Yacht Club cruise, an annual three-day adventure on Long Island Sound, began today with a race from Captain Harbor to Cockenoe Island Harbor.
WASHINGTON, July 14 (AP) -- Senator Clair Engle said today that he had asked a Senate Commerce subcommittee to investigate the lack of laws covering crimes committed on airliners.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., July 14 -- Thomas A. Calandrillo, Suffolk County Commissioner of Jurors, pleaded guilty here today to perjury in the second degree. He had been accused of changing seven Civil Service police examinations four years ago.

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), July 14 -- Adolf Eichmann admitted today that he had deceived the Nazi Foreign Ministry on the extent of the deportations and killing of Jews rounded up in Nazi-occupied and satellite countries.
HONOLULU, July 14 (UPI) -- Sirius II logged 226 miles during the past twenty-four hours to regain the lead from Ticonderoga today in the trans-Pacific yacht race.

WINNIPEG, July 14 (AP) -- The Cupit brothers, Jacky and Buster, riddled the rain-drenched Niakwa Country Club Course with fine rounds today to pace the field in the Canadian open golf championship after fifty-four holes.

ST. LOUIS, July 14 (UPI) -- The United States Davis Cup team today scored two victories over Ecuador in the first day's singles matches. Bernard (Tut) Bartzen stopped Eduardo Zuleta, 6 -- 0, 6 -- 1, 6 -- 1, and Chuck McKinley, having a little more trouble with Miguel Olvera and a headache, won his match, 6 -- 4, 1 -- 6, 6 -- 4, 6 -- 2.
CHICAGO, July 14 -- Roving gangs of Negro youths beat nine whites in six separate incidents today. Sixty-four youths were arrested in connection with the assaults.

ELIZABETH, N.J., July 14 -- A Westfield couple who charged a Newark hospital and a Westfield physician with malpractice involving their invalid child were awarded $250,000 by a Union County jury here yesterday.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 14 -- Alan S. Boyd. chairman of the Civil Aeronautics Board, warned here today that this country would have to take "drastic action" to help United States airlines cope with the "excessive services" offered by foreign air carriers.

Shipments of acetate filament produced by domestic producers of man-made fibers in June came to 20,800,000 pounds reflecting a slight decline from the May level, the Textile Economics Bureau, Inc., reported yesterday.

SEOUL, Korea, July 14 (UP) -- Maj. Gen. Yoo Yang Soo, who headed a South Korean goodwill mission to Washington, said today that the United States Government had assured him of support for his country's military regime.
Two 500-year trusts have been declared tax exempt by the United States Court of Appeals despite a Federal protest that they could ultimately shatter the nation's financial structure.
PARIS, July 14 -- The French turned out by the tens of thousands in France and stayed home by the tens of thousands in Algeria for the traditional Bastille Day military parades today.
WASHINGTON, July 14 -- United States sources indicated today that President Kennedy had declined to take an active role in settling Pakistan's dispute with India over Kashmir.

HARTSDALE, N.Y., July 14 -- Joanne Swanson of Pawtucket, R.I., No. 2 in the draw, defeated Nadine Netter of Scarsdale, the favorite, 6 -- 4, 6 -- 2, today, and won the New York State girls' tennis championship at the County Tennis Club of Westchester.

WASHINGTON, July 14 -- Senator Barry Goldwater charged the Kennedy Administration today with supporting a foreign policy of "drifting," "inaction" and purposeless spending for "outmoded, weak-kneed" objectives.
LONDON, July 14 -- Maj. Yuri A. Gagarin, the first man to enter space, sat at the right of Queen Elizabeth II today at a luncheon in Buckingham Palace.

Investors who have contracted to buy fourteen properties from the Rhinelander Real Estates Company are offering to sell the parcels for $8,750,000. The properties include The New York World-Telegram and Sun building and Loew's Sheridan Square Theatre.

WASHINGTON, July 14 (AP) -- The Senate passed today 79 to 5 a bill aimed at increasing the exchange of students, teachers, actors, artists and athletes between the United States and other lands. The bill now goes to the House.

WASHINGTON, July 14 -- Average wholesale prices moved up 0.1 per cent in the primary markets in the week ended last Tuesday, reaching 119 per cent of their 1947-49 base, the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today.

PARIS, July 14 -- For swagger, audacity and ardor, the French Army is the finest in the West. Parisians who watched it parade down the Champs Elysees on this Bastille Day took pride in the reminder of splendid military traditions. Nevertheless, fanfare, drum rattles and the quick-stepping march could not entirely obscure the fact that France's Army is a bitterly divided force whose future is an uncertain factor in this country's destiny.

DETROIT, July 14 (UPI) -- Two men from Westchester County, N.Y., were free on bond today awaiting sentencing on eleven counts of mail fraud in the sale of a device they said would increase gasoline mileage for motorists.
John M. Leavens, executive director of the Citizens Budget Commission, yesterday criticized the capital budget recommendation of the Mayor's Charter Revision Commission.
TALLADEGA, Ala., July 14 (AP) -- A grand jury here yesterday recommended the death penalty for flogging. It also returned thirty-seven indictments on charges of night riding.

BIJAPUR, India, July 14 (Reuters) -- The death toll in floods ravaging Southern India shot up to 165 today when news reached here of the death of fifty persons in a ferryboat disaster. District officials said that the ferry capsized yesterday while crossing the swollen Krishna River, about sixty miles from here.
HYANNIS PORT, July 14 -- With President Kennedy as he arrived here today aboard Air Force One, his 707 jet plane, were three of his highest assistants.

For centuries there have been occasional waves of migration: the so-called barbarians into the old Roman Empire, voluntary movements of Europeans across the ocean into the Western Hemisphere, and, in our own day, displacements of millions of persons from the homes they loved.

The Republic Natural Gas Company of Dallas, Texas, a producer of natural gas and crude oil, announced yesterday that it was considering the sale of its assets for $150,000,000. Socony Mobil Oil Company, Inc., has proposed to acquire the assets of Republic, subject to the reservation and sale by Republic to third parties of oil and gas payments of $110,000,000.

This country's ability to meet the threat of world conditions and stay free depends on labor-management relations as much as on any other faetor in our national life, according to R. Conrad Cooper, executive vice president for personnel services, United States Steel Corporation.

The Federal suit instituted by Radio Station WMCA to require a more equitable apportionment of seats in the New York Legislature reflects the growing concern in the nation over the under-representation of the city dweller.
Cotton futures were unchanged to 25 cents a bale up yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange.
ORANGE, N.J., July 14 -- Fifty commuters found themselves in the middle of the tracks this morning with an express thundering down on them. All scrambled to safety.
TUNIS, July 14 -- President Habib Bourguiba said today that the struggle for evacuation of French troops from Tunisia would not halt until the last French soldier had left.

MOSCOW, July 14 -- Soviet armed forces are undergoing a radical reorganization, with special emphasis on the equipment of all units with rocket weapons and the formation of small independent nuclear detachments.
Politics in Richmond boiled over yesterday in the wake of the decision of the Democratic County Committee to reject Surrogate John C. Boylan for re-election.

A contract under which the Federal Government will build and the city will operate an ultra high frequency television station was signed at City Hall yesterday by Mayor Wagner and Robert E. Lee, a member of the Federal Communications Commission.
STINNETT, Tex., July 14 -- A District Court jury ordered a labor union today to pay $1,197,072 to twenty-eight of its members who had been dismissed by an oil refinery.

BOND, Colo., July 14 (AP) -- A gunman sought as the killer of a highway patrol lieutenant and an under sheriff was captured today after eluding posses in rugged mountain country for forty-eight hours.
WASHINGTON, July 14 (AP) -- The Kansas City Athletics scored seventeen runs on twenty-five hits tonight and won a double-header from the Washington Senators.
Five men were arrested in a midtown hotel yesterday and charged with possessing $45,000 in stolen securities.
CHICAGO, July 14 (AP) -- Heavy selling beat July soybean futures down sharply today on the Board of Trade, but activity in all other contracts was moderate and net changes generally were small.
When television's top paid performers do their summer disappearing act from home screens, much of the medium's fresh talent is scouted from among the public figures of the day.
GENEVA, July 14 -- V.K. Krishna Menon of India presented today a fifteen-point proposal on controls to guarantee the projected international pledge to respect the neutrality and independence of Laos.

BONN, Germany, July 14 -- West Germany's Farmers Association, aware of its voting potential in this fall's general elections, angrily told the Government today that it wanted a bigger slice of the country's riches.
DETROIT, July 14 (AP) -- Jack Kralick of the Minnesota Twins stopped the Detroit Tigers tonight, 5 -- 2, before 30,999 fans.
WASHINGTON, July 14 (AP) -- The Tiros III satellite -- a hurricane hunter -- took a second photograph of a developing storm in the Atlantic today and relayed the picture to earth.

SHREVEPORT, La., July 14 (AP) -- Four Freedom Riders -- two Negroes and two whites -- arrived here today at a bus station sealed off by the police. They departed to the homes of friends without trying to test segregation facilities.
ST. LOUIS, July 14 (UPI) -- Carl Sawatski's ninth-inning home run to the right-field pavillion gave the St. Louis Cardinals and Lindy McDaniel a 2-1 victory over the Milwaukee Braves tonight.
HAMILTON, N.Y., July 14 (UPI) -- The United States is mistaken if it believes it can defeat a Communist menace by force, Norman Thomas said today.
Burton N. Pugach, a disbarred lawyer, was convicted last night of arranging to have lye thrown in the face of his former fiance.

Members of the Museum of the City of New York already have started making reservations for themselves and their guests for the first ball to be held in the museum at Fifth Avenue and 103d Street. The event will be on Nov. 1.
All active production drawings are being converted into microfilm aperture cards in a drive to conserve time, money and space at major installations of the Air Force Logistics Command.

NEW HAVEN, July 14 -- A Federal court here today set July 25 instead of Aug. 1 as the date to appoint trustees to reorganize the New Haven Railroad. Aug. 1 had been set when the railroad filed an application July 6 for reorganization under the Bankruptcy Act.
"NOBODY KNOWS MY NAME,"* by James Baldwin, is a collection of strikingly clear and eloquent essays on what it means to be a writer, an American, a Negro, in this all but incredible century.
The National Mediation Board sought yesterday to revive stalled negotiations between Pan American World Airways and its flight engineers and avert a possible strike against the airline next week.
Thirty short films in 16-mm. have been made available for rental by Cinema 16 at 175 Lexington Avenue.

A study of present problems of the United States has been made by Bert Cochran, a researcher and free-lance journalist. In his book, called "The Cross of the Moment," the author asks who will lead the world -- the United States or the Soviet Union.
GREENWICH, Conn., July 14 -- This town backed down today from its announced intention of condemning a sizable portion of a family homestead for park purposes.

PURCHASE, N.Y., July 14 -- The semi-finals of the women's Eastern clay courts tennis championship were interrupted by threatening weather late this afternoon at Century Country Club. Light rain fell and it became so overcast that there was little visibility ill the premature darkness caused by storm clouds.

The American Motors Sales Corporation of Detroit has leased 33,000 square feet of space in a one-story building under construction at 55-04 Fifty-eighth Street, Maspeth, Queens. The concern will occupy the quarters in September for the sale and distribution of automobile parts. The lease was negotiated by Louis Carreau Jr. of Louis Carreau, Inc., broker, for H.B. Mack and Soloman Heiferman, builders and owners of the structure.

Five candidates for Mayor denounced yesterday the Board of Elections' decision to use paper ballots instead of voting machines in the primary election Sept. 7. But they disagreed sharply on who was to blame.
DES MOINES, July 14 (UPI) -- Union workers at a Des Moines soybean processing plant were told today they must be clean-shaven.

WASHINGTON, July 14 (AP) -- The Senate took back today a drought relief measure it had passed Wednesday, amended it and then passed it on voice vote after a two-hour debate. The measure now goes to the House.
LONDON, July 14 -- Industrial shares again declined on the stock market here today, although net losses were generally smaller than yesterday's.

INGLEWOOD, Calif., July 15 -- Prince Blessed, running in the Kelly green silks of the Kerr Stables, captured the twenty-second running of the $162,100 Hollywood Gold Cup Handicap today and his stablemate Grey Eagle held on for second place in a rousing finish.
Murray D. Lincoln, president of Nationwide Corporation, Columbus, Ohio, is a big man who thinks big.

WASHINGTON, July 15 -- Joseph McD. Mitchell, city manager of Newburgh, N.Y., said today that he would expand his plan to reduce the city's welfare rolls. He said that he was determined to fight for the controversial thirteen-point plan to stem the increase in what the city spends for welfare aid.
MAMARONECK, N.Y., July 15 -- Despite thunderstorms and a rain squall, the semi-finals in the Anderson Memorial golf tournament were completed today at the Winged Foot Golf Club.
BOSTON, July 15 -- Congress granted Massachusetts temporary relief this week from a situation that threatened to cost the Commonwealth $51,000,000 in highway funds.

ABOARD two square-rigged, eighteenth-century sailing ships bobbing off Alicante, Spain, Herman Melville's "Billy Budd" is finally facing the movie cameras, piloted by scenarist-actor-director Peter Ustinov. Last week, with the location scenes nearing conclusion, the multi-faceted Mr. Ustinov (seen facing camera above, between actors John Neville and Paul Rogers) was preparing to move to London's Elstree Studios for six weeks of interiors, after a month of work under ideal, briny conditions.

MOSCOW, July 15 -- Wilma Rudolph, Frank Budd and Paul Drayton helped America's sprinters set two world records and tie one today on the first day of the United States-Soviet Union track and field meet. A crowd of 70,000 looked on at Lenin Stadium.
Columbia University yesterday put on display hitherto secret documents relating to the historic Manhattan Project that developed the atomic bomb in World War II.

SALT LAKE CITY, July 15 -- Proposals for a new national park "will be opposed to the last ditch" if such plans threaten southern Utah's livestock industry, Gov. George Dewey Clyde, a Republican, made clear today.

The picture story on Greenland ("Land of White Summer," July 2) made good reading on a hot day, with its photographs of ice-capped mountains, glaciers and icebergs. But I wonder if your readers are aware that this forbidding land is inhabited by a people who have advanced from a primitive, savage culture into a modern world in a relatively brief span of time?
Queens gained 40,300 new residents in the year since the 1960 United States census was taken, Ira H. Genet, president of the Queens Chamber of Commerce, said yesterday.
Mayor Wagner accused his former ally, Joseph T. Sharkey, yesterday of attempting to use the appointment of judges for political advantage.

About 8,000 letters were mailed yesterday from a Queens post office to President Kennedy and other political figures protesting the noise of low-flying planes approaching and leaving La Guardia Airport.

QUOGUE, L.I. -- By turning south just after crossing the Quantuck Creek bridge on Montauk Highway (State Route 27), the motorist visiting the eastern tip of Long Island need drive only a short distance to find himself in one of the most delightful country villages in the region.
RIVERHEAD, L.I., July 15 -- Suffolk County's recently adopted Dutch elm disease control program claimed two 100-year-old elms in front of the county courthouse here this week.
WESTBURY, L.I., July 15 -- If Yonkers Raceway acquires an option to buy Roosevelt Raceway, the two tracks are expected to seek concurrent harness-racing meets in 1962.
TAIPEI, Taiwan, July 15 -- Taiwan exported last month a record $20,700,000 worth of products, the Nationalist Foreign Exchange and Trade Control Commission announced today.

WASHINGTON, July 15 (AP) -- A New York Congressman who wants the United States to declare war against communism warned the Soviet Union's leaders today against expecting a peaceful victory in their struggle with the non-Communist world.

EVER since that memorable night in June of 1918 when America's first outdoor symphonic concert was given in the newly built athletic arena on the campus of New York's City College, music for me has been largely a matter of blood, sweat and rain.

THE country fair season will get under way in earnest this week. Approximately a dozen fairs are scheduled in several states in the Northeast, from Maine to Maryland. The places and dates if the almost 300 fairs announced thus far for the current season include:

ST. LOUIS, July 15 (UPI) -- Chuck McKinley and Dennis Ralston, the United States' promising young doubles team, scored a 6-1, 6-2, 7-5 victory over Miguel Olvera and Eduardo Zuleta today to beat Ecuador in the second round of American Zone Davis Cup play.

There are hints in Mr. Khrushchev's speech that * * * the advanced rockets of which they were so confident in the past may impose a harsh choice too soon in any crisis. Behind the retort to the United States there is therefore a shift in Russian military thinking.
AS a citizen, an Air Force officer and information specialist -- and in that order -- I read Mr. Nielsen's article with considerable interest.

THE Federal Communications Commission is bustin' out all over. With the radio and television industries enjoying their usual summer lull, the perky regulatory agency persists in making the major news of the summer.

Rubberized fabric storage tanks designed to hold 65,000 gallons of liquid are being produced for the Air Force by the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company. The tanks will help to provide winter water requirements for soldiers in the far north.

ONCE again the season of the anti-sociologists is upon us. The academic year has ended and professors are ready to turn from talking to writing. A self-selected few will dust off and publish yet again the litany that fiercely imprecates sociology and all its works. This year, the avowed conservative professor of political science, Russell Kirk, got in first.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., July 12 -- To shave, or not to shave: that is the question facing some of the eighty Peace Corps volunteers training at Rutgers University for two years of work in primitive Colombian villages.
Retirement is being made less painful for employes of some companies who follow a program of gradually retiring their workers rather than abruptly ending their services at a fixed age.
WASHINGTON, July 15 -- The countdown will begin on Monday for the United States' second venture at manned flight into space.
More than 500 Orthodox rabbis will fly to Israel this week to attend the first religious convocation ever to be held in that country by an American rabbinic body.

WASHINGTON, July 15 -- Six weeks of Mr. Khrushchev's six months war of nerves on Berlin have now passed. This week, as Mr. K appeared to beat his shoe with increased stridency, the nerves of the Kennedy Administration seemed remarkably unfrayed.

IT would be hard to find a more lucid view of the Algerian problem than this book provides. Germaine Tillion is an ethnologist who came to know and understand the Algerian Moslems back in 1934, when she began to study the somewhat fierce species that exists in the wild Aures Mountains in the east.

DURING the recent Federal Communications Commission investigation of television programing held in New York's Federal Court House, one of the busiest reporters on the scene was Thomas H. Cowan.

The first of a series of static test firings of the complete F-1 rocket engine, the largest in the free world, has attained a thrust of more than a million pounds, it was announced last week by the National Aeronautics and Space Administration.
The Port of New York Authority is approaching the halfway mark in a multi-purpose $400,000,000 marine terminal development program.

TEL, AVIV, Israel, July 15 -- Two bus passengers were injured in Perusalem this evening when Jewish religious zealots barricaded the roads leading to the ultra Orthodox Mea Shearim quarter and stoned buses that tried to enter.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., July 15 -- Easterner, Chandler Hovey's improving 12-Meter yacht, beat Henry Mercer's Weatherly and Paul Shields' Columbia in that order in the dismal weather that began the Larchmont Yacht Club's sixty-third annual Race Week today.

A small ceremony, to be held today at Oxford, England, commemorates a landmark in man's eternal striving for knowledge. On July 16, 1476, in a small shop in Oxford within the glistening spires of the young university, a printer named William Caxton prepared to hand-crank the first crude printing press in the English-speaking world.

BILLY WILDER, producer-director, strode out of his Hilton headquarters here the other day, took a quick look up at the clearing skies and said, in his nervous, impatient way: "Okay. Get your steel helmets, everybody. We're going back to the Gate."
MOSCOW, July 15 (AP) -- Soviet track and field officials were disappointed at the size of the crowd for the start of the United States-Soviet track and field meet.

PARIS during the expatriate decade after World War I is hardly unexplored literary territory. Looming over everything like the Eiffel Tower is "The Sun Also Rises." And on the non-fiction shelf there are Elliot Paul's lyric and knowing "The Last Time I Saw Paris" and the middle sections of "Exile's Return" by Malcolm Cowley.

LONDON, July 15 (UPI) -- Hopes are fading that British steel makers can hit the target of 24,000,000 tons of raw steel this year. The order load has dwindled and deliveries in June were not matched by the flow of new orders, Metal Bulletin reported.

MOSCOW, July 1 -- Soviet women with ten or more children still receive the title Mother-Heroine and young girls still dream of becoming ballet stars. But the leading lady in the Soviet Union today is the worker in industry or agriculture.

Tammany's ability to swamp 'em and get the wampum in New York faces a major challenge this year in the most confused mayoralty race in recent history. There are six candidates for mayor, primary contests in all three major parties, and candidates for the second and third places on the tickets -- the presidency of City Council and the City Controllership -- many voters have never heard of.
WASHINGTON, July 15 -- Foreign Service officers abroad will soon have to justify their entertainment of foreign officials before getting an allowance to pay for it.
CHICAGO, July 15 -- Prisons are being penny wise and pound foolish in giving little or no money to convicts being freed, a prisoner welfare agency charged this week.
WINNIPEG, Man., July 15 (AP) -- Jacky Cupit, a rookie professional from Longview, Tex., shot a one-over-par 71 today and won the Canadian Open golf tournament with a 72-hole total of 270.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., July 15 -- The Bayside Power Squadron predicted-log, contest was won today by Rudolph Cubicciotti in his Junebug II with an accuracy score of 98.88 per cent. The thirty-one-mile contest was held in a downpour and on very heavy seas.
AS ruddy and as spritely as a gnome from the Black Forest in which he lives, Wolfgang Fortner bounced into town recently on his way up to his summer teaching assignment at Tanglewood.

Fifth district economists are cheered by the 1961 tobacco crop forecast of 1,978,000,000 pounds -- largest in five years. Estimated acreage of flue-cured plantings this season is greater than the crop harvested in 1960. June and early July weather has offset earlier weather setbacks that retarded plowing and transplanting.

IN a splendidly crisp, frugal but airways fluent narrative, Col. Netanel Lorch relates how Israel won her life with "The Edge of the Sword." It is an apt title for this masterly deployment of bare facts, devoid of speculative afterthoughts, almost devoid of comment, telling the miracle of a half-born infant chasing from its cot the five murderous adults.

SAN JOSE, Calif., July 11 -- A prototype of an electronic information-retrieving system being built for the Central Intelligence Agency was shown here this week by the International Business Machines Corporation.

Fur-trimmed coats and suits continued to lead the reordering lists for fall merchandise last week, although transitional cottons were still important at the retail level, according to reports from resident buying offices.
Five college players, who will represent the United States in the international students chess tournament in Helsinki, Finland, July 17 to 31, left Friday from New York International Airport.
Growing international tension cast a pall over the securities markets last week, inducing renewed caution on the part of investors and weakening prices until the late, brisk rally on Friday.
MIAMI BEACH, July 15 (AP) -- A blonde 24-year-old German girl won the title of Miss Universe tonight.
ROME, July 15 -- The Vatican restricted today the practice of psychoanalysis by or for churchmen.

GETTYSBURG, Pa., July 15 -- President Mohammad Ayub Khan of Pakistan visited former President Dwight D. Eisenhower at the latter's farm here today after a tour by helicopter of the Civil War battlefield.

LIKE the elderly gentleman in "Gigi" who thanked heaven for all little girls, we are thankful in particular for "Fanny," now on the Music Hall's screen -- and we mean, of course, the whole thing, not just Fanny, played by Leslie Caron.
The new 495-foot cargo ship Solon Turman is now taking on cargo at Southern ports before embarking on her maiden voyages in the Gulf-Mediterranean service of Lykes Bros. Steamship Company, Inc.
WARSAW, July 11 -- Stefan Cardinal Wyszynski was accused this week of trying to idenntify Poland's national existence with the fate of the Roman Catholic Church.
HYANNIS POINT, Mass. July 15 -- President Kennedy announced today a wide-ranging proposal to restore self-government to the District of Columbia.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 15 (AP) -- Jim Davenport and Jose Pagan collected three hits each today, helping Mike McCormick and the San Francisco Giants to a windswept 8-3 victory over the Pittsburgh Pirates.

THE recent resurgence of interest in the blues, a, resurgence that has apparently brought to an end that doleful period when capable blues singers either adapted to rock 'n' roll or were buried under the rock 'n' roll avalanche, has brought renewed attention to many of the bluesmen who were relatively well known in the Nineteen Thirties and Forties.
BOSTON, July 15 (UPI) -- Gene Conley pitched the Red Sox to a 2-1 victory over the Baltimore Orioles today to give Boston two victories in the three-game series.
Two precedents have been found for a recent proposal that bar associations run their own candidates for judgeships if the political parties fail to pick properly qualified nominees.

A group of 150 persons picketed The New York Times at 229 West Forty-third Street yesterday to protest the publication last June 22 of a paid advertisement by the national committee of the Communist Party, U.S.A.

NEW HAVEN, July 15 -- This city, with more than $200,000,000 in redevelopment and urban renewal projects completed, under way or in advanced planning stages, is forming a panel of outside experts to review and appraise the programs.
TOKYO, July 15 (AP) -- Communist China and North Korea asserted today that "the main danger to the present international Communist movement" is in the revisionism of Yugoslavia.

ART-FORGERY calls into question the whole of esthetic philosophy. If a Van Meegeren arranges paint and canvas in such a way that connoisseurs think they are looking at a Vermeer, has he created a work of art? If critics say that a new painting by an unknown is great, have they created a work of art?

THE question often arises as to whether there are national styles in performance as well as in composition. A century ago, the answer surely would have been in the affirmative. Today, however, when musicians circle the globe once or twice a year, and when recordings make audible in Melbourne, Australia, the sounds of music being performed in Montreal, one is not so sure.

HE met a fitting, if unfortunate, end; it would have been anti-climactic had Hemingway died in his bed. Death had grazed him often in the kind of life he lived; indeed, so great was death's fascination for him, that he seemed at times to seek it.

PARIS, July 15 -- A state of sadness, even depression, has settled over much of Western European opinion in the last two weeks, quite apart from the growing seriousness of the Berlin situation. The reason is that the exciting, hopeful trend in Britain toward a "plunge into Europe" appears to have received a major setback.

MOSCOW. July 15 -- Nothing has inspired a greater display of annoyance among Soviet leaders and their propagandists this week than charges in the West that Premier Khrushchev has uttered warlike threats over West Berlin.

The United States took two important steps last week in its program to develop satellites for practical uses. One was the orbiting Wednesday from Cape Canaveral, Fla., of Tiros III, a weather satellite equipped with two wide-angle television cameras to photograph and transmit pictures of cloud formations.

Scores of Polish nationals behind the Iron Curtain will receive more than $500,000 left to them by Brooklyn relatives and friends as a result of a decision handed down yesterday by Kings County Surrogate Maximilian Moss.
LAS VEGAS, Nev., July 15 (AP) -- Four men called to answer charges of racial discrimination in their downtown gambling casino refused to testify today.

PHILADELPHIA, July 15 -- The "Tomb of the Painted Glyphs," containing the headless remains of a male adult and two adolescent children, has been uncovered by archaeologists at the ancient city of Tikal, Guatemala.

WASHINGTON, July 15 (AP) -- The Atomic Energy Commission said today a flatcar derailed at Syracuse, N.Y., yesterday contained nuclear material but that the accident created no danger of radioactivity to those in the vicinity.
CHICAGO, July 15 (AP) -- Dodge Me and Miss Summer Time each won a division of the $20,000 added Princess Pat Stakes for 2-year-old fillies before 26,776 fans at Arlington Park today.

IN most major industries there is an attempt to make the most bothersome internal frictions the concealed part of the industry's iceberg. But in the movie business, the entire iceberg is constantly being pushed to the surface by almost interminable bickering. Next Wednesday an attempt will be made to thaw at least a small portion of the iceberg.

PHOTOGRAPHS will complement, rather than illustrate, the text in a college textbook on sociology now in preparation. This novel approach to a classroom text will be used in "Sociology: Human Behavior in a Changing World," the work of four authors, one of whom, a photographer, will select and arrange the pictures.
GARRISON, N.D., July 13 -- Towering purple-black clouds shoulder across the sky. The temperature drops below 70 degrees. The rain comes.

DJERBA -- This Island, which lies off the southeast coast of Tunisia, is one of sandy beaches, thousands of waving palm trees and constant sunshine. However, despite its South Pacific atmosphere, it has preserved the air of the Arabian nights.

It is evident that Waldemar A. Nielsen ("Huge, Hidden Impact of the Pentagon," June 25) is unhappy and uncomfortable -- as was President Eisenhower and as is President Kennedy -- with our large military establishment.

IN a short foreword, John Fischer, editor of Harper's magazine (where the articles that make up this book first appeared) points out that the "great debate" about American medicine is based on two facts which appear to be contradictory but which are accepted by most Americans: "(1) American medicine is now the best in the world. (2) Millions of people are bitterly dissatisfied with the medical care they are getting."
WHITE PLAINS, July 15 -- The New York Central Railroad has sold its busy Harlem Division passenger station here to private interests for commercial development. The price was not disclosed.

OCEANPORT, N.J., July 15 -- Gustave Ring's Don Poggio made a strong closing bid and won the $112,300 Monmouth Handicap by three and one-quarter lengths from J.J. Colando's Our Hope at Monmouth Park today.

Sunny skies and warmer than average temperatures in the early part of the past week helped retail sales in the New York area climb above last year's level. Gains in retail sales were 6 to 8 per cent compared with the 1960 week, it was estimated by officers of the area's leading department stores.

There can be nothing pleasing to Communist China in the partial Soviet-Yugoslav rapprochement announced in Moscow last week. The cordiality and warmth Soviet leaders from Premier Khrushchev down showed to visiting Yugoslav Foreign Minister Koca Popovic contrasted sharply with the "Hate Yugoslavia" propaganda that emanates regularly from Peiping.

A Lithuanian painter, who is scarcely known here but who occupies an important position in the advance guard of the abstract art movement, is being honored in a commemorative exhibition in the Slavonic Division of the New York Public Library, Fifth Avenue and Forty-Second Street.
Twenty-five state and Federal judges will go back to school tomorrow. They will attend two weeks of classes on judicial procedure at the New York University School of Law.

TO THE EDITOR: I FEEL that Erle Stanley Gardner may have missed a key portion of the foreword of my book "Ninth Life" and as a result fallen into error when he states that the authors considered the Los Angeles police to be "the bad guys" of the Chessman story because they would not turn records over to us bearing on the Chessman sex crimes.

BERLIN, July 15 -- Overt resistance to Communist farm collectivization and to the Soviet Union's threat of a separate peace treaty was again acknowledged today by Neues Deutschland, the East German party paper.
The Dukla soccer team of Prague will meet Espanol of Spain in the second game of an International Soccer League double-header at 4:30 P.M. today at the Polo Grounds.

THE "summer grasses" -- Zoysia japonica and its varieties plus Bermuda grasses -- are valuable for areas of the Northeast where a good turf is desirable from May through the first frost in fall. They are especially recommended for the geographic area extending southward from Philadelphia to Richmond, Va., and west to St. Louis and Omaha.
CINCINNATI, July 15 -- The Cincinnati Reds moved six games ahead of the Los Angeles Dodgers in the National League tonight as Joey Jay pitched them to a 2 -- 1 victory over the Chicago Cubs.

WESTBURY, L.I., July 15 -- Su Mac Lad, by the smallest of noses, outfinished Kracovie of France tonight and gave the United States its first victory in the $50,000 Roosevelt International Trot at Roosevelt Raceway.
NEWBURGH, N.Y., July 15. -- Newburgh's stringent new welfare code went into effect today in defiance of state authorities.

WASHINGTON, July 15 (AP) -- Senator Clifford P. Case, Republican of New Jersey, said today there appeared to be a conflict in Federal Aviation Agency views on the location of a proposed jet airport in New Jersey.

SALT LAKE CITY -- A new $4,500,000 airport is making this city an increasingly popular "port of entry" for vacationists bound for national parks and resorts in Utah and neighboring states. For the most part, the airborne tourists arrive here by jet and then proceed to their destinations by means of a feeder airline, such as Bonanza West Coast or Frontier.

OGDEN NASH, the Wizard of Words, has assembled a new collection of poems that he thinks "everybody ought to know." (Though that's not the only reason for his title, read his foreword and find out you won't regret it.)

BIRKDALE, England, July 15 -- Arnold Palmer won the British Open golf championship by a stroke today with one of his patented late surges and became the first American to win the title since Ben Hogan did it in 1953.

Seymour Peck's report that there is again a trend in Hollywood toward making musicals ("Again the Movies Sing and Dance." July 2) was good news to the many of us who cherish this kind of wonderful frivolity. But isn't there a small trend in reverse -- away from movies that sing and dance?

DESPITE Berlin and other crises, Fidel Castro Ruz is still a major concern for Washington, and the outlook is that he will remain so for an indefinite time. Therefore it is opportune to take a fresh look at the Cuban Premier -- the kind of man he is and how he has changed in his thirty months in power.
Nicholas Marotta, a bowler with the enthusiasm of an amateur and the sagacity of a professional business man, expects to make a strike in Italy in the near future.

GENEVA, July 15 -- George W. Ball, United States Under Secretary of State for Economic Affairs, met today in Bern with Friedrich Wahlen, Swiss President and Foreign Minister. and Halls Schaffner, Minister for Economic Affairs.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., July 15 -- School boards in eight Southern cities and counties have assigned almost 1,050 additional Negro children to biracial schools for the fall term, the Southern Education Reporting Service announced this week.

THE Long Island Arborists' Association will stage its fourth annual Field Day on Tuesday at the Bayard Cutting Arboretum, Great River, L.I. Registration for the program, which is open to the public, will start at 9:30 A.M.
DETROIT, July 15 (AP) -- Dick Sikes captured the United States public links championship today with a 4-and-3 triumph over John Molenda of Detroit.
ROME, July 15 -- Pope John XXIII gave a down-to-earth interpretation today of the social encyclical he issued yesterday.

MORE Americans, in and cut of college, are enjoying classical antiquity than ever before. The rescue of the period from relative obscurity has been led by the archaeologists and historians and finally, with the coming of a new generation able to see the forest as well as the trees, by the literary scholars.
NOTTINGHAM, England, July 15 (Reuters) -- The Australian cricketers sent in to bat by Nottinghamshire, scored 64 runs for one wicket as rain spoiled the opening day of their match today.
ATLANTA, July 15 (AP) -- Ty Cobb, the former baseball star who has been hospitalized several times in recent years, was reported in poor condition today in Emory University Hospital.

IN dealing with the Royal Danish Ballet (as these columns are doing these weeks in relation to its recent festival in Copenhagen), it is necessary to face the serious fact that this may well be the only company outside the Soviet Union (one might even say outside Leningrad) with a mature, reply rooted, flowering tradition, a live and functioning artistic "school."
Some $1,700,000,000 in "hot money" could play an important role in shaping the Federal Reserve's monetary policy as the recovery advances.

COOPERSTOWN, N.Y. -This secluded lakefront village in the highlands of central New York, whose population has remained constant at 2,500 for nearly a century, plays host to some 300,000 visitors a year.

WASHINGTON, July 15 (AP) Frederick Stueck, 55 years old, a member of the Federal Power Commission, was found dead in his automobile tonight with a hose connected to the exhaust pipe. Police detectives said it was a case of suicide.

AS home owners spend more and more time outdoors -- in the evening as well as during the day -- the problem of getting rid of flying insect pests becomes increasingly more difficult. The widespread use of bright lights on the terrace and in the garden serves to attract flying insects of all kinds.

PAMPLONA, Spain, July 14 -- Technically, the celebrated fiesta here ends Sunday, its eleventh day. Actually it began to collapse from exhaustion, too much red wine and too much violence some days ago. Eleven days is too long for a fiesta.
BOSTON, Mass., July 15 -- Forty high school students were selected this week as the entering class of Boston University's new six-year program of medical education.

PHILADELPHIA, July 15 (AP) -- Seymour Cromwell of The Riverside Boat Club of Boston won the United States singles sculls title today. The Detroit Boat Club took the lead for the Julius H. Barnes Club Trophy in the eighty-seventh national rowing championship.

PHILADELPHIA, July 15 -- The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, in the next to last day of its convention here, adopted resolutions today approving the techniques of sit-ins, Freedom Rides and boycotts.
More air travelers than ever before used the Port of New York Authority terminals last year and at the same time air cargo and airmail also reached new peaks.

WASHINGTON, July 15 -- The disclosure that the United States Army is below authorized strength has "shocked" the chairman of the House Armed Services Committee. It may precipitate a special inquiry in the Senate.
The Madison Square Garden debut of Rocky Fumerelle last night was as dismal as the weather. Don Fullmer of West Jordan, Utah, was the man who put a crimp in Rocky's middleweight aspirations.

Mayor Wagner said yesterday that he had summoned all landlords and agents of buildings on Wrest Eighty-fourth Street between Columbus and Amsterdam Avenues to a meeting at City Hall on Tuesday morning.

A coordinated schedule of wholesale fashion openings, all within a single week and well in advance of the seasonal openings of recent years, has been agreed upon by leaders of the dress, coat and suit industries here.

President Kennedy has gone to extraordinary lengths to gain support in Congress for his foreign aid program. Besides the usual persuasion that he can exert through the White House liaison apparatus, he has had frequent talks with key Congressional figures on the subject.

CONTRARY to what many homeowners believe, paint alone is seldom enough to protect wood against possible attack by wood rot. Often referred to as "dry-rot," this type of wood decay is caused, by microscopic fungi which attack the wood whenever the proper moisture and temperature conditions exist.

PHILADELPHIA, July 15 -- The week-long conventional here of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People has stressed the theme of unity and action on all anti-discrimination fronts, but it has also provided a window on some internal disssension.
ST. LOUIS, July 15 (AP) -- Curt Flood hit a bases-filled, pinch-hit double that helped give the St. Louis Cardinals a 12 -- 4 victory over the Milwaukee Braves tonight.

WASHINGTON, July 15 (AP) -- Employers now are paying more than three-quarters of the more than $10,000,000,000 annual cost to worker pension welfare plans. The plans have assets of nearly $60,000,000,000.
I am interested in your July 6 editorial "Why Only Greenbacks?"
MEXICO CITY, July 15 -- A system of traveling self-service markets has been inaugurated here to supply poor neighborhoods of the capital with foodstuffs substantially below prevailing market prices.

ORIGINALLY written in Spanish with the Latin title "Noli Me Tangere" ("Touch Me Not"), "The Lost Eden" is the latest English translation of Jose Rizal's novel. Rizal is the national hero of the Filipinos, and the publication of this new version of his book coincides with the centennial of his birthday.

With Leonard P. Sasso's 6-5 overnight favorite, Globemaster, withdrawn because of the sloppy track, Ogden Phipps' Hitting Away scored a nose victory yesterday in Aqueduct's mile-and-a-quarter $83,600 Dwyer Handicap. The High Tide Stable's Baldpate, the outsider in the field of eight at $28.15-to-$1, was second.

THE time is ripe for a revaluation the writings of Robert Graves. In the United States he is best known as a writer of prose, as the author of an eccentric, brilliant book on the Greek myths, of an equally brilliant study, half-learned, half-speculative on the poetic imagination, under the title, "The White Goddess."

Publication early this year of the winning design for a memorial monument to Franklin Delano Roosevelt -- a composition of tall, slab-like forms -- brought cries of pleasure from some quarters and of acute distress from others.
JAFFA, Israel, July 1 -- A small storm of protest has arisen here out of a rollicking Israeli satire by actors in Arab dress.
MOSCOW, July 12 -- The Soviet Union has registered concern over the prospect that Britain might join the European Common Market.

WASHINGTON, July 15 (AP) -- The Chicago Taxicab Drivers Union is asking the Supreme Court to halt a representation election set for Wednesday on the ground that an election now would create utter confusion.

YOU may remember an article I wrote for this section (it appeared on February 26) about the history of Ellery Queen's Mystery Magazine. When I was preparing that piece, I decided to check my impression of E.Q.M.M.'s superiority to its rivals by reading every story in every crime magazine then on the stands.
Soviet chess players again easily won the European Cup recently. Yugoslavia was runner-up in the six-nation tournament at Oberhausen, West Germany.

WASHINGTON, July 15 -- Informed United States sources said today that the proposals submitted by India to the deadlocked Geneva conference on Laos contained "practically every gimmick" included in the Communist plan.

JANUS FILMS, which has just released Ingmar Bergman's "Secrets of Women" and has been responsible for introducing American audiences to the works of Federico Fellini ("The White Sheik," "Vitelloni"), Michelangelo Antonioni ("L'Avventura"), as well as most of Bergman's films, is about to enter the production field.

ABOARD THE U.S.S. NORTHAMPTON, July 15 (AP) -- Some day, if an enemy should knock out the Pentagon and other command centers, the President and his military chiefs may fly to this ship to direct the nation's retaliatory strike.

KIELCE, Poland, July 15 -- Ignoring a defense plea to avert the "shame" of purge trial justice, the Kielce County Court today pronounced Michal Brodjes, a lawyer, guilty of having slandered a public prosecutor.
The maritime strike, which reduced movements of United States flag merchant shipping in the second half of last month, had little effect on Customs collections in the Port of New York.

CLEVELAND, July 15 -- (AP) -- Ed Sadowski slammed a home run off Frank Funk to lead off the twelfth inning today, enabling the Los Angeles Angels to post 6-5 victory over the Cleveland Indians. Don Dillard had tied the game for Cleveland at 5 -- 5 in the eighth with a lead-off homer.
With all three parties facing city-wide contests, the Sept. 7 primary stands to be the biggest and the most confused in New York history.

CLEVELAND, July 13 -- America's libraries are experiencing a new surge of interest in their books and services. However, the new demands are creating serious problems relating to personnel, budgets, book stocks and patterns of service.

WASHINGTON, July 15 -- It is now almost six weeks since Nikita Khrushchev handed his tough aide-memoire on Berlin to President Kennedy in Vienna, and this long delay in answering has provided a free field for inflammatory propaganda on both sides.
WASHINGTON, July 15 -- The State Department denied today a report that Chester Bowles would give up the post of Under Secretary of State to become a roving ambassador.
FOUR additional commemorative stamps were announced in Washington last week by Postmaster General J. Edward Day.
The Federal Maritime Board announced yesterday that it had begun an investigation of carriers serving Alaska from West Coast ports that have not filed tariff schedules with the agency.
CIUDAD TRUJILLO, Dominican Republic, July 15 (AP) -- The formation of a new opposition political group was announced today by 114 Dominicans, mostly business and professional men.
ENGLEWOOD, N.J., July 15 -- Gerald R. Riso, assistant to the manager of Scarsdale, N.Y., since 1957, will become business administrator of this city Monday.

THERE'S a book just out called "Junky," by William Gohm. The dust jacket has a picture of a guy and a doll embracing before what could be a sports car on any Greenwich Village street. A world accustomed to "The Connection" and modern literary chatter would get the idea at once -- junky, narcotics addict.
THE most important news of the seasonal home-furnishings markets in Chicago and Grand Rapids was the evidence that contemporary furniture is finally coming into its own.
TUNIS, July 15 -- The coming week promises to be decisive in the Tunisian-French crisis over Bizerte and the Sahara.

WASHINGTON, July 15 -- A Republican gain of about five House seats appears to be the most likely effect of the Congressional redistricting battles now going on in the twenty-five states that gained or lost seats in the 1960 Census apportionment, according to the latest Congressional Quarterly state-by-state survey.

WASHINGTON, July 15 -- A sober, moving and non-glutinous portrayal of what America is and the kind of threat it faces from communism has been produced by the Department of Defense as a major element in its troop indoctrination program.
BOGOTA, Colombia, July 9 -- Manuel Antas Herrera lives on a hillside in the central valley of Huila where the Magdalena River winds through the warm flatlands. He is a landless farmer.

DAVENPORT, Fla., July 15 (AP) -- Deaconess Harriet Bedell bounced along Colorado Mountain trails on horseback, drove a dogsled in Alaska and maneuvered a canoe through alligator infested canals of the Everglades during her fifty-five years as a missionary to Indians.

Increased production, employment and new orders are all encouraging, the June report of the business survey committee of the purchasing agents association of Chicago said this week. The report gives further indication that business is continuing to improve, the committee commented.
Soviet chess players again easily won the European Cup recently. Yugoslavia was runner-up in the six-nation tournament at Oberhausen, West Germany.
Leaders of a major group seeking to overthrow Premier Fidel Castro of Cuba are charging the United States Central Intelligence Agency with "repeated interference" in their affairs.
SAIGON, Vietnam, July 16 -- Government troops crushed a Communist guerrilla force today in the biggest and bloodiest battle since South Vietnam gained independence from France in 1954.

WESTBURY, L.I., July 16 -- Kracovie, the French trotter, will get an opportunity to show whether racing luck, a rain-drenched track or the superiority of Su Mac Lad led to her defeat in the $50,000 International at Roosevelt Raceway last night.
Ernest Hemingway will be the subject of an hour-long television portrait next season on the National Broadcasting Company network.
BERNARDSVILLE, N.J., July 16 -- The wife of a tool manufacturer was killed in a fire that destroyed most of a fifty-room mansion in the Mine Mount section here early this morning.

MONTREAL, July 16 (Canadian Press) -- Consolidated Mining and Smelting Company of Canada, Ltd., had an estimated net profit in the six months ended June 30 of $11,414,000, or 70 cents a share, compared with $12,882,000 and 79 cents a share in the 1960 period.
Plans for adding 150 apartments for elderly persons to the La Guardia Houses on the lower East Side were announced over the week-end by the City Housing Authority.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 16 -- Patterns of trade outlined through 1965 among the Soviet Union and its Eastern European satellites appear to leave "practically no margin" for the growth of exchanges with the so-called "people's democracies of Asia," an analysis by the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization indicates.

Greater New York Anglo-Jewish Publications, Inc., has leased office space in 56 West Forty-fifth Street through Gilbert Kammer of Herbert Charles Co., broker. It publishes the Long Island Jewish Press and the Westchester Jewish Tribune.
CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., July 16 -- Favorable weather was forecast today for the United States' second astronaut's short trip into space early Tuesday.

A FAMILY camp where both parents and children are helped to loosen the ties that bind them is operated by by the Educational Alliance in a woodland setting near Brewster, N.Y. The campers, who come from a cross-section of New York neighborhoods reflect many religious groups, nationalities and occupations.
Carmine G. De Sapio said yesterday he definitely favored using voting machines in the Democratic primary election Sept. 7.
WASHINGTON, July 16 -- Senator J.W. Fulbright called upon the neutral nations of Asia and Africa today to speak out firmly and together in defense of the right of self-determination for all peoples.

WASHINGTON, July 16 -- A four-nation investigatory commission of the Organization of American States has concluded that the inter-American system should continue to watch the situation in the Dominican Republic.
Contending factions in the Democratic primary probably will spend $1,000,000 to $1,500,000 between them in an eight-week, hard-sell campaign to influence the votes of 2,375,000 party adherents.

Comments last week by the Commissioner of Internal Revenue, Mortimer M. Caplin, that the Internal Revenue Service was studying the possibility of treating proceeds from the sale of oil properties in a common type of transaction as ordinary income rather than capital gains sent a shudder through the oil industry.
WASHINGTON, July 16 -- Like the Soviet Union after Stalin's death, the Senate has entered an unreal and puzzling transitional era of collective leadership.
LEESBURG, Ind., July 15 (AP) -- Mrs. Kathy Cornelius set a Ladies Professional Golfers Association 54-hole tournament record today in capturing the Tippecanoe open with a six-under-par 20.

Two books dealing with the processes of mass communication will be published this week. For Thursday Van Nostrand has scheduled "Culture for the Millions?" edited by Norman Jacobs. The book is a result of a conference sponsored by the Tamiment Institute and "Daedalus," to which outstanding artists, scholars and radio and magazine executives had been invited.

The first-half report of the Lazard Fund, Inc., released over the week-end, showed a decline in net assets, although the share value on June 30 remained higher than that of six months ago. This was largely because there were 587,796 fewer shares outstanding at mid-year than at the end of 1960.

The American Jewish Committee accused the United States Government yesterday of having yielded to discrimination against American citizens by Arab League nations. It submitted a document detailing its charges to the State Department.

"HAVE SOME MADEIRA, M'DEAR," sang Michael Flanders and Donald Swann on a Broadway stage a couple of seasons ago. As a genuine invitation, however, it is not often heard these days. The popularity of the wine has waned almost as drastically, if not as noisily, as enthusiasm for a wedding charivari.

GENEVA, July 16 -- The Swiss stock markets were jolted last Monday by one of the severest setbacks in a long time. Although they staged a partial recovery, net losses for the week were the rule in all Swiss sectors.

CLEVELAND, July 16 (AP) -- Chuck Essegian hit two home runs to help the Cleveland Indians to a 7-5 victory over Minnesota today. Lenny Green hit a triple, double and three singles to spark the Twins to a 12-5 triumph in the second game of the double-header.

QUITO, Ecuador, July 16 -- President Jose Maria Velasco Ibarra deepened the cleavage between the Right and Left wings of his governing party today with an attack on Vice President Carlos Julio Arosemena Monroy, who has just returned from a visit to Moscow.
The maritime industry is mounting a last-ditch assault on legislation affecting the controversial steamship conference system.
PHILADELPHIA, July 16 (AP) -- The Detroit Boat Club regained the Julius H. Barnes point trophy today with two victories on the closing day of the national rowing championship.
A bleak picture of living conditions in the New York metropolitan region twenty-five years from now is projected in a book to be published today.
SANTA MONICA, Calif., July 16 (AP) -- The Navy has refused to let a Navy band appear at an anti-Communist rally.

TEL AVIV, Israel, July 16 -- Israeli music lovers gave an enthusiastic ovation last night to six soloists from the Metropolitan Opera of New York who sang Mozart's "Cosi fan tutte," under the baton of Thomas Schippers.
A proposal that Welfare Island be turned into a great park similar to Central Park was made yesterday by the New York Chapter of the American Institute of Architects.
Not all the Sunday drivers are on the highways these days. Thousands and thousands have gone afloat.

LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, July 16 -- A group of seventy followers of Patrice Lumumba, the slain Congo Premier, arrived in the capital today. They came to attend the session of the Congolese national Parliament that is scheduled to open this week.

WASHINGTON, July 16 (AP) -- Vice President Johnson disclosed today that the National Space Council had given President Kennedy its unanimous recommendation on Government policy on communications satellites.

WASHINGTON, July 16 (AP) -- Two members of the American Nazi party have been jailed and charged with felonious assault in the manhandling of a 13-year-old boy and four of of a 13-year-old boy and four of his friends who contend they were dragged into the party's headquarters, handcuffed and quizzed about their religion.
STONEWALL, Tex., July 16 (UPI) -- President Ayub said today his people and Texans were alike. "We are friends of friends: we stand by our word. no matter what it costs," he asserted.
BAGHDAD, Iraq, July 15 -- The first major Iraqi project built with Soviet credit, designs, experts anti equipment, a 400-watt radio station, was dedicated today by Premier Abdul Karim Kassim.

Breakaway has been the theme for the clever Dukla team of Czechoslovakia in the second section of the International Soccer League. Yesterday at the Polo Grounds, the Prague eleven scored all its goals on breakaways as it humbled Espanol of Barcelona, 5 -- 1.

GOV. Robert B. Meyner of New Jersey said yesterday that the proportion of his mail favoring a jetport in northern New Jersey had increased from 20 per cent to 50 since a hearing on the proposal in Trenton last week.

Former President Dwight D. Eisenhower has agreed to serve as honorary chairman of the Council for Economic Growth and Security, an organization that seeks to persuade the public to work for national prosperity based on "non-inflationary economic principles."

George Gershwin had his second triumph of the Lewisohn Stadium season last night. It came in the form of a group of extended excerpts from "Porgy and Bess," sung by members of the same cast that had done the work earlier this year at the New York City Center.

I agree with James Warburg, whose letter you published on June 29, that there is no solution for Berlin except within the wider context of a German settlement, but I disagree completely with the conclusion he draws from this statement.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 16 -- Whatever the explanation for juvenile delinquency this summer, it cannot be blamed on movies. For the films about juvenile delinquency have almost vanished.

FLORENCE, July 16 -- The heart of Italian couture has begun to beat. Buyers for stores over the world and reporters swarm here twice a year to see what Italy has to say this time. This month they gathered for the tenth anniversary collections of the Florence couture.

LONDON, July 16 -- Prime Minister Macmillan and his Cabinet are edging toward one of the toughest leadership problems the Conservatives have faced in ten years in office. This is the question of how British public opinion is to be informed, united and inspired to support the joint Western position -- one that may run risk of war -- in the coming crisis with the Soviet Union over Berlin.
Leon Lavallee, Keystone Fund of Canada, Ltd., and the temper of the times got together earlier this month in a happy union aimed at world-wide investing.
KANSAS CITY, Mo., July 16 (UPI) -- The Sinclair Oil Company and the Oil, Chemical and Atomic Workers Union announced agreement today on a new one-year contract.

WASHINGTON, July 15 -- President Mohammad Ayub Khan of Pakistan suggested today that the United States deal directly with Laos, Cambodia and Vietnam rather than through the "slow" Southeast Asia Treaty Organization.

Oren Root, State Superintendent of Banks, has invited written comment from bankers and other interested persons on pending and future bank merger and holding company applications. Mr. Root said the same policy already existed with regard to branch applications.

WASHINGTON, July 16 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission concluded the first round of hearings on control of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad this week, but not before the regulatory agency discovered that it had been asked to settle a "railroad triangle," not unlike the more volatile domestic kind.
The Rev. Dr. John Ellis Large has resigned his pastorate at the Church of the Heavenly Rest, Fifth Avenue and Ninetieth Street, one of New York's best-known Protestant Episcopal churches.
CHICAGO, July 16 -- Two hundred policemen arrested nine young white men today at Rainbow Beach here.

PURCHASE, N.Y., July 16 -- Mimi Kanarek of Brooklyn won the women's Eastern clay court tennis championship today by defeating Sally Wilson of Scarsdale, N.Y., 6 -- 3, 6 -- 4, at the Century Country Club. Neither finalist was seeded.

STOWE, Vt., July 16 -- The Green Mountain Dog Club's annual show at Mount Mansfield today drew the largest entry of the six events of the scenic circuit. It ended in a second best-in-show triumph for the white bullterrier, Ch. Radar of Monte-Ayr.
Samuel Reshevsky and Bobby Fischer began a sixteen-game chess match for the George P. Edgar Trophy yesterday at the Empire Hotel. Reshevsky is 49 years old, Fischer 18.

Controls Company of America, through Deutsche Controls G.m.b.H., its German subsidiary, has acquired the business and operations of Kontrollgerate Handelsgesellschaft of Munich, a large independent distributor of the company's products in West Germany.
United States Attorney Robert M. Morgenthau said yesterday that Albert Wood Moore of Manchester, Mass., had been incorrectly identified as being involved in a $5,000,000 stock fraud.
Whitney North Seymour Jr. charged yesterday that his year-long investigation showed that Mayor Wagner and his Investigations Commissioner would rather hide city scandals than correct them.

CHICAGO, July 16 (AP) -- The Boston Red Sox scored two runs in the twelfth inning for a 5-3 victory today after the Chicago White Sox had taken the first game of a double-header, 4 -- 3, on Minnie Minoso's two-run, two-out single in the ninth.
BOLZANO, Italy, July 16 -Fear and frustration are gripping this scenic area amid continuing terrorism.

George Ball of Woodhaven, Queens, began defense of his Eastern senior clay court championship yesterday by defeating Leon Bernard of Clifton, N.J. 6 -- 2, 6 -- 1, at the Seminole Club, Forest Hills, Queens.
KATMANDU, Nepal, July 16 -- A national council will soon be set up to take the place of Nepal's dissolved Parliament.

I wish to commend you for the editorials on the New Haven Ra road in your editions of July 8 10. You quite correctly against further "palliatives" "trifling help," which would be wasteful of time and money.
An increase in the use of symbols on highway signs to warn motorists of potential hazards is being urged for the future by the nation's top highway officials.

A new one-story industrial building at 57 Newark Way, Maplewood, N.J., has been leased to the Gleicher Manufacturing Corporation, maker of stencils for die cutting, formerly of Newark. The building was erected by the Murdoch Construction Company.

WASHINGTON, July 16 (UPI) -- The Washington Senators scored an unearned run in the tenth inning of their scored game with Los Angeles today to win, 4 -- 3, after the Angels had taken the opener, 11 -- 2.
Auxiliary Bishop James H. Griffiths of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York isssued yesterday a denunciation of "the political bastardy" of East Germany.
Prices of cotton futures in the domestic market advanced early last week, backed and filled in fairly good trading and closed the period with net gains.
WURTSBORO, N.Y., July 16 (AP) -- A car went out of control on Route 17 today, turned over and struck an oncoming auto, killing tile driver of the second car and injuring four persons.

ST. LOUIS, July 16 (UPI) -- Chuck McKinley and Dennis Ralston won the final singles matches today as the United States Davis Cup tennis team completed a 5-0 sweep of Ecuador. The victory sent the United States into the third round of the American Zone competition.

FARMINGDALE, L.I. July 16 -- Neil Connor of Greenville, S.C., with a 247, forty-one under par for 144 holes, took the $5,000 Eastern open championship of the Professional Putters Association today. Par for each hole of the putting tournament was 2.

WASHINGTON, July 16 -- Although there is no distinctive war atmosphere in the capital these days, Administration officials have made it clear that they expect President Kennedy to declare at least a partial national emergency because of the Berlin crisis.
Nearly 20 per cent of the third-grade children in public schools here and 25 per cent of the sixth graders were born outside the city.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 16 (UPI) --Willie Mays hit two home runs and Matty Alou one with two on, helping the San Francisco Giants to a 7-3 victory over the Philadelphia Phillies today.
LONDON, July 16 -- Worry about the measures the Government is to invoke to correct Britain's depressing economic trends overshadowed the stock market again last week.
The Navy, like the vacationer setting out for two weeks at the seashore, is concerned about what to take on a trip and how much of it to pack.
SEOUL, Korea, Monday, July 17 -- South Korea's military Government today took economic and political steps aimed at restoring stability and public confidence in the country.
School Superintendent John J. Theobald faces questioning by another district attorney on the boat built for him by vocational students.
A $36,000,000 rebuilding of the heart of the Coney Island amusement area has been proposed by the Coney Island Chamber of Commerce.

CINCINNATI, July 16 (AP) -- George Altman's sixteenth homer of the year and Bob Anderson's no-hit relief stint enabled the seventh-place Chicago Cubs to score a 4-2 victory today over the league-leading Cincinnati Reds.
HYANNIS PORT, Mass, July 16 -- President Kennedy conferred by telephone today with high-ranking foreign policy and defense officials of his Administration.

The George Junior Republic, a youth-operated community in Freeville, N.Y., will be the beneficiary of a theatre party at the Oct. 2 preview performance of "Sail Away." Noel Coward's new musical is scheduled to open at the Broadhurst Theatre on the following evening.

The Soviet Premier, of course, has often used this issue against the remains of Western colonialism in Asia and Africa. It is time he was reminded this question is a double-edged weapon.
DEER PARK, L.I., July 16 -- A new instrument-landing technique to keep airports open in bad weather is designed to extend radio guidance to pilots to actual touch-down on the runway.

Except for insurance company issues, which showed unusual strength, and some selected utility stocks that benefited from trust buying, trading in the over-the-counter market was mostly quiet last week. Prices of many industrials drifted, downward, particularly on Friday.
