The ninth and final volume of the New York Metropolitan Region Study, conducted by the Harvard Graduate School of Public Administration for the Regional Plan Association, is published today under the title "1400 Governments: The Political Economy of the New York Metropolitan Region."
THE following menu is suggested as a guide to the use of foods that are reasonable in price. A recipe is given for an easy-to-prepare main dish.
CHICAGO, July 16 (AP) -- All the surprises in the Government's July crop report last week exerted a bearish influence in the grain futures trade, and the market turned generally weak.
Hellenic Lines, Ltd., announced last night the settlement of the strike by its office workers.

CEDAR KEY, Fla., July 16 (AP) -- A charter fishing boat rescued a man today who had been adrift in the Gulf of Mexico aboard a cabin cruiser for seventeen days. He had been without food for the last seven days and had had only a few drops of water in the last four days.

AMSTERDAM, July 16 -- The Amsterdam Bourse moved sharply lower last week, reflecting particularly the question of Berlin. Foreign buying interest dwindled, and with the public adopting a reserved attitude, business was very small.
Trading in the foreign exchange market followed an irregular pattern during the past week. British pound sterling continued to slide while the Canadian dollar showed a alight improvement.

PHILADELPHIA, July 16 -- The fifty-second annual convention of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People closed here today in a mood of reaffirmation of the organization's drive toward complete integration of the Negro into American life.
LOS ANGELES, July 16 (AP) -- Johnny Roseboro's tenth-inning triple enabled the second-place Los Angeles Dodgers to gain ground on Cincinnati with a defeat of the Pittsburgh Pirates, 12 -- 11, today.
GREENWICH, Conn., July 16 -- Robert Coulson's Finn Maccumhaill and Patrick O'Gorman's Wahini won three races each today as the Indian Harbor Yacht Club cruise ended.

PARIS, July 16 -- One of the mysteries of Paris to the uninitiated visitor is the eerie humming sound he hears in the middle of the day as he passes the corner of the Rue Notre Dame des Victoires and the Rue du Quatre Septembre. The sound begins promptly at 12:30 P.M. and stops promptly at 2:30 P.M.
Seven new films are scheduled to arrive in local theatres this week. The programs follow:

DETROIT, July 16 (AP) -- The Tigers regained first place in the American League today on a barrage of home runs and the pitching of Don Mossi and Phil Regan, as they beat the Kansas City Athletics twice. The scores were 11 -- 1 and 8 -- 3.
WASHINGTON, July 16 -- President Kennedy will resume tomorrow his fight for his foreign-aid program. He will hold another in the series of White House meetings with influential members of Congress.

A realignment of the top echelon at Cunningham Walsh, Inc., was announced by the agency over the week-end. Carl W. Nichols Jr., 37, was named president and chief executive officer. John P. Cunningham, former chairman, was named chairman of the executive committee, while Robert R. Newell, former president, becomes chairman of the board.

BLACKPOOL, England, July 16 -- A passenger train carrying 300 vacationers to the Irish Sea coast smashed into a standing freight at near-by Weeton today and at least six persons were killed. The injured totaled 125. The six-coach passenger train was bound from Colne, thirty-five miles east of Blackpool, to the seaside resort of Fleetwood, ten miles north of this city.

BALTIMORE, July 16 -- To relieve a pitching shortage caused by the sore arms of Bill Stafford and Ralph Terry and the recent ineffectiveness of Bob Turley and Jim Coates, the Yankees today recalled Alphonse Gigi Downing from their Binghamton (N.Y.) farm club in the Class A Eastern League.

PARISHIONERS of the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest at Fifth Avenue and Ninetieth Street regard their rector, the Rev. Dr. John Ellis Large, as one of the best phrase-makers in theology.
DORTMUND, Germany, July 16 -- Chancellor Adenauer asserted again today that a German peace treaty would be meaningless without world agreement on controlled disarmament.
For women who are interested in the world of fashion, the following books may be ideal for summer vacation reading. They are available at most branches of the New York Public Library.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 16 -- The room had been quiet until Beans Reardon walked in. Then the decibel content shot up alarmingly. Long years of umpiring in the National League have so affected the Reardon voice that Beansie never talks in anything less than a shout. Since he usually is laughing boisterously at the same time, this adds an element of pandemonium to a simple conversation.
ST. LOUIS, July 16 (AP) -- Joe Adcock hit two home runs and Lee Maye one for the Milwaukee Braves today as they routed the St. Louis Cardinals, 9 to 1.
WASHINGTON, July 16 (UPI) -- Newton N. Minow, chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, said today that control of television by advertisers was in some cases "absolutely outrageous."

LARCHMONT, N.Y., July 16 -- Chandler Hovey's 12-meter Easterner, Warner Willcox' International Stardust and Anson Beard's Star Tsunami strung together second successive victories today in the Larchmont Yacht Club Race Week sailing.
The plane was carrying a cargo of dynamite across the Atlantic. Its compass was not working, it lacked sufficient fuel to reach Iceland and it could not make radio contact there.
MOSCOW, July 16 -- The United States and the Soviet Union resume disarmament talks here tomorrow in an atmosphere of pessimism engendered by the Berlin crisis.

While public attention has long been fixed on the violence of boys' street gangs, their girls' auxiliaries have been growing more and more pernicious. Girl gangs now pose almost as grave a problem here as the boy gangs they follow.
LIMA, Peru, July 16 -- The Peruvian Government has acted to forestall another $2-a-ton increase in handling charges for import traffic at the Port of Callao.
PARIS, July 16 -- The twenty-two day, 2,750-mile $110,000 Tour de France bike race was won by a superman among riders today -- Jacques Anquetil of France.
MIAMI, July 16 -- Bob Seever, a Miami airline pilot, won the Gold Coast motorboat marathon today for the third consecutive year. His record-breaking average speed was 77.58 miles an hour.

MINNEAPOLIS, July 16 -- Private investors in Minneapolis and Princeton, N.J., today started a major gold-dredging venture on the Kaka River in Bolivia, a tributary of the Amazon River on the eastern slopes of the Andes mountains.

HERRIN, Ill., July 16 (UPI) -- Samuel E. Woodring, of North Augusta, S.C., was awarded the Elijah Parish Lovejoy Award for courage in journalism tonight at the International Conference of Weekly Newspaper Editors.
A man jumped or fell to his death from the dance deck of a chartered excursion boat into the Hudson River yesterday.
PARAMUS, N.J., July 16 -- Brakes squealed and tires burned here today in the huge parking lot of the Garden State Plaza Shopping Center, but no one asked to have drivers' licenses revoked.

NEW HAVEN, July 16 -- Yale University announced today the appointment of Dr. Isadore Sydney Falk, former director of research and statistics for the Federal Social Security Administration, as Professor of Public Health for Medical Care in the university's School of Medicine.
PITTSBURGH, July 16 -- Steel men were holding to predictions of an August upturn last week.
Despite the brisk pace of industrial recovery, the Labor Department foresees little drop in unemployment in the next six months.
WASHINGTON, July 16 (AP) -- The electrical ion engine is to get its first space test late next year, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration announced today.

MONTREAL, July 16 (AP) -- Adios Butler won the $12,500 purse in the Richelieu International pace and a $1,000 bonus for his driver today. He whirled around the mile track in 1 minute 58 2/5 seconds, a Canadian record.
Yonkers Raceway's efforts to purchase controlling interest of Roosevelt Raceway ran into heavy opposition yesterday.
BALTIMORE, July 16 -- Mickey Mantle's booming bat and Bud Daley's crafty pitching carried the Yankees to a 2-1 victory over the Orioles today in the opener of a three-game series.
A Congregational minister said yesterday that the encyclical of Pope John XXIII challenged "our imagination and our responsibility."

TEHERAN, July 16 -- Today is the sixteenth birthday of the Atomic Age and, at the present rate of indigestion, it is by no means certain it will live to its nuclear majority. Between growth of misunderstanding and inability to curb the spread of mass-destruction weapons, science may yet attain its ultimate accomplishment -- death.

MOSCOW, July 16 (AP) -- Although Soviet and American track and field officials agreed to keep separate scores for the men's and women's competitions in their meet that ended today, Tass, the official Soviet news agency, reported the over-all score as 179 -- 163 in favor of the Russians.

BERLIN, July 16 -- An East Berlin publication said today that the Communists intended to pronounce West Berlin a free city at the conclusion of a peace treaty between the Soviet Union and East Germany.

WASHINGTON, July 16 -- The Kennedy Administration completes its first six months in office this week. This is too short a period to form dependable judgments on its record or philosophy, but it is long enough for an interim report on its approach and progress.
MOSCOW, July 16 (AP) -- Valeri Brumel, Ralph Boston and Tatyana Scheikanova broke world record today as the United States men and Soviet women won their two-day track and field dual meets.

WASHINGTON, July 16 -- The Inter-American Development Bank is expected to announce a $15,000,000 loan to Argentina next week. This will be the largest loan extended to any Latin country by the bank since it began operations last January.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 16 -- Governmental representatives of Latin-American republics are scheduled to converge on Mexico on July 31, for a two-week seminar on electric power.

When the fitful summer breeze becomes too elusive a man may mop his brow and conclude that the time has come for an air conditioner in his home. Facing up to the fact that on sweltering, sleepless nights he looks forward to the daytime hours spent in his pleasant, air-cooled office and even in his air-conditioned car, he decides that sudden changes in temperature from cool to hot are unhealthy.
WASHINGTON, July 16 -- President Kennedy has decided on the first revision of his six-month-old Administration.

THOMPSON, Conn., July 16 -- Gerry Georgi of West Nyack, N.Y., wheeled a big Lister Buick to first place today in a race for modified cars that highlighted a two-day divisional championship meeting of the Sports Car Club of America.
The Soviet Union's leading law journal has printed an article defending private property rights of Soviet citizens with claims on inheritances, life insurance policies and pensions in this country.

WASHINGTON, July 16 -- Robert F. Kennedy, as Attorney General, has no jurisdiction over television programs for children. But as the father of seven children, he feels he has some rights in the matter.

THOSE planning a flying holiday to Europe will find packing a tricky, fastidious procedure. Keeping within the forty-four-pound tourist baggage allowance, or even the sixty-six-pound first-class quota takes a great deal of forethought and much elimination.
SAINT-TROPEZ, France, July 16 -- Fifty-seven modern paintings, many of them masterpieces, were stolen in their frames from a museum here early today.

WASHINGTON, July 16 (AP) -- Sworn reports filed with the Government show that membership of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters under James R. Hoffa, president, actually is lower than it was four years ago under his predecessor, Dave Beck.

Hardly a season goes by that does not have at least two producers coming up with the same idea for Broadway. Several months ago Alexander H. Cohen disclosed that his 'big project" for this term would be a musical dealing with Fhineas T. Barnum, the circus snowman and ballyhoo artist.

UNITED NATIONS. N.Y. July 16 -- The American Association for the United Nations has asked the United States Government to bring the Berlin question before the United Nations "since the issue of Berlin may involve the survival or extinction of much of the human race."
Representative Emanuel Celler said yesterday that the prospects of freeing the Eastern European nations from Soviet domination were remote.
ACCRA, Ghana, July 16 -- E.K. Bensah, Works and Housing Minister, is to tour the Soviet Union, Czechoslovakia. Yugoslavia, Hungary and Poland to recruit technicians for Ghana's civil service.
WARSAW, July 16 -- The Sejm (Parliament) passed new legislation this week-end that, in the judgment of the Roman Catholic Church, lays the legal groundwork for new anti-Church measures in Poland.
GENEVA, July 17 -- Cautious optimism was expressed tonight for a possible break in the procedural deadlock at the fourteen-nation conference on Laos.

TUNIS, July 17 -- President Habib Bourguiba declared today that he would give France until tomorrow night to promise to evacuate the Bizerte naval base and accept Tunisia's claim to part of the Sahara.

In a reassignment of responsibilities Texas Instruments, Inc., has named Mark Shepherd Jr., vice president, formerly in charge of the semiconductor-components division, vice president of operations. At the same time, S.T. Harris, vice president in charge of marketing, was made responsible for developing long-range plans to assure company growth and performance.
Fresh water -- taken for granted where plentiful, and treasured where scarce -- is now being produced at a pace undreamed of a decade ago.
WASHINGTON, July 17 (AP) -- John D. Corcoran of Chesterton, Ind., was named today as associate director for management for the Peace Corps.

WASHINGTON, July 17 (AP) -- In quiet contrast to the mounting "cold war" storms, United States and Russian negotiators will sit down together tomorrow to work out the first direct commercial air route between their two countries.

The Newburgh question is not a matter of law or humanity -- or of "morality" as The Times sees morality. It is a matter of how long taxpayers will be able to afford to support a constantly growing relief roll without tightening standards.
The concern expressed by Chairman Carl Vinson of the House Armed Services Committee about the Army's "declining" strength has both a short-term and a long-term aspect.

WASHINGTON, July 17 -- The obligation of responsible statesmanship, now made more profound than ever before by the weapons piling up in the arsenals of the nuclear powers, required the President to go slow with announcements of positive steps to meet progressively the mounting crisis over Berlin.

Until a few years ago, not many railroads attached more importance to advertising and public relations than the New York Central. But the economy-minded Central has pared such expenditures lately. Its management thinks the time now has come for the Eastern Railroad Presidents Conference, the public relations arm of the Eastern carriers, to do the same.

LONDON, July 17 -- Peter Thorneycroft, Minister of Aviation, said today that India, Pakistan and Ceylon thought it was Britain's responsibility to decide whether she should join the European Economic Community Common Market.
WASHINGTON, July 17 (AP) -- President Kennedy named today eleven new members of the National Advisory Committee on the Selection of Physicians, Dentists and Allied Specialists.
ATLANTA, July 17 -- Ty Cobb, the No. 1 player elected to baseball's Hall of Fame and probably the greatest star in the game's history, died today.

WASHINGTON, July 17 (AP) -- Senator Kenneth B. Keating of New York conceded today that the farmer who said he had bought a Cadillac with money he got from the Government for not growing corn might not be a typical corn farmer.

ORLEANS, Ind., July 17 (AP) -- Swirling underground currents drove rescuers back repeatedly today as they tried to find two students trapped in a flooded limestone cave near here that they were exploring.
Stephen B. Botsford said yesterday that he had resigned as president of The New Yorker magazine.

PHILADELPHIA, July 17 (AP) -- The City of Philadelphia filed twelve new suits, each seeking treble damages, today against seventeen heavy electrical equipment concerns that figured in recent price-fixing and bid-rigging prosecutions.
HOUSTON, July 17 (UPI) -- Edward M. Kennedy, youngest brother of the President, left today on a tour of rural and depressed areas of Latin America. He termed the trip "strictly unofficial."
The reason a pioneer fruit dealer went out of business here recently was that it had been cheated out of more than a half-million dollars, District Attorney Frank S. Hogan charged yesterday.

Sales of mutual funds shares in June slipped almost $14,000,000 from the May level but remained $45,000,000 above the June, 1960, level. Monthly figures issued yesterday by the National Association of Investment Companies put sales for the month at $223,261,000, against $237,039,000 in May and $178,013,000 in June, 1960.

WHEN William J. was 20, he was an unknown who slept in a bathtub and paid his bills with the nickle-and-dime tips he made delivering lunches. He also ushered at the Palace Theatre and did janitorial work to pay his rent.
The Chemical Bank New York Trust Company will move part of its operations from lower Broadway to an office skyscraper to rise at 277 Park Avenue, north of Forty-seventh Street.
The Transitron Electronic Corporation and the Western Electric Company announced yesterday in Wakefield, Mass., the signing of a cross-license patent agreement. Wakefield is the home of Transitron.

The Constantine region in Western Algeria was designated as Wilaya (District) No. II by the Moslem rebels of the National Liberation Front. Constantine is on a rocky plateau 2,130 feet above sea level and some fifty miles inland from the Mediterranean.

Ford Frick threw a protective screen around Babe Ruth's season record of sixty home runs yesterday. The baseball commissioner ruled that no batter would be credited with breaking the record unless he did it in 154 games.
WASHINGTON, July 17 (AP) -- The Senate voted for the fifth time today to reopen National Service Life Insurance to World War II and Korean war veterans.
The use of metal curtain walls on nonresidential buildings is increasing throughout the country, according to a recent study undertaken by the Olin Mathieson Chemical Corporation.
BONN, July 17 -- The heads of the Governments of the six Common Market countries began arriving in Bonn today to discuss political cooperation within their economic union.

The Gyrodyne Company of America filed a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday covering a proposed public offering of 90,000 common shares and $1,500,000 of convertible subordinated debentures with warrants attached for the purchase of an additional 30,000 common shares.
School began yesterday for twenty-five state and Federal judges from many parts of the United States and Canada.

Consumers are continuing to improve their payment record on installment debt, the American Bankers Association reported yesterday. At the end of May, 181 of every 10,000 installment borrowers had one or more payments past due thirty days, compared with 213 at the end of February.
OCALA, Fla., July 17 (AP) -- Two Freedom Riders arrested after a scuffle in the Ocala Bus Station last month drew criticism and jail sentences from a Florida county judge today.
The electronic computer can become a powerful ally of the physician in diagnosis and in keeping knowledge of specific diseases up to date, speakers said yesterday at a scientific meeting here.
LONDON, July 17- The Trades Union Congress, central federation of British unions, announced today that it would conduct an investigation into the Communist-ridden Electrical Trades Union.
Two members of Congress yesterday denounced any purchase of the control of Roosevelt Raceway by Yonkers Raceway as an attempted violation of Federal antitrust laws.

SEOUL, Korea, July 17 -- United Nations and South Korean forces are still struggling with one of the most serious problems that can confront any army -- a breakdown of confidence in the military chain of command.

TRENTON, July 17 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner reiterated tonight his contention that some New Jersey industrialists might be willing to purchase television station WNTA and operate it strictly as an outlet for this state, if they could obtain it at a "modest" price.

The American Waterways Operators, Inc., a group representing the nation's shallow-draft water carriers, will protest the Southern Railway System's impending rate reductions on grain it hauls from the Midwest to the South and Southeast.
CHICAGO, July 17 -- James B. Conlisk, acting Superintendent of the Police, appealed today for a general sense of community responsibility to ease Chicago's racial tension.
The Board of Elections will make a new effort today to find a way for one or more political parties to use voting machines in the Sept. 7 primary.
WASHINGTON, July 17 (AP) -- The Atomic Energy Commission denied today a published report that it has planned an underground atomic test in December.

VIENNA, July 17 -- Tyrolean nationalists in Austria have begun to advocate publicly the right of self-determination, as opposed to autonomous status, for the 250,000 German-speaking people of Italy's Alto Adige Province.
NORWALK, Conn., July 17 -- With the help of the Coast Guard and a local police patrol, Tax Commissioner Rowland A. Schwebel has nearly doubled the yield from a local tax on boat registrations.
BALTIMORE, July 17 (AP) -- Ralph Houk takes the impartial managerial view in the home-run battle between his New York Yankee sluggers, Roger Maris and Mickey Mantle.

American editions of two books by Henry de Montherlant, one of France's most distinguished living authors, will be published by Macmillan on July 31. One will be "Selected Essays," translated from the French by John 'Weightman.

The earnings of the British American Oil Company in the first half of this year were about 9 per cent above the 1960 level after making adjustment for a $2,000,000 nonrecurring profit in 1960. E.D. Loughney, president, making this report to the New York Society of Security Analysts yesterday, said the rate of gain should hold for the full year.

WESTHAMPTON BEACH, L.I. July 17 -- Committees have been working for the success of the Pink and White Ball to be held Saturday at the Bath and Tennis Club here for the benefit of the Central Suffolk Hospital in Riverhead.
WASHINGTON, July 17 (UPI) -- President Kennedy met with Congressional leaders again today in an effort to build up support for his foreign aid program.

Police Inspector William P. Brown strolled past a freshly painted shuffleboard court on West Eighty-fourth Street yesterday morning, then ducked under a guy rope that held a volleyball net taut from sidewalk to sidewalk.
WASHINGTON, July 17 (UPI) -- President Kennedy designated the period from Nov. 17 through Nov. 23 as National Farm-City Week today.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., -- July 17 -- Four members of the Pakhtunistan Independence Movement picketed the United Nations briefly tonight in protest against the warm reception given to President Ayub by the United States.
CHICAGO, July 17 -- Food sales patterns indicate that economic trends and attending job opportunities are on the rise, Don R. Grimes, president of the more than 5,000 IGA stores, said today.
CHICAGO, July 17 (AP) -- Old crop soybean futures closed weak today on the Board of Trade, but the market otherwise was steady to strong with wheat posting gains running almost to 2 cents a bushel.

PHILADELPHIA, July 17 (AP) -- District Attorney James C. Crumlish Jr. said today he would arrest Charles (Sonny) Liston, the heavyweight boxing contender, on two of four charges originally dropped by a magistrate.

WOODBRIDGE, N.J., July 17 -- In this heavily industrialized community, a civic-sponsored outdoor theatre, believed to be the first of its kind in this section of New Jersey, will make its debut July 29 with a production of Shakespeare's "As You Like It."

NIAGARA FALLS, Ont., July 17 (AP) -- Nathan Boya, saying he had enjoyed himself, put up for sale to the highest bidder today the $3,000, rubber-covered steel ball that carried him successfully over thetreacherous Niagara Falls.
HALIFAX, July 17 (Canadian Press) -- The Bermudian freighter Wheat King, beset by labor and engine troubles in eastern Canadian ports for nearly a month, sailed today for London.

The highest sales on record for any quarter were reported yesterday by E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co. for the three months ended on June 30. Earnings for the period, however, and sales and profits for the first half of 1961 were below those of the 1960 periods, according to the chemical producer's preliminary half-year report.
LINDEN, N.J., July 17 -- Twenty-five children splashed into a new pool here today, making history of a sort for the Young Men's Christian Association.

MADRID, July 17 -- Generalissimo Francisco Franco's regime marked today the twenty-fifth anniversary of the start of the Spanish Civil War with a three-hour military parade through the heart of the city.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., July 17 Paul Shield's Columbia, last and next to last in the previous two races among the four 12-meter yachts sailing for Larchmont Race Week honors, today lifted the gloom that had settled upon her adherents.

A 3-year-old mascot tended to dominate the scene yesterday as boys teams from Puerto Rico and the continental United States met on a baseball diamond at Harris Field, near Bedford Park Boulevard, the Bronx.
WASHINGTON, July 17 (UPI) -- The Senate Government Operations Committee voted today 6 to 3 to recommend approval of President Kennedy's plan to reorganize the National Labor Relations Board.

FAIRFIELD, Conn., July 17 -- Nine weeks away from their season opener and with the temperature about 40 degrees above the mean for good football weather, the Giants hung out the "open" sign on their training camp at Fairfield University today.
WASHINGTON, July 17 (AP) -- Sen. Jacob K. Javits, Republican of New York, today introduced a bill to extend the life of the Export-Import Bank five years.

Surrogate John C. Boylan, charging that "fraud, duplicity and deceit" by the Democratic county chairman of Richmond had denied him the party organization's designation this year, said yesterday he would not enter a primary contest.

WASHINGTON, July 17 (UPI) -- The White House Fine Arts Committee accepted a rare early nineteenth century mahogany desk today as a gift from Dr. and Mrs. Maurice Moun of Des Moines, Iowa.

PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, July 17 -- President Francois Duvalier officiated at dedication ceremonies today as the name of the town of Cabaret, thirteen miles north of here, was changed to Duvalierville. The President endorsed the plan to turn the town into a modern "pilot project."

NEWBURGH, N.Y., July 17 -- City Manager Joseph McD. Mitchell announced today that he would meet in Washington tomorrow with Senators Barry Goldwater, Arizona Republican, and John H. Tower, Republican of Texas.

FLORENCE, Italy, July 17 -- Fashion collections often are similar to relaxed, continental lunches. They take time. Everything is not thrown at you at once. This seems to be the mood of the Italian couture showings so far.

WASHINGTON, July 17 (AP) -- An inter-American committee formally recommended today that the Organization of American States adopt a wait-and-see attitude on the doplomatic quarantine now in effect against the Dominican Republic.
RYE, N.Y., July 17 -- The Knollwood Country Club foursome won qualifying honors today in the Westchester County Golf Association's junior team championship tournament at Westchester Country Club.

LOS ANGELES, July 17 (AP) -- Duke Snider, batting eighth for the first time in five years, hit a decisive two-run single in the seventh inning tonight as the Los Angeles Dodgers defeated the Pittsburgh Pirates for the second straight time, 6 -- 4.

WASHINGTON, July 17 -- The Treasury announced tonight the marketing of ninety-one and 182-day bills at the lowest rates since last April. LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, July 17 -- Leaders of rival Congolese regimes faced each other for the first time today in direct consultation on the possible formation of a national coalition government. The consultations are the first step toward the opening of the national Parliament.

NEW DELHI, India, July 13 -- Plans are progressing for the assignment of twenty-four Peace Corps volunteers to help India make better use of her rural resources.

Doug Harvey, the New York Ranger player-coach, went to work for the National Hockey League club for the first time yesterday. Harvey, for many years a hero in Montreal while with the Canadiens, worked with sixty-five youngsters.

WASHINGTON, July 17 -- Tanganyika's Prime Minister, Julius Nyerere, met with President Kennedy today and received assurance that the United States intended to help Tanganyika with economic aid.

DETROIT, July 17 -- The United Automobile Workers contended today that the Ford Motor Company could increase the pay of its workers and provide greater job security without raising car prices.
