A Treasury Department technical staff report recommending substantially higher Federal taxation of mutual thrift institutions came under fire from savings banks and savings and loan associations yesterday.
WASHINGTON, July 17 -- The United States, Britain and France presented notes to the Soviet Union today categorically, rejecting Premier Khrushchev's proposals on Berlin and Germany.
BALTIMORE, July 17 -- Wonderful Whitey Ford pitched the Yankees to a handsome 5 -- 0 victory over the Orioles tonight in the opening game of a twilight night double-header.
Mayor Wagner charged yesterday that the investigation by Whitney North Seymour Jr. into New York City affairs "has gone out of business the way it started -- in a blaze of mud."

Baseball as well as all sport has lost one of its great figures in the death of Tyrus Raymond Cobb. As with two of his outstanding contemporaries, the late Christy Mathewson and Babe Ruth, his was a name which became synonymous with America's national pastime. Curiously, each of these three was cast in his own mold.
CHICAGO, July 17 (UPI) -- Early Wynn limited the Boston Red Sox to three hits tonight and gained his 292d major-league victory, 4 -- 1, for the Chicago White Sox.

THERE is a trick to selecting peaches, a fruit that is now available here in abundance. For most purposes shoppers want ripe peaches. To be sure they are getting them, they should examine what the experts call the "background color" of the fruit.

STUTTGART, Germany, July 17 (AP) -- Fresh from its victory over the Soviet Union, the United States track and field team will oppose West Germany -- probably the strongest track nation this side of the Iron Curtain -- tomorrow and Wednesday.
Samuel Reshevsky defeated Bobby Fischer last night at the Manhattan Chess Club in the first game of their sixteen-game match for the George P. Edgar Trophy.
TRENTON, July 17 -- New Jersey moved today to get a Federal grant for a study of the feasibility of linking major commuter rail lines in North Jersey with the Hudson Tubes system.
Stocks dropped yesterday for the sixth time in the last seven trading sessions and lost about three-quarters of 1 per cent of their aggregate market value on the New York Stock Exchange.

American Electric Power Company and subsidiaries reported yesterday an increase of more than $500,000 in net income for the twelve months ended on June 30. June earnings ran 3.4 per cent higher than in the 1960 month, but net income for the first half year was less than a year before.
Paul Hartman has been signed to play a major role in the Broadway-bound "Journey to the Day," the Roger O. Hirson play, owned by Fred Coe and Arthur Cantor.

BERLIN, July 17 -- Thousands of East Germans are fleeing to the West via West Berlin. Why are they doing so? One answer was given by Horst Metzler, 26 years old, who was with his 20year-old bride of a week.

LONDON, July 17 (Reuters) -- A strike of maintenance men at London Airport has crippled the nationalized British Overseas Airways Corporation for the third straight day. The cost has been estimated at 250,000 ($700,000) daily.

The Columbia Broadcasting System may reopen the door for a one-hour weekly series of television dramas in the fall of 1962. They would be produced either live or on tape by four producers on the network staff -- Herbert Brodkin, Gordon Duff, Robert Herridge and Albert McCleery.
Two of the twenty-seven Chinese-born stewards who jumped ship in Hoboken, N.J., last Saturday were arrested last night by Immigration authorities in Westchester County restaurants.
THE annual tournament played for the European championship is always an impressive affair.
LONDON, July 17 -- An experiment that the sponsors hope will promote better international understanding between students got off to a good start here last week.

WASHINGTON, July 17 -- In the first six months of the Kennedy Administration, United States foreign policy has remained basically the same as under President Eisenhower but has become more flexible and venturesome.

WASHINGTON, July 17 -- For the first time in years the Western Allies appear to be making concrete moves to increase the tactical ground and air forces opposing the huge Communist military establishments in Europe.

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), July 17 -- Hadassah, the women's Zionist service organization, will attempt to transport essential members of its hospital staff here by "ambulance" next week-end to avoid a recurrence of stonings of buses by religious zealots.

Two foreign banks have received approval from the State Banking Department to convert agencies into branches, and a third is seeking the same. The applications, which permit the institutions to accept deposits and conduct a full banking business, are being made under a law enacted last year by the Legislature at Albany.
LONDON, July 17 -- About a thousand British children will start learning to read in September with a new alphabet system that almost entirely scraps letters having more than one sound.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., July 17 (AP) -- This city's newly elected Councilwoman, Mrs. Lucy Wilson toured the beaches yesterday, and then warned that drastic changes must be made within forty-eight hours. She said that if the "chaotic" conditions were not improved, she would demand that the beaches be closed.

Looking relaxed and happy alter a busy week, President Mohammad Ayub Khan of Pakistan said yesterday he would leave for home today with an impression of "spontaneous warmth and friendship" shown him by the American people.

The Westinghouse Electric Corporation reported yesterday that its profits in the first half of 1961 fell 51.6 per cent from the 1960 level, which included the second-best first quarter and the record second quarter in the company's history.
Governor Rockefeller was urged yesterday to convene a special session of the Legislature in August to start a fall-out shelter program for the state.
Airlines fares in Western Europe, already higher than those on comparable routes in the United States, will be increased 5 per cent Nov. 1.

CHICAGO, July 17 (AP) Seeded players, led by Bernard (Tut) Bartzen of Dallas, No. 1, and Chuck McKinley of St. Ann, Mo., No. 2, advanced today through the first round of the national clay court tennis tournament.
Behind the reduced confidence in the pound sterling is the fact that the British have been living beyond their means relative to the rest of the world, buying more abroad than they have been selling.

LONDON, July 17 (Reuters) -- Britain's movie industry may be faced with a complete shutdown of its major studios if 800 film and television technicians do not withdraw a two-week-old ban on overtime, film producers said here tonight.

LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., July 17 -- Mrs. Arnold Wasserman and Tom Devine of the Seawane Harbor Club shot a 71 -- 7 -- 64 and won the Long Island Professional Golf Association's lady-pro tournament at the Piping Rock Club today.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., July 17 (AP) -- This city's newly elected Councilwoman, Mrs. Lucy Wilson toured the beaches yesterday, and then warned that drastic changes must be made within forty-eight hours. She said that if the "chaotic" conditions were not improved, she would demand that the beaches be closed.

Looking relaxed and happy alter a busy week, President Mohammad Ayub Khan of Pakistan said yesterday he would leave for home today with an impression of "spontaneous warmth and friendship" shown him by the American people.

The Westinghouse Electric Corporation reported yesterday that its profits in the first half of 1961 fell 51.6 per cent from the 1960 level, which included the second-best first quarter and the record second quarter in the company's history.

An international professional sports car racing circuit has been formed by three of the largest racing plants in the West -- The Continental Divide Raceway of Denver and the Riverside and Laguna Seca (Monterey) courses in California.
Following is the text of a statement on the political situation issued yesterday by Mayor Wagner:
A fire that was started yesterday to demonstrate the efficiency of a new foam fire- extinguishing system confirmed the effectiveness of another quencher -- water.
City pigeons were pictured as a health menace by Mt. Sinai Hospital yesterday. Employes were ordered to discontinue feeding them.

After reviewing your article by John Sibley in The Times of July 5 I feel obligated to answer the unwarranted criticism and correct the misinterpretation of the urban renewal situation here in Binghamton.

BONN, Germany, July 18 -- The six nations making up the European Common Market took a new step toward European unity today by agreeing on an organized system of future political cooperation and consultation.
GENEVA, July 18 -- The impasse at the nine-week-old conference on Laos appeared to be ended tonight.
Mayor Wagner urged a six-point program for reform within the Democratic party yesterday as he committed himself and his running mates to a continuing war against "invisible government of the bosses."

A block of 385,000 common shares of American Photocopy Equipment Company, Evanston, Ill., is being offered today by certain stockholders through Lehman Brothers and associates at $33.25 a share. An additional 50,000 shares are being offered representing new financing.

ST. LOUIS, July 18 (AP) -- Bill White belted a home run, two singles, two triples and a double in helping the St. Louis Cardinals beat the Chicago Cubs, 8-2 and 7-5, in a twilight-night double-header tonight. White tied a 49-year-old major league batting record in the process.
Earnings of Stokely-Van Camp, Inc., totaled $6,030,000 in its fiscal year ended on May 31, nearly double the $3,456,419 cleared in the preceding fiscal year, the company reported yesterday.

LONDON, July 18 -- The three Allied notes to the Soviet Union on West Berlin and Germany, made public today, were generally approved by politicians and diplomats tonight as a firm and sensible preliminary position.
WASHINGTON, July 18 -- The difficulties at the Department of State in Foggy Bottom these days are a mystery only if you keep your mind on the fog.

LOS ANGELES, July 18 (AP) -- Lee and George Thomas, the unrelated Los Angeles rookies, slammed a homer apiece tonight as the Angels took eighth place from the Minnesota Twins by defeating them. 4 -- 1.

The long-range interests of the United States -- not to mention the much less important question of the prestige of the Kennedy Administration -- have suffered a serious blow with the outrageous vote in the Rules Committee of the House of Representatives yesterday to shelve Federal aid to the public schools along with other aid-to-education legislation.

The Mead Corporation, a major paper and paperboard manufacturer, with headquarters in Dayton, Ohio, and M. Lowenstein Sons, Inc., the country's largest producer of printed cotton fabrics, are looking into opportunities for joint expansion in the textile field through the combined use of techniques of both concerns.

WASHINGTON, July 18 (AP) -- A new general farm-aid bill was tentatively approved by the House Agriculture Committee today. Its backers said that its aim was to assure stability, reduce farm surpluses and save Government money.
CINCINNATI, July 18 (AP) -- The Milwaukee Braves reduced Cincinnati's league lead to three and a half games tonight as they halted the Reds for the second straight time, 12 -- 8.
The city's Board of Elections reversed itself yesterday and ordered the use of voting machines in the Democratic primary Sept. 7.

The following quotations are selling prices in United States dollars and cents for free market banknote transactions at New York. These rates do not apply to regular foreign exchange business transacted by banks.
Paperboard production rose to 245,221 tons last week from 202,725 tons in the preceding week, the National Paperboard Association reported yesterday. In the 1960 week 248,079 tons were produced.

One thousand and seventy-eight persons were injured in automobile accidents in the city last week, the Police Safety Bureau reported yesterday. This was thirty-one fewer than in the comparable period in 1960.

FAIRFIELD, Conn., July 18 -- There will be subtle and major changes in the football Giants this fall. Here at training camp there is already a new look to the way the team will be trained and prepared for the coming campaign.
WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., July 18 -- Four youngsters won the right today to represent the metropolitan area in the United States Golf Association's junior championship.

WASHINGTON, July 18 -- The chairman of the Government Operations Committee said today that the multiplicity of Senate committee units, which do 90 per cent of the work on bills, was overburdening members and hampering the legislative process.
A thirty-three-story office tower uninterrupted by setbacks will rise at the northwest corner of Third Avenue and Thirty-ninth Street.

TOKYO, July 18 -- Premier Hayato Ikeda brought most of his major political rivals into his Cabinet today, creating one of the strongest Japanese Governments since the end of World War II. A "Government of heavyweights" was the way Japanese political specialists summed up the changes.

BUENOS AIRES, July 18 (AP) -- David Patrick Rusk, son of Secretary of State Dean Rusk, disclosed today that he and the daughter of a wealthy Argentine physician and rancher were married here last Wednesday.
Motors and aircrafts were relatively strong yesterday in a market that had little to cheer about. Aggregate market value of all stocks on the New York Stock Exchange fell three-fifths of 1 per cent.

KINGS POINT, L. I. July 18 -- The giant drill hall of the United States Merchant Marine Academy will be transformed into a colorful marine grotto when the North Shore Hospital sponsors its twelfth annual ball, "Soiree dans Le Mer," on Nov. 25.
The shipping industry suffered a setback yesterday in its fight to defeat President Kennedy's reorganization plan for the Federal maritime agencies.

Repenting of a bad decision with record speed, the Board of Elections agreed unanimously yesterday to use voting machines in the Sept. 7 Democratic primary. As recently as last Thursday James M. Power, president of the four-member board, was explaining how the board had no choice but to use paper ballots all around. "Who's to say which primary is most important?" he asked then.
WASHINGTON, July 18 -- As economic recovery continued, the combined personal incomes of all Americans rose sharply in June to a record annual rate of $416,700,000,000.

PARIS, July 18 -- A meeting of the foreign ministers of the United States, Britain and France in Paris in the first week of August will be primarily concerned with assessing Soviet reaction to yesterday's Western notes on the Berlin problem, according to French sources.

MERANO, Italy, July 18 -- The old Tyrolean glanced distrustfully at an Italian girl in lilac slacks and high-heeled gold sandals as she climbed a steep path with a transistor radio in her hand. He took his tasseled pipe from his mouth, spat and muttered: "They just do not belong to our mountains."

United Funds, Inc., reported yesterday that "a generally higher level of security prices combined with record sales pushed total assets of the four domestic funds in the group to a new peak" at the end of the first half of 1961 "despite heavier than normal redemptions."
CHICAGO, July 18 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
AN essential clue was overlooked in the play of this deal. It only cost an overtrick, but the deal occurred in a tournament and the trick had a considerable effect on the score.
TBILISI, U.S.S.R., July 18 (AP) -- Soviet weightlifters won the fourth and final match against their American opponents today at Tbilisi's Sports Palace, 4 -- 3.

The nation's public utility industry is facing the problem of "a house divided." That was indicated yesterday when the American Gas Association announced a joint research program with General Dynamics Corporation's General Atomic division to develop a generator that would convert gas into electricity.

WASHINGTON, July 18 -- The United States has warned the Soviet Union that it will defend its rights in Berlin. In a note to Moscow, the United States also challenged Premier Khrushchev to negotiate a German settlement on the basis of self-determination.

William C. Chanler in his letter published July 6 calls for a "true fusion administration" and urges that "the head of the ticket should, if possible, be an independent Democrat." Having given fusion this political tinge, Mr. Chanler states that Mayor Wagner has demonstrated "independence of the organized political leaders, * * * particularly during the last several weeks."

There has been put before the Federal Maritime Board a case to test whether "self-policing," the latest vogue in steamship conferences, will become authorized high fashion within the steamship industry.
A cloister-like garden behind the Church of St. John the Baptist, 210 West Thirty-first Street, looked like an annex of Noah's Ark for a while yesterday.

GREENWICH, Conn., July 18 Mrs. Bruce McGhie of Apawamis, the defender, and two other former winners advanced to the second round of the Women's Tri-County Golf Association's tournament today at the Round Hill Country Club.
SAIGON, Vietnam, July 18 -- The United States and South Vietnam have reached "a standby agreement" to meet the Communist threat in South Vietnam.
Following are biographical sketches of the three women killed in the plane crash in Jackson Heights yesterday:
Corporate bonds of prime rank vied with United States Government obligations for the leading position in the bond market yesterday.
CHARLOTTE, N.C., July 18 (UPI) -- Integrationist forces here scored a major victory today when the school board ordered the integration of three elementary schools.
Prices of cotton futures moved 15 cents a bale up to $1.40 off yesterday. Old October showed the only gain.
VERSAILLES, France, July 18 (AP) -- Kel Nagle of Australia took a one-stroke lead today in the second round of the French open golf championship.
A country preacher in Paducah, Ky., has begun a foreign aid mission of shipload magnitude and made the world his parish.
WASHINGTON, July 18 -- The Senate Foreign Relations Committee ordered sweeping revisions today in President Kennedy's long-range foreign aid program.
BAGHDAD, Iraq, July 17 -- Cheering, singing and laughter disrupted for a while today a ceremony during celebrations of the third anniversary of the Iraqi revolution.

ORLEANS, Ind., July 18 (AP) -- Rescue workers floated makeshift survival kits down a twisting underground stream today on the slim chance two students trapped by a flash flood Sunday might still be alive.
LONDON, July 18 -- The stock market here reversed the trend of the last few days and finished with gains in most industrial sections.

Earnings in the quarter ended on June 30 for the American Motors Corporation, the first of the five domestic automobile makers to report results for the period, were less than half of those for the 1960 period. However, profits for the latest quarter were more than triple those of the preceding three months, the company reported yesterday.
VIENNA, July 18 -- The Austrian Cabinet urged the Italian Government and the German-speaking terrorists in Alto Adige today to abandon the use of force and return to peaceful procedures.

WASHINGTON, July 18 (UPI) -- The Defense Department issued new and tighter restrictions today to guard against conflicts of interest by active and retired military officers and employes of the department.

LEWES, Del., July 18 -- There's no doubt that this fishing business keeps getting more complicated. There used to be a time when all a fellow had to do was to bait a hook at the end of a line and toss it into the drink.

The New Rochelle School Board argued before the United States Court of Appeals yesterday that a lower court ruling favorable to Negro pupils in New Rochelle might release a flood of complaints from other minority groups, notably Jewish and Italian.
TUNIS, Wednesday, July 19 -- Tunisian troops and civilians besieged the big French base at Bizerte early today. Volunteers were reported to be moving into the French-held Sahara to the south.
WASHINGTON, July 18 (UPI) -- Vice Admiral Hyman G. Rickover, who recently advocated the abolition of the military academies, now proposes to do away with the Air Force.

BONN, Germany, July 18 (AP) -- The West German Defense Ministry reminded the world today that a mighty Communist military ring surrounds Berlin. A survey said about 67,500 troops and more than 1,200 tanks were involved.
TUNIS, July 18 -- The tension between France and Tunisia increased today.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., July 18 -- Henry Mercer's Weatherly achieved her first victory in the 12-meter competition, but Warner Willcox in the International Class and Dick Poole in the Star Class ended sadly behind their kind at the Larchmont Race Week sailing today.

Complaints about "sweatshop" competition from textile producers in the Far East lose some of their effectiveness against the backdrop of wages paid to migrant farm workers in our own cotton fields. A recent report to The Times describes the misery of men, women and children chopping cotton in Arkansas for 30 cents an hour.

BERLIN, July 18 -- A suggestion for the solution of the Berlin problem "in some other way" than the Communist proposal to make West Berlin a free city was featured today in Neues Deutschland, the main East German Communist newspaper.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 18 -- During celebrations of the third anniversary of the Iraqi revolution Premier Kassim has often seemed like a cheerleader attempting frantically to stir up disinterested schoolmates.
LONDON, July 18 -- Britain's new Ambassador to the United States, David Ormsby-Gore, said tonight that the greatest need of the West was for greater unity in the struggle against communism.

LONDON, July 18 -- The British Government will draw a substantial sum from the International Monetary Fund as part of its emergency measures to strengthen the pound and correct unfavorable economic trends.
Louis J. Lefkowitz toured Harlem tenements yesterday and served notice that he would see to it they were cleaned up.
TURIN, Italy, July 18 (AP) Ryszard Parulski of Poland defeated Jeno Kamuti of Hungary in a fence-off tonight and won the foil championship in the world fencing tournament.
ALBANY, July 18 -- The State Law Department prepared today "a long series" of recommendations for Attorney General Lefkowitz on how to deal with the Newburgh welfare program.
The massive road-building program for the 1964-65 World's Fair will entail three years of traffic snarls for motorists traveling through Queens, Robert Moses reported yesterday.
Chalvedele, the filly with the most recent stakes performance, had little trouble turning back seven rivals yesterday in the $7,500 Elm Point Purse at Aqueduct.
MAURER ORIGINALS, designer of wedding gowns for Saks-34th, has eliminated ruffles and tiers from its fall collection and is now advocating the look of simple elegance for brides.
WASHINGTON, JULY 18 (AP) -- More than seventy instances of trouble with hydraulic systems on Douglas DC-8 jet transports have been reported by the Federal Aviation Agency.

Trustees of the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad's 4 per cent first mortgage bonds and of its Harlem River division 4 1/4 per cent first mortgage bonds have formally notified the company they consider the issues due and payable, now that the carrier is in bankruptcy.
Thirty-one landlords of slum buildings on West Eighty- fourth Street were told at City Hall yesterday to clean up their properties promptly or go to jail.

YOUTHFUL square dancers have their choice of several dances this week sponsored by the Department of Parks. A square dance will be held this evening at 8:30 at Wollman Memorial Skating Rink, in Central Park, and at 8 P.M. at Victory Field, Forest Park Queens; Friday at 8 P.M. at Washington Square Park, and Saturday at 8:30 P.M. at Riverside Park. Admission is free.
WASHINGTON, July 18 -- President Kennedy asked Congress today to authorize the creation by the Public Health Service of two new institutes dealing with child care and general medicine.

ALBANY, July 18 -- Eight up-state lawyers were suspended from practice today for violating the Federal income tax laws. Among them were a former Assistant State Attorney General and a former District Attorney.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., July 18 -- Officials of New Rochelle said today they would protest in Albany on Thursday against a reduction from $2,600,000 to $187,000 in the assessed valuation of the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad's properties here.

The approval given by a Senate Committee to President Kennedy's plan for reorganizing the National Labor Relations Board is a contribution to harmonious industrial relations. The plan for speedier handling of unfair labor practice cases will automatically go into effect at midnight Sunday if neither house of Congress vetoes it.

The Murchison brothers of Dallas, Tex., who won control of the Alleghany Corporation in a bitter proxy contest this spring, yesterday reorganized the board of directors of Investors Diversified Services, Inc., the Minneapolis investment company complex that Alleghany controls.

Governor Rockefeller's office promised yesterday that the State Harness Racing Commission would "carefully scrutinize" the proposed purchase by Yonkers Raceway of controlling interest in Roosevelt Raceway.

In a day of revolt against precedent, a revolt as reckless as it is surprising, the New York County Republican organization has designated not only a woman as its candidate for Borough President of Manhattan, but also a woman who happens to be white and furthermore one who is a Protestant. She is Mrs. Dorothy Bell Lawrence, now serving her second term in the State Assembly from a district on the mid-Manhattan East Side.
WASHINGTON, July 18 -- Now that the first salvos have been exchanged between Moscow and the West, the shape of the coming Berlin crisis is beginning to appear in rough outline.
The development of "a bomb-less atomic bomb" was announced yesterday by United Nuclear Corporation's development division at White Plains.
A $200,000,000 issue of Shell Oil Company 4 5/8 per cent sinking fund debentures due 1986 is being offered to the public today. It is priced at 99 3/4 per cent to yield about 4.64 per cent.
Arrangements have been completed for the return of the Old Vic Company to the United States for its fifth visit here.
Five hundred flight engineers of Pan American World Airways will be free to strike at midnight tonight unless Federal mediators win an accord between the engineers union and the airline today.

WASHINGTON, July 18 -- The president of the American Medical Association defended his organization's political role today. At the same time he called on one of its most recent critics, Senator Estes Kefauver, to retract an "unwarranted slur" on the association's publishing policies.

WASHINGTON, July 18 -- President Joaquin Balaguer of the Dominican Republic has informed the Organization of American States that he would welcome the return of its investigators to help bring about the lifting of sanctions imposed on his country last year.
GREENWICH, Conn., July 18 -- Ben Costello and Al (Red) Compo of Mill River, Conn., won the team title in the Ike golf tournament today with a combined 290.

WASHINGTON, July 18 -- A proposed Presidential message to Congress warning of an impending national transportation crisis has been held back until next year, partly because of friction in the White House staff.
Since Karl Theodor von Guttenberg probably speaks for the party in power in West Germany, his rejection of my proposal for an all-German settlement is significant.
CHICAGO, July 18 (AP) -- Bob Mark of Australia, the top foreign player, lost in the first round today of the national clay courts tennis tournament.
WASHINGTON, July 18 -- President Kennedy called the Joint Chiefs of Staff to the White House for a special conference late today and ordered a meeting of the National Security Council for tomorrow.
There appear to be two distinct parts to the biological motor system controlling movements of the human eye, a British psychophysiologist said here yesterday.
STUTTGART, Germany, July 18 -- The United States touring track and field team took a 56 -- 50 lead over West Germany tonight after ten events.
CHICAGO, July 18 (AP) -- In the best show of buoyancy on the Board of Trade in a week, futures prices for soybeans and most grains registered broad gains today.
The Navy invaded Manhattan yesterday when thousands of midshipmen and sailors "hit the beach" during their annual summer cruise.
LONDON, July 18 -- Britain's progress toward the European Common Market appeared tonight to have slowed to a walk as a result of Commonwealth opposition.

WASHINGTON, July 18 (AP) -- Senator Joseph S. Clark told the Senate tonight that "faceless men" and "anonymous assassins" had failed in an effort to get President Kennedy to dismiss Chester Bowles as Under Secretary of State.
Ron Cochran is leaving television news to become the host of "Armstrong Circle Theatre."
WASHINGTON, July 18 -- Senator Barry Goldwater said today that he would like to see the welfare program of Newburgh, N.Y., adopted by every city in the country.

A look at Anglo-American relations and the world situation is taken by Lionel Gelber in "America In Britain's Place: The Leadership of the West and Anglo-American Unity." Mr. Gelber most recently served as Special Assistant to the Prime Minister of Canada.
LONDON, July 18 (Reuters) -- Charle, Creed, who was the first of London's top couturiers to show his fall collection, today brought back a more fitted look.
WASHINGTON, July 18 (UPI) -- The Senate's chaplain and six other persons were slightly hurt today when a heavy temporary wall collapsed just outside the Senate chamber.
WASHINGTON, July 18 -- The Senate approved today Administration plans to build the world's biggest nuclear power plant in conjunction with a new plutonium-production reactor at Hanford, Wash.

WASHINGTON, July 18 (UPI) -- An Alabama restaurant chain told the Interstate Commerce Commission today that anti-segregation regulations would drive it, and similar companies serving Southern bus terminals, out of business.
Terms of the settlement that ended a two-day strike last week by Local 153, Office Employes International Union against Hellenic Lines, Ltd., were made public here yesterday.
Mayor Wagner "urgently" recommended last night that Joseph R. Weiss be removed as Deputy Superintendent of Schools in charge of buildings.

The Report Realty Corporation has bought the apartment house for fifty-eight families at 2760 Grand Concourse, southeast corner of Miriam Street, the Bronx. The property, with a plot 105 by 143 feet, was sold by a client of Eliot Austern, lawyer, subject to mortgages amounting to $261,000.

The International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation plans to acquire the remainder of the outstanding stock of the American Cable and Radio Corporation, the two concerns announced yesterday. International Telephone now owns 56.55 per cent of the stock of American Cable.

The nation's largest manufacturer of paperboard products and two leading makers of paper-based containers and boxes reported yesterday that results in the first half of 1961 were not quite as good as those of the 1960 period.

CHICAGO, July 18 (AP) -- Nellie Fox snapped a prolonged slump tonight with two hits, one a two-run triple in the seventh inning that led the Chicago White Sox to a 4-3 victory over the Kansas City Athletics.
A New York City banker has recommended that the Federal Reserve Board apply "country bank" reserve requirements to the first $150,000,000 of demand deposits in any bank.
Summertime lethargy prevailed yesterday on most New York commodities exchanges and trading was dull. Prices moved in narrow ranges and volume was small.
GENEVA, July 18 -- Belkacem Krim returned here by air today to lead the Algerian rebel Government's delegation again at the peace talks with France.

The R.J. Reynolds Tobacco Company registered the highest sales and earnings for any quarter and half-year in its history in the three and six months ended on June 30, Alexander H. Galloway, president, reported yesterday.
LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, July 18 -- The presidents of the Congolese Parliament's two chambers asked all Senators and Deputies today to convene here tomorrow.
Distress sale -- everything must go."

WASHINGTON, July 18 (UPI) -- Two members of the American Medical Association's Council on Drugs criticized organized medicine today for opposing Government testing to determine whether new drugs met advertised claims as to their efficacy.
The million-dollar mark has been reached in Lincoln Center's drive for seat endowments.
COCOA BEACH, Fla., Wednesday, July 19 -- The 290-mile rocket flight to be undertaken by Air Force Capt. Virgil I. Grissom has been reset for 9 A.M., Eastern Daylight Time today.
A wide investigation of charges of motor vehicle fraud has been ordered by Motor Vehicle Commissioner William S. Hults.
RIDGEWOOD, N.J., July 18 -- Mrs. Katharine L. Auchincloss has returned the $100 she was awarded for excellence in academic work to the School of General Studies at Columbia University.
President Mohammad Ayub Khan of Pakistan left for home yesterday after a week's visit with United States officials to strengthen economic and other ties with his country.

Mrs. Angier Biddle Duke, wife of the State Department's Chief of Protocol, two other socially prominent women and a pilot were killed yesterday when their chartered plane crashed in residential Jackson Heights, Queens.
Sales of the nation's leading retail store chains in the first half of 1961 rose by 2.8 per cent from the level of the 1960 period, according to a survey completed yesterday by The New York Times.

WASHINGTON, July 18 (AP) -- Following are the texts of a United States note to the Soviet Union replying to a Soviet aide-memoire of June 4 on Berlin and Germany, and of the United States-British-Soviet protocol of Sept. 12, 1944, setting up Allied zones in Germany, which was attached to the United States note:

In solemn notes addressed as much to the world at large as to Soviet Russia, the principal countries of the North Atlantic alliance -- United States, Britain and France -- have now set forth their position in the mounting Berlin crisis. They base their stand on two propositions which should find the acclaim and support of free men everywhere -- and of many who are not free.
MacCombs Dam Park near Yankee Stadium in the Bronx is held to be private "turf" by youths from the Highbridge housing project a few blocks away.
FLORENCE, Italy, July 18 -- In his "addi'o" to Italy, Roberto Capucci made sure his last collection in the Pitti Palace would arouse a final emotional crescendo. It did.

Youngstown Sheet and The Tube Company covered its $1.25 dividend in the second quarter for the first time since the comparable quarter of 1960, according to the report issued yesterday for the quarter and six months ended with June.

LOS ANGELES, July 18 -- Baseball managing, as most everyone by now must know, has been perhaps the most hazardous and short-lived form of occupation known to man. You are here today and maybe tomorrow you are still here, but no longer the manager. If you're lucky enough to work for an indulgent boss, you may still be on the payroll, but merely to tell stories, pour drinks and provide laughs.

George B. McGuire has joined the Badger Manufacturing Company as vice president and construction manager. Before joining the Cambridge, Mass., petroleum and chemical engineering and manufacturing company he had been assistant director of the Esso Research and Engineering Company.
Edward Schwartz, builder and realty investor, has leased the property at the southwest corner of Third Avenue and Forty-fourth Street for improvement with a store and office building.

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), July 18 -- Adolf Eichmann admitted today that the disposal of the children of Lidice and the supplying of 150 skeletons of Jews for Heinrich Himmler's skull collection had been matters referred to him.

WASHINGTON, July 18 -- Mickey Mantle paced the Yankees to a 5-3 victory over the Senators tonight with his continued heavy slugging. He blasted two homers, good for three runs, and moved into a tie with his team-mate.
MINEOLA, L.I., July 18 -- The Federal Aviation Agency recommended today that Nassau County establish a public airport for general aviation at Mitchel Air Force Base.
BABYLON, L.I., July 18 -- John (Hap) Fauth clinched the Great South Bay Yacht Racing Association's junior championship today.
SARANAC LAKE, N.Y., July 18 -- The state Board of Social Welfare asked the state Attorney General today to take legal action to prevent Newburgh from enforcing its new welfare code.

OKLAHOMA CITY, July 18 (UPI) -- A lie detector test proved inconclusive today on a former convict who said he had unintentionally caused a 1937 Texas school explosion that killed 293 students and teachers.
A swarm of bees that kept lunch-hour crowds at a distance descended on a truck yesterday in front of 85 Pearl Street in lower Manhattan.

A twenty-five-ton crane-truck -- the same vehicle from which a 500-pound iron ball snapped last Friday and killed a worker -- toppled yesterday from the platform of a moving trailer in midtown and crushed part of a taxicab.
The Cerebral Palsy Recreation Center will receive the proceeds of a supper dance on Sept. 21 at the St. Regis.

One of the world's highest concrete arch structures, the Karadj Dam in northern Iran, is nearing completion. Situated forty miles from Teheran, the dam is being built for the Iranian Government by Morrison-Knudsen International Constructors, Inc., an overseas operating subsidiary of Morrison-Knudsen Company, Inc., of Boise, Idaho.
HABIB BOURGUIBA, President of Tunisia, was described during his eleven-day trip to the United States in May as one of the most admired and respected leaders of African nationalism.

AN audience of 8,500, equal to the largest of the season, assembled at Lewisohn Stadium last night when Stadium Concerts' opened its annual Beethoven cycle. Josef Krips, who has led the cycles of the last three summers, was again the presiding spirit on the podium.

WASHINGTON, July 18 (AP) -- Washington's exclusive Metropolitan Club, recently criticized by Attorney General Robert F. Kennedy for its racial policies, has admitted a man who is believed to be the first Negro guest in is history.
WASHINGTON, July 18 -- The House Rules Committee dealt an all-but-fatal blow today to the Administration's $2,484,000,000 school-aid bill.
The Cerebral Palsy Recreation Center will receive the proceeds of a supper dance on Sept. 21 at the St. Regis.

One of the world's highest concrete arch structures, the Karadj Dam in northern Iran, is nearing completion. Situated forty miles from Teheran, the dam is being built for the Iranian Government by Morrison-Knudsen International Constructors, Inc., an overseas operating subsidiary of Morrison-Knudsen Company, Inc., of Boise, Idaho.
HABIB BOURGUIBA, President of Tunisia, was described during his eleven-day trip to the United States in May as one of the most admired and respected leaders of African nationalism.

AN audience of 8,500, equal to the largest of the season, assembled at Lewisohn Stadium last night when Stadium Concerts' opened its annual Beethoven cycle. Josef Krips, who has led the cycles of the last three summers, was again the presiding spirit on the podium.
CLEVELAND, July 18 (AP) -- Gary Gieger belted two home runs and drove in four runs to power the Boston Red Sox to a 9-2 victory over the Cleveland Indians tonight.
The Franklin National Bank of Long Island, Mineola, is seeking to rent space for new branches in both downtown and midtown Manhattan, a spokesman for the bank confirmed yesterday.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 18 (AP) -- The operating coordinations proposed by the Southern Pacific if it wins control of the Western Pacific would result in some employment cut, the Southern Pacific said today.

THE colors are hot, the textures are rich, the woods are rare and the accessories are offbeat imports. This in substance describes the decorating of the model rooms and story vignettes that opened yesterday at Abraham Straus.

The directors of the Sheraton Corporation of America have elected George D. Johnson and Joseph M. Curry vice presidents, it was announced yesterday by Ernest Henderson, president of the hotel concern.
Mayor Wagner called on the Public Service Commission yesterday to force a strike-bound private water company to comply with its franchise or face revocation of the franchise.

The One William Street Fund reported yesterday it had net assets of $288,000,000 on June 30, reflecting a gain of $22,000,000 for the first half of 1961. Net assets were $266,000,000 on last Dec. 31 and $269,000,000 on June 30, 1960.
Bobby Fischer defeated Samuel Reshevsky in thirty-eight moves last night at the Manhattan Chess Club. Reshevsky had won the first game of their chess series in sixty games Monday night.
BALTIMORE, July 18 (AP) -- Paul Richards said today in a statement he would manage no club except the Baltimore Orioles.

E.B. Kevins, whose letter appeared on July 8, argued that legislation restricting artificial birth control practices was not an "imposition" of the views of one religious group upon citizens who see things differently.

BUENOS AIRES, July 18 -- A nation-wide twenty-four-hour strike called by Argentina's General Labor Federation paralyzed the bulk of the country's industrial and commercial activity today. No serious incidents or disturbances were reported.

North American Aviation, Inc., showed sharp gains in the fiscal quarter ended on June 30. These gains resulted in advances of 24.5 per cent and 12.2 per cent in sales and earnings for the nine months ended on the same date, the preliminary, unaudited results disclosed yesterday.

ENTERTAINING at dinner during the summer presents a problem for those living in city apartments of limited space. Any elaborate cooking heats the apartment unbearably on a hot day. Two solutions are the cold main dishes such as the poached salmon and jellied veal suggested here.

The Estate Securities Company, representing Alvin A. Lavy and Irving Magot, realty operators, has contracted to buy the six-story apartment building at 34-20 Thirtieth Street, Astoria, Queens. The structurs is on a plot 150 by 100 feet and contains eighty-eight apartments.

WASHINGTON, July 18 -- On the home front in his first six months in office, President Kennedy has kept his campaign promise to "get the country going again," but not nearly so far or so fast as he had hoped.
New York's increasing welfare compensations, a current headache to Albany administrators, will be the subject for an independent film to be made here this fall.
The Pennsylvania State General Authority is planning the sale of $25,000,000 of revenue bonds on Aug. 8. The money will be used to finance public works installations.
WASHINGTON, July 19 -- Following are the main points of President Kennedy's news conference today:

FLORENCE, Italy, July 19 -- Hems dropped at the Pitti Palace last night and so did the applause. A chilly reception greeted the collections of Simonetta and Fabiani, both of whom lifted the waistline (an international trend now) and dropped skirts a good three to four inches, to mid-calf. The audience was shocked.
Mayor Wagner yesterday announced two new programs to improve care in the municipal hospitals.
CLEVELAND, July 19 (AP)--The Cleveland Indians swept a double-header from the Boston Red Sox tonight. They won the opener, 4--1, on Barry Latman's eight-hitter, and took the second game, 9--8.
LOS ANGELES, July 19 (AP) -- The Salle Santelli squad of New York won the women's foil team event last night in the United States fencing championships.
The American Can Company announced yesterday that it would enter the soft drink canning business.
A bright-eyed baby llama is scheduled to go on exhibit in the Children's Zoo of the Bronx Zoo today.

There is now an opportunity to correct the discrimination against American citizens resulting from the Arab League boycott, which began in 1951 and was intended to injure Israel. This can be done through the foreign-aid bill which is about to come to the floor of the Senate.
CHICAGO, July 19 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
The state stepped into the city's school scandal yesterday. Education Commissioner James E. Allen Jr. summoned the Board of Education to meet with him today "to discuss the whole current situation."

PARIS, July 19 -- France blamed Tunisia tonight for the fighting at the Bizerte naval base. According to the French, the first shots were fired by Tunisians at a French helicopter seeking to supply an isolated French post on the perimeter of the base.
Food and lodgings on a bonafide trip for convalescence have been ruled to be not deductible on the Federal income tax by the United States Court of Appeals here.

William B. Jordan 3d has been elected treasurer of Chesebrough-Pond's, Inc., cosmetics, toiletries and proprietaries concern. He was vice president of finance and administration of the S.H. Kress Co. Mr. Jordan succeeds William C. Watson, who continues as vice president-finance and president of Chesebrough-Pond's international division.

WASHINGTON, July 19 -- A banner crowd of 27,126 made the rafters of antiquated Griffith Stadium ring tonight as the humble Senators defeated the haughty Yankees twice, 8 -- 4 and 12 -- 2, in a twilight-night double-header.

PARIS, July 19 -- The French Foreign Ministry announced here today that the Western Big Three's foreign ministers would examine the entire international situation during their three-day conference here early next month.
The city's Department of Marine and Aviation announced yesterday it had denied a permit to a new concern to operate Flushing Airport in Queens.

A rate war is brewing among the railroads, barge operators and common carrier truckers. The Southern Railway System has announced that it will put into effect on Aug. 10, instead of on Aug. 15, rates for movement of grain sharply below those it has been charging.

Directors of the Atlantic Refining Company raised yesterday the quarterly dividend on the common stock by 10 cents with the declaration of 60 cents a share. The dividend will be distributed on Sept. 15 to holders of record of Aug. 21. Shareholders had received 50 cents a share a quarter since 1952.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 19 -- Leaders of various segments of the movie industry, which have often been in dispute, met today in an effort to explore one another's problems without friction.

IN this city where almost every historical building bears a plaque posterity will surely endow 5 via Gregoriana with one. This is the house of Simonetta. As a child, she lived on the top floor with her family.
Stocks fell until noon yesterday, then rallied briskly, gaining momentum toward the close on the New York Stock Exchange and ending at the day's high.
BIZERTE, Tunisia, July 19 -- The French garrison of the Bizerte air and naval base exchanged gunfire today with besieging forces as France reinforced the base with paratroopers.
SCITUATE, Mass., July 19 -- A body washhed ashore here was identified tonight as Alfred H. Renshaw, 39 years old, of 525 East Eighty-fourth Street, New York.

WASHINGTON, July 19 -- Following is the text of a letter sent to all members of Congress by Secretary of State Dean Rusk and Secretary of the Treasury Douglas Dillon on the need for the President's foreign aid program:
WASHINGTON, July 19 -- The House Rules Committee voted today to bar from floor consideration a proposal for a Congressional investigation of the controversial John Birch Society.

ROYSTON, Ga., July 19 (UPI) -- Tyrus Raymond (Ty) Cobb, the first member of baseball's Hall of Fame and the man considered the best player in the history of the game, was entombed today in the red-clay north Georgia hills he loved.

With the July coffee contract nearing its expiration date many traders were shifting to later positions yesterday. Liquidation cut the near-by July "B" coffee contract 123 points in trading on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange.

WESTBURY, L.I., July 19 -- The $40,000 Challenge Cup Trot, featuring a rematch between Su Mac Lad of the United States and Kracovie of France at Roosevelt Raceway Saturday night, will have eight, rather than nine, starters.
WASHINGTON, July 19 (AP) -- Administration spokesmen advocated today Senate approval of President Kennedy's reorganization plan for the Maritime Administration and the Federal Maritime Board.

Savings in New York State's 233 savings and loan associations rose by $70,507,000 in June to $4,555,399,818, according to the Savings Association League of New York State. The June rise was 2.1 per cent greater than the previous record increase for the month, established in 1960.
LONDON, July 19 -- A London industrialist and his company won libel judgments totaling 100,000 ($280,000) today in a suit against The Daily Telegraph.

LOS ANGELES, July 19 (UPI) -- The Minnesota Twins scored all their runs on homers by Bob Allison and Harmon Killebrew as Camilo Pascual struck out fifteen batters tonight in pitching a 6-0 victory over the Los Angeles Angels in the opener of a double-header.

WALTHAM, Mass., July 19 (AP) -- A $500,000 gift from a New York family will give Brandeis University a large, modern art enclave. The new facility is underwritten by a gift from the family of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Goldman of New York and Mrs. Goldman's mother, Mrs. Joseph H. Schwartz.

PHILADELPHIA, July 19 (AP) -- Judge John W. Lord of the United States District Court dismissed today a $1,800,000 triple-damage suit filed nearly five years ago by the Viking Theatre Corporation against twelve motion-picture producers and distributors. Testimony had been heard off and on in the case by a jury of five women and seven men.
LONDON, July 19 (Reuters) -- To fit or not to fit seems to be the question so far in the current showings of London's top couturiers.
SCARSDALE, N.Y., July 19 -- A hands-across-the-sea experiment in goodwill between young people of this village and those of Rheims, France, began today.
On Saturday, Blanche Saunders will be at Carmel, N.Y., where she will judge obedience trials at the Putnam Kennel Club show.
The short interest on the New York Stock Exchange dropped again in the month to July 14, as it had in every month since mid-February.
WASHINGTON, July 19 (AP) -- A strike threat at midnight tonight on the global facilities of Pan American World Airways was reported off.

In a report published in these columns last Saturday, it was stated that the building of The New York World-Telegram and Sun and Loew's Sheridan Theatre were among fourteen properties being offered for sale through Helmsley-Spear, Inc.
Roger L. Stevens, one of Broadway's most active producers, has acquired a play about Clarence Darrow entitled "Defender of the Lost," by Morris Ebenstein, for presentation this fall.
National Investors Corporation wound up its first half year with a new high in net assets and share value, the latter figure running 14.8 per cent higher than at the end of 1960.

PARIS, July 19 (UPI) -- Kel Nagle of Australia tied the La Boulie course record with a seven-under-par 65 in the final round today and won the French open golf championship with a 72-hole score of 271.
EVIAN-LES-BAINS, France, July 19 (Reuters) -- French and Algerian delegates were reported in a somber mood tonight on the eve of resuming peace talks that broke off more than a month ago.

Christopher T. Chenery's strapping 2-year-old, Sir Gaylord, equaled the track record of 1:04 for the Great American Stakes at Aqueduct yesterday when he won the $27,950 feature by two and one-half lengths.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 19 -- An export quota type of agreement for the stabilization of cocoa prices has been circulated in draft form to member governments by the United Nations Cocoa Study Group for examination and comment.

WASHINGTON, July 19 (AP) -- An Ohio inventor won a seven-year patent infringement case today that will enable him to collect from the Government for unauthorized manufacture of so-called anti-blackout devices used by Navy and Air Force pilots.

WASHINGTON, July 19 (UPI) -- Three physicians laid a variety of ills at the door of drug makers today. One was that some companies test new products on humans to eliminate the cost of tryouts with laboratory animals.
WASHINGTON, July 19 -- Following is the text of a statement today by President Kennedy on Germany and Berlin:

BIZERTE, July 19 (Reuters) -- I crouched in a ditch with Tunisian volunteers here tonight as Tunisian troops around us opened fire with rifles and machine guns on about a dozen French transport planes landing at Bizerte air base.
New York business leaders were warned yesterday of a possible postal blackout if the "after 5" logjam of mail were not broken.
PRESIDENT KENNEDY -- I have a statement on Germany and Berlin. I will read a few paragraphs of it and it will be available for distribution right after the press conference.
SAN SALVADOR, July 19 -- The Government declared today it had thwarted a plot for a nation-wide revolt.
The Safety Bureau of the Civil Aeronautics Board yesterday pressed an investigation of the crash of a small taxi-service plane that took four lives here Tuesday.

WASHINGTON, July 19 -- The next time the President decides to transfer Chester A. Bowles to a job more suitable to his considerable talents than that of Under Secretary of State, Mr. Kennedy probably will see to it that his inner advisory circle does not furnish advance billing.

The relief of human misery, as provided by law and prompted by man's social conscience, has become a political football; and the uninvited intervention into the Newburgh conflict by Senator Barry Goldwater, Republican of Arizona, has helped to make it so.
Lehman Brothers and associates are offering to the public today bonds and common shares of Northwest Natural Gas Company valued at $10,245,000.

A Brooklyn Supreme Court justice was asked yesterday to make an interpretation on the distribution of a $22,000,000 estate left by Lester Martin, financier and politician, who died April 24, 1959, at the age of 54.
A BOOK about an important subject is not necessarily an important book. We find that out rather frequently, to our fury or dismay. Or both -- depending on our expenditures of money and time.

CHICAGO, July 19 -- Plans for a joint venture in the Netherlands were disclosed today by the Amoco Chemicals Corporation and Algemene Kunstzijde Unie, N.V., big European Chemicals complex.
MINNEAPOLIS, July 19 -- A balloon described as the largest ever released was launched last night after a major eruption of cosmic rays from the sun. It plummeted to earth about two hours later.
BERLIN, July 19 -- A 20-pfennig (5-cent) ride on the elevated or the subway takes Karl Schmidt of East Berlin to the West.
A group of Democratic State legislators from New York City endorsed the Levitt-Mackell-DiFede ticket in the city campaign yesterday.
National Gypsum Company announced yesterday that it would spend $72,000,000 in the next fourteen years to double the capacity of its huge Huron Portland Cement division's mill at Alpena, Mich.

LONDON, July 19 -- Britain's Foreign Secretary today advocated "quiet, serious, patient" diplomacy "free from the threat of force or the use of force" to find a peaceful solution of the Berlin problem.

The Pezenik Realty Corporation, owner of commercial properties in New York, has bought sixteen acres of land in the Montrose-Crugers area of Westchester County for development.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 19 -- United Nations officials outlined their plans today for protecting the Congolese Parliament session.

WASHINGTON, July 19 -- The Department of Justice took a dim view today of pending legislation to ease the tax effect of the Supreme Court's decision requiring E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., to dispose of its General Motors stock.

WASHINGTON, July 19 -- President Kennedy announced today that he would not attend the inter-American conference in Punta del. Estate, Uruguay, opening Aug. 5, which will take up his Alliance for Progress program.
WASHINGTON, July 19 (AP) -- President Kennedy's sharp acceleration of the United States race for the moon won resounding approval today from a Senate-House conference committee.
The Valley National Bank of Long Island, Valley Stream, has completed negotiations for one merger with a smaller institution and is looking toward another, George Auslander, chairman, said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 19 -- The Peace Corps announced tonight that a training program would begin next Monday at Harvard University to prepare forty-five candidates for possible secondary-school teaching assignments in Nigeria.

LOS ANGELES, July 19 -- According to legend, it was Mohammed who bade the mountain come to him. When, as anyone might have told him, the mountain refused to budge, Mohammed did the next best thing. He went to the mountain.

CHICAGO, July 19 (AP) -- The National Labor Relations Board announced tonight that drivers for Chicago's two major taxicab fleets had elected a reform local as their bargaining agent over a local backed by the Teamsters Union.
Prime debt investments continued in strong demand in an active market yesterday.

Leo Silver Sons, Inc., builders, have purchased the vacant plot 50 by 100 feet at the northeast corner of Third Avenue and Thirty-sixth Street. They owned the adjoining property and now control a site 100 by 100 feet.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 19 (UPI) -- The Southern Pacific Railroad disclosed today that it would save about $3,800,000 a year by eliminating nearly 500 jobs in its proposed consolidation with Western Pacific Railroad.
WASHINGTON, July 19 -- President Kennedy put full responsibility on Premier Khrushchev today if war should break out over Berlin.
WASHINGTON, July 19 -- President Kennedy made clear today that the United States would call upon the Western Allies to join in increased defense measures to cope with the Berlin crisis.
JACKSON, Miss., July 19 -- Dissident Southern Governors took steps today at a conference toward organizing the region's conservatives for political action.
BONN, Germany, July 19 -- A West German Government spokesman said today that there was a "slight trend" toward a European federation.

BIZERTE, Tunisia, July 19 -- The naval air base here, which has become a dangerous area of violence between France and Tunisia, was built at the end of the last century in a French move to control the sea lane from Gibraltar to the Suez.
WASHINGTON, July 19 -- The national economy has been producing goods and services at the record annual rate of $515,000,000,000, President Kennedy reported today.

Failure to let the Cuban underground know what moves were being made abroad in the effort to overthrow Premier Fidel Castro was said yesterday by an underground representative to be the reason for suspension of the leaders of an anti-Castro group here.

Gasoline inventories in the nation declined seasonally by 1,460,000 barrels in the week ended last Friday, according to the American Petroleum Institute. At the week-end total supplies were 197,841,000 barrels, compared with 199,301,000 a week earlier and 197,241,000 a year ago.
DETROIT, July 19 -- The United Automobile Workers has injected the automobile industry's pricing policies into the current labor negotiations.

Overwhelming opposition to renaming Third Avenue the "Avenue of the Promenades" has convinced the Third Avenue Boosters to abandon the plan, a spokesman announced yesterday.

The Douglas Aircraft Company, Inc. continued to show a recovery in earnings in the quarter and six months ended on May 31, despite the fact that sales were far below those of a year earlier, the semi-annual report revealed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 19 (AP) -- Twelve Hollywood writers and actors argued today for a preliminary injunction against major movie producers for an alleged employment blacklist against them for political reasons.
WASHINGTON, July 19 -- President Kennedy expressed hope today that Congress would approve his school-aid program at this session.

Arthur Daley, sports columnist of The New York Times, was named yesterday as the winner of the 1961 Grantland Rice Memorial Award of The Sportsmanship Brotherhood. He will receive the award at a luncheon in the New York University Club, 123 West Forty-third Street, on Wednesday, Nov. 1, the anniversary of Rice's birthday.

The city was warned by its Planning Commission yesterday to widen Fulton Street without delay or face the probability "of being foreclosed forever from providing this vitally needed facility, except at prohibitive cost."

BUENOS AIRES, July 19 (UPI) -- An Argentine Airlines DC-6 crashed in flames during a heavy rainstorm today at Azul. 160 miles south of here. All of the sixty-seven persons aboard, including at least one American, were reported by the provincial police to have been killed
A state legislative committee desirous of tightening the laws against obscene publications in the light of recent court decisions began two days of hearings here yesterday.

SEOUL, Korea, July 19 -- Maj. Gen. Pak Chung Hi, chairman of South Korea's ruling junta, asserted today that the form of the country's future civilian government would be made public before Aug. 15, the anniversary of Korea's liberation from Japanese rule in 1945.
DETROIT, July 19 (UPI) -- Home runs by Jim Gentile and Hank Foiles sparked the Baltimore Orioles to a 4-2 victory over the Detroit Tigers tonight.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, July 19 -- An international plan to save Bolivia's state mining industry with $38,000,000 in foreign credits was brought here today by representative of the Inter-American Development Bank.

Commercial paper dealers announced yesterday a reduction of one-eighth percentage point on these short-term unsecured obligations of business borrowers sold in the open market. The change was effective immediately.
CIUDAD TRUJILLO, Dominican Republic, July 19 (AP) -- Maximo Lopez Molina, Leftist leader of the opposition Popular Dominican Movenment (MPD), has gone into hiding, neighbors said today.
SYOSSET, L.I., July 19 (UP) -- The Fairchild Camera and Instrument Corporation reported today new records in sales and earnings for both the second quarter and first half of 1961.
WASHINGTON, July 19 -- President Kennedy said today that Chester Bowles would remain as Under Secretary of State unless he could be used more effectively in another responsible position.

Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 9 points off to 5 points up yesterday. A point equals 5 cents a bale.
LONDON, July 19 -- Mort Sahl made his British debut tonight on a British Broadcasting Corporation television program.
WASHINGTON, July 19 (UPI) -- The State Department, in an economy move, noticed its employes today that they would have to travel tourist class on trans-Atlantic jet flights.

NEWBURGH, N.Y., July 19 -- Enforcement of this city's "get tough" policy in handling relief recipients will proceed slowly because of what City Manager Joseph McD. Mitchell said today was a shortage of personnel in the welfare and legal departments.
WASHINGTON, July 19 -- President Kennedy conceded today the gravity of the birth-control problem of the under-developed nations. He avoided, however, a commitment to help solve it.

WASHINGTON, July 19 (UPI) -- Private housing starts increased 6 per cent in June to a sixteen-month high, the Census Bureau reported today.
St. Petersburg, Fla., is planning the sale of $14,000,000 of sewer revenue bonds on Aug. 8. The issue will come due serially from 1967 to 1991.

PHILADELPHIA, July 19 (UPI) -- Lee Walls' ninth-inning single gave the Phillies a 2 -- 1 victory over the Milwaukee Braves in the finale of a twilight-night double-header tonight. The Braves hammered out an 8 -- 5 victory in the opener.
The City Planning Commission pushed forward a massive series of urban renewal, housing and conservation projects yesterday.
SOUTH BEND, Ind., July 19 (UPI) -- Associates Investment Company announced today it completed the purchase of Federal Finance, Inc., an Indianapolis sales finance company, on July 6.
CINCINNATI, July 19 (AP) -- The Los Angeles Dodgers reduced Cincinnati's league lead to two and a half games tonight as they handed the slumping Reds their fourth straight defeat, 8 -- 3.
WASHINGTON, July 19 (AP) -- The Government announced today that it would put up for sale 500 long tons of pig tin next month. A long ton equals 2,240 pounds.
BERLIN, July 19 -- Thousands of East German Christians braved a Communist ban today and poured into Berlin churches for services opening a large all-German Evangelical Church congress here.
CHICAGO, July 19 -- Plans for a series of "air-right" office buildings, which if all are completed would cost more than $200,000,000, were announced today.

VALLEY STREAM, L.I. July 19 -- A musician who has played with the Valley Stream Community Band for the last eight years is in need of fifty pints of blood to enable him to undergo open-heart surgery in the fall.
WASHINGTON, July 19 (AP) -- A bill that would require more extensive financial reports to the Government on welfare and pension funds was approved unanimously today by a House Labor subcommittee.

Net income of the Allegheny Ludlum Steel Corporation in the second quarter of 1961 was $2,860,892 or 73 cents a share. This was double the first quarter's net of $1,432,000, or 37 cents a share. It was well above the recession level of second-quarter 1960 when the net was only $741,000 or 19 cents a share.
NEW HAVEN, July 19--The bankrupt New Haven Railroad is appealing again for a loan guaranteed by the Federal Government to keep it in operation.

UTICA, N.Y., July 19 (AP) -- Oneida County's Welfare Commissioner said today his department had begun legal moves against welfare chiselers that would "achieve as much as, or more than, the Newburgh Welfare Department is attempting to do."
WASHINGTON, July 19--President Kennedy upheld today the right of American citizens to move in interstate commerce "for whatever reasons they travel."
WASHINGTON, July 19 (UPI) -- The Defense Department opposed today a proposal that would withhold Federal funds from National Guard units practicing racial segregation.

Mayor Wagner last night dismissed Philip H. Gilsten, a Democratic leader in the Bronx, from his $15,000-a-year post as Deputy City Treasurer. JERUSALEM, (Israeli Sector), July 19 -- Adolf Eichmann refused today a last chance to say that his wartime offer to exchange 1,000,000 Jews for 10,000 army trucks had been motivated by compassion.

STUTTGART, Germany, July 19 -- The touring United States track and field team won eight of ten events today and trounced West Germany as expected in the two-day meet. The final score was 120-91. The Americans had won six of ten events yesterday, taking a 56-50 lead.

BERLIN, July 19 (UPI) -- The United States Army announced today a reorganization of its command in West Berlin to give more emphasis to the training of its 5,000-man garrison there.

A device for following in detail the movement of an object through the human digestive tract was described here yesterday by a Swedish scientist.
WASHINGTON, July 19 (AP) -- The Senate Labor Committee voted today to impose criminal penalties on a member of a Communist organization if he applied for or used a Federal scholarship loan.

GREENWICH, Conn., July 19 -- Two extra-hole matches highlighted the second round of the Women's Tri-County Golf Association's eleventh annual golf championship today.
