LONDON, July 19 -- After a hesitant start, prices moved upward on the stock market here today.

The National Broadcasting Company has resumed its efforts to arrange a one-hour television show featuring the music of Alan Jay Lerner and Frederick Loewe. It would be produced by Alfred Productions, Inc., a company owned by the music collaborators.
RIO DE JANEIRO, July 19 -- President Janio Quadros received a Soviet goodwill mission today in Brasilia.

LONDON, July 19 -- A ground station that will serve as part of the Midas missile-defense alarm system being developed by the United States will be built at the Royal Air Force station at Kirkbride, in Cumberland, it was announced today.

Red Star of Yugoslavia routed Petah Tikva of Israel, 7 -- 0, and Rapid of Austria defeated The Shamrock Rovers of Dublin, 3 -- 1, in the International Soccer League double-header at the Polo grounds last night.

TRENTON, July 19. -- A neighborly pooling of services of nonprofit voluntary hospitals to reduce duplication and improve patient care was described in a study report here today by the New Jersey Hospital Association.
Mayor Wagner and two of the rivals for his job have asked to be witnesses at today's public hearing on draft proposals for a new City Charter.
MOSCOW, July 19 -- Soviet fears that the Berlin crisis may be slipping out of control have become evident.

EXAMINATION of a whole vanilla bean discloses one spot where there is a pattern of tiny holes. This is not a natural defect, but is purely man-made. It is actually a brand mark made by the grower of that bean in Madagascar, the world's major supplier, according to a spokesman for the island's farmers.

AS many as 50,000 to 75,000 well-intentioned American parents are having swimming pools built in their back yards each year. While increasing their families' pleasure, they also are adding to the nation's tragedy rate because many parents fail to instill the basic tenets of pool safety in children.
The Angels Ball, an annual event of the New York Section of the National Council of Jewish Women, will take place Nov. 2 in the Grand Ballroom of the Astor.
CHICAGO, July 19 (AP) -- Short interests Began scrambling to even up their commitments in July soybeans today and bid the price up 9 cents a bushel on the Board of Trade.

This is about the time of year when the lady of the house, going into the cellar in search of insecticide for the roses and being unable to find any, will decide that the cellar needs reorganization and a good cleaning.

Most of the old-fashioned railway hand cars that were pumped up and down the rails by "gandy-dancers" gave way a generation ago on many railroads to gasoline-driven track motor cars. Now the Erie-Lackawanna Railroad is replacing the motor cars with closed-cab pickup trucks ca pable of traveling on either railroad tracks or highways.

WASHINGTON, July 19 -- The Administration made an urgent appeal today to all members of Congress for President Kennedy's foreign aid program. It came on the eve of a voting showdown in the Senate Foreign Relations Committee.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 19--Austria has again asked the United Nations to take up her smoldering dispute with Italy over Alto Adige.
Nine operators of Greenwich Village coffee houses were convicted yesterday in Manhattan Arrest Court of operating cabarets without licenses. They were involved in a total of 110 cases.
LARCHMONT, N.Y., July 19 -- Columbia won a 13-mile 12-Meter race on Long Island Sound today, with Easterner and Weatherly close behind. The 23-year-old Nyala was fourth and last.
CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., July 19 -- Capt. Virgil I. Grissom spent four hours atop a Red-stone missile today, ready for a ride into space that was blocked by an abrupt build-up of tropical clouds.

BANGKOK, Thailand, July 19 -- Foreign Minister Thanat Khoman of Thailand quietly but forcefully told the West today that because of an increased Communist threat in Southeast Asia, Thailand might have to re-examine her "exposed position" as well as her obligations, "which have become one-sided."

In 1912 then murder of the gambler Herman Rosenthal and the subsequent investigation exposed police graft, underworld violence and political chicanery in New York City. Involved in the case were Police Lieut. Charles Becker, considered "America's first modern underworld czar," and Charles Whitman, the District Attorney who destroyed him.

They're bringing the six-day bicycle race back to Madison Garden in September Square after an absence of twenty-one years. When the announcement was made during a luncheon at Leone's yesterday, nostalgia immediately mounted his bike and rode riot.

Electric power production rose to 15,071,000,000 kilowatthours last week from 14,133,00O.O0O kilowatt-hours the week before, the Edison Electric Institute reported yesterday. A year ago the figure was 14,608,000,000 kilowatt-hours.
WESTPORT, Conn., July 19 -- Four teen-agers are operating a radio station this summer from a makeshift and cluttered one-room studio on the top floor of the Y.M.C.A. here.
A ninety-day stay in the electrocution of Salvador Agron, which had been scheduled for the week of Aug. 7, was granted yesterday by Judge Adrian P. Burke of the State Court of Appeals.
WASHINGTON, July 19--A program of physical fitness for school children was urged today by President Kennedy.
Your July 3 editorial "A Stronger Attack on Pollution" brought home vividly the dangers inherent in polluted waters. Grants to communities to aid in sewage treatment are an excellent beginning.

WASHINGTON, July 19 (AP) -- The question of how to restrict imports without hurting exports highlighted a Congressional hearing today on the impact of foreign competition on the United States textile industry.
Sales of the Monsanto Chemical Company for the three and six months ended on June 30 were the highest for those periods in the company's history. Earnings, however, were below 1960 levels.
GENEVA, July 19 -- The fourteen-nation conference on Laos broke a prolonged deadlock today by agreeing to begin point-by-point negotiations tomorrow in a restricted session.
CHICAGO, July 19 (UPI) -- The Chicago White Sox defeated the Kansas City Athletics tonight 6 -- 5, in a game marred by eight errors, five by the Athletics.
Yonkers Raceway yesterday abandoned its effort to purchase control of Roosevelt Raceway.
Mayor Wagner moved on two fronts yesterday to solve the activity problems of vacationing young people and children.
WASHINGTON, July 20 -- President Kennedy signed a bill today to provide more money and to extend Federal interest in preventing water pollution.
A Federal judge invalidated yesterday a $9,300,000 television contract between the Columbia Broadcasting System and the National Football League on the ground that it violated antitrust laws.
MENZEL BOURGUIBA, Tunisia, July 20. -- Death has changed this little town from a place where Tunisians and Frenchmen lived and worked side by side into a fear-ridden, divided community.
ZAPATA, Tex., July 20 (AP) -- The Bank of Zapata, one of the few private banks in the nation and the only bank in this county, was placed in receivership today.

THE chief of Washington's newest intelligence unit, the panel of eleven scientists investigating the possibility of secret Soviet nuclear bomb tests, is a short, merry genius with a monumental indifference to clothes and a love for old cars.
PORT JEFFERSON, L.I., July 20 (AP) -- An 18-year-old girt who had earned her Red Cross life-saving certificate was credited today with saving a small boy from drowning.
WASHINGTON, July 20 -- Senator Jacob K. Javits said today that national application of the Welfare program of Newburgh, N.Y., would be "a grave reverse to humane concepts of relief and welfare."
WASHINGTON, July 20 (AP) -- Senator Ernest Gruening, Democrat of Alaska, told Congress today that further discrimination against trade between Japan and Alaska "would be intolerable."
WASHINGTON, July 29 -- General of the Army Douglas MacArthur returned to the White House today for the first time in seven years. He said it was good "to feel a part of the current scene."
LONDON, July 20 -- Stock market prices continued upward here today although most gains among industrial shares were limited to a few pence.

WASHINGTON, July 20 (AP) -- President Kennedy made two appointments today to the board of trustees of the National Cultural Center that is planned for Washington. Those named were Mrs. Mary Lasker of New York and Stanley Marcus of Dallas.

Second quarter earnings of the Republic Steel Corporation were above those for the first quarter and for the 1960 period. However, half-year net income was 48.7 per cent below that of a year ago, according to semi-annual results announced yesterday.
Mississippi borrowed $4,200,000 in the bond market yesterday to finance improvements at the ports of Pascagoula and Gulfport.
WASHINGTON, July 20 -- The Federal Aviation Agency today indicated its satisfaction with the operation of its national network of 800 directional radio stations.
Welfare recipients in this city will not be put to work picking up scrap paper, dusting court files or performing other municipal chores, Welfare Commissioner James R. Dumpson said yesterday.
PARIS, July 20 -- The French Government declared today that it was ready to discuss conditions to bring about an immediate cease-fire in Tunisia.

George H. Bostwick's Tuscarora came along late and won the $11,000 Hitchcock Steeplechase Handicap at Aqueduct yesterday. Expertly rated by Ronald Cartwright, Tuscarora scored by two and a half lengths over Mrs. Lawrence W. Knapp Jr.'s Brannagh, Tommy Walsh up.

LONDON, July 20 (AP) -- The injury-riddled American track team arrived today for a two-day meet starting tomorrow against British athletes. The Americans came to London after meeting the Soviet Union and West Germany within five days.

The Boston and Maine Railroad was denied yesterday a guarantee by the Interstate Commerce Commission for a $1,000,000 4 7/8 per cent loan, due July 1, 1965, which it had privately arranged to make from the First National Bank of Boston.

Berlin, in a strategic sense, is an exposed salient with supply lines that could easily be severed by Communist action. Geography, propinquity and numbers favor the Russians in and around Berlin, and in fact in Germany itself.
HENDERSON, Tex., July 20 (UPI) -- William E. Benson said today that he had lied when he told the police he had caused a 1937 high school explosion that killed 293 persons in New London, Tex.
UNION, N.J., July 20 (AP) -- Californians set the pace today as the Amateur Athletic Union's synchronized swimming outdoor championships got under way at the Brookside Swim Club.
Three major candidates for Mayor -- Mayor Wagner, State Controller Arthur Levitt and Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz -- approved basic proposals for a new city Charter yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, July 20 (AP) -- Twenty-two-year-old Bob Hendley pitched the first complete game of his major-league career tonight as the Milwaukee Braves scored a 5-1 victory over the Philadelphia Phillies.

CINCINNATI, July 20 -- It is one of the peculiarities of baseball that enthusiasms and expert opinions shift more quickly and in more directions than the capricious winds in San Francisco's Candlestick Park.
WASHINGTON, July 20 -- The Treasury raised $3,501,051,000 in new money today.

Paris, Algiers and Tunis now form one of the most troubled geographical triangles in the world as a result of France's inability to free herself quickly enough from her colonial commitments in North Africa. Behind the shooting at the French-held naval base of Bizerte in Tunisia is a great tangle of conflicting interest and ambition running back 130 years.

WHEN Dr. John Briggs labeled two of the ages of contemporary man as the "foolish forties" and the "frenzied fifties" at the 110th annual meeting of the American Medical Association recently, he touched off a considerable amount of controversy, particularly among women in the latter age group.

The money committee of the First National City Bank of New York, as it has every working day for years, met yesterday at 10:45 A.M. One part of the group, however, assembled at 399 Park Avenue at Fifty-third Street, the bank's new uptown headquarters.

COCOA BEACH, Fla., July 20 -- Cloudy weather and the detection of the first hurricane of the year threatened today to force a further postponement in sending the second United States astronaut on a brief sortie into space.
WASHINGTON, July 20 (AP) -- The Senate Finance Committee heard both stockholder and labor witnesses denounce today the stock option plans in use for the benefit of many corporation executives.
CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., July 18 -- A Titan missile with a significant refinement, a packet of decoys to confuse enemy defenses, was fired here tonight.
Dr. James E. Allen Jr., the State Education Commissioner, told the city Board of Education yesterday to take forthright and affirmative measures to improve the operation of the school system.

Francis W.H. Adams, former United States Attorney, former Police Commissioner and a member of the New York City Board of Education by appointment of Mayor Wagner since June 4, 1957, has issued a lengthy statement about the current school scandal.
TUNIS, July 20 -- Thousands of Tunisian volunteers for the "Battle of Bizerte" marched through the streets here today chanting: "We will die so that our country may live!"

PHILADELPHIA, July 20 -- The Philadelphia Lyric Opera Company announced today that it had engaged George Balanchine, artistic director of the New York City Ballet, as choreographer and ballet master for the 1961-62 season.

Ditto, Inc., manufacturer of duplicating and copying supplies, has leased a ground-floor showroom and space on the second floor of the new office building at 733 Third Avenue, corner of Forty-sixth Street. The lessee is moving from 80 Fifth Avenue.

CHICAGO, July 20 (AP) -- The grain futures market finished generally lower today, although a few short interests bid firmer prices for the expiring July contracts in order to even up their commitments.

BOSTON, July 20 -- After last night's narrowing double-header in Washington, Manager Ralph Houk and his Yankees were thankful to have today off to relax and regroup forces for a three-game week-end series with the Red Sox beginning at Fenway Park tomorrow night.
WASHINGTON, July 20 -- The Treasury has recommended to President Kennedy that taxes be increased to meet additional spending required by the Berlin crisis.
WASHINGTON, July 20 -- The Government has initiated plans to permit increased draft calls and to improve the readiness of National Guard and other Reserve units.
A walkless walkout was threatened last night by Joseph Curran's National Maritime Union in a new eruption of its feud with Paul Hall's Seafarers International Union.
WASHINGTON, July 20 (AP) -- Congress was told today that considerations of foreign policy were throttling industrial growth while the Government was urging industry to expand.
WASHINGTON, July 20 (AP) -- The House Post Office Committee handed President Kennedy another setback today in his efforts to raise postal rates. It postponed further action until Aug. 17.

Mayor Wagner said last night he had dismissed Philip H. Gilsten as Deputy City Treasurer "because there is every reason to suspect he was involved in financial deals that were completely incompatible with his holding office."
CAIRO, July 20 (Reuters) -- The Arab League admitted Kuwait to membership tonight after the Iraqi delegation had walked out of the league's Council.

WESTBURY, L.I., July 20. -- Little George Sholty, 5 feet 2 inches and 108 pounds of driving talent and energy, was virtually idle tonight at Roosevelt Raceway. He went to the post only once, finishing fourth with Emlen Hanover in the third race before 23,617 fans.

THE first American frontier along the Appalachian barrier was a drama terrible to be part of, magnificent to look back on. Its components were full measures of horror, war, confusion and supercharged politicking from campfire site to European chancellery. This opening phase of the settlement epic has receded in memory, overshadowed by the later westward roll of the wagon trains.

J.A. Winston Co., a brokerage firm at 11 Broadway, and Lowell M. Birrell, fugitive financier, were indicted yesterday by a Federal grand jury here on charges of stock fraud. The investing public was said to have lost more than $3,000,000.
The New York City Central Labor Council voted an overwhelming endorsement last night of Mayor Wagner's candidacy for a third term. The labor group represents 1,000,000 union members in the city.

A slightly different note was struck in last night's entry in the "Jazz in the Garden" series in the Sculpture Garden of the Museum of Modern Art. Jazz was presently only by implication in the program of gospel singing offered by Marion Williams and the Stars of Faith.

The decision of Columbia College to suspend Contemporary Civilization B as a required sophomore course is read with real regret. The fact that contemporary society is exceedingly complex should be the challenge of college teachers and not a reason for suspending the effort to understand.

WESTPORT, Conn., July 20 -- The Westport Police Department has acquired a new kind of radar device to check the speed of automobiles. The unit is the size of a car's spotlight and its flexible mobility is being praised by policemen here.

Winging into New York each summer Monday come four highly perishable cheeses from France. Their destination is Cheese Unlimited, 1275 Lexington Avenue (near Eighty-sixth Street) and, since their life span is only about five days, they are available during the early part of the week.

Sales of the P. Lorillard Company, maker of Kent, Old Gold and other cigarettes, set a record for the fifth consecutive year in the first six months of 1961. At the same time, earnings rose by 5 per cent from the 1960 level, the semi-annual report of Lewis Gruber, chairman, disclosed yesterday.
Commodity prices on the New York exchanges advanced yesterday in generally quiet trading. Prices moved in narrow ranges and volumes were moderate.

WASHINGTON, July 20 (AP) -- The House passed by voice vote and sent to the Senate today a bill appropriating $641,135,800 for the Commerce Department and the President's office for the current fiscal year.
WASHINGTON, July 20 -- The Federal Aviation Agency was accused today of "questionable interference" in the fight over the site for a jetport in New Jersey.

Production of lumber climbed to 181,855,000 board feet in the week ended last Saturday from 129,809,000 board feet, the year's low, the week before, according to reports received from regional associations. A year ago 184,497,000 board feet were produced.
The board of directors of the New York Central Railroad expanded its membership yesterday to seventeen from fifteen and elected John D. Murchison and Frank E. McKinney to the two new positions.

It would be unreasonable to expect a total absence of interruption in the delivery of electric power in a city of New York's size and vast demand. But it is reasonable to expect that Consolidated Edison will so arrange its distribution that a huge area of the city will not be stricken into darkness, and kept so for hours, as occurred five weeks ago and in 1959 as well.

LONDON, July 20 (Reuters) -- The Ministry of Transport announced here today that dry-cargo vessels of twelve countries planned to follow Britain's example in banning discharge of oil-contaminated ballast water into prohibited zones of the sea.
LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, July 20 -- The Katanga Government threatened today to call on the Soviet Union for help in its dispute with the Central Government over a united Congo.

CHICAGO, July 20 -- The lawyer for an independent taxicab union that defeated a Teamster's Union local in an election conducted by the National Labor Relations Board said today he would press for government recognition despite a pending court case.
MEXICO CITY, July 20 -- President Adolfo Lopez Mateos announced yesterday the expropriation of 266,760 acres of American-owned property on the Tehuantepec Isthmus, in southern Mexico.
CONCORD, N.H., July 20 -- New Hampshire's Legislature has just allowed the State Fish and Game Commission to continue as a separate group, much to the satisfaction of most sportsmen.

Loans to business at the fifteen reporting member banks in New York City declined $111,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. This compared with a decline of $117,000,000 in the like week a year ago.

Simon and Stanley Rappaport, realty investors, have bought the five-story apartment building at 4357 Vireo Avenue, corner of East 239th Street, the Bronx, from AMA Associates, Inc., and have resold the parcel to the Benferen Corporation.

WASHINGTON, July 20 (UPI) -- United States Attorney General Robert F. Kennedy and Alabama's Attorney General MacDonald Gallion submitted sharply conflicting views today on proposed rules banning segregation in bus travel.
Law enforcement officials told a state legislative committee here yesterday that their attempts to prosecute purveyors of "girlie" magazines had been stalled by recent court decisions.

The Abercrombie Fitch Company, owner of the sporting goods store at Madison Avenue and Forty-fifth Street, has leased a one-story warehouse building to be erected to its specifications at Gale Avenue and Van Dam Street in Long Island City, Queens.
WASHINGTON, July 20 -- The House of Representatives killed today a third Administration plan for reorganizing Federal regulatory agencies.

CINCINNATI, July 20 (AP) Four home runs and the seven-hit pitching of Sandy Koufax gave the Los Angeles Dodgers a 10-1 victory over Cincinnati tonight and moved them to within a game and a half of the league leading Reds.

An indictment of New York City's administration is made in a book to be called "S.O.S. New York: A City in Distress -- And What Can Be Done About It." The author is Eric Javits, a New York lawyer and nephew of Senator Jacob K. Javits.
SUMMER bachelors whose wives and children are vacationing in some peaceful clime will find that many businesses have stayed home to help them.
ALBANY, July 20 -- The state informed local welfare commissioners today that able-bodied relief recipients could be put to work without jeopardizing $16,000,000 in new Federal money for New York.
WASHINGTON, July 20 (AP) -- American corporations offered a record of $5,100,000,000 of new securities for cash sale during the April-June quarter.

Sales and earnings of the Gillette Company for the first six months of this year were the highest for any initial half-year in its history, according to the results announced yesterday by Boone Gross, president.
BRIELLE, N.J., July 20 (AP) -- A cabin cruiser with six men aboard was the object of a wide Coast Guard search today after it failed to return last night from a fishing trip.

ST. LOUIS, July 20 (UPI) -- Willie Mays' twenty-eighth home run capped a four-run rally by the San Francisco Giants in the eighth inning as they defeated the Cardinals, 10 -- 6, tonight and ended a five-game St. Louis winning streak.
DENVER, July 20 (AP) -- Charles (Sonny) Liston has come to Denver to take the first step toward wiping out the suspension against him.
WASHINGTON, July 20 -- The United States urged Tunisia and France today to settle the crisis over Bizerte outside the United Nations.
Ambassador Mikhail A. Menshikov expressed confidence yesterday that East-West talks would ease the tensions arising from what he called an "abnormal" situation in divided Berlin.
Samuel Reshevsky and Bobby Fischer played to a draw after twenty-five moves last night at the Empire Hotel in the third game of their sixteen-game series. They thus remained even, 1 1/2-1 1/2.

Daily average borrowings by member banks of the Federal Reserve System rose $8,000,000 to $55,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. Daily average reserves in excess of requirements declined $14,000,000 to $643,000,000.
SAN JUAN, P.R., July 20 (AP) -- The season's first hurricane, Anna, was written off tonight as a threat to Venezuela's coast, and hurricane warnings were lowered for that region.
DETROIT, July 26 -- The Ford Motor Company told the United Automobile Workers today that it wanted to reduce the hourly wage costs in its steel division.

Following are the texts of statements made yesterday before the Charter Revision Commission by State Controller Arthur Levitt, Mayor Wagner and Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz in the order of their appearance:

FLORENCE, Italy, July 20 -- Pino Lancetti was the last-minute hero as the Italian collections came to a close today. A slender young man, dead white and faint with excitement, Lancetti nervously received congratulations after the show for his bright young designs. He produced an ambitious collection that bristled with ideas.

President Kennedy's call for a physical fitness program for children was politely applauded yesterday by educators in the metropolitan area. However, they said they thought their existing programs were as good as the President's, if not better.
SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 20 -- The lush days of the pre-depression Twenties are back again -- at least on the Long Island Rail Road.
PITTSBURGH, July 20 (AP) -- Joe Gibbon of the Pittsburgh Pirates pitched his first major-league shutout tonight, beating the Chicago Cubs, 4 -- 0, on four hits.
WASHINGTON, July 20 -- Rail and truck freight loadings increased sharply last week from those of the preceding week, which included the Independence Day holiday.

WASHINGTON, July 20 (AP) -- A Senate subcommittee heard testimony today that one of every twenty patients in hospitals is there because of treatment with drugs that backfired, and that 10 to 15 per cent of the nation's physicians practice "bad medicine."
DETROIT, July 20 (AP) -- The Detroit Tigers scored eight runs in the seventh inning today, routed the Baltimore Orioles, 15 -- 8, and reclaimed first place in the American League.
Equipment to record and analyze ten hours of a person's heart activity in one day was described here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 20 -- The trend of industry in areas of powerful unions, high taxes and high labor costs to reduce these burdens by moving their plants elsewhere has encountered serious obstacles in the Federal courts. The net of two recent decisions is this:

ANKARA, Turkey, July 20 -- The ruling military junta of Turkey, the National Unity Committee, disclosed in a communique tonight that the resignation of Lieut. Gen. Cemal Madanoglu from the committee had been accepted.

COOKED outdoors or in, steaks and hamburgers are the thing. Housewives are understandably loath to add to the heat by lighting the oven for an extended period, so many a roast has been languishing in a neglected corner of the butcher's meat case.
DETROIT, July 20 (AP) -- Model changeover operations are expected to hold United States car production to only 105,186 units this week, Automotive News, a trade paper, said today.
PLEASANTVILLE, N.Y., July 20 -- Sidney Poitier, young Negro stage and screen star, has purchased a twelve-room Tudor house on a seven-acre site in a neighborhood of large estates near here.
Second quarter earnings of the Radio Corporation of America showed a sharp decline from those of the first quarter, but they were better than in the second quarter last year.
CHICAGO, July 20 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
Two "in-service" institutes for high school mathematics and physics teachers will be offered at City College this fall.

Cesium, a space-age metallic element, is being offered for sale by the Dow Chemical Company. W.J. Rave, manager of Dow's metals department, said yesterday that the company was producing cesium with a purity of more than 99.9 per cent.
LOS ANGELES, July 20 (AP) -- A Philadelphia construction executive, Lawrence Anastasi, is the new men's foil champion of the United States.
Madison Avenue is getting over the recession. But the recovery is not quite as sharp as some ad men had hoped.

WASHINGTON, July 20 (UPI) -- Former President Harry S. Truman, who won an upset victory in 1948 with the help of big-city votes, now believes the cities threaten to impose their choice for President on the rest of the nation.
WASHINGTON, July 20 -- Department store sales in the nation last week were 3 per cent above the level of a year earlier.
THE Brooklyn Championships, an annual tournament of the Greater New York Bridge Association, begin today at the St. George Hotel in Brooklyn. They will continue through Sunday.
WASHINGTON, July 20 -- President Kennedy today put the Pentagon in charge of a greatly increased program to protect American civilians against the effects of nuclear attack.

GENEVA, July 20 -- A twelve-month standstill at the present level of textile exports and imports is the key aspect of a three-part United States proposal being debated in secret by the special International Textile Conference here.

WASHINGTON, July 20 (UPI) -- A spokesman for the Securities and Exchange Commission said today that the agency would seek a court injunction to prevent insurgent stockholders of United Industrial Corporation from voting proxies at the company's annual meeting July 28 in Wilmington, Del.

Alarmed by the new strain imposed on France in the midst of the Berlin crisis, the United States Government has now asked both President de Gaulle and President Bourguiba to end the Franco-Tunisian hostilities over the naval base of Bizerte and a strip of the Sahara.

ELMSFORD, N.Y. July 20 -- Strange things took place before the qualifying round of the forty-second annual Westchester amateur golf championship finally got under way today over the Fairview Country Club course.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 20 -- The 45,270-ton P. passenger liner Canberra slipped through the Golden Gate in a heavy fog today on her maiden voyage from Southampton Crowds lined the Golden Gate Bridge to wave to the indistinc form of the new British ship which was at the halfway mark on her first cruise.

LUGRIN, France, July 20 -- The Algerian rebel negotiators proposed here today a five-point agenda for the resumed peace talks with France that appeared to raise again all the old obstacles to agreement.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., July 20 (AP) -- John Konsek of Buffalo rallied today and defeated Terry Thomas of Rochester, 3 and 1. The victory put Konsek a step closer to a fourth straight New York State amateur golf title.
PARIS, July 20 -- The former German embassy here, which was expropriated by France at the end of World War II, was returned to West Germany today as a gesture of solidarity between the two nations.
GREENWICH, Conn., July 20 -- Mrs. Bruce McGhie of Apawamis and Mrs. Joseph A. Nesbitt of the Westchester Country Club gained the final of the Women's Tri-County Golf Association championship today.
The only evening performance here of the Philippine Bayanihan Dance Company this fall will be on Nov. 19 at the Metropolitan Opera House and will be a benefit for the American Field Service.
GENEVA, July 20 -- The United States formally proposed today an international version of its Peace Corps plan to speed United Nations aid programs for under-developed countries.

TEANECK, N.J., July 20 -- Making a profit on a simple exchange of money at a bank may seem far-fetched, but a teen-aged coin collector apparently has done it. He buys scarce, valuable coins at face value.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., July 20 -- Glit Shields sailed the 12- Meter yacht Columbia to her third Larchmont Race Week victory today on a program that produced fewer starters than any other. The forbidding early conditions held the number of afternoon starters to 164 boats and wiped out the morning program.

When Broadway dramatists volunteered eight weeks ago to take a royalty cut to help the financially stricken theatre, their action was hailed by producers as a major breakthrough in the industry's economics.
Global Marine Exploration Company, a subsidiary of Union Oil Company of California, has agreed to sell 400,000 shares of its treasury stock to Aerojet-General Corporation, it was announced yesterday.
The Public Service Commission directed the Consolidated Edison Company yesterday to change its substation design to prevent a recurrence of the June 13 power failure in Manhattan.
NEWARK, July 20 -- New Jersey business leaders were urged today to seek a greater share of the foreign market to help balance international payments and to promote the principles of a free world.
The North Atlantic Mediterranean Freight Conference, one of the world's major shipping conferences, has been charged with attempting to force one of its member lines into "illegal and unlawful" acts.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 20 -- Asian and African states asked the General Assembly to again take up the question of race conflicts in South Africa for the tenth successive year. The Assembly opens its sixteenth session here on Sept. 19.
CHICAGO, July 20 (AP) -- Don Dell of Bethesda, Md., upset Chuck McKinley of St. Louis today in the quarter-finals of the national clay court tennis tournament, 6 -- 3, 7 -- 5, 6 -- 3.

MILWAUKEE, July 20 (UPI) -- Two Texans, Fred Hawkins of El Paso and Don Massengale of Jacksboro, shot five-under-par 65's today and shared the first-round lead in the $30,000 Milwaukee open golf tournament.
The mobile unit of the Mayor's Information Center will be stationed in the Bronx for six weeks beginning Monday, Mayor Wagner announced yesterday.
TUNIS, Friday, July 21 -- French forces, attacking by land and air, broke the Tunisian siege of the French naval base on the outskirts of Bizerte yesterday.
WASHINGTON, July 20 -- An eleven-man scientific committee will report to President Kennedy tomorrow or Monday what it has learned about the possible testing of nuclear weapons by the Soviet Union.
LONDON, July 20 -- British Government sources said tonight that they had received no request from the United States to concert military preparations to meet the expected Soviet pressure on Berlin.

Ordinarily the killing of a bill in the Rules Committee might be accepted as the end of that measure, at least for the duration of the current session of Congress. But the circumstances surrounding the school-aid bill are not ordinary. There are at least two compelling reasons why extraordinary efforts must be made to circumvent the Rules Committee's road block.

The Tampa Electric Company reported yesterday gains in operating revenues for the twelve and six months ended on June 30 and for the month of June. Net income for the twelve months also ran ahead of the year-ago level.
Moscow has turned to landlocked Czechoslovakia in its drive to build up the Soviet merchant marine to the 6,000,000-ton level by 1965.

The United States Treasury experienced its first gold loss of significant size in five months in the week ended on Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. The gold stock dropped $25,000,000, to $17,526,000,000, which put it $241,000,000 below the level at the beginning of the year. The last gold loss occurred in the week ended on April 26, when there was a decline of $1,000,000.

Heavy rains caused considerable inconvenience and some damage in the metropolitan area yesterday. There was lighting and thunder, a spatter of hailstones in southern Rockland County, and flooding on the fifth floor of a midtown office building.
ARCHIBALD MacLEISH, author of "J.B.," has written a drama about the Declaration of Independence for the July-August issue of Think. "Our Lives, Our Fortunes and Our Sacred Honor," he calls it.
CAIRO, July 20 (AP) -- President Gamal Abdel Nasser nationalized all banks and insurance companies in the United Arab Republic tonight.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), July 20 -- The cross-examination of Adolf Eichmann ended today.

The Buckeye Pipe Line Company announced a dividend of 45 cents yesterday on its common stock, payable on Sept. 15 to shareholders of record of Sept. 1. It previously had paid a quarterly dividend of 40 cents.

GREAT NECK, L.I., July 20 -- The logs for the Griswold Point predicted-log contest, received today showed the winner to be Dr. Allen B. Du Mont in Hurrican III with an accuracy score of 99.28 per cent.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 19 -- Mounting expenses of his revolutionary regime are among compelling pressures behind the Iraqi Premier's claim to the rich oil sheikdom of Kuwait.
PATERSON, N.J., July 20 -- Murder, the gravest of crimes, is also the most expensive to prosecute, the Passaic County Board of Freeholders is learning.
CHICAGO, July 20 -- The formation of a political action committee was announced today by the American Medical Association.

A Negro girl will appear next week in the pages of a major fashion magazine for what is believed to be the first time. Willette Murphy, 22 years old, of Santa Barbara, Calif., has been photographed modeling campus clothes for the college issue of Mademoiselle, which goes on sale on the newsstands on July 27.

Mongi Slim, special Tunisian representative to the United Nations, said on arrival here last night from Europe that the French had called for a truce at Bizerte to evacuate the dead and wounded and, half an hour afterward, had violated the truce.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 20 -- Tunisia accused France of aggression today and called on the Security Council to seek the evacuation of French troops from the naval base at Bizerte.

Plato dreamed of it centuries ago; St. Augustime called it "the City of God"; Francis Bacon applied his clear thinking to it; Robert Owen thought he might, on a small scale, be able to make it work; Edward Bellamy stirred the imagination of our grandparents with his picture of a dully serene society in which everybody lived well on exactly $4,000 a year.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 20 -- By merely looking at the walls of Frederick Brisson's office at the Columbia Studio it becomes apparent that Mr. Brisson does not quite fit the Hollywood pattern, though he has often been part of it.

Stocks trudged up and down yesterday and got virtually nowhere. Standard Poor's 500-stock index rose 0.01 point, to 64.71. The New York Times combined average of fifty stocks fell 0.22 points, to 377.86. More stocks fell than rose.
CLEVELAND, July 20 (AP) -- Successive homers by Jim Piersall and Tito Francona paced the Cleveland Indians to a 12 -- 11 victory over the Boston Red Sox tonight.

ST. JOHN, N.B., July 20 -- This is for the skipper who may be looking for new cruising worlds to conquer after wearing grooves in the waterways from Maine to Miami. He may have already been in and out of the Chesapeake Bay harbors, circumnavigating Long Island and steering courses through the New York State Barge canals, Lake Champlain and even along the new St. Lawrence Seaway.
GENEVA, July 20 -- The Fourteen-nation conference on Laos ran into a snag as soon as it met today for its first point-by-point negotiation in restricted session.
ALBANY, July 20 -- The City of New Rochelle today protested a proposed reduction of almost $3,000,000 in the assessed valuation of the New Haven Railroad's facilities there.

WITH respect to musical substance and public attendance, the three Beethoven concerts given at Lewisohn Stadium this week might be described as sounding a crescendo. The trio of programs reached their climax last night with a performance of the great Ninth Symphony.
A 17-year-old messenger for a Fifth Avenue clothing store told the police yesterday that a gunman had come up from behind him outside a bank and taken the package he was carrying.
Following are the texts of French notes delivered to the Tunisian Government Tuesday and yesterday, as made available here in English translation by the French Information Service:

ITALIAN pasta concoctions such as ravioli and manicotti are readily available in frozen form. However, the prepared, fresh versions are not as easy to find. One excellent source for such products is the shop of Bruno, who calls himself with some justification "The King of Ravioli."

JACKSON, Miss., July 20 (UPI) -- Nine members of a group of clergymen visiting here from many parts of the nation to discuss racial tensions were arrested tonight for refusing to leave the waiting room of the municipal airport.
LONDON, July 20 -- A wildcat strike of maintenance workers of the British Overseas Airways Corporation ended today.

WASHINGTON, July 20 -- A United States Senator named Robertson took issue with a Federal Reserve Governor named Robertson yesterday over Congressional intentions in last year's Federal bank merger statute.

Your July 4 editorial "Polio Vaccines and the A.M.A." omitted mention of a significant portion of the report on polio vaccines recently adopted by the House of Delegates of the American Medical Association.

CHARLESTON, W. Va., July 20 (AP) -- A violent rainstorm deluged Charleston last night. The downpour transformed brooks into roaring rivers that spread death and destruction down the area's narrow valleys.
WASHINGTON, July 20 -- President Kennedy won his first major victory today in the Congressional struggle over his long-range foreign aid program.
WASHINGTON, July 20 (AP) -- Two members of the American Nazi party were sentenced today to twelve months at hard labor for assault on a Jewish boy.
WASHINGTON, July 20 (AP) -- The House Agriculture Committee gave formal approval today to a new catchall farm bill, which it had adopted tentatively on Tuesday.
Cotton futures were unchanged to 25 cents a bale up yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange. Only May and July rose.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 20 -- A former Secretary of Defense invoked the arguments of national defense and national economic strength today in support of the Southern Pacific Company's campaign for stock control of the Western Pacific Railroad Company.
Protracted negotiations between the New York Titans and Art Powell ended yesterday with the pass-catcher signing for his second season with the American Football League club.
STAMFORD, Conn., July 20 -- Fairfield County's economy improved substantially in the first six months of this year, the Fairfield County Trust Company said today.
Federal investigators yesterday studied the twisted engine of the taxi-plane that crashed here Tuesday, killing the pilot and three socially prominent women.
Production and consumption of newsprint in June were below the corresponding levels of last year, according to trade association reports issued yesterday.

Your recent editorials (July 6 and 14) dealing with the plight of the New Haven and transportation in general are most encouraging to us who for a long time have advocated a regional approach toward a solution for our transport problems.
NO matter what the occasion -- attending an embassy garden party, conferring with a Communist official or doing her marketing -- Mrs. H. Alwyn Inness-Brown keeps her hat on.
Louis A. McCarten has been elected treasurer of the Nautec Corporation, New York, diversified manufacturing company. He had been assistant to the treasurer of the Bristol-Myers Company.

LONDON, July 20 (Reuters) -- Although the British couturiers who have shown their collections for fall have voted predominently for a fitted silhouette, today there was a notable exception. Norman Hartnell, Queen Elizabeth's dressmaker, remained faithful to big swinging coats, loose jackets and bloused dresses.

WASHINGTON, July 20 -- In his news conference this week, President Kennedy spoke with extreme caution about two questions on which the Roman Catholic Church has strong views. The first was birth control and the second Federal aid to education.
The demand for high-grade debt investments continued to dominate the bond market yesterday as the curtain went down on the Treasury's $16,000,000,000 refunding and new borrowing operations.
LONDON, July 20 -- A Government-appointed committee said today that effective control of public expenditures was hindered by short-term and stop-and-go economy campaigns.
WASHINGTON, July 20 (AP) -- Assistant Navy Secretary Kenneth E. Belieu said today that naval shipyards were key elements in national defense and were major national assets.

DALLAS, Tex., July 20 (UPI) -- Former United States Senator William A. Blakley announced today he was giving vast ranching, oil and insurance interests worth more than $100,000,000 to the Blakley-Braniff Foundation.
WASHINGTON, July 20 -- The Bureau of Labor Statistics reported the following spot primary market prices for the dates shown:

WASHINGTON, July 20 (UPI) -- The House and Senate, in quick succession, voted today to give President Kennedy all the money he sought to try to put an American on the moon before a Russian gets there.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 20 -- Following are the texts of messages from Sadok Mokaddem, Tunisia Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs, and Habib Bourguiba Jr., head of Tunisia's delegation to the United Nations, requesting a Security Council meeting on the Bizerte crisis:
For the New York Stock Exchange, the second quarter of this year may rank as one of the busiest and most eventful in many years, judging by its quarterly report issued yesterday.

The executive committee of the Nassau-Suffolk Financial Council said yesterday that it opposed the proposal of the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company of New York and six upstate banks to form a new state-wide holding company.

SALISBURY, Southern Rhodesia, July 20 -- Joshua Nkomo, African nationalist leader of Southern Rhodesia, declared today that his party planned country-wide demonstrations to coincide with a referendum next Wednesday on a new constitution for the colony.
BERLIN, July 20 (AP) -- Mayor Willy Brandt of West Berlin declared today that he saw no reason for panic concerning this divided city.
The Alfred P. Sloan Foundation announced yesterday the names of 140 young men selected to receive national scholarships for study this fall at thirty-five colleges and universities.
ALBANY, July 20 (AP) -- L. Judson Morhouse, the Republican state chairman, was elected chairman of the new Lake George Park Commission today.
WASHINGTON, July 20 (UPI) -- The House ways and Means Committee voted today to tax Americans who escape all United States income taxes on big foreign earnings by living abroad temporarily.

WASHINGTON, July 20 (AP) -- The Interstate Coommerce Commission today rejected a proposal that the Susquehanna Railroad be required to operate its passenger trains in and out of Hoboken, N.J., connecting with Erie-Lackawanna ferry service to New York.
WASHINGTON, July 21 -- President Kennedy watched the space flight of Capt. Virgil I. Grissom on television this morning. Then he congratulated the astronaut in a personal telephone call.

" NUNCLE, AND OTHER STORIES,"* by John Wain, is a collection of tales and parables about Britons in generally unusual predicaments. Such as? Well, such as a man who wants to achieve human hibernation; a boy of 5 with the mind and desires of a man of 35; a faded novelist who is ghosting a critical tribute to himself while his father-in-law ghosts his stories.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 21 -- Tunisia and France put their conflicting accounts of the Bizerte crisis before the Security Council today.
BAYREUTH, Germany, July 21 (AP) -- Some Germans are objecting to the selection of Grace Bumbry, American Negro soprano, as Venus in the production of "Tannhaeuser" at the Bayreuth Festival.
With the score tied 4 -- 4, the batter lined a sharp single to center and the Narcotics Squad detectives in the outfield had a choice -- go for the ball or the narcotics suspect in the stands.
WASHINGTON, July 21 -- Navy sources here said they had no knowledge of whether the Soviet Union had nuclear-powered missile submarines. They said they assumed Moscow could build such vessels.

MANASSAS, Va., July 21 -- Two men were wounded by gunfire on the national Battlefield Park today in a rehearsal of the Battle of Bull Run. The battle will be re-enacted tomorrow and Sunday in commemoration of its 100th anniversary.

Sylvania Electric Products, Inc. will introduce a new 21-inch color television set about mid-September. The set will be the first to be introduced by the company, a subsidiary of the General Telephone Electronics Corporation since 1956.
An 18-year-old Brooklyn youth was stomped to death in an argument over a dime last night.

WASHINGTON, July 21 (AP) -- Everett F. Drumright, United States Ambassador to Nationalist China, said after a talk with President Kennedy today that the United States would seek a United Nations agreement keeping Nationalist China in and Communist China out of the world organization.

JACKSON, Miss., July 21 (UPI) -- A New York attorney often employed by the American Civil Liberties Union said today that he would challenge in state courts the arrest of "Freedom Riders" by Mississippi officials.
Kenneth Hartoch, in a letter printed July 10, suggests the use of "anti-smog devices" on Diesel buses.

BIG FLATS, N.Y., July 21 (AP) -- William T. Smith, who bought a $6,100 automobile with money the Government paid him for cutting his corn acreage, is in trouble with a Federal agency that contends he grew too much wheat in 1960.
MITCHELL, Ind., July 21 (AP) -- Captain Grissom's father felt mostly fear -- "pride ran second" -- while his son rocketed into space and back today.

WASHINGTON, July 21 (AP) -- The Justice Department sued five large bakery concerns today for double damages and forfeitures because of alleged rigged bidding on sales of bread and rolls to naval installations in Florida and Georgia.

CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., July 21 (AP) -- Intensive training in how to escape from a sinking space capsule paid off today for Capt. Virgil I. Grissom. The astronaut had to scramble into the sea to avoid going down with his sinking space craft.

LONDON, July 21 -- Nineteen British trade-union officials declared today that they were gravely concerned over the possibility of Britain's entering the European Economic Community on the basis of the Treaty of Rome.
A battle-scarred moray eel arrived with a group of tropical sea companions on the Queen of Bermuda yesterday morning.

WASHINGTON, July 21 (AP) -- The Treasury announced today that this week's $16,000,000,000 financing -- the biggest in more than two years -- was a thorough success. The Treasury said that the largest part of the operation, an offering of three new securities in exchange for $12,500,000,000 of maturing issues, met with widespread acceptance from lenders.
The State Supreme Court yesterday ordered to trial a taxpayers' suit seeking to bar the construction of the Huntington Hartford cafe in Central Park.
SAN RAFAEL, Calif., July 21 (AP) -- A burning railroad tunnel collapsed last night, swallowed an apartment house and plunged a fireman to flaming death.
Edward W. Chapin has been elected secretary of the Sterling Precision Corporation here. He had been associated with Lord, Day Lord, New York law firm.
PARIS, July 21 -- France claimed tonight the achievement of her defensive objectives in the Bizerte fighting.
HYANNIS PORT, Mass., July 21 -- President Kennedy landed here today on a chilly, windy afternoon -- the third straight week-end the sun has refused to shine on him at Cape Cod.
WASHINGTON, July 21 (UPI) -- Surgeon General Luther L. Terry issued new standards today for drinking water consumed by Americans in their homes, on trains, planes, buses and ships.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 21 -- For generations the vast timber resources of the Sudan have stood neglected in favor of the plains that produce cotton -- the country's major source of export earnings. The situation is now changing, as Sudanese hurry to exploit the forest that covers 40 per cent of their territory.

CHAUTAUQUA, N.Y., July 21 -- The patriarchal and richly varied Chautauqua Festival is now in the third week of its eighty-eighth season, and this unusual lakeside resort is taking matters well in stride.
Another in the summer series of walking tours sponsored by The Museum of The City of New York will visit the downtown area famed for "Tycoons and Tickertape" this Sunday.

MADRID, July 21 -- Eight Spanish non-Communist groups have recently joined forces in a program to restore democracy in Spain and oppose "totally" the dictatorship of Generalissimo Francisco Franco, now celebrating its twenty-fifth anniversary.
MOSCOW. THE Soviet Union's "new people" have begun to adhere to the old ideal that a woman should be ornamental as well as useful.

WASHINGTON, July 21 -- A switch invented in the Bell Telephone Laboratories will operate, according to the company, a thousand times faster than those now in use. Its introduction into telephone switching networks of the Bell System is pending.

LONDON, July 21 -- Qualified sources said today that Britain's first military step to meet "any real threat" by the Soviet Union over Berlin would be to recall reservists to the British Army of the Rhine.

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), July 21 -- An Israeli judge's appeal today to soldierly sentiment and family honor failed to melt Adolf Eichmann.

CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., July 21 -- Within a half-hour, Capt. Virgil I. Grissom, the second United States astronaut, floated in two elements. For five minutes of his sixteen-minute ride into space he was in the weightless condition of space flight.

MILWAUKEE, July 21 (UPI) -- Red-haired Bruce Crampton of Australia turned in a 64 today on the rain-soaked North Hills Country Club course to take the lead in the $30,000 Milwaukee open golf tournament. He has a 36-hole total of 134.

Fines totaling $250 were imposed on the managing agent of a tenement at 318 East 101st Street yesterday in Housing Court. But they were suspended when it was explained that the building was in receivership and had insufficient funds for rehabilitation.

The cause of City Charter reform took an unexpectedly large step forward with the testimony before the Cahill commission of the three major candidates for Mayor. While Mayor Wagner, State Controller Arthur Levitt and Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz did not agree on everything, by any means, the remarkable thing about their statements was the size of the area of agreement.
Mayor Wagner announced yesterday that Greenpoint Hospital in Brooklyn would become affiliated with Mount Sinai Hospital, Fifth Avenue at 100th Street, within the next few days.
BOSTON, July 21 -- John Blanchard's pinch-hit grand-slam homer with two out in the ninth inning bailed out the Yankees tonight just when it appeared they were doomed to their third straight defeat.

WASHINGTON, July 21 (AP) -- Senator Strom Thurmond denounced today a Senate colleague's memorandum to the Defense Department as "a dastardly attempt to intimidate the commanders of United States armed forces."
WASHINGTON, July 21 (UPI) -- Attorney General Robert F. Kennedy today urged the nation's clergymen, especially those in the South, to take a more active role in fighting racial discrimination.

The Valley Color and Chemical Company of New York has sold the building containing 6,000 square feet of space at 78 to 82 Wheeler Point Road, Newark. The buyer was the D L Oil Sales Company, which occupies an adjacent building. Feist Feist were the brokers.
EAST NORWALK, Conn., July 21 -- A twenty-eight-foot cutter sails out of this port each morning manned by teen-aged crews and skippered by a Naval Reserve officer.
An American freighter and a Navy submarine were reported yesterday to have been involved in a minor collision Thursday afternoon fifteen miles south of Block Island.

WASHINGTON, July 21 (AP) -- A Senate hearing produced testimony today that medical journal advertising of a synthetic hormone carried no warning that thirty-six pregnant women bore sexually abnormal daughters after being given the drug.
CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., July 21 (AP) -- Why spend millions of dollars to send man into space, billions to get him to the moon?

WESTBURY, L.I., July 21 -- Perhaps the additional 25,000 harness racing fans who had been expected at last Saturday night's International Trot will show up for tomorrow night's Challenge Cup Trot at Roosevelt Raceway.

The market for new capital is expected to be moderately active next week, with fixed-interest securities valued at $109,250,000 slated for competitive sale by units of state and local government and by private industry.
WASHINGTON, July 21 (UPI) -- President Kennedy asked Congress today to renew and broaden American programs to help refugees from communism or other oppression.
Business may still be in the recovery stage, but cash dividends to stockholders have more than recovered. They are somewhat above last year's level.

The use of "rehearsal pictures" to heighten the dramatic effect of television's live coverage of the space flight of Capt. Virgil I. Grissom touched off a controversy among broadcasters and viewers last night.
UPTON, L.I., July 21 -- Dr. Maurice Goldhaber, an authority in nuclear and fundamental particle physics, was appointed director of the Brookhaven National Laboratory here today.
LONDON, July 21 (AP) -- Captain Grissom's space feat was headlined in London tonight as a near tragedy that might have cost the astronaut his life.
BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., July 21 -- A collective sense of continuity and belonging seems to have settled over the New York Titans. A year ago they were a brooding band of nameless, insecure strangers.

Ships built in foreign shipyards and documented under United States registry are the latest major threat to American tramp shipowners and other unsubsidized carriers, a Senate subcommittee has been told.

LOUISVILLE, July 21 (AP) -- Cassius Clay, who figures he has to win every fight to reach his goal of heavyweight champion in two years, will meet his toughest opponent to date in a scheduled ten-rounder against Alonzo Johnson tomorrow night.

CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., July 21 (UPI) -- Capt. Virgil I. Grissom's Liberty Bell 7 space capsule carried two cameras and hundreds of pounds of instruments to the bottom of the Atlantic after its flight today.
Almost 300 years ago "the Governor and Company of Adventurers of England trading into Hudson's Bay" were granted a monopoly of the trade to all lands watered by streams flowing into Hudson's Bay.
WILMINGTON, Del., July 21 (AP) -- Adios Butler won on his seventh straight race tonight, the $30,500 Liberty Bell Pace at Brandywine Raceway. He won by two lengths in a 1:59 1/5 mile.
CLEVELAND, July 21 (UPI) -- Thomas L. Miller of Cleveland was sentenced to two years in prison today for making false telephone reports of bombs aboard airplanes at Cleveland Hopkins Airport.

YONKERS, July 21 -- Subcommittees of the Yonkers City Charter Revision Commission announced today that they had turned down plans to lengthen the terms of office of the city's twelve Common Council members from two to four years.
LOS ANGELES, July 21 (UPI) -- The New York Athletic Club captured the epee team title last night in the national fencing championships.
SHEMYA, Alaska, July 21 (AP) -- An Alaska Airlines cargo plane trying to land in fog hit 300 feet short of the runway today and piled up in flames, killing all six crew members.
If the members of the Board of Education were graded on their attendance, many would receive low marks.
The prospect of a city-administered high school providing training in the gastronomic arts that would make New York City first in producing culinary experts was held out by Mayor Wagner yesterday.
WASHINGTON, July 21--The United States Government announced tonight that it would sponsor a free airlift for more than 20,000 Cubans seeking to come to the United States.

THE Brooklyn Championships tournament at the St. George Hotel in Brooklyn continues today with a two-session open pair contest at 2 P.M. and 8 P.M. There will be one-session games at the same hours for those who do not wish to play in the championship event.
ALBANY, July 21 (AP) -- A Suffolk County official and a driving-school instructor were arrested today in a state-wide drive against fraud in motor vehicle bureaus.
ST. LOUIS, July 21 (UPI) -- The Federal Government filed suits today against three food manufacturers in an effort to bring weight-labeling into line with food and drug laws.
CHICAGO, July 21 (AP) -- Demand for grain futures was light and scattered today and prices generally turned weak in the dullest activity of the week on the Board of Trade.

A Federal grand jury here yesterday indicted the General Investing Corporation, a brokerage concern at 55 Broadway, for fraudulent stock sales. Private investors were said to have lost at least $800,000 last year.
SIOUX FALLS, S.D., July 21 -- Another giant balloon has been sent aloft during a sola flare to assess the hazards such flares may hold for space travel.

BLOOMINGTON, Minn., July 21 (UPI) -- Jose Valdivielso scored from second base in the ninth inning today on Lenny Green's 30-foot single to give the Minnesota Twins a 4-3 victory over the Cleveland, Indians.

DETROIT, July 21 (AP) -- The Chrysler Corporation joined General Motors Corporation and Ford Motor Company today in what amounted to a rejection of the over-all contract proposals of the United Auto Workers on the ground they are excessive and inflationary.

An investing client of Sheldon Olshan, lawyers, has bought the six-story industrial building at 642 Avenue of the Americas (Sixth Avenue), southeast corner of Twentieth Street. The property, with a plot 120 by 170 feet, was one of several parcels that were sold recently by the Rhinelander Estate Company to Lawrence A. Wien and Harry B. Helmsley. Helmsley-Spear, Inc., was the broker in the resale.
SYRACUSE, July 21 (AP) -John Konsek moved into the quarter-finals of the New York State amateur golf tournament today with a 3-and-1 triumph over John Hausen of Albany.

ROME, July 21 -- The first word of Captain Grissom's flight was flashed to Italians over the country's radio network today. Announcers interrupted scheduled programs to report the launching minutes after the rocket had lifted off the pad at Cape Canaveral.

VIRGIL IVAN GRISSOM slipped off as an Indiana schoolboy for solitary swims in abandoned quarries. He explored bat-filled limestone caves -- alone. And he went on all-night Boy Scout camping trips by himself.

The sixtieth triennial General Convention of the Protestant Episcopal Church will meet for twelve days in Detroit beginning Sept. 17. A church spokesman said yesterday that the gathering promised to be "one of the most momentous" in the history of the denomination.

The economics of a partial mobilization along the lines President Kennedy is expected to announce next week have reportedly been under intensive governmental study. While the results of this study are not known, there can be no doubt that the nation has more than enough idle resources to be able to bear the real and financial costs of whatever steps the President is likely to announce.

CHICAGO, July 21 (AP) -- The Quaker Oats Company, which was accused yesterday of short-weighting its puffed wheat and puffed rice, said today it had begun printing the correct weights on the labels of some of its breakfast foods, and was recalling mislabeled packages.
WASHINGTON, July 21 -- Secretary of State Dean Rusk conferred today with British, French and West German diplomats on measures to increase the West's readiness to meet a Berlin crisis.
ELMSFORD, N.Y., July 21 -- James Iverson of Siwanoy, the defender, won two matches today in the Westchester amateur golf championship at the Fairview Country Club.

ST. LOUIS, July 21 (AP) -- The St. Louis Cardinals backed Curl Simmons with a twelve-hit assault led by Joe Cunningham and routed the Los Angeles Dodgers, 10 -- 1, tonight. The defeat ended a four-game Dodger winning streak.
Mayor Wagner and Manhattan Borough President Edward R. Dudley toured Greenwich Village streets yesterday afternoon to see for themselves the route of the proposed "Verrazano Street."
LONDON, July 21 -- Investors took precautions today against whatever measures the Chancellor of the Exchequer might impose to correct Britain's economic difficulties.
KENAI, Alaska, July 21 (AP) -- A modern version of the historic Alaska gold rush is bringing another horde of hardy men to the mountains and arctic plains of the nation's forty-ninth state.
Pools of men available for draft into the armed forces will be more than doubled in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut over the next several months, according to Selective Service System officials.
NEWARK, July 21 -- The Haridor Realty Corporation has filed a notice of appeal from a decision by the state's Division of Civil Rights that would force the corporation to sell a house to a Negro.
TOKYO, July 21 (AP) -- The Tokyo stock market experienced one of its sharpest declines today just before the Bank of Japan ordered a rise in official interest rates.
Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz made clear yesterday that he had not taken sides in the controversy over stringent new welfare rules in Newburgh.

WASHINGTON, July 21 (AP) -- The nation's capital, from President Kennedy to the man in the street, joined today in praise for Capt. Virgil I. Grissom moments after he had made this country's second man-in-space flight.

Your July 18 editorial on Chester Bowles was timely, important and correct. I find it hard to believe that the man who successfully administered the affairs of the State of Connecticut is somehow incapable of administering the Department of State.
CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., July 21--Virgil I. Grissom became the nation's second space explorer today.

PHILADELPHIA, July 21 (AP) -- Tony Gonzales hit his seventh home run of the season with one out in the tenth inning to give the Philadelphia Phillies a 4-3 victory over the Chicago Cubs tonight. Gonzalez drilled one of Barney Schultz' knuckle balls over the right-field wall.
Although he is faced with one of the most formidable production agendas on the contemporary movie scene, Italy's Dino DeLaurentiis has no qualms about adding to an already bulging schedule.
BONN, Germany, July 21 -- The West German Government said today that it was "increasingly worried" over the mounting number of East German refugees.

There were ceremonies this week throughout West Germany recalling the memory of 4,980 men and women who were brutally put to death by Hitler because of the plot against him that came to a head on July 20, 1944. The full story can be found in Shirer's "The Rise and Fall of the Third Reich," which so many Americans are now reading.
WASHINGTON, July 21 -- Argentina will be granted $204,500,000 in loans for industrial development by the United States and the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development.

ORANGE, N.J., July 21 -Carmen Lampe of Forest Hills, Queens, and Mimi Kanarek, also a New Yorker, reached the final of New Jersey State women's singles tennis championship at the Berkeley Tennis Club today.
Earnings of Abbott Laboratories and its subsidiaries rose from the 1960 level in the second quarter but declined slightly for the first half of 1961, the company reported yesterday.
The use of ultrasonic vibrations in diagnosing heart defects was described here yesterday by a German physician.

Initial plans have been made by Mrs. J. Clarence Davies Jr., chairman, and her benefit committee for the NYDA Ball, a gala dinner dance, to be held at the Pierre on Dec. 1. Proceeds will help to expand the services of the New York Diabetes Association.

Mayor Wagner charged yesterday that the State Public Service Commission was two years late with its directive to Consolidated Edison designed to minimize the area affected by Manhattan power failures.
SANTIAGO, Chile, July 21 -- The Chilean Government confirmed today it was adopting a program destined to give the nation more control of production and world marketing of copper.

Savings in the nation's sayings and loan associations rose $1,355,000,000 in June to $66,580,000,000, the United States Savings and Loan League reported yesterday. The gain was greater than that in any other month on record.
WASHINGTON, July 21 (AP) -- State officials were invited today to a two-day conference to get President Kennedy's physical fitness program started.
A $62-a-week Brooklyn bank teller, accused of having embezzled $46,249.56, denied yesterday in Federal District Court, Brooklyn, that he had taken the 56 cents mentioned in the complaint.

GREENWICH, Conn., July 21 -- Mrs. Bruce McGhie of Apawamis became the first to take three straight women's tri-county Golf Association championships today. She defeated Mrs. Joseph A. Nesbitt of Westchester, 7 and 6, in the scheduled 36-hole final.

Dr. James E. Allen Jr., Commissioner of Education, met here this week with members of the city's Board of Education and its Superintendent of Schools. He was "deeply concerned over the serious charges, counter-charges and reports about the administration and management of certain school affairs * * * and, in particular, their adverse effects on the instructional program here and throughout the state."

Charles and Milton A. Kimmelman have obtained a first mortgage loan of $2,200,000 for ten years at 5 1/4 per cent on a thirty-three-story office building at 1441 Broadway. They purchased the property several months ago. The Sonnenblick-Goldman Company was the broker.
Your July 13 editorial "Our Move in Outer Mongolia" approves of plans to seat Outer Mongolia in the United Nations and grant it United States recognition.
MOSCOW, July 21 -- The Soviet Government newspaper Izvestia declared today that the Soviet Union had a larger and faster fleet of rocket-launching nuclear submarines than the United States.
MONTGOMERY, Ala., July 21 (AP) -- Legislation that would make it easier for out-of-state newspapers to be sued for libel in Alabama courts made its appearance today in the State Senate.
NORWALK, Conn., July 21--A "general neighborhood renewal plan" has been approved by the Common Council for the South Norwalk area.
Activity in commodity futures on the New York exchanges was quiet yesterday, with narrow price ranges, moderate volume and mixed closing prices.

WASHINGTON, July 21 (AP) -- A House committee study of the impact of textile imports on employment in the United States ended today.

General Utilities and Industries, Inc., which owns and operates a number of water and sewer systems in Florida, has acquired the Rex Service Company, which provides water and sewer service to about 2,000 customers south of Miami.

Tomorrow the "grand old man" of horse-racing, Sunny Jim Fitzsimmons, celebrates his eighty-seventh birthday. A biography of him has been written by James Breslin and Doubleday is planning its publication in the spring. In "Sunny Jim, the Life of James Fitzsimmons," the author tells of the man and his family and gives a history of horse racing and training in America.
Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 5 points off to 4 up yesterday. A point equals 5 cents a bale.

Charles M. Richardson and Baumeister Baumeister were the brokers for the seller, the Nycleve Corporation of Cleveland.
TEHERAN, Iran, July 21 (Reuters) -- The pro-Western Premier, Dr. Ali Amini, won a victory tonight when Communists and other anti-Government demonstrators abandoned the streets and went home.

WASHINGTON, July 21 -- The Federal Aviation Agency exonerated its tower personnel at La Guardia and New York International Airports today from any blame in the Dec. 16 airliner collision over Staten Island.

TORONTO, July 21 (Canadian Press ) -- The Mexican Light and Power Company, Ltd., had a profit for the three months ended on March 31 of $653,022, subject to year-end adjustment, compared with $1,390,897 in the 1960 period last year.

GENEVA, July 21 -- A sixteen-nation conference on textiles agreed unanimously today on an American plan for short-term and long-term solution of the sensitive problem of low-wage textile exports.

President Kennedy has won an important initial victory in his fight for Congressional approval of his long-range foreign aid program. Now that the Senate Foreign Relations Committee has approved the proposal to authorize long-term development loans over the next five years, using funds borrowed from the Treasury, the arena of Congressional battle will soon move to the floor of the Senate.

WASHINGTON, July 21 (AP) -- The National Association of Manufacturers urged the Senate Finance Committee today to reject a bill by Senator Albert Gore, Democrat of Tennessee, that would end the present tax benefit on stock options granted by corporations to executives.
WASHINGTON, July 21 (AP) -- Four of the nation's largest moving companies, four of their top executives and a trade association pleaded not guilty today to charges of price-fixing.

The United States won three matches from Tunisia yesterday and moved into second place in the international students chess tournament in Helsinki. The Americans now have an 11-4 record. The Soviet Union is on top with 13 -- 2.

DETROIT, July 21 (AP) -- The daughter of the Teamsters Union president, James R. Hoffa, will marry a management man in October.

CHICAGO, July 21 -- The Mogamisan Maru, the first ship of the Japanese-flag Mitsui Line to call at the port of Chicago, was welcomed officially today.
BOLZANO, Italy, July 20 -- The tourist is king here this summer because he is so rare.
GLEN HEAD, L.I., July 21 -Jimmy Bostwick of Meadow Brook won the medal today in the Long Island amateur golf championship for the second year in a row.

PHILADELPHIA -- Sun and fun, combined with a pick-up in business, have brought indications of a boom season for the $600,000,000 seashore and mountain resort industry of Southern New Jersey, Pennsylvania and Delaware.

THREE states will observe anniversaries of their statehood in 1962. Arizona and New Mexico will mark their fiftieth birthdays and Louisiana will celebrate its 150th anniversary. It has been the practice of the Post Office Department to recognize such anniversaries with commemorative stamps.
ANCHORAGE, Alaska, July 22 -- Anchorage not only has dreams of being a big city, but is also planning how to become a good one.

THE success of its "no frills" shuttle service is prompting Eastern Air Lines to double the number of flights on the New York-Boston leg of its commuter operation, starting Aug. 1. Eastern also provides the same type of service between New York and Washington, but it plans no increase on this run at present.

The vacancy on the Cardinal Hayes High School faculty created by the promotion of Bill Krywicki to the position of director of athletics and head of the physical education department at Cardinal Spellman High School, the Bronx, has been filled. Joe Tricario, head football coach at Marist High, Bayonne, N.J., has been signed to take Krywicki's place.

COCOA BEACH, Fla., July 22 -- Capt. Virgil I. Grissom disclosed today he had been "scared" during much of his flight into space yesterday. But he recommended a space trip for everyone because the view is so "fascinating."

IF Spain has an indigenous art-music form (as contrasted with flamenco and traditional dance music) it is the zarzuela. WHEN The Summit Hotel at Lexington Avenue and Fifty-first Street opens its doors a week from tomorrow -- the first new luxury hotel to rise in New York in thirty years -- the accent will be on the foreign accent.

STANTON, Del., July 22 (AP) -- Airmans Guide, a long shot in the field of fifteen fillies and mares, won the $38,612 New Castle Stakes by six lengths today at Delaware Park. The event was the second leg of the track's Distaff Big Three series.
CALCUTTA, India, July 22 -- A tall, lanky professor from Harvard is feeling his way into a new type of diplomacy in India that appears to be winning many friends for the United States.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, July 19 -- The Bolivian Gulf Oil Company, a subsidiary of the Gulf Oil Corporation, announced today it had struck oil in a well thirty-five miles northwest of the city of Santa Cruz in the zone of Caranda. This was the fourth well in the Caranda camp.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 21 -- Now more than ever, Premier Abdul Karim Kassim is employing the art of balancing the political forces in his country.
OTTAWA, Ohio, July 22 -- This village's public and parochial high schools will be merged this fall.
FAIRFIELD, Conn., July 22 -- Charles Hoeveler of Southport, Conn., won the final for 18-year-old-and-under players today in the Connecticut junior tennis championships at the Fairfield Beach Club.
COLOMBO, Ceylon, July 22 -- The Government of Prime Minister Sirimavo Bandaranaike has lost the support of the Trotskyites as it completes is first year in office.

The idea of thieves driving a truck up to a museum's back door one night, loading it with fifty-seven paintings, and getting away without any more disturbance than the momentary disruption of the sleep of neighboring citizens, is absurd enough to be the opening scene of a funny movie. But it has actually happened at the Museum of Modern Art in St. Tropez; and the loot included paintings by Matisse, Bonnard, Utrillo and others.
WASHINGTON, July 22 -- The Kennedy Administration believes it is about to make a major advance in the long and so far frustrating fight on organized crime.
Mrs. Albie Booth has been named honorary chairman of a luncheon at which the women of Connecticut will be acquainted with the Albie Booth Memorial Fund and its purposes.

IN an Iranian village an interpreter-guide leads a group of visitors through the treeless dun-colored lanes. "Our landlord is an evil man," he says. "We would like to hang him to the only tree in our village."

Although building volume continues on the high side, Cleveland business activity in general has begun to reflect the vacation season slowdown which, as a customary, began during the fourth of July holiday week. Building permit volume in the week ended on July 15 was $2,900,000 and consisted of a wide assortment of large and small projects.

MARBLEHEAD, Mass. -- This community's seventy-second annual Race Week has just opened, and until next Saturday night visiting sailors will swell the harbor's normally large racing fleet to nearly 500 craft.

IN summer many woody plants are easy to propagate by cuttings and layering. The gardener who makes use of modern materials and methods to speed root formation, and observes a few basic propagation principles, is virtually assured of successful results with a variety of plants.
Primitive toolmaking man may have roamed the earth 1,750,000 years ago, according to a radioactive-dating measurement announced yesterday.

A rival tried to steal the mile-and-a-quarter Brooklyn Handicap from the Bohemia Stable's Kelso at Aqueduct yesterday, but the 4-year-old son of Your Host finished well in advance of the pack. He registered his eleventh straight victory, under a package of 136 pounds.

The windy city's third annual world's fair of trade starts Tuesday amid great expectations. The International Trade Fair is hoping to do at least $30,000,000 of wholesale business during its 17-day run.

The 23,800-ton bulk carrier Tamara Guilden has received Maritime Administration approval for a two-year charter to the Government of Israel Supply Mission.
