AT a recent forum in New York on youth crime that brought together some rehabilitated juvenile delinquents from various cities, a reformed girl from Detroit told the audience of parole officers, sociologists and educators: "Make the girls good, and delinquency will lessen."

Horses ran, bettors bet and pickets picketed yesterday at Aqueduct. For the second day stablehands continued their walkout against owners and trainers. They are seeking recognition of their union, Local 917 of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, and improvement of their economic status. But, as on the first day, the labor dispute had little effect -- if any -- on the nine-race program.

WATERTOWN, N.Y., July 22 -- The Seventy-seventh Infantry Division from New York City returned to its home station today after two weeks of extensive field training at near-by Camp Drum under the command of Maj. Gen. J.W. Kaine.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 22 -- The United Nations Security Council called today for an immediate cease-fire in Tunisia and a return of all forces to the positions they occupied before fighting began last Wednesday. The vote was 10 to 0.

Running counter to the usual seasonal decline, factory employment rose 5,900 to 1,354,000 in mid-May in Pennsylvania. The State Bureau of Employment Security reported a net rise of 7,200 in durable goods industries had been partly offset by a decline of 1,300 jobs in non-durables.

SYRACUSE, July 22 (UPI) -- John Konsek of Buffalo and Don Allen of Rochester, a former captain of the Colgate golf team, reached the final today of the New York State amateur golf tournament.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., July 22 -- Pride and pressure goaded the New York Titans to prolonged self punishment today in their opening workouts for the American Football League campaign.

LOS ANGELES, July 22 (UPI) -- The medical director of Culver City Hospital yesterday defended its sterilization procedures.

SEOUL, Korea, July 22 -- In a major attempt to step up economic development, South Korea's ruling junta established today an agency to plan, coordinate and oversee all economic policies and programs.

NEW PALTZ, N.Y. -- Old Stone House Day will be observed by antiquarians, historians and tourists in this little tree-shaded college town on Aug. 5. It is just half a mile from Exit 18 on the New York State Thruway to New Paltz's old Street of the Huguenots, a half-mile that takes today's motorist out of the modern world and into the seventeenth century.

A 36-million-volt betatron, the world's most advanced radiation weapon against cancer, was given a pre-clinical demonstration last week at Montefiore Hospital, in the Bronx. The machine produces a beam of powerful electrons, which, it was explained, has the advantage over X-rays in that the depth of penetration can be precisely controlled.

WOODS HOLE, Mass. -- Visitors to Cape Cod this summer will find an attractive and interesting new aquarium here at Woods Hole, the famous center for ocean research. Passengers waiting in this port town for the ferryboats to Martha's Vineyard and Nantucket can spend the time watching a fascinating collection of sea creatures that live in or visit local waters.

After some prodding by Senator J.W. Fulbright, the Defense Department has issued a sensible directive curbing the freedom of military officers to advocate Right Wing political theories in official public appearances. The former Grace Line passenger ship Santa Paula, renamed Acropolis and flying the Greek flag, will leave for the Mediterranean today at the end of a tow line to begin a second career as a cruise liner in the Mediterranean.

Then the Queens Democrat got his Irish up and said "no" to the Administration's program of Federal aid to education.
THE Brooklyn championships ended last night with the final session of the two-session team-of-four contest.
LONDON, July 23 -- An uneasy stock market, waiting for the Government to announce its long-promised cures for Britain's economic ills, slid to the lowest point of the year last Monday.

GENEVA, July 23 -- Spokesmen of the United States textile and apparel industry took a wait-and-see attitude in a statement today on the sixteen-nation trade agreement reached here yesterday on cotton textiles.
Nine persons who were arrested after a street brawl in the Bronx on Saturday night were told to "stop acting like savages" yesterday in Bronx Magistrate's Court.
CINCINNATI, July 23 (AP) -- The Cincinnati Reds snapped a six-game losing streak today with power hitting that produced 6-5 and 11-2 victories over the San Francisco Giants.

SYRACUSE, July 23 (AP) -- Don Allen, a 23-year-old former Colgate University Golf Captain, today ended John Konsek's three-year reign as New York State amateur champion with a 5-and-4 victory in their scheduled 36-hole final.

BIZERTE, Tunisia, July 23 -- The French continued to ring the city of Bizerte today. They have not withdrawn. They have reinforced their perimeter. They control particularly the two main roads south to Tunis, forty miles away.
GLEN HEAD, L.I., July 23 -- Age -- rather than youth -- was served today at the North Shore Country Club when 53-year-old Bob Kiersky won the Long Island amateur golf tournament.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 23 -- Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold left tonight for Tunisia on the invitation of President Habib Bourguiba. The Secretary General will discuss means of carrying out the United Nations call for an immediate cease-fire between Tunisia and France.
MANASSAS, Va., July 23 -- Two thousand skirmishers began breaking camp tonight on the hills of the Manassas National Battlefield Park after three re-enactments of the Battle of Bull Run.

TEHERAN, Iran, July 23 -- There is a single long-range constant in current Iranian foreign policy and this can be described in one word -- Russia. With the exception of fellow travelers and members of the illegal Communist party, most Iranians recognize the danger to the north.

HUNTINGTON, L.I., July 23 -- The Lakeville Stable's brown gelding Tennessee Williams from Great Neck, L.I., scored 11 points to win the open junior jumper championship during the Hollow School of Equitation horse show staged by the Melville Fire Department today.

WOODBRIDGE, N.J., July 23 -- George Davidson and Dr. Michael Bucella of Forest Hills won the New Jersey Golf Association's sixteenth annual Scotch foursomes tournament today with a 36-hole total of 148 at the Colonia Golf Club.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 23 -- Iran protested today against alleged Soviet efforts to bring about the overthrow of the Iranian Government and got a soft answer from the Russians.
MOSCOW, July 23 -- "The Island," a Japanese film without dialogue and the Soviet war movie, "The Clear Sky," tonight shared the Grand Prize of the second Moscow Film Festival.
The majority of the accounts of Cohen Aleshire, Inc., and most of its key personnel, will join Donahue Coe, Inc., on Aug. 1.

ABOARD THE COAST GUARD CUTTER MACKINAW, July 23 (AP) -- Spurred by a freshening northeast breeze, the yawl Dyna tonight neared the finish line in the 235-mile yacht race from Port Huron to Mackinac Island Mich.

The objections raised by the American Medical Association to Senator Kefauver's bill for more Federal testing of new drugs have been challenged by two members of the A.M.A.'s own Council on Drugs. Their testimony and that of other distinguished physicians and pharmacologists before the Senate Antitrust subcommittee cast doubt on the adequacy of organized medicine's prescription for safeguarding the public without an extension of governmental activity in the pharmaceutical field.

The Rev. Dr. Lawrence L. Durgin, minister of the Broadway Congregational Church, charged yesterday that "activity of the Roman Catholic heirarchy has resulted in a cynical conspiracy to frustrate support for public education."
Monaco, the French League champion, and Rapid of Vienna triumphed in the International Soccer League double-header at the Polo Grounds yesterday.

LORD BYRON once remarked that "Since Eve ate apples, much depends on dinner." It was from that quip that Peter Robotti has taken the title for his recently published book, "Much Depends on Dinner," or The Tablecloth Game (Fountainhead Publishers, Inc., $8.50).

St. Christopher's Chapel, one of two chapels in the lower East Side Mission of Trinity Protestant Episcopal Church, celebrated its patronal Feast Day yesterday with a day-long program of liturgy and secular entertainment.

Membership of the Lutheran churches in North America totaled 8,456,863 adults and children at the end of 1960, according to the annual statistical summary issued here yesterday by the National Lutheran Council.

THE energetic young president of New College is a perennial optimist with the ability to transmit his enthusiasm and hopefulness to his associates. And the results often seem to have a way of justifying his optimism.
MOSCOW, July 23 -- The Soviet Union established today control commissions with extraordinary powers to deal with false economic reporting by managers in agriculture and industry.
The three main transcontinental airlines -- American, Trans World and United -- are seeking permission to cut coach excursion fares between principal coast-to-coast points.
Sam Minskoff Sons, New York builders, have announced plans to build a twenty-six-story office building in the financial district of Detroit.
PHILADELPHIA, July 23 (AP) -- The Chicago Cubs ended a seven-game losing streak today by defeating the Philadelphia Phillips, 11 -- 5, with four home runs, two by Don Zimmer.
HYANNIS PORT, Mass., July 23 -- President Kennedy is himself drafting much of the speech he will make to the nation at 10 P.M. Tuesday.

Within a few hours after Capt. Viral Grissom's suborbital flight, President Kennedy signed a bill, passed by Congress Thursday, authorizing the National Aeronautics and Space Administration to spend $1,784,300,000 on a vastly expanded space program, including a start toward sending a man to the moon "before this decade is out."
PITTSBURGH, July 23 (AP) -- The Milwaukee Braves replaced Pittsburgh in the first division today by beating the Pirates in a double-header, 11 -- 4 and 5 -- 4.

VIENNA, July 23 -- A Swiss newspaper charged yesterday that Austria's Foreign Minister, Interior Minister and three leading politicians had participated in forming a separatist partisan organization in Italy's Alto Adige.
The establishment of a new privately endowed liberal arts college in Sarasota, Fla., was announced here yesterday.

STUTTGART, Germany, July 23 (AP) -- Innes Ireland of Britain, driving a Lotus, won the 177-mile German Grand Prix today. He beat Joakin Bonnier of Sweden by a few feet in a duel before 300,000 spectators.

WASHINGTON, July 23 (AP) -- A study sponsored by the Brookings Institution reported today that the aim of the Soviet Union in disarmament negotiations apparently was to disarm only the West or to achieve a disarmament agreement without effective controls.

Furs and their influence on the colonization of North America constitute the content of a huge two-volume illustrated work that will be issued Aug. 7 by the University of Oklahoma Press, entitled "The Fur Trade." The 1,230-page history describes the economic and political influence the trade had on the United States, Canada, France, Spain and the Indians from the sixteenth century into the nineteenth.
WATCHUNG, N.J., July 23 -- Larry and Helen Hough of Westport, Conn., in a Mercedes Benz 190, won their second national sports car rally in a row today.

" DOLCE NOTTE," sang Cio-Cio-San from the stage of Lewisohn Stadium on Saturday night. And, in truth, it was a lovely night there, ideal for the concert performance of "Madama Butterfly" that was being given.

In the fiscal year just ended, plans were unveiled for the addition of 190 new plants under Puerto Rico's "Operation Bootstrap" industrialization program, according to the Puerto Rico Economic Development Administration here.
NEPTUNE CITY, N.J., July 23 -- "This happens to be one of your oldest relatives," the professor said, and held up the unexpected ancestor -- a starfish.

Drivers of ready-mix concrete trucks will vote today on whether to end their three-week-old strike. The members of Local 282 of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters are scheduled to decide whether they want to go back to work on the terms they rejected before the walkout.

BAYREUTH, Germany, July 23 -- At 3:45 this afternoon the warning tuckets sounded, as they do every year, and about fifteen minutes later the 1961 Bayreuth Festival, the oldest and still the most important of its kind, got under way.
LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, July 23 -- President Joseph Kasavubu appealed to the secessionist Province of Katanga today to send representatives here to participate in the coming session of Parliament.
RYE N.Y., July 23 -- A former college president is hanging tattered garments and rags on clotheslines in front of his home here to protest the amount of his taxes.

CHESTERTON, Ind., July 23 -- Secretary of the Interior Stewart L. Udall toured the Indiana dunes today and threw the weight of his office behind efforts to save a major part of the area from the threat of industrial encroachment.

THE city of West Berlin was the subject of a realistic and informative documentary last night over Channel 4. The hour-long presentation of the National Broadcasting Company was designed as background for President Kennedy's address tomorrow evening and the program constantly discharged its mission.
Direct obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public that will mature within twelve months amount to $82,826,375,552. They consist of Treasury securities as follows:
It is good to be reminded occasionally -- so that we do not take ourselves too seriously -- that people were complaining a half-century ago about some of the things we fret about today.
Stocks eased last week in the over-the-counter market. Trading was extremely quiet, almost on the lackadaisical side.

WASHINGTON, July 23 -- Republican Chairman William E. Miller, in office less than two months, has initiated a quiet shake-up of the national committee organization and a realignment of some of its basic policies.

THE first United States trade center, which opened in London last month, displays household, bathroom and garden items. The center, at 57 St. James Street, in the heart of London, is the first attempt of its kind on the part of the American Government to promote the export of American goods.
The City Club of New York urged Mayor Wagner yesterday to take personal charge of a campaign for a minimum wage of $1.50 an hour in the city's "sweatshop" industries.
MARLBORO Vt., July 23 (UPI) -- A ten-minute standing ovation from a capacity audience at the Marlboro Music Festival Hall rewarded a glowing performance tonight of the Beethoven Triple Concerto.

Commissioner Bernard Katzen of the State Commission against Discrimination said yesterday that East Side "luxury apartments" had maintained a pattern of discrimination against Negro elevator operators.

CHICAGO, July 23 (AP) -- Weather and crop development became the major considerations last week in grain futures dealings on the Board of Trade, but expiration of July contracts provided the only excitement.
The operation of the Bureau of Weights and Measures in the Department of Markets was declared basically sound yesterday, but nineteen changes were recommended to improve the bureau.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., July 23 -- Five classes scheduled special Yacht Racing Association events on Long Island Sound today, with the Larchmont Yacht Club regatta committee sending a total of fifty-seven starters across the line.
Prices of cotton futures in the domestic market began firm last week, turned weaker then closed moderately firmer.

TWENTY-FIVE years ago one of the most successful works of topical journalism ever written was published in this country -- and soon in many other countries. "Inside Europe" sold and sold in repeatedly revised editions. It made its young author famous. Now, twenty-one books later, John Gunther is no longer young, but he is more famous than ever.

LONDON, July 23 (Reuters) -- A British clergyman described today atrocities allegedly committed by Portuguese troops in attempts to crush, a five-month-old revolt in the West African territory of Angola.

WASHINGTON, July 23 -- The United States is not planning any new emergency measures to help bring out of Cuba about 20,000 prospective refugees awaiting transportation to Miami, it was reported today.
ST. LOUIS, JULY 23 (AP) -- Ron Fairly doubled twice today, putting one run in scoring position and driving in the other, to pace the Los Angeles Dodgers to a 2-1 victory over the St. Louis Cardinals.

MILWAUKEE, July 23 (AP) -- Bruce Crampton, a former Australian open champion, withstood challenges by Gay Brewer Jr. and Bob Goalby today and won the $30,000 Milwaukee open with a 72-hole total of 272.
GENEVA, July 23 -- The Swiss stock markets took another trouncing last week continuing the slide that set in at mid-June. The losses were straight across the board.

PARIS, July 23 -- Secretary of Defense Robert McNamara held a day-long meeting today with the top commanders of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization to plan Western strategy in the face of the Soviet threat to Berlin. Mr. McNamara, accompanied by Gen. Lyman L. Lemnitzer, Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, was expected to outline President Kennedy's plans for strengthening conventional forces in Europe.

SALISBURY, Southern Rhodesia, July 23 -- Africans in Southern Rhodesia overwhelmingly rejected today proposals approved by Britain for a Constitution. They voted in an unofficial nation-wide referendum organized by the powerful National Democratic party.

The Federal Government is offering for sale to American ship operators a 14,800-ton freighter. The Government had bought the ship back in June for more than $1,000,000 to protect its mortgage insurance investment.
The manpower shortage hampering Mayor Wagner in his fight for renomination against the Democratic organization will be alleviated when the New York Committee for Democratic Voters endorses him.
MIAMI, July 24 (AP) -- Following, as made public today by Eastern Air Lines, are the names and destinations of the thirty-three passengers aboard the plane seized over Florida and flown to Havana:
CHICAGO, July 24 -- Dr. Dwight J. Ingle, chairman of the University of Chicago Physiology Department, contends "there are reasons for thinking that racial differences in intelligence may be real."
A new Madison Square Garden will be built on top of Pennsylvania Station as part of a $50,000,000 complex that will include sports arenas, offices, restaurants, convention halls and a hotel.
Afternoon thunder showers drew brief smiles of relief from heat-weary New Yorkers yesterday, but no major break in the weather was expected before Friday at the earliest.

MONTICELLO, N.Y., July 24 -- When officials at Monticello Raceway dubbed their cozy Catskill Mountain plant "The Mighty M" at the start of last year, there was considerable snickering. The picturesque half-mile oval, it was felt, did not rate such impressive billing.
LEXINGTON, Ky., July 24 (AP) -- The world record price for a thoroughbred yearling was paid tonight when a colt by Swaps brought $130,000 at the Keeneland sale.
WASHINGTON, July 24 -- President Kennedy returned to the capital today and shined up his Berlin speech for presentation tomorrow evening.
Walter Hagen, one of golf's first great internationalists, was named yesterday to receive the first Walter Hagen Award of the Golf Writers Association of America.

WASHINGTON, July 24 -- Adlai E. Stevenson has advised Secretary of State Dean Rusk that even some high Government circles in Latin America believe that the United States and Cuba are engaged in "a purely bilateral quarrel capable of mediation."
CHICAGO, July 24 (AP) -- Soybeans, wheat and rye were strong in a slow grain futures market. Soybeans prices worked well ahead on a variety of considerations.

There is little surprising in the Soviet Army newspaper's bitter complaint that the orbiting of the Tiros and Midas satellites represented espionage on the part of the United States. Tiros provides an independent source of information about Soviet weather when it passes over that country; Midas can detect Soviet rocket launchings when similarly situated.
A sharp reduction of the deficit in the United States' balance of international payments from $3,800,000,000 for 1960 to $500,000,000 for 1961 was forecast yesterday by a major trade group.

THE chance to reassess contemporary opera -- particularly contemporary American opera, with its high mortality rate -- is rare. Last night it was possible for New Yorkers to re-examine Jan Meyerowitz' "The Barrier," which had been seen here eleven years ago in a production at Columbia University and then in a brief Broadway run.
A New Jersey office designer has developed a plan for offering the leaseback system of renting to banks and other lending institutions.

HAVERFORD, Pa., July 24 -- A violent rainstorm that trapped some of the players and spectators under umbrellas and canopies washed out all except a few of the men's opening round matches in the Pennsylvania lawn tennis championships at the Merion Cricket Club today.
WASHINGTON, July 24 (AP) -- Chester Bowles, Under Secretary of State, left today on an eighteen-day mission to improve the American ambassadorial system abroad.
WASHINGTON, July 24 -- The Department of Commerce announced today the approval of the country's first project under the new program of federal aid to depressed areas.

GLASSBORO, N.J., July 24 -- Officials of the largest migrant farm labor camp in New Jersey accused a subcommittee of the House Labor Committee today of refusing to let them reply to charges against the camp made by a witness before the subcommittee.
RIO DE JANIERO, July 24 -- Foreign Minister Afonso Arinos de Melo Franco told a Soviet goodwill mission today that Brazil hoped to establish diplomatic relations with the Soviet Union "very shortly."
The Cuban Refugee Appeal of the International Rescue Committee will benefit from the Cuban Ball, to be held in the Plaza's Grand Ballroom on Oct. 4.

District Attorney Frank D. O'Connor of Queens announced yesterday that Dr. John J. Theobald, Superintendent of Schools, would be called before a grand jury investigating alleged irregularities in the city school administration.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 24 -- Following, as made public today, are the texts of a letter to the President of the Security Council from Mongi Slim Tunisian representative, and of a message to the Secretary General from Habib Bourguiba Jr., Tunisia's acting chief representative, both bearing yesterday's date, and of a letter to the Council President from Armand Berard, French delegate:

THE six-story apartment house at 715 St. Marks Avenue, between Nostrand and New York Avenues in Brooklyn, has been purchased for $670,000 by Philip Hirth, real estate investor, from Keller Industries, Ltd. The building contains eighty-four apartments.

LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, July 24 -- A final attempt was made jointly by the Congo and the United Nations today to persuade Antoine Gizenga to come to Leopoldville for a session of the national Parliament.
Mayor Wagner toured the upper West Side yesterday to inspect housing and study the area's police problems.

WASHINGTON, July 24 (UPI) -- Senator Jennings Randolph, West Virginia Democrat, said today that opposition by the National Coal Association to a coal-research program was not "wise, appropriate or timely."
BIZERTE, Tunisia, July 24 -- The evacuation of French families began here today when 420 women and children boarded the cruiser Colbert to sail for France.
Construction employers estimated last night that at least 25,000 building trades workers had been made idle by the strike of 1,200 concrete mix drivers, now in its fourth week.

WHEN one comes to the point where winter weather would seem a blessing, it is time to refresh the summer wardrobe. More and more large stores as well as small shops have hot weather clothes in stock at the end of July.
A $2,000,000 suit was filed yesterday in State Supreme Court here against the New York Stock Exchange and its officers by a former customer's man of a Wall Street broker.

Stay-at-homes must be wooed and won by the oil industry to assure continued prosperity. That is the belief of the Chase Manhattan Bank. It reports in its monthly petroleum review that the first half of 1961 ended "on a somber note" for the oil industry, with demand 1 per cent below that in the 1960 period.

WASHINGTON, July 24 (AP) -- The Federal Reserve Board reaffirmed today its refusal to authorize a merger of the Marine Midland Trust Company of Southern New York, Elmira, and the First National Bank and Trust Company, Ithaca.
WASHINGTON, July 24 -- The Administration presented Congress today new proposals for providing hospital and nursing care for the aged through expanded Social Security taxes.
HONG KONG, July 24 -- Peasants in a key rice-growing area of Communist China are battling a serious drought that is "even worse" than those of the last two years, the Peiping radio reported today.
FISHERS ISLAND, N.Y., July 24 -- Two vessels from the host club won the trophies today in the fog-enshrouded overnight race that opened the thirtieth annual American Yacht Club cruise.
WASHINGTON, July 24 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture reported today that this country's stocks of wheat, corn and sorghum grains at mid-year were at record levels.
BERLIN, July 24 -- East German industry has been called upon for extraordinary efforts to increase the production of "urgently needed" consumer goods and housing.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, July 24 -- The Latin American Free Trade Association was formally opened for business here tonight. The seven-nation group had an oversupply of red ink and black clouds and a full measure of hope and determination.
RICHMOND, Va., July 24 -- A challenge of Prince Edward County's action in closing its public schools to avoid desegregation opened in Federal Court here today before District Judge Oren R. Lewis.

A central figure in the Queens tow truck racket inquiry entered the grand jury room yesterday, but refused later to say whether he had testified. Assistant District Attorney Francis X. Smith also declined to say whether the man -- William Lade, proprietor of the J B Auto Shop at 34-34 Linden Place, Flushing -- had testified.
Industry -- power stations, paper mills, cement plants and other large production units -- is now moving to waterside sites more than twice as fast as it did a year ago.
In Federal Reserve System circles here it is felt that this year's business recovery has been achieved without generating and serious inflationary influences.

PARIS, July 24 -- The French Government vigorously denied today Tunisian charges that new French troop reinforcements had been landed in the Bizerte area since the proclamation of an uneasy cease-fire there.

Woodcutters leveling a path for the final 1.3-mile segment of the Clearview Expressway in Queens were nearing the end of their job yesterday in Cunningham Park between Seventy-third and Hillside Avenues.

Sir Abubakar Tafawa Balewa, Prime Minister of Nigeria, arrived by air yesterday to start an official visit. It will take him and his party to Washington this morning and later to Chicago and Knoxville, Tenn., before his return to New York next Monday.
HAVANA, July 24 (AP) -- Maj. Yuri A. Gagarin, the Soviet space pilot, arrived in Havana today for celebrations marking the eighth anniversary of the start of the Cuban Revolution.
One hundred jockeys led by Eddie Arcaro volunteered yesterday to replace striking exercise boys in morning workouts at Aqueduct and Belmont race tracks.

CINCINNATI, July 24 (AP) -- United States District Judge John H. Druffel overruled today a motion for an injunction to halt a proposed merger of the Ohio River Company with Eastern Gas and Fuel Associates. The transaction is scheduled to be completed on Wednesday.

Next Monday afternoon movie stars will flash toothy smiles, civic officials will line up for photographs, Mayor Wagner will cut a chain of flowers, television cameras will grind away and traffic will be tied up along Lexington Avenue.

The Transnation Realty Corporation, Henry Goelet, president, has purchased thirteen properties in Queens in a package deal. The parcels were bought from the Cohen-Krausher Realty Corporation. They include three gasoline stations, a shopping center and eight parcels of vacant land. The price was about $1,000,000.

WASHINGTON, July 24 -- Charles J. Hitch, Controller of the Defense Department, outlined a new Pentagon budgeting system today. It is designed to help civilian policymakers keep a closer check on the department's spending plans.
Tilden Cummings, president and director of the Continental Illinois Bank and Trust Company, has been elected a director of the American Brake Shoe Company.
The Israeli merchant marine is making progress toward the 1,000,000-ton mark, a goal set as part of a $160,000,000, five-year expansion plan.
WASHINGTON, July 24 -- President Kennedy's program for $8,800,000,000 in long-term foreign-aid loans was formally approved by the Senate Foreign Relations Committee today.

Production of steel in the nation last week was almost even with that of the preceding seven days. In the earlier period, output had turned sharply upward after six consecutive weeks of declines. Even so, it was still well below the levels of previous weeks.

COOPERSTOWN, N.Y., July 24 (AP) -- The Los Angeles Dodgers whipped the Baltimore Orioles, 6 -- 2, today. Three Dodger pitchers teamed for a five-hitter in the annual Hall of Fame Cup game before 9,787 fans at Doubleday Field.
GENEVA, July 24 -- The conference on a treaty to ban nuclear tests continued today in what the Soviet delegate described as a "war of words."
ELISABETHVILLE, the Congo, July 24 -- Godefroid Munongo, Interior Minister of secessionist Katanga Province, said today that his Government had accepted offers of help from the Soviet Union.
WASHINGTON, July 24 -- U.E. Baughman, chief of the United States Secret Service, plans to retire next month.

LONDON, Tuesday, July 25 (AP) -- A financial battle between two United States pharmaceutical companies for a stake in British Drug Houses (B.D.H.), a large concern with offshoots throughout the British Commonwealth, came into the open today. Mead Johnson Co. and the Warner-Lambert Pharmaceutical Co., Inc., are the United States concerns.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 24 -- Mongi Slim of Tunisia conferred today with the President of the Security Council, Dr. Leopoldo Benites of Ecuador, on the continued tension caused by reported French violations of the cease-fire in Tunisia.

PARIS, July 24 -- Although it was a mad scramble up the long curling stairway to Cardin's salon, an almost hair-tearing battle to hold on to one's seat and an exhausting wait for the collection finally to begin, it was worth it.

The arrival in Washington next Monday of Nationalist China's Premier General Chen Cheng and Foreign Minister Shen Chang-huan will inaugurate one of this year's more important state visits of foreign leaders to this country.

The Japanese Government has canceled a visa it had issued to Dr. Herbert Aptheker, a member of the national committee of the Communist party of the United States, who had intended to attend a Tokyo conference against nuclear weapons.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., July 24 -- Lifeguards at this city's public beaches were instructed today to be clean shaven and to have neat crewcuts at all times as part of a campaign to correct beach conditions.
Record sales and earnings were reported yesterday by the Corn Products Company for the quarter and six months ended on June 30.

The bullish excitement that has dominated the bond market over most of the past fortnight died down yesterday. Trading lapsed into a quiet session more characteristic of the midsummer vacation season.
The state has disciplined seventeen physicians thus far in connection with frauds in injury cases, and expects to check on the activities of about 300 others.

WASHINGTON, July 24 -- The United States will soon open a new phase in the scientific exploration of the moon and the planets. It will do this by sending a complex satellite on a test mission more than 500,000 miles into space.

WASHINGTON, July 24 -- Tunisia's Ambassador, Habib Bourguiba Jr., challenged the Western world today to help Tunisia end the Bizerte conflict "before another world does." His mention of "another world" was an allusion to the Communist-bloc countries.

TUNIS, July 24 (AP) -- Tunisia, which suffered heavy losses in the military action touched off by Tunisian fire on French aircraft last Wednesday, charged today that landing barges had debarked French reinforcements at Cap Blanc, five miles north of Bizerte.

Mrs. Robert A. Schmid is chairman and Mrs. William Joshua Barney Jr. is honorary chairman of the benefit evening performance Nov. 1 of the National Horse Show at Madison Square Garden and a reception and supper dance at the Astor in honor of the international jumping teams.

When Representative Edith Green of Oregon led a House subcommittee through a Brooklyn slum a few hours after a teen-ager had been murdered in a squabble over a dime, the youths to whom she talked made it plain that the thing they needed and wanted most was a job. Perhaps their words will help provide the push required to speed Congressional action on the Administration's proposal for a Youth Employment Opportunities Act.

FIT and flare, the trend that has made itself felt along Seventh Avenue, has successfully invaded Arnold Constable's fur department, but there is a variety of other designs for those whose taste is along more classic lines.
Massachusetts Investors Trust, the nation's oldest and second largest mutual fund, reported yesterday that net assets on June 30 were 13.7 per cent above the 1960 level.

The Honolulu Oil Corporation has postponed indefinitely a special stockholders' meeting that had been scheduled for Friday to consider the sale of its assets for $380,000,000 to a subsidiary of the Standard Oil Company (Indiana) and the Tidewater Oil Company.
LAS VEGAS, Nev., July 24 (UPI) -- The Del E. Webb Corporation has completed negotiations to acquire the Sahara-Nevada Corporation of Las Vegas, a $20,000,000 hotel holding company.
MIAMI, July 24 -- An armed passenger took over an Eastern Air Lines Electra over Florida today and forced the pilot to fly to Havana. The plane carried thirty-three passengers and five crew members.

A FEW months before he died, the one and only Christian Dior embraced his young protege Pierre Cardin at a large dinner party and told him Paris would forever remain the center of haute couture so long as there were new, bright talents such as his.
WASHINGTON, July 24 (AP) -- The Senate Interior Committee approved today a bill to promote Federal and state preservation of shoreline areas for public recreational use.
Four hours of off-the-record meetings failed to produce a settlement yesterday of unfair labor practice charges filed against the General Electric Company by the National Labor Relations Board.

The United states met strong opposition from Czechoslovakia in the sixth round of the students chess tournament at Helsinki yesterday, according to a report from Finland. The Czechs led, 1 -- 0, with three games adjourned.

THE world everywhere today is poised between victory and surrender. In an infinitude of different guises presented by the books that reach this table that is the somber alternative of our disheveled era.
Two of the city's major banking institutions have announced the acquisition of equipment to facilitate their bookkeeping.

In his address of July 8 to new military officers of the U.S.S.R., Khrushchev announced that the Soviet Government has suspended the cut in its armed forces which had been planned for this year. He also announced that the Soviet defense budget for 1961 was to be increased by 3.144 billion rubles.

Net income of the Packaging Corporation of America for the fiscal year ended on June 30 fell to $4,090,000, or 97 cents a common share, from $6,510,715, or $1.64 a share, for the preceding year, W.D.P. Carey, president, disclosed in a preliminary report at a meeting of the New York Society of Security Analysts yesterday.
WASHINGTON, July 24 (AP) -- Senator Allen J. Ellender urged today legislation that he contended would cut down on crop surpluses, save money for the taxpayers and help the farmers.

WASHINGTON, July 24 (AP) -- Attorney General Robert F. Kennedy said today there had been a lot of talk but little action to improve the physical fitness of American youth. He said foreign boys and girls consistently outperformed them in physical tests.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), July 24 -- Adolf Eichmann completed his testimony today before an Israeli tribunal trying him on charges of having directed the annihilation of millions of Jews.
A 10 o'clock scholar may find it difficult to qualify for "The College of the Air." The credit course in biology will be televised over Channel 2 at 6 A.M., Monday through Friday, beginning Sept, 25.

The Humble Oil and Refining Company, domestic affiliate of the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) announced yesterday an increase of 3/10-cent a gallon in prices of light heating oils, Diesel fuel and kerosene in fifteen East Coast states and the District of Columbia.
SIOUX FALLS, S.D., July 21 -- Hot air balloons, the first vehicles to lift man into the sky 178 years ago and later abandoned as impractical, have staged a comeback here.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., July 24 (AP) -- Peaches Bartokowicz of Hamtramck, Mich., the defender, gained the quarterfinals of the girls' 13-years-old-and-under division today in the national junior tennis tournament.
Newburgh officials conferred with the State Attorney General here yesterday on the city's controversial new welfare code, which may face legal challenge.
FAIRFIELD, Conn., July 24 -- The regulars arrived today at the New York Giants' training camp and the coaching staff promptly began experimenting.
Inaccuracy in reporting and editorializing is becoming more and more the hallmark of The New York Times. Your latest transgressions appear in your July 20 editorial.
LONDON, July 24 -- Qualified sources disclosed tonight that Britain intends to strengthen her front-line forces in Germany and alert part of her strategic reserve to meet Soviet pressure in Berlin.

Anthony Baldanza, a Brooklyn insurance broker, and Alexander DeRise, the proprietor of a bowlers' pro shop, are good mixers. They got stirred up two months ago and the resulting concoction was an unusual bowling league.
Saferris of the Two Brooks Farm was one of several friends of the favorite players at Aqueduct yesterday, where the fellows who like the chalk had a carefree day.
COLLEGE shops are opening in many New York department stores. Although clothes for college can he found in most stores, only those with special departments are listed below:
JERUSALEM, (Israeli Sector), July 24 -- The Knesset (Parliament) affirmed today the Cabinet decision absolving Pinhas Lavon of blame for a disastrous adventure seven years ago.
WASHINGTON, July 24 (UPI) -- The Bureau of Engraving and Printing accused recently of racial discrimination, has hired its first Negro machinist, the Treasury announced today.
The Jesuit weekly America regards the latest papal encyclical as one that manifests "calm confidence, a burning thirst for justice and an abiding sense of human compassion."
A letter on this page today gives Senator Barry Goldwater's reply to a Times editorial of July 20 on the Newburgh welfare controversy.

WASHINGTON, July 24 -- The Kennedy Administration came out today in favor of private ownership and operation of a communication satellite system capable of linking together "the farthest corners of the globe."

CANBERRA, Australia, July 24 (AP) -- The Antarctic Treaty Organization concluded a two-week meeting today with a communique announcing agreement on sixteen recommendations that will be presented to member governments.
WASHINGTON, July 24 (AP) -- The Justice Department is seeking grounds for possible criminal prosecution of George Lincoln Rockwell of Arlington, Va., and his American Nazi Party.
DETROIT, July 24 (AP) -- The automobile industry is wondering if it has built enough 1961 cars in the popular models to last until the 1962's come on the market late in September.
OTTAWA, July 24 -- Louis Rasminsky was appointed Governor of the Bank of Canada today to succeed James E. Coyne.
NEW HAVEN, July 24 -- The first Federal Court hearing in are reorganization of the bankrupt New Haven Railroad will be held here tomorrow noon.

TUNIS, July 24 -- Dag Hammarskjold, United Nations Secretary General, arrived here tonight at the invitation of President Habib Bourguiba. The Secretary General will seek a solution for the impasse created by the French military occupation of the region of Bizerte.

New York City has borrowed $30,000,000 on tax anticipation notes due on Nov. 1, 1961, at an interest rate of 1 7/8 per cent, Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa said yesterday. The notes were sold by allotment to eighteen banks and trust companies, as follows:

General Telephone Electronics Corporation's second quarter was marked by "a gradual improvement in overall business," Donald C. Power, chairman and chief executive officer, announced yesterday. "The improvement was not sufficient, however, to overcome a slow first quarter, with the result that net income for the half trailed the year-ago level," he said.

The charge in your editorial of July 9, that "Congress is still dawdling, weeks behind schedule, over one of the most vital measures of our foreign and defense policies -- the foreign-aid bill" is most unfair.
SALISBURY, Southern Rhodesia, July 24 -- The police fired on African rioters here today, killing two men and wounding four.
IN view of the squalid news about the schools of New York City, here are some facts and comments, about a school -- probably a typical school -- in a farming area in Greene County.

State Controller Arthur Levitt, Democratic organization candidate for Mayor, charged yesterday that New York City had drifted under Mayor Wagner "without direction, without guidance and without leadership."

It would be interesting to know how many people would turn to the nearest atlas or map of Europe if asked to locate Ruritania. With the world in a perpetual state of international effervescence these days most of us have a more accurate notion of where remote lands are than people did a generation or two ago, but it is safe to guess that for some Ruritania might be a puzzler.
OTTAWA, July 24 -- Louis Rasminsky, named today as governor of the Bank of Canada, has driven some hard bargains as Canada's representative on the International Monetary Fund.
GARDEN CITY, L.I., July 24 -- The qualifying round in the junior division of the Long Island Golf Association tournamnet ended in a three-way tie for first at 75 today.

According to a recent study by the mortgage finance committee of the American Bankers Association, a majority of bankers throughout the country believe that mortgage interest rates will remain steady during the next few months.

LOS ANGELES, July 24 (AP) -- The Detroit Tigers took command on Rocky Colavito's twenty-eighth homer -- a three-run shot in the sixth inning -- and increased their American League lead over the Yankees to a game by defeating the Angels, 5 -- 2, tonight.
TUNIS, July 24 -- For the moment the battle of Bizerte is over. Both sides observe a nervous cease-fire, the dead are buried and the diplomats talk.
Plans of the Wiltwyck School for Boys to relocate in Yorktown were upset yesterday by the State Supreme Court's Appellate Division.

The Kalart Company, Inc., Plainville, Conn., manufacturer of photographic equipment, has announced the purchase of Technical Service, Inc., Farmington, Mich., producer of special purpose projectors. The transaction is effective Sept. 1.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 10 points off to 5 up yesterday. A point equals 5 cents a bale.

The Echo I satellite will be visible over New York, weather permitting, twenty-four times between today and Sunday, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration announced in Washington yesterday.
Pan American World Airways flight engineers and pilots began secret negotiations here yesterday in an effort to settle their dispute over the manning of jet cockpits.
WASHINGTON, July 24 -- Treasury borrowing costs rose fractions on today's marketing two issues of bills.
LOWELL, Mass., July 24 (AP) -- Fire in a crowded tenement early today took the lives of a mother and five of her ten children.
CHICAGO, July 24 (AP) -- The re!ort of toIdaN's livesiock markets ere by the 'DeactI ment of Agriculture follovs:

WASHINGTON, July 24 (AP) -- Edgar Hoover, Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, reported today an "astounding" upsurge of crime in the United States. Arrests and convictions are increasing but not as rapidly as offenses, he said.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., July 24 -- Slinging Sammy Baugh, the head coach of the New York Titans, took one look at the thermometer this morning, whistled, and sent his squad of sixty-five Titans out for their first contact drill.
LONDON, July 24 -- Dancers who appeared with the Leningrad State Kirov Ballet here recently cost the National Health Service slightly more than 100 ($280) for dental treatment.

WASHINGTON, July 24 -- "All they [Eastern railroad presidents talk about," said Chairman Heineman of the Chicago North Western Railway in an interview with Robert E. Bedingfield of this newspaper, published in its July 23 issue, "is their passenger problems and their need for subsidy assistance.

FORT MONMOUTH, N.J., July 24 -- The Army Signal Materiel Support Agency here today made public what is believed to be the world's largest automatic dry battery test facility. It is capable of testing 17,280 batteries at one time.
The Wagner administration is considering a forty-hour week for the city's 24,000 policemen, 13,000 firemen and 2,000 correction officers.

An acting State Supreme Court justice yesterday dismissed the Parochial Bus System's application seeking to restrain the Board of Education from negotiating a five-year contract with the Children's Bus Service, Inc.

PARIS, July 24 -- The United States Grand Prix, counting toward the race-car drivers' world championship, may be held at the Daytona International Speedway at Daytona Beach, Fla., in late November, Alex Ulmann, the race promoter, said today.
Commodity activity on the New York exchanges yesterday reflected mid-summer sluggishness. Prices held to moderate ranges and volume was small.

WASHINGTON, July 24 (AP) -- Federal Judge Edward A. Tamm denied today the motion for a preliminary injunction sought by twelve Hollywood writers and actors who said they had been blacklisted in the motion picture industry.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 24 -- Many actors have become movie directors. But it is doubtful if any have chosen the roundabout path of J. Lee Thompson, who directed "The Guns of Navarone" and the recently filmed "Cape Fear."
Jack Elliott, a vagabond minstrel whose theme has been the song of the open road for nearly half, of his thirty years, rambled into Gerde's Folk City last week.

LONDON, July 24 -- Prices advanced in the stock market here today despite the fact that the Chancellor of the Exchequer will announce tomorrow measures to curb spending and to improve Britain's economic position.
LONDON, July 24 (AP) -- "Bingo is a greater sin than sex immorality," said the Rev. Cyril Blount yesterday as he faced 400 enthusiastic bingo fans.
PARIS, July 24 -- Stock markets on the continent snapped back today after the sharp declines of the last few weeks.

Second-quarter earnings of the American Can Company were 23.8 per cent higher than those of the 1960 period, on a sales gain of 2.5 per cent, it was announced yesterday. The company is a leading manufacturer of metal, paper and plastic packaging products.
WASHINGTON, July 24 (UPI) -- J.W. Fulbright, the Senate Foreign Relations Committee chairman, denied today a contention that he favored "nonintervention" against Communism.

Stocks drowsed through a quiet session of the New York Stock Exchange yesterday and closed with unimpressive gains, largely in steels, golds and rails. Oils, coppers and drugs were weak. Changes in other groups were mostly in fractions.

The Minerals and Chemicals Philipp Corporation is expanding its mining interests in Latin American through the acquisition of a controlling share in Compania Minera Santa Fe for $8,000,000, half in cash and half in notes.
LONDON, July 24 -- Reginald Bevins, the Postmaster General, told the House of Commons today that he was raising postal and telephone charges, beginning Wednesday.

MILWAUKEE, July 24 (AP) -- Joey Jay scored his fourteenth victory tonight with the help of a fourteen-hit attack led by Frank Robinson as the Cincinnati Reds beat the Braves, 9 -- 3. The loss snapped the Braves' five-game winning streak.
WASHINGTON, July 24 -- President Kennedy's Cabinet, which is seldom summoned to official meetings, has decided to hold unofficial gatherings.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 24 -- This city, the birthplace of the United Nations, was planning today a salute to the people of African nations.
Blood will be given to the Red Cross today at the First National City Bank of New York, 20 Exchange Place, by employes of downtown securities concerns.
THEY inducted Max Carey and the late Billy Hamilton into the Hall of Fame at Cooperstown yesterday. In the case of O1' Maximillian, it certainly was a distinction long overdue.
A Baltimore savings and loan company was directed yesterday to show cause why it should not be barred from the securities business in New York State.
The New York Central Railroad cleared $56,289, equal to 1 cent a share, for June, the company reported yesterday. This compared with earnings of $1,017,436, or 16 cents a share in June, 1960.
LONDON, July 24 -- More than 600 public housing tenants in the town of Smethwick are threatening a rent strike tomorrow to keep a Pakistani family from moving into their development.
THE deal shown today was played in the Brooklyn tournament held over the week-end.

INGLEWOOD, Calif., July 24 (UPI) -- The favored Whodunit, a distance-loving horse who won the same stakes two years ago, came back today to capture the $85,800 Sunset Handicap by three and three-quarters lengths in the stakes that brought the Hollywood Park meeting to a close.
WASHINGTON, July 24 -- Following is the text of President Kennedy's statement on communication satellite policy:

WASHINGTON, July 24 (AP) -- The Treasury agreed today to go along with a bill by Senator John J. Williams, Republican of Delaware, to give a tax break to stockholders in E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., in the antitrust case involving du Pont's General Motors stock.
WASHINGTON, July 24 (AP) -- The Peace Corps will begin training next Monday about 150 men and women who will serve in the Philippines as teaching assistants in English and general science.

President Kennedy's foreign aid program, a major weapon in his crusade for freedom, appears to be well on its way toward final victory. There will be some cuts and changes, but the indications are that it will come out of the Congressional wringer substantially intact and, in any case, adequate enough to meet the needs for which it was devised.
CAPE CANAVERAL, July 24 (UPI) -- Capt. Virgil I. Grissom, America's second man in space, went through intensive interrogation again today by engineers and psychologists.
The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company will allocate $180,000,000 for capital expenditures in 1961 and 1962, E.J. Thomas, chairman, said yesterday.

ABOUT this time each year shooters tend to consider the family coffers with larcenous intent. Their minds are on guns and associated equipment because The Shooter's Bible, the Stoeger Arms Corporation catalogue, has been published.
ALEXANDRIA, Va., July 24 (UPI) -- Junius Irving Scales, former leader of the Communist party in the Carolinas, lost an appeal today for a reduction of a six-year prison sentence.
A new type of high-speed alloy steel described as nearly as hard as a diamond has been developed and put into commercial production by Continental Copper and Steel Industries, Inc.

WASHINGTON, July 24 (AP) -- The Commerce Department today announced action against a New York electronics concern and a freight company, accusing them of plotting to ship strategic goods behind the Iron Curtain.
TUNIS, July 24 -- Everyone concerned -- France, Tunisia, the United States and the Western powers -- stands to lose heavily in the Bizerte crisis.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y. July 24 -- As recently as 1955 Japan was the world's largest importer of rice, with a volume of 1,246,400 metric tons. Today a spectacular expansion of domestic output is causing concern over the prospect of surplus production.
The San Francisco Giants, New York's prodigal sons, proved last night that you can go home again -- and in style, too.
Despite lower second-quarter sales, the National Steel Corporation increased its net income to $10,302,140 or $1.35 a share from $9,583,019 and $1.26 the 1960 quarter, the company reported.

Burnham Co., investment bankers and brokers, has leased one floor and most of another in the office building being constructed by the Uris Buildings Corporation at 60 Broad Street. The lease, which involves 55,000 square feet of space, was negotiated by Anthony J. Peters, executive vice president of Cushman Wakefield, Inc., renting agent for the building.
Tad Mosel's prize-winning drama, "All the Way Home," announced yesterday that it would end its Broadway run on Saturday night after 278 performances.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 24 -- Kuwait is informing Arab League states that the arrival of a token Arab force would bring about the full withdrawal of the British forces from Kuwait. The sheikdom is also offering to earmark oil revenue funds for general Arab development projects.
RED BANK, N.J., July 24 -- Consciences are not traveling as fast as the cars on the Garden. State Parkway yet, but they are catching up.

Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., and subsidiaries reported yesterday gains in operating revenues and net income for twelve and six months ended on June 30. However, share earnings in both periods declined slightly because of increased dividends on preferred stock and an increased number of shares outstanding in the most recent period.
The Police Safety Bureau reported yesterday that 1,015 persons had been injured in the city last week in automobile mishaps. This was a drop of eighty-two from the similar period the year before.
" The oil industry is going through a frenzied period in which advertising agencies are taking the rap for the antiquated marketing methods of the big petroleum companies."

WASHINGTON, July 25 -- President Kennedy said tonight in his speech to the nation that he would ask Congress for $207,000,000 in additional funds for civil defense, including a household warning system.
WASHINGTON, July 25 -- Senator Styles Bridges fired the opening rounds today in what is expected to become a sustained Republican attack against United States plans to recognize Outer Mongolia.

Carlos Moseley has been appointed managing director of the New York Philharmonic by the board of directors of the orchestra society, it was announced today. Mr. Moseley succeeds the late George E. Judd Jr., who held the post from June, 1959, until his death last July 1.
Cotton futures prices moved 30 cents a bale up to 10 cents off yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange. The near months were strongest.
The Transit Authority announced with satisfaction yesterday that it had gained almost twenty million fares and increased its passenger revenues by $3,023,934 in the fiscal year that ended June 30.
IT wasn't the heat. It was the incredibility -- of "The Little Hut," which came to the Forty-first Street Theatre last night.

The sixteen-story buildingl containing thirty-three apartments at 935 Park Avenue,I southeast corner of Eighty-i first Street, has been purchased', by the tenants. Norman F.i Levy, vice president of theI Cross Brown Company, was the broker.

C.L. Sulzberger stated in your July 12 issue that "it is worth while considering among offers we could make to reinsure our tenure in Berlin whether, as a quid pro quo, we might legally recognize Russian absorption of the Baltic states and also agree to the Oder-Neisse border between Germany and Poland * * *."

BALTIMORE, July 25 (UPI) -- Steve Barber pitched hitless ball for six and a third innings tonight, recording his eleventh victory with a four-hitter as the Baltimore Orioles beat the Boston Red Sox, 5 -- 1.
WASHINGTON, July 25 -- President Kennedy outlined a series of measures tonight that will provide a 1,000,000-man army for the first time since 1956.
WASHINGTON, July 25 (AP) -- Revenues and expenditures of cities rose in the fiscal year 1960, the census Bureau reported today.

Robert Whitehead, president of the League of New York Theatres, expressed optimism yesterday on the chances of getting city officials to abolish the 5 per cent ticket tax for legitimate theatres this season.
The anti-Tammany Democrats led by former Senator Herbert H. Lehman endorsed Mayor Wagner and his ticket last night by a vote of 84 to 1, with three abstentions.
CHICAGO, July 25 (AP) -- The United Cement Workers announced today that two-year agreements providing a 14-cent-an-hour wage increase had been negotiated with all major companies.

Reflecting record unit sales for most products in the first hall of this year, earnings of the Cities Service Company rose 28 per cent above those for the 1960 period, Burl S. Watson, chairman, reported yesterday.

GENEVA, July 25 -- The Soviet Union attacked today as a "cold war" maneuver a United States proposal for an international corps of volunteers to work under the United Nations technical assistance program.

Except for a bit of hestitation in the fifth hour, quickly swallowed up in the closing minutes, the stock market rose briskly all day yesterday. Aggregate market value on the New York Stock Exchange gained 0.55 per cent.

The Gulf Oil Corporation reported yesterday that consolidated net income for the first half of this year was $169,701,000, or $1.64 a share. This represented an increase of 8.7 per cent from the $156,096,000, or $1.51 a share, cleared in the first six months of 1960.
The moves announced in London yesterday to defend the British pound are fully as rigorous as advanced warnings suggested they would be.
Since Dukla of Czechoslovakia has climbed the second-section title, tonight's International Soccer League double-header at the Polo Grounds will pair teams fighting for lesser honors.
John W. Galbreath's Wintervale, favored at 65 cents to the dollar, had an easy time turning back half a dozen rival 3-year-olds in the seven-furlong allowance feature at Aqueduct yesterday.
JULES-FRANCOIS CRAHAY, the Belgian-born designer who has injected new vitality into the aging house of Nina Ricci, is a man of many tastes.
GARDEN CITY, L.I., July 25 -- Paul Young of Clarke High led the way into the semi-final round in the junior division of the Long Island Golf Association tournament today.

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), July 25 -- Two American Jewish Orthodox spiritual leaders called on American and Israeli rabbis today to organize a "joint Torah corps" to visit communities in under-developed nations and assist in strengthening Jewish religious life.

WASHINGTON, July 25 -- High-ranking British officials arrived here today to discuss the substantial drawing on the International Monetary Fund that is a major part of Britain's effort to strengthen her economy and her currency.

CHICAGO, July 25 (AP) -- A Couple of Government reports brought soybean futures their most general bullish support in several weeks today and prices on the Board of Trade gained more than 5 cents a bushel.
HAVANA, July 25 -- Six Soviet-built MIG's flew over Havana today in the first public display of Cuba's new jet strength.

The section of the Federal bankruptcy laws that involves bankrupt railroads such as the New Haven, which had its case heard in court yesterday, actually provides for the opposite of what bankruptcy laws provide for industrial corporations.

DEPENDING on one's preference in reference books, Lilith was either an Assyrian demon, vampire and "night-monster"; or a Jewish demon of Babylonian origin, an embodiment of female evil, best known for a legend that she was Adam's first wife. Whoever she was, her reputation is bad.

The American Shakespeare Festival Theatre and Academy at Stratford, Conn., will benefit from a preview performance of "Kean" on Nov. 1. The musical, based on Jean-Paul Sartre's play about Edmund Kean, is scheduled to open at the Broadway Theatre on Nov. 2.

THIS almost sounds like a piece of cloak-and-dagger business. The Russians have a couple of agents in this country, and they are interested in buying a horse. Not any horse, mind you, because they have plenty of those in their own country, real big ones, which Khrushchev insists his people will eat should the food situation become that acute.
JUNEAU, Alaska, July 25 -- Alaska is about to offer its first state government bond issue.

TWENTY YEARS AGO, style was epitomized by the plat-form-soled shoe, the broad-shouldered suit and the thin, young woman who hurried through midtown Manhattan, divulging her haughty status with the Cavanagh hatbox she carried.

The six-story apartment house on a plot 100 by 90 feet at 110 Bank Street in Greenwich Village has been sold by Bank Street Properties, Inc., which erected the building in 1958. It contains sixty-one apartments and a self-service elevator.

ATLANTA, July 25 -- A tournament played at Chattanooga, Tenn., over the week-end drew a cosmopolitan attendance for a relatively small sectional tournament. One reason was that several high-ranking tournament players were driving from farther west to the national tournament that will begin in Washington, D.C., on Saturday, and they stopped off for some practice.

RICHMOND, Va., July 25 -- Reynolds Metals Company and two of its subsidiaries have filed suit against Cuba seeking to recover $7,303,000 as compensation for funds and properties confiscated late last year.

HAVERFORD, Pa., July 25 -- Three times within a stroke of defeat after trailing at 6-7 and 0-40 in the third set, Robert Mark of Australia almost miraculously averted disaster and defeated Mike Green in the Pennsylvania lawn tennis championships today.
BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., July 25 (UPI) -- After a strenuous contact scrimmage the day before, the New York Football Titans limited their activity today to two light drills in shorts and T-shirts.

The new nations that formerly made up French West Africa represent a virtually untapped market for United States exports, from air conditioners to road-building equipment. This was among the main conclusions of a United States trade mission that recently made a seven-week visit to the West African area.

WASHINGTON, July 25 (UPI) -- The Senate Appropriations Committee gave President Kennedy today all of the extra $549,000,000 he asked to speed the space program and put a man on the moon within a decade.
Plans to sell American sport jackets and barbecue wagons in Britain will have to be shelved for the duration of the new austerity program announced in London yesterday.

Angry verbal duels between stockholders and management of the Sperry Rand Corporation highlighted the three-hour annual meeting of the big defense products and business machines company at the Astor Hotel here yesterday.

LIFE is no longer a picnic for Jimmy Yu. In fact, since he opened his own restaurant (the House of Yu, 2090 Linden Boulevard, Brooklyn) some five months ago, he has not had time for a single picnic with his friends.

New peace efforts failed yesterday to break the deadlock in the twenty-five-day-old strike of concrete-mix drivers. The Investing Builders Association reported last night that the walkout had forced a near-halt on projects involving $500,000,000 in construction.
VIENNA, July 25 -- The Austrian Government has run into difficulties in coping with Austrian extremists believed involved in terrorist activities in Italy's Alto Adige.
WASHINGTON, July 25 (UPI) -- A Treasury official said today that a house-passed pension bill for the self-employed would cost the Government $358,000,000 a year in tax revenues.
A combination of near-record heat and very high humidity kept the city and the suburban areas sweltering yesterday for the fifth consecutive day of 90-degree temperature or more.
CHICAGO, July 25 (UPI) -- Ken Boyer of the Cardinals hit a grand-slam home run before the first out was made today. But St. Louis had to exploit one of four Chicago errors to beat the Cubs, 6-5.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 25 (AP) -- The Homestake Mining Company and the Sabre-Pinon Corporation announced jointly last night a plan for combining their uranium interests in the Ambrosia Lake district of New Mexico.
NEWBURGH, N.Y., July 25 -- Newburgh's city officials decided today to ignore an ultimatum from the state and proceed with their controversial new welfare code.
A major shipline opened a new inland cargo-consolidation site here yesterday, in effect moving much of its waterfront pier operations into the heart of Chelsea.

Federal agents and the New York police checked airline passenger lists and watched airplane departures for Florida here yesterday after reports had circulated that sympathizers of Premier Castro planned to seize five airliners and divert them to Cuba.
SPRINGFIELD, Ohio, July 25 (AP) -- The field of nearly 175 boys was trimmed to sixty-four today in the Western junior and boys' tennis championship.

NEW ORLEANS, July 25 (AP) -- The United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit will review a Federal judge's decision in a case involving suits filed by Alabama Gov. John Patterson and Montgomery City Commissioner Frank W. Parks against The New York Times.
Victor Wittgenstein, concert pianist, was found dead yesterday in the rear courtyard of the building where he lived at 260 West Seventy-second Street.
EAST HAMPTON, L.I., July 25 -- The focal point of the East Hampton summer season is the annual Ladies Village Improvement Society Fair, held traditionally on the last Friday in July.

LOS ANGELES, July 25 (AP) -- The Los Angeles Angels dissipated a two-run lead in the top of the ninth but rallied for two runs in the same inning and knocked the Detroit Tigers out of first place in the American League by defeating them tonight, 5 -- 4. Eddie Yost's single with two out drove in the winning run.
PHILADELPHIA, July 25 (AP) -- A three-run homer by Gil Hodges and a two-run triple by John Roseboro powered the Los Angeles Dodgers to a 7-2 victory over the Philadelphia Phillies tonight.
WASHINGTON, July 25 (UPI) -- House Republicans temporarily sidetracked today a Senate-approved plan to build the world's largest atomic power plant at Hanford, Wash.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 25 -- The United Nations has appealed urgently for additional troops for the Congo, officials here said today. The troops are needed to replace the Tunisian contingent being withdrawn because of the Bizerte crisis.

The Second Symphony by George Rochberg has won the 1961 Naumburg Recording Award in the field of orchestral music. Mr. Rochberg's work was composed in 1956, and was first performed three years later by the Cleveland Orchestra under George Szell.
PHILADELPHIA, July 25 -- The directors of the Reading Railroad today deferred action on the dividend on the first preferred stock because of mounting losses.
WASHINGTON, July 25 -- Administration forces in Congress claimed the votes today to pass President Kennedy's long-range foreign aid program without serious modification.
A campaign against illegal and unlicensed taxicabs operating in the city was ordered yesterday by Mayor Wagner.
An application by 900 dock workers for state unemployment insurance benefits during the recent eighteen-day strike by seamen and officers was rejected yesterday.
MINEOLA, L.I., July 25 -- Nassau county executive A. Moses today made it clear in a telegram to the Federal Aviation Agency that their plans for Mitchell Field did not include a civilian airport.
WASHINGTON, July 25 -- Outraged Senators demanded forceful United States action today to bring about the release of an Eastern Air Lines airplane by the Cuban Government.
Twenty pickets marched for about half an hour at City Hall yesterday morning to protest the planned use of paper ballots in the Republican primary election Sept. 7.

MIAMI, July 25 -- Thirty-two passengers and the five crew members of the Eastern Air Lines Electra that was commandeered by a passenger yesterday and forced to fly to Havana returned to the United States today.

PHILADELPHIA, July 25 -- The Court of Common Pleas quashed today Republican petitions calling for a special grand jury investigation of the payola scandals and alleged contract frauds in Philadelphia's Democratic-controlled City Hall.
BINGHAMTON, N.Y. -- A gunman who tried to force an airline co-pilot to take him aloft was disarmed today after holding the flier at gunpoint for more than an hour.

Paperboard production rose to 310,025 tons last week from 245,221 tons in the preceding week, the National Paperboard Association reported yesterday, in the same week last year 310,052 tons were produced.
A thirty-story hotel with 700 rooms is planned by Loew's Hotels, Inc., at the northwest corner of Park Avenue and Sixty-first Street.
WASHINGTON, July 25 -- A railroad spokesman told Congress today that "a crisis of monumental proportion" might befall major segments of his industry unless relief was provided.

LONDON, July 25 -- Selwyn Lloyd, Chancellor of the Exchequer, announced today his long-heralded measures to reduce home consumption and Government spending and to stimulate exports and strengthen the pound.
WASHINGTON, July 25 -- The American consumer paid $12.76 last month for goods and services that would have cost him $10 in 1947-49, the Labor Department reported today.

Al Dewlen has won the McGraw-Hill Fiction Award for his third novel, "Twilight of Honor." The prize consists of $2,500 as a grant and $7,500 as an advance against royalties. The award is given at any time during a calendar year to a writer with a novel in progress or a completed work.
The Federal Aviation Agency praised the airlines serving New York International Airport yesterday for "a definite effort to reduce the noise problem" in the area.

The Consolidated Edison Company announced yesterday it would comply with a Public Service Commission directive to redesign its Manhattan substations to prevent power failures such as occurred June 13.
WASHINGTON, July 25 (UPI) -- Secretary of Interior Stewart L. Udall announced today a new policy that he said would be of major aid in reducing school construction costs in eighteen states.
CHICAGO, July 25 -- Chicago's third International Trade Fair opened today. It will close Aug. 10.

WASHINGTON, July 25 -- President Kennedy and Premier Khrushchev have now done two things in common. They have announced increased defense expenditures [up $3,247,000,000 in the United States] and they have called for negotiations on Berlin and Germany.

One positive sign that the speculative surge in securities trading may be over, at least on the New York Stock Exchange, came yesterday. The exchange removed its ban on "stop orders" in the shares of eight companies, effective today. As a result, none of the stocks listed on the exchange are under this ban at present.
ALBANY, July 25 (AP) -- State grants totaling $190,000 will be made to sixteen districts to help them give special attention to potentially talented but underprivileged children.

Grayson-Robinson Stores, Inc., plans to expand its operations through an agreement to acquire 51 per cent of the common stock of the A.S. Beck Shoe Corporation from the Shoe Corporation of America, it was disclosed yesterday.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, July 25 (AP) -- Murray Halberg of New Zealand bettered the world record in the three-mile run at an international meet tonight. His time was 13 minutes 10 seconds. The listed record for the distance is 13:10.8. It was set by Al Thomas of Australia in 1958.

KANSAS CITY, July 25 (AP) -- Jim Perry of the Cleveland Indians held the Kansas City Athletics to two hits in seven innings tonight, but they got to him in the eighth for all their runs and went on to win, 3-2.
BLOCK ISLAND, R.I., July 25 -- George B. Gibbons Jr.'s forty-foot sloop Mariann won in the big-boat division of the American Yacht Club cruise for the second time in a row today.

The one-story taxpayer building at 15-17 Broad Street, Bloomfield, N.J., has been sold by the Sian Realty Company to an investing client of Albert D. Meltz, vice president of the Rachlin Company, Newark brokers.
BLOOMINGTON, Minn., July 25 (AP) -- Dick Donovan of the Washington Senators won his fourth straight game tonight as he outpitched Jack Kralick of the Minnesota Twins to triumph, 2 -- 1.
Sales of Merck Co., Inc., for the quarter and six months ended on June 30 exceeded those of the 1960 period, but earnings fell, the semi-annual report disclosed yesterday.

Hopes for racing at Saratoga Springs received a setback last night when James R. Hoffa rejected a plea by the resort's Mayor to let thoroughbred horses be moved from struck stables at Aqueduct and Belmont Park.
GENEVA, July 25 -- The conference on Laos agreed today on the substance of a general international undertaking to respect the independence and neutrality of the Southeast Asian kingdom.

The repertory for the season of the Leningrad Kirov Ballet (formerly the Maryinsky Ballet) at the Metropolitan Opera House beginning Sept. 11 has been announced by S. Hurok, the American impresario. He will bring the company to this country for a twelve-week tour under the Cultural Exchange Agreement between the United States and the Soviet Union.
Native folk art, which was mourned as dead, is apparently still alive, an art sleuth has discovered in travels around the country.

Prospects for a 1961 Grand Prix race in the United States aren't too bright. The hopes of the promoter, Alex Ulmann, to run the event on Nov. 25 at Daytona International Speedway in Florida, as reported from Paris yesterday, are dwindling, for several reasons.
LONDON, July 25 -- The Earl of Avon -- formerly Sir Anthony Eden -- went through traditional rites today to take his seat in the House of Lords.
Four-fifths of the ship classification work of the American Bureau of Shipping now involves vessels under construction abroad, David P. Browr president of the bureau, said yesterday.
WASHINGTON, July 25 (AP) -- Two of the five big companies that make Salk polio vaccine have halted production until they can eliminate a monkey virus that turned up in some of their output.

Druckman Hill, an accounting firm that recently merged with MacAlbert Bank Co., has leased a floor in the Union Dime Savings Bank Building at 111 West Fortieth Street, northwest corner of the Avenue of the Americas (Sixth Avenue).

In response to your July 5 editorial which cited the state government of New York as a model of fiscal health, in contrast to its neighbors, may I respectfully submit that the facts disclose a somewhat different picture.

Checking account velocity declined in June from the month before, but was above the 1960 level, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. The decrease was one-haft of 1 per cent from the May level at local reporting member banks.

LEOPOLDVILLE, The Congo, July 25 -- Antoine Gizenga, head of the Soviet-backed regime in Stanleyville, said today that he would attend the Parliament session scheduled to begin here within the next few days.

Sales volume of the Union Carbide Corporation in the second quarter of 1961 aggregated $383,159,000, for a gain of 5 per cent above the $364,299,000 of the first quarter. This compared with a volume of $376,341,000 in the 1960 period, Morse G. Dial, chairman and chief executive officer reported yesterday.

ANCHORAGE, Alaska, July 25 -- A six-man Italian team was reported today to have made the first ascent of the sheer south face of Mount McKinley, North America's loftiest peak. Its height is 20,320 feet.

LONDON, July 25 -- An immediate assessment of the effects of the Government's emergency measures was attempted today after the statement by the Chancellor of the Exchequer of his plans to improve the economy.

PITTSBURGH, July 25 (AP) -- The San Francisco Giants battered five Pittsburgh Pirate pitchers for twenty-two hits tonight as they exploded for a 16 -- 7 victory over the Bucs. The loss was Pittsburgh's fifth straight and ninth in last eleven games.
WESTBURY, L.I., July 24 -- Has Su Mac Lad been overraced this season?
WASHINGTON, July 25 -- The Senate neared completion tonight of a farm bill shorn of President Kennedy's major recommendation for dealing with the surplus. Passage is expected tomorrow.
PENN YAN, N.Y., July 25 -- Locating fishermen in this section of the Finger Lakes presents no special difficulty.

Middle South Utilities, Inc., and subsidiaries reported yesterday an increase of 4.2 per cent in operating revenues for the twelve months ended on June 30 and a decline of one-tenth of 1 per cent in such revenues for the first half of this year. However, net income increased by 14.7 per cent for the twelve months and by 10.5 per cent in the first half.
The city has undertaken a survey of all structures here to determine how well adapted the buildings are to provide protection against radioactive fall-out.

The position of the New York Racing Association, which conducts thoroughbred horse racing at Belmont, Aqueduct and Saratoga, continued yesterday to be a focus of dispute in the strike of grooms and other stable hands.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), July 25 -- The presentation of evidence was completed today in the trial of Adolf Eichmann.

WASHINGTON, July 25 -- Government scientists reported to Congress today that no solution was in sight for the critical problem of developing reliable methods of detecting clandestine nuclear explosions underground or in space.

An armed bank robber was shot dead and his confederate was captured yesterday in a wild gun battle with the police that sent hundreds of West Side pedestrians scurrying for cover. The gun battle followed a hold-up in which a bank official was wounded.
The New York City Housing Authority borrowed $25,822,000 at short term yesterday for the development of low-rent projects being financed with state subsidies.

Foreclosures of mortgages backed by the Federal Housing Administration and the Veterans Administration are running 85 per cent higher than those from conventional mortgages, according to a survey by the American Bankers Association.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 25 -- Contingents of Arab volunteers will leave for Tunisia "within the next few days," the Arab League reported today to the United Nations.
