LUGRIN, France, July 25 -- France and the rebel Provisional Government of Algeria reached an "accord in principle" today on the procedure of their peace talks here. Hard bargaining on the status of the Sahara began at once.
PHILADELPHIA, July 25 -- Thirty-four witnesses at a City Council hearing attacked tonight Mayor Richardson Dilworth's controversial parking plan for a congested South Philadelphia neighborhood.
NEW HAVEN, July 25 -- The Kennedy Administration put in a strong appeal today for a Kennedy supporter to become the trustee of the bankrupt New Haven Railroad.

TEHERAN, July 25 -- When he inserted a new fuse into his Berlin time bomb, Khrushchev inferentially posed three questions. Does he mean to grab West Berlin, regardless of risk? Does he mean merely to test Western unity and reserve? Or, does he mean to focus our attention on Berlin while planning a sudden crisis elsewhere?
Following is the text of President Kennedy's address to the nation last night, as recorded by The New York Times:
WASHINGTON, July 25 (AP) -- The Food and Drug Administrator testified today that worthless medicines had been sold over his objections.
FAIRFIELD, Conn., July 25 -- Hoping that Joel Wells may become as successful as Alex Webster, the New York football Giants today were cautiously pointing out similarities in the two halfbacks.

TUNIS, July 25 -- Observers in Tunisia attribute the Bizerte catastrophe to a series of miscalculations. These miscalculations are laid to President Habib Bourguiba, President de Gaulle and perhaps even to President Kennedy.

WASHINGTON, July 25 -- The House of Representatives approved today an Administration program to provide $180,000,000 in grants to help states, communities and nonprofit organizations improve their health service facilities.

Samuel Reshevsky and Bobby Fischer will leave for Los Angeles today where they are scheduled to meet tomorrow in the fifth game of their sixteen-game chess match. Eight games will be played on the Coast before the grandmasters return here to complete the series for the George P. Edgar Trophy.
The Wagner administration drafted a protest to the state Rent Commission yesterday about what the Mayor had called "exorbitant" rents in a West Side slum rooming house.

The City Planning Commission voted yesterday to let the city's builders file plans for new structures under the existing zoning law right up to Dec. 15, the date when the new Zoning Resolution will take effect.
BERLIN, July 25 -- West Germany's Minister for Refugees said today that the increasing flow of refugees from East Germany constituted "an unceasing accusation of the inhuman system there."

PARIS, July 25 -- French officials noted today a hardening of the position of President Habib Bourguiba of Tunisia in his dispute over the French base at Bizerte and an intensification of his diplomatic offensive.
SALISBURY, Southern Rhodesia, July 25 -- A new appeal was made today to African workers in this British colony to stay home as a protest during tomorrow's referendum on a new Constitution.
News of an increase in the British bank rate resulted in uneasy trading on the New York commodity exchanges. More futures declined than advanced and volume was moderate.
MILWAUKEE, July 25 (UPI) -- Lew Burdette of the Milwaukee Braves beat first-place Cincinnati, 2 -- 0, on a two-hitter tonight to trim the Reds' margin to one game over the Los Angeles Dodgers.
Joseph R. Weiss was suspended without pay yesterday as Deputy Superintendent of Schools in charge of construction and maintenance.
High-grade bond prices lost ground yesterday following the decision of the Bank of England to raise its discount charge on commercial bills from 5, to 7 per cent.
WASHINGTON, July 25 -- The Mali Embassy has denied a report that it would seek Soviet aid if the United States did not provide aid in building the Sotuba hydroelectric project.
RIO DE JANEIRO, July 25 -- President Janio Quadros announced today that he had given orders for a renewal of diplomatic relations with the Soviet Union.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, July 25 -- Delegates to the first conference of the Latin-American Free Trade Association have been told that their labors will produce much more than a purely economic integration.
An accord has been reached between the Metropolitan Opera Company and one of the two performers' unions with which it has been deadlocked.
Arthur Leff, a National Labor Relations Board trial examiner, yesterday adjourned until Sept. 6 a hearing on charges of unfair labor practices made by the board against the General Electric Company.

The United States Steel Corporation reported yesterday sharply reduced sales and earnings for the second quarter and first six months of 1961 as compared with the 1960 levels. Financial results for the last three months, however, showed a marked increase over the first-quarter figures.
MOSCOW, July 25 -- John J. McCloy, President Kennedy's disarmament adviser, left here unexpectedly today by air for the town of Sochi on the Black Sea for a meeting with Premier Khrushchev.

CHICAGO, July 25 -- A Chicago company said today that it had become the first United States concern to obtain 100 per cent ownership of a Japanese camera manufacturing facility. The company was Mansfield Industries, Inc., a producer and distributor of photographic equipment.

In light of the article by Milton Bracker, published on July 14, on the first group of 101 teachers who left for East Africa sponsored by the International Cooperation Administration and trained at Teachers College, we the remaining members of the group who are continuing with the orientation and graduate courses feel that misconceptions may easily arise from this news report.

BERNARDSVILLE, N.J., July 25 -- Mrs. J.B. Balding and her son, Robert M., of The Creek again won the annual Women's Metropolitan Golf Association mother-son championship by firing a 40, 37 -- 77 today at the Somerset Hills Country Club.
A THIRTY-TWO-FOOT sloop bobs at anchor these days at the mouth of the Mystic River in Connecticut. Its owner is kept ashore by another form of transportation -- railroads.
A $35,000,000 issue of 4% per cent sinking fund debentures of the Northern Natural Gas Company was offered to the public yesterday priced at 101 to yield 4.80 per cent.
WASHINGTON, July 25 (UPI) -- The Senate Labor Committee unanimously approved a four-year program today that would provide training and retraining for unemployed workers to help them find new jobs.
CHILDREN can watch theatre luminaries play softball in a Broadway League game on Friday at 2:30 P.M. in Central Park, near Seventy-third Street.
SAN LUIS POTOSI, Mexico, July 25 (UPI) -- Mexican Army troops and riot policemen fought street battles today with more than 1,000 political supporters of a defeated gubernatorial candidate.
The Triple Crown of Trotting Trophy, a sculptured sterling silver award, was displayed for the first time yesterday in a luncheon at The Four Seasons Restaurant.

In a speech at once solemn, determined and conciliatory, President Kennedy last night reasserted American leadership of the free world and outlined some of the measures and the sacrifices that are necessary to safeguard our survival and our heritage in the face of the Soviet challenge. We are confident that the American people and free men everywhere will support him.
WASHINGTON, July 25 -- President Kennedy asked tonight for an over-all increase in the nation's military preparedness to meet a Soviet threat he described as "world-wide."
Manhattan's Baronet Theatre is about to be crowned with a 600-seat, second-story auditorium called the Coronet.
The first full series of basic physics experiments with the most powerful particle accelerator in the world was completed yesterday at Brookhaven National Laboratory, Upton, L.I.
MIAMI, July 25 (AP) -- Capt. W.E. Buchanan told today how a man with a gun in his hand entered the cockpit of the airliner he piloted yesterday and told him "to turn the plane around."

PARIS, July 25 -- Jules-Francois Crahay had the perfect chance to set the world on fire today, but instead he decided to play it cool. This gifted designer for Nina Ricci became a big name with his hit collection in 1959.
BECAUSE it rained Monday night in Philadelphia, Wagner and Stravinsky got drawn into the Brahms festival that opened last night at the Lewisohn Stadium.

WASHINGTON, July 25 -- The Federal Communications Commission called today upon nine United States companies engaged in international communications to organize a joint venture that would own and operate a communications satellite system.
BONN, Germany, July 25 -- Chancellor Adenauer said today that he did not believe there would be a war over Berlin.

VANCOUVER, B.C., July 25 (AP) -- The American Newspaper Guild is playing a leading role in planning an amalgamation of seven major unions in the printing and publishing industry, the guilds executive vice president, William Farson of New York, said yesterday.

Arthur Levitt's first formal statement as the Democratic organization candidate for Mayor, issued in opening his campaign headquarters, attacks Mayor Wagner on the issue on which he is most vulnerable; the validity of his reformation into a "new" Wagner.
WASHINGTON, July 25 -- A group of anti-Castro Cuban leaders called on Congress today to recognize a Cuban exile government.

While President Kennedy and the Western powers wrestle with the Berlin problem, another crisis appears to be in the making in the Mediterranean and in Africa that could gravely affect Western defenses.
WASHINGTON, July 25 -- President Kennedy bid for African support of the West on the Berlin crisis in a more than hour-long talk today with the Nigerian Prime Minister, Sir Abubakar Tafawa Balewa.

FAIRVIEW, N.J., July 25 -- A new Italian embroidery machine using the schiffli process was put on display today for embroidery manufacturers, designers, Wall Street representatives, union people and others.

An appeal for action to put into effect additional major aspects of President Kennedy's program for the combined textile and apparel industries was sounded yesterday by Robert T. Stevens, president of J.P. Stevens Co., Inc., textile manufacturer.

TUNIS, July 25 -- President Habib Bourguiba called on brother nations and friendly powers today to send arms and guerrilla fighters to aid Tunisia against the French Army in the event of a new battle.
The Baltimore and Ohio Railroad announced yesterday that it had a net loss of $1,790,077 in June, contrasted to a net profit of $916,636 in the 1960 month.

One seismic tremor after another shook the Stadium last night as Yankee bats -- the heaviest in baseball -- smashed eight home runs against the White Sox. Four were belted by Roger Maris, highlighting the Bombers' sweep of a twilight night double-header. The scores were 5 -- 1 and 12 -- 0.
An Israeli rabbi and an American minister offered conflicting views yesterday of recent stonings of a Church of Christ mission church in Jerusalem.
Neighborhood Youth Projects, Inc., founded in 1958 to combat juvenile delinquency on the upper East Side, will be the beneficiary of the Oct. 31 preview performance of "The Complaisant Lover."
Mayor Wagner directed several city agencies yesterday to combat increasing youth crime in the Bedford-Stuyvesant area of Brooklyn.
LONDON, July 26 -- The British are slowly and uncomfortably awakening to the bitter realities of the developing crisis over Berlin.
Women from India, Pakistan and Burma, three hot and sticky lands, met for tea at Asia House yesterday. Their main topic of conversation was the heat and humidity here.

"The Mark," a British-made drama with Maria Schell, Stuart Whitman and Rod Steiger, will be the next attraction at the Sutton Theatre, after the current engagement of "Two Women." Guy Greene directed the Continental Distributing, Inc., release, which was filmed in Ireland.
Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange were unchanged to 7 points (35 cents a bale) up yesterday.

Philip Godfrey's undefeated Bolinas Boy made his first stakes appearance a winning one at Aqueduct yesterday. The home-bred son of Nantaliah opposed three others in the $21,650 Gravesend Handicap, and he came through with a solid success.

WASHINGTON, July 26 -- The nation's railroad system, despite the financial anemia that afflicts it in the East, has the plant and equipment to move troops and supplies as needed in a limited national emergency.

UNIONDALE, L.I., July 26 -- The first unit of a new Nassau County Home for the Aged and Infirm was dedicated today. Ultimately the $12,000,000 project will occupy sixty-five landscaped acres on Jerusalem Avenue here.

The Owens-Illinois Glass Company reported yesterday that its earnings in the first half of 1961 were below those of the corresponding period last year despite a gain in sales. The company is a leading producer of glass, paper and plastic packaging products.

VIENNA, July 26 -- Austria's Foreign Minister, Dr. Bruno Kreisky, described today as "slander" charges that he and four other leading Austrian politicians had helped to set up a separatist partisan organization in Italy's Alto Adige.
BALTIMORE, July 26 (AP) -- Four Baltimore pitchers limited the Boston Red Sox to eight hits tonight as the Orioles swept a double-header, 5 -- 1 and 9 -- 2.

The Pyramid Chain Stores Corporation, Benjamin Kinzel-berg, president, has leased the four-story building at 153 East Forty-second Street near the Chrysler Building. The lease, which is for twenty-one years, was arranged by the Charles Berger Company, broker.

Electric power production rose to a record 15,829,000,000 kilowatt-hours in the week ended July 22 from 15,071,000,000 a week before, the Edison Electric Institute reported yesterday. A year ago 14,830,000,000 kilowatt-hours were produced.
WARSAW, July 26 (AP) -- Communist authorities here are officially ignoring the first American exhibition of modern Polish painting, which opens next Tuesday at the Museum of Modern Art in New York.
CALCUTTA, India, Thursday, July 27 -- Considerable concern was expressed in India last night about President Kennedy's warning to the Soviet Union on Berlin.
BLOOMINGTON, Minn., July 26 (UPI) -- Ray Moore put down a ninth-inning Washington Senator rally tonight to preserve a 10-9 victory for the Minnesota Twins.
Taking their cue from the American Medical Association, some physicians in New York have organized for political action. They are expected to take part in the forthcoming city campaign.
LONDON, July 26 -- Britain quickened her military preparations today and warned the Soviet Union that unilateral action over Berlin would involve "the most serious dangers."

A DAPPER 37-year-old Frenchman, Guy Laroche has captured the imagination of Paris younger set. While "old hands" frown on his simple, almost Americanized designs, young Frenchwomen have continued to buy his easy, streamlined clothes.
The State Rent Commission indicated yesterday it would not move to lower rents in a West Side rooming house until the city proved the management had violated housing laws.

The Reynolds Metals Company had a net income of $11,271,000, or 56 cents a common share, in the first half of this year, the company reported yesterday. This compared with $13,218,000, or 66 cents a common share, in the first half of 1960.

The Republic Aviation Corporation reported a sharp rise in sales and earning in the first half of this year. Mundy L. Peale, president, said the favorable results followed the pattern set in the first quarter, and reflected the continued scheduled deliveries of the all-weather F-105D fighter-bomber to the Air Force.

THERE are more dried beans in Manhattan than anyone could logically shake a bean pole at. They come in more colors than the rainbow, including white, black, yellow, green and a striated combination of pink and yellow, which is the cranberry bean.

TAMPA, Fla., July 26 -- With a large Cuban population, including some Castro sympathizers, this Gulf coast city today alter its International Airport to the possibility of further attempts to hold up planes and fly them to Havana.

NEW HAVEN, July 26 -- A lawyer, an investment specialist and a retired railroad executive were appointed today to reorganize the bankrupt New Haven Railroad. Federal Judge Robert P. Anderson, in naming the trustees, warned that if they could not find a solution to the chronic financial plight of the New Haven, it "simply will have to go out of business."

LONDON, July 26 -- The General Council of the Trades Union Congress decided today to order the 240,000-member Electrical Trades Union to oust its president, a Communist, and to hold a new election for that office.
THESE are busy days and nights at Westbury, where the Roosevelt Raceway management is preparing to wind up its harness racing meet with a flourish.

WASHINGTON, July 26 (AP) -- President Kennedy's nomination of Lawrence J. O'Connor Jr. of Houston, Tex., to the Federal Power Commission ran into sharp opposition today from Senator William E. Proxmire, Democrat of Wisconsin.

WHITE PLAINS, July 26 -- Edwin G. Michaelian, the County Executive of Westchester, was accused today by a political foe of using a $30,500 brochure published at the expense of the taxpayers as a campaign device.
WASHINGTON, July 26 -- The White House has issued a new code of conduct for Federal employes that prohibits them from disclosing "official information."
WASHINGTON, July 26 -- From President Kennedy down, the White House was pleased today with the reaction to his address last night.
TOKYO, July 26 -- Japan's Communist party is holding a convention to proclaim the doctrine that two revolutions are better than one.
WASHINGTON, July 26 -- The Senate passed an omnibus farm bill tonight with a new program for cutting the nation's big wheat surplus. Passage was by voice vote.

MIAMI, July 26 (AP) -- Wilfredo Roman Oquendo, a Cuban-born waiter at resort hotels, whose wife thought he was a loyal American, was booked in absentia today as the man who held up an airliner and forced the pilot to land in Havana.
THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, July 26 -- Public opinion in the Netherlands and Belgium was generally favorable to the Kennedy speech.
Directors of the Brooklyn Union Gas Company voted yesterday a 10 per cent common stock dividend. It is payable on Oct. 9 to stockholders of record of Sept. 25.

BOSTON, July 26 -- A survey of New Englanders indicated widespread satisfaction with the President's speech on the Berlin situation. A general air of relief was evident that he had spoken firmly in a way that still left the road open to peace.

Salomon Brothers Hutzler and associates placed the winning bid yesterday for $4,845,000 of equipment trust certificates of the Southern Pacific Company. The bid was 98,307 for obligations carrying a 4 1/4 per cent interest coupon.
LOS ANGELES, July 27 (AP) -- Righthander Frank Lary of the Detroit Tigers got home run support from Rocky Colavito and Al Kaline tonight and defeated the Los Angeles Angels 5 -- 4.
Net new orders for metal cutting and forming machine tools received by the industry in this country in June aggregated $36,950,000, a drop of 1.9 per cent from the $37,650,000 recorded in May.

LIMA, Peru, July 22 -- A school-lunch program for 30,000 children in the highlands of Peru is so small a matter as to pass virtually unnoticed in the billion-dollar concept of President Kennedy's Alliance for Progress.

HAVERFORD, Pa., July 26 -- A 19-year-old stripling of 6 feet 4 inches commanded the attention of the Davis Cup selection committee today with a convincing victory over Chuck McKinley in the Pennsylvania lawn tennis tournament.
Their doubts (if any) resolved, the "reform" Democrats have endorsed Mayor Wagner for re-election.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., July 26 (UPI) -- The Justice Department filed suit in Federal court here today demanding that Negroes be allowed to use all facilities of Montgomery's municipal airport, including restaurants and drinking fountains.
ONE of the functions of literature is to produce forgotten masterpieces. One of the functions of criticism is to discover them -- again and again and again.

The institutions and services of the Salvation Army in the New York metropolitan area will undertake a $6,000,000 expansion as the first step in a development program described as the organization's largest in the United States.
Alexander's Department Stores, Inc. filed suit yesterday in Federal Court seeking to prevent E.J. Korvette, Inc., from gaining control of Alexander's.

RENSSELAER, Ind., July 26 (AP) -- The College All-Stars today displayed a blistering air attack, mainly behind the passing of Bill Kilmer of the University of California at Los Angeles, to tie the Chicago Bears, 14-14, in a full game football scrimmage.
The military build-up recommended to Congress yesterday by President Kennedy will not alter in the near future the vital statistics of the Berlin crisis.

ANCHORAGE, July 26 -- Alaska's first non-competitive, oil lease sale -- likened to a lottery by many critics -- broke the golden dreams of many speculators yesterday, but may have been the first step toward riches for others.
TOKYO, July 26 (UPI) -- Textile manufacturers' associations in Japan have issued a joint statement opposing the draft agreement adopted at the international textile conference in Geneva last week.
WASHINGTON, July 26 -- A Senate subcommittee prodded Maritime Administrator Thomas E. Staken today on his agency's implementation of the Vessel Exchange Act.

The Ampruf Paint Company and the A.C. Horn Company, divisions of the Sun Chemical Corporation, have leased a one-story, building being constructed to their specifications in the new Bergen County Industrial Park at Industrial Road and Gregg Street.
PHILADELPHIA, July 26 (AP) -- Norm Larker clouted his first grand-slam home run tonight as the Los Angeles Dodgers gained a 6 -- 1 victory over the Phillies.
PHILADELPHIA, July 26 -- The State Supreme Court today outlawed Pennsylvania's new movie censorship code in a 4-3 decision.

HONG KONG, July 26 -J. Cowperthwaite, Financial Secretary of this British Crown Colony, said tonight that he had made reservations on behalf of Hong Kong on certain important provisions of the draft agreement reached at the Gatt-sponsored meeting of textile exporting and importing countries at Geneva.
A gunman held up teller in a downtown savings and loan association yesterday and escaped with $4,350.

WASHINGTON, July 26 -- The Administration sought today to reassure Congress that its control over spending would not be jeopardized by passage of President Kennedy's foreign aid program of Treasury-financed long-term development loans.
WASHINGTON, July 26 -- The Administration is raising its estimate of the pace of economic recovery and tightening its planning for next year's budget.
Mediation efforts failed last night to end the six-day-old strike of stablehands at Aqueduct.
ORANGE, N.J., July 26 -- The young wife of a radio announcer was routed from her bed at 3 A.M. today and taken to police headquarters on a warrant charging her with failure to pay a $1 parking fine.
CHICAGO, July 26 (AP) -- General and fairly heavy selling in late dealings sent the grain futures market sharply downward today on nearly all contracts on the Board of Trade.

LONDON, July 26 (AP) -- Britain granted temporary asylum tonight to a Chinese Nationalist who flew here from the United States. He charged that the Federal Bureau of Investigation was trying to send him back to Taiwan to face execution.
WASHINGTON, July 26 (AP) -- Senator Frank J. Lausche, Democrat of Ohio, said today that United States military leaders had been muzzled by repeated attacks on their public statements.

SEOUL, Korea, July 26 (AP) -- The South Korean Military Government ordered tonight the retirement of 1,201 officers. The Defense Ministry said officers ranging from lieutenants to colonels would go into the reserve Sunday.

PARIS, July 26 -- Today all was quiet on the Paris front. On the third day of the collections, the interest in fit, flare, oblique seams, side fastenings, back wrappings and a few lifted waistlines increased, but no new fashion ideas developed.

What is really "outrageous" about the defeat of the school-aid bill that Catholic educators and legislators have been branded by successive editorials in The Times as the betes noires of this unfortunate climax. This reflects the consistent inability of The Times to see the discriminatory character of aid of public schools alone.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 26 -- The all-star baseball players who moaned about the tricky winds at San Francisco's Candlestick Park, did not begin to face the complications that a movie company has encountered since it decided to film a baseball game at the home the Giants built.

The bond market lost further ground yesterday as the financial district appraised the implications of President Kennedy's appeal for strengthening the nation for a showdown with Russia on Berlin's future status.
WASHINGTON, July 26 -- The United States will begin negotiations tomorrow to improve its four-year-old cultural exchange program with the Soviet Union.
Arthur Levitt, the Democratic organization candidate for Mayor, blamed Mayor Wagner yesterday for the city's school problems.

BIZERTE, Tunisia, July 25 -- French paratroops were pulled back today from an advance post near here. President Habib Bourguiba of Tunisia had charged that the French occupation of the post was a violation of the United Nations resolution calling for a cease-fire.

ROME, July 26 -- One seldom hears the Berlin situation mentioned in the streets or in other public places here. Nobody seems to be worried or even to feel that the situation has taken on new urgency of late.
Power disruptions caused delays on several subway trains yesterday and held up rush-hour service on two lines for about twenty minutes.

LONDON, July 26 (Reuters) -- Two Russians convicted of "systematic profiteering" in currency deals have been shot aftr earlier having been sentenced to fifteen years' imprisonment, the Moscow radio reported tonight.
YARMOUTH, N.S., July 26 -- More than 5,000 visitors from the United States and Canada are here this week for the celebration of the 200th anniversary of the founding of Yarmouth.

Webb Knapp (Canada) Ltd., and the British interests that have joined it as co-owners of the Place Ville Marie development in Montreal announced plans yesterday for a second major real estate investment partnership.
Improved waterfront safety will save the Port of New York's stevedoring industry about $5,000,000 a year, the Labor Department reported yesterday.
WASHINGTON, July 26 -- The Kennedy Administration asked Congress today for $10,000,000 to put into operation a home buzzer system that would give warning of impending nuclear attack.

Too bad Emily Mehr and her associates in the "Association for the Protection of Our Water Supply" (her letter in your issue of July 20) are not interested and informed about the protection of our teeth.

HARRISBURG, Pa., July 26 -- Anne X. Alpern of Pittsburgh, the first woman to be appointed to the Pennsylvania Supreme Court, is small in stature but packs a legal wallop that has won her the respect of lawyers.
Mayor Wagner ordered penalties yesterday against seven employment agencies accused of "petty chiseling" against domestic workers they had brought to the city.

STAMFORD, Conn., July 26 -- A series of entertainments to raise funds for the proposed Ezio Pinza Theatre, named for the late operatic star who was a resident of Stamford, will open Saturday with a ball, "An Enchanted Evening," at Columbus Auditorium.
Record first-half sales and earnings were announced yesterday by Avon Products, Inc., toiletries and cosmetics concern.
SALT LAKE CITY, Utah, July 26 -- President Kennedy's speech amused a feeling of urgency over Berlin among some people in Utah but there is no pervasive feeling of crisis.

Grooms never ride horses, win silver trophies or get their names in the paper. Grooms clip, rub, brush, water, lead, curry and feed horses. They are ubiquitous in the backstretch and totally absent during a race. Grooms are indispensable.

The United States chess team completed its adjourned seventh-round match with Finland in the international students' tournament at Helsinki when Charles Kalme, University of Pennsylvania, drew his game with Alltio yesterday, according to a report from Finland.

Thirty-four years ago today, a Yankee home run derby was in progress that was every bit as hot as that between Roger Maris and Mickey Mantle. That year Babe Ruth established his record of sixty homers for a 154-game season.

James Marshall of the American Jewish Committee in a letter published July 21 accuses Arab League states of alleged discriminatory practices against American Jewish personnel in the Middle East. These accusations convey a distorted view of the attitudes of Arab League states toward religious minorities.
CHICAGO, July 26 -- Three thousand two hundred inside dairy workers at ninety Chicago area milk plants struck today in a wage dispute after contract negotiations collapsed.
A SOMEWHAT novel trinity of introspection was presented last night over radio station WBAI. Barry Gray, David Susskind and Mike Wallace were put in the same room and had to talk to one another.
More than 250 union leaders last night promised Mayor Wagner and his running mates large-scale support in the Democratic primary.
Chile's new plan to force an increase in copper production was criticized yesterday by Charles M. Brinciierhoff, president of the Anaconda Company, as tending to achieve just the opposite.
The truncated frames of big new office and apartment buildings are being turned into ghost structures by the twenty-six-day-old strike of 1,200 concrete mix drivers.
PHILADELPHIA, July 26 -- Despite mixed reactions, there was general agreement in this area today that the President's address had increased awareness of the threat of war in the Berlin crisis.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 26 -- Robert K.A. Gardiner of Ghana has been appointed director of the United Nations division for public administration, it was announced today. He will be the highest ranking African on the United Nations Headquarters staff.
WASHINGTON, July 26 (UPI) -- Supreme Court Justice Hugo L. Black denied today a writ of habeas corpus for the release of a New York Freedom Rider from the Mississippi State Prison.

PITTSBURGH, July 26 (AP) -- Bob Friend's two-out bases-filled single in the sixth inning tonight broke a 3-3 tie and the Pittsburgh Pirates went on to defeat the San Francisco Giants, 8 -- 3. The Pirates ended a five-game losing streak.

CHICAGO, July 26 -- The Inland Steel Company announced today that net income for the second quarter of this year was $13,605,988, or 77 cents a share, compared with $14,323,569, or 82 cents a share in the second quarter of 1960.

WASHINGTON, July 26 -- President Kennedy's immediate Civil Defense goal is to provide fall-out shelters in existing buildings for one-fourth of the nation's population, which is in major target areas.

HIGH school graduates seeking their first jobs a more interested in opportunity for advancement than in creature comforts, according to personnel officers who help the take their first step on the employment ladder.
DETROIT, July 27 -- Ward's Automotive Reports said today that mid-July sales of new cars were the highest in six years.

Judged from the economic point of view alone, President Kennedy Vas able to ask Congress for approximately $3,500,000,000 is additional defers appropriations without at the same time demanding compensatory tax increases only because the country has not yet fully recovered from the recession and still has an appreciable amount of unused human and material resources.

Prices of stocks rose yesterday as investors looked forward to more defense spending with tax increases deferred until next year. More than one broker described the President's Tuesday night address to the nation as inflationary.
LONDON, July 26 -- Dealers marked down shares heavily when the stock market opened here today in response to the economic measures announced yesterday by the Chancellor of the Exchequer.

WASHINGTON, July 26 -- The speed with which President Kennedy, projected his verbal promises last night of a military build-up into a detailed legislative program for Congress today, and the speed with which Congress is operating its machinery to produce this program, could furnish a more effective deterrent to nuclear war than any since Soviet Russia broke the West's monopoly of atomic weaponry.

WASHINGTON, July 26 -- Prime Minister Sir Abubakar Tafawa Balewa of Nigeria called today for stxengthening the power of the United Nations "to make it impossible for any nation to ignore its authority."
Details of a $75,000,000 development atop Pennsylvania Station, including a new Madison Square Garden center, were announced yesterday. The project had first become public Tuesday.
President Kennedy's proposed mobilization program would affect youths registered with Selective Service, those in the Reserve and in the National Guard.
Mary Martin's next show will be a musical adaptation of "Blood and Thunder," a forthcoming book by Dwight Taylor. This was disclosed yesterday by Richard Halliday, Miss Martin's husband.
LONDON, July, 26 -- Sean O'Casey's "The Bishop's Bonfire'' had its London premiere tonight at the Mermaid Theatre.

With the annual cost of freight transportation exceeding $41,000,000,000 a year, transportation officials as well as their customers continue to seek improved methods of packaging and handling the nation's cargo.
The Board of Superintendents of the city school system has recommended the elimination of all after-school and vacation programs in the schools for which children are charged a fee.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., July 26 -- Ed Cooke, a 6-foot 4-inch 250-pounder, could save the New York Titans a large aspirin bill this season. The 25-year-old player from Maryland could be the man to fill what the defensive coach, John Dell Isola, calls "the most difficult position in football," the strong-side linebacker.

BOSTON, July 26 (UPI) -- The Massachusetts Boxing Commission today granted a license to Championship Sports, Inc., to promote a Floyd Patterson-Tom McNeeley heavyweight title fight at Boston, probably on Oct. 23.

Alaska borrowed in the public market as a state government for the first time yesterday. A total of $13,975,000 was raised on three bond issues, with most of the money earmarked for a ferry system to! serve as a "marine highway" in southeastern n south-central Alaska.
WASHINIGTON, July 26 (AP) -- The Civil Aeronautics Board today started action to fill in some of the major competitive gaps that may have resulted from the merger of United and Capital Airlines.

GENEVA, July 26 (UPI) -- The General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT) published today the agreement for a temporary standstill on cotton textile exports to unrestricted markets. The agreement was negotiated here last week.

The Olin Mathieson Chemical Corporation achieved, in the three months ended June 30, record sales for any quarter and earnings 81.5 per cent higher than in the preceding quarter, the report disclosed yesterday.

LONDON, July 26 -- A sudden strike of teachers at a secondary school twenty-five miles outside London today was the first direct answer to the plea by Chancellor of the Exchequer Selwyn Lloyd for wage restraint.
MOSCOW, July 26 -- The Soviet Union accused President Kennedy tonight of exploiting the Berlin dispute as a pretext for accelerating the East-West arms race.

The Pennsylvania Railroad announced yesterday that it cleared $515,500 last month, whereas there was a deficit of $409,100 in the same month last year.
GENEVA, July 26 -- Communist China assailed the Southeast Asia Treaty Organization today and demanded that it renounce its offer to defend the sovereignty and political independence of Laos.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., July 26 -- In general, residents of this area approved of President Kennedy's speech and seemed ready to back him up. They felt it was a good thing for him to explain the problem so clearly to the people so that they could make plans for their future.

Along Wall Street, the nation's financial center, the reaction yesterday to President Kennedy's speech was immediate and strong. Its emphasis on a long-term increase in military preparedness and greater Federal spending -- without an immediate rise in taxes -- tended to drive away any bearish sentiments about stocks and to rally the bulls, or optimists.
MOSCOW, July 26 -- In conversations heard on the streets of the Soviet capital, Berlin has not taken the focus of attention away from talk of summer vacations, sports and the cost of living.

The second annual Forecast of Fashion, to be held in the Grand Ballroom of the Plaza on Sept. 27, will be a benefit for Carnegie Hall. Proceeds from last year's event went to the Museum of Modern Art's building fund.
ROME, July 26 -- Communism has already lost the first decisive round in its struggle for world domination, Adlai E. Stevenson told an audience of leading Italians today.

ELIZABETH, N.J., July 26 -- Curfew may soon ring here to stop the clanging of ice-cream street venders' bells after 8 P.M. Parents complain that some ice cream men, in their friendly way, have been ting-a-ling-a-linging right up to midnight, awakening small children.

PARIS, July 26 -- France welcomed with "great satisfaction" President Kennedy's speech yesterday announcing the United States' intention to prepare for war while hoping for a reasonable negotiated solution of the Berlin dispute with the Soviet Union.
WASHINGTON, July 26 (UPI) -- House Investigators blamed an "entrenched" Government official today for major failures of the American foreign aid program in Peru.
A television play that has since been adapted for the Broadway stage, where it is expected to open next fall, will be repeated on Sept. 5 by the Columbia Broadcasting System.

Increased sales from expanding international operations and rising capital expenditures were major topics at the General Foods Corporation's annual meeting yesterday. In addition, two executive were promoted and two prominent industrialists were elected directors.

HAVANA, July 26 -- Premier Fidel Castro said tonight that Cuba would not return the Eastern Air Lines plane that was stolen Monday during a Miami-Tampa flight and flown to Cuba Havana, until the United States returned "the ten Cuban planes which it has stolen."

The Scovill Manufacturing Company, maker of metal products, has leased most of the tenth floor in the new twenty-four-story office building at 733 Third Avenue, southeast corner of Forty-sixth Street. The Durst Organization is the owner.

ROME, July 26 -- President Kennedy's speech was prominently displayed in nearly all Italian newspapers. Except for the Communists and pro-Communists, the reaction was favorable.

Not only the men between the ages of 18 1/2 and 26 who are subject to the draft, but also their parents, wives and sweethearts by the hundreds telephoned headquarters of the Selective Service System for New York at 205 East Forty-second Street seeking information.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 26 -- The President's speech in general won approval here. Its tone was judged to be about right generally.

GLEN COVE, L.I., July 26 -- Ralph W. Johnston of Garden City Country Club, a 19-year-old Texas A. and M. junior, and Charles J. Slicklen Jr. of North Hempstead, a 27-year-old paper salesman, today shared the medal in the Long Island sectional qualifying competition for the metropolitan amateur golf championship.

The American Tobacco Company achieved the highest sales and earnings for a first half year in the concern's history in the six months ended last June 30, Paul M. Hahn, president, reported yesterday. Second-quarter sales were the highest for any quarter in the company's history, he added.

A decline of 1,386,000 barrels in the nation's gasoline stocks last week was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. The decline was less than usual for this time of year and reflected in part an increase in gasoline production in the week ended Friday to 30,812,000 barrels from 29,558,000 the preceding week.

WASHINGTON, July 26 (AP) -- N.E. Halaby, Administrator of the Federal Aviation Agency, said today it would adhere to plans for use of Mitchel Field on Long Island -- "until a superior alternative is offered by state or local leadership."

OLD GREENWICH, Conn., July 26 -- Light airs, which canceled yesterday's opening session in Eastern Junior Race Week, were in evidence again today at the event conducted by the Junior Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound.

The American Stock Exchange announced yesterday that officers, directors and large stockholders in listed companies reported last month, pursuant to the Securities Exchange Act, the following changes in their stockholdings. The New York Stock Exchange did not report any insiders' changes yesterday.

The Phillips Petroleum Company reported yesterday that net income for the first half of this year was $54,902,000, or $1.60 a share on 34,368,515 shares outstanding. Gross income was $607,290,000.

Spaniel field trials for years had been a masculine pursuit. So the Ladies Amateur Spaniel Handlers Association, more familiarly known as Lasha, was organized.

OTTAWA, July 26 (AP) -- Icebergs traveling through Davis Strait have several times cut the undersea cable carrying radar information from Thule, Greenland, to the North American Air Defense Command in Colorado, authoritative sources here have disclosed.
A policeman chasing a teenager who had jumped a stolen car shot and killed a 38-year-old bystander in Brooklyn last night with a stray bullet.

WASHINGTON, July 26 -- President Kennedy won bipartisan assurances of full Congressional support today for his determination to stiffen United States military strength on hold firm against Soviet pressure on Berlin.

KANSAS CITY, July 26 (AP) -- The Cleveland Indians, led by Woody Held and Jim Piersall, pounded five Kansas City Athletics' pitchers fox seventeen hits and a 12-5 victory tonight. Held got four hits, including a home run. Piersall had a triple and three singles.

MINNEAPOLIS. July 26 -- A poll conducted by The Minneapolis Tribune and published last Sunday found 90 per cent of Minnesotans support President Kennedy's insistence that United States troops remain in West Berlin. Two per cent were opposed and 8 per cent undecided.

Food Fair Stores, Inc., the nation's sixth largest supermarket chain, attained new records in all phases of its business in its fiscal year ended on April 29.
PARIS, July 26 -- France snubbed Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold of the United Nations tonight. She accused Mr. Hammarskjold of favoring the Tunisian cause in the Bizerte dispute.

OLD CHATHAM, N.Y., July 26 -- New Yorkers with summer homes here are working on plans for the sixth annual Shaker Museum Festival, scheduled for Aug. 5 and 6 on the museum grounds.

MOSCOW, July 27 -- John J. McCloy returned here today from private talks with Premier Khrushchev and gave a cautious hint of progress on disarmament. "Maybe we are further along," Mr. McCloy said. "We have to do more talking before we have anything definite."

The Maritime Administration's ship mortgage insurance program increased $27,000,000 during the first half of 1961, raising the agency's total commitments to about $468,000,000, the administrator reported yesterday.

Loans to business at the fifteen reporting member banks in New York City rose $9,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. That compared with a decline of $43,000,000 in the 1960 week.
The Whitewood Stud's Gawain won the featured Mount Kisco Purse at Aqueduct yesterday in a thrilling finish.
The Southern California Edison Company announced yesterday that earnings for the quarter and the twelve months ended on June 30 rose from the year-earlier levels.

LONDON, July 27 -- John Osborne's "Luther," which had its premiere at the Royal Court Theatre tonight, after a preliminary performance in Paris, was acclaimed by the audience and critics tonight as a major work.

After several active days in which trading was stimulated by international happenings, midsummer sluggishness returned to New York's commodity exchanges yesterday. Price changes generally were mixed and volume was light.

The Times of July 23 reports that the membership of the American Astronomical Society is being circulated, at the instigation of Senator Paul Douglas, to ascertain if it considers worth while the proposed expedition to the moon. This is a step in the right direction.

Production of lumber climbed to 218,810,000 board feet in the week ended last Saturday from 181,855,000 board feet the week before, according to reports received from regional associations. A year ago 228,043,000 board feet were produced.

IN days of yore, the souring of cream was achieved by letting time have its inexorable effect. Nowadays, however, the commercial product is achieved by adding a culture under controlled conditions. Daily average borrowings by member banks of the Federal Reserve System declined $5,000,000 to $50,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. Daily average reserves in excess of requirements declined $85,000,000 to $608,000,000.

The removal of rusty deposits in teakettles can be a problem to the homemakers who encounter it.
