State Controller Arthur Levitt called on Mayor Wagner yesterday to stop the "arbitrary firing" of city officials and employes who oppose the Mayor politically.

WASHINGTON, July 28 -- President Kennedy designated Attorney General Robert F. Kennedy today to be his personal representative at the first anniversary celebrations of the Ivory Coast's independence Aug. 6 and 7.

Three high officers retiring from the United States Army Transportation Terminal Command, Atlantic, were honored yesterday in ceremonies in Brooklyn that also marked the nineteenth anniversary of the United States Transportation Corps.
DUBLIN, July 28 -- The Irish International Airlines closed its twenty-fifth year March 31 with the best traffic and financial results in its history.

BUENOS AIRES, July 28 -- The publicly expressed concern of Senator Prescott Bush of Connecticut, and other Americans, with the type of plays being presented in Latin America by the New York Repertory Theatre here proved to be much ado about nothing.

WASHINGTON, July 28 -- The Senate approved overwhelmingly today President Kennedy's request for more weapons and troops to cope with Soviet pressure in Berlin and other trouble spots. The House is expected to act Monday.
BOSTON, July 28 (AP) -- A Boston rookie, Don Schwall, checked Chicago on eight hits, four of them scratch blows, for an 8 -- 3 victory tonight. It was his eleventh triumph against two defeats.
DETROIT, July 28 (UPI) -- Car production in the nation dropped to 75,911 units this week as fifteen more assembly plants closed for changeover to 1962 models, ward's Automotive Reports said today.
A Federal grand jury indicted two claims investigators for the Social Security Administration yesterday on charges of falsifying documents and reports in support of false social security claims.
NEWPORT NEWS, Va., July 28 (AP) -- The Newport News shipyard today launched its first dry-cargo freighter in seven years.
TEHERAN, Iran, July 27 -- A spokesman for the new Iranian Government headed by Dr. Ali Amini laid out a timetable today for land reform and an anti-corruption drive.

MYSTIC, Conn., July 28 -- George B. Gibbons Jr.'s forty-foot sloop Mariann and Franklin J. Dickman's thirty-one-foot sloop Puritan won the major trophies today as the thirtieth annual American Yacht Club cruise ended.

A light week is ahead in the market for new capital issues. Debt issues aggregating $117,117,400 are expected to reach the market, but more than half of this volume will consist of a single issue. It is a $60,315,000 bond issue of the Public Housing Administration, which is to be offered at competitive sealed bidding on Wednesday.

BERLIN, July 28 -- Mayor Willy Brandt of West Berlin proposed anew today that the Western powers consider calling a peace conference of all fifty-two countries that fought against Germany in World War II.
CHICAGO, July 28 (AP) -- The three-day Chicago milk strike ended tonight when the second of two striking unions reached agreement with the city's sixty dairies in a marathon bargaining session.
Man o'War consistently knew where he would wind up when he was racing. In the twenty-one races that Big Red engaged in through the seasons of 1919 and 1920, he was first twenty times.
LONDON, July 28 -- A constitutional conference leading to greater internal self-government and eventual independence for the British protectorate of Uganda will open here Sept. 18.

In your recent editorial "Flare-Up in Venezuela" you outline the serious problems facing the present Government and mention "the always dangerous animosity of the small, wealthy, reactionary industrial and banking community which thrived on the worst kind of dictatorship, but which resents a truly democratic government like President Betancourt's."

WASHINGTON, July 28 (AP) -- The Treasury Department made public today its compromise proposal for legislation taxing the income of United States stockholders in corporations operating in foreign "tax havens."
BERLIN, July 28 -- The bankrupt Borgward Automobile Company of Bremen will cease operations forthwith and "soon" go into liquidation proceedings, tire Bremen State Government announced today.
PARIS, July 28 -- France's position in North Africa continued to deteriorate tonight.
WASHINGTON, July 28 -- A new tiny detector makes it possible for a pilot to take the temperature of the air some distance ahead of his plane.

What may be the richest one-day program in thoroughbred racing's history is on tap today. Four major stakes events will find 2-year-old colts and fillies, grass-course specialists and older fillies and marcs running for some $565,000.
DAYTON, Ohio, July 28 (UPI) -- The Master Electric Company announced yesterday it was closing its Dayton operations after forty-one years, ending the jobs of 1,450 persons.
PARIS, July 28 (AP) -- Experts from the Big Three Western Powers and West Germany met today to begin mapping a joint diplomatic strategy on Berlin and Germany.

Directors of Eastern Airlines, Inc. failed again yesterday to take action on a common stock dividend for the third quarter. The airline omitted the second-quarter dividend, but paid 25 cents a share in the first quarter of this year.

WASHINGTON, July 28 (AP) -- The Federal Communications Commission announced today a broad program of television channel shifts in various parts of the country. The move is designed primarily to encourage the use of ultra high frequency channels, numbered 14 through 83.

The Glickman Corporation, a national realty investment company, announced yesterday that it had contracted to buy the St. Regis Hotel at the southeast corner of Fifth Avenue and Fifty-fifth Street. Louis J. Glickman, president of the corporation, said the deal involved cash and mortgages amounting to more than $22,000,000.

WASHINGTON, July 28 -- Average wholesale prices primary markets edged up 0.1 per cent during the week ended last Tuesday to 118.6 per cent of their 1947-49 base, the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today.

Ferdinand Roth, Commissioner of the Department of Real Estate, announced yesterday a plan to canvass industry to obtain applicants for positions of real estate managers in the department. He said he also would try to interest recent college graduates.

Eminent figures, long since fully established in the literary pantheon -- Dickens, Tennyson, Trollope, Byron and others -- seldom if ever are seen as the authors of best sellers are seen today. Not all of them enjoyed (or suffered) the cocktail party technique, the autographing bee, the jacket blurb of today and the endless devices to secure publicity in one form or another.
" I ADORE YOU," a tiny woman with the figure of a boy, the face of a gypsy and the voice of a parakeet told the late Christian Dior! "But you dress women like armchairs."

BERLIN, July 28 (Reuters) -- Neues Deutschland, East Germany's main Communist newspaper, said today that there was "at present no legal basis" for the Western powers' use of land, air or water connections to West Berlin.
WEST DANVILLE, Vt., July 28 (UPI) -- Two Roman Catholic nuns drowned late today when an overloaded outboard motorboat sank in a pond here. Four other persons, including two other nuns, were rescued.
LONDON, July 28 -- A Treasury official told the House of Commons today that the Government hoped to announce later this year whether Britain would adopt a decimal coinage system.
WASHINGTON, July 28 (AP) -- Farm product prices advanced 1 per cent between mid-June and mid-July.

MINNEAPOLIS, July 28 (AP) -- Judy Kimball of Sioux City went over par on five of the last six holes today and lost a chance to be the sole leader at the halfway mark of the $7,500 American women's open golf tournament.

WARSAW, July 28 -- America's best miler, Dyrol Burleson of Oregon, declared himself out of the track and field meet between the United States and Poland that begins here tomorrow. He has a slight muscle pull in the back of a thigh.
CHICAGO, July 28 (AP) -- The Bell Howell Company called today for redemption on Sept. 1 of all its cumulative preferred stock.

At least the French delegation did not walk out of the Security Council meeting yesterday. But it did ostentatiously refrain from joining in the discussion while (Tunisia charged that the French troops in and around Bizerte had disregarded the Council's order to stop shooting, and had not only refused to pull back their lines but had in some places extended them and in the course of the fighting had committed shocking atrocities.
WASHINGTON, July 28 (UPI) -- A Hollywood producer appealed to Congress today to smash the power of the television networks.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 28 -- Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold said today that he had observed French military forces policing Bizerte in violation of Tunisian sovereignty.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 28--A United Nations inquiry panel said today that the United Nations must intervene in South-West Africa to prevent armed conflict.
Dr. Ray E. Trussell, Commissioner of Hospitals, yesterday described the Board of Estimate's approval of a new Gouverneur Hospital on Thursday as "a routine processing" of hospital plans.
MILLINGTON, N.J., July 28 -- A mountain lion may be wandering about Morris County. Policemen, armed with riot guns, and auxiliary police and private citizens are hunting the animal.
MOSCOW, July 28 (AP) -- The discovery of a group of white dwarf stars, never before spotted in such a large cluster, was reported today by the Soviet press agency Tass.
The wholesale commodity price index rose to 84.7 on Thursday from 84.6 on Wednesday. The daily index, compiled by the Bureau of Labor Statistics, stood at 85.8 in July 21, 1960.

The alumnae of the Katharine Gibbs School here are sponsoring a reception and tea on Nov. 2 in the Embassy Ballroom of the new Summit Hotel to celebrate the fiftieth anniversary of the founding of the first of the secretarial schools. Proceeds will go to the New York school's scholarship fund.

PARIS, July 28 -- The press beamed with joy this afternoon like children on Christmas morning who got what they wanted. "Coco" Chanel was responsible. She showed beautiful, newsworthy fashions that also were eminently wearable. That is a lot to expect, but Chanel delivered it.
GENEVA, July 28 -- The fourteen-nation Conference on Laos called a temporary halt today in its heated debate over the Southeast Asia Treaty Organization.

WASHINGTON, July 28 (UPI) -- Newton N. Minow, chairman of the Federal Communications Commission angrily denied today a Congressman's charge of conflict-of-interest in a Moline, Ill., decision on the awarding of a television channel:

Of the many ironies implicit in that increasingly gargantuan sequence involving the "celebration" of the Civil War Centennial, it strikes this observer that the recently completed frolic designated as the "Re-enactment of the First Battle of Bull Run" perhaps underlines most clearly the misplaced sense of enthusiasm that has too often pervaded these occasions.

LONDON, July 28 -- Prices of British Government securities and blue chips rallied after a dull start in the stock market here today. Although net changes were slightly lower, the tone was described as good.

One workman was killed and two others were injured yesterday as tons of bricks collapsed at a construction project on Broadway across from City Hall Park. The bricks, part of an old foundation wall in an excavation for a twenty-nine-story office building, fell with a rumbling roar at 11 A.M.

Telephones, Inc., an independent telephone company with offices in Chicago, has filed a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission covering a proposed public offering of 250,000 common shares.
WASHINGTON, July 28 -- The Senate quickly passed today six of eight bills recommended by Attorney General Robert F. Kennedy to combat organized crime and racketeering.

PRINCETON, N.J., July 28 -- Two Princeton University paleontologists were preparing today to preserve what is believed to be the most complete skeleton of a Mosasaurus maximus, or sea serpent, ever unearthed.
The Walt Whitman School, a nonprofit, private elementary and high school at 342 East Sixty-third Street, sought help from financial difficulties yesterday in Federal Court under the Bankruptcy Act.
KANSAS CITY, July 28 (AP) -- The Washington Senators defeated the Kansas City Athletics, 10 -- 6, tonight in a contest marked by twenty-four hits.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., July 28 -- The Connecticut State Women's Golf Association defeated the Women's Westchester-Fairfield Golf Association, 27 1/2 to 17 1/2, today in their annual match at the Brooklawn Country Club.

WASHINGTON, July 28 (AP) -- A spokesman for the American Nurses Association said today that doctors had exerted "pressure" on nurses to withdraw their support for Social Security health care provisions for the aged.

The stock market rally that began last Tuesday on the eve of President Kennedy's address to the nation ran out of steam yesterday. Even so, after backing and filling, prices closed with a moderate gain on the New York Stock Exchange.

A study of Southern legend is presented in "Cavalier and Yankee: The Old South and American National Character," which Braziller will publish on Sept. 25. The author, William R. Taylor Harvard historian, discusses the significance that Southerners and Northerners before the Civil War attached to the legend in their search for a distinctive national character.
WASHINGTON, July 28 -- A high-ranking delegation from secessionist Katanga Province in the Congo denied today that Katanga was negotiating for Soviet aid.

Only the Baltimore Orioles managed to knock baseballs into the stands at the Stadium last night -- borrowing without permission from the Yankee handbook and beating the American League leaders, 4 -- 0.
HAVANA, July 28 -- There is no prospect that any new work by Ernest Hemingway will be published in the near future, according to his widow.
WASHINTGTON, July 28 (AP) -- The Navy said today that it was ahead of schedule in building the Polaris ballistic-missile ubmarines.

Evidence that at least 100 Board of Education employes collected monthly pay-offs from contractors for expediting payments on school construction projects has been uncovered by the city Department of Investigation.

Amid all the bad news there is one item of bright sunshine for Mayor Wagner. Representative Adam Clayton Powell Jr. of Harlem has turned against him and is now planning to campaign vigorously for Arthur Levitt for Mayor. Only three months ago he favored Wagner's renomination by the Democratic party, saying, "I get along with him all right."

The Central and South West Corporation and its subsidiaries reported yesterday that electric operating revenues and net income for the twelve, six and three months ended on June 30 rose from the year-earlier levels.

MOSCOW, July 28 (UPI) -- Premier Khrushchev's ambitious new Communist party program will be published Sunday. It will be the first document of its kind since Lenin produced the foundation for a Communist society in 1919.
Mayor Wagner yesterday accused Frank Kenna, the Republican leader of Queens, of "sordid use of political office for private profit."
HYANNIS PORT, Mass., July 28 -- President Kennedy joined his wife here late today in time to help celebrate her thirty-second birthday.
WASHINGTON, July 28 (AP) -- A bill proposing a huge program to develop marine sciences and exploit the resources of the oceans and the Great Lakes won Senate approval today by a vote of 50 to 32.
PARAMUS, N.J., July 28 -- Mrs. M.H. Higgins and Chet Sanok of Upper Montclair, N.J., won low gross honors with a 33, 33 -- 66 today in a Women's New Jersey Golf Association mixed-foursome tournament.

THE national bridge news today is that the biggest bridge tournament held annually in this hemisphere, the summer championships of the American Contract Bridge League, is beginning at Washington, D.C.
BERLIN, July 28 -- People caught up in massive events are likely to turn from contemplation of the big scene to fix on small, easily comprehensible details. So it is with Berliners.
LOS ANGELES, July 28 (AP) -- The Los Angeles Angels rallied tonight with a four-run splurge in the sixth inning, driving Barry Latman to the showers and going on to defeat the Cleveland Indians, 8-5.
President Kennedy has given American private enterprise a major challenge and a major opportunity through his decision that communications satellites will be operated commercially.

By remaining at the table in the United Nations Security Council yesterday but not taking part in the discussion, France made a diplomatic protest and avoided a diplomatic penalty -- the loss of her veto.
HARRISON, N.Y., July 28 -- The International Business Machines Corporation, has purchased thirty-nine acres here for new administrative offices of one of its divisions.
Gamal Abdel Nasser will appear on the Columbia Broadcasting System's "At the Source" telecast Thursday, Aug. 24, at 10 P.M.

HAVERFORD, Pa., July 28 -- Frank Froehling of Coral Gables, Fla., was overpowering once again today with his mighty service and gained the final round of the Pennsylvania lawn tennis championship at Merion Cricket Club.
SUMMIT, N.J., July 28 -- Mrs. William Tracy of Essex Fells swept the Garden State Women's Golf Association championships this season by winning the medal-play title today at Canoe Brook.

CHICAGO, July 28 (AP) -- In a heated session during which packed galleries chorused jeers, the City Council voted 40 to 3 today to close self-service laundries and dry cleaning shops from 11:30 P.M. to 6:30 A.M. daily.

What was the busiest stock on the New York Stock Exchange in the first six months of 1961? Not a new electronics issue, by any means, but a solid, well-known space and electronics company called the Sperry Rand Corporation.

HOUSTON, Tex., July 28 (AP) -- Senator Barry Goldwater said today that United States military leaders were "so busy defending themselves against trumped-up allegations" that they might not have time to do their jobs.

JERUSALEM, July 28 -- Six years ago, prior to the brief Suez war, Israeli foreign policy sought to get United States agreement for a mutual security pact. This effort failed. Three years ago, when President Eisenhower sent Secretary Anderson on a secret mission trying to find a formula for Middle Eastern peace, Israeli foreign policy hoped American influence could in that way safeguard this country.
CHICAGO, July 28 (AP) -- Wheat futures maintained most of a fairly solid rally today on the Board of Trade and closed with gains of about a cent. Otherwise the market generally eased.
The word is still "stalemate" in the negotiations between the Metropolitan Opera Company and the American Federation of Musicians for the signing of a new contract.
Commodity trading reflected the mid-summer, pre-week-end dullness yesterday on the New York exchanges. Prices moved in a narrow range and volume was generally slim.
WASHINGTON, July 28 -- A spokesman for a Senate subcommittee on merchant marine said tonight that the unit expected to complete its hearings on steamship conferences by next Thursday.

CHICAGO, July 28 (AP) -- Frank Robinson, an outfielder, hit two home runs today in leading the first-place Cincinnati Reds to a 4-3 victory over the Chicago Cubs. Bill Henry, a southpaw, turned in a good pitching job in relief.

NO exact record has been compiled but it can be shown that the number of cups of coffee consumed in any working day by Mongi Slim, chief delegate of Tunisia to the United Nations, is an uncannily good indicator of political turmoil or quiescence south of the Mediter ranean.
Several leases of offices and stores in downtown buildings were among rental transactions reported in Manhattan yesterday.
A lease of almost an acre of ground in Flushing Meadow Park for a three-story building to house home-furnishing exhibits was signed yesterday with the New York Worlds' Fair 1964-65.

MANCHESTER, England, July 28 (Reuters) -- An undefeated innings of 90 by Peter May and a partnership of 111 for the third wicket between May and the opening batsman, Geoff Pullar, today put England in a favorable position on the second day of the fourth cricket test against Australia.
WASHINGTON, July 28 -- The Senate voted unanimously tonight against Communist Chinese membership in the United Nations and against United States recognition of the Peiping regime.
THE 11-year-olds lay on their cots, engrossed in comic books and unaware of being studied or of the notes being entered on large index cards.
MOSCOW, July 28 -- United States and Soviet officials failed today to resolve their differences on the terms for convening a multination conference on disarmament.

THE homemaker browsing in the East Sixties will find Pottery of All Nations on Lexington Avenue at Sixty-fourth Street a worth-while stop these hot days. A large collection of glass accessories of every shape imaginable has recently taken over the shop.

VANCOUVER, B.C., July 28 (Canadian Press) -- Arthur Rosenstock of New York was elected today to his second term as president of the American Newspaper Guild as the 194 delegates from across the continent ended their biennial convention here.
Mayor Wagner made his third slum tour in ten days yesterday, a forty-minute inspection of a turbulent block of decaying tenement houses in Spanish Harlem.
NOT long ago chicken was a luxury; now it is one of the cheapest meats available to American man. Still more recently history has repeated the process with the Rock Cornish Game hen.

I have just finished reading Arthur Krock's July 18 column, "Stand Firm as the Be-All and the End-All of Policy." I was glad to see that the fears I had were put so well into words. I have no patience with those who are hasty to meet fire with fire in order to save our country.
LOS ANGELES, July 28 -- Bobby Fischer and Samuel Reshevsky adjourned the fifth contest of their sixteen-game chess series after forty-two moves last night in a queen's gambit declined.
GENEVA, July 28 -- The United States rejected today Soviet charges that it was seeking an excuse to resume nuclear weapons testing.

DETROIT, July 28 -- American Motors Corporation offered the United Automobile Workers today a profit-sharing plan and annual pay increases of 7 cents an hour in a three -year contract. Union representatives called the profit-sharing plan "a start in the right direction." They were displeased, however, with the company's condition that the present cost-of-living escalator clause and the annual improvement factor clause be omitted in a new contract.

A contempt charge against Joseph (Joe Palisades) Rosato, 55-year-old gangland figure who attended the conference in 1957 at Apalachin, N.Y., was dismissed yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Chalres A. Loreto.

TRENTON, July 28 -- Officials of a score of seaside resort communities denied charges today that juvenile lawlessness was rampant but was ignored by the police. They termed the charges "fallacious" and "absurd."
DETROIT, July 28 (AP) -- Bob Allison cracked two-run home runs in the first and ninth innings tonight and carried the Minnesota Twins to a 4-3 triumph over the Detroit Tigers before 35,034 fans.
Baseball heroes of yesteryear will gather at Yankee Stadium today for the annual Old-Timers Day celebration. A crowd of more than 60,000 is expected.
Putting money into oil and gas exploration is often considered a good investment risk for rich men seeking a refuge from heavy taxes on high incomes.
MILWAUKEE, July 28 (UPI) -- Larry Jackson held the Milwaukee Braves to six hits tonight as the St. Louis Cardinals won 6 -- 2. The Cards pounded three pitchers for nine hits.
Emile Griffith, the world welterweight champion from St. Thomas in the Virgin Islands, is the favorite over Yama Bahama of Bimini, B.W.I., night in a Madison Square Garden (nontitle) ten-round bout.

Tom Okker, the 17-year-old junior tennis champion of the Netherlands, won the junior title in the Long Island junior and boys tennis championship yesterday at the North Shore Tennis and Racquets Club in Bayside, Queens.
BUFFALO, N.Y., July 28 (AP) -- The Duval Engineering and Contracting Company of Jacksonville, Fla., has been purchased by Houdaille Industries, Inc., of Buffalo.
NEWBURGH, N.Y., July 28 -- Peter Z. Petrillo Jr., an assistant football coach and physical education instructor at Cornwall Central High School, was named Acting Commissioner of Public Welfare today.

HAVANA, July 28 -- The picture most widely displayed here during the 26th of July celebrations this week marking the anniversary of the start of Fidel Castro's fight against the Batista regime in 1953 was not that of Premier Castro but the smiling, boyish features of Major Yuri A. Gagarin.

CHICAGO, July 28 -- Members of the house of delegates of the American Bar Association will be asked to oppose the seating of Communist China in the United Nations when the house meets in St. Louis, Aug. 7 to 11, the association announced today.
CRANFORD, N.J., July 28 -- A female mallard duck that presumably had been shot by a youngster, successfully underwent surgery today for the removal of an arrow in its neck.
Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz obtained a Supreme Court order yesterday dissolving the corporation that owns a slum tenement house at 55 West Eighty-fourth Street.
Scattered violence, rumors and milling crowds disrupted the crossroads of Harlem at Seventh Avenue and 125th Street last night.
WASHINGTON, July 28 -- The Pentagon is arranging special assistance for Cuban refugees who want to join the armed forces of the United States, officials announced today.

BERLIN, July 28 -- An additional total of 1,030 refugees made their way to West Berlin in the twenty-four hours ending at 4 P.M. today, indicating that East German police efforts to halt the flow were largely ineffective.

The bankrupt New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad, which went into reorganization on July 7, reported yesterday that under independent operation in June it experienced a net loss of $2,139,174. This raised the line's deficit for the first half of the year to $11,777,063.
MADISON TOWNSHIP, N.J., July 28 -- A youthful hypnotist was questioned here yesterday by the police after they had found him putting children into trances.

A recommendation has been made by the agriculturists for the Park Department that ailing London plane trees on Forty-second Street between Broadway and the Avenue of Americas and in other midtown areas be replaced by the more sturdy Ginkgos.

WESTBURY, L.I., July 28 -- It turned out that Su Mac Lad was not overraced, after all. He wasn't even tired tonight at Roosevelt Raceway as Stanley Dancer guided him to victory in 2:00 4/5, the fastest clocking for a trotter anywhere this season.
Sixteen features and eighty-five short subjects will be presented at Montreal's second International Film Festival, to be held from Aug. 11 through 17, in the Loew's Theatre.
UTICA, N.Y., July 28 (AP) -- A 60-year-old man has died of heat prostration while shoveling debris on a work-relief project of the Oneida County Welfare Department.
UTICA, N.Y., July 28 (AP) -- A 60-year-old man has died of heat prostration while shoveling debris on a work-relief project of the Oneida County Welfare Department.
JERUSALEM (Israeli sector) July 25 -- A growing financial emergency is threatening the Jewish Agency for Israel's program of resettlement, agricultural help and housing for immigrants.

A select gathering of some 700 persons met under murky skies to greet Alfredo Salmaggi and his opera company as they opened a short season of opera at the Triboro Stadium on Randalls Island last night. The opera was Verdi's "Aida," and while "fun" is not the word one usually associates with that epic, the circumstances seem to justify its use at this time.

PITTSBURGH, July 28 (AP) -- Johnny Padres of the Los Angeles Dodgers, with ninth-inning help from Dick Farred, pitched a 6-4 victory over the Pittsburgh Pirates tonight. The triumph was the sixth straight for the Dodgers, who remain one game behind the first-place Cincinnati Reds.

WASHINGTON, July 28 (UPI) -- The National Security Agency has dismissed twenty-six sexual deviates since two of its code clerks defected to the Soviet Union last summer, Representative Francis E. Walter said today.

ROME, July 28 -- The Italian Government is both sensitive and worried about criticism from her allies over the subject of large imports of Russian oil, but it believes the story is far from one-sided.

Edith Harwood has bought the five-story building containing ten apartments at 115 East Thirty-sixth Street, between Park and Madison Avenues, in the Murray Hill district. The house, on a lot 25 by 100 feet, was sold for cash over a mortgage of $75,000 by clients of Walter Scott Co.
GENEVA, July 28 -- Britain informed her partners in the European Free Trade Association today that she would seek membership in the Common Market, and won their approval in principle.

WASHINGTON, July 28 (AP) -- An agreement signed today will put private industry into the communications satellite business next year for experiments that could lead to world-wide television broadcasts.
One of the taller trees of Manhattan, an aged cottonwood poplar whose topmost branches reached above the roofs of a row of five-story apartment houses off East Sixty-sixth Street, is no longer there.

President Kennedy's long-range foreign aid plan will be brought to the Senate floor substantially in the form in which he presented it last March. The Senate is expected to pass the measure; but in the House the mathematicians are doing close figuring on the outcome.
HEIDELBERG, Germany, July 28 -- The United States Army in Europe issued orders today tightening pass and leave regulations with the aim of improving troop combat readiness.
WASHINGTON, July 28 (UPI) -- The Census Bureau reported today that five out of eight American households have washing machines and less than half of them are the old-fashioned wringer type.
The Methodist Board of Missions will begin a rush program this fall to train African Christians for leadership positions in their native lands.

The Standard Oil Company (Kentucky) said yesterday that it had won a preliminary round in the suit brought by the Humble Oil and Refining Company to establish Humble's right to use the Esso trade mark in Kentucky Standard's marketing territory.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 28 -- Following is the text of a letter today to the President of the Security Council from Armand Berard, chief French delegate:
Further studies on the comparative new technique of using explosives to alter metal are being pursued at The Martin Company's Baltimore division.
The Washington Suburban Sanitary District, Md., is planning the sale of $10,000,000 of bonds on Aug. 15. The issue will come due serially from 1963 to 1992.

Sales of the Weyerhaeuser Company for the first half this year rose to $237,439,403 from $225,616,642 for the 1960 period. Earnings of the big West Coast lumber company, however, were sharply lower, the semi-annual report disclosed yesterday.

LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, July 28 (Reuters) -- Antoine Gizenga, head of the dissident, Soviet-backed Congo regime at Stanleyville, has protested to the United Nations over alleged violations of an agreement under which the Congolese Parliament is meeting, it was disclosed today.

WASHINGTON, July 28 -- The Administration began preparing for the race to the moon today by asking industry to build a multi-ton space craft that would carry a three-man expedition to the moon before 1970.

PALO ALTO, Calif., July 28 (AP) -- Senator J.W. Fulbright said today that if the non-Communist world is to meet the challenge of communism North Atlantic nations must give up some of their sovereignty.

TUNIS, July 28 -- President Habib Bourguiba said today that the only thing the United States could do to resolve the Bizerte crisis was to help Tunisia obtain "the complete evacuation'' of French forces from her territory.

TOKYO, July 28 (UPI) -- Chet Jastremski of Indiana University bettered the listed world records in the 100 and 200 meter breast-stroke tonight in the opening heats of the Japanese swimming championships.
WASHINGTON, July 28 (AP) -- The Army made a start today on development of a rubber-tracked vehicle that could travel on water, hard surface, snow or mud.
Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 4 points off to 5 up yesterday. Only for December rose, on a bid.
Following is the text of a French Government communique on the base at Bizerte, as made available here yesterday by the French Information Service:

KANSAS CITY, July 29 (UPI) -- Norm Siebern's two-run single in the seventh inning and Bob Shaw's four-hit pitching sparked the Kansas City Athletics to a 2 -- 1 victory over the Washington Senators today.

EUONYMUS species and varieties have long been popular garden plants in the North and South. Unfortunately for gardeners in the North, the large, shiny-leaved Japanese euonymus is not hardy, but some new hybrids, selected during the past few, years, may be excellent substitutes.

MANCHESTER, England, July 29 (Reuters) -- Australia, facing a first-innings deficit of 177, hit back strongly today when Bill Lawry and Bobby Simpson made 63 without being separated against England in the fourth test match at Old Trafford.

WASHINGTON, July 29 -- A wise old colleague once remarked to Senator John F. Kennedy that though he be the world's greatest statesman, a President of the United States might as well be a dunce unless he was politician enough to get his program through Congress.
PITTSBURGH, July 29 -- Duke Snider's ninth-inning home run, a pair of singles and a sacrifice gave the Los Angeles Dodgers two runs and a 5-4 victory over the Pittsburgh Pirates today.
THE morning was cloudy, with a threat of rain. At 10:30 a group of people gathered on the grounds of Villa Wahnfried to pay homage to Richard Wagner.
NEWARK, July 29 -- Newark will open its $5,600,000 underground garage for 1,030 cars in Military Park Wednesday thirty-two years after it was first proposed.
LONDON, July 20 -- A new method of protecting crops against fungus infections may result from the discovery of a powerful series of fungus-resistant chemicals inside the tissue of certain plants.
Mayor Wagner announced plans yesterday for the city's first neighborhood center for narcotics addicts.
The Queens span of the Triborough Bridge was the most dangerous spot in the city for motorists last year, according to a list of "accident prone" locations compiled by the Police Department.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), July 29 -- After two years of arbitration and bitter fighting in court, work will be resumed within the next two days on a Reform synagogue in Jerusalem.

THE first favorable public recognition of Sigmund Freud and the nascent theory and practice of psychoanalysis occurred in 1909, when Stanley Hall. then President of Clark University in Worcester, Mass., invited Freud and his colleague, Carl Gustav Jung, to give a series of lectures for the university's twentieth anniversary.

The newspapers in Dallas, Tex., last Thursday decided that it was not news when a total of 159 Negroes dined quietly at thirty-six previously all-white restaurants and cafeterias. In a sense it wasn't news, because there were no "incidents." In the department stores and other eating places that were visited, there were three complaints from white customers.
NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., July 29 -- The Huguenot Yacht Club's fourth annual predicted-log contest was won today by John A. Buckbee in Anchors Aweigh, with an accuracy score of 99.47 per cent.

The article by Secretary Abraham Ribicoff, "To Promote the General Welfare" (July 9), is a substantial contribution in helping to explain the welfare concept as it has been developed in the United States.
At least 200 extra policemen will reinforce Harlem details at night as a result of the violent milling of crowds near Seventh Avenue and 125th Street Friday night.

TOWNSHEND, Vt. -- A splendid system of earthworks and towers, augmenting the majesty of this Green Mountain region and increasing its recreational resources, soon will be ready for the tourist along State Highway 30 in southern Vermont's West River Valley.
"THE Dispossessed," a drama about Indians but no cowboys, has been selected as the first in a series of six one-hour original plays to be televised next season by the Columbia Broadcasting System.

From its shores, nearly two decades ago, the Allies -- and General Charles de Gaulle -- began the liberation of Europe from Nazism. In its Arab souks and casbahs, a decade ago, began the Tunisian, Moroccan and Algerian independence struggles that sapped the Fourth Republic.

COMMUNIST diplomacy made its inroads on art at the second annual Moscow Film Festival which ended here last Sunday in a splurge of prize-giving. The Soviet hosts were determined that just about every one of the participating fifty-five nations should go home clutching some award and glowing with peace and friendship.

CHICAGO, July 29 (UPI) -- Milk glowed into Chicago grocery stores today for the first time since Wednesday. Tank trucks hauled a thousand tons of milk into the city hours after Local 753 of the Teamsters Union agreed on a two-year contract with the Associated Milk Dealers ending a forty-eight-hour strike.

WILLIAM FULBRIGHT, chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 29 -- The Save the Redwoods League is sounding an alarm over a threat, from erosion, to the 8,000-acre Rockefeller Forest in Humboldt Redwoods State Park.

WASHINGTON, July 29 - "We are clear about what must be done -- and we intend to do it," President Kennedy said Tuesday in his address to the Nation on Berlin. By the weekend Congress was moving swiftly with unanimous force to lend credibility to his words.

For the fifth consecutive month, the members of the National Association of Purchasing Agents reported that business conditions continued to improve in July. However, there was some tapering off in new orders and the rate of production, in line with the usual summer lull.
BERLIN, July 29 -- The East German Government warned its citizens today to cease traveling to West Germany and West Berlin.
PARIS, July 29 (AP) -- Premier Michel Debre spoke on television tonight to outline new Government plans for aiding France's discontented farmers.

THE urge to create has always been a fascinating phenomenon. Where does it come from? Why should one want to create something, be it a painting, a piece of music or sculpture, or a bit of knowledge? Parturition, even in this sense, is seldom without pain, and serious creation demands great devotion and concentration, study and hard labor, often at the cost of personal interests.
FAIRBANKS, Alaska, July 29 -- America's northernmost university plans to establish an Arctic Research Center.

BEACON, N.Y., July 29 (UPI) -- The slayer of Mr. and Mrs. Maxwell Bodenheim was recaptured with three other inmates today within hours after breaking out of the Matteawan State Hospital for the Criminal Insane.

CHICAGO, July 29 -- Home runs by Ernie Banks, Billy Williams and Ron Santo powered the Chicago Cubs to a 7-6 victory today that tumbled the Cincinnati Reds out of the National League lead.

BERLIN, July 29 -- Brig. Gen. Frederick O. Hartel, the veteran infantry officer who would command United States forces in a fight over Berlin, put in an unusual extra hour of work today.

Emile Griffith, the world welterweight champion from New York via St. Thomas, Virgin Islands, has said repeatedly that his right hand packs more power than his left. Onieva, translated by Patricia May O'Neill, is named "A New Complete Guide to the Prado Gallery" and costs 80 pesetas ($1.28).
PALO ALTO, Calif., July 29 -- Many college and university programs were roundly criticized this week on the Stanford University campus. So were courses in schools below the college level.

SPRINGFIELD, Ohio, July 29 (AP) -- Charles Pasarell, who won the boys' singles title here two years ago, won the junior division (18 years and younger) crown today in the Western open junior and boys tennis tournament.

OCEANPORT, N.J., July 29 -- The Wheatley Stable's 2-year-old filly Batter Up survived a foul claim at Monmouth Park today after she had crossed the wire two and three-quarter lengths ahead of seven rivals in the $100,000 Sorority Stakes. An inundated crowd of 24,754 was on hand.

DETROIT, July 29 -- Harmon Killebrew greeted a rookie relief pitcher, Manuel Montejo, with an upper-deck three-run homer in the eighth inning today, the drive carrying the Minnesota Twins to a 5-4 victory over the Detroit Tigers.

NORMAN, Okla., July 29 (UPI) -- Oklahoma went into every football game last year "in a sod-pawing, horn-tossing mood," but "was decisively out-fought and out-finished in the last half," according to the Sooners' 1961 football brochure just released.

They came and they stayed because the Indians had a grain called maize.

Lake Forest College in Illinois will adopt a new calendar and a new program next fall in an effort to place greater emphasis on learning in depth. The traditional two semesters will be replaced by three terms of approximately eleven weeks each, including an examination period.

The ailing British economy was given rather bitter medicine last week. The Government raised the bank rate from 5 to 7 per cent; increased various excise taxes, and added 10 per cent to existing sales taxes, which already range up to 25 per cent.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., July 29 (AP) -- The first six Rutgers Urban Fellows were named today. They will receive stipends commensurate with their salaries to study urban problems during the coming college year at the New Urban Studies Center of the State University.

HOUSTON, Tex, July 30 (AP) -- Texas members of the American Legion asked Congress today to investigate the State Department and the Supreme Court.
ROME, July 30 -- This year, for the first time in Italian history, it is said, want ads have appeared in newspapers offering jobs not only for skilled workers but even for the unskilled.

The suddenly festering quarrel over Bizerte has cost several hundred lives, has shaken the position of Tunisia as a friend of the Western world, has brought new doubt into the Franco-Algerian discussions and may even have had a bad effect on the situation in Berlin. Tranquillity in North Africa, including Tunisia, would have enabled General de Gaulle to reinforce his European defense and stand more firmly and unitedly with his allies in that area.
Roman Catholics have "the same duty to the man and woman next door as the Pope has to the world," the Rev. Daniel P. Byrne of the New York Apostolate Mission Band said yesterday.

LAKE GROVE, L.I., July 30 -- Danny Lopez of Old Brookville, L.I., rode his thoroughbred mare, Little Scubbie, to the junior jumper championship of the Fox Hill Stables junior horse show today. Little Scubbie won blue ribbons in three events to take the title. Reserve honors went to Neal Shapiro's Maid Marion with 14 points.
WASHINGTON, July 30 (UPI) -- The New York Congressional steering committee called today for greater use of New York's port for shipping grain overseas.
A shipment of 180 tropical fish has survived an eighty-two hour flight around the world in an air cargo experiment devised by a Florida tropical fish farm.
GETTYSBURG, Pa., July 30 (AP) -- A coded message in an old English military journal may cast new light on the assassination of Abraham Lincoln ninety-six years ago.

HOLLYWOOD, July 30 -- Two films that were the subjects of national controversy in censorship rows have quietly received the seals of approval originally denied them by the movie industry's self-censoring group.
Warner Brothers has acquired film rights to "The Story of Edith Piaf." Frank P. Rosenberg will produce the biography of the French singer-actress.

Efforts to modify Government pest-spraying programs so as to safeguard public health and minimize damage to wildlife, are making some progress. But the recklessness of official pest-control agencies is only part of the problem.
MANASQUAN, N.J., July 30 -- Three persons were injured today when a gas stove exploded aboard a sixty-foot yacht. However, all eight persons aboard were rescued.

A chess tournament to determine an opponent for Mikhail Botvinnik, the world champion, will be held in the United States late next year, it was reported yesterday by Tass, the official Soviet news agency.

MOSCOW, July 30 -- Premier Khrushchev appeared to have taken a firmer grip today on the leadership of the World Communist movement with the presentation of the draft program of the Communist party of the Soviet Union.

ENERGETIC Mrs. Evelyn Sharp, the only woman who owns and operates a major hotel organization in the United States, said last week that what the hotel business needs is a few more bright young women executives, but that by women she did not mean "flair people."
PITTSBURGH, July 30 (AP) -- Don Drysdale, with help from Ron Perranoski in the ninth, pitched the Los Angeles Dodgers to a 7-3 victory over the Pirates today.

JERUSALEM, July 30 -- The present Government of Israel, which is to say David Ben-Gurion, is guided by four basic tenets: the search for more population from among the earth's Jews; the quest for fresh water; the drive for new energy sources, above all solar or nuclear; and the Old Testament.
The new draft program of the Soviet Communist party appears to depart in some significant measure from a policy favoring consumers indicated by Premier Khrushchev earlier this year.
BUENOS AIRES, July 30 (AP) -- The Soviet commercial attache here denied yesterday a published report that he and two other Soviet Embassy officials had been spying in Argentina.
" The Opening of a Window" will introduce Patrolman Gene Radano as a playwright, Mr. Radano, who has been one of the city's "finest" since 1946, is a warrant officer attached to the Fifth Precinct.

LONDON, Monday, July 31 -- As thousands of jazz fans left the historic grounds near Beaulieu Abbey in Hampshire early this morning, after the two-day annual jazz festival, Lord Montagu of Beaulieu announced that it had been the last.
The Berlin crisis will spark a war in the fall if the United States and the Soviet Union continue to steer a collision course, the Rev. Donald S. Harrington warned yesterday.
Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz charged yesterday that Mayor Wagner was responsible for making New York "one of the worst-governed cities in America."

The Aetna Supply Company, distributor of refrigerating machinery supplies, has purchased the one-story commercial building and abutting two-story office and residential building at 503 Wales Avenue, the Bronx. It paid cash for the parcel, which is 93 by 100 feet, and will move from 210 East 138th Street.
WASHINGTON, July 30 -- This week Congress will open its first major review since March, 1960, of the nation's controversial civil defense effort.
The state Mediation Board continued intensive efforts yesterday to prevent a strike by maintenance workers at New York International Airport.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 30 -- United Nations maneuvering on the Bizerte crisis turned today to what has been called the "traditional sphere of private diplomacy."

The frightening experience of performing before the biggest crowd in the Orioles' history apparently so affected Baltimore's "kid" pitchers yesterday that they couldn't get out of Yankee Stadium fast enough.

DETROIT, July 30 (AP) -The Minnesota Twins completed a sweep of a three-game series against Detroit by blanking the second-place Tigers, 4 -- 0, today behind Jack Kralick. The left-hander scattered eight hits in posting his tenth victory.
The Beekman-Downtown Hospital plans to increase its capacity by almost 50 per cent by acquiring and developing about half an acre of land south of its main building at 170 William Street.
Mutual funds, by and large, did no better and no worse than the securities markets in general during the second quarter.
MOSCOW, July 31 -- The Soviet people had their first look today at what their leaders visualize as the basis for a Communist society by 1980.

WASHINGTON, July 30 (AP) -- The United States Public Health Service announced today the formation of a task force to map an attack on syphilis, which has shown a threefold new-case increase in four years.

Gen. Curtis E. LeMay, Chief of Staff of the Air Force, said yesterday that the Soviet air show in Moscow on July 9 had not produced a request by the Air Force for more bombers, as reported in The New York Times on July 12.
CALCUTTA, India, July 30 -- A great concentration of urban planning talent will go to work here soon.
The Maryland Port Authority has stepped into a controversy involving Maritime Administration ship allocations that may determine the future pattern of the off-shore trade with Puerto Rico.

The death of Ty Cobb recently brought back to the memory of baseball fans decades of the past and the changes wrought since those days. Cobb's era, during which he held the batting championship of the American League consistently from 1907 through 1915 and then with only one year's interruption from 1917 through 1919, links with that of Babe Ruth.
Prime Minister Sir Abubakar Tafawa Balewa of Nigeria said yesterday that he could see no solution for the Tunisian crisis other than immediate and complete withdrawal of French troops from Bizerte.

Chipping and painting, for decades one of a seaman's most onerous tasks, may become a minor chore with the development of a new robot painting device, Esso Research and Engineering Company indicated yesterday.

Christianity and Crisis, a Protestant weekly published here, views the latest papal encyclical as a "formidable" document "explicitly designed to emphasize and give contemporary application to the social teachings of the church."
ASHDOD, Israel, July 30 -- The cornerstone for a new $75, 000,000 port was dedicated here today. The port will ultimately give Israel a new trade door to Europe and the rest of the world.

PITTSBURGH, July 38 -- Orders for steel this month, when all the figures are in, will fall short of June bookings by as much as 10 to 15 per cent. But advance soundings on August prospects suggest that order intake in August will range from 5 per cent below to equal to June bookings.

The Transnation Realty Corporation, Henry Goelet, president, has announced a plan for converting the thirteen-story apartment building at 12 Beekman Place, comer of Fiftieth Street, to cooperative ownership.
BERLIN, July 30. -- Many East Germans took refuge in West Berlin over the weekend.
ATHENS, July 30 -- GreekBulgarian relations are swiftly reaching the "breaking point," according to diplomatic observers here.
Religious leaders who seek state and Federal aid may be unwittingly compromising their churches, the regional director of Americans United for Separation of Church and State said yesterday.

Officials of the Treasury Department are organizing statistics and other data in preparation for their general tax revision proposals expected next year. When President Kennedy presented his tax message to Congress in April, he said that the changes he suggested at that time were only the beginning -- that general tax reform would be requested later.
THE celebrations in Cuba last week deliberately emphasized the increasing strength of Premier Fidel Castro's pro-Communist state.
WASHINGTON, July 30 (UPI) -- Secretary of Labor Arthur J. Goldberg announced today that a new national survey of employment had shown improvement in 90 per cent of 150 major labor markets.

The Aluminum Company of America reported over the week-end a net income of $19, 941,526, or 88 cents a common share for the first six months of this year. That compared with $21,726.308, or 96 cents a common share, in the first half of 1960.
HYANNIS PORT, Mass., July 30 -- President Kennedy is expected to confer in Washington tomorrow with John J. McCloy, who spent more than two days last week in consultation with Premier Khrushchev.

A realignment of executive authority for Eastern Air Lines. Inc., has been approved by the directors, it was announced over the week-end. A new level of executive authority has been set up, responsible to the president, Malcolm A. MacIntyre, who also is chief executive officer.

BAYREUTH, Germany, July 30 -- The first full week of the Bayreuth Festival ended tonight with a performance of "Goetterdaemmerung," the last of Wagner's "Ring" cycle. Earlier in the week the other three operas had been presented, all in Wolfgang Wagner's staging.

WESTBURY, L.I., July 30 -- Adios Butler is the chief attraction of the final program of the sixty-one-night summer meeting tomorrow night at Roosevelt Raceway. The 5-year-old pacing sensation will seek his eighth straight victory in the $25,000 Pace of the Century free-for-all.
The creation of "the material and technical basis of communism'' is stated as the goal of the new draft program of the Soviet Communist party.
WARSAW, July 30 -- Rain poured down. It was so dark at the end, the runners and jumpers no longer could be seen clearly.

THE camp director who talks expansively about the psychology of child-rearing and its application to his camp's programing does not always run the most professional private camp. Sometimes he does not even run the camp at all.
SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., July 30 -- Strikers picketed sleepy-looking Saratoga today for the first time in the history of the picturesque ninety-eight-year-old track. No disorders occurred.

For several years now, sales of color television sets have been dragging along like the tailfeathers of the National Broadcasting Company's peacock. Volume has been disappointing to the television industry in general and particularly to giant Radio Corporation of America; which has invested millions of dollars in color sets and programing.

PELHAM MANOR, N.Y. July 30 -- The New York Athletic Club A team won the Amateur Athletic Union national outdoor water polo title today by defeating the Toronto Water Polo Club, 6--3, at the Travers Island pool.

The four-week-old strike of 1,200 concrete-mix drivers has forced 50,000 building trades workers into idleness and halted scores of huge projects. No real negotiations have taken place, and it is doubtful that any can until the leaders of the striking Local 282 of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters are ready to assume the elementary responsibilities of leadership.

TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES:In an editorial on July 23 on the situation in Bizerte you condemn the war by labeling it "stupid," lifting the epithet from a speech by Bourguiba. You do not do your readers the honor of explaining why Bourguiba thus characterized it, so that they might be in a better position to judge for themselves where the stupidity lies.

A long-range plan to redesign all standard works in the repertory of the New York City Opera will be begun with the presentation of "Madama Butterfly'' on Oct. 14. Gordon Micunis will create the scenery and costumes for the Puccini opera, and Albert Felmar will restage it.

SOUTH DARTMOUTH, Mass., July 30 -- Henry D. Mercer's Weatherly not only scored her third successive victory against the other 12-Meter yachts during the New York Yacht Club's cruise today, but also carried off one of the fixture's leading plums.
WASHINGTON, July 30 (UPI) -- Factory sales rose nearly 1 per cent in June and new orders held steady. The Department of Commerce reported today.
UNADILLA, N.Y., July 30 (AP) -- The Mayor of this Ostego County village, ravaged yesterday by torrential rain and flash floods, asked the state today to designate it a disaster area.
MIAMI, July 30 -- Eight of ten Cuban prisoners who have been here since June 24 representing nearly 1,200 others held by Premier Fidel Castro will return to Havana tomorrow morning.
GENEVA, July 3O -- A three-day advance on the Swiss stock market after its recent sharp losses was followed by a two-day decline last week.
The first completely automated assembly line for the manufacture of electronic resistors -- a bread-and-butter item in the electronic industry -- has been announced by the Western Electric Company.

A marathon program of folk music was run on Saturday to initiate the live music project of the city's newest FM radio outlet. Aside from a few pauses to identify station WRVR, the sound of ballads, blues, banjos and bouzoukis was heard from 9 A.M. to 9 P.M.

QUEBEC, July 30 (Canadian Press) -- Rafael Osuna and Antonio Palafox of Mexico beat Bob Bedard and Francois Godbout of Canada, 10--12, 9--7, 8--6, 6--4, today and put Mexico into a 2-1 lead in the North American zone Davis Cup tennis series.
HAVERFORD, Pa., July 30 -- Seventeen-year-old Billie Jean Moffitt of Long Beach, Calif., is the new Pennsylvania women's lawn tennis champion.

The halting of the downward trend and sharp upward swing of the British pound sterling featured the movements in the foreign exchange market last week. This recovery followed the announcement by Mr. Selwyn Lloyd, Chancellor of the Exchequer, on Tuesday, of measures to reduce home consumption and Government spending and to advance exports and strengthen the pound. The bank rate was raised to 7 per cent. The Canadian dollar was steady on light dealings.

Nuclear insurance will have renewed discussion as the major topic at the annual conference of the International Union of Marine Insurance, according to Emil A. Kratovil, president of the American Institute of Marine Underwriters.
PHILADELPHIA, July 30 (UPI) -- Willie Mays hit his twenty-ninth homer of the year today as the San Francisco Giants methodically chipped away at Jim Owens and beat the Phillies, 5 -- 2.
This is a portrait of the artist in New York -- how he lives, and how he makes his living. It should be stated at once that he almost never makes it from his art alone.
Mayor Wagner charged the Democratic and Republican county leaders of Brooklyn yesterday with making "sinister deals to rob voters of an honest choice" in the election of State Supreme Court Justices.
Trading in cotton futures last week was relatively dull with prices moving in a narrow range. At the close Friday active contracts were 15 cents a bale lower to 55 cents a bale higher.

In a recent excellent review of the Kennedy Administration to date in The Times James Reston referred to my biography of John F. Kennedy as an "official biography." Since previous correspondents of The Times have also referred to it in these words, I would like to explain its actual status.

IN spite of all the learned books that have been written about it, nobody really knows much about the nature of comedy. Various theorists have suggested that what makes us laugh is the unexpected, or the incongruous, or a suddenly induced feeling of superiority (we are dignified and upright while the other fellow has hilariously slipped on a banana peel).
There will be no more waiting in line for renewal of drivers' licenses in New York after tomorrow.

International financial interests have begun a race to exploit the enormous iron ore resources of two West African countries, according to information disclosed last week by investment sources on Wall Street.
PARIS, July 30 -- France charged today that French citizens were being expelled from Tunisia with little more than the clothes they wore at the time of internment.
WASHINGTON, July 30 -- Not to be outdone by the White House, the Senate has hired a French maitre d'hotel to break the corn-pone-and-bean-soup monotony of its cuisine.
The Hanover Bark, which recently vacated five floors of the office building at 20 Broad Street under a lease that had twenty years to go, has been released from its commitment on the space.
The anticipated television income for teams in the National Football League will be cut by $2,264,000 as a result of a recent decision by a Federal judge.
LONDON, July 30 -- Britain's Council on Prices, Productivity and Incomes laid down a program today for correcting the nation's economic ills and attaining greater productivity.

It now appears that one of the more interesting by-products of this year's primary campaign will be a disclosure of some of the inner workings of politics. It may also reveal the motivations of those who engage in politics on full-time basis.

BOSTON, July 30 (AP) -- Joe Ginsberg's tenth-inning pinch single enabled Boston to divide a double-header with Chicago today. Ginsberg's hit scored the winning run in the 9-8 finale after Frank Baumann had beaten the Red Sox in the opener, 4 -- 2, on a six-hitter that snapped a five-game White Sox losing streak.
MIGUEL FERRERAS, the Cuban-born designer who recently opened a salon in Paris at 11 Rue du Faubourg Saint Honord, has been variously called "a man to watch," "a publicity hound" and an "ingrate."

AT lunch time in a fashionable midtown restaurant, business is bustling -- not only for the restaurant but for much of the clientele. Scribblings on tablecloths suggest that many of the patrons are engaged in that strange mixture of banter and barter, the business lunch.

KANSAS CITY, July 30 (AP) -- Bennie Daniels pitched his first shutout for the Washington Senators today, a six-hitter that beat the Kansas City Athletics, 4 -- 0. It was the 29-year-old right-hander's sixth victory against five losses.
LOS ANGELES, July 30 (AP) -- The Los Angeles Angels slammed five home runs and survived four by Cleveland today as they defeated the Indians, 8 -- 6.

NEWTON, N. J., July 30 -- Ch. Evening Star de Luchar, a Skye terrier owned by the Glamour Kennels of Oyster Bay, L.I., scored her second best-in-show victory in two days today. She took top honors in the eighteenth annual Newton Kennel Club show at Memory Park over an entry of 560.
CHICAGO, July 30 -- Jerry Barber's sensational putting on the last three holes today enabled him to tie Don January for first place in the Professional Golfers Association championship.
WASHINGTON, July 30 -- Foreign aid, the nation's defense build-up and the Berlin crisis will continue to dominate Congressional debate this week.

The second volume of John Masters' autobiography, "The Road Past Mandalay," will be published Aug. 16 by Harper. It covers the years from 1939 to 1945, from the day in September when war came to the author and his battalion in a little Indian outpost near the Afghan border to war's end when he had to face the dilemma confronting his generation of officers in the Indian Army.
WASHINGTON, July 30 -- Developments in Laos and South Vietnam have stimulated the study of problems of guerrilla warfare by officials in the White House and the State and Defense Department.

The astounding theft Friday night of ten paintings from the residence of G. David Thompson in Pittsburgh has frightened other collectors not by its magnitude but by its brutality. The canvases were crudely hacked from their frames by thieves who were equally indifferent to the paintings as works of art and ignorant of the most rudimentary facts concerning the physical nature of the objects they were violating.
Paris, July 30 -- Miguel Ferreras is ready to snare some private customers. Whether he does remains to be seen, but anyone wearing his designs this season is virtually promised a beautiful figure.

A three-year agreement between the League of New York Theatres, the managerial group, and the stagehands union, Theatrical Protective Union, Local 1, is expected to be reached this afternoon. The current contract expires today.
Greasing the tracks to tow a subway car with a broken wheel must have seemed like a good idea at the time to the Transit Authority. Yesterday it wasn't so sure.

BOSTON, July 30 -- For the next twenty-four hours, major league baseball's torrid pennant races, along with the dizzy Maris-Mantle home run duel, move into what one might call a state of suspended animation.

LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, July 30 -- President Moise Tshombe of Katanga Province and President Joseph Kasavubu, Congolese chief of state, made tentative plans today for a personal meeting here tomorrow.
MOSCOW, July 30 -- The Soviet Union staged its big navy show at Leningrad today with a boast that missile-armed atomic submarines were the backbone of its navy.
ALBANY, July 30 -- The state Education Department offered today to evaluate the teaching programs of school districts requesting such an appraisal.
BOSTON, July 30 -- Round 2 of the annual all-star baseball Donnybrook is scheduled for tomorrow afternoon in Fenway Park. Several early "knockouts" are expected.

Dr. Matthew Ies Spetter. Ethical Culture leader, pleaded yesterday for a return from the "never-never land of military blackmail." He spoke at the New York Society for Ethical Culture, Central Park West and Sixty-fourth Street.

QUONSET POINT, R.L. July 30 -- Reservists of the Lakehurst, N.J., naval training unit, Air Anti-Submarine Squadron No. 753, wound up two weeks of intensive training today in their chosen specialty of tracking and killing submarines.
WASHINGTON, July 30 -- Preliminary agreement has been reached with the principal Western Governments for an expansion of the potential resources of the International Monetary Fund.
Demand for industrial stocks, traded over the counter, was the strongest last week in months. However, price gains generally were moderate.
The city is investigating activities in the Queens Borough President's office while it was under Republican control in 1957.
BARCELONA, Spain, July 30 (UPI) -- A 102-year-old Spanish-born nun expelled recently from Cuba after seventy-two years there said today she hoped to return to Cuba.

The 100,000 voluntary health and welfare agencies in the nation were warned yesterday to clarify their financial reporting. If they do not, the warning continued, they face the loss of public confidence and increased Government controls.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, July 30 (Reuters) -- Tanyug, the official Yugoslav press agency, issued today a 2,000-word summary of the draft program of the Soviet Communist party made public in Moscow.
MELBOURNE Australia, July 30 -- Three New Guineans were killed today and hundreds were injured in communal rioting in Rabaul, New Guinea. Gunfire by the police caused two of the fatalities.

In Greenwich Village yesterday, the movies thrived, taverns were busy and, in West Third Street night clubs, strippers did bumps and grinds. But five bookstore owners received summonses for selling books and were warned by the police -- never on Sunday.
The coordinator of Children's Services at the New York Public Library, Mrs. Frances Lander Spain, will retire today.
CASSVILLE, N.J., July 30 About 6,000 Russian-Americans from nineteen states and two Canadian provinces converged here today to honor the memory of St. Vladimir.

I heard Senator Kennedy speak on civil rights last October in New York. When he finished I would have said that, if a situation developed like the one now involving the Freedom Riders, President Kennedy would get on a bus with Ralph Bunche or Martin Luther King, ride to Montgomery, go arm in arm with his companion to the white lunch counter, and let the Ku Kluxers take it from there.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 30 -- Dr. Nathan Barnes, Liberia's chief delegate to the United Nations, believes that the growing influence of political moderates in Africa will serve to check Communist expansion there.

BEAR MOUNTALN, N.Y., July 30 -- Despite the rain yesterday, an audience of more than 1,750 persons showed up last night for the performance of "Madama Butterfly" given by the Empire State Music Festival at the Anthony Wayne Recreation Area of Bear Mountain-Harriman State Park.
Direct obligation of the United States Government in the hands of the public that will mature within twelve months amount to $73,207,048, 138. They consist of Treasury securities as follows:

In an action considered to be rare and possibly unique in recent legislative history in this country, representatives of foreign business interests have written a regulatory measure for a committee of Congress.

CHICO, Calif., July 13 (UPI) -- A man went berserk aboard a Pacific Airlines plane on the ground here tonight, shot the pilot in the head, fired on a dozen passengers and attempted to fly the plane himself before he was subdued.
DETROIT, July 31 (AP) -- The United Automobile Workers served notice on General Motors today that it would terminate its contract with the company at midnight Aug. 31.

Johnson Johnson, manufacturer of surgical dressings, medical and allied products, attained record sales in the first six months of this year. Net earnings in the half year, however, dipped 2.8 per cent from the level in the 1960 period, according to the semi-annual port yesterday of Robert Wood Johnson, chairman.

BONN, Germany, July 31 -- Foreign Minister Heinrich von Brentano said today he was "certain" that no concrete proposals for negotiations on Berlin would come out of the foreign ministers' meeting in Paris starting next Saturday.
An old Brooklyn trolley car will make its last journey today -- by trailer truck -- to a new haven where it will be restored as a museum piece.
The questions in a June licensing examination for physicians were reported yesterday to have been sold in advance for as much as $2,500.

Dividend Shares, Inc., reported yesterday that net assets aggregated $308,035,661, equal to $3.35 a share, on June 30. This compared with assets of $268,791,248, or $2.96 a share on fewer shares outstanding, a year earlier.

NEWARK, N.J., July 31 (AP) -- The Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) said today that it had filed a $53,120,000 suit in Federal Court against an Italian oil company that asked damages of Standard in a suit last April.
Sale of television station WNTA-TV to a group of citizens interested in educational video will not be considered by the Federal Communications Commission until the fall, it was learned last night.

The following quotations are selling prices in United States dollars and cents for free market banknote transactions at New York. These rates do not apply to regular foreign exchange business transacted by banks.
The Prime Minister of Nigeria said yesterday that he foresaw continuing trouble in Africa but that he regarded the trouble as Africa's "growing pains."
BANGKOK, Thailand, July 31 (Reuters) -- Thailand, Malaya and the Philippines launched a new association today aimed at establishing closer links among non-Communist countries in Southeast Asia.
WASHINGTON, July 31 (AP) -- The Kennedy Administration asked the Senate Labor subcommittee today to give it the tools to enforce the Welfare and Pension Plans Disclosure Act of 1958.

Good for Goldwater. As usual he hits the welfarists where it hurts. How they howl when he or another does, as witness your July 20 editorial, and the professionals in the state and Federal welfare departments with a political axe to grind.

The International Society for Rehabilitation of the Disabled will benefit from the Oct. 27 performance of "Sail Away." The new Noel Coward musical comedy is scheduled to open at the Broadhurst Theatre on Oct. 3.
The occupancy rate in representative Manhattan office buildings has remained substantially unchanged in the last year. Vacancies as of last May 1 were less than 3 per cent.
CHICAGO, July 31 -- Commonwealth Edison Company and three other electric utilities filed nine suits today to recover damages for alleged overcharges on electrical equipment.
The value of new securities offered here to the public in July was the smallest for any month this year and below the July levels of the two preceding years.
"COOKING, no matter how exciting the dish, is part drudgery," says Helen Worth, whose cooking school has been inspiring would-be home chefs for the past twenty-one years.
WESTPORT, Conn., July 31 -- Discarded spikes from the roadbed of the New Haven Railroad are being made into sculpture by a commuter here.

The Borden Company Is negotiating to acquire Greenwood Foods, Inc., of Waterloo, N.Y., which is said to be the nation's largest packer of red cabbage and pickled beets and a handler of glassed spiced fruits.

Anthony Franciosa will leave for Rome on Thursday to start pre-production for "As a Man Grows Older," a romantic drama based on the novel by Italo Svevo. Mauro Bolognini will direct and co-produce the film with Morris Ergas, last represented here by "General Della Rovere."

MINNEAPOLIS, July 3I (AP) -- Judy Kimball of Sioux City Iowa, scored the first victory of her short professional golf career today when she won the American women's open in close finish with Betsy Rawl of Spartenburg, S.C.
VIENNA, July 31 -- The Austrian Government announced tonight that it was prepared to follow the lead of Britain and to negotiate with the European Common Market.

BOSTON, July 31 -- Baseball's finest pitchers won their psychological war with The Wall and their dangerous guessing contest with the sport's best batters in the major league all-star game at Fenway Park today.

Three convicts who were converted to the Black Muslim sect while in prison were granted a hearing yesterday on charges that their religious beliefs had subjected them to solitary confinement in Clinton Prison, Dannemora. N.Y.
BOSTON, July 31 (AP) -- "They warned me about his slow curve," said Mickey Mantle, one of Stu Miller's strikeout victims in the all-star baseball game today. But never expected a curve that slow.
ALBANY, July 31 -- A plan to require all New York drivers to install exhaust purifying equipment in their cars is under study.

HAVERFORD, Pa., July 31 -- Corporal Jon Douglas, a Marine from Santa Monica, Calif., administered a crushing defeat to Frank Froehling 3d of Coral Gables, Fla., today in the final of the Pennsylvania lawn tennis championship.
New York City has borrowed $15,000,000 on tax anticipation notes bearing 1 7/8 per cent interest and maturing on Nov. 2, Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa said yesterday.
TOKYO, Tuesday, Aug. 1 (AP) -- Defense Minister Rodion Y. Malinovsky of the Soviet Union hailed today what he called the unbreakable ties between the Soviet and Chinese Communist forces.
Communist China's contribution to world communism is dismissed in eleven words in the draft program of the Soviet Communist party.

After last week's sharp advance, the stock market drifted aimlessly yesterday in the doldrums. Prices on the New York Stock Exchange made a small gain on average, but there was little evidence of any real pattern either upward or downward.

The American press recently summed up the first six months of John F. Kennedy. Today Latin America is pondering the results and meaning of an equally important milestone in that area -- the first six months of Janio Quadros, President of Brazil.

The Atlantic Refining Company had a net income of $21,649,000 or $2.31 a common share, in the first six months of this year, the company reported yesterday. Sales and other income aggregated $290,724,000.
PARIS, July 31 -- The Danish Government announced today that it would apply for membership in the six-nation European Economic Community.

SCARBOROUGH-ON-HUDSON, N.Y., July 31 -- The Apawamis team of Frank Cardi, assistant professional, and Frank Donahue, won the pro-amateur tournament of the Westchester Professional Golfers Association today with a best-ball score of 33, 34 -- 67.
Alfred Feinberg is an artist whose works hang in no gallery, whose strokes are rarely flattering, and whose subjects are usually under anesthesia.
Representative John V. Lindsay has asked for a Congressional investigation of New York City's housing and urban renewal program.
WASHINGTON, July 31 -- President Kennedy and his advisers explored today the prospect of opening talks with the Soviet Union on Berlin and Germany.

GENEVA, July 31 -- The rebel Algerian Provisional Government urged France today to abandon the "myth" of a French Sahara. The Algerians also voiced a readiness to resume their interrupted peace talks with France.

SCHUYLERVILLE, N.Y., July 31 -- Wilbur Hauck, one of the country's top ten rifle builders and custom gunsmiths, is amused at the rumor in the shooting fraternity that he has forsaken firearms for boats.

QUEBEC, July 31 (Canadian Press) -- Mexico clinched its North American Zone Davis Cup Tennis series with Canada today when Mario Llamas beat Francois Bodbout, 6 -- 0, 6 -- 3, 6 -- 1, on the clay courts of the Civil Servants Tennis Club.

HAVANA, July 31 -- The eight prisoners of the Cuban invasion who returned here from the United States today were taken to headquarters of G-2, the political police. It was presumed that after questioning they will then go to Principe Prison, where the lest of the prisoners from the invasion are being held.

Heavy rains accompanied by thunder and lightning hit the metropolitan area during the evening rush hour yesterday. The storm snarled traffic, disrupted subways and knocked out service on the Pennsylvania Railroad's main line to Philadelphia.
OTTAWA, July 31 -- The New party, a political party intended to be an amalgam of farmers and labor dedicated to Socialist principles,' opened its founding convention here today.
SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., July 31 -- The Battle of Saratoga, thoroughbred division, was renewed today under atmospheric conditions close to normal.
AMERICAN influence in Europe is nowhere more evident than in frozen foods. Everything from soup greens to black currant pies now is being converted to the frozen state.

Profits of two of the nation's biggest producers of defense materials -- the Martin Company and the Boeing Company -- showed sizable increases for the first six months of 1961 from the levels of the 1960 period, their semi-annual reports disclosed yesterday.

Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., and associates are offering to the public today $4,000,000 of bonds of the Northwestern Public Service Company. The bonds are due in 1987 and are priced at 102.147 to yield 5.10 per cent. The group bid 100.959. for a 51/2 er cent interest coupon.
The Echo I satellite will be visible over New York, weather permitting, twenty-seven times today through Sunday, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration announced in Washington yesterday.

How many billion-dollar banks are there in the Free World? Quite a few, according to the latest yearly tally made by the American Banker, trade publication. At the start of this year sixty-seven commercial banks could boast of $1,000,000,000 or more in deposits; twenty-three of them in this country.
The Aluminum Company of America, the nation's largest aluminum producer, will put several minor price adjustments into effect today on fabricated aluminum products, including sheet.

OCEANPORT, N.J., July 31 -- With Aqueduct and Delaware Park closed and no competition closer than Saratoga, Monmouth Park drew 23,203 fans today. They saw Sam Boulmetis ride the 2-to-5 favorite, Whippleton, to an two-and-a-half-length victory in the feature, a $25,000 allowance sprint.
LONDON, July 31 -- Prime Minister Macmillan told a tense and at times rowdy House of Commons today that his Government intended to seek negotiations for membership in the European Common Market.

Whether the property owner or the contractor should bear the additional costs if subsurface conditions encountered during construction differ materially from those originally anticipated is a problem that has plagued the construction industry for many years.
MADISON, Wis., July 31 (AP) -- A sit-in began in the Wisconsin Capitol Building today in support of civil rights legislation pending in the state legislature.
