CHICAGO, July 31 -- The Jackson-Green Building, which has housed the national headquarters of the Boy Scouts of America for twenty-two years, was purchased today for $1,000, 000 by Real Properties Corporation of America.

WASHINGTON, July 31 -- The United States and Nationalist China exchanged public assurances of mutual support today. The exchange occurred at the start of an official visit here of Chen Cheng, Vice President and Premier of Nationalist China.

SAIGON, July 31 (AP) -- Communist guerrillas staged a pre-announced hand-grenade incident in Saigon last night to demonstrate their ability to cause trouble in the stronghold of President Ngo Dinh Diem.

TEL AVIV, Israel, July 31 -- The entry of Israel's 1,000,000th immigrant since her establishment as a state was celebrated with special ceremonies tonight. A dinner was given by 400 Jewish leaders from the United States, Canada and Latin America.
American Airlines asked the Civil Aeronautics Board yesterday to let it fly passengers 12 through 21 years of age for half the first-class fare.
The United States Lines' America will cruise Bermuda waters over Thanksgiving for the first time since World War II.
HONG KONG, July 31 -- Peiping's newspapers carried only a brief report today on the draft program of the Soviet Communist party. At the same time, the Communist papers in

WASHINGTON, July 31 -- The first of two final rounds in the masters' mixed team-of-four contest began here tonight in the American Contract Bridge League's national tournament at the Sheraton Park Hotel.

Steel production in the nation dipped 2.2 per cent last week from the preceding week's level, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported. The decline occurred after two weeks in which output had held relatively steady.
Young men and women continued yesterday to respond in sizable numbers to President Kennedy's call for increasing the nation's military strength because of the Berlin situation.
WASHINGTON, July 31 (AP) -- Maurice H. Stans urged restraint in non-defense spending today.
A five-man Buildings Department team yesterday followed up Mayor Wagner's latest slum tour with an intensive inspection of an East Harlem tenement building.
Five-cent transfers will be available today for passengers changing between Fifth Avenue buses and the Fourteenth, Twenty-third and Thirty-fourth Street crosstown lines.
Only 25 per cent of the Negroes in the southern United States who have reached voting age are registered to vote. This figure is increasing, but the rate of growth is painfully slow.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., July 31 -- TWO Nigerian exchange students who were refused lodgings at a motel in southern Illinois on July 11 will be luncheon guests of Gov. Otto Kerner at the Executive Mansion tomorrow.
Police Commissioner Michael J. Murphy yesterday denounced recent attacks upon policemen, some of which have almost developed into riots.

"THE GREAT FORTUNE,"* by Olivia Manning, is a novel about the forlorn, desperate gaiety of Bucharest in the first year of World War II. There the world-lings of a polyglot civilization worked and played to the long roll of the drums of jeopardy.
RIO DE JANEIRO, July 31 -- Ambassador John Moors Cabot will leave his post here within two weeks, the United States Embassy announced today. His transfer has been rumored for some time.

This newspaper devotes eight pages today to the full text of the latest Communist manifesto, the so-called third Soviet program, embodying the basic ideas of Premier Khrushchev. As the Soviet dictator is the most powerful adversary of the free world, and as the first maxim of survival must always be "know thine enemy," this document should be studied by all who value freedom.

To say that the Senator's outspoken comments have turned the relief of human misery into a political football and encouraged disobedience of state and Federal law impresses me as being a distortion of the real picture. On the contrary City Manager Joseph Mitchell's action is directed toward long-recognized inequities in welfare roles.

ATHENS, July 31 -- The Greek Government decided today to recall Michael Papadopoulos, charge d'Affaires in Sofia, Bulgaria, as a protest against what an authoritative source described as "repeated provocations."

WASHINGTON, July 31 (AP) -- Senator Mike Mansfield, the Senate majority leader, said after a meeting of committee chairmen today that it was doubtful the Senate would act this year on a tax revision bill.

The first public offering is being made today of investment participation units of the Nuveen Tax-Exempt Bond Fund, an investment in high-yielding bonds of twenty-six local government bodies in fifteen states.
RIO DE JANEIRO, July 31 (UPI) -- Maj. Yuri A. Gagarin, the Soviet space pioneer, spent ten minutes today with the outspoken anti-Communist Governor of the state of Rio de Janeiro, Carlos Lacerda.
DETROIT, July 31 (AP) -- Production of 1962 model automobiles will begin one week from today.

Commonwealth Edison Company and subsidiaries reported yesterday a 3.1 per cent increase in kilowatt-hour sales in the first half of the year from the 1960 level. Residential sales rose 6.4 per cent, while sales to small commercial and industrial users were up 2.7 per cent.
WASHINGTON, July 31 (AP) -- Senator Stuart Symington, Democrat of Missouri, said today he had been informed that the Soviet Union might soon be able to put an armed satellite into space.

As disclosures of bureaucratic inefficiency and possible corruption in the management of New York City's school building and maintenance program continue, there must inevitably be growing uneasiness about the substance of education in the vast system. If the managers' ability to cope with the relatively simple problems of bricks and mortar is being subjected to serious doubts, their effectiveness and wisdom in matters of instruction and curriculum will legitimately be open to searching questions.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 3 points up to 12 points off yesterday. A point equals 5 cents a bale.
An eight-week school for bowling is being held at Bridge Lanes in Whitestone, Queens, but as yet the beginners haven't rolled at a single pin during class.
WASHINGTON, July 31 (UPI) -- The House Agriculture Committee approved today a two-year, experimental program for renting tobacco acreage allotments.

ALBANY, July 31 -- The State Education Department announced today the plan under which financially hard-pressed school districts will receive a total of $1,200,000 in additional aid in the 1961-62 school year.
More than 750 Democratic election district captains cheered State Controller Arthur Levitt last night as he accused Mayor Wagner of attempting "to stab in the back the organization in which he rose."

LONDON, July 31 -- Britain officially stated today her willingness to negotiate with the Soviet Union on Germany, and Berlin. But the Government's spokesman to the House of Commons said that there could be no question of the Western Allies' right to be in West Berlin and to have free access to that city.

WASHINGTON, July 31 (AP) -- American textile, fiber and apparel industries told the Office of Civil and Defense Mobilization today that textile imports displaced at least 100,000 workers in textile and apparel plants of the United States last year.

Dr. Victor F. Weisskopf of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology takes office today as director general of CERN, the European Organization for Nuclear Research, located near Geneva. He will serve for two years.

No reasonable man, regardless of political affiliations, would question the giving of charity or relief to any truly needy or unfortunate person. This has been a part of the American tradition. However, during the past thirty years the inefficiency of relief administration and the unfortunate desire of certain people to get something for nothing have had a clearly degrading effect on many of the individuals concerned.

Bonds redeemed before maturity in July and the first seven months of 1961 were at their highest totals for the periods in several years. A quarter-billion-dollar refunding of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company's 5 3/8 per cent debentures, due in 1986, made up the greatest part of last month's figure.

BOSTON July 31 -- It seems even the elements are opposed to this business of two all-star baseball games. In San Francisco on July 11, a gale almost blew the wick out of Candlestick Park and made a shambles of that ten-inning, seven-error game, which the Nationals won, 5 -- 4.

CHICAGO, July 30 -- Aided by keen putting and a spectacular recovery from a hazard on the final hole, Jerry Barber of Los Angeles beat Don January of Dallas today in the Professional Golfers Association title play-off.

Gus Hall, general secretary of the Communist party of the United States, said yesterday that the draft program to be submitted to the Soviet Communist party Congress in October was "a challenge to the capitalists to do as much or better for the people."

WASHINGTON, July 31 (UPI) -- Congress sent to President Kennedy today his requested legislation cutting from $500 to $100 the amount of foreign goods an American can bring home from abroad without paying duty.

WASHINGTON, July 31 -- A major example of the perplexities that have beset United States foreign policy since it incurred the burdens which go with the status of a world power is the impasse between France and Tunisia. Among the factors which the Government of the United States must balance in formulating a positive attitude toward the dangerous dispute are these:
The Builders Institute of Westchester and Putnam Counties has begun a program to encourage contractors to build family fall-out shelters.
Television station owners in eight regions prepared yesterday for what will probably be a long battle, marked by legal and political infighting, to retain the channels on which they broadcast.

Confusion over the administration of New Jersey's new tax on commuters apparently has prompted some employers to withhold taxes for both New York and New Jersey from the pay of employes working in one state and living in the ether.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 31 -- The African-Asian group in the United Nations called today for an emergency special session of the General Assembly to meet Thursday on the dispute between France and Tunisia.
WASHINGTON, July 31 -- A resounding 403-to-2 vote of approval in the House completed today Congressional action to empower President Kennedy to call 250,000 reservists to active duty.
WASHINGTON, July 31 -- Treasury bill rates rose again on today's sale of new issues, but were still well within the range that has held for the last two months.
Shares on the New York Stock Exchange staged a sharp rally late last month to close with a small gain in prices over the level at the end of June.
WASHINGTON, July 31 -- President Kennedy appointed Philleo Nash today to be the Commissioner of Indian Affairs.

Another national agency, the National Tuberculosis Association, yesterday criticized a report on voluntary health and welfare agencies. The report, published by a citizens committee this week, was criticized Sunday by the National Foundation.

EDGARTOWN, Mass., July 31 -- Chandler Hovey's Easterner overcame a solid lead by Henry D. Mercer's Weatherly and went on to win the fourth race for 12-Meter yachts on the New York Yacht Club cruise today. Between them at the end was Paul Shields' Columbia, close astern of Easterner.
Borough President John T. Clancy of Queens yesterday urged a "better break to property owners" by moving up the effective date of the proposal to eliminate local assessments for streets and sewers.

Bobby Fischer of Brooklyn, holding a favorable position, is expected to win from Samuel Reshevsky of Spring Valley, N. Y., when the adjourned fifth game of their sixteen-game chess series is resumed in Los Angeles.

The business recovery has brought a marked improvement in corporate profits from the depressed levels of early this year, the First National City Bank of New York reported today in its monthly bank letter.
WESTBURY, L.I., July 31 -- Eddie Cobb never flicked his whip as Adios Butler romped to victory in the $25,000 Pace of the Century at Roosevelt Raceway tonight.
BERLIN, July 31 -- The date of Aug. 1 is another "scare day" on Berlin's calendar because, theoretically, a new air control system goes into effect tomorrow over all East Germany.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., July 31 -- Otto Preminger, who could, if he wished, have spent this day gloating about an unprecedented victory over movie censorship, was, instead, planning another movie that is likely to be as controversial as most of his films in recent years.

The city of Yorktown Heights has again been saved from the ominous presence of 100 small boys under 12, who for three years now have threatened to endanger Yorktown residents' -- and, what is more, their property values -- by moving into that Westchester community.
State Controller Arthur Levitt challenged Mayor Wagner yesterday to repeat under oath to a grand jury his charges of a judgeship deal.

BERLIN, Tuesday, Aug. 1 Communist East Germany moved today to restrict travel between its territory and West Germany with a contention that West German tourists were spreading poliomyelitis beyond the Iron Curtain.

Irvington House, a treatment and research center for children with rheumatic fever and rheumatic heart disease, will be the beneficiary of the eighth annual Famous Designers and Artists Auction. It will take place in the Parke-Bernet Galleries at 980 Madison Avenue on Nov. 21.

Allan Haymes, real estate developer, has signed a contract to buy the one-story building at 1017 Madison Avenue and the five-story building at 1019 Madison Avenue, between Seventy-eighth and Seventy-ninth Streets.

MIAMI, July 31 -- Eight prisoners of Cuba who had sought unsuccessfully to arrange a ransom deal here for the release of nearly 1,200 other prisoners left for Havana this morning. They were accompanied by three Cuban exiles who still hope for the return to the United States of the prisoners, captured in the ill-fated rebel invasion of Cuba last April.
WASHINGTON, July 31 -- The Kennedy Administration this week will make its biggest reduction to date in the backlog of Federal Judicial appointments.
The emergency program undertaken by the Board of Education to put the city's schools in good repair by September is now going forward in 424 schools, it was reported by the board yesterday.

LONDON, July 31 -- Trading was quiet in the stock market here today pending Prime Minister Harold Macmillan's statement on Britain's applying to join the European Common Market, which came after the market closed.

MOBILE, Ala., July 31 (AP) -- Waterman Steamship Corporation of Mobile said today that a $13,000,000 refinancing plan is being completed to permit the steamship line to divorce itself from McLean Industries, Inc.
VALLEY STREAM, L.I., July 31 -- Three armed men forced a bank messenger into a car here today, tied him up, pushed him out a few minutes later and rode off with a deposit bag he had been carrying.

Where, I wonder, did The Time: receive the authority to act as prosecuting attorney, judge and jury to unilaterally brand Newburgh as following "an outlaw course"? Have the courts ruled that Newburgh is an outlaw? Have the courts upheld the laws you say Newburg flouts ?

COLD SPRING, L.I., July 31 -- A birdie 4 on the first hole helped Joe Maresco and Richard Schlanger of Woodmere win the pro-junior tournament of the Long Island Professional Golfers Association today. They had a score of 32, 31 -- 63 at the Cold Spring Country Club.

WASHINGTON, July 31 (AP) -- W. Walton Butterworth, United States envoy to the European communities -- the atomic, common market and coal and steel groupings of nations -- was nominated by President Kennedy today for promotion to Ambassador.
An electric typewriter that eliminates type bars and movable carriages and that can use six interchangeable type faces was introduced by the International Business Machines Corporation yesterday.

WESTPORT, Conn., July 31 -- The Army has been asked to stop raising a lift bridge here on weekday mornings because commuters pile up in angry groups and miss their trains while small boats cruise slowly out to sea.

POLISH painting has now been processed by the Museum of Modern Art and the results are displayed in an exhibition opening today. The Poles have come out looking a bit less like everyone else than one might have expected, since the selection is made from the museum's familiar international code of standards, which is somewhat restrictive.
CHICAGO, July 31 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
PARIS, July 31 (AP) -- The Bank of Brazil received loans today aggregating $110,000,000 from a group of European banks to refund and stabilize the country's European debts.
The international diplomatic flavor of the word "summit" received an embodiment in reinforced concrete yesterday with the opening of the Summit Hotel.
MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, July 31 -- The Latin American Free Trade Association elected today Romulo de Almeida of Brazil as executive secretary of its permanent organization.

HUBERT de GIVENCHY, the tall French couturier who looks like an American basketball player, likes to shop in the United States. But since Paris is his home and the place where he can work best, Givenchy relies on his American friends to supply him with American filtered cigarettes, American bath towels (in Kabuki colors) and blue shirts from Sears, Roebuck.

LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, July 31 (Reuters) -- Lieut. Gen. Joseph Mobutu, Congolese Army commander, was turned back by a border guard shortly after he arrived in the former French Congo tonight on a conciliation mission.
PARIS, July 31 -- Hubert de Givenchy has spoken and has left the buyers shouting "Divine, divine."

LONDON, July 31 (UPI) -- Stockholders of British Drug Houses, Ltd. (B.D.H.), today voted to accept 5,000,000 ($14,000,000) from the American concern, Mead Johnson Co., in return for a 35 per cent interest in the English drug company.
RICHMOND, Va., July 31 (AP) -- The state's Pupil Placement Board approved the applications of thirty-two Negroes today for transfer to white or predominantly white public schools in Norfolk.

WASHINGTON, July 31 (AP) -- "Private insurance simply has not met the need," Gov. David L. Lawrence of Pennslyvania said today as he testified for President Kennedy's health-care plan for the elderly.

It is with great pleasure that write you in behalf of the wonderful and dedicated service you are performing in regard to the Newburgh public welfare situation. Your editorial of July 20 deserves plaudits from all persons who are interested in knowing the facts in this situation.
The business of communication is so challenging, so filled with variety, and so important that it seems strange young men (and women, too) often have to be persuaded to enter it.
THE invasion of Cuba last April, it is now clear, was lost in Washington.
WASHINGTON, July 31 (UPI) -- The Senate approved President Kennedy's program tonight to accelerate the space program. It calls for sending a man on a round trip to the moon within a decade.

WARSAW, July 31 -- Sport in Poland is a bulky governmental machine with the Glowny Komitet Kultury Fizycnej i Turystyki (the Main Committee for Physical Culture and Tourism) on top and the individual sports federations on the bottom.
BONN, Germany, July 31 (AP) -- West Germany's economic boom continued in full force during June but there are signs of levelling off, an Economics Ministry report said today.

MOSCOW, July 31 -- The Soviet Union emphasized today the military preparedness aspects of the new draft program of the Communist party. The emphasis was a warning to those in the West who were depicted as spurring the arms race.
The 65-year-old American Weekly was the nation's first Sunday newspaper supplement and, until recent years, held a position of complete predominance in the Sunday supplement field.

THERE is a meeting place for East and West at the Penthouse Gallery, 15 West Fifty-fifth Street. The small shop that for the last ten years has been known for clothes from the Far East has just introduced a collection made in the Far West state of Hawaii.
The election of William J. Kenney, Joseph B. Koechel and W. Kennedy B. Middendorf as vice presidents has been announced by the Bank of New York.

As a soldier expecting to be released this October from active service I read with interest your July 20 editorial criticizing Barry Goldwater for "encouraging local disobedience of state and Federal law."
Philadelphia regained last year the top position among the nation's ports handling foreign waterborne trade, the Chamber of Commerce of Greater Philadelphia reported yesterday.

KINGS POINT, L.I., July 31 -- Clarence D. Martin Jr., Under Secretary of Commerce for Transportation, said here today that the Soviet Union was using slapping as a long-range weapon in the "cold war."
AMITYVILLE, L.I., July 31 -- Dave Beebe's Duchess led the Jet-14 Class as the Great South Bay Yacht Racing Association Cruise Week began off here today.
Five shots were fired last evening as a youth gang "rumble'' began in an East Harlem playground.
Prices of high-grade bonds fluctuated within narrow limits in an inactive trading session yesterday.
OMAHA, Neb., July 31 (AP) -- Secretary of Labor Arthur J. Goldberg issued a warning today about the voluntary no-strike, no-lockout pledge in effect at missile and space bases.
WASHINGTON, July 31 (AP) -- A researcher scoffed today at a report of evidence linking the Union Secretary of War, Edwin M. Stanton, with the assassination of Abraham Lincoln.
MIAMI, July 31 -- The United States today ended direct payments to members of the Cuban expeditionary force who were not captured in the repulsed invasion of April 17.

ALBANY, July 31 -- Dr. James E. Allen Jr., the state Education Commissioner, put it up to the New York City Board of Education today to act on the boat-building incident involving Dr. John J. Theobald, the Superintendent of Schools.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., July 31 (AP) -- Three ranking United States players -- Ron Holmberg, Whitney Reed and Ramsey Earnhart -- today won opening-round matches in the seventy-third Meadow Club invitation tennis tournament.
Julie Harris has agreed to star in "The Naked Truth," the Harry Kurnitz version of Marcel Achard's Parisian success. However, contracts have not been signed yet.

All world sugar positions fell to new lows for the lives of the contracts yesterday on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange. The market closed at or near the lows of the day, with prices off 5 to 8 points (hundredths of a cent a pound), on sales of 6,450 tons.
The highly controversial proposal to widen most of Fulton Street between Broadway and South Street was shelved by the Board of Estimate yesterday until Sept. 22.
The United States Military Academy at West Point announced yesterday a new program and permanent organization for the contributing of private funds to the academy.

MOSCOW, July 30 -- Following is the text of the draft program of the Soviet Communist party, to be presented to its Twenty-second Congress in October, as translated into English by Tass, the official Soviet press agency:

BROOKVILLE, L.I., July 31 -- Carol Beinbrink, a 6-handicap player from Southward Ho, scored a 36, 38 -- 74 and won the medal in the sixth annual Women's Cross Country Golf Association tournament today at Brookville Country Club.

LONDON, July 31 -- In October, 1959, a British writer noted that there were two schools of thought about the Right Honorable Edward Richard George Heath. One, the writer said, put him down to the lowly level of a reliable private secretary; the other pictured him as a fu ture Conservative Prime Minister.
WASHINGTON, July 31 (AP) -- Two key appointments were announced today in a reorganization of the headquarters staff at the Republican National Committee. Others are expected.
Premier Khrushchev's new draft party program heralds the end of the classic "dictatorship of the proletariat" and proposes a more democratic system in both government and party.

A biography of the late Ernest Hemingway by his younger brother, Leicester, is planned for January publication by World. The author, who is himself a magazine writer and novelist, has spent three years in writing the book.
TUNIS, July 31 -- Tunisia moved today toward developing diplomatic support in the Bizerte crisis from the Soviet Union and African nations.
Two special television shows starring Harry Belafonte, the singer, have been canceled. One was to be presented next fall and the other in the spring over the Columbia Broadcasting System network.

HARRISON, N.Y., July 31 -- Christopher Siegler of Knollwood shot 40, 39 -- 79 today for the Westchester District medal in the 15-to-17-year-old class of the New York State junior golf qualifying round at Harrison Country Club.

The Small Business Administration issued a progress report yesterday for the first six months of this year. John E. Horne, administrator, said that "without exception the aid given small firms through each major S.B.A. program was greater in the January-June period than in any comparable period since the start of the agency."

City investigators were told yesterday that local inspectors of the Federal Housing Administration had approved construction at a Queens apartment project. Later, however, a national F.H.A. check found a number of tenant complaints to be justified, the investigators were told.
Staten Island commuters had their schedules disrupted early yesterday when 150 Transit Authority drivers instituted a "safety campaign" and refused to take their buses on the road.
GENEVA, July 31 -- The fourteen-nation conference on Laos bypassed today the question of the withdrawal of foreign troops from the kingdom.
The Welfare Department has assembled a special task force for a new assault against poverty.
EDISON TOWNSHIP, N.J. July 31 (AP) -- Arson complaints were filed today against two Brooklyn men injured during a fire and explosion that destroyed Keefe Brasselle's night club Friday.
NICOSIA, Cyprus, July 31 -- Chester Bowles said today that the United States was trying to edge away from the policy of massive retaliation.

PARIS, July 31 -- Adlai E. Stevenson, United States representative at the United Nations, disclosed today that he had been engaged in efforts to promote direct French-Tunisian negotiations on the Bizerte dispute.
K.L.M. Royal Dutch Airlines denied yesterday, in an answer filed with the Civil Aeronautics Board, that it had violated the Netherlands-United States bilateral air agreement.
SEA CLIFF, L.I., July 31 -- The defender, Lynn Cunningham of the Pequot Y. C., Southport, Conn., won today's only qualifying race for the junior girls sailing championship of Long Island Sound.

PARIS, July 31 -- Adlai E. Stevenson, United States representative at the United Nations, disclosed today that he had been engaged in efforts to promote direct French-Tunisian negotiations on the Bizerte dispute.
HAYSI, Va., July 31 (UPI) -- Residents of this small southwestern Virginia mountain town began mopping up late today in the wake of a flash flood that struck before dawn, causing heavy damage.
WASHINGTON, July 31 (AP) -- The House of Representatives passed a bill today to permit the sale of Government-owned feed to farmers in disaster areas at 75 per cent of the price-support level.

WASHINGTON, July 31 (UPI) -- The Department of Agriculture estimated today that cotton consumption in the United States and exports during the 1961-62 marketing year would be 14,500,000 bales, slightly less than in 1960-61.

CHICAGO, July 31 (AP) -- The week-end weather appeared to be the major factor in grain futures transactions on the Board of Trade today. It exerted a mildly bullish influence in wheat and a generally bearish pressure elsewhere.
NICOSIA, Cyprus, July 31 -- Chester Bowles said today that the United States was trying to edge away from the policy of massive retaliation.
LONDON, Aug. 1 -- The number of serious crimes per head of population has more than doubled in London since World War II began in 1939.

Everton of the English League's First Division admitted professionals will face Dukla of Czechoslovakia tonight in the opening contest of the two-game total-goal series for the American Challenge Cup at the Polo Grounds.

YONKERS, Aug. 1 -- Action, camera, lights and 28,035 fans returned to Yonkers Raceway tonight for the start of the fall meeting. The customers appeared to have made the switch from Roosevelt Raceway at Westbury, L.I., to this Westchester County harness racing plant without missing a bet.
GENEVA, Aug. 1 -- The Communist powers at the fourteen-nation conference on Laos here made a determined bid today to oust French military instructors from Laos.

OCEANPORT, N.J., Aug. 1 -- Ogden Phipps' Hitting Away, winner of the Dwyer Stakes at Aqueduct in his last start on July 15, is the top-weighted 3-1 favorite among the fourteen 3-year-olds named for tomorrow's $60,100 Choice Stakes at Monmouth Park. He will carry 126 pounds.
MOSCOW, Aug. 1 -- The Berlin issue and the prospect of a Communist society seemed remote today on a hot day in Moscow.

Twice this month The Times has given its editorial support to the myth, fostered and fabricated by the New Haven Railroad management for over a decade, that the railroad's commuter service is maintained at tremendous sacrifice in the shape of huge deficits.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Aug. 1 (AP) -- Admiral George W. Anderson took command today of a United States naval establishment described by his predecessor as ready for the challenges of peace or war.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange started the new crop season yesterday by advancing 9 to 17 points (45 to 85 cents a bale).

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 1 (AP) -- Home runs by Charlie Smith, Johnny Callison and Pancho Herrera led the Philadelphia Phillies to a 9-1 victory over the Minnesota Twins in the Philadelphia Junior Baseball Federation exhibition game today.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 -- The White House announced today the appointment of James J. Rowley, who has helped guard Presidents since 1939, as chief of the United States Secret Service.

PARIS, Aug. 1 -- At least half million Frenchmen were on the move today. They headed for places where the food would be intriguing, the wine satisfying, the atmosphere pleasing and the talk about something other than plastic bombs and Berlin.
The operators of three Greenwich Village coffeehouses that provided entertainment were convicted yesterday of failing to obtain cabaret licenses.

Ty Cobb, the first to enter, Baseball's Hall of Fame, completed his autobiography several months before he died on July 17. Written in collaboration with Al Stump, the book is called "My Life in Baseball -- The True Record."
Amid the popping of champagne bottles and a noisy clang of nostalgia, the double-decker bus returned to Manhattan yesterday.

The city yesterday began receiving applications for accommodations at its first home for the ambulatory aged. The institution, the Neponsit Home for the Aged, Rockaway Beach Boulevard and Beach 149th Street, Neponsit, Queens, will open later this month.
Stan Musial of the St. Louis Cardinals and eleven other outstanding athletes were the guests of honor yesterday as Sport Magazine celebrated its fifteenth year of publishing.
BONN, Germany, Aug. 1 -- The Government said today that there was no polio epidemic in West Germany.

An issue of $6,885,000 of equipment trust certificates of the Northern Pacific Railway is being offered to the public today by Salomon Brothers Hutzler and associates. It is priced to yield from 3.40 per cent for the Aug. 23 1962, maturities to 4.45 per cent for the certificates falling due on Aug. 23, 1976.
THE anonymous hotel rooms that African delegates to the United Nations called home when they first arrived here last fall are almost a thing of the past.
The ten-team American League, aided by the new Minesota and Los Angeles teams, is nearing its season record for home runs. The mark probably will fall next week.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 -- The Pentagon advised sixty-four Air National Guard and seven Air Force Reserve units throughout the country today to be ready for a call to active duty.
THE military measures begun this week to prepare for the Berlin crisis may eventually increase the Army's permanent strength to sixteen divisions, an addition of two divisions.
The nation's output of passenger automobiles in July dropped below the level of a month before and of July, 1960, it was announced yesterday.

BABYLON, L.I., Aug. 1 -- Only five skippers managed to score repeat victories today in the Cruise Week championships of the Great South Bay Yacht Racing Association. The winners in the fifteen other classes came from among yesterday's also-rans.

When a man dedicates his life to the cause of education, as his father did before him, and has had a long and distinguished career, it is a sorry thing that his name reaches the headlines only in connection with the building of a small seagoing craft.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 -- The Kennedy Administration got set today for a campaign to enact foreign aid legislation substantially as it has cleared committee hurdles.
MANCHESTER, England, Aug. 1 -- (Reuters) -- Australia today won the fourth test match against England and retained the "ashes" -- an honor symbolic of Australian-English cricket supremacy.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 (AP) -- The Senate Commerce Committee approved today the nomination of Lawrence J. O'Connor Jr. of Houston, Tex., to the Federal Power Commission.

MORE than 2,000 authentic Shaker items will be auctioned on Saturday at New Lebanon, N.Y. Furniture, tools, stoves, crockery, baskets and books, all from a Shaker settlement founded in 1786, will be included.

Dividend action is beginning to catch up with corporate optimism. This was indicated yesterday when the Standard Poor's Corporation reported that the number of dividend increases in July came closer to equaling the year-earlier figure than in any previous month this year.

Premier Khrushchev's new party program constitutes the most radical revision of Marxist doctrine since the early days of Bolshevism, in the opinion of specialists on Soviet affairs. Not since the years when Lenin was experimenting in the application of Marx's theories to the new Russian revolutionary state have so many dialectical chips been splintered off the Communist monolith.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 (AP) -- The House voted today to prevent the Federal Aviation Agency from operating the former Air Force base at Mitchel Field, L.I., as a general aviation airport. The bill now goes to the Senate.

A study of voluntary health and welfare agencies released here this week by a citizen's committee was approved yesterday by a spokesman for organized labor. He agreed with the report in substance, but added that it did not go far enough.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 -- The Government is starting a new campaign to have banks keep separate duplicate records that will be available if their originals are destroyed in war. Fewer than half of the nation's 13,400 banks keep such records now, but those that do hold about 60 per cent of the nation's bank deposits.
NICOSIA, Cyprus, Aug. 1 -- United States Ambassadors to North Africa and the Middle East were urged at a meeting here today to be frank about the problems of their homeland.

NEWARK, Aug. 1 -- A fireman paused a few minutes today at a four-alarm blaze to tackle and capture a robbery suspect. He dodged three bullets in the process. Then he returned to his pumper assignment to help bring the fire under control.
The number of persons injured by automobiles here decreased last week compared with the same period a year ago, the police safety bureau reported yesterday.

VANCOUVER, B.C., Aug. 1 -- The Social Credit Government of British Columbia today announced that it planned to take over of the billion-dollar British Columbia Electric Company in a specially-called session of Parliament in Victoria.
MIAMI, Fla., Aug. 1 -- Cuban refugees are voluntarily repaying United States relief funds at the rate of $2,500 a week.

The Goodyear Tire Rubber Company increased its earnings in the quarter and six months ended on June 30 from the year-ago levels despite lower sales, the semi-annual report of E.J. Thomas, chairman, disclosed yesterday.

FORT WAYNE, Ind., Aug, 1 (UPI) -- The Magnavox Company said today that it had received more than $40,000,000 in military electronics contracts within the last ninety days. The contracts included an initial order for a new radar guidance system for missile control, one for communication systems to be installed in satellites and one for $20,000,000 for submarine detection equipment.

The Bowla Bowla recreation center, a one-story building at 450 South Washington Avenue, Bergenfield, N.J., has been sold by Morrissey Associates, a Bergen County building and realty investment company. It was bought for investment by Goodman, Guidera Solow of Englewood. J.I. Kislak, Inc., was the broker.

HE is aloof and inaccessible, this Mount Everest of haute couture. Inevitably, his name is introduced into the conversation of buyers, reporters, store executives and private customers and, just as inevitably, it is pronounced in tones that are both hushed and reverent.
IF there were thirty handsome young musicians by the name of Van Cliburn, there might be some heavy gunfire along musical thoroughfares, but at least Lewisohn Stadium might be saved.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 -- The Administration's fall-out shelter plan could save at least ten to fifteen million lives in case of a nuclear attack, Defense Secretary Robert S. McNamara said today.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 -- State Department officials are hopeful that France and Tunisia may soon agree on a formula designed to break the stalemate over Bizerte.

MOSCOW, Aug. 1 (UPI) -- Premier Khrushchev said today that nothing could stop the Communists from attaining their goals. He warned "lovers of military adventures" to remember that the Soviet Union possessed powerful weapons.
BENNINGTON, Vt., Aug. 1 -- A bizarre diversion to which trout fishermen are pitifully susceptible is the curious pastime known as beaver-pone fishing.

HONG KONG, Aug. 1 -- The Chinese Communist Army is ready to "liberate" Taiwan and cope with "any aggressive war that United States imperialism might launch," Gen. Lo Juiching, army chief of staff, declared in Peiping tonight.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 1 -- The Soviet Union has accused the United Nations Secretariat of failing to obey Security Council orders to insure the personal safety of members and freedom of action the Congolese Parliament.
Edward Powis Jones is to be commended for his June 17 letter on saving the approaches to Manhattan Bridge. The south entrance to the Bronx Zoo would prove an excellent site for them.
CARSON CITY, Nev., Aug. 1 (UPI) -- A complaint charging Gov. Grant Sawyer and two other state officials with violating Nevada's open meeting law was dismissed today.
Mayor Wagner appealed yesterday to both sides in the strike of 1,200 concrete mix drivers to hold "realistic negotiations" to settle their month-long deadlock.

The American Civil Liberties Union complained yesterday that the proposed new foreign aid program in Congress included a "weaker formulation" against racial and religious discrimination than the current act.
MOSCOW, Aug. 1 -- The thirty-second international fur auction ended today in Leningrad, Tass, the Soviet press agency, reported. A record 203 foreign buyers and representatives attended.
A lawyer who owns three tenements on East Ninety-eighth Street may face perjury charges as a result of testimony he gave yesterday in Housing Court.

CHICAGO, Aug. 1 (AP) -- Soybean futures were under steady to moderately heavy selling pressure again today on the Board of Trade and lost more than a cent a bushel on all contracts, with the September delivery off 3 cents.

France is about to lift the export ban from "Les Liaisons Dangereuses," the controversial modern film adaptation of the classic eighteenth-century novel, which has proved the greatest French box-office success since 1954.

Recent news accounts and editorials in The Times recommending that bar associations be given more power in the selection of judicial candidates have excellent intent but, to paraphrase the poison bottles, should be marked "for restricted use only."

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 1 -- Arriving here from the Merion Cricket Club, where he won the Pennsylvania lawn tennis championship yesterday, Jon Douglas began his quest for the Southampton Bowl at the Meadow Club today.

BASEBALL'S bizarre all-star interlude, which this year spread itself over three weeks and across 3,000 miles, is finally out of the way. So far as most of the critics are concerned, it could well have vanished much sooner. At least, all can settle down to the more serious business at hand, with the resumption of two torrid pennant races and the Mantle-Maris home-run duel.
PARIS, Aug. 1 -- The six governments of the European Common Market, through their foreign ministers, accepted today early negotiations on Britain's application for membership in their club.

Land parcels at 37-23, 37-27, 17-21, 21-35 and 37-39 Seventy-third Street, Jackson Heights, queens, have been sold by Beacon Apartments, Inc. The property, which contains a row of private homes, includes a plot of 240 by 100 feet.

The normally sedate political scene in Canada has had a dramatic interruption. A new party (in fact, its name is the New party) is holding its founding convention in Ottawa with every indication that it will play an important role.

The new program of United States aid worked out for South Vietnam by Vietnamese officials and an American group under Dr. Eugene Staley should strengthen the embattled state appreciably in its fight against Communist subversion.
The $2,000,000 Smith-Corona Merchant, Inc., account has been awarded to Batten, Barton, Durstine Osborn, Inc. The typewriter company formerly had been handled by Cunningham Walsh, Inc.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 1 -- The chairman of the Pennsylvania Power and Light Company testified today that Philadelphia's largest banks were too small to lend his company the money it might need in a hurry.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 -- A forty-member delegation led by Secretary of the Treasury Douglas Dillon will represent the United States at the inter-American Alliance for Progress conference opening Saturday in Uruguay.
The Interstate Commerce Commission approved yesterday the three trustees selected by Federal Judge Robert P. Anderson of New Haven to run the bankrupt New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad.

The Government's efforts to collect the income taxes of American citizens residing outside the United States has been "greatly strengthened" by a decision of Federal Judge Edward J. Dimock, United States Attorney Henry M. Morgenthau reported yesterday.

All domestic sugar futures dropped to new lows for the lives of the contracts yesterday on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange. The decline was influenced by the reallocation of the 476,000-ton Puerto Rican and Hawaiian deficit.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 (UPI) -- The Senate rejected by 67 to 22 today an attempt by Senator William Proxmire to cut $297,000,000 from a $5,200,000,000 bill to finance the Government's health, welfare and labor activities.

ROOSEVELT, L.I., Aug 1 -- The junior high school here has been selected to participate in a trial program to plant the desire for college education in intelligent but "culturally deprived" youngsters.

TUNIS, Aug. 1 -- Bahi Ladgham, the number two man in the Tunisian Government, left here today for Washington. Mr. Ladgham's trip marks the Tunisian Government's drive for a world-wide diplomatic offensive against France in the Bizerte crisis.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 (AP) -- The personnel director of the National Security Agency has been questioned by a House committee about discrepancies in his personal history statements filed with the agency
A relatively new method of resurfacing streets to make repairs speedier and cheaper was recommended yesterday as "well worth study" by city agencies.
The music of Victor Herbert and George M. Cohan resounded in Broadway's most southern canyon at noon yesterday as the Downtown Manhattan Concert Band moved into Bowling Green from Batterry Park.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 (AP) -- The Justice Department announced today the indictment of two election officials and fourteen poll workers in Telfair County, Ga. They are accused of casting and counting fraudulent ballots in last November's Presidential election.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 1 -- Barbara Benigni of San Francisco defeated Justina Bricka, St. Louis, 8 -- 6, 6 -- 0, today in the second round of the Philadelphia and district women's grass-court tennis championship at the Germantown Cricket Club.

LONDON, Aug. 1 -- Prime Minister Macmillan said today that there would probably be a meeting of Western heads of government to discuss European problems. He was replying to a questioner in the House of Commons.

PARIS, Aug. 1 -- Store buyers, famous for sitting on their hands at fashion shows, really let go this morning and gave Balenciaga a boisterous ovation. After the show was over, glowing comments erupted like machine-gun fire.
BOSTON, Aug. 1 (UPI) -- The player representatives of the major league baseball clubs came out today in favor of continuing with two all-star games every season.

MILWAUKEE, Aug. 1 (AP) -- The world's two largest manufacturers of optical equipment, a parent association of one and individual executives of each were indicted by a Federal grand jury today on charges of conspiring to fix prices and reduce competition.

EDGARTOWN, Mass., Aug. 1 -- Four skippers engaged on the New York Yacht Club cruise ended at the wrong end of race committee decisions today after protest hearings involving breaches of the sailing rules.

SURELY it is a fine thing to have written a good book or even a good short story. How many writers labor industriously all their lives and never accomplish as much! But it is certainly a far more impressive achievement to write many good books and stories. Productivity is an important point in judging the stature of an artist.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 (AP) -- A physician accused the American Medical Association today of issuing "shockingly misleading" material against President Kennedy's health program for the aged.

" Angel, Angel, Down We Go" has been acquired for production this season by Theatrical Interests Plan, an investment-producing group. Although the organization has participated in various enterprises, the new venture will be the first to be done here entirely by T.I.P.

Defense Minister Franz Josef Strauss of West Germany said yesterday he believed a solution for the Berlin crisis "can be worked out" if the Soviet Union was convinced that the United States would go to war if necessary to protect Allied rights in the city.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 (AP) -- A Senate committee voted today for a 150,000-man Youth Conservation Corps. The panel also approved education benefits for servicemen discharged since Jan. 31, 1955.
MOUNTAIN HOME, Idaho, Aug. 1 (AP) -- All officers of the armed forces should be taught labor-management relations to help preserve peace at military installations, Arthur J. Goldberg said today.
OTTAWA, Aug. 1 -- Louis Rasminsky, new governor of the Bank of Canada, suggested today that the Government be given full control over monetary policy.

Gerald L. Phillippe was elected seventh president of the General Electric Company yesterday. Mr. Phillippe was promoted from controller and principal financial officer of the giant company to succeed Ralph J. Cordiner, who continues as chairman and chief executive officer.
DETROIT, Aug. 1 -- The General Motors Corporation notified the International Union of Electrical Workers today that their labor agreement would end at midnight Sept. 1.

Aeronca Manufacturing Corporation, Middletown, Ohio, has filed a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission covering the acquisition of Flight Refuelling, Inc., Baltimore, Md., maker of fueling systems for aircraft and ships.
The New York County Democratic organization, which is headed by Carmine G. De Sapio, has denied redesignation to four of the party's five members of the City Council from Manhattan.
MOSCOW, July 25 -- The two Russians looked at the abstract painting done by a United States artist and argued.
After dawdling along most of the day, the stock market abruptly came to life yesterday afternoon and swept ahead to new highs in excited trading.
COTONOU, Dahomey, Aug. 1 (UPI) -- The West African state of Dahomey seized the tiny Portuguese enclave of Ajuda today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 -- Two days of discussions between President Kennedy and Premier Chen Cheng of Nationalist China have disclosed Taiwan's firm intention to veto the admission of Outer Mongolia to the United Nations.

The Brunswick Corporation, manufacturer of bowling equipment, is expanding into the outboard motor boat field, through the purchase of the Kiekhaefer Corporation of Fond du Lac, Wis. The merger agreement involving some $34,000,000 in Brunswick common stock was announced jointly yesterday by B.E. Bensinger, president of Brunswick, and E.C. Kiekhaefer, founder and president of the builder of Mercury outboard motors.

PASADENA, Calif., Aug. 1 (AP) -- Carla Glasgow, from near-by Whittier, upset the national amateur champion, Jon Anne Gunderson of Seattle, 1 up, today in the first round of the women's western golf championship.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 -- The marble rotunda of the Senate Office Building served briefly today as a stage for an internationalism session.
The consolidated net income of Texaco, Inc., in the first six months of this year was $198,726,264, or $3.22 a share on the 61,774,186 shares outstanding at the end of the period.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 (AP) -- The National Labor Relations Board ruled today that it was an unfair labor practice to award extra seniority to workers who replace strikers or to strikers who return to work during a strike.
NEWARK, Aug. 1 -- The city's $5,600,000 underground garage in Military Park accommodating 1,030 cars was dedicated today. It is New Jersey's first underground parking garage.
WHITTIER, Alaska, Aug. 1 (AP) -- A multimillion-dollar Army facility, which includes a "city under a roof," is up for lease.
The Hamilton-Wenham Regional School District, Mass., borrowed $2,085,000 in the bond market yesterday to finance school construction.
The Ford Motor Company reported yesterday a modest rise in earnings and sales for the second quarter of 1961 from the levels of the 1960 period.
RIO DE JANEIRO, July 31 -- President Janio Quadros completed six months in office today with his reform Government counting its successes and holding the political initiative in Brazil.
Luis A. Oviedo, Dominican diplomat and legislator, took up yesterday his new post as head of the Dominican Consulate General in New York.

MINEOLA, L.I., Aug. 1 -- The Nassau County Board of Assessors announced today that the total assessed valuation for the county's 57 school districts for the 1961-62 school year would be a record $2,821,323,501, but that the percentage of increase was the lowest in fifteen years.
The Board of Elections yesterday revised one primary election ruling that Mayor Wagfier had charged was designed by the "party bosses" to hamstring his candidacy.
Mayor Wagner shifted his attack yesterday from state Controller Arthur Levitt, his opponent in the Democratic primary, to Carmine G. De Sapio, the leader of Tammany.
The Canadian National Railway's operating expenses in June were $9,949,000 more than the road's operating revenues.
The Legal Aid Society will benefit from two theatre parties in the autumn. One will be to the Oct. 31 performance of "Sail Away," and the other to "The Complaisant Lover" on Dec. 11.
TORONTO, Aug. 1 (Canadian Press) -- Falconbridge Nickel Mines, Ltd. and Ventures, Ltd., two of Canada's largest and wealthiest nickel mining companies have announced plans for a merger.

A sweeping reversal of its tight amateur rules for competition was voted by the Sports Car Club of America's Board of Governors at a special meeting at the Drake Hotel in Chicago last Saturday and Sunday.

Leading sales finance companies reduced by one-eighth percentage point yesterday the rate on one maturity of their short-term unsecured obligations sold directly to investors. The new rate on the thirty-to-fifty-nine day maturity, effective immediately, is 2 per cent.
The New York Air National Guard began taking steps yesterday to bring itself up to full strength.

The Board of Education was called into special session yesterday to hear a report from Assistant District Attorney Aaron E. Koota of Brooklyn on the boat-building incident involving Dr. John J. Theobald, the Superintendent of Schools.
BOONTON, N.J., Aug. 1 -- A New Jersey team of amateur golfers won the Stoddard Cup intersectional matches today at the Knoll Golf Club by one of the widest margins in the history of the event.

A new nylon casting process that is said to permit, for the first time, low-cost production of massive nylon plastic shapes for heavy industrial use, was introduced yesterday by the Polymer Corporation.
Borough championships in the twentieth annual harvest dance contest of the city Park Department wilt be held next week, weather permitting. All will start at 8:30 P.M.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 -- For fifteen years, James Joseph Rowley's job has demanded that he walk with Presidents, see all and yet stay inconspicuous. How well Mr. Rowley succeeded is evident in his promotion today from chief of the White House detail to chief of the United States Secret Service.

President Kennedy has never left any room for doubt that he considers Federal aid to the public schools a matter of the highest national priority. In his special message to Congress last February he warned that "our progress as a nation can be no swifter than our progress in education," and he made it clear that Federal aid for public school construction and teachers' salaries is essential to such progress.
LONDON, Aug. 1 -- Prime Minister Macmillan's decision to seek negotiations for membership in the European Common Market was given wide public support today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 (AP) -- Representative John E. Moss, Democrat of California, chairman of the House Government Information subcommittee called on the White House today to reverse instructions he said cultivated a "restrictive attude" on news.
BERLIN, Aug. 1 -- An additional 1,322 East Germans fled to West Berlin in the twenty-four-hour period ending at 4 P.M. today despite a control system that made their escaping seem incredible.
CREVE COEUR, Ill., Aug. 1 (UPI) -- Deadly ammonia fumes from a river barge injured at least fifty-two persons and forced 10,000 to evacuate four communities shortly after midnight today.
SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Aug. 1 -- Two young Nigerians who were subjected to racial discrimination in Abraham Lincoln's home state were treated like celebrities here today as guests of the Governor.

AMID the doldrums of summer television, a touch of much-needed spice and controversy is being furnished by Betty Furness. The actress and erstwhile custodian of refrigerator doors is demonstrating on Channel 13 that she is also an efficient and quick-witted moderator of the liveliest panel show on on the air at the moment.
Five youths with a shotgun wounded three teen-age boys, for no apparent reason, in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn last night.

SEA CLIFF, L.I., Aug. 1 -- Elizabeth (Buzzy) Drake of the Port Washington Yacht Club, took the lead in the junior girls' sailing championship on Long Island Sound today. Miss Drake led from start to finish, defeating four other candidates in the first of five championship races.

The Lockheed Aircraft Corporation scheduled its first cash dividend since the first quarter of 1960 with the declaration yesterday of 30 cents a share. It is payable on Sept. 11 to holders of record of Aug. 11. The previous payment was a 2 per cent stock dividend in July, 1960, prior to which 30 cents quarterly was distributed.

Coincident with a report of record earnings for the first half of this year, the Pepsi-Cola Company announced yesterday the formation of a division and the election of Robert M. Worden as a vice president in charge of the new unit.

Diversified Growth Stock Fund, Inc., reported yesterday an increase of 25 per cent in total net assets and a rise of almost 13 per cent in share values for the six months ended on June 30 from those at the start of the year.
NAIROBI, Kenya, Aug 1 -- Jomo Kenyatta, convicted organizer of Kenya's terrorist Mau Mau movement, is to be given complete freedom in about two weeks.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 -- A meeting of Western leaders later this year is "certainly possible," Pierre Salinger, the President's press secretary, said today.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Wednesday, Aug. 2 (Reuters) -- Belgrade's leading newspaper, Politika, rejected today the charge in the Soviet Communist draft program that Yugoslavia's revisionism was one of the greatest threats to communism.
ALBANY, Aug. 1 -- A $75,010 slander verdict against Louis A. Wehle, the state Conservation Commissioner under former Gov. W. Averell Harriman, was cut in half today by an appelate court.

Gov. Robert B. Meyner, who wants to keep Channel 13 under New Jersey's state colors, met yesterday with the group that wants to convert it to educational television. The confrontation was friendly, but it changed nobody's mind.
LONDON, Aug. 1 -- Small but steady buying of leading equities was the highlight of a generally firm stock market here today.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 1 -- The United States was working actively behind the scenes today to bring France and Tunisia together for direct talks on their dispute before an emergency General Assembly session can be called.

GLEN HEAD, L.I., Aug. 1 -- Carol Beinbrink of Southward Ho, the medalist, defeated Mrs. William Renner, Hempstead, 3 and 2, in the first round of the Women's Cross County Golf Association championship at the Brookville Country Club today.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 (AP) -- The Civil Aeronautics Board may allow airlines to continue on a reasonable basis the widespread practice of overbooking.

ALBANY, Aug. 1 -- Richard G. Denzer, an assistant district attorney in New York County for twenty-three years, was appointed counsel today to the State Commission on Revision of the Penal Law and Criminal Code.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 1 -- 'Twas a balmy summer day in this lush, verdant region, and a lot of the citizenry took the opportunity to go sightseeing or something. At any rate, they didn't visit the race track in teeming numbers today.

LONDON, Aug. 1 (Reuters) -- The Moscow radio said today that Britain's decision to negotiate for membership in the European Common Market was "economic and political capitulation" to the United States.

VIENNA, Aug. 1 -- Dr. Bruno Kreisky, Austria's Foreign minister, told the Italian Ambassador, Enrico Martino, today that the Austrian Government did not hear any share of responsibility for the terrorism prevalent in Alto Adige.
Adlai E. Stevenson said yesterday that Western Europe was far less jittery over the possibility that the Berlin crisis might lead to a shooting war than were many Americans.
LEOPOLDVILLE., the Congo Aug. 1 -- Cyrille Adoula, a Socialist Labor leader with strong anti-Communist views, was appointed Premier-designate today by President Joseph Kasavubu.
CHICAGO, Aug. 1 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

The United Gas Corporation and its subsidiaries reported yesterday a gain in net income for the first half, although total operating revenues declined from the 1960 level. Natural gas revenues in the period ran higher than a year earlier, but these were more than offset by declines in revenues from gasoline and processing of natural gasoline, crude oil and sulphur, potash and copper.
SANTIAGO, Chile, Aug. 1 -- An estimated total of 2,000 families -- 10,000 persons -- have set up tents and other rude shelters on the site of a long-delayed Government housing project near here.

The New York State Board of Regents has acted vigorously in the shocking disclosures about the advance sale of questions scheduled for last June's physician licensing examination. In this case, at least, the possibility that incompetent people might be licensed was avoided by the authorities' prompt action in substituting a new test.
A Hudson River pilot, whose license as a first-grade pilot was suspended for a year after his ship had grounded, is seeking to have his record wiped clean.
DETROIT, Aug. 1 (UPI) -- [ Directors of Dow Chemicall Company today raised the quar-[ terly common dividend to 40I cents from 35 cents. It is pay-[ able on Oct. 14 to holders of/ record of Sept. 15.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 -- The masters' mixed team contest in the American Contract Bridge League's national tournament entered its fourth and last session here tonight.
Some slight improvement was registered in the market for prime debt securities yesterday, but the gain was more of tone than of price.
The hydrofoil ship Denison, which is expected to travel the equivalent of seventy miles an hour at sea, crossed twelve miles of Long Island by land yesterday at a mile and a half an hour.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 -- Federal Aviation Administrator Najeeb E. Halaby told Congress today that a newly developed Administration research program called for the United States' developing not the first but the best supersonic jet transport.
Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz instituted legal proceedings yesterday to prevent the city of Newburgh from restricting relief payments.
James Reston's column "Rusk on the Spot in the Berlin Planning" in The Times of July 30 is enlightening if not somewhat disappointing.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Aug. 1 -- Shimon Peres, Deputy Defense Minister, asserted tonight that Israel must build up her defense forces as a deterrent for the Arab states. The Arabs, he said, are receiving a "constant flow of new and modern arms."

Quite apart from the cogency ofI his over-all argument, there is onei shocking passage in the President's speech on Berlin. That is where he answers those who regard the city{ as "militarily untenable" by saying "So was Bastonge. So, in fact, was Stalingrad.

Dolph Estates, Inc., has sold the fifteen-story and penthouse apartment building at 91 Central Park West, northwest corner of Sixty-ninth Street, to a tenant group. The buyers have set up a cooperative program for the building under the direction of Donald Jones, senior vice president of William A. White Sons, the brokers in the sale.

Rod Gilbert, a 21-year-old right wing considered one of the best young players obtained by the Blues in many years, yesterday signed with the New York Rangers of the National Hockey League. He will report for pre-session training, probably at Guelph, Ont., about Sept. 10.

The eight major department stores in the New York metropolitan area recorded an average aggregate gain of 5 per cent in sales last month from the 1960 level. This was indicated by a survey yesterday by The New York Times.

JERUSALEM, Aug. 1 -- The Eichmann trial, which enters its last phase Thursday, is so compounded of paradox that it seems unreal, like the presentation of some tortuous Kafka tale dramatized with an expert touch of vraisemblance.

The recommendations of the Rockefeller Foundation-financed Citizens Committee on Voluntary Health and Welfare Agencies should go a long way, if put into effect, toward increasing the confidence of the public in the 100,000 such organizations to which it gives no less than $1,500,000,000 a year.

TO many New Yorkers the name E. Joseph brings back memories of the Washington Market. In that vast emporium of spice shops, produce stands, fish stalls, cheese booths and lunch counters where fresh oysters could be consumed by the dozen, his was the largest and most exotically stocked of the meat stores.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 1 (UPI) -- President Kennedy praised the Fulbright educational exchange program today for bringing some "benefit to humanity out of the destruction of war."
DETROIT, Aug. 1 -- The United Automobile Workers said today it wanted a look at the books of the General Motors Corporation.
LONDON, Aug. 1 -- The Government-owned British Broadcasting Corporation appeared today in the unlikely role of leg-puller.

SANTA FE, N.M., Aug. 1 (AP) -- Tests have shown that a Pecos, N.M., man died a month ago from bubonic plague, Stanley J. Leland, New Mexico public health director, said today. Another suspected case, however, turned out to be blood poisoning.

PARIS, Aug. 1 -- France answered Algerian rebel claims to the Sahara tonight. She asserted that the real dispute was over possession and distribution of the Sahara's oil riches rather than sovereignty.

Rudolf Bing, general manager of the Metropolitan Opera Company, has cut short his European tour and is flying to New York today to try to resolve the dispute between the Metropolitan and the American Federation of Musicians. The dispute may force the cancellation of the 1961-62 opera season.

Eighteen-year-old Bobby Fischer, the United States champion, won the adjourned fifth game of his sixteen-game series with Samuel Reshevsky at Los Angeles Monday night for a lead of 3 1/2 to 2 1/2. Fifty-seven moves of a Queen's Gambit declined had been made when Reshevsky surrendered.
Ralph Houk, the Yankee manager, was fined $250 yesterday and suspended for five days by Joe Cronin, the American League president.

Shipments by manufacturers of residential gas central-heating equipment in June rose by 4 per cent from the year earlier level to 108,647 units, a new high for the year, the Gas Appliance Manufacturers Association reported yesterday.

A Roman Catholic nun who can speak Japanese is learning to read and write it here. She says the children she helps on Okinawa "can't understand how the angel of mercy can talk to them in their own tongue but at the same time not understand the writing."
Lack of union support is threatening to kill a plan by organized labor to run a chain of nonprofit, cut-rate drug stores in the metropolitan areas.

Issued a joint communiqu with Vice President Chen Cheng of Nationalist China reaffirming determination to oppose admission of Communist China to the United Nations; breakfasted with Secretary of State Rusk; met with Treasury Secretary Dillon prior to Mr. Dillon's departure for Montevideo; saw Gov. lfichael V. DiSalle of Ohio; met with Bahi Ladgham, Defense 1inister of Tunisia.

A MOST peculiar situation was developing in the world of harness racing. One of the top drivers and trainers, 44-year-old Ralph Baldwin, was sitting astride the horns of a dilemma and even for an expert reinsman that's no simple trick. Now that he's made his choice, he fervently hopes he'll have better luck than he had a couple of years ago.

Caressa, Inc., a maker of medium-priced women's shoes sold through department and specialty stores yesterday filed a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission covering 150,000 shares of common stock.

BOSTON, Aug. 2 (AP) -- The Boston Red Sox swept a double-header from the Los Angeles Angels today, 7 -- 2 and 8 -- 7. Chuck Schilling hit a game-winning homer in the finale after starting the winning rally in the opener.

CHICAGO, Aug. 2 (AP) -- The grains futures market finished on a rally today and most prices closed at or near their highs of the day, with corn, rye and soybeans strong. Wheat was about steady, oats firm.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 (UPI) -- Senate-House conferees approved tonight an omnibus farm bill giving President Kennedy part of the program he proposed to trim surpluses and raise income.
Because of a disagreement over advertising signs, the New York World's Fair Corporation and Restaurant Associates, Inc., have canceled their contract for fifteen food concessions at the fair.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 2 (AP) -- Frank McGuire, head basketball coach of the University of North Carolina, tonight was named coach of the Philadelphia Warriors of the National Basketball Association.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 -- Following is the text of a joint communique issued here today by President Kennedy and Chen Cheng, Vice President and Premier of Nationalist China:

Both world and domestic sugar futures continued to fall to new lows for the lives of the contracts on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange yesterday. All months dropped to the lows as ample supplies of actuals depressed prices.
CHICAGO, Aug. 2 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

The American Stock Exchange reported yesterday the changes listed below in the securities holdings of officers, directors and controlling stockholders of companies whose shares are traded on that exchange.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 -- President Kennedy and Secretary of State Dean Rusk held lengthy talks today with Tunisia's Defense Minister, Bahi Ladgham, in an effort to end the crisis over Bizerte.

Hot weather and the resultant use of air conditioners around the nation last week caused electric power production to set a record for the second straight time. Output was 16,107,000,000 kilowatt-hours in the week ended on July 29. This compared with 15,829,000,000 kilowatt-hours a week earliers and 15,157,000,000 in the 1960 week.
State Controller Arthur Levitt pledged yesterday that if elected Mayor he would establish "a humane and intelligent relocation program" for families displaced by public works projects.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 -- Congress completed action today on authorizing the basic weapons and manpower increases President Kennedy requested last week.

The Morgan Guaranty Trust Company of New York announced yesterday it would sell the downtown block bounded by Broadway, Cedar, Nassau and Liberty Streets. Erwin S. Wolfson, the prospective buyer, said he planned to improve the block with a thirty-two-story office building representing an investment of $36,000,000.
Jack Lescoulie, who was associated with Dave Garroway for nine and a half years on the "Today" show, has found a new job on a television children's program.

The Uris Buildings Corporation announced yesterday details of the forty-one-story office skyscraper with arcades it plans in the blockfront on the west side of the Avenue of the Americas (Sixth Avenue) between Fifty-second and Fifty-third Streets.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 (UPI) -- Spokesmen for the Kennedy Administration and the American Medical Association accused each other today of spreading falsehoods in the fight over the President's medical-care plan.

According to reliable figures recently compiled with great care by an experienced investigator who does occasional bits of undercover work for this department, the people over on Madison Avenue are rapidly developing a new group of unsung heroes.
One of the most widely discussed issues in Europe today is whether England will become a member of the European Common Market.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 -- Unemployment declined by 400,000 in July, roughly in keeping with normal developments at this time of year. But the number of workers who have been unemployed for a long time increased by 100,000.

Since the time of the Suez crisis m late 1956 and early 1957, when oil prices were raised suddenly and sharply, the oil industry has been feeling the whiplash of public disapproval. Most price increases, especially in view of the heavy surpluses on most oil companies' hands, have brought some sharp reaction.
TEL AVIV, Israel, Aug. 2 -- The trial of Adolf Eichmann, which was scheduled to resume tomorrow, has been postponed until next Tuesday because of the illness of one of the judges.
A man described as an international adventurer long sought for thefts and check forgeries in fourteen states was seized in an East Side apartment early yesterday.
LONDON, Aug. 2 -- British Government securities sank to new lows in the stock market here today. By way of contrast, industrial shares had their best day in weeks.
Four days are left for many New Yorkers who are not now qualified to become eligible to vote in the Sept. 7 primary.

BLACKSBURG, Va., Aug. 2 (AP) -- A University of California scientist reported today the development of the first promising warning service against what he called the worst radiation hazard to manned space flight.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 -- The draft program of the Communist party of the U.S.S.R. for the next twenty years is the most open proof thus far that the Russian people have grown weary of living on ideological doctrine. Its glowing promises of material blessings closely describe those long enjoyed under limited socialistic regimes in Western Europe, and to a greater degree by the citizens of this democratic Republic.
BUFFALO, N.Y., Aug. 2 (UPI) -- A 15-year-old girl was indicted today on charges of kidnapping two boys and murdering one of them.

District Attorney Edward S. Silver of Brooklyn said yesterday there was no evidence to warrant criminal action against Dr. John J. Theobald, the Superintendent of Schools, in the case of the student-built boat.
MANY outdoor chefs continue to spend summer after summer struggling to start a barbecue fire, oblivious of the fact that there are many new methods to ease the strain.
CINCINNATI, Aug. 2 (AP) -- The Cincinnati Reds regained first place in the National League tonight as they swept a twilight-night double-header from the Philadelphia Phillies, 4 -- 2 and 3 -- 2.
The State Investigation Commission is considering making public the report it had sent Mayor Wagner on three city political fiugres.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 (UPI) -- The Senate approved tonight $5,200,000,000 for Federal health, labor and welfare activities. Earlier it rejected two Republican moves to use the money bills as a means of continuing aid to 4,000 "Federally impacted" school districts.

Samuel Reshevsky, an international grandmaster, caught up with Bobby Fischer, the 18-year-old United States champion, by winning the seventh game of their sixteen-game match in twenty-eight moves at the Herman Steiner Chess Club in Los Angeles Tuesday night.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 2 -- Hopes tonight for direct talks between France and Tunisia over their dispute on the Bizerte naval base made it likely that a special session of the General Assembly Would not be held on the issue.

FREEHOLD, N.J., Aug. 2 -- Harness racing, it appears, has discovered the Chinese -- and vice versa. At Freehold Raceway, where on Saturday the twenty-first consecutive season will get under way with the first of fifty ten-race afternoon programs, management is going all out to attract and to retain the interest of the action-loving Chinese.

LISBON, Portugal, Aug. 2 (Reuters) -- Portuguese forces were ported today to be carrying out a large-scale land and air offensive against Angolan insurgents in the northern mountains of the West African territory.

The executive board of Local 802 of the American Federation of Musicians denied yesterday afternoon Rudolf Bing's request to send a telegram to individual members of the Metropolitan Opera Orchestra asking them to accept the Metropolitan's best offer.
SEA CLIFF, L.I., Aug. 2 -- Nanette Grant, a 16-year-old sailor from the Belle Haven Beach Club, won the Long Island Sound girls championship as the three-day regatta ended today in Hempstead Harbor.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 -- The Federal Reserve Board reported today that the condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in leading cities showed the following principal changes for the week ended on July 26, 1961:
WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 (AP) -- The Secret National Security Agency hired two men branded disloyal by other Government agencies, the House Committee on Un-American Activities said today.

"Antislavery: The Crusade for Freedom in America," a new book by Dwight L. Dumond, will be issued Oct. 6 by the University of Michigan Press. In words and pictures, the work describes the struggle in constitutional conventions, legislative halls, courtrooms, churches, schools and finally on the battlefield.

The Civil War Centenary is turning up or bringing out of the attics a number of strange relics, including the charge that Lincoln's War Secretary, Edwin M. Stanton, knew about the plot to kill the President and didn't do anything to stop it.
A recent editorial in The Times lamented the failure of the so-called Lehman faction to undertake "any mission that took it outside the Democratic party in search of better city government."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 (UPI) -- The White House said today it had amended a code-of-conduct directive for Federal employes to emphasize that they should not withhold from the press or public any information that did not affect security or would not give anyone speculative advantage.
The Marine Engineers Beneficial Association, one of the five maritime unions that struck in June and July, announced yesterday that it had signed agreements with two more shipping companies.

The two-story building on a plot 150 by 100 feet at 513 to 523 West Twenty-fourth Street, between Tenth and Eleventh Avenues, has been sold by the Dairymen's League Cooperative Association. It was used as a milk processing plant by Meridale Dairies, Inc., which vacated it July 1. The property is assessed at $250,000.
"Caps" for the solid-fuel booster engines that hurl rocket into space are being made by an advanced process just announced by the Lukens Steel Company of Coatesville, Pa.
SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 2 -- California's Attorney General bracketed the John Birch Society with the Communist party today.

PARIS, Aug. 2 -- The fall and winter fashion collection have ended and the little gold chairs are being quietly stacked away. Abrupt changes were missing this season, but there were enough significant developments to stamp 1961 fashion with a definite new look.

ON Tuesday night Lewisohn Stadium pulled out its biggest drawing card -- Van Cliburn -- and, with the aid of good weather, drew a capacity audience of 20,000, the largest of the season. Last night, as if from exhaustion at such effort, the Stadium had a very tired air.
A 10-year-old girl was charged last night with throwing a 2-year-old boy out a ninth-floor window in their Brooklyn housing development.

The largest composite map of New York City and vicinity ever assembled by topographical engineers of the Department of the Interior's Geological Survey was presented yesterday to Mayor Wagner at City Hall.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 -- The shipping industry made a "final" plea today for changes in proposed legislation affecting the controversial question of steamship conference practices.
Dr. Ray E. Trussell, the city Hospital Commissioner, confirmed yesterday that the closed-down ward section of Gouverneur Hospital would be used by the state to treat mentally retarded children.
ROME, Aug. 2 (UPI) -- Pope John XXIII presided today at the funeral service for Domenico Cardinal Tardini, one of his closest friends and most important advisers.

The dramatic conflict over Bizerte has tended to obscure the breakdown last Friday of the talks between the French and the Algerian rebels. While the two developments had no apparently direct connection, it is hard to believe that they were not linked.
