In a display of power that had its opponent reeling before the game was a half-hour old, Dukla of Czechoslovakia defeated Everton of England, 7 -- 2, last night at the Polo Grounds.

The American Independent Oil Company announced yesterday the signing of an agreement through which it will pay taxes to the Kuwait Government at the rate of 57 per cent on the net realized profits from the sale of crude oil it produces in the Neutral Zone -- between Kuwait and Saudi Arabia.
Cotton futures prices on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 7 points (35 cents a bale) off to 10 points (50 cents a bale) up yesterday.
The Western Union Telegraph Company plans to compete directly with new services recently offered by the American Telephone and Telegrap Company.
BALTIMORE, Aug. 2 (AP) -- Dave Philley's eighth-inning pinch single gave the Baltimore Orioles a 4 -- 3 victory over Minnesota tonight after the Twins had won the opener, 4 -- 3.

CIUDAD TRUJILLO, Dominican Republic, Aug. 2 (AP) -- The Joint Chiefs of Staff announced today the disbanding of three civilian armed groups organized as a Dominican Army auxiliary.
OTTAWA, Aug. 2 -- Canada's New party, now holding its founding convention, is emerging as a liberal organization just a little left of center.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 -- The Administration is completing plans to remove from the Central Intelligence Agency its function of over-all intelligence evaluation.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 2 -- The Philadelphia Electric Company and a subsidiary, the Conowingo Power Company, filed thirteen triple damage suits in the Federal District Court today against twenty-four companies involved in the recent price-fixing prosecutions in the electric industry.
SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 1 -- Plans for a $6,500,000 twenty-two-story apartment house for Nob Hill were announced today by Robert M. Haynie, president of Haas Haynie, the builders.

GENEVA, Aug. 2 -- The fourteen-nation conference on Laos called on its British and Soviet co-chairmen today to find a solution for the stalemate over the presence of French military instructors in Laos.
SANTIAGO, Chile, Aug. 2 -- Political storm warnings are going up all over Chile these days.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 (AP) -- The Federal Government and four states are reported near agreement on a proposed Delaware River compact.

The appointment of a new Superintendent of Schools and the resignation of some members of the Board of Education were urged yesterday by State Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz, Republican candidate for Mayor.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 2 -- A reproduction of the New York Yankees' dugout at Yankee Stadium is being built at the Revue Studio here for the film debuts this month of Mickey Mantle, Roger Maris and Yogi Berra.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 2 -- Turf racing was offered on the local thoroughbred program today for the first time since the Alabama Stakes of 1903. The feature race, the Moreau Pond Handicap, scheduled for the new course, proved so attractive with the trainers and the owners that it had to be contested in two divisions.

The Theatre Guild American Repertory Company, with Helen Hayes, Leif Erickson, June Havoc, Nancy Coleman, Dran Seitz and Peggy Burke in the cast, will begin the second leg of its goodwill journey on Monday in Port of Spain, Trinidad.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 -- President Kennedy reaffirmed today United States opposition to the admission of Communist China to the United Nations. He also attested to continuing support for the membership of Nationalist China in the world body.

HOUSTON, Tex., Aug. 2 (AP) -- Ten Southern producers and shippers of liquefied petroleum gas are reportedly joining a Houston gas transmission company in the construction and operation of a $60,000,000 pipeline.
SANTA MONICA, Calif., Aug. 2 (UPI) -- Douglas Aircraft Company announced today a major organization realignment, setting up a separate missiles and space division.
ST. LOUIS, Aug. 2 (AP) -- Joe Cunningham's three-run homer in the seventh inning gave the St. Louis Cardinals a 4-2 victory over the Pittsburgh Pirates tonight.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 -- The Peace Corps appeared headed for trouble in Congress today.
PARIS, Aug. 2 -- British entry into the European Common Market would mark the third major turning point in basic British trade policy in a little more than a century.

MADRID, Aug. 2 (UPI) -- The former Argentine dictator, Juan D. Peron, has sent a letter to President Kennedy accusing the United States of responsibility for Latin America's political and economic troubles, reliable sources reported tonight.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 -- The Administration's newly proposed $207,000,000 fall-out shelter program ran into Congressional objections today that it did not go far enough.
Five colleges in upper New York and Pennsylvania have agreed to a cooperative venture to combine sound economies with high academic standards.
HAVANA, Aug. 2 -- A wide-ranging reorganization of the trade union system was announced today by the Cuban Government. The effect will be to identify a worker's union with his place of employment.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 (AP) -- The United States said today that there were normal legal processes by which Cuba could head off the sale of Cuban aircraft seized under United States court orders.

NANTUCKET, Mass., Aug. 2 -- There was no competition on the New York Yachting Club cruise today because of wind failure. After wating two hours, the race committee aboard Antiope broke out the checkered N flag indicating no race and the squadron proceeded to this port under power.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 2 (AP) -- Ben Ray Redman, literary critic and author, died today an apparent suicide after telling his wife he was depressed over the state of international affairs.

HERGISWIL, Switzerland, Aug. 2 -- A bus carrying American tourists, most of them women, plunged into the chill waters of Lake Lucerne today. The police said that sixteen of the thirty-eight occupants were killed and twenty-two survived.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 (AP) -- Secretary of Commerce Luther H. Hodges announced today a reorganization of his Business and Defense Services Administration to broaden and strengthen the activities of its industry divisions.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 (UPI) -- The Republicans formally opened their campaign for the 1962 elections today by announcing a series of regional conferences to be held throughout the country next fall.
ALBANY, Aug. 2 (AP) -- Six alerted state units of the Air National Guard were told today to double training time to be ready for a possible activation call.

ALBANY, Aug. 2 -- The creation of an interstate transportation agency to help underwrite continued operation of the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad with public funds was proposed today by a Republican State Senator.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 (AP) -- Congress was urged today to split its sessions in two so they would conform to the school year.

THIS is how to keep up with the Joneses gastronomically. The Evan Joneses live in a penthouse in Manhattan and when they dine it is more often than not with an excellent view of the city's roofs. They live by the dictum that food is fun and that cooking is a prime pleasure.
MOSCOW, Aug. 2 -- Premier Khrushchev declared today that his Government believed there would be no war over Berlin.

CHICAGO, Aug. 2 (AP) -- The Chicago Cubs and Milwaukee Braves played to a 7-7 eleven-inning tie in the second game of a double-header. The Braves won the opener, 4 -- 2, with a three-run attack in the eighth.

DETROIT, Aug. 2 (AP) -- Bud Zipfel of the Washington Senators hit his first major-league home run in the eleventh inning of the second game of a double-header tonight and helped beat the Detroit Tigers, 6 -- 2.

Record half-year earnings of American Broadcasting-Paramount Theatres, Inc., were further enhanced by a capital gains credit lifting the net income to $11,843,000 from $6,981,000 in the first six months of last year.
A jewelry salesman reported to the police in the Bronx yesterday that two hold-up men had forced him to give up two cases containing $75,000 worth of assorted jewels, mostly diamonds.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 (AP) -- President Kennedy today asked Secretary of Commerce Luther H. Hodges for recommendations by Nov. 1 designed to "achieve and maintain healthy and efficient transportation systems."
LEOPOLDVILLE, Aug. 2 (AP) -- The death toll in the massacre of Luntu tribesmen in Kasai Province by Congolese soldiers was reported today to have risen to 600 men, women and children.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 2 (AP) -- Charles (Sonny) Liston was released in $500 bail today on a charge resulting from an incident in Fairmount Park last June 12.

President Kennedy's choice of Philleo Nash to be Commissioner of Indian Affairs is welcome evidence of the Administration's determination to deal fairly and wisely with the 366,000 Indians who still live on reservations as Federal wards.

ALBANY, Aug. 2 -- The State Department of Education will prepare new material to help teachers strengthen their present teaching about "communism and its dangers to the free world," Commissioner James E. Allen Jr. announced today.

Voluntary support of the leading colleges and universities has more than doubled in the past five years, with alumni setting the pace, according to a special survey by the Council for Financial Aid to Educators.

PRETORIA, South Africa, Aug. 24 (Reuters) -- Balthazar Johannes Vorster, a wartime Nazi supporter, became South Africa's new Justice Minister today. Mr. Vorster was named in a Cabinet shake-up that paved the way for national elections in October.

The world hopes that exaggerated fears of clandestine testing or other arguments of advantage and disadvantage based on wholly undependable material will not lead the American Government to resume tests. The world hopes that the moratorium will be kept up whatever be the difficulties in the way of reaching an agreed test ban.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 (AP) -- Even President Kennedy's emergency telephone in his bedroom is not immune to wrong number calls. He answered one last week from an insistent caller asking for an animal hospital.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 2 (AP) -- Juan Marichal scored his second straight shutout with a one-hitter tonight as the San Francisco Giants stopped the Los Angeles Dodgers' eight-game winning streak by beating them, 6 -- 0.

BAY SHORE, L.I., Aug. 2 -- It is still evident that most of the class championships of the Great South Bay Yacht Racing Association's annual Cruise Week Regatta will not be decided until the final day. Today, the fleet sailed in the choppy seas off here with a moderate southeasterly wind prevailing. It was heavy weather without a heavy wind.

It is erroneous to assume that the recent establishment of the United Church of Christ is a remarkable achievement in Christian unity. This action has created a serious schism of the Congregational-Christian fellowship which will take a long time to heal.
LONDON, Aug. 2 -- An airport authority will be established to manage Britain's principal international airports at London, Gatwick, Stansted and Prestwick, the Ministry of Aviation announced today.

BERLIN, Aug. 2 -- The East German regime clamped down today on 50,000 residents of East Berlin and East Germany who go into West Berlin each day to work. The Communist police were reported to be taking identity cards away from many workers who insisted on going to their jobs.

The State Harness Racing Commission denied the appeal of Adios Butler, Inc., from Rule 12, Section 14, the conflict-of-interest rule, following the meeting of Chairman Robert Glasser and Commissioners Spencer B. Eddy and James H. Farley in their Manhattan offices yesterday.
Harvey Aluminum, Inc., in the nine months ended on June 30, achieved higher sales and earnings than for any similar period in its history.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 -- Gerald A. Behn, a Secret Service agent since 1939, was given responsibility today for the personal safety of president Kennedy and his family. The President chose him to head the service's White House detail.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 2 (AP) -- Jim (Mudcat) Grant pitched the Cleveland Indians to a 3-2 victory in the opener of a double-header tonight, but Jim Landis paced the Chicago White Sox to an 8-4 victory in the second game. Landis hit a homer in each contest.
LONDON, Aug. 2 -- Prime Minister Macmillan said today that Britain sought membership in the European Common Market as a means of achieving unity in Western Europe.
LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, Aug. 2 -- A landslide vote in Parliament swept Cyrille Adoula, a staunch follower of President Joseph Kavubu, into office today as the new Premier of the Congo.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 -- President Kennedy said today that the hopes of millions of people might depend on the success of the United States delegation to the inter-American economic conference that opens in Uruguay Saturday.
MIAMI, Fla., Aug. 2 -- Alberto de Obarrio, Panama's most recent Ambassador to Cuba, was shot in the head early this morning in his apartment here.
The United States Court of Appeals upheld Federal Judge Irving R. Kaufman yesterday on his order to New Rochelle to desegregate the predominantly Negro Lincoln School.

MILWAUKEE, Aug. 2 (AP) -- Directors of the Anis-Chalmers Manufacturing Company today declared a quarterly dividend of 25 cents on the common stock, payable on Sept. 30 to shareholders of record Sept. 1. In previous quarters 37 1/2 cents was paid.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 (AP) -- Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) charged in Federal District Court today that the Government's method of allocating crude oil imports was unfair, inequitable, arbitrary and discriminatory.
The 1961 home-run deluge is a greater mystery to two of baseball's foremost executives than it is to the abused and worried men who are thinking of organizing a Pitchers Beneolent Association.
A housing violation against John E. Hand, real estate agent and Democratic political figure, was dismissed in Housing Court yesterday because a building inspector was on vacation.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Aug. 2 -- Leaders of the Israel Bond Organization from the United States, Canada and Latin America called today for the sale of another $500,000,000 in Israel bonds during the next seven-year appeal.

The New York State Bankers Association expressed its opposition yesterday to a plan for withholding taxes at the source for dividend and certain kinds of interest income. It said that the proposal, now before Congress, would "unjustly hurt millions of small savers."

Twenty local government housing authorities subsidized by the Public Housing Administration borrowed $60,315,000 in the public market at long term yesterday at an interest cost of slightly less than 3 1/2 per cent. The securities, which will come due serially from 1962 to 2002, were sold at competitive bidding to two banking syndicates.
Negotiations to end the month-long strike of 1,200 concrete mix drivers were held yesterday in a "hopeful" atmosphere.

Gasoline inventories declined by 2,945,000 barrels in the week ended last Friday, the American Petroleum Institute reported yesterday. A dip in gasoline production to 30,449,000 barrels in the period from 30,812,000 a week earlier accounted for part of the lower gasoline inventories.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 2 -- Escaping disaster by a single stroke in the second set, Chris Crawford defeated Dennis Ralston of Bakersfield, Calif., in the Southampton invitation tennis tournament at the Meadow Club today, 1 -- 6, 8 -- 6, 6 -- 4.
WHITE PLAINS, Aug. 2 -- Ten large railroads filed suit in Supreme Court today asking exemption from New York State's full-crew laws.

GLEN HEAD, L.I., Aug. 2 -- Carol Beinbrink of Southward Ho defeated Mrs. Joseph Dempsey Jr. of the same club, 2 and 1, in a quarter-final match of the Women's Cross County Golf Association championship at the Brookville Country Club.

GLOUCESTER, Mass., Aug. 12 -- Consolidated Lobster and Chemical Company, Inc., once, the world's largest, producer and distributor of lobsters, has abandoned the field it had dominated for many years.
LONDON, Aug. 2 (Reuters) -- Heavy buying of the pound sterling pushed it up to par with the United States dollar -- $2.80 -- today for the first time since mid-April.
Long-term United States Government bonds moved further into the 4 per cent yield area yesterday as buying interest dried up in all maturity areas occupied by interest-bearing issues.
OCEANPORT, N.J., Aug. 2 -- Out of contention up to the stretch run, Orleans Doge won the $59,600 Choice Stakes at Monmouth Park today with a powerful burst in the last three-sixteenths.
TEHERAN, Iran, Aug. 2 -- A major problem of the Government of Premier Ali Amini is that it plans to do so many unpopular things.

The land used as a parking lot on West Seventy-second Street, 200 feet from Central Park West, has been sold by the Glickman Corporation. It has been bought by the First National Realty and Construction Corporation for improvement with an apartment building. Ackman Brothers were the brokers.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 -- The Senate today confirmed Rear Admiral John Harllee of the District of Columbia to be a member of the Federal Maritime Board.
A panel of mathematicians and educators from eighteen countries called yesterday for a revolution in the teaching of mathematics.
PARIS, Aug. 2 -- Stocks have risen slightly on the Continent in the last week -- the first weekly increase in nearly two months.
The Phelps Dodge Corporation, the nation's second largest domestic copper producer, registered an 18.2 per cent rise in earnings on a sales gain of 11.7 per cent in the first six months of this year.

Experiments to find if it is possible to rest the heart during the critical few days following a heart attack will be conducted over the next two years at the New York Medical College-Metropolitan Hospital Center.

LONDON, Aug. 2 (AP) -- Charles James Spencer-Churchill may be the Earl of Sunderland, but he's also a 5-year-old boy who knows when he has had enough.
The Salute to America Ball at the Summit Hotel on Oct. 24 will benefit the Girls Club of New York and will observe the reaching of a total of 100 member clubs by the Girls Clubs of America.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 (UPI) -- Congress gave final approval today for a national seashore park on Cape Cod.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 -- A Justice Department official said today that the Government was considering antitrust action to force the American Telephone and Telegraph Company to get rid of its overseas operations.
On Aug. 16 the guest of honor at a dinner in the Crystal Room at the Palmer House in Chicago will trot to the dais. He will be hailed as the year's Dog Hero of Heroes.

The Manhattan brownstone in which Theodore Roosevelt was born in 1858 and the Victorian home on Long Island where he died in 1919 were offered to the Federal Government yesterday as national monuments.
Carmine G. De Sapio was assailed yesterday by Mayor Wagner for Tammany's attempt to deny renomination to Manhattan Councilmen who had voted for Edward R. Dudley as Borough President.

Dillon, Read Co., Inc., and associates are offering to the public today $30,000,000 of 5 3/8 per cent debentures due Aug. 1, 1981, and 200,000 preferred shares of the Texas Eastern Transmission Corporation. The preferred shares are of the 5.125 per cent sub-ornate convertible series, with a par value of $100.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 -- Exports in June were only slightly greater than the level to which they fell in May, the Department of Commerce reported today. The growth of the surplus of exports over imports appears to have stopped, partly because exports are not rising and particularly because imports are.

With a little bit of luck in the first game and a lot of power in the second, the Yankees swept a double-header from the Kansas City Athletics at the Stadium yesterday. The scores were 6 -- 5 and 12 -- 5.

Manager Ralph Houk of the Yankees spent most of the first day of his five-day suspension in the comfortable surroundings of the television lounge adjacent to the Yankees' dressing room. From there he watched the screen of a television set for five and a half hours as his team performed successfully.
LONDON, Aug. 2 -- A painting by Gova whose purchase by an American stirred protests here will remain in Britain after all.

One of the more unexpected developments in the magazine industry in recent years has been the rise of the hard-cover periodical. Opulent in design (and in price), magazines like American Heritage and Horizon have carved out an important niche in the publishing field.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 (AP) -- Senator Strom Thurmond assailed today criticism of military sponsorship of Right-Wing speakers as "a clandestine assault on the fundamental foundations of our republic."

SHORT HILLS, N.J., Aug. 2 -- The new three-story Bonwit Teller women's apparel specialty store at the Mall in Short Hills shopping center will be opened at 10 A.M. next Thursday. Mrs. Robert B. Meyner, wife of the Governor of New Jersey, will cut a garland of violets at the entrance.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 -- Two of the major contests in the American Contract Bridge League's national tournament at the Sheraton Park Hotel ended today.

LONDON, Aug. 2 -- Field Marshal Sir Francis Festing, Chief of the Imperial General Staff, will accompany the Earl of Home, the Foreign Secretary, to the meetings in Paris this week-end of the Western foreign ministers.

The future of the Phoenix Theatre in its present quarters at 189 Second Avenue is in doubt. The uncertainty became known yesterday when it was learned that its lease, which expires in October, had not yet been renewed.

Attorney General Louis K. Lefkowitz, the Republican organization candidate for Mayor, was sprayed with bits of broken glass but escaped injury yesterday morning when an unidentified object struck his automobile.

The Sun Oil Company had a consolidated net income of $24,048,000, equal to $1.84 each on the 13,046,590 shares outstanding for the first half of this year, Joseph N. Pew Jr., chairman, reported yesterday.

The Board of Estimate has again voted to postpone the inevitable -- the urgently needed widening of Fulton Street. By shelving the controversial proposal until after the primary election next month and with every portent that action will again be deferred then until after the general election on Nov. 7, the board is demonstrating more concern with election-year politics than with the city's traffic and economic health.

HONG KONG, Aug. 2 -- The Chinese Communist view on the need for "struggle" in dealing with the West as opposed to more peaceful methods was presented anew today in Jenmin Jih Pao, official organ of Chinese Communist party.
LONDON, Aug. 2 -- The Reserves of gold and convertible currencies held by Britain as central banker for the sterling area fell last month by the largest amount of any month since December, 1951.

Summer shipments from steel service centers to consumers are declining rather less than industry leaders had expected.
TUNIS, Aug. 2 -- Tunisian authorities charged today that French aircraft violated Tunisian air space fifty times in the last forty-eight hours and that the flights were continuing.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 (UPI) -- The Government filed three civil rights suits today. They charged that Negroes had been denied voting rights in Montgomery County, Alabama, and Walthall and Jefferson, Davis Counties, Mississippi.

State Controller Arthur Levitt told Democratic county and district leaders yesterday that the "life, destiny and continued existence of the Democratic party" were at stake in the Sept. 7 primary election.
VINEYARD HAVEN, Mass., Aug. 3 -- A squadron run of the New York Yacht Club cruise was spoiled for the second time today because there wasn't enough wind.
DEAL, N.J., Aug. 3 -- Mrs. William Tracy of Essex Fells won the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association's Shore Tournament for the second straight year today at the Deal Golf Club.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 (UPI) -- The Highlander Folk School, an integrated adult institution near Monteagle, Tenn, appealed to the Supreme Court today against a state ruling that revoked its charter.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 -- Adlai E. Stevenson was reported tonight to have intervened on behalf of Under Secretary of State Chester Bowles when Mr. Bowles' job appeared in jeopardy.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 3 -- Hollywood needs a sage who can define for movie executives the point at which keen competition becomes cinematic claim-jumping.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Aug. 3 -- The president of the Board of Education said today that he would seek a Supreme Court review of the Federal Court ruling to desegregate the predominently Negro Lincoln Elementary School.
LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, Aug. 3 -- The United Nations may soon begin a "slow phase-out" of its forces in the Congo, Dr. Sture C. Linner, head of the world body's mission here, said today.

BALTIMORE, Aug. 3 (AP) -- Tony Lema's 35-foot chip into the twelfth hole for an eagle 3 enabled him to tie Ken Venturi today for the first-round lead in the $35,000 Eastern open golf tournament. Both were four strokes under par.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 -- Secretary of the Treasury Douglas Dillon said today that taxes would not have to be increased to balance the budget next year unless the international situation worsens.
Following is the text of a letter sent to all members of the city Board of Education by Dr. James E. Alle, Jr., state Commissioner of Education:
A plastic blue whale with a a mouth that is wider than a Volkswagen and higher than a telephone booth arrived yesterday at the Children's Zoo in Central Park.
LONDON, Aug. 3 -- Twentieth Century-Fox has brought suit for upward of $1,000,000 in insurance on "Cleopatra," its off-again, on-again movie starring Elizabeth Taylor.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 (AP) -- News of the latest airliner hijacking angered Congress today. Most of the anger was directed at Fidel Castro in the early belief that the hijacking was linked to the Cuban Premier.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 -- Reports from both the rail and truck industries indicated today that an improved economic picture should develop during the latter part of the present quarter. Last week's figure from both industries reflected this improvement.

THE recent Senate Judiciary Subcommittee hearings on packaging and labeling practices of manufacturers of pharmaceuticals, cosmetics and food have made many women shop more warily. Careful inspection of some of the products in retail stores indicates that the buyer often does well to beware.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 3--President Kennedy was reported today to be seriously considering the invocation of the Trading With the Enemy Act against the Cuban regime of Premier Fidel Castro.

POINT O'WOODS L.I., Aug. 3 -- E. Carleton Arink's Ariel took today's race and gained the lead in the Narrasketuck Class series as the Great South Bay Yacht Racing Association's Cruise Week fleet moved to this Fire Island port.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 -- The Kennedy Administration may lose the support of Senator Pat McNamara, Democrat of Michigan, in the battle over foreign aid. A squabble over patronage may be responsible.
Fidelity Fund, Inc., reported yesterday a gain of 16 per cent in net assets for the twelve months ended on June 30. The share value rose 12 per cent in the same period.

MIAMI, Aug. 3 -- Henry (Hank) Hornidge, a 25-year-old mechanical engineer from Mamaroneck, N.Y., outsailed all other skippers today as the North American championships of the 5-0-5 Class began in South Biscayne Bay.

A decision in one of the most controversial shipping problems the Maritime Administration has faced in years will be held up until the agency is reorganized, Administrator Thomas E. Stakem indicated yesterday.

VANDENBERG AIR FORCE BASE, Calif., Aug. 3 (UPI) -- Discoverer satellite XXVIII hurtled aloft today carrying a recoverable instrument capsule. But the Air Force announced ninety minutes later that the satellite had failed to enter orbit.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 -- A compromise farm bill calling for sharp cutbacks in the next crops of wheat, corn and other grains won Congressional approval today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 (UPI) -- The Federal space agency today was reported about ready to speed development of a rocket powerful enough to send a three-man space craft around the moon within four or five years.
OSAKA, Japan, Friday, Aug. 4 (AP) -- Club-swinging policemen charged through Osaka's slums at dawn today, breaking up a third consecutive all-night riot. Officials expect another battle tonight.

Loans to business by the fifteen weekly reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve in New York City rose $81,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.

All domestic sugar futures again hit new lows for the lives of the contracts in early trading yesterday on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange. Liquidation and light trade selling depressed prices. The market rallied in dull trading toward the close on short covering and new buying.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 (AP) -- The House of Representatives got another chance today for a showdown vote on whether to permit the Government to use a nuclear reactor to generate public power in the Northwest.
" Transportation U.S.A.," an official exhibition designed to show the Russians how this country moves people and goods was previewed here yesterday.
CHICAGO, Aug. 2 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
PATERSON, N.J., Aug. 3 -- William Beeching, his wife and their six children, will move from their $54-a-month apartment in the Brooks-Sloate housing project because of their love for a squirrel.
Prices of cotton futures moved 15 cents a bale off to 25 cents up yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange.

A landlord accused of eighty housing and fire violations was fined $350 in Housing Court yesterday, rather than the maximum of $1,000, after the city praised his cooperation with its rehabilitation efforts

New York and Connecticut have decided that they want the Metropolitan Regional Council, now an informal organization of elected officials, to organize as an official body. New Jersey's Senate has concurred and it is to be hoped that the Assembly will soon make tri-state legislative ratification complete. Governor Meyner's approval is believed assured.

The Grand Prix of the United States, the last event on the 1961 calendar for the world driving championship, may be held at Watkins Glen, N.Y., on Oct. 7 and 8. An application to run the event has been forwarded to the Federation Internationale de l'Automobile in Paris by the Watkins Glen promoters.
SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 3 -- George D. Bostwick's Tuscarora made his move at the right time and won the Beverwyck Steeplechase Handicap by seven lengths today.
DHEKELIA, Cyprus, Aug. 3 -- Saboteurs have kept this British Army base without a steady supply of water for eight days.
A group of economists from Barranquilla, Colombia, who, at their own expense, are promoting an economic development program for their city, are in New York to advance their project.

Handy Harman, Inc., refiner and fabricator of precious metals, has sold the six-story commercial building at 82-88 Fulton Street, corner of Gold Street, through a subsidiary, 82 Fulton Street, Inc. The buyer was the Consolidated Edison Company, owner of the adjoining building at 33-43 Gold Street, a former sub-station.
Dr. James E. Allen Jr., the State Education Commissioner, told the city Board of Education yesterday to put its house in order or step aside so a new board could do so.

LAST week with the thermometer outside my window registering 93 and the humidity in my library coating my books with mildew it seemed a good idea to read something light, clever and not too taxing on the brain cells. Like what? Well, not like "Stranger in a Strange Land,"* by Robert A. Heinlein.

Armour Co. directors authorized yesterday the filing of a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission covering a proposed public offering of $32,500,000 of convertible subordinated debentures.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 -- The House of Representatives virtually completed Congressional action today on a reorganization of the Federal Communications Commission.

LONDON, Aug. 3 -- Britain's spacious New Towns, the suburban developments planned to provide cramped city dwellers with light, air and greenery, are doing just that. But for many residents they are producing what the Ministry of Housing calls the "New Town blues."

EAST HARTFORD, Conn., Aug. 3 (UPI) -- The Pratt Whitney division of United Aircraft Corporation announced today the receipt of a $64,900,000 Navy contract for additional production of J-52 jet engines and a $5,000,000 contract for development testing of the engine.

Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa was bewildered but lighted yesterday when he saw a formal-looking invitation being sent through the mail in his behalf inviting New Yorkers to an "Election Day Poll" on Nov. 7.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 -- The Federal Aviation Agency authorized United States airlines today to arm their crews on all flights.
One of the new trustees of the New Haven Railroad said yesterday they hoped to reorganize the line in a fraction of the twelve years that it took the last time.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 -- The United States and West Germany are preparing a relatively small but essential aid package for Iran with the aim of bolstering the pro-Western, reform Government of Premier Ali Amini.

It seems to me that one reason for the trouble with the schools in New York City is that we are still running them on a system which worked long and well in small communities, but which is not suited to the problems of a great metropolis.
The Publishers Association of New York City and New York Typographical Union 6 reached tentative agreement yesterday on the terms of a new two-year contract.

The film adaptation of "Advise and Consent" will be released by Columbia Pictures instead of United Artists, it was announced yesterday. Otto Preminger, who will produce and direct the film for his own independent company, said that the transfer would not affect his distribution commitments with either organization, and that the production would start on schedule next month.
BOSTON, Aug. 3 (AP) -- Don Schwall spaced three hits tonight and pitched the Boston Red Sox to their fourth straight victory, a 4-0 decision over the Los Angeles Angels.

Shareholder accounts with the 160 mutual fund members of the National Association of Investment Companies passed the 5,000,000 mark during the first half of 1961. The total on June 30 was 5,109,780, against 4,644,208 a year before.
Record sales and earnings were reported yesterday by Sterling Drug, Inc., for both the second quarter and first half of 1961.
ITHACA, N.Y., Aug. 3 (AP) -- Steve Whitman of California defeated Claude Harmon Jr., 2 and 1, today in the first round of the fourteenth United States Golf Association junior championship.

PNOMPHEN, Cambodia, Aug. 3 -- Prince Souvanna Phouma, the Laotian neutralist leader, declared today that Prince Boun Oum's Right-wing, pro-Western Government was "playing into the hands of the Communists" by making impossible proposals for ending the bitter factional strife in Laos.
MANILA, Aug. 3 (UPI) -- Oil exploration in the Philippines shifted to high gear today with the entry of two American oil companies into the search of petroleum.

IT is possible to talk turkey this week-end, to the tune of only 29 cents a pound. One large chain currently offers large-sized birds at this figure -- probably one of the lowest ever recorded and a bargain in anyone's pocketbook.

Production of lumber climbed for the third consecutive time to 231,649,000 board feet in the week ended last Saturday from 218,810,000 board feet the week before, according to reports from regional associations. A year ago, 235,532,000 board feet were produced.

The American Telephone and Telegraph Company and the Western Union Company have reached a tentative agreement whereby Western Union will lease additional Bell System circuits with which to expand its private wire services.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 (UPI) -- Senator Ralph W. Yarborough, Democrat of Texas, called today for the death penalty for plane hijackers.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 -- The White House described today as "inaccurate" an article appearing in The New York Times this morning outlining proposed changes in the functions and responsibilities of the Central Intelligence Agency.

In a world of highly competitive costs, the old saying about "carrying coals to Newcastle" no longer seems like a paradox. For several months the British Government has been debating just that -- importing American coal to be used by British steel companies at about $3 to $4 less a ton than home-mined coal.

CAMP PERRY, Ohio, Aug. 3 (UPI) -- S/1c William B. Blankenship Jr., of Richlands, Va., withstood a last-day rally by Marine Capt. William W. McMillan Jr., of Monroeville, Pa., to win the national pistol championship today with 2,631 points.
The North Hempstead, L.I., Union Free School District 10 (Mineola) borrowed $4,525,000 in the bond market yesterday on serial obligations due from 1961 to 1980.

Stocks moved ahead yesterday in lighter trading and on the way registered new highs for the third straight day. The drop in volume was somewhat disconcerting to the bulls, who have been ranging freely these days, but it was far from discouraging.

The Federal Trade Commission issued a consent order yesterday prohibiting an American representative for foreign correspondence schools from making any claims that such institutions could issue college degrees or diplomas valid in the United States.

In a statement offering support to the mayoralty primary campaigns of Arthur Levitt and Louis J. Lefkowitz, and promising that "the teachers will teach the Mayor [Wagner] a lesson," Mrs. Rita T. Develin, as chairman of the City-Wide Committee for Equal Retirement for New York City Teachers, charges Mayor Wagner with "lack of interest in teachers' problems."

Authorities investigating the Queens crash that killed Mrs. Angier Biddle Duke and three others have been told that the same plane had been involved before in a forced landing. And for the same reason -- a faulty door.
" Enthusiastic response" to President Kennedy's plea for a speed-up in Federally aided building programs was reported yesterday by the regional office of the Public Housing Administration.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 -- The Senate Foreign Relations Committee tonight deferred final action until tomorrow on President Kennedy's controversial $40,000,000 fund request for the Peace Corps.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 (UPI) -- Congress completed action today on a $135,000,000 money bill to keep itself in business.

Blyth Co., Inc., and associates offered $30,000,000 of twenty-five-year 4 3/8 per cent sinking fund debentures of Kimberly-Clark Corporation yesterday at a price of 100. A spokesman for the underwriters said that the issue was oversubscribed.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 -- The Pentagon told Congress today that the Administration's $207,000,000 fall-out shelter plan did not rule out future long-range programs.
The deterioration in the high-grade bond market continued yesterday as institutional investors, apprehending a return of inflationary strains in the economy, held back on their buying.

President Bourguiba of Tunisia made a statesmanlike proposal to the French yesterday. He offered to drop his complaint to the United Nations if the French would agree to discuss "a reasonable evacuation timetable" for the Bizerte naval base.
THE white marlin are just refusing to cooperate with Atlantic City and the Atlantic City Tuna Club.
General Electric Company introduced its new top officials at a press conference yesterday in the board room at 570 Lexington Avenue.

Senator Strom Thurmond of South Carolina and Senator J.W. Fulbright of Arkansas, both Democrats, are in dispute over how much propaganda the officers in the armed services should be allowed to carry on.
LOS ANGELES, Aug. 3 (AP) -- Violence in the air is nothing new to Capt. Byron D. Rickards, 52 years old, commander of the hijacked airliner.
CLEVELAND, Aug. 3 (AP) -- The Chicago White Sox scored two unearned runs and beat the Cleveland Indians, 8 -- 6, tonight.
NEW HAVEN, Aug. 3 -- The New Haven Railroad will get Government-backed loans totaling $5,000,000 from two New York City banks.
MOSCOW, Aug. 3 -- The Soviet Union delivered long parallel notes on Berlin today to envoys of the United States, Britain, France and West Germany.
SLOWLY but surely it is beginning to look as if the American League's preseason form chart is finally vindicating itself. Soon now, the Yankees should be making their long-awaited pennant drive.
DETROIT, Aug. 3 (AP) -- Reno Bertoia, a third baseman, and Gerry Staley, a 40-year-old relief pitcher, reported to the Detroit Tigers today.

GLEN HEAD, L.I., Aug 3 -- Carol Beinbrink of Southward Ho and Mrs. Pat Cici of Lido gained the final of the Women's Cross County Golf Association's sixth annual match-play championship at the Brookville Country Club today.

A modified employer proposal for ending the month-long strike of 1,200 concrete mix drivers was rejected yesterday by members of Local 282 of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters. The vote was 638 to 315.
DETROIT, Aug. 3 (UPI) -Stockholders of the Evans Products Company approved at a special meeting today a plan to acquire Aberdeen Plywood and Veneers, Inc., of Aberdeen, Wash.
YONKERS, Aug. 3 (UPI) -- Adios Butler, the world record-holding pacer, will race in the $25,000 Hal Dale Pace at Yonkers Raceway Monday night.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 (AP) -- The Senate voted today to give Air Force personnel serving on the Texas towers the overseas allowances they were promised but did not get.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 -- President Kennedy reappointed Frank A. Southard Jr. today as the United States representative to the International Monetary Fund. He has held that position through the Eisenhower Administration and the concluding three years of the Truman Administration.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 (AP) -- The Tariff Commission recommended today that the duty on imported lower-price Wilton, velvet and similar carpets and rugs be increased from 21 to 40 per cent.

LONDON, Aug. 3 -- Prime Minister Macmillan won an easy victory in the House of Commons tonight on his proposal to seek negotiations for membership in the European Common Market. The vote was 313 to 5, with many members abstaining.

C.L. Sulzberger wrote in your July 22 issue that the Shah of Iran is unhappy over American policy toward his country, despite the very substantial economic and military aid the United States has given his Government over the last decade. In fact, your correspondent is fearful that the Shah will turn to Russia for salvation if we do not raise the ante.

The four-story building containing thirty-eight apartments and occupying a plot 100 by 117 feet at 39-82 Sixty-fifth Place, Woodside, Queens, has been sold by the Kod-Rose Holding Corporation, which erected the structure in 1928.

OSAKA, Japan, Aug. 3 (AP) -- Chet Jastremski and Tom Stock, Indiana University students who have been surpassing world swimming records in every appearance in Japan, did it again tonight in the first half of the two-day Osaka swimming meet.

Daily average borrowings by member banks of the Federal Reserve System rose $25,000,000 to $75,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. Daily average reserves in excess of requirements declined $154,000,000 at $495,000,000.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 3 (AP)- The United States asked Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold today to circulate to all United Nation members a United States statement declaring that Cuban authorities had no right to hold an Eastern Air Lines plane hijacked July 4.

HERGISWIL, Switzerland, Aug. 3 (AP) -- A diver went deep into the water of Lake Lucerne today to search for bodies of sixteen American tourists, whose bus plunged into the lake yesterday after having collided with a truck.
PARIS, Aug. 3 -- A French spokesman reaffirmed today that there could be no question of evacuating the French air-naval base near Bizerte in the present state of international tension.
A four-engined cargo plane preparing to take off burst into flames at New York International Airport last night and was destroyed.
BOONTON, N.J., Aug. 3 -- Rain failed to halt the start of the New Jersey Golf Association's four-ball team championship today. Sixty-five teams competed at The Knoll Golf Club course.
TEL AVIV, Israel, Aug. 3 -- The United Arab Republic has approached a United States concern about acquiring a new Israeli process for recovering fresh water from the sea.

A new share listing on the New York Stock Exchange fifty years ago today received little attention from investors, although it represented the first automobile security among the 454 issues then traded on the Big Board.

Retail installment contracts purchased by the General Motors Acceptance Corporation in the April-to-June quarter aggregated $914,600,000, compared with $1,195,000,000 in the 1960 period, according to Charles G. Stradella, chairman, and Thomas W. Towell, president.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 -- The conflict in Congress over the President's request for a five-year advance appropriation for foreign aid is one of the steadily recurring instances in government when both advocates and opponents have strong points in their favor.
In The Guardian of July 20 the stair Cooke quotes a recent dispatch in The New York Times which acknowledged that the British detest the Germans.

Anthony A. Bliss, president of the Metropolitan Opera Association, will hold a press conference Monday afternoon. It is expected that he will make a statement then concerning the Metropolitan's new season which has been threatened by the fact that the Met and Local 802 of the American Federation of Musicians still have not agreed on contract terms.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 3 (AP) -- The Pittsburgh Pirates bombarded St. Louis with a major league season high of twenty-four hits tonight and buried the Cardinals, 19 -- 0. They tied the National League modern record for the highest score in a shutout game.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 (AP) -- The House Merchant Marine Committee approved today a Senate-passed bill to authorize acceptance of donations for the United States Merchant Marine Academy at Kings Point, L.I.
About 150 labor leaders who say they represent 300,000 unionists established a committee last night to aid Mayor Wagner in his Democratic primary fight against State Controller Arthur Levitt.
EL PASO, Tex., Aug. 3 -- A former convict and his 16-year-old son hijacked a jet airliner in the air today. They held control of it for nine hours before they were captured.
OTTAWA, Aug. 3 -- T.C. (Tommy) Douglas, Premier of Saskatchewan, was elected tonight to lead the new Canadian political party, which chose as its name the New Democratic party.

Weary of waiting for legislative relief at Albany, the railroads have carried to court a test of the constitutionality of New York's "full-crew" laws that have for many years required overmanning of some trains under the guise of "safety." The Public Service Commission, after prolonged study, recommended repeal of the laws as a built-in mandate for featherbedding, unnecessary to safety, which can be adequately assured by regulation.

Pleasure boating is a sport in which the yacht owners and skippers want to know the whys and wherefores of the craft they take out to sea. It is a participation sport. The man at the wheel commands his own destiny.
NEWBURGH, N.Y., Aug. 3 (UPI) -- City Manager Joseph McD. Mitchell said today he would use "thought control" over his social workers as the next phase of his welfare crackdown.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 3 -- After feverish backstage negotiations, backers of Tunisia in her dispute with France said tonight they expected a special session of the General Assembly Monday or Tuesday to discuss the question.

MINEOLA, L.I., Aug. 3 -- Federal Aviation Agency officials said today they were holding to their insistence on a civilian airport at Mitchel Field despite restrictive action by the House of Representatives.
HIROSHIMA, Japan, Aug. 3--The city of Hiroshima, first victim of the Atomic Age, is struggling to prevent its agonies from being used as a major political weapon by the Communists.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 -- The French-Tunisian deadlock over Bizerte appeared to be thawing today following two days of talks between the Tunisian Defense Minister, Bahi Ladgham, and high Administration officials.

A report by Maurice Hindus on the Russian people, based on a visit to his native land last year, will be published by Doubleday on Aug, 18. It will be titled "House Without a Roof: Russia Forty-three Years After the Revolution." The author says the people in Russia are ignorant of conditions beyond the Iron Curtain, particularly about Berlin.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 3 -- An eight-week hearing on a Department of Justice petition to block the merger of two big Philadelphi banks ended today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 -- The Senate took up a record $46,848,292,000 defense appropriations bill today. It included $207,600,000 for civil defense protection against possible nuclear attack on this country.
In a sense, a world's fair is a type of advertising medium, since nations and companies display their wares in the hope of improving their "corporate images."
BABYLON, L.I., Aug. 3 -- A hold-up man stole a commuter's car here this morning, robbed a bank in near-by North Lindenhurst of $967 and then returned the car to its parking field.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 -- Secretary of State Dean Rusk expressed confidence today that the major Western powers would agree this weekend to face the Berlin crisis "with firmness and determination and also reasonableness."
BALTIMORE, Aug. 3 (AP) -- Hal Brown extended his scoreless inning streak to thirty-two tonight as the Baltimore Orioles whipped the Minnesota Twins, 3 -- 0.
LOS ANGELES, Aug. 3 (AP) -- The Los Angeles Dodgers scored the winning run on a tenth-inning error by Joe Amalfitano and defeated the San Francisco Giants, 4 -- 3, tonight.

TUNIS, Aug. 3 -- Belkacem Krim, Vice President of the Algerian rebel Government, charged here today that France was preparing to set up "a vast political, economic and military organization" in the Sahara.
The Alfred P. Sloan Foundation reported yesterday it had granted a total of $18,400,000 to 161 colleges, universities, medical research centers and other institutions in 1959 and 1960.

THERE is no doubt that the freezer has been the greatest aid in preparing sandwiches since they were invented. (The sandwich is supposedly an eighteenth-century brain child of the Fourth Earl of Sandwich.) Freezing not only avoids a hectic round of last-minute preparation, but also helps keep sandwiches fresh on the way to the picnic ground.
DETROIT, Aug. 3 (AP) -- Jim Bunning's four-hit itching and Rocky Colavito's thirtieth home run enabled the Detroit Tigers to defeat the Washington Senator, 2 -- 1 today.
PORTSMOUTH, N.H., Aug. 3 -- The Navy's newest and most modern nuclear submarine, the U.S.S. Thresher, joined the fleet at commissioning exercises this afternoon at the Portsmouth Naval Shipyard.

HOUSTON, Tex., Aug. 3 (AP) -- Some of the passengers from Continental Airlines' highjacked jet passenger plane arrived here by another plane this afternoon. Most of them said they were not frightened during the time they were held prisoner.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 (AP) -- United States District Judge J. Cullen Ganey, who levied almost $2,000,000 in fines and sent seven men to jail in the Government's anti-trust case against electrical companies, today was nominated by President Kennedy to be a judge of the Third United States Circuit Court.
