I wish to express appreciation for and agreement with the views expressed in the letter of Frederick L. Redefer, published July 21, commenting on The New York Times account of changes in the second year of the Contemporary Civilization program in the Columbia College curriculum.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 (AP) -- Loading of atomic fuel on the nuclear ship Savannah will start about Sept. 1, the Atomic Energy Commission reported today.

Sixteen Asian newspaper executives will attend a three-week seminar organized by the American Press Institute of Columbia University. The seminar, which begins today, is designed to help build free, responsible, strong newspapers, to provide the visitors with an accurate picture of the United States and to help increase American understanding of Asia.
PARIS, Aug. 2 (Reuters) -- Oleg Cassini, Jacqueline Kennedy's official dressmaker, is in Paris attending several of the couture openings.

To obtain much-needed funds for the multiple nonprofit ventures initiated by the American National Theatre and Academy, the tax-exempt organization, which holds a Congressional charter, is contemplating the sponsorship of "A Man for All Seasons."
The oppointment of a new Secretary of the Armed Forces for the Dominican Republic was made known here yesterday by the Dominican Consulate General.

Sales of the National Dairy Products Corporation in the quarter and six months ended on July 1 were higher than in the 1960 periods. Increased costs of raw materials narrowed the company's profit margins, reducing earnings from the record levels of a year earlier E.E. Stewart, chairman, and J. Huber Wetenhall, president, said in their report to stockholders.
FITCHBURG, Mass., Aug. 3 (UPI) -- A pioneering New England paper company put in a bid today to be one of the first United States manufacturers to adapt atomic power to its business.
TUNIS, Aug. 3 -- President Habib Bourguiba offered France a negotiated settlement in the Bizerte crisis today.
Successful surgical removal of blood clots in the lungs, a serious complication of some types of surgical operations, was reported yesterday.

The Gulf Oil Corporation yesterday named W.C. Brodhead to succeed the late Carl F. Vander Clute as manager of its marine department. The oil company, which operates one of the major privately owned tanker fleets in the world, recently completed a $114,000,00 modernization of its United States fleet.

As a variation on the house-and-garden theme, a committee of Westchester residents has arranged a tour of twelve swimming pools in Rye, N.Y., and Purchase, N.Y., on the afternoon of Aug. 21 as a benefit for the Herald Tribune Fresh Air Fund.

Your July 27 editorial raised the question as to why the Reform Democratic movement endorsed Mayor Wagner after many of its leaders, including myself, had been critical of certain aspects of his administration.

The Crane Company, Chicago plumbing equipment manufacturer, has traded its disputed 21 per cent interest in the Briggs Manufacturing Company to the American Metal Products Company for AllianceWare, Inc., a subsidiary of American that produces pressed-steel plumbing fixtures.

Thomas J. Fitzharris, whose letter appears in The Times of July 31, identifies himself as a Catholic, and makes the statement that he is "interested in seeing that any Federal aid to education is offered to all children, regardless of the school they attend."

THE clothes they wear are just as important in their work as the cameras they use, according to five women who have successfully invaded the male-dominated world of industrial photography. However, when it comes to a choice between being fashionable or getting good pictures, they agree that the pictures are likely to be more important.
CINCINNATI, Aug. 3 (AP) -- The Cincinnati Reds collected fifteen hits tonight to rout the Philadelphia Phils for the fifteenth straight time this season, 7 -- 1.

CHICAGO, Aug. 3 (AP) -- The highest rated group of college football all-stars ever assembled, with an attack built around Joe Bellino, Norm Snead, Bill Kilmer and Tom Matte, will face the Philadelphia Eagles tomorrow night at Soldier Field before a crowd of 65,000.

EXOTIC woods are in vogue again. Buyers who viewed wholesale furniture showings in Chicago in June found themselves transported back to their grandmother's Victorian drawing rooms by the sight of rosewood chairs, chests and tables.
Robert Moses dug the first ground yesterday in a nine-month project that will turn 1,900 feet of the Flushing River underground.
Chen Cheng, the Vice President and Premier of Nationalist China, bustled through a strenuous day of social and official appearances here yesterday.
COWES, Isle of Weight, Aug. 3 (AP) -- United States skippers held on to the lead in the race for the Admiral's Cup today despite failing to finish among the first three.

TUNIS, Aug. 3 -- Habib Bourguiba, the talkative President of Tunisia, bears the title in the Neo-Destour party of "Supreme Combatant." The No. 2 man in the Government and party, Bahi Ladgham, also has a special party sobriquet: "The Silent Chief."
WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 (AP) -- The Federal Aviation Agency is looking for simplified plumbing to avert future hydraulic system failures in airliners.
BERLIN, Aug. 3 -- The three Western commandants in Berlin pressed the Soviet commander today to put an end to measures against East Berliners who work in West Berlin.
GOTEBORG, Sweden, Aug. 3 (AP) -- Jim eaBtty and Frank Budd led an American contingent to five victories in an international track and field meet tonight.

Yankee blunders provided the Kansas City Athletics with a heal start toward the winner's circle last night at the Stadium. The notorious Yankee finishing kick never appeared and the Athletics won, 6 -- 1, without serious challenge.

The Radio and Television Executives Society, which announced last April it would start presenting annual radio and television awards in October, has postponed the project. It had set up twenty-five award categories, including those for outstanding programs and performances by actors and actresses.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 -- Department store sales in the nation in the week ended Saturday, July 29, were 2 per cent above the year-ago level.
SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 3 -- A heavy rainfall forced the cancellation of play today in the Southamption invitation tennis tournament at the Meadow Club.

Members of Local 282 of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters have turned down an improved employer proposal for ending the month-long strike of 1,200 concrete mix drivers. This newest rejection of peace terms means that thousands of additional building mechanics besides the 50,000 already laid off because of the strike will soon be without work and that millions of dollars worth of new construction will be further delayed.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 -- The national tournament of the American Contract Bridge League entered its sixth day at the Sheraton Park Hotel here today. The three-session contests for masters' pairs and women's pairs got under way, and the masters' team contest for the Nat B. Spingold Trophy continued.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (AP) -- Secretary of Commerce Luther H. Hodges named five officials today to assist in the depressed-areas program.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 -- The possibility of Government ownership of a space communications system underwent a significant revival in Congress today. Hitherto, it had long been regarded as a dead issue and had been rejected by the Kennedy Administration.
TRENTON, Aug. 3 (AP) -- The New Jersey Supreme Court issued a stern set of rules today barring nearly all court employes from political activity. It is certain to cause a furor in many a courthouse.
CHICAGO, Aug. 3 -- Newton N. Minow, chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, was chided by a Harvard professor today for oversimplifying the nature of television's "vast wasteland."
DETROIT, Aug. 3 (AP) -- The General Motors Corporation was threatened today by a strike of the International Union of Electrical Workers.

OCEANPORT, N.J., Aug. 3 -- Despite rainy weather on four of the last five racing days, Monmouth Park continues to draw horse-playing wetbacks who pour large numbers of soggy greenbacks through the mutuel machines.
LONDON, Aug. 3 -- Prices of leading industrial shares bounded ahead in the stock market here today. But government securities set new lows for the second successive day.
An innovation in the competition of trans-Atlantic airlines for air freight will offer shippers the chance for a profitable gamble.
CHICAGO, Aug. 3 (AP) -- Profit cashing raked the grain futures market from top to bottom today and most commodities finished lower, some off sharply in spots.

EL PASO, Tex., Aug. 3 -- An athletic Immigration Service officer with a potent right hand played a principal role in foiling the attempted hijacking today of a Continental Airlines jet plane by a father-son team.
CHICAGO, Aug. 3 (UPI) -- Lew Burdette pitched a three-hitter today to lead the Milwaukee Braves to a 5-2 victory over the Chicago Cubs.

Second-quarter results of American Metal Climax, Inc. (AMAX) were higher than those of the preceding three months but were well below the second quarter a year ago. First-half results also declined, the company reported yesterday.
A twenty-six-foot aluminum statue was affixed to the facade of the new American Field Service headquarters at 313 East Forty-third Street yesterday.

The halfway mark in the sixteen-game match between Bobby Fischer and Samuel Reshevsky, at the Herman Steiner Chess Club in Los Angeles, was reached with the eighth game adjourned after forty moves Thursday night.

DETROIT, Aug. 4 (AP) -- The Detroit Tigers snapped a weeklong hitting slump tonight by smashing eleven hits, including home runs by Al Kaline and Jake Wood, that helped Frank Lary to a 6-1 victory over the Cleveland Indians.
For people who like animals there is satisfaction in knewing that wild beasts have some tolerance for the human species. This was demonstrated during the recent strike which closed the Bronx Zoo.

Three major ports on the east coast of Africa are spending nearly $50,000,000 to improve and expand harbor facilities in a rapidly growing economy. The ports -- Durban, Beira and Mombasa -- are part of a broad area including such widely separated ports as Monrovia, Abidjan, Lagos and Walvis Bay, all on the west coast, in which ship congestion has been the norm during the last few years.

CHICAGO, Aug. 4 (AP) -- Fred W. Hooper's Crozier, unable to win since the Kentucky Derby Trial although close up in many big races, will get another chance in the fifty-first running of the $100,000-added American Derby tomorrow at Arlington Park.
DETROIT, Aug. 4 -- Automobile dealers sold 420,026 new domestically-built cars in July, compared with 538,746 units in June.

A GOOD investment for the cook interested in enlarging her culinary repertoire are paperback cookbooks. More than sixty such volumes are in print now. Some are of little value, but others are a relatively inexpensive source for a variety of American and foreign recipes.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 -- Contestants in the masters' men's pair and women's pair contests played the second qualifying round today in the American Contract Bridge League's national tournament at the Sheraton Park Hotel here.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 (AP) -- A civilian employe of the Army Map-Service acknowledged today that he belonged to the Fighting American Nationalists, an organization associated with the American Nazi party. He is Schuyler D. Ferris, His dismissal has been demanded by Representative Seymour Halpern, Republican of Queens.

ATHENS, July 27 -- Greece expects to earn more than $100,000,000 from shipping this year. George Andrianopoulos, Merchant Navy Minister, made this forecast in announcing that remittances by shipowners and seamen, as well as taxes on ships, yielded $40,110,000 in the first five months of 1961 -- a 25 per cent increase over the same period last year.

More than 3,000,000 residents of New York City have, by keeping their permanent registration in good standing by regular voting and by enrolling in a political party before last November's election, made themselves eligible to cast their ballots in the Sept. 7 primary. For certain others, but not all, it is still possible to qualify, but time is short.
Consolidated Gold Fields of South Africa, Ltd., London, has expanded its share holdings in the American Zinc, Lead Smelting Company through open-market purchases, it was reported.
The American Broadcasting Company hopes to tape a Shakespearean play as presented in the theatre at Stratford-on-Avon, England, for showing next summer.
LOUISVILLE, Ill., Aug. 4 (AP) -- Led by an armored half-track, more than 100 policemen and Federal agents smashed their way into an estate here today to seize a military deserter.

ATLANTA, Aug. 4 (UPI) -- Thirty-eight cases of poliomyelitis were reported in the United States last week. The total was more than three times the figure for the previous week, the Federal Communicable Disease Center said.

After a talk at the White House on Wednesday with the leaders of the United States delegation to the special meeting of the Inter-American Economic and Social Council, which opens in Punta del Este, Uruguay, today, President Kennedy said: "The hopes of millions of people throughout the Americas rest to a very large extent on the success of your efforts.

PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Aug. 4 -- Prince Souvanna Phouma, Laotian neutralist leader, appeared today almost certain to become Premier of a new coalition government to be entrusted with the task of ending the three-sided power struggle in Laos.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 (AP) -- President Kennedy's health care program would load an unfair tax burden on young earners, a House committee was told today by spokesmen for the United States Junior Chamber of Commerce and the National Association of Manufacturers.

CHICAGO, Aug. 4 -- If Nick Skorich, the new coach of the Philadelphia Eagles, had any doubts that he would have difficulty replacing Norman Van Brocklin at quarterback, they were removed tonight in the twenty-eighth annual All-Star football game at Soldier Field.

A study of the social and economic revolution that has taken place in the South since 1920 is given by Thomas D. Clark in "The Emerging South." Dr. Clark is Professor of American History and chairman of the Department of History at the University of Kentucky, as well as author of a number of books.
CIUDAD TRUJILLO, Dominican Republic, Aug. 4 (AP) -- Policemen armed with clubs and machine guns went into action today against a group of opposition supporters.
A well-dressed young man quickly and quietly stole jewelry, valued at $71,600 from a display case in the Colony restaurant yesterday afternoon.
Leading manufacturers of corrugated boxes are raising prices 10 to 14 per cent. The containers are used to package a wide variety of consumer and industrial goods.
BERLIN, Aug. 4 -- The East German Communists took two more steps today in their campaign against commuters who work in West Berlin.
If the Mayoral election had been held yesterday in the Rockaways, in Queens, Republican Louis J. Lefkowitz probably would have won -- beach sandals down.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 4 (AP) -- George Airman slammed his twentieth and twenty-first homers of the season and drove in three runs tonight as the Chicago Cubs defeated the second-place Los Angeles Dodgers, 4 -- 2.
BALTIMORE, Aug. 4 (AP) -- Ken Venturi, battling wind and rain five holes from home, carded a 69 for 137 and held a one-stroke lead in the Eastern open golf tournament today.

NEW "ORLEANS, Aug. 4 (AP) -- The United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit ruled illegal today the expulsion of six students from Alabama State College for Negroes. The six staged a sit-in in a courthouse lunch grill and were expelled without notice.
"Right this way, ladies and gentlemen," began this newspaper's highly laudatory review of "Jumbo" in 1953, after Billy Rose's giant-sized circus musical had settled in the vastness of the Hippodrome.
MILAN, Italy, Aug. 4 (AP) -- Italy, bidding for another shot in the challenge round, gained a 1-1 tie with Sweden today in the opening singles matches of the European Zone Davis Cup tennis final.
DETROIT, Aug. 4 -- A group of Chrysler Corporation stockholders who are not satisfied with recent changes in the company's management met here today to make plans for a proxy battle.
McKEEVER, N.Y., Aug. 4 (AP) -- This Adirondacks hamlet has been sold to an auctioneer who says he plans to cut the community into parcels and resell them at a public auction.
YONKERS, N.Y. Aug. 4 -- The police hurled tear gas bombs into a house tonight to drive out a man who was suspected of having killed another in an argument.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Aug. 4 -- Israel is a country of cruel contradiction and paradox par excellence. Born from the dream of a Jewish state, Israelis disagree on what a Jew is except that he can be defined neither religiously nor racially. Yet rabbinical influence intrudes.
CHICAGO, Aug. 4 (AP) -- Export and mill buying firmed wheat futures prices today on the Board of Trade but other commodities were mixed or weak in rather slack dealings.
BALTIMORE, Aug. 4 (AP) -- Jack Fisher stopped the Los Angeles Angels, 3-0, on five hits in the second game tonight to give the Baltimore Orioles a split in a well-pitched doubleheader.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 4 -- The class winners in one of the two really long runs of the New York Yacht Club cruise today were Henry Mercer's 12-Meter Weatherly, James J. O'Neill's Stormy Weather, Gregory B. Smith's Welkin, W. Stuart Caldaras' Baroda and A.E. (Bill) Luders Jrs. Storm.
Governor Rockefeller and Mayor Wagner brought pressure in separate actions yesterday for a speedy settlement of the five-week-old strike of 1,200 concrete mix drivers.

Sales of notions in department stores, variety chains and other outlets are running at the record rate of more than $600,000,000 a year, with further sales rises of 3 to 6 per cent in prospect for fall and Christmas, it was reported yesterday by the National Notion Association, Inc.

GLEN COVE, L.I., Aug. 4 -- Robert Gilmartin and son, Robert Jr., of North Hempstead today regained the Long Island father-son golf championship they held two years ago by scoring a 36, 38-74 over the Nassau Country Club's par 35, 35-70 course.

HERGISWIL, Switzerland, Saturday, Aug. 5 (AP) -- Swiss skin divers early today recovered the bodies trapped in the tourist bus that took sixteen Americans to their death at the bottom of Lake Lucerne.

I was greatly disappointed in the favorable treatment The Times has given President Kennedy's military build-up address to the nation. "Spot-check Finds Nation Firm in Backing President." I am disappointed in the current militant mentality of the American people and their allies.
Observers from the World Council of Churches and the Roman Catholic Church have been invited to attend the Pan-Orthodox meeting to be held on the Island of Rhodes Sept. 24 to Oct. 1.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 (UPI) -- The House Merchant Marine and Fisheries Committee approved today a bill liberalizing the terms of the preferred maritime mortgage law.
Cotton futures moved 15 cents a bale off to 40 cents up yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange.

STONY BROOK, L.I., Aug. 4 -- The boundaries of a former cornfield were marked off here today to start another search for the body of a 36-year-old society matron who disappeared twenty-four years ago.

The twelve-story store and office building at 180 Broadway between John Street and Maiden Lane has been sold by Walter and Matthew P. Berger. It is on a plot 26 by 100 feet. The buyers were investing clients of Philip Gold of the Prywes Realty Company, broker.

The Louisiana Land and Exploration Company reported yesterday that its net income for the first six months of this year was $11,873,704, equal to $1.32 a share. This compared with $11,061,787, or $1.23 a share, for the 1960 period. Total income increased to $24,137,231 from $22,150,195.

After a ten-game hiatus in his assault on Babe Ruth's homerun record, Roger Maris resumed with a bang last night at the Stadium, belting No. 41 in the first inning. However, it made only a momentary impression on the Minnesota Twins, who did not succumb to the Yankees until Johnny Blanchard smacked his fourteenth of the season in the tenth.

ATHENS, Aug. 4 -- Edwin A. Link of New York, industrialist and submarine explorer, was fined $740 today in Corinth, fifty-one miles southeast of Athens, for having engaged in unauthorized underwater archaeological activity.

The Republican party cry has always been that the Democratic party has been "soft on communism" and that wars have always been brought about by Democratic Administrations. Therefore, President Kennedy must show that his Administration is not "soft on communism" and that a modus vivendi can be had with the Soviet Union.
TULSA, Okla., Aug. 4 -- Robert H.W. Welch Jr. disclosed today that the John Birch Society would conduct a $2,300 essay contest this fall on "grounds for the impeachment" of Chief Justice Earl Warren.

VANCOUVER, B.C., Aug. 4 -- The British Columbia Provincial government announced here today a $100,000,000 issue of 5 per cent Government parity bonds to reimburse the British Columbia Electric Company for a check sent to the British Columbia Power Corporation.
Antonino Rocca, the professional wrestler, received a suspended sentence in Traffic Court yesterday after he told the Magistrate he had spent $122 to fly here to answer a speeding charge.

OCEANPORT, N.J., Aug. 4 -- Christopher T. Chenery's 2-year-old colt Sir Gaylord, a winner of three stakes, heads the field of eleven in Monmouth Park's $123,410 Sapling Stakes, tomorrow's closing-day feature.
A proposed new City Charter that would increase the power of the Mayor and create a larger and more powerful City Council was filed with the City Clerk yesterday.
Departmental charges were preferred yesterday against twenty-six school employes accused of accepting Christmas gifts and gratuities from contractors doing business with the Board of Education.

The Sheraton Corporation of America attained record revenues in the fiscal year ended on April 30 and slightly higher net income than that of the preceding year, the annual report of Ernest Henderson, president of the hotel company, disclosed yesterday.

The General Dynamics Corporation and its subsidiaries had a net loss of $39,532,496 in the first six months of this year after allowing for a tax credit of $44,044,000, the semi-annual report disclosed yesterday. In the 1960 period the company had a net income of $12,095,151, equal to $1.22 a share on the 9,946,080 shares then outstanding.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 (UPI) -- A House-Senate conference committee made a token cut of about $75,000,000 today in President Kennedy's request for his stepped-up space program.

MOSCOW, Aug. 4 -- The Soviet Union confronted the Western powers today with the alternative of negotiating a Berlin solution on Moscow's terms or contending with an enforced change in the status of the isolated city.
NEW ROCHELLE, Aug. 4 -- The Board of Education voted 5 to 1 tonight to ask the United States Supreme Court to hear an appeal in the Lincoln School desegregation case.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 (AP) -- A group of labor-relations experts conferred today with Secretary of Labor Arthur J. Goldberg on methods to revise the national emergency strike procedures of the Taft-Hartley Law.
I, too, must take issue with your editorials regarding Senator Barry Goldwater and the Newburgh contretemps.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 4 -- Jon Douglas played one of his best matches of the season today on soft turf heavy from yesterday's rain. He overcame the blazing shotmaking of Whitney Reed in the Southhampton invitation tennis tournament, 6 -- 2, 3 -- 6, 6 -- 2.

BONN, Germany, Aug. 4 -- The West German Government announced its readiness today to comply with any requests by the North Atlantic Treaty Organization that would put more flesh and punch into the country's armed forces.

HAVANA, Aug. 4 -- Five hundred thousand people -- about one-twelfth of Cuba's population -- are now enrolled in neighborhood, factory and farm vigilence committees, according to an announcement made here today.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 -- In his recent speech to the nation on Berlin and the Communist challenge, President Kennedy said he would be glad to have suggestions on what to do.

"HIS OWN MAN,"* by Martha Gellhorn, is a novel about an American in Paris. Although he is decidedly no diplomat, the fellow is engaged right up to his ears in international affairs. They are private ones of course -- if any privacy includes becoming the talk of beau-monde Paris.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 -- Senator J.W. Fulbright vigorously defended today President Kennedy's request for authority to borrow from the Treasury to finance long-term foreign aid.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 -- The United Arab Republic's Embassy here denied today that its Government had approached a United States concern about the purchase of a new Israeli process for desalting sea water.
James Reston's column of July 28 "How to Read a Newspaper Without Gasping" was a most useful how-to in these slightly hysterical times.

A TRIO of old friends revisited Lewisohn Stadium last night: Haydn and Mozart, who appeared on the program for the first time this season, and the pianist Jose Iturbi, returning after twelve years' absence.

The Kennedy Administration has made a moderately good start in filling the 106 vacancies in the Federal courts -- both by the Attorney General's request to the Senate for approval of the three recess appointments made by President Eisenhower and by the nominations President Kennedy has made.
RYE, N.Y., Aug. 4 -- A candidate for Mayor of Rye sleeps with his head in Rye and his feet in Port Chester. The boundary of the communities cuts across his bed at home.
EL PASO, Tex., Aug. 4 -- Federal authorities moved quickly today to seek indictments against a former convict and his son who hijacked a jet airliner.
BOONTON, N.J. Aug. 4 -- A schoolboy pair was among the teams to move through the opening round of the New Jersey four-ball golf championship at The Knoll Golf Club today.
The Youth Consultation Service of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York will be the beneficiary of the Nov. 13 performance of the musical "How to Succeed in Business Without Really Trying."

THE full implications of the first legal evidence of a new baby -- an 8 by 8 1/4 inch scrap of paper marked Certificate of Birth -- may be lost on ecstatic, but inexperienced parents. This bit of evidence actually represents an investment of $20,000, according to specialists in the field.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 (AP) -- Master mortgage and down payment terms for houses costing $20,000 and more were authorized today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 -- A control device invented for Gulton Industries, Inc., of Metuchen, N.J., makes possible delicate engravings in glass, gem stones and mother of pearl by ultrasonic drilling. The tip of the drill vibrates about 20,000 times a second, cutting the material without creating heat.
An elderly Florida couple who realized "we can't take our money with us," are using some of it to take twenty-four members of their family on a Caribbean cruise instead.
PORTLAND, Ore., Aug. 4 -- The Oregon Journal, one of the city's three newspapers, was sold here today to Samuel I. Newhouse of New York. The price was estimated at $8,000,000.
A travel agency clerk with a knack for imitating an English aristocrat was being sought yesterday by the police of thirteen states on charges of swindling his employer out of at least $50,000.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 4 -- Cuba made new charges today that the United States was on the verge of armed aggression against her.
BRITAIN, an island kingdom in the Atlantic, took a long look at Japan, an island kingdom in the Pacific, on Channel 7 last night.

OTTAWA, Aug. 4 -- The founding convention of the New Democratic party of Canada ended tonight after party neutralists were overwhelmingly defeated in a move to commit the party to withdrawal from the Atlantic alliance.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 -- The State Department disclosed today that it had considered but rejected, for the time being, the idea of curtailing trade with the Soviet bloc in retaliation for threats to West Berlin.

BIG FLATS, N.Y., Aug. 4 (AP) -- William T. Smith, a farmer, and a Government agency have come to an agreement over his 1960 wheat crop. Mr. Smith will not have to pay a fine of $321.84 for exceeding his quota.
The Government's suggestion that airline crews carry guns to prevent the hijacking of planes was widely opposed in the aviation industry yesterday.
CHICAGO, Aug. 4 (UPI) -- One engine of a United Air Lines DC-8 jetliner with 128 persons aboard caught fire shortly after take-off from O'Hare International Airport tonight.
LONDON, Aug. 4 -- The British Government announced agreement today on an increased program of aid to Tanganyika after that East African territory becomes independent Dec. 9.

LENOX, Mass., Aug. 4 -- Clouds, some of them threatening rain, passed across the sun all day at Tanglewood, where the Berkshire Festival is holding forth. By twilight, however, the sky had cleared to provide a benign evening for tonight's concert.

PARIS Aug. 4 -- Former Gen. Raoul Salan, fugitive leader of the attempted military coup in Algeria last April, was hailed today as France's "indispensable man" and future chief in a pamphlet circulated here.

PARIS, Aug. 4 -- A sharp case of jitters is building up among West German officials as the Western Allies prepare to work out a new negotiating position on the potentially explosive Berlin and German issues.
Six foreign student joined snoozing and newspaper-reading commuters on the 3:22 train yesterday afternoon to Pleasantville, N.Y.
PARIS, Aug. 4 -- The Western foreign ministers gathered here today, unanimously determined to defend West Berlin against pressure from the Soviet Union.

PUNTA DEL ESTE, Uruguay, Aug. 4 -- A message from President Kennedy will open the inter-American economic conference here tomorrow. The hemispheric meeting will con sider the application of the President's Alliance for Progress program of aid to Latin America.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 -- Ordinary buildings can provide considerable protection against radioactive fall-out, specialists of the Atomic Energy Commission told Congress today.
Eugene Rhodes, a Harlem slum landlord, turned up in Housing Court again yesterday, charged with twenty-two violations, some of which dated to March, 1957.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 4 -- Two fillies -- one of whom has beaten colts and the other with a record of nine victories in ten starts -- will meet tomorrow in the eighty-first running of the Alabama Stakes. There are four other 3-year-old fillies in the historic mile-and-a-quarter race, but they are expected merely to provide background for the stars.
CINCINNATI, Aug. 4 (AP) -- Frank Robinson's double in the ninth inning broke a 4 -- 4 tie tonight and gave the Reds a 5 -- 4 victory over the Pittsburgh Pirates.
CALCUTTA, India, Aug. 1 -- A 160-year-old Jewish community with a New York-trained rabbi is gradually dwindling toward extinction here.
TUNIS, Aug. 4 -- The Soviet Union has granted Tunisia a ruble credit calculated to be equivalent to $27,750,000 it was announced tonight.
DETROIT, Aug. 4 (UPI) -- Chrysler Corporation and the United Auto Workers accused each other today of stalling in contract negotiations.
NORWALK, Conn., Aug. 4 -- The draft of the charter providing a strong mayor form of government will be put before Norwalk's voters in November.

Civil Aeronautics Board experts began an inquiry yesterday into a fire that damaged an Eastern Air Lines cargo plane late Thursday night as the aircraft was taxiing for a take-off at New York International Airport in Idlewild, Queens.

The five-and-a-half story building containing thirty-eight apartments and occupying a plot 75 by 100 feet at 680 East 140th Street, the Bronx, has been sold by Lyman Lautman. It was bought by an investing client of Milton Cooper, lawyer, for $65,000 in cash over a mortgage.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 (AP) -- Senate investigators were told today that the United States could start now to build components for around-the-clock service with a satellite communications system.

The Tennessee Gas Transmission Company and subsidiaries reported yesterday gains in operating revenues and net income for the twelve months ended on June 30. Revenues for the June quarter also rose, but net income fell well behind the level of the 1960 period.
GENEVA, Aug. 4 -- The United States proposal for an international version of its Peace Corps program was adopted today by the United Nations Economic and Social Council.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 4 -- A special session of the United Nations General Assembly next week to discuss the French-Tunisian dispute over Bizerte was confidently predicted tonight by members of the African-Asian group.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 -- The index of average wholesale primary market prices rose 0.1 per cent during the week ended last Tuesday, to 118.7 per cent of its 1947-49 base, the the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 -- The Administration now plans to increase the size of the armed forces by 185,000 men instead of the 225,227 President Kennedy announced last week.

LONDON, Aug. 4 -- Prime Minister Macmillan told Britons in a television broadcast tonight that there was "perhaps" a possibility of negotiating with the Soviet Union over West Berlin, but he said the West would stand firm on its rights.

F. Scott Fitzgerald's daughter has written a musical about politics called "See How They Run." She has completed the music and lyrics but is looking for someone who will collaborate with her on the libretto.
Bond prices drifted down again yesterday.

OGDEN, Utah, Aug. 4 (AP) -- The National Boxing Association middleweight champion, Gene Fullmer, today remained the favorite to defeat Florentino Fernandez, but the Cuban was given a puncher's chance to score an upset.
Few issues of fixed-interest securities are slated for public sale next week but a number of major equity issues are set tentatively for offering to the public.
OSAKA, Japan, Aug. 4 (AP) -- Chet Jastremski of Toledo, Ohio, continued his assault on world breast-stroke records tonight in the Osaka swimming championships.
PICTON, Ont., Aug. 4 (AP) -- Miss Supertest III, Canada's high-powered defender, opens its bid tomorrow to become the first boat to win the Harmsworth Trophy three times.

A TALENT scout seeking a "pillar of society" might pick John Thomas Cahill in spite of the fact he unassumingly rides the subway to his office in downtown Manhattan. A powerfully built, carefully groomed man with close-cropped white hair and thick, black horn-rimmed spectacles, Mr. Cahill radiates respectability and quiet dignity in the most prosaic circumstances.

OTTAWA, Aug. 4 (Canadian Press) -- A substantial drop in exports in May sharply increased Canada's commodity trade deficit for the first five months of the year to $107,200,000, the Dominion Bureau of Statistics reported today.
LOS ANGELES, Aug. 4 (UPI) Parole officers for Beardon de scribed him today as "kind of a sharpie" but probably a stooge for someone else in the plot.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 (AP) -- Senator Strom Thurmond, Democrat of South Carolina, said today that Senator J.W. Fulbright, Democrat of Arkansas, had attacked military efforts to inform Americans about "communism and the 'cold war.'" He proposed a formal investigation.

YONKERS, Aug. 4 -- A track record of 2 minutes flat gave Su Mac Lad an easy victory in the $25,000 Scott Frost Trot at Yonkers Raceway tonight. In front virtually all the way, Su Mac Lad was a length and a half ahead of the runner-up, Air Record, at the finish of the mile race.
Out of the twenty-five-foot excavation it had dug for the foundation of the new Princeton Club of New York a sixty-five-ton power shovel crawled slowly up to West Forty-third Street yesterday.

Following, a transmitted in English by the Soviet press agency Tass, is the text of the Soviet note to the United States on the Berlin and German questions that was handed to the United States Ambassador in Moscow Thursday (Parallel notes were delivered to the envoys of Britain, France and West Germany):
Mayor Wagner moved yesterday to end the city's 5 per cent admissions tax for legitimate theatres. He said legislation to effect the repeal would be sent to the City Council for early action.
LONDON, Aug. 4 -- Industrial shares scored further large gains in the stock market here today -- but British Government securities continued to tumble.
The Wagner administrator is taking steps to prevent a threatened strike of artists in the city on Sept. 11.

CHICAGO, Aug. 4 -- Most television and radio broadcasters are going to conform to the programing standards suggested by Newton N. Minow, chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, rather than run the risk of committing "business suicide," a prominent Washington lawyer said today.
As the Western foreign ministers meet in Paris to plan the defense of West Berlin, the focal point of the Soviet drive against the free world, they have before them two new developments.
A running mate of State Controller Arthur Levitt in the mayoral campaign offered a program yesterday to bolster police morale.

TUNIS, Aug. 4 -- Tunis is beginning to come out of the state of shock provoked by the French military occupation of the city of Bizerte and its environs two weeks ago. But the toll of 670 Tunisian dead -- the count is official and probably not exaggerated -- is still a major preoccupation here.

BOSTON, Aug. 4 (AP) -- Norm Bass, making his first start far the Kansas City Athletics in five weeks, beat the Boston Red Sox, 5 -- 0, tonight on a four-hitter. Norm Siebern's 420-foot homer was all the support he needed.

BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 4 -- Cuba's Consul General in Uruguay, Leonardo Bravo Puig, and the Cuban Consul General in Argentina, Vitalio de la Torre y Perez, requested and have been granted political asylum here, the Argentine Foreign Ministry has announced.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 -- Britain will withdraw the largest amount ever to be removed from the International Monetary Fund. She will use the money to cover international debts and to strengthen the pound.
BAGHDAD, Iraq, Aug. 4 (Reuters) -- Premier Abdul Karim Kassim has renewed his claim to the neighboring sheikdom of Kuwait.

NEWBURGH, N.Y., Aug. 4 -- Supreme Court Justice John P. Donohoe reserved decision today on the state's request for an injunction to halt operation of Newburgh's stringent new welfare code and on the city's motion for dismissal.

Joseph Saker, a co-owner with William Bresnahan Jr. of the Fair Acres Stable of Freehold. N.J., yesterday denied a charge that he and his partner on several occasions had asked a driver "not to try and win" a race.
TEANECK, N.J., Aug. 4 -- To prevent the creation of a Negro ghetto here, a Fair Housing Committee is circulating an anti-bias petition for presentation to the Town Council.
Bonanza Air Lines, which appears to have struck a rich lode in excursion fares, has come up with another travel plan, which it describes as "entirely new for airlines."

GLEN HEAD, L.I., Aug. 4 -- Mrs. Pat Cici of the Lido Club, the 1959 winner, defeated Carol Beinbrink, Southward Ho, 10 and 9, in the final of the sixth annual Women' Cross County Golf Asosciation match-play championship at the Brookville Country Club today.
ST. LOUIS, Aug 4 (AP) -- Julian Javier and Jim Schaffer hit two-run doubles in a leading twelve-hit attack as the Cardinals beat the Philadelphia Phillies, 9-8, tonight.

Stocks reached new highs yesterday for the fourth time this week as prices advanced on the New York Stock Exchange.

Bankers acceptances outstanding in the United States rose by $67,681,000 in June to a new high at $2,270,681,000, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York has reported. This was a counter-seasonal increase and raised the total $888,682,000 above the level of a year earlier.

REHOBOTH BEACH, Del., Aug. 5 (UPI) -- The United States may skid toward an economic disaster if all of President Kennedy's "pie-in-the-sky" proposals are approved, William E. Miller, the Republican national chairman, said today.

BOONTON, N.J., Aug. 5 -- Jack Reilly Jr. of Spring Brook decided to keep a date as best man at a friend's wedding today. But his golf partner didn't waste time waiting at the tee. He went on alone and won.

PARIS, Aug. 5 -- The negotiations for Britain's entry into the European Economic Community will present one of the most formidable technical problems in the history of international diplomacy.

AUCKLAND, New Zealand, July 26 -- Threatened with the loss of traditional outlets in Britain, New Zealand is making strenuous efforts to develop a favorable climate to expand sales in the United States.
Skin diving oceanographers are set to plunge into a patch of ocean near Bethany Beach, Del., tomorrow. They will loose dyes and photograph the hues as they are carried away by underwater currents.

THE language barrier is one of the major problems facing those who would like to see the United States develop a significant tourist trade. For all its historic reputation as a melting pot of diverse nationalities, this country is ill-equipped, linguistically, to cope with foreign visitors who have little or no English at their command.

Pedro and Ricardo Rodriguez, the racing brothers from Mexico City, will be members of the Ferrari factory's Grand Prix team next year, according to the gossip around Rene Dreyfus' Chanteclair Restaurant Round Table.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 5 (AP) -- Jim Brewer, who had appeared in twenty-four games this season without a victory, started for the Chicago Cubs tonight as they sought their second straight victory over the Los Angeles Dodgers.

MILWAUKEE, Aug. 5 -- Some 1,500 residents of a section of Philadelphia staged a violent demonstration recently when Mayor Richardson Dilworth proposed that they pay $40 a year for the privilege of parking all night on city streets.

COLUMBIA, the 12-Meter yacht, may or may not be the gem of the ocean, depending upon what develops at sea this season and next, but she is the gem of Shields and Company. Paul V. Shields, the head of the Wall Street firm of investment bankers, has made her his special pride as the new owner. So has Cornelius Shields Sr., his brother and partner.
BOSTON, Aug. 5 (AP) -- Vic Wertz of Boston drove across four runs with a triple, double and single today as the Red Sox defeated the Kansas City Athletics, 10-4.

WHEN Florence Nightingale sailed to the Crimea in 1854, among her nurses were five Roman Catholic Sisters of Mercy who served with her throughout all the horrors, intrigues and jealousies of that historic mission. In "Florence Nightingale's Nuns" Emmeline Garnett tells the story of their devotion and service and of their deep and lasting friendship with Miss Nightingale.

Britain's move to enter the European Market presages considerably more than economic confederation of Western Europe. The British action promises also, by effecting European unity, to give vitality to the larger Atlantic Economic Community, of which the United States and Canada are members.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 -- Ever since the disastrous failure of the Cuban invasion last April, the Central Intelligence Agency, which was in charge of planning and executing the attempt, has been the center of controversy here. Despite the inability of helicopters to retrieve the space capsule used by Capt. Virgil I. Grissom, Project Mercury officials have tentatively decided to use the same aircraft in future recovery operations.

Thedecision was taken at a meeting of the Warsaw Pact countries here Thursday through yesterday.

DACHAU, Germany -- This small residential town, a suburb of thriving, driving Munich, has two points of interest for the American traveler. The first is the Dachau Concentration Camp Museum, all that remains of the Nazi Germany death camp in which so many thousands of men, women and children were dispatched in the crisp efficiency of the crematorium. The second is the United States Army base at Dachau.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Aug. 5 -- Tennessee River traffic set a ton-miles record in 1960. But it is off for the first six months of this year because of the collapse of the Wheeler Dam navigation lock in Alabama.

DENVER, Colo. -- Every cross-continent route in this country goes through the Great Plains, which contain a fifth of the land area of the United States, but only 3 per cent of the population. Frank Kenna, Queens Republican leader, and four associates were accused in a city report yesterday of having "blackjacked" builders into paying $156,000 for appraisals that were never made.

Major Titov's successful trip into space yesterday and safe return to earth is one of the most dramatic technological achievements in human history. It leaves us almost speechless with admiration for the man and for those who made his feat possible. Both deserve praise and are getting it. But all this brilliance is marred by the swift Russian propaganda campaign to exploit this latest Soviet space feat for political and psychological warfare ends.

Loud praises of Mickey Mantle reverberated through the Stadium yesterday as the celebrated slugger slammed three home runs that helped the Yanks sweep a double-header from the Minnesota Twins. The scores were 7 -- 6 and 3 -- 2.
A realty syndicate has contracted to sell three downtown apartment buildings, having a total of 289 apartments, to the Morgan Holding Corporation, Manny E. Duell, president.

PUNTA DEL ESTE, Uruguay, Aug. 6 -- The United States hopes to dramatize at the Inter-American Economic and Social Conference here its three major targets of Latin social development: Primary education, land reform and low-cost housing.
CINCINNATI, Aug. 6 (AP) -- Vada Pinson's home run in the tenth inning enabled the Reds to beat the Pirates, 3 -- 2, today and gain a split in a doubleheader. The Pirates took the first game, 9 -- 4.

Four Negro leaders came to the defense of Superintendent John J. Theobald in the school controversy yesterday. They charged that current attacks on him were in "savage reprisal" for his efforts to integrate the schools.

HALIFAX, N.S., Aug. 6 (UPI) -- Maj. Yuri A. Gagarin, the Soviet Union's first man in space, cut short a visit to Halifax today. He flew to Moscow intending to greet his fellow astronaut, Maj. Gherman S. Titov upon his return from space.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 6 -- The Women's Christian Temperance Union is declaring war anew on the liquor traffic at its eighty-seventh annual meeting in this city. It is doing this with prayers, hymn-singing and hard-hitting speeches.
LONDON, Aug 6 (AP) -- Factory sirens and auto horns blared when the Soviet spaceship passed over East Berlin late in the afternoon, according to an East German news agency dispatch.

Revlon, Inc., reported yesterday for the first half of this year a net income of $5,500,000, or $1.05 each on the average of 5,252,668 shares outstanding. This was a 6 per cent gain over the net income in the first half of 1960 of $5,200,000, or $1 each on the 5,202,920 common shares then outstanding.

WHITE PLAINS, Aug. 6 -- "Terribly bad directional signs" were blamed today for some of the increasing accidents on high-speed highways north of New York City.

NUERBURGRING, West Germany, Aug. 6 -- In a brilliant display of virtuoso driving, Stirling Moss today won the Grand Prix of Germany and Europe in a Lotus. He held back two Ferraris far faster than his own car for 212.4 miles -- fifteen blazing laps of this dangerous 14.2-mile circuit through the Eifel Mountains.

PARIS, Aug. 6 -- The Western foreign ministers reaffirmed today the West's willingness to negotiate the Berlin question on a "reasonable basis," but postponed a decision on whether to take the initiative for such talks.

WASHINGTON. Aug. 6 -- Concern is developing among some Administration officials and exiled Dominican leaders here over events in the Dominican Republic. Increasingly severe reprisals are reported to have been taken by the Dominican regime against democratic opposition parties.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 -- The first reactions of Administration officials to Premier Khrushchev's address today added up to the view that it contributed almost nothing to a solution of the Berlin problem.

Dr. Gordon A. McLean will become deputy manager and secretary of the trust division of the American Bankers Association on Sept. 1, it was announced yesterday by Dr. Charls E. Walker, executive vice president. Dr. McLean has been secretary of the economic policy commission of the association's department of economics and research.

BLOOMFIELD, N.J., Aug. 7 -- Robert Foehl of Woodhaven, Queens, fired a three-over-par 35, 38 -- 73 and led the qualifiers in The New York Journal-American's junior golf tournament today at the Forest Hill Field Club.

The Glidden Company plans to expand its chemical line through a proposed merger with the Pemco Corporation, Baltimore producer of inorganic coatings. City Democratic organizations are ready to file designating petitions with the Board of Elections today on behalf of State Controller Arthur Levitt, their candidate for Mayor. The petitions bear more than 270,000 signatures.

NUERBURGRING, West Germany, Aug. 7 -- Midsummer is a quiet time for organized sports in Europe and the stage mostly is left to the curious and the bizarre. The wrestling arenas of Paris are closed, but the suburban arenas are going full blast with woman wrestlers starring.

Steel production around the country rose 1.8 per cent last week from the preceding week's level, which was 2.2 per cent below that of the week earlier, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday. DETROIT, Aug. 7 (AP) -- Automobile production this month may reach its lowest level for the month of August since the end of World War II.

CHICAGO, Aug. 7 -- The General Electric Company said today that it was offering utilities a full line of atomic power plants designed on the basis of data compiled at the Dresden nuclear power station near Chicago.
ATHENS, Aug. 7 -- Fifteen wooden vases made by Greek artists 2,500 years ago have been discovered during excavations near Athens, it was announced here today.

The city paid tribute yesterday to India's great poet, playwright and philosopher, Rabindranath Tagore. As part of a world-wide centenary celebration of his birth, Times Square officially became Tagore Square for the occasion.
EL PASO, Tex., Aug. 7 (UPI) -- A United States grand jury indicted Leon Bearden and his 16-year-old son Cody in the hijacking of an airliner last Thursday.
BABYLON, L.I., Aug. 7 -- Details were announced today of the study of Great South Bay to be made by the state Water Pollution Control Board beginning Aug. 15.

Several thousand jewelers converged on the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel yesterday to see several million dollars worth of jewelry, heavily guarded around the clock by polite but firm Pinkerton men in uniform.

The C.I.T. Financial Corporation, the nation's largest independent sales finance company, reported yesterday net earnings of $21,429,000, or $2.22 a common share, for the first six months of 1961. That compared with $21,196,000, or $2.20 a common share, for the first six months of 1960.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 (UPI) -- Lieut Col. Elizabeth Ray, former Oklahoma newspaper woman and World War II veteran, was named today Director of Women in the Air Force.

LENOX Mass., Aug 7 -- Successful scoundrels generally make good subjects for comedy. Take, for example, Baron Theodore von Neuhoff, an eighteenth-century personage who by guile and charm got himself elected King of Corsica.

GREEN BAY, Wisc., Aug. 7 (AP) -- Vince Lombardi, the general manager and coach of the Green Bay Packers, today was given a new five-year contract -- and probably a pay rise -- for his job in rebuilding the team into a National Football League power.
The newest Soviet space achievement poses some ugly military implications for the future.
Although a number of critics and advertising men already have written off the coming television season as an artistic disaster, indications are that it will be a ringing commercial success.
After wobbling back and forth in an indecisive fashion, stocks closed thoroughly irregular yesterday. Prices, on average, showed a minor loss on the New York Stock Exchange.
YONKERS, N.Y., Aug. 7 -- Adios Butler achieved his ninth straight victory tonight, this one in record-time, and the rich got richer at Yonkers Raceway.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 7 -- The plan of the Barnes Foundation to charge $2 for admission to its art museum when it is reopened Sept. 1 was blocked today by the Montgomery County Orphans Court. The museum is in suburban Merion, which is in Montgomery County.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 (AP) -- A youth who clashed with Rotarians in Miami, Fla., over the film "Operation Abolition" is traing for the Peace Corps, R. Sargent Shriver, director of the corps, said today.

LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, Aug. 7 -- The Soviet-backed regime led by Antoine Gizenga in Stanleyville has declared itself "dissolved" in favor of the Congo's new Central Government of Premier Cyrille Adoula.

Rejection by the United States of the new agreement to regulate international trade in cotton textiles and products was urged yesterday by an official of the Association on Japanese Textile Imports. Samuel Ishikawa, secretary-treasurer of the group, cited two reasons for rejection of the one-year, sixteen-nation agreement approved at Geneva on July 21 as a short-term solution to broad problems of textile trade. They were:

WHITE PLAINS, Aug 7. -- Hod carriers and common laborers in the building trades in Westchester will be getting a minimum of $148 a week within three years, according to the terms that ended a six-day strike today.

The safe landing of the Soviet cosmonaut, Gherman S. Titov, after orbiting the earth seventeen times in a space capsule, marked the climax of man's greatest single adventure so far. It was a triumph for Soviet space technology and engineering. But it was also a triumph of the human mind and spirit, regardless of political or geographical boundaries.

LONDON, Aug. 7 -- The United States Sixth Fleet in the Mediterranean is already at full strength and will not be affected by President Kennedy's plans to build up Western military and naval forces, Vice Admiral David L. McDonald, the fleet's new commander, said here today.
HONG KONG, Aug. 7 -- A Soviet trade delegation headed by Pavel N. Kumykin, deputy Minister of Foreign Trade, arrived in Peiping today, according to Hsinhua, the Chinese Communist press agency.

MOSCOW, Aug. 7 (UPI) -- Following is the transcript of the telephone conversation between Premier Khrushchev and Maj. Gherman S. Titov after the astronaut's space flight, as reported by Tass, the Soviet press agency:
Ethiopia, which is preparing to enter the jet age, has signed a contract with a New York engineering concern to improve her airports.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 -- Automobile makers were told today to pledge to install control devices against air pollution on 1964 cars or face compulsion by Congress.
Union and industry spokesmen in the five-week-old strike by 1,200 concrete mix drivers resumed face-to-face bargaining yesterday after a joint meeting with state, Federal and city mediators.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 (AP) -- Paul M. Butler, former chairman of the Democratic National Committee, is to be appointed by President Kennedy to the advisory board of the St. Lawrence Seaway Development Corporation.

MOSCOW, Aug. 7 -- Premier Khrushchev combined tonight a proposal for a conference on Berlin with a warning that Soviet divisions might mass on the West European frontiers as a precautionary defense measure.

All domestic sugar futures fell to new lows for the lives of the contracts yesterday on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange. The decline reflected a drop in the spot price to the lowest level since March, 1960.
NEW DELHI, India, Aug. 7 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru said today that he was sure the United States had no intention of letting the arms it supplied to Pakistan be used against India.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 (UPI) -- The House today passed and sent to the Senate a bill that would prohibit premanently a former Federal employe from representing a private party in any matter on which he acted while with the Government.

CARACAS, Aug. 7 -- Venezuela supports Iraq in its request for postponement of a scheduled petroleum conference, according to officials here. The conference of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries was to be held in Baghdad this month.
Bowling balls, like baseballs, apparently are livelier than they were twenty-five years ago. This is because bowling balls are softer than they used to be, according to one expert.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 -- Treasury bill rates advanced on today's sale of the regular weekly issues for the third successive week. Today's rates were the highest in two months.
DETROIT, Aug. 7 -- The United Automobile Workers again asked the General Motors Corporation today for information on its price-profit formula.
Louis J. Lefkowitz, the Republican organization candidate for Mayor, went prospecting for votes on the sidewalks of Brooklyn yesterday.

MOSCOW, Aug. 7 (AP) -- A Soviet eyewitness reported today that Maj. Gherman S. Titov had been fired into orbit in a silver space ship that looked like a "roaring fiery globe" as it shot upward from a barren plain.

Loans to farmers by the Government's Farmers Home Administration are expected to set a record for the year to end June 30, 1962, according to Orville L. Freeman, Secretary of Agriculture. He estimated that the loans would reach $481,500,000, well above the previous peak of $395,700,000 in fiscal 1961.

Whether Wagner, Levitt, Gerosa, Lefkowitz or somebody else is elected the next Mayor of New York, he can be a better Mayor if voters on Nov. 7 approve the new City Charter that has been completed on time by the Cahill commission. Every one interested in city government had preconceived ideas of what a revised Charter should be.
Although business wasn't exactly booming yesterday at the opening of the first Eastern Housewares Show at the New York Coliseum, exhibitors were not complaining.

BEACH people whose sun-bleached or just plain worn wardrobes are in need of a little refurbishing will find, although stores are already in an autumnal mood, that there still is a variety of seasonless odds and ends that will serve their summertime purposes.

Incorporated Investors reported yesterday net assets of $318,870,668, equal to $8.50 a share, on the 37,521,257 shares outstanding on June 30. This compared with $306,254,746 or $8.63 a share on 35,497,847 shares outstanding a year before.
PASADENA, Calif., Aug. 7 -- A leading Soviet astronomer indicated today that the Russians would now concentrate on rocket shots at the moon.
IN this city, where a number of well-dressed citizens bare their feet at the first whiff of hot weather, any American who also wants to wear sandals is advised to get a pedicure.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 (AP) -- The Government today revoked the brokerage license of D. Earle Hensley Company Inc. of Seattle, Wash., holding that the company had engaged in fraudulent dealings.

The long, tortuous process of getting the Federal Government and the states of New York, New Jersey, Pennsylvania and Delaware together on a Delaware River compact is nearly finished. Only a few reservations by high Federal officials need to be met or overcome before a unified water resources agency for the Delaware River Basin can come into being.
Cotton futures moved 1 point off to 5 up yesterday in light trading on the New York Cotton Exchange. A point equals 5 cents a bale.
NEW DELHI, India, Aug. 7 -- India made public today a $24,360,000,000 program to develop her economy over the next five years.
Teams from Long Island and New Jersey won semi-final matches in the Eastern Lawn Tennis Association's Junior Davis Cup matches yesterday at the West Side Club, Forest Hills, Queens.

President Kennedy evidently took particular pleasure yesterday in signing the bill that created the Cape Cod National Seashore Park. He had supported this measure when a Senator. What the bill does is to set aside the whole outer beach and a considerable portion of the inner beach that fronts on Cape Cod Bay and enfolds Provincetown within its protecting arm.

Reflecting the sharp rise in sales, the Minnesota Mining Manufacturing (3-M) Company, in the three and six months ended June 30 lifted earnings well above those for the corresponding periods of last year, according to a report issued yesterday.

BLACKSBURG, Va., Aug. 7 (AP) -- America must stop fooling around and initiate an intense "manhattan project" to meet the space achievements of the Soviet Union, a group of the nation's top space scientists were told here today.
The $5,000,000 borrowed by the New Haven Railroad last week with an Interstate Commerce Commission guarantee does not assure continued operation, the road's trustees said yesterday.

SOUTHPORT, Conn., Aug. 7 -- The Riverside Yacht Club crew, with Eric Muller as the helmsman, held a point lead in the qualifying series for the junior championship of Long Island Sound after the first two races off Pequot Y.C. today.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 -- Angier Biddle Duke, the State Department's chief of protocol, has resigned from the Metropolitan Club in a dispute over its policy of excluding African diplomats.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 -- President Kennedy signed a farm bill today aimed at cutting down surpluses while bolstering farm income.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 (AP) -- A bill providing stiff penalties for crimes on planes sped through the Senate Commerce Committee today.

ONE of the most delicately flavored and aromatic of all herbs is now in full leaf in the New York area. It is sweet basil, a plant that is easy to grow and that thrives in almost all climates. It has a plenitude of uses in cuisine and is listed as one of the first ten herbs in American cookery.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 -- Trained local leaders will be almost as important as adequate group shelters in the event of a nuclear attack, Navy researchers told Congress today.

Stirling Moss' sensational victory at the Nuerburgring in Germany last Sunday puts the world driver championship for 1961 in a new light. Though a couple of miracles and one big if are involved, he now has a chance to win the title that has eluded him all through the Juan Manuel Fangio, MAke Hawt horn and Jack Brabham years.
British girls who embark on a matrimonial career without knowing how to cook do not have to worry any more, according to United Press International.

CHICAGO, Aug. 8 -- The Chicago, North Shore and Milwaukee Railroad reported today that it was facing a "staggering" estimated operating loss of more than $550,000 in 1961. The deficit was foreseen in spite of a voluntary, rider-inspired fare increase last year of 23 per cent, average labor costs lower than any of its three competitors, and maintenance economies that could imperil the safety of the railroad if continued, it was said.

Four major shoe associations have joined in a program to reduce the number of trade shows, improve the timing of the events and increase the promotional activities for the exhibitions, it was announced yesterday.
DETROIT, Aug. 8 (UPI) -- Paul M. Corp, formerly president of AllianceWare, Inc., has been elected president and chief executive officer of the Briggs Manufacturing Company, it was announced today.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 8 -- William Partee's Cavalanche came close to equaling a 15-year-old record in winning the feature race on today's program. Participating in a five-and-a-half-furlong race against eight rivals his own age, the 2-year-old ran the distance in 1:03 4/5.
CHICAGO, Aug. 8 (AP) -- The report of today's livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
MOSCOW, Aug. 8 (AP) -- The Soviet Union's most controversial scientific figure, Trofim D. Lysenko, has been elected president of the Soviet Academy of Agricultural Sciences.

" Shadow of Heroes," purporting to be the inside story of the Hungarian revolt in 1956, will open Nov. 14 at the York Playhouse. Robert Ardrey is the author of the drama, which traces the uprising to 1944.

CHILDREN'S tours of the Metropolitan Museum of Art begin at 11 A.M. Mondays through Fridays. This week's tours will examine "Ancient Egypt," "The Age of Exploration," and "French Paintings," among other subjects.
Carmine G. De Sapio mounted a counter-attack against Mayor Wagner yesterday in answer to the Mayor's charge last Saturday that Mr. De Sapio was leading a "battalion of corruption."
MOSCOW, Aug. 8 -- Maj. Gherman S. Titov said today he had "felt like a real pilot" when he took over manual control of his space ship.

The fact that Trans World Airlines, Inc., had brought suit against its chief stockholder, Howard Hughes, caught many observers by surprise yesterday. For several months there had been a growing belief that at any time Mr. Hughes might be the plantiff in a suit involving T.W.A., instead of a defendant.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 -- It may be decided Friday whether an inter-American observers' group will return to the Dominican Republic.

The New York City Ballet will begin a three-week season Aug. 29, at the City Center. Twenty-six works are scheduled for presentation. None will be new, but one, Jerome Robbins "The Cage," will be restored to the repertory after an absence of a year and one-half.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 -- The policy and security operations of the State and Defense Departments have been unsatisfactory to President Kennedy, but improvements are being made, an Administration official has told Congress.

The Pennsylvania General State Authority borrowed $25,000,000 in the bond market yesterday to finance public works. The money was raised by the sale of serial bonds running out to 1988 at an interest cost of 3.54416 per cent.
YONKERS, Aug. 8 -- The withdrawal of Sprite Kid from Thursday night's Yonkers Futurity Trot at Yonkers Raceway today cut the field from nine to eight and the purse from $101,830 to a mere $100,330.
EUGENE, Ore., Aug. 8 (AP) -- Sandra Spuzich of Indianapolis upset the medalist, Sherry Wheeler of Glasgow, Ky., 1 up, today in the Women's Trans-Mississippi Golf Association tournament.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 -- The masters' team-off-four contest, last event of the American Contract Bridge League's national tournament that has been going on here since July 29, developed into a three-team final round that began tonight and will be completed tomorrow afternoon.

Mayor Wagner stepped into the Metropolitan Opera dispute yesterday. He invited Al Manuti, president of Local 802 of the American Federation of Musicians and other union officials to meet with him at City Hall today at 3 P.M.
The Transit Authority is investing $10,800 in new light bulbs to save $29,400 annually in replacement and power costs on the IND subway division.
SWANSEA, Wales, Aug. 8 (Reuters) -- A heavy shower brought cricket play to an end in midafternoon today, with Glamorgan fighting hard against the Australian bowlers.

MYSTIC, Conn., Aug. 8 -- A guest lecturer at the weekly session of the Munson Institute course in American maritime history pointed out here today that petroleum now represents 85 per cent of all seaborne traffic in the principal New England ports.

CHICAGO, Aug. 8 -- "Jewish life in Russia is now virtually at an end," J.I. Fishbein, editor and publisher of the Sentinel, Jewish weekly newspaper in Chicago, reported today after a three-week tour of the Soviet Union.

PORT-OF-SPAIN, Trinidad, Aug. 8 -- The Theatre Guild Repertory Company's American presentation of Thornton Wilder's "The Skin of Our Teeth" received a thunderous ovation and seven curtain calls from a capacity audience in Queens Hall last night.

Kurt W. Marek, cultural historian, who is better known as C.W. Ceram, author of "Gods, Graves and Scholars," "The Secret of the Hittites" and of "The March of Archaeology," has written another book titled "Yestermorrow."
WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 (AP) The Department of Agriculture today forecast this year's Government-controlled cotton crop at 13,918,000 bales of 500 pounds gross weight each.
The conviction of a man who was "pilloried by the court and unprotected by his own counsel" was reversed yesterday by the United States Court of Appeals. A new trial was ordered.

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), Aug. 8 -- Israel's Attorney General, Gideon Hausner, began today a wrathful summation of Israel's case against Adolf Eichmann. He portrayed the former Gestapo officer as an unrepentant henchman of Hitler.
MINEOLA, L.I., Aug. 8 -- Robert Moses, president of the Long Island State Park Commission, today recommended five new boating safety laws.

BLOOMFIELD, N.J., Aug. 8 -- A fifteen-foot putt for a birdie 2 on the 197-yard eighteenth hole enabled Martin Schlissberg of the Bronx to take the lead at the end of the first round of the metropolitan junior golf tournament staged by the Journal-American at the Forest Hill Field Club today. Schlissberg had a 74.
Union and industry negotiators reached a "negotiated proposal" last night for settlement of the five-week strike by 1,200 concrete-mix truck drivers.
ALBANY, Aug. 8 -- The State Conservation Department official who sued Louis A. Wehle for slander agreed today to accept a $37,500 verdict in place of the 875,000 he had been awarded by a trial jury.
THE beginning of the school year is more than a month away, but for incoming college freshmen it is not too early to start making plans.

Charges of conspiracy and extortion against John J. McNamara, a former Teamsters Union official and close associate of John (Johnny Dio) Dioguardi, labor racketeer, were dismissed yesterday by General Sessions Judge Gerald P. Culkin.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 -- The Administration appears to have decided that Moscow must make the first move in the diplomatic maneuvering over Berlin if the issue is to be resolved by negotiations.

RYE, N.Y., Aug. 8 -- Wes Ellis Jr. established a course record of 63 at the Apawamis Club today in the eighth annual one-day pro-amateur golf tournament for the benefit of the United Hospital of Port Chester, N.Y.
The American Book Company is planning to expand through the proposed purchase of the McCormick-Mathers Publishing Company, Inc., a textbook publisher of Wichita, Kan.

THE new, white passenger liner San Roque (7,000 tons, twin screws, turbine engine) was of Panamanian registry. CHICAGO, Aug. 8 (AP) -Gains in the grain futures trade today were few and limited mainly to three corn contracts which rallied moderately from their lowest levels of the season on the Board of Trade.
BONN, Germany, Aug. 8 -- Dr. Frank Buchman, founder of the Moral Re-Armament movement, died last night of a heart attack at Freudenstadt in southern Germany. He was 83 years old.

The five-story building containing seventy-two apartments and five stores at 2135 Grand Avenue, the Bronx, has been purchased by Lazar Seidenfeld for investment. It is on a plot 182 by 100 feet. The sale was made for cash over mortgages of $288,234 through Nathan Rikelman, broker.
Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz, freed of threat of a primary contest for the Republican nomination for Mayor, assailed Mayor Wagner on two counts yesterday.
The president of the Board of Education gave a low mark to one of the three schools he visited yesterday in a continuing check on the school building and maintenance program.

PARIS, Aug. 8 -- Western information officials who conferred here concurrently with the meeting of foreign ministers are agreed that "what we must do is to capture the headlines of the world" from the Soviet Union.

THE following menu is suggested as a guide to the use of foods that are reasonable in cost. A recipe is given for an easy-to-prepare main dish.
The downward price drift of the high-grade bond market persisted yesterday, but the afternoon trading brought scattered indications of a return of firmness.
Nearly 600 young men appeared yesterday at the Army Recruiting and Induction Center, 39 Whitehall Street, for processing in line with this country's increase in military preparedness.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 (UPI) -- The Army issued formal orders today converting three training divisions into combat-ready outfits that could be deployed to Europe on short notice.

The United States is preparing to send some more money into Iran. The authorities in Washington must wonder: is it worth while after all these years, after so much money and so little, apparently, to show for it?
A communications system that can move information between distant points more than 1,000 times as fast as the human voice was demonstrated yesterday by International Business Machines Corporation.

METUCHEN, N.J., Aug. 8 -Mrs. Joseph Rudnick of Jumping Brook carded a 45, 43 -- 88 today and gained the second-round lead of the Elizabeth Goss Memorial round-robin golf tournament with a plus 14 total. Points are scored on the basis of winning holes.
CLEVELAND, Aug. 8 (AP) -- A passed ball with the bases filled in the tenth inning allowed the winning run to score tonight as the Indians defeated the Washington Senators, 6-5.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 -- The House of Representatives rejected today an Administration proposal to convert a plutonium-producing reactor at Hanford, Wash., into the world's largest atomic power plant.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 -Representative Dale Alford in effect called upon the voters of Arkansas today to retire Senator J.W. Fulbright from public life.
BALTIMORE, Aug. 8 (AP) -- Haywood Sullivan's three-run homer with two out in the ninth inning gave the Kansas City Athletics a 6-5 victory tonight and a split with the Baltimore Orioles.
The New York Rangers of the National Hockey League will begin their home season on Thursday night, Oct. 12, against the Boston Bruins at Madison Square Garden.

The International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (World Bank) added $95,300,000 to its reserves during the fiscal year ended on June 30, raising the total reserves to $601,800,000.
DETROIT, Aug. 8 (UPI) -- The United Auto Workers planned a billboard publicity campaign today to counter Ford charges that its contract demands were inflationary and the most costly in history.

Injuries in city traffic last week totaled 929 in 645 accidents, the Police Safety Bureau reported yesterday. This was a decrease from 1960, when 1,025 persons were injured in the comparable period. Three persons were killed last week, compared with ten a year ago.

The Hambletonian, last held in this state in 1956, may return in 1963.
A system to be used instead of communication satellites for transoceanic broadcasting was demonstrated here yesterday.

EARLY in the first act, Donald Cook, witty, confident, immaculately dressed, took command of the revival of "The Moon is Blue" at the 41st Street Theatre last night. He never let go. He is re-creating the role of the middle-aged libertine he played in the original version that opened on Broadway in 1951 and ran for twenty-six months.
SOUTHPORT, Conn., Aug. 8 -- The Cold Spring Harbor Beach Club crew was ahead after the first two races in the final round of the Long Island Sound junior sailing championships today.

EVEN the most optimistic old-timer will reluctantly concede the good old days can never be brought back. And yet, they're about to give it another try. In the final week of September they are going to revive the six-day bicycle race in Madison Square Garden. And that should bring out the old boys.

WASHINGTON. Aug. 8 -- The House Rules Committee sent Attorney General Robert F. Kennedy's controversial program for apprehending fugitive felons to the full House today. The committee vote, taken after heavy opposition from witnesses, was reported to have been close.

Stocks advanced in early trading yesterday but then came under pressure in the afternoon. The turnabout, however, was not sharp enough to cancel all of the earlier gains. The result was a minor rise on average in prices on the New York Stock Exchange.
VIENNA, Aug. 8 -- Nine leading Austrian intellectuals accused the Government today of ruining Austria's reputation by its policy against Italy in the Alto Adige district of Italy.
NAIROBI, Kenya, Aug. 8 -- The Government banned today a secret organization that was said to have been started by former Mau Mau terrorists with the intention of seizing control of Kenya by force.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 8 (AP) -- Ken Boyer hit his second home run of the game and his seventeenth of the year in the ninth inning and gave the St. Louis Cardinals a 6 -- 5 victory over the Cincinnati Reds tonight.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 (AP) -- John M. Bailey, the Democratic national chairman, has rounded out his staff at party headquarters with five new appointments. He continued two others in key positions.

TROODOS, Cyprus, Aug. 8 -- Khrushchev's essential program -- if he does not in the meantime gamble the world into destructive war -- is to increase Soviet industrial output sixfold by 1980 and to leave the United States "far behind." Paperboard production climbed to 328,490 tons last week from 316,686 tons the week before, the National Paperboard Association reported yesterday. It was the fourth successive week-to-week rise. In the comparable 1960 week 320,464 tons were produced.

New Jersey proudly calls itself the "Garden State" because of the famed productivity of its soils. The word garden also connotes beauty, and New Jersey residents have a right to be proud of the many pleasant vistas that greet the eye, from the wooded hills of the north, across the sweeping farmlands, to the pine barrens, the salt marshes and the beaches in the east and south.

The Commercial Credit Company had record consolidated net income of $14,070,774, in the first six months of this year, according to the semi-annual report of Edmund L. Grimes, chairman, and Charles C. Greene, president.
NEWBURGH, N.Y., Aug. 8 -- Welfare Commissioner Peter Z. Petrillo further tightened relief regulations today.
BLACKSBURG, Va., Aug. 8 (AP) -- A map that will enable astronauts to dodge dangerous radiation in space has been devised experimentally at the State University of Iowa.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 (UPI) -- The Justice Department announced that Henry Lower, former president of a Teamsters Union local in Detroit, was indicted today on charges of filing false income tax returns in 1955.
