WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 (AP) -- Officials of the American Petroleum Institute said today that the appointment of Representative Frank Ikard, Democrat of Texas, as executive vice president of the organization was almost certain, but that no announcement would be made until after Congress adjourned.
Arthur Krock's Aug. 4 column on the subject of borrowing authority for foreign aid omits a number of pertinent facts and does not state accurately other facts.
Mayor Wagner finished third yesterday in the number of voters' signatures filed with the Board of Elections in support of his primary designating petitions.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 (UPI) -- The House Interstate Commerce Committee unanimously approved today legislation calling for a broad investigation of stock markets by the Federal Securities and Exchange Commission (S.E.C.).
Second-quarter sales and income of the International Paper Company exceeded the 1960 levels, but half-year results failed to match the 1960 figures, it was announced yesterday.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 8 -- The United States refused today to support for the present the move for a special session of the General Assembly on the Bizerte crisis.
ARMONK, N.Y., Aug. 8 -Mrs. John H. Bartol of Greenwich led the way into the second round of the Women's Westchester and Fairfield Golf Association's thirty-sixth annual match-play championship today.

The Interstate Commerce Commission has been accused of being "arbitrary and capricious" or "clearly in error" on sixteen points in a decision denying North Atlantic ports rail freight-rate parity with Atlantic ports' to the South.
JERSEY CITY, Aug. 8 -- A physician who vanished on a skin-diving trip here eleven days ago was found alive today in Amarillo, Tex.

LONDON, Aug. 8 -- The stock market reopened here today after the long August Bank Holiday week-end with a reversal of last week's pattern. Industrial shares weakened on the withdrawal of support by trustee investors while British Government bonds improved.

WHEN it comes to head-totoe beauty, the toes are frequently forgotten. The pleasures of a pedicure are an unknown quantity to many women, yet hot weather brings two reasons for fitting the feet into the beauty picture.

Foreign investment by United States companies for new plant and equipment this year will amount to some $4,500,000,000, Luther H. Hodges, Secretary of Commerce, said at a news conference in Washington yesterday.
CAMP PERRY, Ohio, Aug. 8 (AP) -- Leslie A. Winter of Bournemouth, England, took the lead in the national small-bore rifle prone championship yesterday with 1,198 of a possible total of 1,200 points.
KLM Royal Dutch Airlines has named Ogilvy, Benson Mather, Inc., to be its advertising agency in the United States.

Rumors of dissent among stockholders of the Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation, widespread through the motion-picture industry in recent months, resulted yesterday in a realignment of company executives but no substantial change.

SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., Aug. 8 -- Robert Mark of Australia elected to compete in the Eastern grass court championships today despite his injured leg. He was beaten by James Shaffer of St. Petersburg, Fla., at the Orange Lawn Tennis Club, 6 -- 1, 6 -- 4.

PARIS, Aug. 8 -- France, prosperous amid plastic bombs and coup rumors, learned today just how affluent she is. The reserves backing the franc have climbed to the equivalent of nearly $3,000,000,000 and the foreign trade surplus is larger than ever, the Government announced.
Borough President John T. Clancy of Queens made known his views yesterday that the city should acquire the two private water supply companies in his borough.
PARIS, Aug. 8 -- The very sharp recovery of the pound sterling in the Last two weeks has had the incidental effect of helping the dollar in various countries of Europe as well.

Retail stores throughout the country were sharply affected by the recession in the early part of the year, according to an analysis of figures made public yesterday by the Controllers Congress of the National Retail Merchants Association.

Contracts awarded for new construction throughout the country in the first half of this year amounted to $18,220,000,000, the F.W. Dodge Corporation reported yesterday. This is an increase of 4 per cent over the comparable period last year, when the total was $17,573,828,000.
PARIS, Aug. 8 (UPI) -- Following is the text of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization communist issued tonight:
WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 (UPI) -- President Kennedy asked Congress today to provide $14,700,000 to pay Governmentguaranteed loans defaulted by the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad.
WASHINGTON, Wednesday, Aug. 9 -- Senator William Proxmire continued to demonstrate yesterday and early today that one way to make a point in the Senate is to deliver a long speech.
For the first time in many years the Democrats in New York City may find themselves without any candidate for a judicial vacancy to be filled at the November elections.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 10 cents a bale off to 25 cents up yesterday.
LONDON, Aug. 8 -- Strong public pressure is building up here for negotiations with the Soviet Union on the Berlin question.
A contract to buy the twenty-two-story Crystal Building at 801 Second Avenue, southwest corner of Forty-third Street, has been signed by Harry G. Silverstein Sons, realty investors.
GENEVA, Aug. 8 -- The International Control Commission, which is attempting to supervise the cease-fire in Laos, has warned of a possible resumption of hostilities between the rival Loatian factions.
The State Investigation Commission decided yesterday to withhold a report on three political figures who, it has said, merit further investigation and "possible disciplinary action."
WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 -- Six members of President Kennedy's Cabinet are planning to visit Japan in the fall.
BERLIN, Aug. 8 -- -The influx of refugees to West Berlin from East Germany increased sharply today, a rise attributed to reaction to Premier Khrushchev's speech last night.
ALBANY, Aug. 8 -- A physician and an educator disagreed today over the wisdom of raising the legal drinking age in New York State from 18 to 21.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 -- Gold, dollars, Deutsche marks, yen and several other major currencies changed hands today in the largest such transaction that has ever taken place.

I should like to disagree with a fellow Christian clergyman whose letter printed Aug. 1 endorsed Senator Goldwater's criticism of the Newburgh program and disagreed with your editorial of July 20 on this subject. It is my strong feeling that the thirteen-point Newburgh plan is substantially contrary to Christian thought and ethics.
CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Aug. 8 (UPI) -- A deadly new-type Atlas intercontinental ballistic missile was fired 5,000 miles into the Atlantic Ocean tonight.
SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 8 (UPI) -- Jack Sanford smashed a two-run homer tonight while pitching the San Francisco Giants to an 8-1 victory over the Chicago Cubs.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 (AP) -- The country's population center has been officially located in a field on the farm of Fred Kleiboeker about a mile south-southwest of Shattuc, Ill., a small rural community.
ATLANTIC CITY, Aug. 8 (UPI) -- Elkcam Stable's Opus unleashed a powerful stretch drive today to overcome Beau Admiral and win the feature $5,000 allowance race, the Claridge Purse, at Atlantic City.
MOSCOW, Aug. 8 -- Workers in Soviet defense industries asked the Government today to extend their work day from seven to eight hours.

DURHAM, N.H., Aug. 8 -- Dr. Eldon L. Johnson, whose championing of academic freedom involved him in disputes with two Governors of this state, resigned today as president of the University of New Hampshire.
HAVANA, Aug. 8 -- Premier Fidel Castro announced tonight the confiscation of all savings in cash above the amount of 10,000 pesos.

In a New Haven Railroad coach on a siding under the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, a film crew started shooting the story yesterday of a Redcap who for more than fifteen years has been conducting prayer meetings in Grand Central Terminal.

BOOKS have always played a major role in the life of Mrs. Augusta Baker, the Coordinator of Children's Services of the New York Public Library. In her new capacity, which she assumed last week, she is in charge of one of the largest collections -- more than 1,000,000 -- of children's books in the world.
PUNTA DEL ESTE, Uruguay, Aug. 8 -- Cuban foes of Premier Fidel Castro, shouting "Long live Cuba! Death to communism!" threw the Inter-American Economic and Social Conference into turmoil today.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 8 (AP) -- The Pittsburgh Pirates beat the Phillies twice tonight in a twilight-night double-header marked by a second-game free-for-all that was game ended by the police. The scores were 10 -- 2 and 3 -- 2.

Kings County Judge Samuel S. Leibowitz made good yesterday his threat to deal harshly with attackers of policemen. He sentenced Rafael Appelaniz, 21 years old, to seven and a half to fifteen years in Sing Sing Prison, terming him "a thug and a wild animal."
HELSINKI, Finland, Aug. 8 (UPI) -- Tom Ripic of Endicott, N.Y., won the discus throw in the IX Olympics for deaf athletes today with a heave of 41.52 meters (136 feet 2 1/4 inches).

Wool prices were strong at the opening of trading yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange. General buying and commission house purchasing pushed quotations more than 2 cents a pound above Monday's close. Heavy profit taking late in the session cut gains about in half.
The Museum of Modern Art has announced a showing of pictures recently acquired for release by its Film Library.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 (AP) -- A substantial cut in interest rates on loans from the Indian Bureau's revolving fund was announced today.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 8 -- United Nations expenditures on economic and social affairs, including technical aid, are the biggest items in the organization's budget and rising rapidly, according to a report published today.
MIAMI, Fla., Aug. 8 -- A "new wave" of Cuban refugees -- fishermen, small farmers, laborers -- has been arriving here in the last few weeks.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., Aug. 8 -- Gus Salerno and Edward Berkin of the Hampshire Country Club carded a gross best-ball 34, 32 -- 66 over the Sunningdale Country Club course today to win the Westchester County Golf Association's eighth annual pro-junior tournament.
VIENTIANE, Laos, Aug. 8 -- A year ago tomorrow a diminutive and obscure paratroop captain led his 800-man battalion in a mutiny that quickly overpowered this capital of Laos.

The seventeen-orbit flight by Maj. Gherman S. Titov has virtually ended chances that this nation might carry out a third short-range manned flight 300 miles out to sea, a space agency spokesman said yesterday.

The Committee for the Rehabilitation of Crippled Children will hold its annual bridge and canasta party in the ballroom of the Pierre on Nov. 13. Proceeds will go to the Cerebral Palsy Recreation Center at 652 West 170th Street.
Charles H. Silver made it clear yesterday that the city's Board of Education did not intend to resign because of recent criticisms of the school system.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 8 (AP) -- Duke Snider drove in two runs and scored three tonight as the league-leading Los Angeles Dodgers dealt Lew Burdette his first Coliseum loss in more than three years by beating Milwaukee, 7 -- 3.

EAST NORWICH, L.I., Aug. 8 -- Mrs. Walter Cooperstein of Harbor Hills shot a 39, 39 -- 78 to win the low gross prize today in the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association's one-day tournament at the Pine Hollow Country Club.

NOERVENICH, Germany, Aug. 8 -- As far as Col. Gerhard Barkhorn is concerned, the fighter-bomber pilots on this small air base are "as good as anything the Luftwaffe had during the height of its success in World War II."
ST. LOUIS, Aug. 8 -- Supreme Court Justice Tom C. Clark warned today that stiff criminal penalties for aggravated violations of the antitrust laws would probably become commonplace.

COLORADO SPRINGS, Col., Aug. 8 (AP) -- Another large defense exercise, Sky Shield II, will be held Oct. 14, it was announced today by the North American Air Defense Command, nerve center of the aerial defense of this country and Canada.

SETAUKET, L.I., Aug. 9 -- The fourth annual summer theatre party in support of the Emma S. Clark Memorial Library here will be at the dance performance of the Andre Eglevsky Company on Sept. 3 at Dogwood Hollow in Stony Brook.
SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 9 -- Shield Bearer held off the closing bid of Jerome Fendrick's Art Market and won the $29 200 Bernard Baruch Handicap today.
SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 9 (AP) -- Matty Alou led off the last of the ninth inning with a home run today, enabling the San Francisco Giants to score a 6-5 victory over the Chicago Cubs.

TOKYO, Aug. 9 -- Dr. Earle L. Reynolds, an American scientist who has devoted the last few years to campaigning against the use of nuclear weapons, was told today he could not attend the Communist-influenced seventh Work Conference Against Atomic and Hydrogen Bombs.

SYRACUSE, Aug. 9 -- The MG Car Club's ninth annual 1,000-mile international sports car rally started its first stage this morning in a maze of traffic circles. Nine hours and 278 miles later most of the twenty-seven teams were counting their errors in hundreds of points.

Continued hot weather and the resultant use of air conditioners last week caused electric power production in the nation to set a record for the third successive week. Output was 16,137,000,000 kilowatt-hours in the week ended on Aug. 5.
KEY WEST, Fla., Aug. 9 (AP) -- A Cuban Navy patrol boat was ordered seized today on behalf of a Miami advertising concern that has a $429,000 court judgment outstanding against the Castro Government.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 -- An increasing impatience with Cuba was indicated in Congress today in the wake of the third theft of a United States airliner in little more than two weeks.
The city has virtually abandoned attempts to rent two small stores that were built into its garage at Eighth Avenue and Fifty-third Street.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 -- The Small Business Administration expressed concern to Congress today of possible discrimination against small businesses in a communications satellite system.
SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 9 (UPI) -- Willie Mays' financial counselor said in court today the outfielder had drawn $65,200 in salary advances because of heavy debts.
DULUTH, Minn., Aug. 9 (UPI) -- Nicholson Transit has closed its doors, sold all its equipment and completely disbanded operations here.
Mayor Wagner attacked Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz yesterday for failing to repudiate Frank Kenna, the Republican party leader of Queens County.
Organization of a mutual savings bank, the first in the state, has been completed in Alaska. The new institution, to be known as the Alaska Mutual Savings Bank, will be in Anchorage.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 9 (AP) -- Julian Javier sliced all opposite-field grand-slam home run in the eighth inning against Pittsburgh tonight as the St. Louis Cards scored their seventh straight victory, 4 -- 0.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 (UPI) -- The Defense and Labor Departments have urged Kennedy to ask Congress to strengthen the job rights or men called to military service in the Berlin crisis.

LONDON, Aug. 9 -- Led by the undated issues, prices of British Government securities leaped ahead in the stock market here today as much as a pound ($2.80). Among the undated bonds the gains represented rises of as much as 3 per cent.

Fischer-Landis, realty investor, has contracted to buy the four-story office and showroom building at 236-38 East Fifty-third Street, near Third Avenue. The building, which was reconstructed last December, is being sold by the Durst Organization, builder.
The development of a central vacuum system for papermaking machines was announced yesterday by the Ingersoll-Rand Company, a leading manufacturer of industrial processing equipment.

The task of reversing growing world doubts of the diplomatic resourcefulness and internal vigor of the United States confronts President Kennedy with unusual imperativeness at his news conference today. Dispatches to this newspaper recounting reactions in Western allied nations to Premier Khrushchev's latest speech, and the bold diversion to Cuba of another hijacked American airplane, are abundant evidence that this burden rests heavily on the President.

Eight of the country's top 3-year-olds will compete in the seventh Yonkers Futurity Trot at a mile and a sixteenth tonight at Yonkers Raceway. The event, worth $100,330, is the first gem of trotting's triple crown.

Baseball's summit conference -- the gab session at the mound, usually between the pitcher and the catcher -- has long intrigued students of the game, who often wonder: "Just what are they saying out there?"
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 9 (AP) -- The Cincinnati Reds tonight defeated Philadelphia, 5 -- 0, behind the six-hit pitching of Joey Jay. It was the sixteenth victory against seven defeats for Jay.

If proof were needed that Mayor Wagner has a hard row to hoe in his campaign for renomination in the Democratic primary, it was provided by the showing he made in getting signatures for his designating petitions.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 (UPI) -- The Justice Department refused a request by the Congress on Racial Equality today to provide Federal marshals to protect Freedom Riders returning to Jackson, Miss., for court appearances next week.
LOS ANGELES, Aug. 9 (AP) -- Don Drysdale hit a grand-slam home run, pitched a four-hitter and struck out eleven batters tonight as the league-leading Los Angeles Dodgers defeated Milwaukee, 8 -- 3.
A food industry pavilion that will offer exotic international snacks is planned for the New York World's Fair.

HUNTINGTON, L.I., Aug. 9 -- Mrs. Joseph Dempsey Jr., of Southward Ho led a field of thirty-six with 41, 38 -- 79 to take the low gross award in the Women's Long Island Golf Association's one-day tournament at Huntington Country Club today.
MADRID, Thursday, Aug. 10 (Reuters) -- A Civil Guard was shot dead and another was injured in a clash with "terrorists" near the French frontier, the Interior Ministry said early today.
HAVANA, Aug. 9 -- Passengers and crewmen aboard the Pan American World Airways jet airliner hijacked over Mexico today spent an almost festive eight hours while detained at Jose Marti Airport here.
PARIS, Aug. 9 (Reuters) -- President de Gaulle conferred today with his top Government leaders and the commander of the French base at Bizerte.

The premiere of "Discovery," described by the American Broadcasting Company as "a new concept in TV programing for children," has been canceled. The network cited "insufficient station acceptances" as the reason.

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), Aug. 9 -- The Israeli police began to close in today on religious zealots who have been hiding a boy from his parents for a year and a half.

BEHIND a shop filled with brand new dolls, stuffed animals and all manner of toys lies a place dear to the heart of doll-lovers. It is the long, narrow "factory" of the New York Doll Hospital at 1021 Third Avenue.
A new bridge was erected over Ninth Avenue between dusk Tuesday and dawn yesterday.

The Underwood Corporation, typewriter manufacturer, has bought the four-story office, showroom and warehouse building at 122 to 130 East Twenty- third Street. The seller was the Wilson-Jones Company of Chicago, which had used the property for its New York quarters.

The sixth draw in the sixteen-game match between Samuel Reshevsky and Bobby Fischer was recorded at the Herman Steiner Chess Club in Los Angeles Tuesday night. The series thus remained tied, 5 -- 5.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 -- Premier Khrushchev's remark that Soviet scientists could build a warhead equivalent to 100,000,000 tons of TNT was viewed today by United States officials as a technical and military possibility in the nuclear arms race.

The American Shakespeare Festival Theatre and Acade.ly will present its annual awards tomorrow night in Stratford. Conn., "in recognition of Works which stimulate appreciation of Shakespeare and the classical theatre."
WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 -- Mrs. John F. Kennedy announced today that the first of a series of Concerts for Young People by Young People would be presented on Aug. 22 on the south lawn of the White House.
Hope for a 1961-62 season at the Metropolitan Opera was renewed last night.
MOSCOW, Aug. 9 -- Premier Khrushchev warned tonight that the Soviet Union had the capability of constructing a rocket with an explosive warhead equivalent to 100,000,000 tons of TNT.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 -- Gen. Walter Bedell Smith, Dwight D. Eisenhower's chief of staff in Europe during World War II, died of a heart attack tonight at Walter Reed Hospital.
CHICAGO, Aug. 9 (AP) -- Light but steady pressure weakened prices of grain and soybean futures again today on the Board of Trade. Losses ranged from small fractions to nearly 2 cents a bushel.
Fairfax County, Va., borrowed $9,125,000 in the bond market yesterday to finance public improvements.

SPRING LAKE HEIGHTS, N.J., Aug. 9 -- Ed Famula, a 25-year-old professional from Galloping Hill, fired ten birdies today for a course-record 32, 32 -- 64 and took the first-round lead in the New Jersey Professional Golf Association tournament at the Homestead Country Club.

The announcement that the United States and the Soviet Union have agreed on a direct Moscow-New York air service comes as a welcome contrast to much other current news about relations between our two countries.

SOUTHPORT, Conn., Aug. 9 -- The Noroton (Conn.) Yacht Club captured the Pequot Cup, symbolic of the junior sailing championship of Long Island Sound, for the fourth straight year today and the fifth time in six years.

GREENWICH, Conn., Aug. 9 -- The Convent of the Sacred Heart here will benefit from a fashion show and tea, "September Song," to be held at the school on Sept. 27. The event is under the sponsorship of the faculty and alumnae of the convent, and it is hoped it will become an annual one.
JIMMY DURANTE had a one-hour show on Channel 4 last night in which he shared the stage with two other formidable headliners, Bob Hope and Garry Moore.

SALISBURY, Southern Rhodesia, Aug. 9 -- British authorities outlawed today the United National Independence party in the Northern Province of Northern Rhodesia. Troop reinforcements were flown to the province.
Sterling Drug, Inc., announced yesterday the election of two officers to new posts in its two major medicinal preparation divisions. They are Carl J. Singler and John F. Roggenkamp.
BAY SHORE, L.I., Aug. 9 -- A largely hostile audience heard arguments today on the state's plan to convert the boulevard-like Sunrise Highway between West Babylon and Oakdale to an expressway.

Step by step up the political ladder the willing Wagner was borne by Tammany and like endorsement of the party regulars.

BLOOMFIELD, N.J., Aug. 9 -- Martin Schlissberg of the Bronx and Peter Dachison of Denville, N.J., placed first and second, respectively, in the New York Journal-American metropolitan junior golf tournament at the Forest Hill Field Club today.
The New York Times of Aug. 2 and 3 published two articles by your correspondent Edward C. Burks, commenting on two recent political incidents that occurred in Chile.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 9 -- The Kennedy Administration received both a commendation and a warning regarding its handling of judicial appointments today from a major committee of the American Bar Association.

CHICAGO, Aug. 9 -- Dr. Andrew C. Ivy completed today an analysis of 4,200 cancer cases treated with Krebiozen, the controversial drug. He reaffirmed his position that the substance had "merit" in treatment of the disease.

BOSTON, Aug. 9 -- This city's first major midsummer play opening in a generation drew a glittering crowd of Bostonians and visiting stage personalities to the Colonial Theatre tonight for the premiere of Noel Coward's musical, "Sail Away."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 -- President Kennedy announced today that he would appoint Judge James Benton Parsons of the Cook County (Chicago) Court to be a United States district judge for the Northern District of Illinois.

Prices of United States Treasury bonds and high-grade corporate debt securities moved in opposite directions yesterday in another trading session dominated by the efforts of professional dealers to adjust trading positions.

VIENTIANE, Laos, Aug. 9 -- Elaborate celebrations were reported being held today in Xiengkhouang, capital of the rebel-held part of Laos, in observance of the first anniversary of the coup d'etat that led to the present civil war.

THE popularity of cold, molded dishes seems fairly constant throughout the summer. The step photographs on this page show the making of a jellied veal and pork loaf, which, with stuffed eggs and a simple salad, would be ideal as a luncheon or supper dish.

HOUSTON, Tex., Aug. 9 -- The 46-year-old oil man who was approved as a member of the Federal Power Commission today after a marathon Senate speech opposing him, got his childhood wish refilled -- the wish to "be somebody."
CLEVELAND, Aug. 9 (AP) -- Testimony on a series of proposed amendments to the Great Lakes Pilotage regulations centered today on the establishment of an apprentice pilot program.

Commercial paper dealers yesterday raised by one-eighth percentage point the interest rate on these short-term unsecured obligations of business concerns sold in the open market.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 9 -- A beaming unofficial salesman for blocks of potential British Columbia-owned electric power came to California today fresh from a power "nationalization" coup in the Provincial Legislature at Victoria.

The New Haven Railroad improved its on-time record in its first month of operation under trustees named to reorganize it. But the trusteeship order on July 7 probably had very little to do with the betterment, a spokesman said yesterday.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 9 -- Cuba formally asked the United Nations today to put "new plans of aggression and acts of intervention" by the United States on the agenda of the next regular General Assembly session starting Sept. 19.
NEW DELHI, India, Aug. 9 -- Under-developed India apparently faces even greater economic austerity in a drive to conserve foreign exchange needed for her growth.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 (UPI) -- The Government assigned to the Massachusetts Institute of Technology today the job of developing a guidance-navigation system for the space craft it hopes will carry three Americans around the moon within four or five years.

Richardson-Merrell, Inc., formerly known as the Vick Chemical Company, attained record sales and earnings in the fiscal year ended on June 30, according to preliminary figures reported yesterday by Smith Richardson Jr., president.

" THE Bachelors,"* by Henry de Montherlant, a celebrated member of the French Academy, is a resolutely gloomy novel written with what seems to be a kind of delighted malice. If you can imagine a play by Jean Anouilh with the cobwebby poetry left out, or a picture by Rene Clair without the high-hearted laughter, you will have a fair idea of Montherlant's approach to the lives of the dispossessed.
CAIRO, Aug. 9 -- The United Arab Republic is in the grip of an economic revolution whose end is not in sight.
SOUTHAMPTON, England, Aug. 9 (Reuters) -- The Cunard Steamship Company has installed slot machines on the 81,000-ton liner Queen Mary "as an experiment," the company said today.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Aug. 9 -- The return here of Harold Arlen after art absence of nine years has dramatized a question that bothers many persons who have faith in the movie world. CHICAGO, Aug. 9 (UPI) -- Frank Lary stopped the Chicago White Sox on five hit tonight in pitching the Detroit Tigers to an 8-2 victory. It was his sixteenth victory of the season.

The Phoenix Theatre, which is in need of funds, will switch its activities from its 1,200-seat home, 189 Second Avenue, at Twelfth Street, to a more economical operation in the 299-seat East 74th Street Theatre, 334 East Seventy-fourth Street, between First and Second Avenues.

A Pan American World Airways jet airliner was hijacked over Mexico yesterday and diverted to Havana by a man identified by Cuban authorities as a French Algerian. There were eighty-one persons aboard.
CHICAGO. Aug. 9 (AP) -- Bye Bye Byrd, harness racing's leading money-winner, has been retired to stud. His owner, R.C. Larkin, a Chicago industrialist, made the announcement today.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 -- A Senate subcommittee on the Merchant Marine has completed its version of a controversial House measure on steamship conferences.
Young Mike Hegan joined his father -- Coach Jim Hegan -- in the Yankee organization yesterday, signing a minor league contract for "a substantial bonus."

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 9 -- Tunisia accused France in the United Nations today of "fresh acts of aggression" and "disgraceful behavior" as member nations continued consideration of the request for a special Assembly session on the Bizerte crisis.

BUFFALO. Aug. 9 (UPI) -- Federal Judge John O. Henderson gave lawyers today until Aug. 22 to work out a compromis in the complicated antitrust suit by the Government against leading printers of color Sunday supplements for newspapers.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 -- Two Federal agencies went on the record today in favor of making savings and loan associations and mutual savings banks subject to income taxation on terms similar to those imposed on commercial banks.

MIAMI, Fla., Aug. 5 -- These are the days of "Cuba libre" in Miami. This has nothing to do with a tall mixture of run and Coco-Cola. It reflects, rather, the intense consciousness of Dade County that it has become the world center of anti-Castro refugee activity.
The hijacking yesterday of a Pan American World Airways jet was the third time since May 1 that a United States airliner was forced to fly to Cuba.
OTTAWA, Aug. 9 -- Communist China has supplied Albania with some of the wheat it bought from Canada in April.
PARIS, Aug. 9 -- A Western diplomatic step to start negotiations with the Soviet Union on the Berlin dispute early in the fall is foreseen by authoritative Western sources here.
Alexander H. Reynolds Jr. has been named vice president for long range planning of the Leeds Northrup Company. Stephen Loidl Jr., controller, succeeds him as treasurer.

THE wheels will be whirring in Yonkers tonight. For this is the night of the one-hundred-grand Yonkers Futurity, the first tier of the highly prized triple crown for 3-year-old trotters. And the event has no end of intriguing angles.
HELSINKI, Finland, Aug. 9 (AP) -- The United States won one gold medal in the fourth day of the deaf Olympics today by beating Finland, 91-43, in basketball.

Salomon Brothers Hutzler and associates are offering to the public today $3,600,000 of 4 3/8 per cent equipment trust certificates of Gulf, Mobile and Ohio Railroad. The securities are priced to yield 3.25 per cent for those due on next March 1 out to 4.60 per cent for the longest maturities, which fall due in 1976.

The United Jewish Appeal praised American Jews yesterday for helping 1,000,000 immigrants settle in Israel. The influx, aided by American philanthropy, has occurred since Israel won independence in May, 1948.
WASHINGTON. Aug. 9 -- The Senate confirmed the appointment of a former Texas oil man to the Federal Power Commission today.
A group of teen-aged boys on an East River pier last evening stole the cap, shoes, watch and money of a policeman who had leaped into the water to rescue a man.
Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange were unchanged to 50 cents a bale up yesterday. Far October was unchanged on a bid.
District Attorney Frank S. Hogan announced the arrest yesterday of a Building Department inspector on a charge of accepting an $80 bribe.
MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., Aug. 9 -- This city's 1961 starling shoot began at dusk today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 (UPI) -- President Kennedy announced today the reappointment of William Randolph Healer Jr., editor-in-chief of the Hearst publications, as chairman of the President's Committee for Traffic Safety.

Jack Gould, your excellent TV reporter, correctly reported in The Times for Aug. 4 that in the conference at Northwestern University Law School on freedom and responsibility in broadcasting I criticized as oversimplified Federal Communications Commission Chairman Newton Minow's famous attack on the "wasteland" of TV.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 -- Administration leaders in the Senate began casting about today for concessions that might insure approval of President Kennedy's long-range foreign-aid program without impairing it in substance.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 -- The masters' national team-of-four championship, played annually for the Nate B. Spingold trophy, was won today by William Root of New York, Andrew Gabrilovitch of Washington, Edward Kantar of Los Angeles and Marshall Miles of San Bernardino, Calif.

BOSTON, Aug. 9 (UPI)--Mike Fornieles pitched the Boston Red Sox out of ninth-inning difficulty tonight and saved at 5-4 victory over the Minnesota Twins.
The Western Union Telegraph Company reported yesterday a gain in total operating revenues for the first six months of this year but a dip in net income from the year earlier levels.

The American Federation of Radio and Television Artists has leased three floors in 724 Fifth Avenue, near Fifty-seventh Street, and will move this fall from 15 West Forty-fourth Street. The Fifth Avenue lease was negotiated by James D. Washington, vice president of Cushman Wakefeld, Inc., and Jerry L. Cohen and Ian G.M. Brownlie of Brown, Harris, Stevens, Inc., agent for David W. Frankel, the owner.
ST. LOUIS, Aug. 9 (AP) -- District Attorney Edward S. Silver of Brooklyn said today that the nation's District Attorneys were not being portrayed fairly on television screens.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 (UPI) -- The Republican Congressional Committee charged today that the Kennedy Administration was subsidizing "union-busting shops" through the aid-to-depressed-areas program.
Stocks lost ground yesterday, although the setback was not a major one.

WASHINGTON', Aug. 9 (AP) -- A hearing examiner for the Interstate Commerce Commission today said a 10 per cent increase in commuter fares on the Hudson Transit Lines of New York and New Jersey was just and reasonable.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 9--President Kennedy and his aides are reported to be worried that restive East Germans may stage another uprising against Communist rule.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 -- Edward R. Murrow has sent a firmly worded memorandum to all United States Information Agency personnel expressing his displeasure over the efforts of some to "resist tough assignments."

OTTAWA, Aug. 9 -- The board of directors of the Bank of Canada has reversed an earlier decision to increase the pension of a retiring governor from $12,000 to $25,000 a year, Finance Minister Donald Fleming said today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 (AP) -- The Federal Trade Commission announced today a broad inquiry to determine whether makers and distributors of drugs gave illegal price cuts to favorite customers or exaggerated the effectiveness of their products.
BABYLON, L.I., Aug. 9 -- Robert Moses today asked television and radio stations to broadcast weather forecasts "without ad-libbing and ornamentation."
Webb Knapp, Inc., will take title in November to the Gotham and Stanhope Hotels here and the Beverly Wilshire in Beverly Hills, Calif., according to an agreement announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 (UPI) -- The House Rules Committee today authorized a Congressional inquiry into problems posed by jet aircraft noise. The study will be made by the House Commerce Committee.
Quiet trading on the New York commodities exchanges yesterday produced narrow price movements.
The final version of India's third Five-Year Plan, made public in New Delhi, outlines a program calculated to cost $24,300,000,000, a billion dollars more than tentative earlier estimates.
BISMARCK, N.D., Aug. 9 (AP) -- A Federal District Court jury today convicted twenty men and acquitted ten in the Lenders Service mail fraud case.

The approach in New York City and State to the problem of wayward adolescent girls, aged 16 to 21 years, who are in deep trouble with the law is a disgrace.
NEW DELHI, India, Aug. 9 -- Leaders of the ruling Congress party moved today to amend the party constitution to avoid naming a potential successor to Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru.

BOGOTA, Colombia, Aug. 9 -- The Colombian Government tonight demanded the release of Foreign Minister Julio Cesar Turbay Ayala, his wife and other Colombian officials traveling on the Pan American plane diverted to Havana.

Robert A. Sklar of Cambridge, Mass., has been granted a maintenance fellowship by the Eugene F. Saxton Memorial Trust. The 24-year-old author was graduated from Princeton University in 1958 summa cum laude and the next year received a Fulbright grant for a year at the University of Bonn in West Germany.

ALBANY, Aug. 9 (AP) -- A leader of Civil Service employes and the city manager of Newburgh disputed each other today on the approach to welfare problems.

The nation's inventories of gasoline declined 1,098,000 barrels last week, the American Petroleum Institute reported yesterday. This was less than the usual seasonal decline and reflected in part greater gasoline production, which rose to 30,626,000 barrels from 30,449,000 in the preceding week.
Carmine G. De Sapio called upon the five District Attorneys in the city yesterday to investigate Mayor Wagner's charge that "a secret battalion of corruption" was trying to seize City Hall.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 -- Armed border patrolmen were placed aboard some United States airliners flying in this country and Latin America today. Hours later the Senate voted to make aerial hijacking punishable by death.
HELSINKI, Finland, Aug 10 (UPI) -- An American quartet set a world 1,500-meter relay record for deaf athletes today at the wind-up of the ninth international Deaf Olympics.
LONDON, Aug. 10 -- Colonel von Kleist arrived in Pembrokeshire, Wales, today to inspect the camp and firing ranges at Castlemartin, where his unit will train.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 -- President Kennedy disclosed today that he had made an agreement that Vice President Johnson would exercise the rights and duties of the President in the event of any period of Presidential incapacity.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector), Aug. 10 -- Attorney General Gideon Hausner demanded today the conviction of Adolf Eichmann as a merciless and insatiable murderer of millions of Jews.

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Aug. 10 (AP) -- The winds of change in Africa are blowing against the continent's oldest independent ruler, Haile Selassie I, Negus Negusti, Lion of Judah and until last December the unchallenged ruler of Ethiopia.

Three aluminum companies -- Alcoa, Kaiser and Reynolds -- have formed a Committee of Aluminum Producers. One function of the committee is to plan strategy now that aluminum-boat building has grown in popularity.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 -- President Kennedy said today that he had found nothing new in Premier Khrushchev's latest discussion of the Berlin crisis. But the President promised to use "every device available" to find a peaceful solution.

SOME of the sweetest corn produced in the United States will be harvested in the Hudson Valley during the remaining weeks of summer. Dining on the freshly picked ears, hot from the kettle and slathered with butter, is a Lucullan experience indeed.

LONDON, Aug. 10 (Reuters) -- A Victorian-era music-hall spectacle, which has been a feature of night life here at the Players Theatre for the last twenty-five years, soon will branch out to New York.

The Anaconda Company lifted its second-quarter earnings to $14,830,000, or $1.39 a share, from $14,200,000, or $1.32 a share, in the 1960 period. Half-year results, however, were lower than those of a year ago, according to the report of the big copper producer.

CORFU, Greece, Aug. 10 (AP) -- Prince Constantine of Greece, the Olympic Dragon Class champion, refused to accept the European and Pan-Hellenic Lightning Class yacht championship at the awards ceremonies last night because a fellow Greek had embarrassed the Prince's guest.

NEWBURGH, N.Y, Aug. 10 (AP) -- This city created today what amounts to a new welfare post to guard against relief fraud.

BERLIN, Aug. 10 -- Marshal Ivan S. Konev, former supreme commander of East European forces and one of the leading longtime Communists in the armed forces, was announce today as the new commander of Soviet troops in East Germany.

Negotiators for the Metropolitan Opera and the union representing its orchestra resumed contract talks yesterday. They met for more than three hours and got on well enough to justify calling another meeting for this morning.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 -- The commercial banking industry argued before the House Ways and Means Committee today that "there is no creditable evidence to indicate that even a single home will go unbuilt" if taxes are raised for savings and loan associations and mutual savings banks.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 (AP) -- Representative Francis E. Walter, chairman of the House Committee on Un-American Activities, said today that the National Security Agency was now ready to support legislation he had introduced to tighten its oxm security.
Columbia University will place on public display today a fifteen-inch-long flintlock pistol that may be the gun that killed Alexander Hamilton.
EDWARDS AIR FORCE BASE, Calif., Aug. 10 (UPI) -- Navy Comdr. Forrest S. Petersen flew a new X-15 rocket plane for the first time today.

Congress is naturally alarmed and indignant over the rash of airplane hijacking, but the answers are not to be found in extreme reactions against Cuba, as some Senators demand. As President Kennedy said yesterday, "We should not get overexcited about matters when our information is so faulty -- so incomplete."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 (UPI) -- The ten Republican members of the House Ways and Means Committee urged the Administration today to drop its plan to spur business expansion and modernization through tax reductions.
Pan American World Airways began installing crossbars yesterday behind cockpit doors on planes flying its Latin-American routes.
The National Medical Association, an organization of Negro physicians, took the position of the American Medical Association yesterday in rejecting medical care for the aged under Social Security.
The Federal Government devoted seven-tenths of 1 per cent of its budget to medical research in the fiscal year that ended June 30, according to the National Health Education Committee, Inc.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 -- President Kennedy put himself squarely on the side of Senator J.W. Fulbright today in limiting the political activities of military officers.
PARIS, Aug. 10 -- The creation of a "provisional executive," or governing body, in Algeria is under consideration by the French Government, an official source said today.

Check transactions in July totaled $118,919,018,000 at the twenty-six leading cities in the nation, a record for the month. However, they were off 11.7 per cent from June's $130,897,471, 000. Volume last month was 8.7 per cent higher than the $109,419,610,000 cleared in July, 1960.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 -- Following are the texts of a White House announcement today on an agreement between the President and Vice President on steps to be taken in the event of a Presidential incapacity and the Attorney General's conclusion in an opinion holding the agreement valid:

In a politically significant move, the Liberal party last night endorsed Joseph F. Periconi, the Republican candidate, for Borough President of the Bronx. The move appeared designed to accomplish these purposes:

Advertisers have been showing renewed interest lately in so-called "documentary commercials." These are the little television sequences in which "real life" persons deliver the advertising pitch instead of a hired actor or announcer.
Indiana has been depicted as a big, bad wolf by Senator Paul Douglas, as he proposes to deprive the Hoosiers of a seaport and substitute instead a national Dunes park.
President Kennedy was reported yesterday to have decided on two New York City men for the Federal bench without consulting the city Democratic organizations or seeking their endorsements.

BOSTON, Aug. 10 (AP) -- Vito (Babe) Parilli twice mustered the Boston Patriots for long scoring marches and a 14-3 victory over the New York Titans tonight in an exhibition game between American Football League teams.
SYRACUSE, Aug. 10 -- Teams in the MG Car Club's 1,000-mile rally found the Alleghany Mountain roads in Pennsylvania rather easy to negotiate today on the 330-mile second stage of the four-day event.

BALTIMORE, Aug. 10 (UPI) -- Dave Philley broke an American League pinch-hitting record and Milt Pappas pitched a six-hitter tonight to pace the Baltimore Orioles to an 8-0 victory over the Kansas City Athletics.

LONDON, Aug. 10 -- John Brown and Company, the builders of the two giant "queen" liners, said today it had put in an unprofitable bid to build the Cunard Steam-Ship Lines' third "Queen," it was annuonced today.

Panhandle Eastern Pipe Line Company and subsidiaries reported yesterday total operating revenues of $93,393,007 for the first six months against $76,764,628 a year ago. Net income rose to $12,807,596, equal to $1.89 a share, from $10,734,924, or $1.59 a share, a year earlier.

BERLIN, Aug. 10 -- Walter Ulbricht, Communist leader of East Germany, indicated today that new measures might be enforced to halt the flow of refugees and put pressure on East Berliners not to work in West Berlin.
State Motor Vehicle Commissioner, William S. Hults yesterday reassured motorists whose drivers' license renewal forms contain mistakes.
Guy Lombardo has been provided with equal time to present his own weather forecast over television station WPIX (Channel 11).

JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector) Aug. 10 -- The Israeli police disclosed today that three more persons were arrested yesterday on suspicion of complicity with religious zealots who have been hiding a 9-year-old boy from his parents for a year and a half.
" JOINT APPEARANCE," a new series of public affairs telecasts had a lively, provocative premiere last night over Channel 2.
MINEOLA, L.I., Aug. 10 -- A. court order signed here today forbids the Nassau Bowling Proprietors Association from engaging in price-fixing in the future.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 -- President Kennedy said today that he would make a "most critical" and probably "decisive" judgment this month of the Soviet Union's willingness to arrange a well-policed ban on nuclear testing.

MIAMI, Fla., Aug. 10 (UPI) -- The Federal Bureau of Investigation filed piracy charges today against the Frenchman who forced a Pan American World Airways jetliner to fly to Cuba in what he termed a protest against United States policy on Algeria.
Former Senator Herbert H. Lehman buttressed Mayor Wagner's re-election campaign yesterday with a charge that "the bosses" had joined to poison the political atmosphere of the city.
STUDIES of an integrated or unified supply system or agency for all the armed forces have aroused the concern and interest of many active and retired officers and civilian contractors.

The city election campaign could benefit by a serious discussion of the grave problems facing New York. After all, the next Mayor will have to deal with them, and the voters would be glad to find out what the candidates propose to do.
MILWAUKEE, Aug. 10 (AP) -- Warren Spahn of the Milwaukee Braves will bid for his 300th National League victory tomorrow night when he opposes the Chicago Cubs.
Operating revenue of Pan American World Airways in the second quarter of this year climbed to $117,392,000 from $105,682,000 in the 1960 period but earnings declined, the company reported yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 (AP) -- The House voted today to let long-time military aviators receive some flight pay without actually flying.

Austria is lamenting some injustices inflated out of proportion, supposedly suffered by an Austrian minority in Italy. Before assuming the moral right for such complaints, Austria should wait at least twenty-five years, until the gruesome memories have somewhat faded of the example Austria herself set in the treatment of a minority comparable in size which Austria considered poorly adapted to her customs.
BRANCHVILLE, N.J., Aug. 10 -- Countryside Lane won two blues today and took a long lead in the open jumper competition at the Sussex County horse show today.
SAN DIEGO, Calif., Aug. 10 -- A Department of State official gave a formula tonight for combating what he described as communism's guerrilla-style "internal wars."

SHORT HILLS, N.J., Aug. 10 -- Mrs. Robert B. Meyner, wife of New Jersey's Governor, joined here today with local officials and store executives in a ceremony opening Bonwit Teller's first operation in a shopping center.
YONKERS, Aug. 10 -- The favored Duke Rodney won the $100,330 Yonkers Futurity Trot before 26,176 at Yonkers Raceway tonight.
A seven-ton machine that will test as many as 1,800 miniature electronic tubes an hour has been placed in operation at the Raytheon Company's plant in Newton, Mass.

Warner Brothers' "Splendor in the Grass," directed and produced by Elia Kazan, with Natalie Wood and Warren Beatty in the leading roles, has been scheduled to open in October at the Victoria and Trans-Lux Fifty-second Street Theatres.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 -- Department store sales in the nation last week were 3 per cent above the year-ago level, the Federal Reserve Board reported.

BONN, Germany, Aug. 10 -- The West German Government is preparing a number of major steps, to be taken after next month's national election, as part of the Western preparedness program advocated by President Kennedy.
SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 10 -- Brannagh skimmed the jumps closely in the fifty-sixth running of the North American Steeplechase today and won the $11,100 race by a half length.

ALBANY, Aug. 10 -- Low bids for two New York City highway projects totaling more than $32,000,000 were received today by the State Public Works Department. Contracts are expected to be awarded to the low bidders in about a month.
HAVANA, Aug. 10 -- A wild exchange of shots aboard a Cuban airliner, during which the pilot was killed, has considerably overshadowed here the hijacking of a Pan American World Airways jet yesterday.

TUNIS, Aug. 10 -- The United States and Britain appear to be losing the race to persuade France to pull her military forces out of Bizerte before the session of the United Nations General Assembly due to begin Monday. Aug. 21.

The Pure Oil Company reported yesterday, for the six months ended on June 30, a net income of $10,874,000, or $1.10 a common share. This compared with $13,756,000, or $1.39 a common share, in the first half of 1960. Gross income rose to $336,592,000 from $328,452,000 in 1960.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 (AP) -- President Kennedy said today he believed the United States was putting a maximum effort in money and manpower into its space program.
In the latest flare-up of assaults upon policemen, a plain-clothes patrolman shot his assailant in the arm during a chase yesterday at 111th Street and Fifth Avenue.
Mayor Wagner said yesterday that he would "lead or help in any way possible" a campaign to end the Federal 10 per cent tax on theatre admissions.
ST. LOUIS. Aug. 10 -- Lawyers in annual convention behave just about the way physicians, teachers, editors and insurance salesmen do.

Holyoke, Mass., borrowed $2,065,000 in the bond market yesterday to finance water and street improvements. The money was raised on serial obligations due from 1962 to 1986. The bonds were sold at public bidding to a syndicate headed by Glore, Forgan Co.

John B. Law of Tarrytown, N.Y., a former University of Notre Dame football player, was sworn in yesterday as a member of the State Commission of Correction. The commission oversees the operation of the state prison system.

JERSEY CITY, Aug. 10 -- A four-day-old strike of 1,100 employes of the Emerson Radio and Phonograph Company, here, ended today after management agreed to withdraw its demand for an eight-minute reduction in the employes' afternoon time off.

Murray Eisdorfer, builder, has bought eleven and one-half acres at Route 9 and Speedway Boulevard, Lakewood, N.J., for improvement with a shopping center. A building containing 22,500 square feet will be the first unit to be constructed.

J. Lindsay Thomas explains in his letter published Aug. 4 why in his opinion many Britishers do not wish to fight for Berlin. His feelings are understandable: twice in one generation the British have borne the brunt in defending, against Germany, the liberal constitutional tradition of the modern West and England, its historical citadel.

Production of lumber totaled 221,214,000 board feet in the week ended Aug. 5, compared with 231,649,000 board feet a week before and 223,835,000 board feet a year earlier, according to reports from regional associations.

Loans to business by the fifteen weekly reporting member banks of the Federal Reserve System in New York City dropped $155,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. This compared with a decline of $50,000,000 in the like week a year before.
In the ninth of the sixteen-game chess match between Samuel Reshevsky and Bobby Fischer at the Herman Steiner Chess Club in Los Angeles, Reshevsky had the white pieces.

CHICAGO, Aug. 10 -- Net profits of Zenith Radio Corporation rose to record heights in the second quarter and first six months of 1961, Hugh Robertson, chairman, and Joseph S. Wright, president, said today.

In all those years George always knew exactly what he was doing, where he stood and where everybody else who was working for him was supposed to be standing.
GENEVA, Aug. 10 -- The Communist powers denounced today Western proposals for international controls to guarantee the neutrality and independence of Laos.

THE heat is off for many parents whose children are away at summer camps. Despite the vagaries of the T.H.I., thousands of local homes have become low pressure areas in which the shedding of parental responsibilities has resulted in lives of comparative abandon.

LONDON, Aug. 10 -- The stock market here today followed the pattern of the last two days with Government securities surging ahead, and leading industrial shares again falling a shilling (14 cents) or so.
LONDON, Aug. 10 (AP) -- Britain's treasury head informed 650,000 Government civil servants today that their wages were to be frozen as part of a drive to bolster the nation's financial position.
BERLIN, Aug. 11 -- East Germany's Foreign Minister told the Legislature today that the Communist bloc nations would meet in the fall to review preparations for a German peace treaty.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 (UPI) -- the United Mine Workers Welfare Fund reported today that its income from royalty payments on coal production dropped to a record low in the year ended last June 30.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- The Army will send 3,000 more troops to Europe in the immediate future, Secretary of the Army Elvis J. Stahr Jr. said tonight.
BUDAPEST, Hungary, Aug. 11 (Reuters) -- The passenger plane that crashed here Aug. 6, killing thirty persons, had been stunting, the Hungarian press agency M.T.I. reported today.

PUNTA DEL ESTE, Uruguay, Aug. 11 -- Delegates to the Inter-American Economic and Social Conference worked tonight to resolve a major dispute over the method of putting the Alliance for Progress program into action.
PARAMUS, N.J., Aug. 11 -- The unbridled growth of welfare may destroy America morally, economically and socially, Newburgh City Manager Joseph McD. Mitchell said tonight.

Three Russian-made films have been added to the program of the fifth annual Stratford (Ont.) International Film Festival, a two-week event starting Aug. 21. Two are features completed earlier this year -- "The Song of the Woods," based on a classic Ukrainian fantasy, and "Dimitri Gorin's Career," a comedy.

Your editorial of Aug. 10 entitled "Who Made Wagner Mayor?" is an erudite and lucid exposition on the logic of logic. Unfortunately, you use the art of syllogism to arrive at your conclusions. These conclusions, therefore, are really unrelated to logic.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 Congress was told today that seven Peace Corps trainees had been dropped and that others would eventually be eliminated.

Mrs. Lewis W. Douglas and Mrs. Robert S. Salant are serving as committee co-chairmen of the theatre benefit for the Child Adoption Service of the State Charities Aid Association. The event will be the Nov. 22 evening performance of "The Gay Life."
LONDON, Aug. 11 (AP) -- Expulsion of the Union of South Africa from the British Commonwealth Sugar Agreement was announced in London tonight.
The American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals last night removed a 160-pound, sixteen-month-old lion from the Astor Garage at 225 West Forty-ninth Street to the zoo in Central Park.
MOSCOW, Aug. 11 -- Maj. Gherman S. Titov said today that he had ejected himself from his spaceship and had landed by parachute at the end of his twenty-five-hour flight around the earth last Monday.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 11 -- A United Nations cash deficit of $90,000,000 by next June was forecast today by Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold. In presenting the annual budget estimate he called the position "increasingly critical."
WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 (AP) -- The National Labor Relations Board held today that a vessel operated by a foreign company came under United States labor laws.

The public has lost confidence in the New York City Board of Education and the Superintendent of Schools. We judge from Mayor Wagner's Thursday evening television speech that he has grave doubts himself. How otherwise can this passage be interpreted?
GENEVA, Aug. 11 -- India warned today that new movements of foreign troops into Laos added urgency to the need for an agreement to guarantee the Southeast Asian kingdom's neutrality and independence.

William P. Gleason, a longshoreman of 340 Duncan Avenue, Jersey City, N.J., was arrested yesterday on a complaint brought by George J. Newsome, a hiring agent. Mr. Newsome, who lives at 544 East 191st Street, the Bronx, charged that last Tuesday Gleason attacked him with a baling hook during an argument while they were loading the liner Queen Elizabeth, at Pier 90, North River.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Aug. 11 (AP) -- Poland has offered Indonesia a 10,700,000 ($29,960,000) credit toward financing industrial projects.
Mayor Wagner called upon the Board of Education yesterday to end the "delay and confusion" over collective bargaining for teachers and hold an election before Oct. 15.
Associates Investment Company, South Bend, Ind., the nation's fourth largest sales finance company, raised the rates yesterday on its short-term obligations placed directly with investors.
LONDON, Aug. 11 -- British motorists were officially criticized yesterday for being excessively polite in using their horns.

CHICAGO, Aug. 11 (AP) -- The Government's August crop report brought about a further downward adjustment in prices of soybean futures today on the Board of Trade, but it had little or no effect on the grains.

ALBANY, Aug. 11 (AP) -- An Albany-bound bus with twenty-three passengers collided head-on with an automobile today. The bus then struck another car and smashed through the wall of a gasoline service station.
BONN, Germany, Aug. 8 -- West German industry, although facing signs that the boom it has been enjoying is abating, still hires every hand it can.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 (AP) -- The Food and Drug Administration announced new regulations today for labeling of chemical products for home use.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- The United States has canceled plans to establish diplomatic relations with Outer Mongolia. It apparently acted to enhance its bargaining power at the Sept. 19 session of the United Nations General Assembly.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 11 (AP) -- The Pittsburgh Pirates struck hard and fast against Robin Roberts tonight as Bob Friend shut out the Philadelphia Phillies, 6 -- 0. The game was called after six innings because of rain.

BRANCHVILLE, N.J., Aug. 11 -- Beau Mischief and Citadel won the green working hunter events of the Sussex County horse show today.

CHERAW, S.C., Aug. 11 (UPI) -- More than 4,000 paratroopers from the 101st Airborne Division filled the skies over Cheraw, S.C., today in a new phase of this nation's most extensive war games since World War II.

Commercial banks, savings banks and savings and loan associations in Nassau County have been engaged in a "branch war" for the last year, a group of these institutions charged yesterday. The Nassau-Suffolk Financial Council said that thirty-five new offices of financial institutions had been approved since July 1, 1960, bringing the total of such offices to 212.

HAVERSTRAW, N.Y., Aug. 11 -- Derrick Williams' no-hit pitching and a sixth-inning double by Willie Bonilla today carried Sedgwick of the Bronx, the New York City Little League champions, into the final of the state play-offs. Sedgwick defeated Islip, the Long Island champion, 1 -- 0, before a crowd of nearly 1,000 in the second game of the semifinals.
NEWBURGH, N.Y., Aug. 11 (AP) -- The state contended today that Newburgh's stringent new regulations aimed at cutting relief costs could actually increase the tax burden on the city's citizens.
BONN, Germany, Aug. 11 (AP) -- The Government Press Office said today that it had halted the distribution some time ago of a German election campaign booklet carrying Queen Elizabeth's likeness.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- A physician and a dentist have jointly invented a hearing aid that gives sound a new route to the brain -- through the teeth and facial nerves. They believe it can be used to restore the hearing of persons who otherwise would remain totally deaf.
MOSCOW, Aug. 11 -- Premier Khrushchev declared today that the prestige of the Soviet Union required him to go through with the signing of a German peace treaty despite determined Western opposition.
BALTIMORE, Aug. 11 (AP) -- The Baltimore Orioles, aided by home-runs by Jim Gentile and Brooks Robinson, staved off an eighth-inning rally by Boston tonight and defeated the Red Sox, 6 -- 3.

VIENTIANE, Aug. 11 (AP) -- Reports of fighting in the Plaine des Jarres area in violation of cease-fire agreements stirred new trouble today for the three Princes seeking to form a coalition Government for Laos.
NEW ORLEANS, Aug. 11 (AP) -- The United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit has refused a rehearing in a decision involving suits against The New York Times.
PARIS, Aug. 11 -- The French Government announced today that it had given "greater freedom of action" to its armed forces in Algeria.

METUCHEN, N.J., Aug. 11 -- Mrs. Joseph Rudnick of Jumping Brook finished with a five-round plus 31 to win the Elizabeth Goss Memorial round-robin golf tournament today at the Metuchen Golf and Country Club.
NEW DELHI, India, Aug. 11 -- India appealed today for more liberal import policies in Europe to accompany Britain's proposed membership in the European Economic Community, or Common Market.

SPRING LAKE, N.J., Aug. 11 -- Wes Ellis of Mountain Ridge shot two sub-par rounds at the Homestead Country Club today and won the New Jersey State Professional Golfers Association championship by eleven strokes with a 266.

DETROIT, Aug. 11 (AP) -- Earl Morrall threw three second-period touchdown passes through Cleveland's green pass defenders tonight and sparked the Detroit Lions to a 35-7 victory over the Browns. It was the first pre-season football game for the National Football League teams.
SUMMIT, N.J., Aug. 11 -- A 19-year-old collegian, Ralph Johnston of Jackson Heights, Queens, gained the semi-finals of the Metropolitan amateur golf tournament today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 (UPI) -- House investigators started public hearings today on charges that the Federal Home Loan Bank Board had pressured the head of the Federal Savings and Lean Association of Atlanta into resigning as a member.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 (AP) -- A little-publicized House Small Business subcommittee has set out to learn how the mandatory controls on oil imports are affecting the oil and coal industries.

Stockholders of the First National Bank of Boston will vote at a special meeting on Oct. 24 on a proposed one-for-seven stock dividend to be paid on Nov. 15 to stockholders of record of Nov. 1. The action would follow an increase from 3,500,000 to 4,000,000 in the number of $12.50 par value shares outstanding, increasing the bank's capital stock from $43,750,000 to $50,000,000.
Your editorial of June 28 and your comments on the soundly conceived letter of Paul B. Jessup published on July 22 are both seriously in error.

Prices of United States Government securities and prime corporate obligations advanced yesterday in an inactive trading session. Little business was reported in the secondary market for local government obligations, where the major concern was the pricing of a new issue of $225,000,000 of State of California bonds next Wednesday.

NEW DELHI, India, Aug. 11 -- Fifty-eight slightly weary young singers of Harvard University flew to Bombay today for the end of a two-month concert tour of Asia.

The first volume of a history under the general title "From the Dreadnought to Scapa Flow" will be published Sept. 7 by Oxford University Press. The volume, called "The Road to War, 1904-1914," has been written by Arthur J. Marder, Senior Professor of History at the University of Hawaii.
STAMFORD, Conn., Aug. 11 -- A marine surveyor who has been feuding with the city over land ownership was ordered today to remove a 120-foot barge he had beached on the waterfront.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 11 (AP) -- Willie Kirkland drove in the winning run with an eighth-inning sacrifice fly tonight as the Cleveland Indians beat the Los Angeles Angels, 3 -- 2, for their fourth straight victory.
Notice of a suit of foreclosure against three of the fifteen buildings of the Lindenwood Gardens cooperative apartment project at Howard Beach, Queens, has been filed.

A plot of land about 130 by 100 feet at 228 East Forty-fourth Street has been leased by Hyman Dressner, Marvin Greenfield and Preston Golden for improvement with a thirteen-story and penthouse apartment building.
The Pillsbury Company attained record sales and earnings in its fiscal year ended last May 31, its stockholders were told.

General Dynamics Corporation said yesterday it had concluded a two-year, $200,000,000 revolving credit agreement with a group of twenty banks, headed by The Chase Manhattan Bank. In addition, the corporation has an existing long-term loan agreement with the Prudential Insurance Company for $135,000,000.
Most railroads find that freight pays the way and the passenger is a financial burden. In the natural gas business, the situation is a bit different.

RABAT, Morocco, Aug. 11 -- The Moroccan army will join forces with Algerian nationalist guerrillas to meet any attack on Morocco's eastern border by the French army in Algeria, according to a declaration by the Moroccan Defense Minister published today.
MADISON, Wis., Aug. 11 (UPI) -- The Wisconsin Legislature killed three human rights bills today despite the pressure of a sit-in at the Capitol rotunda that was in its twelfth day.

MILWAUKEE, Aug. 11 (AP) -- Warren Spahn, the Milwaukee Braves' 40-year-old left-handed pitching star, gained his 300th major league victory tonight by defeating the Chicago Cubs, 2-1 with a masterly six-hitter.

PUNTA DEL ESTE, Uruguay, Aug. 11 -- There were strong indications today at the Inter-American economic conference that Cuba might sign the Alliance for Progress agreement. The possibility posed a tactical problem for the United States.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 11 (UPI) -- Juan Marichal, who never had beaten the Cincinnati Reds, did it tonight with the aid of a two-run single by Orlando Cepeda as the San Francisco Giants scored a 4-2 victory.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- The United States reassured worried astronomers of the world today that "no harmful effects" would result from the planned Air Force experiment to create a 2,000-mile-high belt of "needles" around the earth.

WASHINGTON Aug. 11 (AP) -- A Senate committee gave swift approval today to a bill to continue aid to so-called impacted areas -- school districts with heavy concentrations of Federal workers or military personnel.

A RAINY summer week-end in the country -- or in the city for that matter -- can leave the family at loose ends. A good book or a day-long game of Monopoly is not always the solution. This might be a good time to tackle some of those often postponed tasks, such as polishing the furniture, silver and brass, pasting loose photographs in an album, or doing miscellaneous sewing jobs.
John E. Hand, a Democratic political figure and real estate agent, will appear in Housing Court next Wednesday to answer a summons similar to one that was dismissed last week.

BELLPORT, L.I., Aug. 11 -- A second-place finish behind Harold Halstead today all but clinched the Corry Cup for Hartwell (Bucky) Moore of the Huntington Bay fleet. Moore's Mavourneen could finish fifth in tomorrow's final race and still win this Star Class series.

Production of steel in July came to 8,090,060 net tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday. The July output compared with a revised total of 8,551,856 net tons in June and 6,350,924 net tons in July, 1960.

Eastern Air Lines, Inc., reported yesterday a net loss of $6,380,000 from operations in the first half of this year. The figure was after all taxes and charges and the inclusion of an unused andvertising reserve.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Aug. 11 -- Mrs. Martin Fisher of Old Oaks scored 45, 46 -- 91 to head a field of ninety-eight in the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association Class B tournament at Fenway Golf Club today.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 (AP) -- A bill to create a new Cabinet post was approved today by the Senate Government Operations Committee. The vote was 5 to 2.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 11 -- Food Fair Stores, Inc., the supermarket chain, concluded an agreement today to acquire Enterprise-J.M. Fields, Inc., operator of a chain of thirty-three discount department stores.

SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., Aug. 11 -- Another meeting between Chuck McKinley of St. Ann, Mo., and Michael Sangster of Britain was set up with their victories today in the quarter-finals of the Eastern grass court championships at the Orange Lawn Tennis Club.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 (AP) -- Secretary Abraham A. Ribicoff said today this country must develop its young people physically as well as intellectually.

PARIS, Aug. 11 -- The French Government announced tonight that one of the three parachute regiments sent to defend the Bizerte base last month would be withdrawn from Tunisia. A brief communique issued in behalf of Premier Michel Debre said:

OYSTER BAY, L.I., Aug. 11 -- Four professors at the State University-Long Island Center here resigned today from administrative posts after numerous disagreements with the college's new president. They will remain on the faculty.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- The space agency announced today that it would launch late next year an experimental communications satellite that would remain fixed over the same longitude on earth.

Liquidation and hedge selling of potatoes were aggressive on the New York Mercantile Exchange yesterday, in response to the Department of Agriculture's fall crop estimate, released Thursday afternoon. The trade interpreted the report as being mildly bearish.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 (AP) -- The Justice Department revised today the proposed regulations it is asking the Interstate Commerce Commission to adopt to ban segregation in interstate bus transportation.

HOBOKEN, N.J., Aug. 11 -- The latest addition to the metropolitan New Jersey skyline, the fourteen-story Stevens Center of the Stevens Institute of Technology, has passed the half-way mark in construction.

HIROSHIMA, Japan, Aug. 6 -- Japanese women, on a pilgrimage with their wooden Buddhist rosaries on their shoulders, busily sweep the sandy square in front of the great green mound. They do not make much progress with the dust, but the sweeping is an act of piety, a symbol, and every now and then they turn and bow deeply before the mound that covers the ashes of the dead.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- Secretary of State Dean Rusk reported to President Kennedy today that there would be prolonged and difficult East-West negotiations this year to resolve the diplomatic crisis over Berlin and Germany.

HARTFORD, Aug. 11 (UPI) -- Ted Kroll, a long-time performer on the professional Golfers Association tour, fired a nine-under-par 62 today to take the 36-hole lead in the Insurance City open tournament. His total of 129 was thirteen strokes under par.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 11 (AP) -- Donna de Varona, the 14-year-old star from LaFayette, Calif., broke her own world record for the 400-meter individual medley and Robyn Johnson, an unknown from Arlington, Va., upset the mighty Chris von Saltza in the 100-meter free-style tonight in the woman's national Amateur Athletic Union outdoor swimming and diving championships.

This being the vacation season (summer division) it is a certainty that someone, somewhere, is planning to begin tomorrow the tedious journey back home after two weeks or so of carefree, if expensive, living.
Fort Hamilton, Brooklyn, marked the progress of its reconstruction program yesterday with a symbolic cornerstone-laying ceremony at the post's new headquarters building.

The Control Data Corporation's board of directors proposed yesterday an increase in the authorized common stock to 6,900,000 from 2,300,000 to pave the way for a three-for-one stock split. The proposal will be considered by stockholders at the annual meeting on Sept. 19, William C. Norris, president, stated.
Some voters will be entitled to as much as two hours off from work, with pay, to vote in the primary Sept. 7, Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz said yesterday.
State Controller Arthur Levitt proposed yesterday that the Federal and city powers of taxation be used "to take the profits out of slums."

Frank Kenna, the Queens County Republican leader, who has been under attack by Mayor Wagner, quit his post yesterday. The 67-year-old politician had been under behindthe-scenes pressure from Governor Rockefeller and L. Judson Morhouse, state Republican chairman, to resign.

ALGIERS, Aug. 11 -- A military spokesman explained today that new orders to French troops meant that they were again allowed to take "preventive" measures against rebel fighters. He said that under the unilateral cease-fire France had adopted, the armed forces had been under orders to repel rebel attacks but not to take any initiative to prevent such attacks.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 11 -- George Ball of New York opened defense of his Middle States senior grass court tennis championship today by defeating Howard Holmes of the host club, 6 -- 0, 6 -- 3, today at the Germantown Cricket Club.
LEOPOLDVILLE, the Congo, Aug. 11 -- The Congolese Government displayed today four Portuguese military men captured on the Congolese side of the Angola-Congo border near the port town of Boma.
Four kinsmen drowned in Brooklyn yesterday when they were swept into a sewer line from an excavation in which they had been working.

The New York Central Railroad asked the Interstate Commerce Commission yesterday to obtain evidence it said was being withheld by the Chesapeake Ohio Railway, needed to Complete the commission's record on the competing applications by Central and C. O. to control the Baltimore Ohio Railroad.
A Federal Court here at all times holds about $20,000 in forfeited seamen's wages as a result of desertion charges brought by various ship captains, an aide of the court said yesterday.

YONKERS, Aug. 11 -- Countess Adios flashed a fine finishing kick to score a one-and-a-half length victory over Arania in 2:00 3/5 tonight in the one-mile Salem Pace before 30,026 fans at Yonkers Raceway.
A floating school containing the biggest contingent of African students ever to visit the United States docked in New York yesterday.
ARMONK, N.Y., Aug. 11 -- Mrs. John H. Bartol of Greenwich, Conn., won the thirty-sixth annual championship of the Women's Westchester and Fairfield Golf Association today.

In response to a request by the Board of Education for an evaluation of its operations, Dr. James E. Allen Jr., the state Commissioner of Education, made references yesterday to two such studies that had been undertaken in the last three years.
AN inconspicuous bakery at 198 Mott Street in a rundown block of sooty brick buildings has a reputation for fine bread that is known as far west as California and as far south as Florida.

Judge Henry J. Friendly of the United States Court of Appeals refused yesterday to reduce the $100,000 bail of Dr. Robert A. Soblen, convicted Soviet spy, pending appeal. The defendant has been senteenced to life in prison.

SEOUL, Korea, Saturday, Aug. 12 (AP) -- South Korea's ruling junta today set a two-year time limit on its military rule, promising general elections in May, 1963, and a return to civilian government that summer.

A syndicate of investors headed by Milton Kestenberg, a lawyer and realty investor, has bought a thirty-year lease on the Governor Clinton Hotel, Seventh Avenue and Thirty-first Street. The price was more than $1,500,000.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 (AP) -- The Army's Board of Engineers for Rivers and Harbors announced today it had recommended a $591,000,000 plan to develop the water resources of the Delaware River basin.

ALBANY, Aug. 11 (AP) -- Police Chief John P. Tuffey said today a former police detective, shot and wounded during an alleged burglary attempt Monday, had admitted committing forty-two burglaries and safecrackings within the last eleven months.
