WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- The Administration won a victory of unexpected dimensions tonight on the first and most crucial test for President Kennedy's long-range foreign aid program.

As a Greenwich Village resident for twenty-eight years and a home owner too, I am happy to see the progress which the city and the New York Public Library are making to preserve the Old Jefferson Market Court Building, not only as an edifice of historic and architectural merit but also as a vital functioning branch of the library in an area of expanding need for its services.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., Aug. 11 -- Lloyd Ribner of Metropolis and Mrs. Walter L. Kahn of the Century Country Club won the Lucy Foreman trophy in the annual mixed-foursomes tournament of the Women's Tri-County Golf Association today with a 70 at the Quaker Ridge Golf Club.
A Cabinet member from Washington and an Archbishop from Africa will address a national Roman Catholic meeting on civil rights in Detroit on Aug. 26.
A bond issue of $225,000,000 of California will swell the volume of fixed interest securities to nearly $300,000,000 in the market for new capital next week.
DUBLIN, Aug. 11 -- The highlight of Dublin's annual horse show was reached today when thousands thronged the jumping enclosure for the Aga Khan Cup competition. Germany was an easy winner.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 10 cents a bale off to 10 cents up yesterday. The near months dipped.
A week from Monday the United Nations General Assembly will try to do what the Security Council twice vainly attempted -- it will try to settle the dispute between the French and the Tunisians.
TOKYO, Aug. 10 -- United States naval forces in the Far East have heightened their state of readiness because of the crisis over Berlin.

TUNIS, Aug. 11 -- President Habib Bourguiba declared today that the failure of the Western powers to persuade France to pull her troops out of Bizerte "does not mean I will jump into the arms of the Russian bear."
WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 (AP) -- President Kennedy signed a bill today creating a new position as Assistant Secretary of Labor.
SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 11 -- Ballots were sent today to about 8,000 bay area teamsters for a mail vote on a three-year contract backed by James R. Hoffa, the union's international president.

York Associates, Inc., has purchased the two-story business building at 1568-70 Broadway, southeast corner of Forty-seventh Street, for investment. The building, which fronts forty feet on Broadway and eighty feet on the street, is occupied by the United Cigar Whelan Stores Corporation under a net lease running to 1966.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- Mickey Mantle and Roger Maris slugged homers as the Yankees won their ninth straight and the Senators lost their seventh straight tonight at Griffith Stadium. The score was 12 -- 5.
SYRACUSE, Aug. 11 -- Warren von der Esch and David Probstein held their point lead today through the third stage of the MG Car Club's four-day 1,000-mile international rally.
OLD SAYBROOK, Conn., Aug. 11 (AP) -- Harry Levinson of Indianapolis, the defender, retained the national Snipe class sailing championship today under pressure that continued through the final race.

"THE MAN WHO SOLD THE EIFFEL TOWER," by James Johnson and Floyd Miller, is a real-life narrative of galvanic crime and rather belated punishment. I think you will enjoy it the more if you take the writing less seriously than the story behind it.

NICOSIA, Cyprus, Aug. 11 -- Khrushchev builds his assumption that communism will continue to spread on the coordinated use of several varying techniques. In peripheral areas such as Laos and South Vietnam his bloc counts on subversion and guerrilla warfare.
BLOOMINGTON, Minn. Aug. 11 (AP) -- Earl Battey slammed two home runs tonight as the Minnesota Twins edged the Detroit Tigers, 2 -- 1.

ATLANTIC CITY, Aug. 11 (UPI) -- Brae Burn Farm's General Arthur passed Lil Fella in the stretch today to win the $5,000 allowance test at Atlantic City.
PUNTA DEL ESTE, Uruguay, Saturday, Aug. 12 -- Reports of an uprising in Argentina caused a brief sensation early today at the inter-American Economic Conference here.
WHITE PLAINS, Aug. 11 -- The creation of a department to administer Westchester County's Grasslands Hospital and to effect broad economies and improve medical services was recommended today.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 (AP) -- The Atomic Energy Commission announced today a major streamlining of its operating staff.
NAIROBI, Kenya, Aug. 11 -- Elaborate preparations for the release of Jomo Kenyatta have been made in Kenya.
Beginning Nov. 1 the Health Insurance Plan of New York will cost most subscribers more but some subscribers less a year. The new rates have been approved by the State Insurance Department.
GLEN HEAD, L.I., Aug. 11 -- Mrs. Walter Heesch from the host club, Brookville, won the low gross honors today in the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association's one-day tournament with a 41, 45 -- 86.

The 22-month-old son of an Indian official went for a walk in the Bronx last night, fell asleep three blocks from his home and set off a three-tour search by fifty policemen.

E.I. has been told by the Chicago and North Western Railway that if the L. N. should not be interested in a merger with C. E.I., the North Western might be.
CHAMPAIGN, Ill., Aug. 11 (UPI) -- The leading sponsor of a controversial drug for cancer treatment will retire from the staff of the University of Illinois Aug. 31.
Kings County Judge Samuel S. Leibowitz proposed yesterday that the system of early prison paroles be revised.
BONN, Germany, Aug. 11 -Chancellor Adenauer forecast tonight that negotiations to be undertaken with the Soviet Union over Berlin and Germany would wind up in an East-West summit conference.
FRANK KENNA, who took over the Queens Republican organization thirteen years ago, was described by one of his friends yesterday as a "Republican Charlie Buckley."

Directors of the Zenith Radio Corporation raised the quarterly dividend yesterday to 50 cents each on the present shares and proposed a stock distribution of two additional shares for each one held, in effect, splitting the stock three for one.
The Columbia Broadcasting System apparently has found an exception to its rule that all public affairs and news shows must be made wholly under network control.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 (UPI) -- The National Labor Relations Board ruled today that union members could hand out do-not-buy circulars in front of concerns not involved in labor disputes.

With the score tied at 5 -- 5, Bobby Fischer and Samuel Reshevsky adjourned the eleventh game of their sixteen-game series at the Herman Steiner Chess Club in Los Angeles Thursday night after forty moves.
After much backing and filling, stocks ended irregularly higher yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange.
LONDON, Ang. 11 -- Prices of British Government securities wilted under profit taking in the stock market here today.

WASHINGTON, Aug 11 (AP) -- Four of the candidates for the first United States orbital space flight have scattered to stations thousands of miles apart from which they will observe a forthcoming test shot.
NEW DELHI, Aug. 11 (AP) -- French assistance will permit India to conduct an oil exploration that the Standard Vacuum Oil Company of the United States had sought to undertake.

A suit to prevent the Fifth Avenue Coach Lines, Inc., from selling a block of stock to O. Roy Chalk, the Washington, D.C. transit operator, was dismissed yesterday by State Supreme Court Justice Frederick Backer on the ground that the court was being asked "to stay an action which hasn't been taken."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- The State Department sent a note to Cuba today indicating that the United States would be receptive to exchanging a Cuban patrol boat for a hijacked Eastern Airlines Electra. The plane has been held in Havana since July 24.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 11 -- This country's oldest major stakes race, the Travers, will be contested tomorrow for the ninety-second time since the thoroughbred sport was instituted here in 1863. A field of eight 3-year-olds will compete in the mile-and-a-quarter race that has been won by some of the most important campaigners in American turf history.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 (UPI) -- Senator Clair Engle today urged airlines to reduce fares by eliminating fancy meals and champagne flights.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 (UPI) -- House-Senate conferees agreed today on a bill carrying funds for more agents to find counterfeiters and income tax cheats.

VIENTIANE, Laos, Aug. 11 -- The Laotian rebel base at Xiengkhouang has been under attack for the last several days.
BUENOS AIRES, Saturday, Aug. 12 -- A small band of armed rebels seized two key buildings in Downtown Buenos Aires last night in an attempt to overthrow the Government.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 (AP) -- The Interstate Commerce Commission today opposed a bill it says would tie its hands in regulating rail and truck freight rates.

Under the impact of the Berlin crisis a unanimous Congress has given expression to a united nation's determination to defend itself and freedom by passing the biggest peacetime defense budget on record. CHICAGO, Aug. 11 (AP) -- Luis Aparicio's home run supported Billy Pierce's five-hit shutout pitching tonight and gave the Chicago White Sox a 1-0 victory over the Kansas City Athletics. The game took only 1 hour 32 minutes.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 -- The index of average wholesale primary market prices rose 0.2 per cent to 118.9 per cent of its 1947-49 base during the week ended last Tuesday, the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today.
JERSEY CITY, N.J., Aug. 11 (AP) -- A $15.5 million bond issue for development of a proposed 960-acre public market facility will be guaranteed by the Hudson County Board or Freeholders.
DETROIT, Aug. 11 -- The bargaining committee of the United Automobile Workers at the Ford Motor Company decided today to ask for a secret strike vote among the company's 120,000 hourly workers.

FRANKFURT, West Germany, Aug. 11 (AP) -- Jay Silvester, a United States Army lieutenant from Trementon, Utah, threw the discus 198 feet 8 1/4 inches tonight -- more than 2 feet beyond the listed world record. He made the throw during an international track and field meet.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 (AP) -- The Federal Aviation Agency has agreed to furnish a noise-level map of the Newark, N.J., airport as soon as present noise studies are completed in about mid-November.

TRENTON -- New Jersey acted promptly and decisively last week to stamp out the most recent serious threat to its multibillion-dollar coastal resort industry -- offshore litterbugs. Their activities reportedly have cost the industry thousands of dollars in lost trade over the last few weeks.

ARLINGTON, N.J., Aug. 12 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner put up a good battle before losing his second-round singles match today in the New Jersey seniors tennis championship at the Arlington Players Club.

BIZERTE, Tunisia, Aug. 12 -- A French military spokesman announced tonight that "some elements" of the Second Foreign Legion Paratroop Regiment had left here by sea for their previous station "in accordance with orders from Paris."

PARIS -- The rediscovery of railroads -- to be specific, of the first-class international services in Western Europe -- is a solid foundation on which to build a circle tour from Paris to Paris via, for example, Venice and Vienna.
GETTYSBURG, Pa., Aug. 12 -- Former President Dwight D. Eisenhower promised Governor Rockefeller today that he would be in New York City "once or twice" during the fall campaign for Mayor.
LOS ANGELES, Aug. 12 -- It may take 50,000 Republicans to convince Richard M. Nixon that he should run for Governor of California.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 12 -- Several unusual summerI homes here will be opened to theI public on Aug. 22 for the bene-t fit of the Guild Hall, eultural f and art center here. Since all l the homes are hidden from view by high fences, extensive acreage and long driveways, the tour is being called a "summer saunter through hidden houses in indmill country."

ALGONQUIN PARK, Ont. -- A slice of the hard life that Canadian loggers led a century ago is on display in this vast provincial park, 130 miles west of Ottawa and 140 miles northeast of Toronto. Here, scarcely 100 yards from Route 60, which traverses the park, the visitor enters another world.

EUGENE, Ore., Aug. 12 (AP) -- Four straight birdies today gave JoAnne Gunderson of Kirkland, Wash., a 3-and-2 victory over 18-year-old Heidi Prentice of Winnetka, Ill., in the final of the Women's Trans-Mississippi.
CHICAGO, Aug. 12 (AP) -- Minnie Minoso's twelfth homer of the season, in the fourth inning, proved decisive today as the Chicago White Sox won, 2 -- 1, from the Kansas City Athletics.

THE most celebrated, most controversial and -- let's face it -- the smelliest fruit in Southeast Asia is a spiky, football-sized extravaganza that looks as if it could stop a tank, tastes like Camembert and onions and sells out constantly. This is the durian, around which a great debate has raged for centuries.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 12 -- The gardens of the Parrish Art Museum will be the setting for the annual fiesta through which the Southampton Village Improvement Society receives support. The event has been arranged for Aug. 25.

AS the revolution in the teaching of mathematics continues one thing on which there has been fairly general agreement is the necessity for broadening the child's understanding of numbers. This demands greater emphasis on the history and the possible future uses of mathematics.

PROBABLY the most frequently used -- and the most frequently misused -- tool around the home is the ordinary screwdriver. All too often used as a scraper, chisel, prying tool or can opener, the screwdriver blade can be easily damaged so that it no longer works satisfactorily when used on the only job for which it was designed -- that of driving or loosening screws.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Aug. 12 -- Don McNair of the Port Washington Yacht Club won the first race -- the only one completed -- in the Atlantic Coast Lightning Class championship series today. Poor wind conditions forced the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club committee to shorten the course and then call off a second race.

SALADS have come a long, long way since the days of Marcus Gabius Apicius, a Roman epicure. Aug. 12 -- The North Shore committee of the women's division of the Nassau County Mental Health Association is planning an autumn antiques sale for Sept. 29 and 30 and Oct. 1 at the Neighborhood House here, for the benefit of the association's new rehabilitation center in West Hempstead.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., During the last two or three years, the main beach at East Hampton, L.I., has become a major summer outpost of Broadway. THE Corning (N.Y.) Gladiolus Show, which may be seen today, salutes outer space flights in its flower arrangement themes. Sponsored by the Corning Garden Club in cooperation with the Empire State Gladiolus Society, the two-day show opened yesterday.
HYANNIS PORT, Aug. 12 -- President Kennedy named acting members of the new Federal Maritime Commission today.

It is with a small selection of these makers of modern anthropology that Abram Kardiner and Edward Preble deal in this ably written and informative book.
